DOC.HEADLINE: Android will top smartphone market in 2011: researchers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 22:09:45 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Google Inc.'s Android operating system is expected to take the biggest share of the smartphone market next year on the back of growing interest from consumers and handset vendors, local researchers said Tuesday.

Shipments of smartphones running the Android system, which are forecast to rank in second place this year with 58.45 million units sold, will top the market in 2011 with an estimated 29.7 percent share, according to an e-mail statement from Luke Lin, an analyst and project manager of Digitimes Research, an industry tracking company.

Nokia's Symbian will slide to second place with 28 percent of the market share, followed by Apple Inc.'s iOS with 16.7 percent, RIM's BlackBerry with 14 percent and Microsoft's Windows with 5.1 percent, according to a report issued that same day by Digitimes Research.

Despite problems of diverse system versions and patent right lawsuits, Google still attracts smartphone makers wishing to launch various under-US$100 models, making Android likely to reach the top spot a year earlier than a previous forecast in 2009, Lin noted.

Joey Yen, a market analyst of PCs and peripherals at International Data Corp. Taiwan, said in a telephone interview with CNA that the Android system will grow rapidly in 2011 because developers are more willing to produce applications for the platform due to its open source and low license fees.
Moreover, consumers and vendors are getting more interested in the phones.
"With the increasing number of products and rising awareness of the Android system, consumers and vendors have become more confident in them," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctors explain why KMT official's son's wounds healing so fast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 22:23:29 (By Chen Li-ting and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Doctors said Tuesday that as there was no major tissue damage caused by the Nov. 26 gunshot wound to Sean Lien, the son of Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, it was reasonable that he had started taking food and that his face was no longer swollen.
Lien was shot on the eve of the municipal elections while stumping for a city councilor candidate, but his speedy recovery has fanned rumors that the whole drama might have been staged.
He was moved from an intensive care unit to a regular ward at National Taiwan University Hospital a day earlier after doctors determined that he was out of danger.

Chou Tsung-tuo, an experienced gunshot wound specialist at the Tri-Services General Hospital, said Lien was "extremely lucky" in that major tissue in the mouth and throat was not damaged by the bullet.

At first, the victim's face would certainly be so swollen that he might not be able even to open his eyes, Chou said. But, he added, the facial wounds would recover soon and it would be reasonable to see the swelling recede in three days.
NTU Hospital doctors said Lien's face was still a bit swollen under the right eye and that it would take at least two weeks for the swelling to completely disappear.
They said the left side of his face was less damaged than the right and that he was able to chew on the left side of his mouth.
Wei Kuo-chen, chief of neurosurgery at the Chang Gung Hospital in Linkou, used the word "miracle" to describe how lucky Lien was to have escaped major injury.

It is exactly because of this "miraculous" luck that pro-opposition Democratic Progressive Party pundits suspect that the KMT or its sympathizers might have manufactured or choreographed the shooting.
DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin has claimed that organized crime rings "really could have staged the incident for the sake of winning a gamble."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to focus on party's China policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 22:36:51 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to establish a think tank to help formulate its China policy and improve the party's engagement with China, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Tuesday.

The DPP welcomes any form of dialogue with China as long as no prerequisites are set, Tsai said in a briefing for foreign media three days after her defeat in the Nov. 27 municipality mayoral elections.
The DPP secured just two of the five municipalities but won more of the popular votes than its rival, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Tsai also highlighted the party's progress in the city council elections that took place alongside the mayoral elections, as the DPP won as many seats on the five city councils as the KMT, with both parties tied at 130.

The DPP plans to spend several months discussing its China policy, which will be a part of the party's "10 year platform" covering a wide range of issues, she said, although she did not set a timetable.

The DPP's new China policy under Tsai is greatly anticipated, as she has been trying to move the party more to the middle and appeal to moderate voters after its previous hardline stance earned it an "anti-China" label.

Tsai, who received more than a million votes in the Xinbei City mayoral election but lost to the KMT's Eric Liluan Chu, said the funding for the think tank will come from her election subsidy of more than NT$30 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH launches safe sex campaign in night club
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 22:46:10 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang visited a night club Tuesday evening to distribute condoms to young people in a campaign against HIV and AIDS.

"The idea of launching the campaign in a club came to mind because the ratio of HIV carriers aged between 15 to 24 is on the rise in Taiwan, " said Yaung, adding that as much as 90 percent of the infections are caused by unsafe sex.

Admitting that he had never been to a club before and that he was uncomfortable with the loud music, Yaung said he came to help young people establish a better understanding of the disease that they can be so easily exposed to.

"Aside from advocating the use of condoms to prevent AIDS, I also want to tell HIV carriers that they can still lead healthy and normal lives, " said Yaung as he hugged "Piaochung, " a muscular man who was infected 10 years ago.

Wearing a big smile, "Piaochung" said confidently that he has traveled to Hawaii three times in the past five years. "My friends and colleagues often ask me whether it is true that I have AIDS or if I am just faking," he laughed.

Noting the government's support for AIDS patients, Yaung said that advanced drugs for treating AIDS are covered by national health insurance and that there is therefore no need for people who test HIV-positive to panic and fall into depression.

According to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control under the DOH, as of the end of October, there were 19,735 Taiwanese HIV carriers, of which 3,000 were reported to have died. The highest concentration of HIV carriers by age was in the 20-29 age bracket (38.1 percent) followed by those in the 30-39 age group (35.2 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP members trade barbs over 2012 presidential candidate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 22:58:33 (By Wen Kuei-shiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Senior members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have begun trading barbs over how to select a candidate for the 2012 presidential race after it secured only two out of five seats in Saturday's municipality elections.

While urging the party to start discussing the issue as soon as possible, former DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun argued that incumbent DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen should not have to step down to take responsibility for the election results.
He contended that Tsai should stay and continue leading the DPP, as the outcome of elections shows that it performed better than the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in terms of ballots garnered.
"Although Tsai herself lost the race in Xinbei City, the DPP, however, fought a surprising battle under her leadership by gaining the support of half of Taiwan's voters," Yu said.
According to Yu, Tsai has succeeded in getting the ballots of the youth, women and swing voters. "She helped the party find new voters and created a new way of fighting an electoral battle," he said.
The heads of the DPP's local branches in Taipei and Taoyuan counties, as well as younger DPP lawmakers, echoed Yu's view and asked Tsai not to quit because of her Xinbei City defeat.
The DPP lost in Taipei City, Xinbei City and Taichung City, but won in Tainan and Kaohsiung by large margins.
The party grabbed 49.87 percent of the total ballots cast, while the KMT secured 44.54 percent.

Given the election results, many supporters urged Tsai and former Premier Su Tseng-chang, who was defeated by KMT incumbent Mayor Hau Lung-bin in Taipei City, to vie for the party's nomination to run in the next presidential election.
In response to calls for her to run for president in 2012, Tsai replied that she will consider it, but she also made it clear that she will continue leading the DPP.
Meanwhile, some of the party's old guard, such as Legislator Chai Trong-rong and former Vice President Annette Lu, are opposed to the idea and said Tsai should opt for just one of the positions.
Lu said in a recent interview on local cable TV that she is opposed to a failed candidate representing the party in the 2012 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait investment protection agreement not framework in nature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 23:05:09 (By Charles Kang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A proposed investment protection agreement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not be set up like a framework agreement, the minister of economic affairs said Tuesday amid media reports of the signing of a framework agreement to come before the formation of the formal pact.

"Taiwan has signed more than 20 investment protection agreements" with its foreign trade partners, none of which are in the nature of framework accords, Shih Yen-shiang said, underlining that the planned cross-strait pact on investment protection will be a "complete agreement."

Asked whether the proposed agreement will be signed as anticipated in a coming meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, which is scheduled to take place in Taipei City before the end of the year, Shih declined to answer.

Addressing the new accord, Shih said that the two sides are still discussing a proposed investment protection mechanism, measures to gradually remove barriers against mutual investment activities, ways to increase the transparency of investment regulations, and methods to facilitate the launch of investment programs.
The issues of wide concern, such as the safety of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China will also be discussed, he added.
Earlier that day, meanwhile, ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, arrived in Taiwan for a visit.
During his stay, Zheng will have working-level discussions with his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian, according to the SEF.
They will exchange opinions on when the upcoming biannual meeting between Chiang and Chen will take place, SEF officials said.
Zheng will return to Beijing Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan top destination choice among Hong Kong tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 23:10:32 (By Stanley Cheung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the first choice of Hong Kong people as a destination for overseas travel, according to the results of a MasterCard survey released Tuesday.

Among 10,502 MasterCard holders in the Asia-Pacific region, the Middle East and Africa who answered the survey between September and November, 58 percent of the respondents in Hong Kong said they plan to fly abroad in the next six months.
Their three most favored destinations are Taiwan (47 percent) , China (45 percent) and Japan (44 percent) , according to the survey results.

Chen Tsao-ming, director of the Hong Kong office of the Taiwan Tourism Bureau, said the similar cultural background is the reason Taiwan is the most popular overseas destination for Hong Kong tourists, along with Taiwan's food and hospitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspect wants to face victim over shouting his name
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 30 (CNA) 11/30/10 23:15:25 (By Huang Hsu-sheng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The gunman suspected of shooting the son of a KMT official wants to confront his victim over the latter's allegation that the gunman called out his victim's name before shooting him, the suspect's legal counsel said Tuesday.

Lin Cheng-wei's lawyer said his client admitted to having sworn at Sean Lien, the son of Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, but said he absolutely did not call him by his name and would like to face Lien to clear things up.
Lin, who has not cooperated with police investigators, also wants to take a lie- detector test, the lawyer said.
Whether Lien heard the gunman call his name right before firing at him is a key question prosecutors were trying to make sure of when they questioned him in hospital where he was receiving treatment.

Banciao District Court Chief Prosecutor Sun Chih-yuan, along with two other court officials, raised a number of questions regarding where Lien was standing, how he was attacked and other circumstances at the time of the shooting during a Nov. 26 election-eve campaign rally in Yunghe, Taipei County.
As the suspect insists that he had "identified the wrong target" and shot Lien by mistake, the prosecutors said they will decide whether to allow Lin and Lien to cross-examine each other.
Prosecutor Chen Cheng-fen said many things remain unclear in Lin's accounts of the origin of the weapon used, his motivation and his intended target.
Key points in the investigation are whether there is a mastermind behind the shooting, who the suspect talked to before committing the crime, and whether gambling interests are involved, Chen said.

The prosecutor also said there is no need to publish the X-rays of Lien's injury, since the police and hospital authorities have made public all available details about Lien's medical treatment and condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 1, or the 26th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 10:21:57 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 58.12 points at 8,430.60 on a turnover of NT$3.081 billion (US$101.02 million).
The weighted price index rose 5.31 points, or 0.06 percent, to close at 8,372.48 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Elections at gunpoint

TEXT.P: The Nov. 26 election-eve shooting of Sean Lien, son of Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, has sparked various conspiracy theories. Police must resolve the case rapidly to uphold justice for the victim and rebuild the public's confidence in the government's ability to maintain law and order.
There have been suspicions that the shooting was masterminded by an underground gambling ring taking bets on the elections, in the hope that the incident would sway the election outcome in its favor.

If proven true, it would be a serious problem. We must deal gambling rings a blow, or else Taiwan will always hold elections under the shadow of guns, which would constitute the greatest blow to the country's democracy.

Some legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), meanwhile, speculated that the incident was staged by the KMT to win sympathy votes and that Lien's wounds were faked. We wonder whether those politicians have any shred of humanity. Don't forget that Lien is still in the hospital waiting to undergo rehabilitation while another innocent bystander lost his life as a result of the incident. How far is the DPP going to tolerate such heartlessness by its public office-holders? (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 1, 2010)
