DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Please shut up

TEXT.P: Just as with the shooting of former President Chen Shui-bian on March 19, 2004, a day before that year's presidential election, the Nov. 26 shooting of Kuomintang politician Sean Lien on the eve of the special municipality elections also led to a last-minute reversal of the expected outcome.

Being able to overturn election results at the last minute is very tempting. Who can guarantee that similar incidents will not occur again in future polls? If voters allow bullets to have their way again and again, bullets will not disappear from elections.

The worst part of shooting incidents, however, is not that they generate sympathy votes, but that they result in endless conspiracy theories and rumors. In the aftermath of Chen's shooting, the blue camp spent more than a year weaving scores of conspiracy theories, while the green camp was busy rebutting them. This time, it is the green camp's turn to suspect the blue camp of staging Lien's shooting.

Lawmakers and political pundits, on the other hand, are quick to create rumors based on their partisan interests. These politicians and pundits should keep their mouths shut before the outcome of the investigation is released, and they should not impose their arbitrary interpretations if the investigation results do not match their expectations.

Prosecutors and police must also learn a lesson from the 319 shooting. They should carefully collect related evidence to reveal the truth, so as to ease social confrontation and unrest. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based property developer seeks to issue TDRs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 12:14:53 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Fantasia Holdings Group Co. Ltd., a Chinese property developer, is seeking to issue Taiwan depositary receipts on the main board, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) said Wednesday.
The stock exchange said Fantasia has submitted an application for the TDR listing and plans to issue 120 million TDRs, each of which will represent two common shares of the company.
If the application is approved, Fantasia will the first foreign property developer to list TDRs in Taiwan, the TWSE said.
Fantasia, which is headquartered in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, has been listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2009.

The property developer said its real estate development activities are largely located in four of the fast-growing economic areas in China -- the Chengdu-Chongqing Economic Zone, the Pearl River Delta region, the Yangtze River Delta region and the Beijing-Tianjin metropolitan region.
According to Fantasia's prospectus, it is hoping to raise NT$1.37 billion (US$44.94 million) and plans to use the funds to set up a subsidiary in Taiwan.
Fantasia said the subsidiary is expected to invest NT$1.2 billion to develop a vacation resort in offshore Kinmen in cooperation with Taiwan-based Astro Corp.

"The introduction of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) will prompt further commercial interaction between the mainland and Taiwan, which we believe will present substantial business opportunities for us," Fantasia Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Pan Jun said in a statement on the company's website.
"We are actively looking at new opportunities and seeking to expand our business and operations to the next level, effectively utilizing alternative financing channels," Pan said.
Taiwan and China signed the ECFA in late June. It took effect in September.
Jihsun Securities has been appointed as the underwriter of the TDR issuance, Fantasia said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Inheritance dispute over two Chiangs' diaries

TEXT.P: A dispute has erupted over the right to inherit the diaries of two late presidents of the Republic of China -- Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching- kuo.
A fourth-generation family member has demanded that terms of the contract giving the Hoover Institution at Stanford University the right to preserve the diaries for 50 years be renegotiated.

Chiang You-mei, the daughter of Chiang Ching-kuo's deceased eldest son Chiang Hsiao-wen, issued a statement through the international law firm Baker & Mckenzie Tuesday asking her aunt Chiang Fang Chih-yi to help in getting the U.S. research institute to negotiate a new contract with her and other legal heirs to the two Chiangs' diaries.
The two diaries are of significant academic value because they documented crucial historical events in modern China and recounted relevant policy-making processes, local observers said.

On Jan. 10, 2005, Chiang Fang Chih-yi, the widow of Chiang Ching-kuo's third son, Chiang Hsiao-yung, signed an agreement with the Hoover Institution that authorized the San Francisco-based think tank to take possession of the diaries for the next 50 years.

The diaries of Chiang Kai-shek span 1918 through 1975, a period that included a war of resistance against Japanese invasion, a civil war with the Chinese Communists and his exile to Taiwan and rule over the island.
Chiang Ching-kuo's diaries began in 1939 and ended in 1979, a period during which he succeeded his father, serving as premier and then president of the ROC.
The Hoover Institution has since made copies of the diaries available for public inspection under strict conditions.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the dispute:
United Daily News:

Chiang You-mei, who resides in Britain, said in the statement that Chiang Fang Chih-yi should not have signed the contract with the Hoover Institute by herself, because she is only one of nine legal heirs to the two Chiangs' diaries. Her act infringed on the legal rights of the other heirs, the statement said.

As one of the legal heirs to the diaries, Chiang You-mei said she had long tried to persuade Chiang Fang Chih-yi to push the Hoover Institution to negotiate a new contract with all legal heirs, but had yet to receive a positive response.

Chiang You-mei said she and other heirs will not continue tolerating Chiang Fang Chih-yi's arbitrary action and that if necessary, they will take legal action to protect their own rights. (Dec. 1, 2010).
China Times:

Sources close to the Chiang family said following the death of Chiang Ching-kuo, many important documents and files, including the two Chiangs' diaries, were left to the custody of his third son Chiang Hsiao-yung.
Chiang You-mei said Tuesday in a statement that Chiang Kai-shek's diaries were part of Chiang Ching-kuo's legacy that should be equally shared by all of his legal heirs.
Chiang Hsiao-yung's widow should not have authorized the Hoover Institution to take possession of the diaries without the consent of other heirs, she argued.
CommonWealth Publishing Co. reportedly is scheduled to publish volumes of Chiang Kai-shek's diaries from 1945 to 1949 next week. (Dec. 1, 2010).
Liberty Times:
The inheritance dispute shed light on disharmony among family members of the once powerful and glamorous Chiang clan.
Some pundits wondered if the issue could be settled by turning the diaries over to the Kuomintang or to the country rather than remaining in the hands of Chiang's heirs.
The Kuomintang would not comment on the suggestion, saying it would not interfere in the Chiangs' family matters.

As for the possibility of the diaries being taken over by the state, legal experts said the two Chiangs' diaries were basically private property and would have a hard time being defined as national files or documents under the country's Archives Act. (Dec. 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: New book on China's AIDS pandemic unveiled in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 14:28:05 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese AIDS activist who now lives in the United States after being persecuted by Beijing launched her latest book on China's AIDS epidemic in Taiwan on Tuesday, giving local readers new insight on why AIDS has become such a major problem there.

Speaking by teleconference from New York, Gao Yao-jie was excited to present to Chinese-speaking readers "China's AIDS Plague, " one of a series of three manuscripts aimed at exposing the seriousness of HIV transmission through blood transfusion in China.
The 84-year-old activist said that a large percentage of the AIDS population in China had contracted the disease through contaminated blood transfusion and unsanitary blood donation procedures.

Blood contamination, Gao said, was originally the result of a "bloodhead" scandal, in which government officials and businessmen aggressively collected blood using unhygienic equipment in all 31 provinces of China in the early 1990s.

Large groups of farmers were lured to sell their blood under unsanitary conditions for money -- with 800 cc of blood earning 40-160 Chinese Yuan (NT$160-NT$640) -- under the slogan "selling blood makes you richer, healthier and keeps you away from high blood pressure."

Without the proper disinfection equipment, however, the blood stations in turn spread the HIV virus to patients undergoing blood transfusions, said Gao, who was unable to attend the book's launch in Taiwan in person because of health issues.

She added that similar conditions contributing to the spread of AIDS through blood transfusions still exist today, though many of the unsanitary blood collection stations have gone underground to avoid government scrutiny.
Gao's presentation set off a heated discussion among local doctors, scholars, and social activists gathered in Taipei for the event on China's approach to the disease.

Zhang Jin-hua, a professor in National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Journalism, said China had yet to recognize the problem of blood infection and was underestimating the gravity of the issue, as seen in a Dec. 2009 report in which China's health authorities said AIDS was spread mainly through sexual activity.

Liao Say-tsung, an HIV and AIDS specialist at Taipei Medical University Hospital, said that while it was true that about 70 percent of AIDS patients in liberal countries were infected through sexual intercourse, China's case was different.
He gave credit, however, to China's current AIDS prevention campaign, saying that Chinese scholars and researchers are working hard to remedy the situation.
When asked how many AIDS patients in China caught the disease through blood transfusions, Zhang said it was hard to tell because of the lack of official data.
But based on rare reports of individuals suing the Chinese government for compensation and the victim's stories in Gao's new book, Zhang said the problem was clearly serious.
Liao advised Taiwanese to take precautions if they required emergency blood transfusions in China.
"Have the hospital staff go over the transfusion procedure carefully so as to protect yourself," Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-funded 'Taiwan Yonghe King' permitted to register in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 14:43:29 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has approved a Chinese investor's application to set up an enterprise called "Taiwan Yonghe King" in Taiwan to sell food and beverages and groceries, the ministry announced Tuesday.
Under the approved investment plan, the Chinese investor will put NT$5 million (US$163,860) into the new business, MOEA officials said.
The investment plan stirred controversy because of the company's proposed name and speculation that the company backing it was a soybean milk-chain in Shanghai called Shanghai Yonghe King Co.
MOEA officials, however, denied the speculation, saying the investor was not involved with the Shanghai company.
Soybean milk is a traditional breakfast beverage in Taiwan that often goes with a flat sesame seed bread stuffed with a fried dough stick.
Yonghe in Taipei County has been one of the best-known places for the breakfast foods, and its popularity has made "Yonghe" soybean milk a brand representing the Taiwanese soybean milk breakfast.

Use of the name could be seen as conflicting with existing breakfast and late- night snack chains in Taiwan, but MOEA officials explained that companies are allowed to register any company name in Taiwan as long as it is unique.

But they acknowledged that if a company wanted to register the name "Taiwan Yonghe King" as a trademark in Taiwan, the move would very likely be rejected because there would be too little differentiation between it and other existing trademarks, such as "Yonghe Soybean Milk" and "Yonghe Soybean Milk King."
It was still unclear Wednesday if the newly approved company actually intended to set up a soybean milk store.

During Tuesday's investment review meeting at the MOEA, 24 investment projects were approved, including 10 investment plans proposed by overseas Chinese and foreign nationals and eight by Chinese investors.
Investments in China proposed by one overseas investor and five Taiwanese companies were also approved.
One surprise was that the high-profile plan of panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) to invest in a 7.5 generation panel factory in China was not put on the agenda of the review meeting.
MOEA Vice Minister Huang Chung-chiu said the authorities involved are still reviewing AUO's application.
AUO is one of the world's major manufacturers of large-sized TFT-LCD panels.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer signs accord to set up Chongqing base in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 15:27:15 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Acer Inc., the world's second largest PC vendor, said it signed an agreement Wednesday with the Chongqing Municipal Government to set up its second operating hub in China.
Acer said the Chongqing base is scheduled to start operations in January of next year at the earliest.

The PC vendor announced last week that it would invest up to US$150 million in the southwestern Chinese city and hoped Taiwanese component suppliers would move to Chongqing to create a manufacturing cluster.
Acer, which currently operates an operating hub in Shanghai, is joining other local high tech companies in developing a presence in China's inland market.

Quanta Computer Inc., the world's largest notebook computer ODM service provider, and Hon Hai Group, the largest contract electronics maker in the world, have already set up operating bases in Chongqing.
According to Acer, Chongqing, which has a sound infrastructure and enjoys a stable supply of manpower, is a transportation hub connecting Europe and southeast China.

Acer said the company will follow the Chinese government's lead in developing the southwestern part of the country through the Chongqing base, and it expected the new production base would help the company grab the title of largest notebook computer vendor in the world.
At present, Acer ranks as the second largest PC and notebook computer vendor behind Hewlett-Packard.
Meanwhile, Acer and its Chinese counterpart Fonder Group have set up a strategic alliance.

Under the terms of their cooperation, Acer is allowed to use Founder's broad distribution network in China to sell Acer products in tier 4-6 Chinese cities -- which have populations of under 20,000 people -- as well as in rural areas.
Acer said its arrangement with Founder began contributing to the company's sales in October.
The Taiwan-based company expects its sales in China will reach US$2.5 billion by 2011 through its cooperation with Founder, compared with US$843 million in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wikileaks revelations not necessarily true: defense minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 15:45:20 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said Wednesday that Taiwan-related information obtained by the whistle-blowing website Wikileaks was not necessarily true.

The ministry has kept track of the classified documents unveiled by the website and has confirmed that none of them were leaked from Taiwan, Kao said during a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.
He said a special task force headed by Vice Minister Andrew Yang would follow future leaks by the website and analyze and verify any details that were related to Taiwan.
Wikileaks announced on its website that over the next few months, it will release in stages 251,287 cables originating from 274 U.S. embassies between Dec. 28, 1966 to Feb. 28, 2010.
Among them, there are 3,456 that were sent between the U.S. State Department and the American Institute in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. representative office in Taiwan.

Taiwan was also mentioned in some of the documents that have already been released. One of the documents showed that China opposed the U.S. sale of Black Hawk helicopters and F-16 C/D fighters to Taiwan, and also opposed Taiwan's sale or rent of SuperCobra AH-1W helicopters to Turkey.
Commenting on the information, Kao said that although Beijing has openly opposed U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, the government was confident it could still procure weapons from the U.S.
As to the helicopter deal with Turkey, the minister said this was the first time he had heard of the matter.

Even if the United States requested Taiwan to sell or rent the AH-1W helicopters to Turkey, Taiwan would not have agreed to it because the helicopters were needed to meet its own defense requirements, Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares hit 29-month high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 17:12:22 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices hit their highest level in more than 29 months on Wednesday on expectations that the next round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China would help accelerate commercial activity between the two countries, dealers said.

The weighted index rose 147.63 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at the day's high of 8,520.11, its highest finish since closing at 8,587.96 on June 9, 2008, on turnover of NT$149.90 billion (US$4.92 billion).

The market opened up 0.69 percent as investors shrugged off a fall on Wall Street overnight, and buying then intensified, focusing on financial firms and property developers, which are expected to benefit from booming business ties with China, dealers said.
A total of 2,802 stocks closed up, and 1,406 finished down, with 363 remaining unchanged.
The financial sector scored the strongest gains, gaining 4.4 percent. Construction, cement and textile stocks rose 2.7 percent, and paper and pulp shares closed up 2.2 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares added 1.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 1.2 percent, and foodstuff shares closed up 0.3 percent.
The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) will hold negotiations in Taiwan later this month.
The market is expecting that the two organizations will sign agreements on investment protection and medical cooperation.
"Investors have embraced high hopes that closer cross-strait business ties after the talks will further boost the local economy, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.

Lin said Saturday's municipal elections, which left the China-friendly Kuomintang government holding on to three of the five mayoral seats up for grabs, paved the way for Taiwan's continued pursuit of economic cooperation with China to raise domestic demand.
Interest continued in property developers as investors were upbeat that local property prices would push higher on rising demand, Lin said.

He said the strong showing staged by bellwether financial firms also reflected optimism toward the local property market as these companies, which own large chunks of property assets, are expected to see the value of their assets rise.
"After's today's gains, the market has become technically healthier by overcoming strong resistance at around the 8,400-8,500 point level," Lin said.
"As the market remains awash in liquidity, there is room for further upward momentum," he said.
Among financial shares, Chang Hwa Bank rose 6.91 percent to NT$21.65, Hua Nan Financial gained 6.87 percent to NT$21.00 and First Financial added 6.86 percent to NT$21.80.

DOC.HEADLINE: China pneumatic product maker to list Dec. 13
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 18:24:42 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Airtac International Group, a China-based pneumatic product maker, is scheduled to launch its primary listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Dec. 13, underwriter Yuanta Securities said Wednesday.

Airtac will issue 17.05 million shares for the listing at a price of between NT$82 (US$2.69) and NT$92, with a public subscription starting from Wednesday and running through Friday, the underwriter said.
The listing price will be set Dec. 6, the underwriter added.
The company has scheduled a conference on Dec. 10 to brief local investors about its operations, Yuanta Securities said.

Airtac, which was set up in 1988 and registered in the Cayman Islands, runs production facilities in China that churn out a wide range of pneumatic products, including pneumatic control components and actuators.
Its products, under the brand "AirTac", are used in the production of automation equipment for the electronics, electrical, auto, transportation, food and mechanical sectors, the company said.
China accounts for almost of 90 percent of Airtac's total revenue, the company added.
With labor costs in China on the rise, demand for automation equipment on the mainland is growing rapidly, which is boosting Airtac's bottom line, Yuanta Securities said.
Currently, Airtac operates 31 branches and 23 representative offices throughout China and is working with more than 500 distributors, serving over 40,000 customers there, Yunata Securities said.

In addition to maintaining a strong presence in the China market, Airtac is aiming to penetrate markets in the United States, Japan and Europe over the next three years by setting up 100 marketing centers worldwide.
Airtac has 2,600 employees globally, about 500 of whom work in the technical and engineering secor.
In 2009, Airtac posted about NT$550 million in net profit, up 32 percent from a year earlier, with earnings per share (EPS) at NT$7.1 percent.
In the first half of this year, the company's net profit hit some NT$542 million with an EPS at NT$4.07.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to tighten restrictions on Chinese trainees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 18:43:40 (By Pan Chi-I and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government is planning to tighten restrictions on Chinese nationals traveling to Taiwan for training to prevent employers from using the trips as a guise to import cheap labor, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju- hsuan said Wednesday.

The permitted length of stay for "research and study" purposes will be shortened from three months to one month, and the number of trainees will not be allowed to exceed a quarter of the total number of Chinese visitors invited to Taiwan for business purposes by the same employer in a single year, Wang said at a legislative hearing.
In addition, the length of training courses provided for the trainees cannot exceed four hours per day, she said.

According to existing regulations governing business visits by Chinese nationals, business owners, managers and skilled technicians are allowed to visit Taiwan at the invitation of Taiwanese organizations for purposes such as fact-finding missions, conferences, speeches, exhibitions, and research and study.
Training is currently grouped in the same category as research and study.

On Nov. 16, prosecutors raided a factory run by touch panel manufacturer Young Fast Optoelectronics in Taoyuan County and discovered 28 Chinese nationals allegedly working on the production line in the guise of receiving training.

The raid was made in response to complaints by labor rights groups that the company was using the model to bring in cheap labor from China, with 18 Taiwanese workers having been dismissed as a result.
According to Wang, the CLA has required Young Fast to explain the dismissal of the workers by Dec. 9, and it has also temporarily frozen the company's right to hire foreign workers.

Young Fast on Wednesday again denied the allegations, saying that bringing workers from the company's China facilities to Taiwan for training for such a short stay involved high costs, making it impossible for the company to use the model to import Chinese laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-vice president calls for rationality on election-eve shooting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 19:10:47 (By Wang Hung-kuo and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu called for public restraint Wednesday amid a flurry of rumors about the motives behind the shooting of a prominent Kuomintang figure on the eve of Taiwan's recent municipal elections.
Lu, herself a victim of an election-eve shooting in 2004, made the appeal after visiting former President Chen Shui-bian at the Taipei Detention Center.
She and Chen are urging the public to stop speculating on the motives behind the Nov. 26 shooting at a campaign rally in Taipei County, she said.
Sean Lien, the son of KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan, was shot in the face but is now in stable condition. A bystander was killed in the incident.
Lu recalled that when she and Chen were wounded in a similar incident on March 19, 2004 in Tainan, speculations were raised that Chen had choreographed the shooting.
Chen sustained a non-life threatening wound to the abdomen in that incident.

Lu said she and Chen are both concerned about the shooting of Lien and the ensuing "weird atmosphere" that has prevailed in the country as rumors continue to fly that the KMT or pan-blue camp had engineered the shooting to help shore up their sagging voter support.
Such speculations have been raised mainly by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the wider pan-green camp.
Lu urged the judicial authorities to quickly investigate the case in order to reduce tensions between the ruling and opposition parties.
She also called on President Ma Ying-jeou to authorize a new probe into the facts behind the 2004 shooting.
"The threat of violence in our democracy will disappear only when the truth behind the shootings is made known," she said.

According to Lu, former President Chen cited statistics to show that the Nov. 26 shooting had not affected the results of the next day's vote, just as the 2004 shooting did not have any significant effect on the presidential poll the following day.
In 2004, Chen and Lu won a second term by a slim margin.
Boasting about the effects of the shooting on voter behavior will only induce more people to resort to violence, which would hurt Taiwan's democracy, Lu said.

The comments by Lu and Chen were made amid arguments by other DPP heavyweights that Lien's shooting had galvanized KMT moderates and swing voters into handing the KMT candidates in Taipei and Xinbei cities a bigger-than-expected win.

DOC.HEADLINE: Uni Air flies underprivileged children to flora expo for free
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1(CNA) 12/01/10 19:21:38 ( By Ni Kuo-yen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: One of Taiwan's domestic air carriers Uni Air is offering free flights to underprivileged children and families in the outlying Kinmen County to visit the Taipei International Flora Expo being held in Taipei City.
Uni Air General Manager Chen Hsien-hung flew to Kinmen Wednesday morning to welcome a group of 33 children and parents from low-income and single-parent families on board the first of the flights.
Although the number of visitors to the flora expo has already exceeded one million, attending the six-month event has been just a dream for many disadvantaged children, Chen said.
"I couldn't fall asleep last night because I was so excited," one of the children told the Central News Agency.
The company will also extend the sponsorship program to impoverished families on the offshore islands of Matsu and Penghu, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll reveals worries of potential violence in future elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 19:40:15 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shien-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Scholars have urged President Ma Ying-jeou to thoroughly investigate the truth behind a shooting incident on the eve of Saturday's municipal elections after a poll revealed fears that violence would be used to affect Taiwan's elections in the future.

The shooting of Sean Lien, the son of former Vice President Lien Chan, the night before the elections, is believed to have boosted support for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , which won three mayoral races after being seen as potentially vulnerable in those cities.

According to the results of a Taiwan Thinktank poll released on Wednesday, nearly two-thirds (62.4 percent) of those polled worried that guns would be used a means to manipulate election results in every important election in the future.
Respondents were split, however, on whether a shooting would affect the fairness of an election, with 52.3 percent saying it would and 47.7 percent saying it would not, the survey found.

Also, when asked which of the two major political parties -- the KMT or the opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- gained the most from Friday's shooting, two-thirds (66.5 percent) said the KMT benefited the most compared to 4.7 percent who said the DPP.
Over half (53.3 percent) of those polled believed the shooting actually helped the KMT win three out of the five mayoral races being contested, while 43.9 percent disagreed with the proposition.

Taiwan Thinktank analyst Hsu Yung-ming said the survey results indicated that most people believed the shooting had affected the elections and that the incident had raised public fears over repeated violence in future polls.
He called on the president to publicly pledge that similar incidents would never happen again during his administration.
Hsiao Hsin-huang, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Sociology, suggested that Ma order a thorough investigation into the Nov. 26 incident to dig out the truth.

The survey was conducted by Master Survey and Research Co. at the behest of Taiwan Thinktank on Nov. 29-30 among adults aged over 20 years of age. A total of 1,085 valid samples were collected, and the poll's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.

Meanwhile, as rumors continued to spread that the event was staged to affect the elections, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said it was extremely unlikely that either Lien or the suspected gunman staged the shooting.
He refused to make any further comments on the case, saying only that all aspects are under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 19:51:20 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.002 to close at NT$30.852.
Turnover totaled US$641 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.950 and moved between NT$30.411 and NT$30.955 before the close.
Taiwan's central bank repeated intervention in the foreign exchange in late trade reversed the early gains posted by the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar, dealers said.

Before the central bank's presence, buying in the New Taiwan dollar by exporters continued in the local foreign exchange market, in particular as investors took cues from a rebound of the Korean won with the joint military drills of the United States and South Korea coming to an end, dealers said.

The New Taiwan dollar gained momentum as the local stock market hit its highest point in more than 29 months on expectations that the sixth round of cross- strait talks scheduled for later this month will produce further measures to boost economic ties between Taiwan and China, dealers said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 1.76 percent at 8,520.11, the highest closing level since June 9, 2008.

The buying in the U.S. dollar by the central bank vaulted the greenback above the NT$30.800 level at the close, off an early low, showing the bank's determination to protect Taiwan's competitive edge in the world market, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: French official urges government support for digital art
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 20:08:36 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Digital technology has had an immense impact on artistic creation and the government should give support in this field as the wider society would benefit, a French official said at a seminar in Taipei Wednesday.
Jean-Marc Prevost, an official from France's Ministry of Culture, said that the use of advanced technology to create art has become the norm.

When singers no longer need record companies to release their albums, but instead publish their music online on their own, "we know artistic creation has taken a completely new turn, " he said at a three-day seminar titled "Artistic creation and digital technology."
The French government is working closely with cultural centers to help create a vibrant environment for artists and allow the public to have easy access to the work of artists, he said.

"Through government support, we hope to provide public access to artistic creations and fulfill the concept of 'the democratization of culture' so that everyone has more opportunities to enjoy the cultural assets," he added.
In recent years, the French government has been actively involved in the establishment of national cultural centers to better link artists with audiences, Prevost said.

These centers include Dispositif pour la Creation Artistique Multimedia (DICREAM), a trans-border institute established in 2001 to assist artists who are engaged in the creation of original digital art works, and Centre National du Livre (CNL), which is dedicated to digital and multimedia publication, he said.
Curator James Giroudon from the National Center for Musical Creation in Lyon, France said there are six national musical centers in France and the number will continue to grow.

"We are not saying all artists have to use high tech in their musical creations, he said. "But the medium of technology is certainly the new tool to produce artworks, and we always need new perspectives on art."

The seminar was organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs, which invited several keynote speakers, mostly from France, to share their views on how the arts could be reshaped through the application of digital technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first couple to begin serving time soon: prosecutors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 20:31:55 (By Lai You-chia, Chen Yi-wei and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife Wu Shu-jen will begin their prison sentences soon, as the conviction documents were sent to the Supreme Prosecutors Office Wednesday, a senior judicial official said.

The former first couple has been sentenced to a total of 19 years behind bars for accepting bribes. The convictions were made in two high profile cases involving a land deal in Lungtan, Taoyuan County and the appointment of a chairperson of the Taipei 101 Building.

Hung Tai-wen, chief of staff of the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said the verdicts, more than 200 pages in total, will be forwarded to the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, which is responsible for executing the jail sentences.
Chen, who is being held at the Taipei Detention Center, will be moved to the Taipei Prison in Kuishan, Taoyuan County.

The documents on Wu's conviction will be sent to the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office in southern Taiwan, which will see to it that her jail sentences are carried with effect from mid- or late December.
As Wu is wheelchair-bound and in poor health, judicial authorities will decide at which prison in the Kaohsiung area she should be confined or whether to grant her probation on medical grounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO, German firm to jointly develop green energy business
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 20:38:56 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp., a Taiwan-based flat panel maker, said Wednesday it has set up a strategic alliance with Evonik Industries of Germany to jointly develop the green energy business.
Both sides have signed a memorandum of understanding to engage in the research, development and manufacture of solar energy, lighting and other unspecified green energy activities, AUO said.
The two companies also aim to enter the business of recycling poly methyl methacrylate (PMMA), which is a clear plastic, for use as a shatterproof replacement for glass.

Further details of the partnership have not yet been finalized, but the cooperation with Evonik, one of the world's leading specialty chemicals makers, will enhance AUO's capability in the areas of material research and development, the Taiwan company said.
In 2008, Forhouse Corp., an AUO affiliate, set up a joint venture with Evonik to produce PMMA for use in thin-film transistor liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCD).
AUO said the joint venture has been going very smoothly, therefore, it was decided that it should be extended into the green energy business.
The Forhouse and Evonik joint venture, which is called Evonik Forhouse Optical Polymers, is planning to double its annual production to 85 kilotons in 2012.
AUO currently owns a stake of more than 90 percent in the Japan-based silicon wafer maker M. Setek, which gives AUO access to the upstream solar-energy business.
In addition, AUO jointly runs a solar cell plant in Malaysia in cooperation with the U.S.-based SunPower Corp.

The flat panel maker is one of many Taiwanese high tech companies that have been diversifying, in particular into renewable energy, in the hope that it will soften any impact from a cyclical downturn in their core businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical agreement to be signed in next cross-strait meeting: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 20:54:58 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: An agreement on cross-strait medical cooperation that is expected to be signed in the next round of negotations between Taiwan and China will serve to better safeguard the health and safety of the Taiwanese people, the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

The government is aware of the problems that could derive from frequent contact between Taiwan and China, said Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang, noting that about 5 million people travel across the Taiwan Strait each year.

For example, Yaung said, many Taiwanese visitors to China like to buy medicine there, but "we have no way of stopping them from purchasing drugs that do not meet medical certification standards in Taiwan."
Under the proposed agreement, a higher accreditation system, like the one used in Taiwan, will be implemented in China to protect consumers, he said.
It is also important to establish a platform for communication on medical emergencies and epidemic prevention, he said.
One of the gaps in Taiwan's SARS prevention and control efforts in 2003 was the lack of a mechanism for cross-strait cooperation, the minister said.

He said the details of the agreement have not yet been finalized, but both sides have agreed to focus on four major areas -- disease control and prevention, drug safety management, the safety of herbal medicine, and emergency rescue.

Minister of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Lai Shin-yuan said the agreement is complex and that an inter-ministerial consultation team, including representatives from the DOH, Ministry of Economic Affairs, and Council of Agriculture, is working on the negotiation process.
The agreement will be signed under a reciprocal and egalitarian framework and a principle of "Five Noes" will be employed to protect the rights of the Taiwanese people, she said.

The five points are no Chinese medical personnel will be allowed to obtain a license or practice medicine in Taiwan, no China capital will be permitted for the establishment of hospitals in Taiwan, no interference will be made in the education of medical personnel, and medical treatment at hospitals in China will not be covered by Taiwan's health insurance program.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. diplomat recognizes Taiwan's democratic achievement
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:01:44 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday he felt deep regret over a shooting incident on the eve of recent municipal elections, while the top U.S. liaison officer with Taipei lauded Taiwan's response to it as a sign of political maturity.

Speaking during a meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt at the Presidential Office, Ma said it was very regrettable to see the shooting at a campaign rally outside Taipei the day before the Nov. 27 polling.

The shooting of Sean Lien, the son of former Vice President Lien Chan, was reminiscent of similar election-eve violence in 2004, when then-President Chen Shui-bian was shot while campaigning for his re-election bid in the southern city of Tainan.
"Violence is relatively rare in Taiwan. It was baffling and unfortunate to witness recurrence of election-eve shooting while our democracy is maturing," Ma said.
Noting that the case is still under probe, Ma told his guest that his administration will make a thorough review and take steps to prevent recurrence of similar tragedies.
In response, Burghardt said the smooth conclusion of the municipal elections were Taiwan's yet another democratic achievement.

The way both the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party handled the incident "was also a sign of political maturity, " said the head of the AIT, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle U.S.-Taiwan relations in the absence of diplomatic ties.
On the just-concluded elections, Ma said the merger and upgrading of some local administrative districts marks a historical milestone in government restructuring.
The expansion and upgrading of two southern cities -- Kaohsiung and Tainan -- also mainfests "our determination to promote balanced development in different parts of the country," Ma noted.

Touching on Taiwan-U.S. relations, Ma said Taiwan faces great challenges as the balance of military power across the Taiwan Strait is increasingly tilting in Beijing's favor. He urged the U.S. government to sell defensive high-performance jet fighters to Taiwan.

The president also mentioned that the number of countries that offer visa-free privileges to Taiwan passport holders has increased from 53 to 96 since he assumed office in May 2008. Canada and 35 European countries have recently agreed to include Taiwan in their visa-waiver programs.
By now, only 6 percent of countries where Taiwanese people often visit have not yet offered Taiwan visa-free privilege, including the United States, Ma said.

Meanwhile, Ma expressed the hope that a Taiwan-U.S. extradition agreement can be signed soon to pave the way for notorious Taiwanese criminals taking refuge in the U.S. to be repatriated to stand trial or serve their prison terms.

Since Taiwan and China signed a judicial assistance agreement last year, Ma said, cross-strait cooperation in fighting crime has scored encouraging results, with some most wanted fugitives having been sent home to face justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mobile banking prospects look good: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:05:19 (By Stacey Wu and Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese people using mobile banking services is expected to increase by 25 percent in the future as smart phones are becoming more popular, according to a survey by Citibank Taiwan Wednesday.
In a poll of respondents between 25 and 49 years old, the bank found that there are currently around 2 million people in Taiwan who use mobile Internet services.

Some 11 percent of the respondents said they are also use mobile phones for transactions and payment services, while 62 percent said they are still considering this move as they are concerned about security.

In response, bankers will focus on the issue of online security and are confident that they can raise the number of mobile banking users to 30 percent of the netizens in Taiwan, said Sung Chih-chiang, chief of Direct Banking & Business Development and Alliance Department of Citibank Taiwan.@
Vice President of Chunghwa Telecom Lee Yen-sung also said as mobile communications develops in Taiwan, he expects e-commerce to flourish alongside the growth of smart phone use.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free trial service on MRT Luzhou Line to end Dec. 2
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:44:56 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The one-month free trial service on the Taipei mass rapid transit Luzhou Line will end Thursday, following mostly positive public reviews, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation (TRTC) said Wednesday.

According to statistics, the new 12.5-kilometer line has lifted the MRT's current average daily total of 1.41 million passenger trips to around 1.57 million, which the TRTC said has met its expectations.
In the first three weeks of service, 3.05 million passenger trips were recorded on the Luzhou Line, the TRTC said.

Unlike the Wenhu Line, which has been plagued by glitches since it started operation in July last year, the Luzhou Line has proved to be stable and reliable and has had no major malfunctions in the past month, according to the TRTC.

"The two cases are very different, " said TRTC manager Wilson Chiang, referring to the Alstom transport system that is used not only in the Luzhou Line, but also in most part of the Taipei MRT network, while the Wenhu Line adopts a hybrid system of Matra of France and Bombardier of Canada, which has taken the blame for its frequent glitches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shooting victim's medical records cannot be made public: hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:48:16 (By Chen Li-ting and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University Hospital said Wednesday that it cannot release the medical records of Sean Lien, a prominent Kuomintang (KMT) figure who was shot in the face during an election-eve campaign rally in suburban Taipei.
Lien's medical records were turned over to Taipei County investigators after he underwent surgery last Saturday, the hospital said in a statement.
The hospital said it cannot make public the records of a patient in cases that are under judicial investigation.
Furthermore, neither Lien nor his family has given authorization for the release of information regarding his medical treatment, including his X-rays, the hospital said.

Lien, a member of the KMT Central Committee and a son of former Vice President Lien Chan, was stumping for a candidate in Taipei County last Friday night when a gunman shot him with a handgun at close range.
According to police reports, a single bullet entered his left cheek and exited near his right temple. He is recovering well after surgery and can now eat soft foods, his doctors have said.
Lien's speedy recovery and what has been described as his extremely good luck in escaping any serious damage have given rise to speculations that the shooting was staged.
Some people in the opposition have called on the hospital to publish all the details of Lien's treatment since he was admitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Convenience store expansion slows on saturated market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:54:37 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The overall number of convenience stores in Taiwan increased last year amid a trend of slower expansion since 2006, according to a survey released by the Fair Trade Commission on Wednesday.

Five major convenience store chains -- 7-Eleven, FamilyMart, Hi-Life, OK Mart and TSC Million -- opened 41 more outlets in 2009 to make a total of 9,245, up from 4,950 ten years ago, the study showed.
But the year-on-year increase of store numbers has dropped from 14.6 percent in 2000 to 0.4 percent last year as a result of slower expansion over the past three years, the Cabinet-level agency said.
In average, there is one convenience store per 0.26 kilometers throughout the country, which is quite dense, results of the survey found.
The density has caused the operators to hold back stretching and instead to provide more services such as home delivery, bill payment, and pre-ordering, the release said.

In terms of geographical distribution of convenience stores, Taipei County, Taipei City, and Taoyuan County are the three regions that have the most stores. All stores in northern Taiwan account for nearly half of the country's total, statistics showed.
Meanwhile, Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, and Taichung City are the top three places in terms of store density.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2011 Computex Taipei to feature tablet computers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:58:13 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: More exhibitors will use more booths at Computex Taipei, the world's second largest computer trade show, next year to feature increasingly popular devices, including tablet computers and e-readers, the organizer said Wednesday.

More than 1,800 local and foreign companies have signed up for the annual event, which will take place from May 31 to June 4, said the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) at a pre-show press briefing.
These companies will use a total of over 5,000 booths next year, compared with 4,861 booths used by 1,715 exhibitors this year, TAITRA added.
Major companies at home and abroad often use the event, now in its 31st year, as a platform to showcase their new products, which will include tablet computers next year, it noted.

The exhibition will take place at a time when several companies -- such as Acer, Asustek, Samsung, ViewSonic, Dell and HP -- have unveiled or are ready to launch their tablet devices to get their slice of a boom started by Apple's iPad.

In addition to representatives from other countries, more Chinese buyers will visit the show next year after Taiwan and China signed a landmark pact for a more liberalized trade earlier this year, according to Brian Lee, deputy executive director of TAITRA's Exhibition Department.
"Of course, we have also been focusing on emerging markets, " he said.
"The average number of foreign visitors to the show is about 36,000 every year, but there will probably be 40,000 next year," Lee added.
He also forecast that after Computex concludes, the value of transactions will total at US$23 billion in the following 12 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Loss of civil war was biggest setback for Chiang Kai-shek: diary
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 21:58:46 (By Lee Shu-hua & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The loss to the Communists in China's civil war in the 1940's was the biggest setback and humiliation for former Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek, according to the entries in his diary.

After relocating his government to Taiwan in 1949, Chiang spent a lot of his time in "thorough soul-searching", trying to understand why only four years after winning a hard war against Japanese invaders in World War II, his Nationalist forces yielded the Chinese mainland to the Communist army, the diary shows.
"The root causes, among other things, were putting the wrong persons in wrong positions," Chiang wrote.
Two such examples were naming Soong Tse-ven as premier and General Pai Chung-hsi as his top military aide, Chiang reflected.
Soong failed to adequately address the problematic economy, and Pai failed to stop the communists from advancing, Chiang said in the diary.
The diaries of Generalissimo Chiang and his son, the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, are now on display at the Hoover Institute, Stanford University in the United States.

Shao Ming-huang, director of the Kuomintang's Party History Hall, said Wednesday that the senior Chiang wrote in his diary every day for more than 50 years between 1917 and 1972. This was a reflection of his one of his personal characteristics of "perseverance" throughout life, Shao added.

The 55-volume diary of the senior Chiang, written in Chinese calligraphy, touched on a wide range of matters such as national and party affairs, the international situation, personnel disputes within the Nationalists government, the China civil war, cross-Taiwan Strait confrontations, family affairs and Chiang's romances, said Shao, who visited the U.S. to read the diaries before they went on display.
Shao said that the senior Chiang used to keep a diary as a means of "examining himself" and correcting his mistakes.
Generalissimo Chiang, who died in 1975 in Taiwan, never tried to hide his personal feelings toward anyone, Shao said.
The Generalissimo once intentionally called U.S. General George Catlett Marshall "Ma Hsia-er", a contemptuous name in Chinese that implied the general was the son of an indecent Marshall family.

Marshall was a five-star general sent by then U.S. President Harry Truman in 1945 to broker a proposed Chinese coalition government between the Nationalists and Communists. But Chiang thought General Marshall had favored Mao Zedong, leader of the Communist forces, and that the Nationalists' failure was linked to that.
When he learned of Marshall's death from a stroke in 1959, Chiang wrote "Ma Hsia-er just got the punishment he deserved."
Shao said the diary showed that the senior Chiang "went beyond the general impression of being just a general, as he never tired of reading in his lifetime."
Chiang's personality underwent a lot of changes during the last years of his life, and his temper softened as he grew older, Shao said.
"The only thing that did not change was his determination to 'recover the Chinese mainland' -- a dream that failed to come true before he died," Shao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tsai Ing-wen favored to continue serving as DPP head: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:11:09 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) impressive performance in the just-concluded municipal elections has raised the popularity of its chairwoman, according to a survey released Wednesday.

Taiwan Thinktank, which contracted a poll and research company to conduct the post-election survey in late November, said 71.4 percent of the respondents voiced support for Tsai Ing-wen to remain on the post, while 15.7 percent opposed the idea.

Although the DPP has only secured two out of five mayoral seats in the elections on Nov. 27, it gained more ballots in total than the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) did in the mayoral elections in Taipei City and other four to-be-created special municipalities.
The survey showed the satisfaction rate for Tsai's performance as DPP chairwoman reaches 67.3 percents, while the dissatisfaction rate stands at 23.9 percent.

On President Ma Ying-jeou's performance since he took the power in May 2008, 39.9 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with Ma's administration. Those who are dissatisfied with Ma's job performance, however, account for 56 percent of all respondents.

The poll by the non-profit research organization, which is generally perceived as more sympathetic with the pro-independence pan-green camp headed by the DPP, also showed that 45.9 percent of the surveyed think the DPP wins the elections, while only 35.2 percent regard the KMT as the winner.
In his analysis of the elections, Hsiao Hsin-huang, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Sociology, said although the DPP lost the mayoral race, it won more votes and support.
In general, the opposition party was marching toward the northern areas from its strongholds in the south, the researcher said.
The survey was conducted on Nov. 29-30 among adults over 20 years of age. A total of 1,085 valid samples were collected, and the poll's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lien's gunshot wound authentic: hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:20:40 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) on Wednesday scoffed at the speculation that Lien Sheng-wen, the son of a former vice-president, had orchestrated his own shooting on election eve last Friday, saying the patient would not have had the "courage" to arrange for someone to shoot him in the head.
Lien, 40, also known as Sean Lien, was shot in the face while he was stumping for a Kuomintang Xinbei council candidate last Friday night at a campaign rally in suburban Taipei.
The bullet entered Lien's left cheek and exited below his right temple, according to police reports. After a four-hour operation at NTUH, Lien is now able to talk, eat, and smile, the hospital said.

Lien's rapid recovery and the lack of pictures of his injury have prompted some people, in particular a few Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers, to speculate on the authenticity of the shooting.
Some have said that Lien orchestrated the entire incident to bolster the KMT's chances in the municipality elections.
Various political commentators have argued that the incident gave the KMT a much needed last-minute push to edge ahead in an election that they said was deadlocked.
However, such notions were strongly refuted by NTUH trauma specialist Ko Wen-je, the head physician who treated Lien in the first 30 minutes after he was rushed to the hospital.

"I saw the injury with my own eyes and treated him personally. There is nothing fake about it, " Ko said. " Lien would not have had the courage to arrange for a gunman to shoot him in the head. That would have been too dangerous."
The doctor said that as a staunch DPP supporter he is the most convincing witness to vouch for Lien.
Lien's wound is real and was definitely caused by a bullet that went through his face, Ko said, lamenting the lack of trust between rival parties in Taiwan.

The doctor attributed Lien's speedy recovery to the hospital's medical expertise as well as the patient's "good luck." Had the bullet struck one centimeter in another direction, the patient could have lost his sight, Ko said.
According to the NTUH press release, Lien remains under hospital watch and is in stable condition.

Amid calls by the public to disclose Lien's medical records, the hospital pointed out that under the Medical Care Act health institutions are not permitted to release patient records without the consent of the patient.
"The hospital has no authority to publicize any medical records, x-ray pictures or any related information regarding Lien's condition," NTUH said.
The law also requires hospitals to forward all relevant information and documents to the judiciary upon request, as in this case, NTUH added.

The police reported that a man was fatally shot in the same incident. It is still unclear whether he was killed by the same bullet that struck Lien. A suspect was immediately arrested on the scene of the incident and is still in detention.

DOC.HEADLINE: History of German video art on display in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:29:48 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The Goethe Institute Taipei is currently holding an exhibition of more than 40 German video art works that date back to the 1970s, showing the development of the art form, Markus Wernhard, director of the institute, said Wednesday.

The exhibition, titled "40 Years of Video Art in Germany, " includes a vast collection of video shorts from 1969 to 2008 made by famous artists such as Joseph Beuys, Klaus vom Bruch, Lutz Dammbeck, Wold Kahlen and many others. It will run until Dec. 17.
Video artworks began to emerge in Germany in the early 1970s but could not be put on display since the format was totally different from the digital technology in use today.

In 2004, the German Federal Cultural Foundation began to collect, restore, and covert old video artworks with the aim of saving and maintaining the cultural heritage of video art, Wernhard told the Central News Agency in an interview.
It has become one of the most influential art forms of the 20th century, he said.

On display at the exhibition are three different categories of videos -- artists using technology to record an event, artists trying to use video to express their artistic point of view, and works that are strongly related to social and political movements.
There are some pieces that were done by East German artists and which reflect the historical atmosphere in the 1970s and 1980s, the director said.
Compared with past video artworks, Wernhard said, the scope of modern video creation is becoming bigger and bigger, which means the differences between film and video art are disappearing.

Contemporary video artists work with big camera teams and many of the works consist of several projections, which need to be shown in big exhibition halls, he said. Old video works, on the other hand, were presented on old-fashioned TV sets only, he noted.
"Artists are very interested in exploring new ways of creation. Through the exhibition, one can get an impression of how quickly our world has changed during the last 40 years," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC sales forecast to remain flat or shrink slightly in Q1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:33:26 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, will likely see its sales in the first quarter of next year remain at the same level as the fourth quarter of this year, company Chairman Morris Chang said Wednesday.
However, there is also a possibility that the company's sales in the Jan.-March period will fall slightly within a 5 percent range, he said.
First-quarter sales might not be strong, but will still be better than in the same periods of past years, he told reporters after a local forum.
He expressed cautious optimism over the industry's outlook and forecast that the wafer foundry industry will grow 14 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Austria to cooperate in cloud computing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:42:25 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese government-backed institute plans to work with Austrian companies in cloud computing next year, the first ever cooperation between the information and communication technology (ICT) industries of the two countries, the Austrian Trade Delegation (ATD) said Wednesday.

About 20 Austrian software companies, including those in the online storage and Internet protocol business, were interested in cooperating with Taiwanese manufacturers, ATD Deputy Trade Delegate Martin Hiesboeck told the Central News Agency on the sidelines of a press conference held for "ICT Month" trade fair scheduled for Dec. 4-12.

Hiesboeck will make a proposal to Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) later this month after a business briefing to the software companies in Austria Dec. 7-22, but he declined to name the participants.
"Taiwanese firms are good at hardware manufacturing, which is a complement to the Austrian ICT industry," Hiesboeck added.
In Austria, nearly 26,000 companies are running ICT business, while more than 45 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) comes from the ICT industry, according to the ATD website.

Vienna, capital of Austria, has become the third largest ICT cluster in Europe behind London in Britain and Munich in Germany, with more than 8,000 ICT firms setting operation bases there, the website said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sale of HTC Windows 7 phones in Asia said "O.K."
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 22:53:06 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's HTC Corp., the world's No.4 smartphone brand, said Wednesday that the sale of its new smartphones with the Windows operating system has been passable so far in Asia, but the company will keep oberving the market demand until early next year.

"Sales of the Windows Phone 7 (WP7) series are O.K. in Asia after its launch in November because many Asian consumers have got used to the Windows system, " Jack Tong, vice president of HTC Asia-Pacific region, said at a press briefing.

Taiwan's largest telecom operator Chunghwa Telecom began to sell two WP7 models --the HTC HD7 and the HTC 7 Mozart-- on Nov. 11, while the country's second- largest telecom carrier, Taiwan Mobile Co., offered only the HD7 model.
HTC needs time to collect responses from consumers and retailers, so it will not make any comment on market demand for the WP7 until the first quarter of 2011, Tong said.
Shipments of the WP7 will be going smoothly beginning this month and the company will try to meet local demand first, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chair calls for swift probe into election-eve shooting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 23:05:29 (By Wen Kuei-shiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen urged the government Wednesday to uncover the truth of the election-eve shooting of Sean Lien, the son of a former vice president, and to help prevent any recurrence of such incidents.

"The government must quickly dig out the truth and clearly explain the matter to the public and the families of the victims, " Tsai said during the DPP's first weekly Central Standing Committee meeting since the Nov. 27 municipality elections.

There have been speculations that the shooting, which left Lien with serious wounds to his face and resulted in the death of a 29-year-old man at a campaign rally in Xinbei City, helped boost the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to a 3-2 win in the elections.

The DPP maintained control of Tainan and Kaohsiung, two of its traditional strongholds in southern Taiwan, while the KMT won in northern Taiwan's Taipei City and Xinbei City and central Taiwan's Taichung City.

At the meeting, Tsai rebutted allegations hinting at the DPP's possible role in the shooting. She said that the assailant, the mastermind, and those trying to spread rumors should be harshly condemned for attempting to provoke confrontations.

Tsai said the incident cast a shadow on the weekend elections. She called on the government to devise measures for preventing a recurrence of such violence and to dissuade the media from misleading the public.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the party will set up a task force to track and monitor developments in the shooting case. Anyone caught using the incident to smear the DPP must be prepared to take legal responsibility, he said.

In response to Tsai Ing-wen's remarks, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said the KMT fully supports the DPP's call to unearth the facts of the case. However, he asked Tsai not to rehash the incident as means of shirking responsibility for her party's loss in the mayoral elections.

Yen Da-ho, chief prosecutor of the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, said in a legislative committee hearing later Wednesday that after checking the video footage of the campaign rally, he had found "nothing to indicate that the shooting was orchestrated by Sean Lien."
"I will ask the Banciao Prosecutors Office to solve the case as soon as possible, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chiang diaries should be returned to Taiwan: lawmaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/10 23:05:38 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government should seek the return of the diaries of its two late presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek and his son Chiang Ching-kuo -- which have been kept at a U.S. research institute since 2005, a ruling Kuomintang lawmaker said Wednesday.
Legislator John H. Chiang, the son of Chiang Ching-kuo born out of wedlock, made the remarks after an inheritance dispute over the two Chiang diaries came into the spotlight Tuesday.

Chiang You-mei, the daughter of Chiang Ching-kuo's deceased eldest son, issued a statement through the international law firm Baker & Mckenzie Tuesday asking her aunt Chiang Fang Chih-yi to help in getting the Hoover Institution at Stanford University to negotiate a new contract with her and other legal heirs to the two Chiang diaries.

On Jan. 10, 2005, Chiang Fang Chih-yi, the widow of Chiang Ching-kuo's third son Chiang Hsiao-yung, signed an agreement with the Hoover Institution that authorized the San Francisco-based think tank to take possession of the diaries for the next 50 years.

Chiang You-mei, who resides in Britain, said in the statement that Chiang Fang Chih-yi should not have signed the contract with the Hoover Institute on her own, because she is only one of nine legal heirs to the two Chiang diaries. Her act infringed on the legal rights of the other heirs, the statement said.

As one of the legal heirs to the diaries, Chiang You-mei said, she has been trying for a long time to persuade Chiang Fang Chih-yi to push the Hoover Institution to negotiate a new contract with all legal heirs, but has yet to receive a positive response.
Chiang You-mei said she and other heirs will not continue to tolerate Chiang Fang Chih-yi's arbitrary actions and that if necessary, they will take legal action to protect their own rights.
Legislator Chiang said he is not in a position to comment on the inheritance dispute, but that he looks forward to an early solution to the controversy.

"I can understand the reasons why the diaries were sent abroad in 2005, " he said, referring to the then-pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party administration's campaign to wipe out "dictator" Chiang Kai-shek's legacy.
However, since the political situation has changed, the issue should be addressed with new way of thinking, he said.
The two diaries are of significant historical value, because they document crucial events in modern China and recount relevant policy-making processes, Chiang said.

"Therefore, they should not be regarded as family assets. They belong to the Kuomintang, to our people and to our country, " Chiang said. He suggested that a special library be built to store the diaries and other historical documents and artifacts.

The 55-volume diaries of Chiang Kai-shek span 1917 to 1972, a period that included a war of resistance against Japanese invasion, a civil war with the Chinese Communists and his exile to Taiwan and rule over the island, according to a KMT official.
Chiang Ching-kuo's diaries began in 1939 and ended in 1979, a period during which he succeeded his father, serving as premier and then president of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 2, or the 27th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial- level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six- and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.
Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Act against gang violence
DOC.DATELINE: 12/02/10 11:56:05 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 2, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Nov. 27 special municipality elections were marred by an election-eve shooting incident that resulted in the injury of Kuomintang politician Sean Lien and the death of a bystander. The country's top priority now should be to seek institutional reforms to prevent gang violence and the interference of outside forces in future polls.

There is a need to conduct a thorough review of election laws and plug any loopholes that allow criminals to manipulate the outcome of elections. Currently, an election can be suspended only in the event of the death of a candidate. Indeed, the 2004 presidential election was held as scheduled despite the shooting of former President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu a day before the polls, because the pair suffered only minor wounds. The incident was, nevertheless, believed to have reversed the expected outcome of the election by generating sympathy votes for Chen and Lu.
Similarly, the Nov. 27 elections were not suspended because none of the victims of the shooting was a candidate, and the election outcome was also influenced by the incident.

The laws should be made more comprehensive to prevent criminal acts that intend to change election outcomes. There is also a need to consider whether the conditions for suspending elections should be increased to include situations other than the death of a candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Mind the feelings of common people
DOC.DATELINE: Although the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 12/02/10 12:46:47 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: won three of the five mayoral seats that were up for grabs in the Nov. 27 elections, it, nevertheless, secured 400,000 lesser votes than the opposition Democratic Progressive Party in total. This, certainly, should ring alarm bells for President Ma Ying-jeou's 2012 re-election bid.

So why did a recovering economy and stable relations with China not translate into votes for the ruling party? Generally speaking, the main focus of Ma's economic policy was normalizing economic and trade ties with China and incorporating Taiwan into a globalized economy. But often, common people do not feel the benefits of such a policy.

The experience of countries worldwide has shown that the beneficiaries of globalization have always been entrepreneurs, while workers are victimized. That is why globalization often widens the gap between the rich and the poor and increases the pay disparity between highly-skilled talent and low-skilled workers.

Although the Ma administration is taking the right path by adopting a policy of liberalization, it has overlooked the policy's impact on different social groups. One example of this is the reduction in the corporate income tax rate and the gift and estate tax rates favoring the wealthy, which make the disadvantaged class feel relatively deprived.
Still, the Ma administration has more than a year to correct its mistake. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- TSMC to rank among top 10 global brands
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) 12/02/10 13:33:11 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chairman Morris Chang forecast Wednesday that the company's brand worth will exceed US$10 billion in the near future, catapulting the world's largest contract chipmaker into the ranks of the top 10 global brands.

Speaking at a panel session organized by the Chinese-language Business Today weekly, Chang said he believes the TSMC brand worth could even surpass that of famous Japanese brand Sony in the next five to 10 years.
Chang recalled that three years ago, TSMC commissioned an international market research company to evaluate his company's brand worth.
"It was estimated that the 'TSMC' brand will be worth more than US$10 billion in the next five to 10 years," Chang said.

The panel session followed a speech by Nouriel Roubini, a New York University economics professor known as "Dr. Doom" because of his pessimistic forecasts. The forum was organized by the Chinese-language Business Today weekly.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the event:
Economic Daily News:
Although many technology companies are investing a lot in branding, Chang said he feels branding is not as important to high-tech firms as it was 20 to 30 years ago.
"There are already many brands in the technology sectors, such as Apple, HP, Dell and Acer in the PC field and Motorola, Samsung and Nokia in the cellphone world," Chang said.
Many tech firms' branding strategies were short-sighted, he noted.

There are two categories of brands -- B2C (business to consumers) that describes activities of businesses serving end consumers with products and/or services, and B2B (business to business) that describes commerce transactions between businesses, such as between a manufacturer and a wholesaler or between a wholesaler and a retailer. Chang said TSMC falls in the B2B category.

"We do not sell products directly to end consumers, but our brand is highly valuable. TSMC would not spend huge sums on advertisement. Our brand worth is built on our edge in technological innovation," he said confidently. (Dec. 2, 2010).
Commercial Times:
Chang said TSMC has consistently focused on opening up new business frontiers since its establishment in Taiwan 20-plus years ago.

"We have never been satisfied with maintaining the status quo or following existing market trends. We have always tried to break new ground and create new demand. This strategy has brought us big business opportunities," Chang said.

He also gave an optimistic forecast on the company's business prospects for the first quarter of next year. Although Q1 tends to be a low season for the technology sector, TSMC is forecast to score better-than-expected sales in Q1 2011, Chang said.

"Our Q1 sales will only shrink by a maximum 5 percent from the level of Q4 2010, a range far less than in previous years, " Chang said, adding that the company's Q1 sales are even likely to match the Q4 level.
