He attributed his optimism in part to China's rise as a major consumer market.
"China is no longer just a world factory. It is now a promising consumer market and Taiwan stands a good chance to cash in own China's growing domestic demands and purchasing power," Chang noted.
He also forecast that the global contract chipmarket could post a 14 percent growth year-on-year growth in 2011. (Dec. 2, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: World Congress of Poets opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 14:05:21 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of poets from 35 countries gathered in Taiwan to share their creative thoughts at the opening of the 30th World Congress of Poets in Taipei Thursday.
The opening ceremony was attended by several high-ranking officials and by former President of India Abdul Kalam, who is also a poet and is widely regarded as the "father of India's missile program."
"Poetry makes our life beautiful. The whole world can be connected through the words of poets, " Kalam said at the opening ceremony.
Taiwanese poet Yu Hsi, who is also known as Hung Ching-yu and is the current president of the 2010 World Congress of Poets, said at the opening ceremony thatpoems are like a panacea for our souls."
Yu said he is sure the Taiwan visit will be a great source of inspiration for the participating poets.
The poets attending the congress will converge on eastern Taiwan during the six- day congress, reciting poems at several scenic spots in Yilan and Hualien.
They are expected to return to Taipei on Dec. 7 to wrap up their Taiwan trip with a visit to the Taipei International Flora Exposition.

At the opening of the congress, Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng welcomed the international guests and invited them to visit again next year for the year-long cultural performances that will be held in celebration of the country's 100th founding anniversary.
The first World Congress of Poets was held in the Philippines in 1969. Taiwan is one of the founding members of the congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's white pomelos enter Japan's market
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Taiwan, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 14:55:12 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Around two tons of the fruit that passed all the quality tests and met the strict requirements set by the Japanese government have been shipped to Japan, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said at a press conference held to celebrate the new market access.
The appearance, as well as the weight and size, of the fruits are required to comply with Japan's regulations, which are tougher compared to that of other foreign markets, Cho said.
And although the products had undergone local inspections for chemical substances, they will still have to pass the spot checks at the quarantine office in Japan when they arrive.

Taiwan has marketed the white pomelos to China and Singapore, but the market prices there were low due to the low market demand, said Tsai Wen-lin, the chairwoman of the farmers' association of Ershuei Township, adding that sales in Japan are expected to improve the livelihood of local fruit farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait investment protection agreement delayed: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 15:45:53 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: It will be very difficult to sign an investment protection agreement in the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks scheduled for this month, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang said Thursday.

Taiwan was hoping to sign an investment protection agreement and a medical cooperation agreement with China this month in the next stage of cross-strait cooperation after the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between the two sides in June.

"The two sides could not agree on a mechanism for settling investment disputes and are still in talks on that aspect (of the agreement) , " Shih said in a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economic Committee Thursday morning.
"It will be very difficult to seal the deal in this round of negotiations," he said.

Investment protection has been one of the major issues in the follow-up negotiations after the signing of the ECFA. Taiwan and China had agreed that substantial agreements on trade in goods and services, investment protection and dispute settlement should be signed within six months of the ECFA's implementation in September.

With trade and investment activities across the strait growing amid warming bilateral ties, trade and investment disputes have also increased. According to the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) , 3,969 complaints related to trade disputes have been filed by China-based Taiwanese businessmen from 1991 to September this year.

The dispute settlement mechanism cannot be routed through the World Trade Organization (WTO) , which only deals with bilateral matters, or through the World Bank, because Taiwan is not a World Bank member, Shih said.

The two sides failed to reach a consensus in the working group meetings on whether the mechanism should be included in the investment protection agreement, given that the mechanism will be regulated in one of the four follow- up agreements, Shih told legislators.

"It's more than likely that the mechanism will be established under the proposed Cross-Strait Economic Cooperation Committee, " which consists of government official from Taiwan and China designated to handle bilateral economic exchanges related to the ECFA, Shih said.

The sixth round of cross-strait negotiation reportedly will be held from Dec. 16-17 in Taipei, but Shih and Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Deputy Chairman Kao Charng declined to confirm the date, during the interpellation session.

The cross-strait negotiations are also known as Chiang-Chen talks because they are led by Taiwan's SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI expected to obtain accreditation for Energy Star testing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 16:22:13 (By Shu Wei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) is expected to gain accreditation to test LED lighting products that are seeking U.S. Energy Star certification, an official said Thursday.
The accreditation will likely be achieved in the first quarter of 2011, according to Chuang Po-nien, deputy director of the ITRI's Center for Measurement Standards (CMS).

Energy Star is an international standard that originated in the U.S. and is applied to energy efficient consumer products. Devices carrying the Energy Star label generally use 20 percent to 30 percent less energy than required by government standards.

The CMS is an organization authorized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection to conduct testing for products, including LED lighting, seeking national CNS certification.
The standards adopted by the CNS program for LED lighting are almost as stringent as those in the Energy Star program, Chuang said.
Therefore, the ITRI is confident that it will qualify for accreditation as an Energy Star testing organization, he added.
The ITRI's accreditation will help speed up the process for Taiwanese LED lighting products seeking to obtain the Energy Star label, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier demands punishment for election-eve shooter
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 16:47:54 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih demanded Thursday that the judicial authorities investigate the truth about the election-eve shooting of the son of a high-ranking ruling Kuomintang (KMT) official and punish whoever is responsible.

"We will absolutely not allow violent and law-breaking incidents to continue to happen, " said the premier after hearing a Central Election Commission briefing on the Nov. 27 elections for Taiwan's five municipalities.

In a violent turn of events that night, Sean Lien, son of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, was shot in the head during a campaign rally in suburban Taipei. He survived, but an innocent bystander was killed.
Wu instructed the relevant officials to take good care of the bereaved family of the victim, identified as Huang Yun-sheng.
While all reports point to a greatly improved election environment prior to the shooting, the incident doubtlessly has had an immense impact on the country's social safety, according to Wu.

He urged the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Justice to investigate the shooting and act accordingly in order to demonstrate the government's determination to punish lawbreakers and to root out election irregularities.
The shooting has sent a shockwave through all sectors of Taiwanese society, adding yet more fuel to the disaccord between the opposition pan-green camp and the ruling pan-blue camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.77 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 17:09:00 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.77 percent Thursday, with buying triggered by an overnight surge on Wall Street, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 65.66 points to 8,585.77, after moving between 8,572.65 and 8,641.13, on turnover of NT$171.20 billion (US$5.63 billion).

The market opened up 0.91 percent as investors were encouraged by better-than- expected auto sales and the private sector's payroll data in the U.S., which lifted Wall Street, the dealers said, adding that follow-through buying continued to boost local financial stocks.
However, right after the index breached the nearest resistance level of 8,600 points, profit-taking set in to compromise the gains, they said.
A total of 2,697 stocks closed up and 1,672 were down with 346 remaining unchanged.

The financial sector scored the largest gains, up 1.3 percent. Machinery and electronic stocks rose 0.9 percent, foodstuffs added 0.5 percent, textile shares gained 0.3 percent and the cement sector closed up 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemicals rose 0.1 percent, while paper and pulp stocks closed unchanged and construction shares fell 0.3 percent.

"After political uncertainty was removed following the Nov. 27 municipality elections, institutional investors resumed buying, targeting market bargains, in particular financial stocks, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
"Investors are upbeat that the government will forge closer business ties with China in the sixth round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations" scheduled for later this month, Chiang said.
He said that as the financial sector has been consolidating for a long time, its valuation appears very attractive.
"I do not think interest in financial shares will quickly fade, as many of them have large property assets whose value is expected to rise on higher domestic demand," he said.
However, the market is likely to encounter more pressure ahead of the 8,600-point level in the short term before making another breakthrough, Chiang said.

In the financial sector, Hua Nan Financial gained 4.76 percent to end at NT$22.00, First Financial rose 4.59 percent to finish at NT$22.80, and Chang Hwa Bank added 3.23 percent to close the day at NT$22.35.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. rose 2.48 percent to NT$66.20 after the company forecast that the wafer foundry industry will grow 14 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: I didn't play up Lien shooting: Taichung mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 17:16:46 (By Lee Hsi-chang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, who was re-elected by a small margin last week, said Thursday he had not played up -- much less taken advantage of -- a shooting incident on the eve of the municipal elections.

Hu told the media that when he first learned of the shooting of Sean Lien, son of Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, his impression was that Lien had suffered a head injury while stumping for Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.
As the information was sketchy, Hu said, he immediately asked his supporters at his own rally in Taichung to pray for Lien and he called off the gathering ahead of the 10:00 p.m. schedule.
"I don't think anyone can fault me for my actions at that time, and I can assure you no one was trying to take advantage of the incident," he said.
He said he acted restrained upon hearing the news.
"If I had any intentions of using the incident, I would have extended my campaign rally until 11: 00 p.m. and played up the tragic events in Taipei to produce a different result," Hu said.
Hu, who knows the Liens well,0 won a third term with a margin of just over 30,000 votes, or about 2 percent more than his Democratic Progressive Party challenger Su Jia-chyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president begins serving corruption sentences
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 17:26:50 (By Pien chin-feng, Chiu Chin-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian was moved from a detention center on the outskirts of Taipei to a regular prison in neighboring Taoyuan County Thursday to begin serving his corruption sentences.

The transfer followed a November decision by the Supreme Court to uphold Chen's convictions in two high-profile bribery cases involving a land deal in Lungtan, Taoyuan County and the appointment of a chairwoman of Taipei 101 tower.

The Supreme Court sentenced Chen to a total of 19 years in prison for the two bribery charges Nov. 11 in the first final verdict in a string of corruption cases implicating him and his wife, Wu Shu-jen.
Chen -- the first president from the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- is the first former president of the Republic of China to be imprisoned for graft.

The disgraced former president had an emotional meeting with his son Chen Chih- chung Thursday as he awaited his transfer from the Tucheng Detention Center to the Taipei Prison in Gueishan, Taoyuan County.

Chen Chih-chung, who himself is pursuing a political career following his election as a member of the city council of the southern port city of Kaohsiung last weekend, said after emerging from the meeting that his father was very worried about his wife's health.
The wheelchair-bound former first lady was also given a combined 19-year prison sentence for her roles in the two bribery cases, but it remains unclear when she will begin serving her time.

Judicial authorities said previously that they will decide after receiving her conviction documents at which prison in the Kaohsiung area she should be confined or whether to grant her probation on medical grounds.

Dozens of supporters gathered outside the prison, chanting "A-Bian is not guilty" and "A-Bian Go Go, " referring to the former president by his nickname and protesting his conviction. Some held up placards proclaiming that Taiwan is an independent county separate from China, in support of Chen's political cause.

In its Nov. 11 ruling, the Supreme Court also sent three other graft cases involving the former first couple to the Taiwan High court for retrial -- embezzling state funds, laundering money and taking bribes in connection with the Nangang Exhibition Hall construction project.
Chen's office issued a statement Thursday blasting his convictions as "politically motivated" and accused the pro-China Kuomintang administration of interfering in the court proceedings.
The office also announced the establishment of a panel to continue promoting Taiwan's de jure independence and insisting on Chen's innocence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fund tracking Shanghai stocks to list Dec 8
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 18:12:08 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The W.I.S.E. SSE 50 China Tracker exchange traded fund (ETF) , which tracks 50 stocks listed in Shanghai, is scheduled to list on the main board Dec. 8, the Taiwan Stock Exchange said Thursday.

The SSE 50 China Tracker fund was registered in Hong Kong in April 2009 and has been listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, with BOCI- Prudential Asset Management Ltd. serving as the fund's manager. Taiwan-based KGI Securities has been appointed as a trustee of the fund.

With the listing, the new fund will become the 15th ETF and the third offshore ETF to be listed on the TWSE. The first two offshore ETFs on the main board were the Hang Seng H-Share Index ETF and Heng Seng Index ETF.

The fund will be the first foreign ETF in Taiwan to track the performance of the 50 largest cap A shares listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. The 50 stocks are the constituents of the SSE 50 Index, which is the largest and most liquid index launched by the Shanghai Stock Exchange, the TWSE said.

As the 50 stocks account for more than 70 percent of the Shanghai Stock Exchange's capitalization, they can generally reflect the operations of the bellwether and most influential enterprises listed in the Shanghai stock market, it added.

The 10 largest stocks in the fund include Ping An Insurance Group Co. of China Ltd., China Merchants Bank Co. Ltd., Bank of Communications Co Ltd., China Minsheng Banking Corp. Ltd., Industrial Bank Co. Ltd., and CITIC Securities Co. Ltd.

There will be no 7 percent daily upward and downward limits set for the fund in the local bourse as stipulated for other stocks on the main board since that particular stock has been listed in Hong Kong, a market without such limitations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 18:16:05 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.064 to close at NT$NT$30.788.
Turnover totaled US$557 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.852, and moved between NT$30.325 and NT$30.860 before the close.
Foreign investors kept moving funds into the local market, further shoring up the New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
Momentum in the local stock market further boosted buying in the local currency, with many foreign banks standing on the buy side throughout the trading session, they said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.77 percent at 8,585.77 after a 1.76 percent surge posted a day earlier.
Taiwan's central bank intervened in late trade again to slow the pace of appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar in a bid to protect the island's exports, the dealers said.
Dealers said that as political tension on the Korean peninsula and concern over the debt problems in Europe remain in place, the market is expected to be mindful of these factors in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to promote smart green architecture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 18:35:25 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government will funnel NT$3.2 billion into the development of smart green architecture over the period 2010 - 2015, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.
In line with this policy, from 2012 the government will require that all new public buildings constructed at more than NT$50 million adopt smart green architectural designs.

The project is expected to attract NT$28.4 billion in private investment, create 243,000 jobs and generate output of NT$752.9 billion by the related sectors, the MOI said in a report presented in a weekly Cabinet meeting.
In addition, the project will help reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the country by 3.82 million tons, the report said.
Under the project, various measures will be introduced, targeting the residential, service and industrial sectors.

The developments in the residential sector will include a home energy management system and a smart electricity consumption control system. Incentives and subsidies will also be offered to encourage improvement of existing residential buildings.

In the service sector, a green store rating and certification program will be launched next year, targeting the country's approximately 9,000 convenience stores that consume a total of 1.5 billion kilowatt-hours of power per year.
An evaluation and certification system for green factories will also be introduced in the industrial sector, according to the MOI.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT head: Ex-president betrayed friendship if irregularities true
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 18:44:37 (By Kalvan Huang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt referred Thursday to remarks he made in California 18 months ago that he would count former President Chen Shui-bian's alleged irregularities, if true, as a betrayal of the friendship between them.

Burghardt, who had earlier in the day called on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, was commenting to the press on the removal that day of Chen from the Taipei Detention Center, where he had been held since late 2009, to the Taipei Prison to serve a 19-year jail term.

"In a speech in California, I was asked about my feelings about President Chen going to jail, and what I said was that, as someone who had been his friend, if it was true... that he did what they said he did, then I felt that our friendship had been betrayed," Burghardt said.

Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, were each sentenced to 19-year jail terms by the Supreme Court last month for taking bribes in a land acquisition deal and the appointment of the chairwoman of the Taipei 101 Building.
The former first couple are also facing trial in various courts on other charges, including embezzlement of state funds, money laundering and corruption.

Burghardt established a friendship with Chen during his term as director of AIT's Taipei Office between 1999 and 2001, while Chen was elected to power first in 2000 and again in 2004. The AIT Taipei Office head is the de facto U.S. ambassador in Taiwan in the absence of official ties between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businessmen's safety paramount in cross-strait talks: lawmakers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:07:38 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The safety of Taiwanese businessmen in China should be ensured and protected in the proposed agreements that are scheduled to be signed in upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks later this month, lawmakers said Thursday.

Text should be included in a proposed investment protection agreement Taiwan hopes to sign with China later this month, along with a medical cooperation agreement, to ensure China upholds two international human rights covenants it has signed, lawmakers on the Economics Committee proposed in a draft resolution.

"The safety of Taiwanese businessmen in China can be guaranteed only if Chinese law enforcement is in line with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights it has signed, " said Pan Meng-an, a legislator of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during an interpellation session.

Statistics of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which is charged with dealing with matters concerning Taiwan's exchanges with China, show that 2,250 of 3,969 complaints filed by China-based Taiwanese businessmen from 1991 to October 2010 were related to personal safety. The number was more than the 1,719 complaints filed in connection with trade disputes.
Among the 2,250 safety-related cases, 649 Taiwanese nationals were detained, 396 were reported missing and 103 were killed.

Legislators expressed concern ahead of the sixth round of cross-strait talks, which reportedly will be held Dec. 16-17 in Taipei. Despite the assurances of government officials present at the interpellation session, including Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang and Mainland Affairs Council Deputy Chairman Kao Charng, that the protection of Taiwanese nationals is the government's priority, they said that it will be difficult to include this demand in the agreement.
"Taiwan wants the Chinese authorities to handle trade disputes in the spirit of the two international covenants, but investment protection agreements usually do not cover this field, " Shih said.

Compared with investment protection, safety protection is even more urgent for the bilateral negotiation agenda because Taiwanese businessmen have been complaining about the issue for years, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Wu Ching-chih said, adding that some businessmen have had to flee China in the dead of night to avoid being illegally detained by Chinese law enforcement authorities.
However, Ting Shou-chung, also a KMT legislator, warned that if Taiwan insists on including the safety aspect in the text of the agreement, the negotiations could collapse.
"In any case, China does not abide by international covenants, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computer industry summit opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:17:41 (By Stacey Wu and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Asian-Oceanian Computing Industry Organization Summit (ASOCIO ICT Summit) is being held in Taipei for the first time in 16 years, the organizers said Thursday.
The two-day meeting has drawn a record number of participants from 21 member states, said the Information Service Industry Association of the ROC.
Taiwan has been chosen as the host in recognition of its achievements in developing the ICT industry, President Ma Ying-jeou said at the opening ceremony.
Taiwan's hardware manufacturers have impressed the world with their integration of global sources, Ma said.
The software industry should focus on deepening regional integration and creating high added value products in an effort to make Taiwan a global manufacturing hub, he said.
The signing of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement with China in June has paved the way for Taiwan to take center stage internationally, Ma said.

In an effort to boost industrial innovation, the president said, the government is focusing on six emerging industries in the tourism, medical, energy, biotech, cultural and agricultural sectors to help create a better investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Dec. 2 (1I)

TEXT.P: head

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity hospital launches medical tourism program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:31:43 (By Andrew Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien, eastern Taiwan launched a medical tourism program Thursday in a bid to become a regional player as Taiwan seeks to expand its tourism industry.
The hospital, the largest medical center in eastern Taiwan, said it has decided to collaborate with travel agencies to introduce medical tourism packages for visitors from home and abroad.

The hospital will put together several packages to meet the needs of tourists, including fast affordable checkups, high-technology diagnostics, plastic surgery, and micro-plastic surgery, said Hsu Wen-lin, the hospital's vice president.

Tsai Shih-tzu, director of the hospital's Preventive Medicine Center, said more and more people are taking the approach that "an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, " and are having health checks as the best form of prevention.
In addition, Tsai said, an increasing number of people are seeking to improve their appearance and lives through plastic surgery or micro plastic surgery.
"Medical tourism packages can meet these people's needs, " he added.

Meanwhile, Hsu Hsiang-ming, director of the Hualien County Government Department of Health, noted that Thailand, Singapore, South Korea and India have all been aggressively promoting medical tourism and have generated commendably high values of business.
Taiwan's tourism and medical resources are by no means inferior to those countries' and it would be regrettable if Taiwan decided to sit idly by and not develop its medical tourism, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film on immigrant social activism to be released Saturday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:36:15 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Holding the microphone tightly with both hands, Yadrung Chiou's voice resonated throughout the entire room as she gave her usual rallying cry -- "sisters, let us stand up and don't be afraid."
Although small in stature, Chiou is seen as giant when it comes to fighting for the rights of immigrants, especially other women like her from Southeast Asian countries married to Taiwanese men.

"We have to stand up proud and strong so people can hear our voices. Don't be afraid to speak out and fight for your rights,"said the slightly built Chiou, a social activist who came to Taiwan from Thailand 12 years ago as the bride of a Taiwanese man.

Speaking at a press conference to promote the release of a film "Let's Not Be Afraid," Chiou said the 47-minute documentary is the first in the country produced entirely by the members of the TransAsia Sisters Association (TASAT).

The film, which took nearly 15 years to complete, chronicles the personal experiences of so-called "foreign brides" and their struggle over the last decade to transform from voiceless victims into powerful activists.
Some of the footage was shot in 2007 when a TASAT group took to the streets in protest against what it said was the inherently discriminatory staffing of the National Immigration Agency (NIA).
The group said that the NIA's staffing of 70 percent policemen implied that the agency needed a strong police presence to deal with matters pertaining to immigrants.

Throughout the years, the group has also lodged numerous protests against government regulations such as the one requiring immigrant wives to provide proof of substantial financial assets before they can apply for a residency permit and thus seek employment.

TASTAT Director Phayao Su, who is also a "Thai-wanese" said the documentary demonstrates the courage and hard work of immigrant woman in Taiwan as well as the love and acceptance they are given by their families.
"At first, I cried tears of sadness because of the prejudice against me. But now, I am crying because I am so moved by the strong love the (TASTAT) sisters have for each other," she said.
With the help of the office of an internationally famous movie director Hou Hsiao-hsien, the women filmed, edited, and produced the documentary on their own.
Hou said he was impressed with the group's tenacity and determination to get the job done.
Taiwan would be a much better place if everyone had the same follow-through zeal as the TASTAT sisters, he said.
The Chinese title of the film is "Sister, mai dong gua" which in Mandarin translates as "sell winter melons" but in Thai means "don't be afraid."

The documentary will be shown Saturday night at SPOT Taipei Film House at 6: 00 p.m. and will be followed by a seminar on various immigration issues. The panelists will include professors and members of TASAT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of generals to be cut by 101: defense minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:38:49 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The number of generals in the military will be trimmed by 101 by early 2015, Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu said Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan's National Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee, Kao said that the country now has 393 generals out of a total of some 200,000 military personnel and that the number will be reduced to 292 in line with a government effort to streamline the armed forces.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang questioned why Taiwan maintains a higher ratio of generals to total military officers than the United Sates, saying the ratio is 0.76 percent in Taiwan at present, compared to 0.43 percent in the U.S. in 2007.

Kao said in response that the 101 generals to be trimmed are all under the jurisdiction of his ministry and that "there is still room" for a further reduction in the number of high-ranking officers, as many generals work for other agencies, including the Presidential Office, the Coast Guard Administration, the National Security Bureau and the Education Ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier rules out dissolution of National Stabilization Fund
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 19:53:25 (By Chou Yung-chieh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Sean C. Chen on Thursday ruled out the possibility of dissolving the National Stabilization Fund in the wake of its recent retreat from the stock market.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chen said the fund was set up with the aim of " helping to maintain a stable stock market" rather than earning money.
The fund is like the "fire extinguisher" in a building -- it must be in place even if there is no blaze at the moment, he said.

Operators of the fund purchased a total of around NT$60 billion (US$1.9 billion) worth of shares on the local stock market between September and December in 2008 when the global financial crisis hit, he noted.

A recovering economy and booming stock market have prompted the operators to sell the stocks from the beginning of this year, Chen said. So far all of the stocks have been released on the market, earning NT$31.9 billion (US$1.1 billion), he added.
If the NT$1.8 billion in dividends from the stocks is included, the investment- return rate will be as high as 56 percent, Chen said.
The government has been closely monitoring the European debt crisis and the situation on the Korean Peninsula and will reactivate the stabilization fund if necessary, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mozart music helps improve epilepsy in children: study
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 20:19:05 (By Hsia Nien-tse and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Listening to Mozart's piano concertos for eight minutes a day can reduce the frequency of seizures in young epilepsy patients by 30 percent, a study here shows.

The study, carried out by Kaohsiung Medical University (KMU) in collaboration with scholars at National Sun Yat-sen University's music department, examined the effects of Mozart's music on epilepsy children 17 years old and under.

Lin Chang-lung, a child neurologist at KMU Hospital and a member of the research team, said brain wave tests on 58 epilepsy patients in the age group showed that the frequency of abnormally excited electrical signals in the brain dropped an average of 30 percent in 47 of them, after listening to eight minutes of Mozart's piano concerto K448.
In a second-phase test over a longer period, it was found that the longer the music healing lasted, the better its healing effects on the patients.
"Six months would be the best time span for music healing, " Lin said.

In a third-phase test, 18 patients with a high frequency of seizures or convulsions were found to have experienced a whopping 53 percent reduction in frequency after a long period of music healing, Lin said.

Yang Jui-cheng, another team member and child neurology expert at KMU Hospital, said the study found that in addition to "markedly improving" epilepsy in children, the music can also help to reduce patients' medication dosage and side effects.

In fact, he said, foreign studies have shown that music can help cure Parkinson disease, dementia, strokes, sleeping disorders and attention deficiency syndrome, and has a good record of improving patients' quality of life.
In 1993, a medical journal reported that college students who took an IQ test after listening to Mozart's piano concerto K448 had scored eight or nine points higher than usual, Lin said.
Lin said his team's research will be published in "Epilepsy Research," a well- known medical journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Key shooting witness absence did not hurt probe: police

TEXT.P: Police investigators said Thursday that the brief disappearance of a key witness in the election-eve shooting of aruling Kuomintang (KMT) official's son will not affect their probe.
Tu Yi-kai, campaign manager for Xinbei City Council candidate Chen Hung-yuan, became a hot news item after he left for Shanghai Wednesday with police consent, returning the following day.
Sean Lien, son of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, was shot in the head while stumping for Chen at a campaign rally Nov. 26. The gunman, Lin Cheng-wei, was arrested on the spot.
Police found that the gunman called Tu three times before going up on the campaign stage and shooting Lien at close range. Tu thus has become a key witness in the case.
Tu's departure from Taiwan was seen by some as an attempt to flee to China, and opposition lawmakers demanded an explanation from the government.
Kuan Bi-ling, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), speculated that Tu might have gone to China to "bury evidence" and that he might not even be safe in China.
She said she did not know whether police investigators were incompetent or had purposely let Tu go and she demanded that the government officials responsible step down for botching the probe.
DPP spokesman Lin You-chang, describing Tu's exit from Taiwan as "incredible, " also demanded an explanation from the judicial authorities, as well as from the KMT.
Hardly had the opposition politicians finished lodging their complaints, however, than Tu returned to a crowd of reporters at the Taoyuan International Airport.
Tu immediately complained about some media reports that he was asked by the suspect to appear at the police station soon after the shooting and to hire a lawyer for the shooter.
"Such reports are nonsense! " said Tu, who insisted that he had received police approval before leaving for Shanghai.
The police investigation has found that Tu and Lin know each other but are not close friends.
The investigation results also show that Lin did call Tu three times prior to shooting Lien, but that Tu did not take any of the calls.
Police were also focusing their efforts to find out who provided Lin with the weapon used to commit the crime. (By Johnson Sun, Bien Chin-feng, Justin Su, Sophia Yeh and S.C. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Ford to launch four new models in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 20:27:03 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Ford Motor said Thursday it is planning to launch four new models in the Taiwan market over the next three years on expectations that the local auto market will continue to grow steadily.

With domestic demand rising on Taiwan's economic rebound, vehicle sales on the island in 2010 will rise to about 330,000 units from the 290,000 units recorded last year, said Ford Lio Ho Motor Co. Ltd., the Taiwan subsidiary of the U.S. auto maker.
Ford Lio Ho rolled out its 2 millionth car in Taiwan Thursday after 38 years in business.
The company is a joint venture with the Lio Ho Group and is 70 percent owned by Ford Motor. It was set up in 1972 and has become one of Ford Motor's important overseas production bases, it said.

In a ceremony to unveil the 2 millionth car, Joe Hinrichs, Ford Motor Group Vice President and President for Asia Pacific and Africa, said buying in the Taiwan auto market is currently strong and is expected to grow further in the future.
The company has announced plans to launch four new models, but Hinrichs declined to disclose any further details.
Hinrichs said sales of Ford's Asia Pacific and African markets in the first 10 months of this year rose 40 percent from a year earlier, with profit hitting US$166 million.
Last year, Ford's Asia Pacific and African division incurred net losses of US$86 million.

However, the Asia Pacific and African regions are expected to serve as a key driver of growth in the global auto market over the next 10 years, with China, India and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations making the most significant contribution to the growth, according to Hinrichs.
This year, in the 10 months to October, Ford's sales in the China market rose 40 percent from a year earlier, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek eying high-end users of tablet PCs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 20:34:29 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: AsusTek Computer Inc. said Thursday that it will launch a tablet computer priced at NT$30,370 (US$1,000) early next year, as part of the world's fifth-largest PC maker's efforts to meet the demand of the high-end market.

The Taiwan-based company will begin selling the 12-inch tablet device running the Windows 7 operating system in the first quarter of 2011, although the local market is not included in the first allocation of units, AsusTek Senior Product Manager Jose Liao told reporters at a press conference.
"Our tablet PCs will be available in Taiwan in March or April next year," Liao said.

At the same press conference, AsusTek announced the launch of a series of lightweight laptops that will be sold during the Dec. 4-12 "ICT Month, " a technology fair in which 350 companies, including giants such as Acer, AsusTek, Sony, HTC and Epson, will be represented.
Many companies are expected to offer discounts to consumers visiting the fair, which has free entry, according to the organizer.

AsusTek expects to sell 13,000 devices at the show, including regular notebooks, netbooks and e-readers, a gain of 30 percent compared to last year's show, said AsusTek Sales General Manager Kevin Lin.

In addition, the company's total shipments of notebooks are forecast to grow by at least 20 percent this year, although the actual number will not be disclosed until closer to the end of the year, Lin noted.

Asked about the notebook prospects in the first quarter of 2011, Lin said they are not bad because of strong demand in the Chinese market. People will begin to spend their money after receiving their traditional "red envelopes, " monetary gifts exchanged during the Lunar New Year holiday, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flora expo specialties commercially available
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:11:34 (By Chen Hung-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Specialties at the Taipei International Flora Expo that showcase Taiwan's floriculture prowess, technological strength and environmental awareness are commercially available as souvenirs, an expo official said Thursday.

Of the specialties, paper-thin flexible speakers developed by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) being used at the popular Pavilion of Dreams have been probably the biggest draw for expo goers.

The speakers -- basically a sandwich of paper and metal filled with an electro- active polymer that contracts and expands with an audio signal's electric field -- have been a research program of the ITRI since 2006 and was used and displayed for the first time at the expo.

At 22 cm by 18 cm, the units available for expo visitors as souvenirs are about half the size of those displayed at the Pavilion of Dreams, according to the company in charge of marketing the product.
The speakers, which can be connected to an MP3 player or an iPhone, cost NT$1,980 (US$66) per set of two.
Another hot attraction at the expo -- "eternal flowers" made of genuine cut flowers -- is also available as a souvenir.

Bouquets of roses, dendrobium and hydrangea arranged with baby's breath have been processed using a quick freeze-drying technology and are available with all their vivid freshness that will last forever, according to the official.
Other sought-after souvenir items include thermo drink bottles, expo passports and bracelets.
In related news, 4.31 million admission tickets had been sold as of Thursday, nearly one month after the expo's official Nov. 6 opening, according to Ting Hsi-yung, the expo's general producer.
Total revenues had reached NT$820 million as of that day, with some NT$200 million coming from the sale of food, beverages, farm products and souvenirs, Ting said.
The number of souvenir items exceeds 1,500 and is expected to be increased to 2,000 in the near future, he added.

The Taipei International Flora Expo 2010 -- which has not only added much needed color to the capital city's environment but has also solidified Taiwan's place as the world's "flower kingdom" -- is scheduled to run until April 25, 2011.

It is home to 14 pavilions and more than 800 varieties of orchids, 329 million stems of locally developed plant varieties, from impatiens and bamboo to bonsai trees, as well as award-winning landscape and gardening designs from 22 countries and 26 cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ridership doubles after `crystal cars' added to Maokong Gondola
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:22:07 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Ridership of the Maokong Gondola has doubled in the past month after the introduction of 30 glass-floored cabins, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday during a visit to the scenic Maokong area.
The "Eyes of the Maokong Gondola" cabins have proved overwhelmingly popular among the public, said Hau.
Wearing blue jeans and enjoying tea at a Maokong teahouse, Hau praised the gondola as "the best of its kind in the world. "

He said that among the 7,863 Gondola systems produced by POMA, a world leader in cable-driven lift systems, the Maokong Gondola has been recognized as having the highest availability by the French company's president, Jean Gauthier.
"We will keep working on transport services and urban renewal projects in areas surrounding the gondola to attract more visitors, " Hau said.
The one-way fare of the special cabins, bought at a cost of NT$275,000 (US$9,000) each, is just NT$50.

The Maokong Gondola, which suffered a service hiatus of 18 months until this March due to safety concerns, has provided over 7.58 million rides to tourists since it was inaugurated in 2007, according to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diaries of two Chiangs are public property: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:22:31 (By Lin Szu-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday the diaries of the country's two late presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo -- should be treated as national property in terms of their contents.

"Legally, the diaries are the private assets of the Chiang family, but judging from their contents and from a historical and cultural perspective, they should be regarded as public property," Ma said in response to a media inquiry after attending an international seminar on the Chiang Kai-shek diaries and history of the Republic of China.

Ma's remarks came two days after a row broke out among family members of the Chiang clan over the rights to handle the diaries, which have been kept at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University in San Francisco since 2005.
A granddaughter of Chiang Ching-kuo issued a statement Nov. 30 challenging the right of another relative to sign over the diaries to the U.S. research institute.
Ma said he earnestly hopes that the late presidents' family members can settle their dispute soon so that the invaluable diaries can be published for academic study and public scrutiny.
According to Ma, the dispute arose five years ago and mediatory efforts have so far failed to achieve any positive results.

The 55-volume diaries of Chiang Kai-shek span 1917 through 1972, a period that included a war of resistance against Japanese invasion, a civil war with the Chinese Communists and Chiang's exile to Taiwan and rule over the island.
Chiang Ching-kuo's diaries began in 1939 and ended in 1979, a period during which he succeeded his father, serving as premier and then president of the ROC.

"All those diaries are national treasures. Few political leaders in the world have so patiently and consistently written diaries for such a long time. The diaries should be preserved for academic study, " Ma said.

In a statement issued through the law firm Baker & Mckenzie, Chiang You-mei, the daughter of Chiang Ching-kuo's deceased eldest son, said that Chiang Fang Chih-yi, widow of Chiang Ching-kuo's third son, had acted without the consent of the other legal inheritors of the late presidents' estate when she entrusted the diaries to the Hoover Institution Jan. 10, 2005.
"I will not remain silent on the issue any longer, and will take legal action if necessary," Chiang You-mei stated.
She claimed that Chiang Fang Chih-yi had disregarded the rights of the other inheritors, whom she said, "do not recognize and cannot accept her actions.

Regarding publication of the diaries, Chiang You-mei said most of the inheritors are not opposed to the move, but that the matter of Chiang Fang Chih-yi's unauthorized action must first be resolved in order to avoid any unnecessary trouble in the future.

With Chiang Fang Chih-yi's agreement, the Institute of Modern History under Taiwan's highest research body Academia Sinica originally planned to published part of the diaries of Chiang Kai-shek Thursday. But the plan has been suspended after the inheritance row came into spotlight.
The institute said it will wait until the dispute is resolved to publish the diaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake Ropeway welcomes 3 millionth rider
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:37:09 (By Lin Heng-li and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The Sun Moon Lake Ropeway greeted its 3 millionth rider Thursday, barely one year after its launch.

The operator of the cable car system, located near scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County, congratulated Wu Pei-ju as its 3 millionth passenger when she swiped her ticket through the turnstile.

Wu, a real state broker from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, said while being presented with a congratulatory garland that she had been feeling lucky. "I have had a nervous tic in my eyelid for three days, but I didn't expect to win this prize," she said.

Wu also won several prizes provided by the company, including lifetime free admission to the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, free rides for life on the ropeway and one night's accommodation at the five-star Lalu Hotel.

Two other lucky riders were the 2.99 millionth and the 3.01 millionth passengers. Chen Kuei-lan and Chen Kuei-li both won a year's free admission to the aboriginal theme park and a year's-worth of free ropeway rides.

The ropeway has caused tourist arrivals in the area to increased rapidly and it is expected that visitor numbers will break 8 million before the end of the year, according to Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration Director Tseng Kuo-chi.
The 1.877-meter ropeway, which officially began operating in December 2009, is the country's first build-operate-own ropeway system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's health tourism attracting thousands of Chinese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:50:08 (By Kang Shih-ren and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Thousands of Chinese nationals visited Taiwan to have health checkups in the first eight months of this year, taking advantage of the medical tourism offered to Chinese tourists since 2008, a health official said Wednesday.

Tallies show that more than 3,000 Chinese who arrived as part of tour groups received health checkups during their visits to Taiwan in the eight months, said Shih Chung-liang, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the Department of Health, at a conference on cross-Taiwan Strait medicine and healthcare cooperation.
Chinese visitors, attracted by Taiwan's advanced medical skill and equipment, are willing to pay as much as NT$100,000 (US$3,289) for a half-day or full-day medical examination.

Medical tourism has been working out well in terms of Chinese tourists, so is not scheduled to be on the agenda of the next round of talks between the top cross-strait negotiators of the two sides, Shih said.

The new talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin will be held in Taipei by the end of this year, mainly to sign accords on cross-strait medical cooperation and investment protection.

It has become common for Chinese visitors to get medical checkups while here, said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Minister Liu Te-hsun. He added that some China-based Taiwanese businessmen also arrange checkups for their employees when they make trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five noes to prevail in health pact with China: DOH minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:05:09 (By Charles Kang, Ho Meng-kui and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Thursday that China has agreed to his "five noes" principle in the signing of a medical and health cooperation agreement with Taiwan later this month.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang told lawmakers that as long as he is health minister, he will make sure all of the five principles in the cross-strait agreement will prevail, both in letter and in spirit.

The five principles are: that Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to take local exams for licenses; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to practice here; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese investment in building and running hospitals; that Taiwan's national health insurance program will not pay for medical bills incurred by its citizens in Chinese medical facilities; and that the agreement will not contain any provisions regarding joint efforts to educate and cultivate medical professionals.

In spite of Yaung's best efforts to assure lawmakers, however, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Chieh-ju expressed concern that Chinese doctors will end up practicing in Taiwan in the capacity of trainees.

She also voiced worry that Yaung's principles will be abandoned under increasing pressure from China, so that he might be forced to "allow Chinese investment in medical services" in Taiwan and eventually to reimburse medical bills by Taiwanese who receive treatment in Chinese medical facilities.
In response to the opposition lawmaker's concerns, Yaung said the government has strict rules on foreign medical trainees in Taiwan and additional rules that apply to those from China.
"While on a trainee program, they can only watch and cannot lay their hands on medical equipment. If they violate the rules, the host hospitals face heavy fines," he said.
Unimpressed by Yaung's reassurances, Chen asked: "Haven't you said you will leave your current post once the second-generation health reform bill has been passed?"
Yaung denied saying anything to that effect and said he will stay in his post.

The pact, to be signed during the next round of talks between the top negotiators on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait scheduled for mid-December in Taipei, will enable the respective health authorities to alert each other of disease outbreaks and to exchange information on food and drug safety.

Under the proposed agreement, Taiwan and China will also work in concert to study and manage the production and sale of Chinese herbal medicine and to provide emergency medical assistance to each other's visiting nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dust cloud to blanket Taiwan Friday: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:07:35 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A dust cloud sweeping in from China is expected to hit Taiwan Friday and affect air quality, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) warned Thursday.
The dust storm from China will be the first to affect Taiwan this winter, with sand-laden wind arriving along with a cold front that is expected to last until the following day.
Sand particles in the air are expected to reach between 150 micrograms and 250 micrograms per cubic meter, which is three to four times the normal amount, according to the EPA.
"We are now in the dust storm season, " said Chu Yu-chi, director-general of the EPA's environmental monitoring and information management unit.
Dust clouds usually hit Taiwan from November to May, when the strength of the seasonal winds from the northeast reaches its height, Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Premier Lee Huan dies at 95
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:30:44 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Lee Huan died of cardiopulmonary failure at Taipei Veterans General Hospital late Thursday at the age of 95.
The former premier is survived by four children.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua, the second child of the late politician, made the announcement of his father's passing and said the family will hold a simple funeral without a public memorial ceremony, according to his father's wishes.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said President Ma Ying-jeou immediately extended his condolences to Lee's family upon being informed of the death.
Lee was born in China's Hubei Province in 1917 and served as premier from 1989-1990. He also served as minister of education from 1984-1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nationals might not retain Taiwanese pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:54:24 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Washington Nationals might not retain the services of injury-hobbled Taiwanese pitcher Chien-ming Wang any longer, the agency representing Wang said Thursday.

"It seems hard to believe the Nationals will take Wang back, because they have serious interest in free agent Brandon Webb, another pitcher with a serious shoulder injury who has not pitched in a big league game in almost two years, " Lee Wei-chuan, an agent with Octagon Baseball, which represents Wang, quoted a news report on the Nationals official website as indicating Thursday.
Whatever decision is finally made, Octagon Baseball will seek a contract for Wang with a Major League Baseball (MLB) club, Lee said.
The deadline for MLB clubs to spell out whether they are continuing player contracts is noon Dec. 3.

Wang has played only 27 games in the past three seasons because of foot and shoulder injuries, the report said. It quoted a baseball source as saying that Wang will listen to offers from other clubs, but his first choice is to stay with the Nationals.

In a move described as more of a gamble than a purchase by a Washington newspaper, the Nationals signed an incentive-laden one-year deal with the 29 -year-old right-hander in February this year, agreeing to pay Wang a guaranteed US$2 million, with up to US$3.2 million in incentives for the 2010 season.

Among the incentives, Wang would receive US$250,000 if he remained on the Nationals' MLB roster for more than 60 consecutive days and another US$200,000 if he won the Comeback Player of the Year Award.
Wang won more games than any other big league pitcher (38) between 2006 and 2007, but his injuries had limited him to just 27 appearances over the past two years.
In 2009, when he earned US$5 million, Wang was 1-6 with an atrocious 9.64 ERA before being shut down for the season because of his shoulder.
Even prior to the injury, however, Wang's sinker was clearly not as effective as in the past, tailing sideways rather than darting downward, making it much easier for batters to hit.

The Nationals hoped that his woes were simply the result of Wang not being in top shape. He suffered a Lisfranc injury to his right foot in July 2008 and had trouble regaining his fitness level in early 2009 after being told by the New York Yankees -- his previous team -- not to do his typical off-season leg exercises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ming Chuan becomes Asia's first U.S.-accredited university
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 23:02:12 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ming Chuan University (MCU) has received accreditation from the Middle States Commission on Higher Education (MSCHE) to become the first university in Asia to be accredited in the U.S. education system, MCU President Lee Chuan said in a press conference in Taipei Thursday.

Lee explained that the MSCHE, one of six regional accrediting bodies in the U.S., granted MCU the honor Nov. 18 after more than five years of assessment carried out between 2006 and 2010. World-famous universities including Columbia University, New York University and the University of Pennsylvania are accredited by the MSCHE, according to Lee.
"The accreditation serves as a signal that the quality of Taiwan's higher education is now getting positive attention on the international stage," he said.

Lee said the achievement means that the academic degrees and credits taken by MCU students are now acknowledged in all of the 524 MSCHE-accredited universities, increasing the opportunities of MCU students to be accepted in U.S. graduate schools and to find jobs on the global market.
Moreover, U.S. students studying at MCU are able to apply for scholarships and student loans offered by the U.S. government, taking effect from the day MCU was granted accreditation, he said.

Tony Lin, director of the Ministry of Education's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations, noted that the Malaysian government has yet to recognize Taiwan's academic degrees, but said the accreditation might help Malaysia reconsider its decision.

"This is more important than just an educational achievement, " Sheila Paskman, American Institute in Taiwan spokeswoman and chief of the institute's Public Affairs Section, said in the press conference.

"Although we are very excited about the increasing exchanges of students that the new accreditation will bring, we are also excited because this is very important for long-term relations between the U.S and Taiwan, for we will be able to understand more about each other," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ridership doubles after `crystal cars' added to Maokong Gondola
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:22:07 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Ridership of the Maokong Gondola has doubled in the past month after the introduction of 30 glass-floored cabins, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday during a visit to the scenic Maokong area.
The "Eyes of the Maokong Gondola" cabins have proved overwhelmingly popular among the public, said Hau.
Wearing blue jeans and enjoying tea at a Maokong teahouse, Hau praised the gondola as "the best of its kind in the world. "

He said that among the 7,863 Gondola systems produced by POMA, a world leader in cable-driven lift systems, the Maokong Gondola has been recognized as having the highest availability by the French company's president, Jean Gauthier.
"We will keep working on transport services and urban renewal projects in areas surrounding the gondola to attract more visitors, " Hau said.
The one-way fare of the special cabins, bought at a cost of NT$275,000 (US$9,000) each, is just NT$50.

The Maokong Gondola, which suffered a service hiatus of 18 months until this March due to safety concerns, has provided over 7.58 million rides to tourists since it was inaugurated in 2007, according to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diaries of two Chiangs are public property: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:22:31 (By Lin Szu-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday the diaries of the country's two late presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo -- should be treated as national property in terms of their contents.

"Legally, the diaries are the private assets of the Chiang family, but judging from their contents and from a historical and cultural perspective, they should be regarded as public property," Ma said in response to a media inquiry after attending an international seminar on the Chiang Kai-shek diaries and history of the Republic of China.

Ma's remarks came two days after a row broke out among family members of the Chiang clan over the rights to handle the diaries, which have been kept at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University in San Francisco since 2005.
A granddaughter of Chiang Ching-kuo issued a statement Nov. 30 challenging the right of another relative to sign over the diaries to the U.S. research institute.
Ma said he earnestly hopes that the late presidents' family members can settle their dispute soon so that the invaluable diaries can be published for academic study and public scrutiny.
According to Ma, the dispute arose five years ago and mediatory efforts have so far failed to achieve any positive results.

The 55-volume diaries of Chiang Kai-shek span 1917 through 1972, a period that included a war of resistance against Japanese invasion, a civil war with the Chinese Communists and Chiang's exile to Taiwan and rule over the island.
Chiang Ching-kuo's diaries began in 1939 and ended in 1979, a period during which he succeeded his father, serving as premier and then president of the ROC.

"All those diaries are national treasures. Few political leaders in the world have so patiently and consistently written diaries for such a long time. The diaries should be preserved for academic study, " Ma said.

In a statement issued through the law firm Baker & Mckenzie, Chiang You-mei, the daughter of Chiang Ching-kuo's deceased eldest son, said that Chiang Fang Chih-yi, widow of Chiang Ching-kuo's third son, had acted without the consent of the other legal inheritors of the late presidents' estate when she entrusted the diaries to the Hoover Institution Jan. 10, 2005.
"I will not remain silent on the issue any longer, and will take legal action if necessary," Chiang You-mei stated.
She claimed that Chiang Fang Chih-yi had disregarded the rights of the other inheritors, whom she said, "do not recognize and cannot accept her actions.

Regarding publication of the diaries, Chiang You-mei said most of the inheritors are not opposed to the move, but that the matter of Chiang Fang Chih-yi's unauthorized action must first be resolved in order to avoid any unnecessary trouble in the future.

With Chiang Fang Chih-yi's agreement, the Institute of Modern History under Taiwan's highest research body Academia Sinica originally planned to published part of the diaries of Chiang Kai-shek Thursday. But the plan has been suspended after the inheritance row came into spotlight.
The institute said it will wait until the dispute is resolved to publish the diaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake Ropeway welcomes 3 millionth rider
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:37:09 (By Lin Heng-li and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The Sun Moon Lake Ropeway greeted its 3 millionth rider Thursday, barely one year after its launch.

The operator of the cable car system, located near scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County, congratulated Wu Pei-ju as its 3 millionth passenger when she swiped her ticket through the turnstile.

Wu, a real state broker from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, said while being presented with a congratulatory garland that she had been feeling lucky. "I have had a nervous tic in my eyelid for three days, but I didn't expect to win this prize," she said.

Wu also won several prizes provided by the company, including lifetime free admission to the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, free rides for life on the ropeway and one night's accommodation at the five-star Lalu Hotel.

Two other lucky riders were the 2.99 millionth and the 3.01 millionth passengers. Chen Kuei-lan and Chen Kuei-li both won a year's free admission to the aboriginal theme park and a year's-worth of free ropeway rides.

The ropeway has caused tourist arrivals in the area to increased rapidly and it is expected that visitor numbers will break 8 million before the end of the year, according to Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration Director Tseng Kuo-chi.
The 1.877-meter ropeway, which officially began operating in December 2009, is the country's first build-operate-own ropeway system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's health tourism attracting thousands of Chinese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 21:50:08 (By Kang Shih-ren and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Thousands of Chinese nationals visited Taiwan to have health checkups in the first eight months of this year, taking advantage of the medical tourism offered to Chinese tourists since 2008, a health official said Wednesday.

Tallies show that more than 3,000 Chinese who arrived as part of tour groups received health checkups during their visits to Taiwan in the eight months, said Shih Chung-liang, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the Department of Health, at a conference on cross-Taiwan Strait medicine and healthcare cooperation.
Chinese visitors, attracted by Taiwan's advanced medical skill and equipment, are willing to pay as much as NT$100,000 (US$3,289) for a half-day or full-day medical examination.

Medical tourism has been working out well in terms of Chinese tourists, so is not scheduled to be on the agenda of the next round of talks between the top cross-strait negotiators of the two sides, Shih said.

The new talks between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin will be held in Taipei by the end of this year, mainly to sign accords on cross-strait medical cooperation and investment protection.

It has become common for Chinese visitors to get medical checkups while here, said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Minister Liu Te-hsun. He added that some China-based Taiwanese businessmen also arrange checkups for their employees when they make trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five noes to prevail in health pact with China: DOH minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:05:09 (By Charles Kang, Ho Meng-kui and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official said Thursday that China has agreed to his "five noes" principle in the signing of a medical and health cooperation agreement with Taiwan later this month.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang told lawmakers that as long as he is health minister, he will make sure all of the five principles in the cross-strait agreement will prevail, both in letter and in spirit.

The five principles are: that Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to take local exams for licenses; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to practice here; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese investment in building and running hospitals; that Taiwan's national health insurance program will not pay for medical bills incurred by its citizens in Chinese medical facilities; and that the agreement will not contain any provisions regarding joint efforts to educate and cultivate medical professionals.

In spite of Yaung's best efforts to assure lawmakers, however, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Chieh-ju expressed concern that Chinese doctors will end up practicing in Taiwan in the capacity of trainees.

She also voiced worry that Yaung's principles will be abandoned under increasing pressure from China, so that he might be forced to "allow Chinese investment in medical services" in Taiwan and eventually to reimburse medical bills by Taiwanese who receive treatment in Chinese medical facilities.
In response to the opposition lawmaker's concerns, Yaung said the government has strict rules on foreign medical trainees in Taiwan and additional rules that apply to those from China.
"While on a trainee program, they can only watch and cannot lay their hands on medical equipment. If they violate the rules, the host hospitals face heavy fines," he said.
Unimpressed by Yaung's reassurances, Chen asked: "Haven't you said you will leave your current post once the second-generation health reform bill has been passed?"
Yaung denied saying anything to that effect and said he will stay in his post.

The pact, to be signed during the next round of talks between the top negotiators on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait scheduled for mid-December in Taipei, will enable the respective health authorities to alert each other of disease outbreaks and to exchange information on food and drug safety.

Under the proposed agreement, Taiwan and China will also work in concert to study and manage the production and sale of Chinese herbal medicine and to provide emergency medical assistance to each other's visiting nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dust cloud to blanket Taiwan Friday: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:07:35 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A dust cloud sweeping in from China is expected to hit Taiwan Friday and affect air quality, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) warned Thursday.
The dust storm from China will be the first to affect Taiwan this winter, with sand-laden wind arriving along with a cold front that is expected to last until the following day.
Sand particles in the air are expected to reach between 150 micrograms and 250 micrograms per cubic meter, which is three to four times the normal amount, according to the EPA.
"We are now in the dust storm season, " said Chu Yu-chi, director-general of the EPA's environmental monitoring and information management unit.
Dust clouds usually hit Taiwan from November to May, when the strength of the seasonal winds from the northeast reaches its height, Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Premier Lee Huan dies at 95
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:30:44 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Lee Huan died of cardiopulmonary failure at Taipei Veterans General Hospital late Thursday at the age of 95.
The former premier is survived by four children.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua, the second child of the late politician, made the announcement of his father's passing and said the family will hold a simple funeral without a public memorial ceremony, according to his father's wishes.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said President Ma Ying-jeou immediately extended his condolences to Lee's family upon being informed of the death.
Lee was born in China's Hubei Province in 1917 and served as premier from 1989-1990. He also served as minister of education from 1984-1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nationals might not retain Taiwanese pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/10 22:54:24 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Washington Nationals might not retain the services of injury-hobbled Taiwanese pitcher Chien-ming Wang any longer, the agency representing Wang said Thursday.

"It seems hard to believe the Nationals will take Wang back, because they have serious interest in free agent Brandon Webb, another pitcher with a serious shoulder injury who has not pitched in a big league game in almost two years, " Lee Wei-chuan, an agent with Octagon Baseball, which represents Wang, quoted a news report on the Nationals official website as indicating Thursday.
Whatever decision is finally made, Octagon Baseball will seek a contract for Wang with a Major League Baseball (MLB) club, Lee said.
The deadline for MLB clubs to spell out whether they are continuing player contracts is noon Dec. 3.

Wang has played only 27 games in the past three seasons because of foot and shoulder injuries, the report said. It quoted a baseball source as saying that Wang will listen to offers from other clubs, but his first choice is to stay with the Nationals.

In a move described as more of a gamble than a purchase by a Washington newspaper, the Nationals signed an incentive-laden one-year deal with the 29 -year-old right-hander in February this year, agreeing to pay Wang a guaranteed US$2 million, with up to US$3.2 million in incentives for the 2010 season.

Among the incentives, Wang would receive US$250,000 if he remained on the Nationals' MLB roster for more than 60 consecutive days and another US$200,000 if he won the Comeback Player of the Year Award.
Wang won more games than any other big league pitcher (38) between 2006 and 2007, but his injuries had limited him to just 27 appearances over the past two years.
In 2009, when he earned US$5 million, Wang was 1-6 with an atrocious 9.64 ERA before being shut down for the season because of his shoulder.
Even prior to the injury, however, Wang's sinker was clearly not as effective as in the past, tailing sideways rather than darting downward, making it much easier for batters to hit.

The Nationals hoped that his woes were simply the result of Wang not being in top shape. He suffered a Lisfranc injury to his right foot in July 2008 and had trouble regaining his fitness level in early 2009 after being told by the New York Yankees -- his previous team -- not to do his typical off-season leg exercises.
