DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 3, or the 28th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Lessons for Beijing from Taiwan's elections

TEXT.P: Beijing probably has heaved a sigh of relief at the results of Taiwan's recent municipal elections in which the ruling Kuomintang won three of the five mayoral seats up for grabs.

The narrow victory achieved by the China-friendly KMT indicates that the Taiwan people are generally satisfied with President Ma Ying-jeou's conciliatory approach to relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Nevertheless, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), known for its pro-independence policy line, managed to overtake the KMT in the overall vote count.

This indicates that Taiwan's leaders might not be able to maintain their grip on power solely with a correct and effective cross-strait policy. If there is another change in ruling parties, the issues of national identity and cross- strait relations could be at the forefront again.

The problem lies mainly in Beijing's denial of the Republic of China's existence as a sovereign state and its relentless suppression of the ROC's international profile. The stronger Beijing's oppressive moves, the higher the pro- independence sentiment in Taiwan. This is why even though President Ma's modus vivendi approach has improved Taiwan's status at home and abroad, many people still feel the DPP's pro-independence policy could serve as a safety valve in Taiwan's engagement with China.

We earnestly hope the Chinese leadership will carefully assess the outcome of Taiwan's latest elections and recognize the ROC as "an equal part of China." Only when the ROC gains a dignified status in the world can the people of Taiwan abandon the desire to build another independent country. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 3, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: A-bian's fall from grace

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian began serving his long prison sentences Thursday, making history as the first former head of state in Taiwan to be jailed for corruption.
Chen's spectacular fall from grace highlights the merits of the democratic system. It also serves as a good reference in studies on democracy.
Official corruption has had a long history in traditional Chinese political culture. In the past, most Taiwanese people did not regard political graft as a serious crime.

However, after two years of heated rhetoric by politicians and sensational reporting in the media, more people have come to realize that political graft should not be taken for granted and corrupt officials should not be excused.
The case of A-bian (Chen's nickname) has served to strengthen Taiwan's democratic system and rule of law.
We hope A-bian will do some soul searching while he is behind bars and will write an objective memoir of his eight years in office. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 3, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai plans to issue NT$12 billion bonds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 12:20:45 (Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd., the world's largest contract electronic maker, said Friday it is planning to issue up to NT$12 billion (US$395 million) in unsecured company bonds.
Hon Hai said its board has approved the bond sale as part of efforts to boost the company's working capital.
In October, the high tech firm issued US$1 billion-worth of overseas convertible bonds to buy production materials.
"Hon Hai needs funds to further expand its operations, in particular in China," Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.
Expansion is necessary as the company expects to raise its sales by 10-20 percent per year," Miao said.
Miao said Hon Hai is relocating its production facilities from Shenzhen on the coast to inland Chinese areas, such as the Henan province, where labor costs are relatively lower.

According to market observers, Hon Hai has secured a large number of orders from Apple and the funds raised from the bond sale will be used to boost production capacity at its facilities in inland China to meet demand from Apple.

In addition, they said, the company is preparing to set up a comprehensive retail network on the mainland in a bid to offset the impact from a squeezed profit margin in the manufacturing sector due to fierce competition in the global market.
Hon Hai said the bond sales will be also used to repay its short term debts.
According to Grand Cathay Securities, Hon Hai had about NT$160 billion in short term debts as of the end of the third quarter.
Miao said despite its big short term debt, Hon Hai is still financially healthy as it is capable of generating massive revenue every year.
In 2009, Hon Hai posted NT$1.42 trillion in sales on a consolidated basis, the highest among all Taiwan enterprises.
"I expect that it will be easy for Hon Hai to raise the NT$12 billion fund through the bond sales as investors are upbeat about the company's outlook," Miao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment promotion group to visit Guangdong next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 12:48:33 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A delegation to be assembled by the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) will visit Guangdong Province in southern China next week with the aim of seeking investment, organizers said Friday.
CNFI Secretary General Tsai Lien-sheng said he will head the delegation, which is scheduled to depart on Nov. 7 for Guangzhou and Shenzhen.
Other members of the delegation will include officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and Hsinchu County government and representatives from some CNFI member companies, he said.
The delegation will hold a workshop in Shenzhen on Nov. 11 to present Taiwan's policy on Chinese investment, he said.
Lin Chih-hsiang, secretary-general of an association in Taiwan that deals with Chinese investment and procurement services, said that it will be the first such visit to Shenzhen by MOEA officials.

The trip is part of an effort to implement the landmark Economic Framework Cooperation Agreement that was signed between Taiwan and China in June to boost bilateral exchanges in the investment and trade sectors, he said.
Businesses in Guangdong are seen as more willing to explore new overseas markets than those in other parts of China, Lin said.
He suggested that the government invite more Guangdong entrepreneurs to Taiwan to do business.

The CNFI is a nonprofit organization comprising 152 member associations in several manufacturing industries in Taiwan. Together, the associations represent more than 100,000 industrial companies in the country, according to the CNFI website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Ex-president Chen begins serving term

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian began serving his prison sentence Thursday for corruption during his time in office, making history as Taiwan's first former head of state to be jailed.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:
Chen was escorted under tight security Thursday from a detention center in Taipei County, where he had been held for 734 days, to a regular prison in Taoyuan County.
Dozens of supporters of the former political star gathered outside the detention center and the prison, shouting "A-bian is innocent" and "A-bian take care."

Although Chen has been deprived of the privileges for a former head of state, the Ministry of Justice has accorded him special treatment with regard to the prison arrangements, in light of his status as a former president.

First, he was not handcuffed or shackled during the trip from the detention center to the prison. Second, he was not required to carry his belongings himself as other prisoners do, but bailiffs were assigned to carry them for him. (Dec. 3, 2010).
United Daily News:
From this day, Chen will be identified by his inmate serial number "1020, " instead of his name. However, he seems unable to shed his status as a former president.

When asked by a prison officer about his past experience -- a routine question aimed at arranging suitable work for inmates -- Chen replied, "I have served as president " and said his field of expertise is "administration."

Chen appeared calm during his first day in prison and ate all the food he was served for his first dinner there. The meal consisted of rice, stew ribs with herbs, fried dwarf beans, tofu miso soup and coconut tart.

It was arranged that he would share a 1.2 ping (3.96 square meter) cell with another inmate. Prison officials said Chen's cellmate is a fraud convict with a mild temperament and no political inclinations. The officials promised that the man "will not lose his temper" even if Chen frets every day.
According to sources familiar with prison affairs, the man was carefully selected to help take care of the former president and help him adapt quickly to prison life. (Dec. 3, 2010).
Liberty Times:

A senior judge said Chen's time in prison will probably amount to 17 years. This was calculated based on a 10-percent reduction of Chen's total 19-year sentence for accepting bribes in the Lungtan land deal and the appointment of a chairman of the Taipei Financial Center Corp. The time he spent in the detention center can also be set off against the sentences.
Chen's wheelchair-bound wife, Wu Shu-jen, who was also sentenced to a combined 19 years in the same cases, will likely be ordered next week to report to prosecutors in preparation for imprisonment.
In an interview with Era News, former Vice President Annette Lu said that Thursday marked the most embarrassing and miserable point in Chen's life.
She said Chen's imprisonment was a tragedy for him, his family, and Taiwan's democracy. It is worth pondering why a former two-term president who was highly popular has ended up in jail, she said.
She argued that even if Chen was at fault, he should not have been made to take all the blame. (Dec. 3, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Visa processing time in L.A. shortened for overseas PRC nationals
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/10 13:55:21 (By Leaf Chiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Los Angeles has shortened the visa processing time for overseas Chinese nationals intending to visit Taiwan, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles said Thursday.

The new service -- currently being provided on a trial basis before it is expanded to other U.S. cities -- allows eligible applicants to obtain entry permits to Taiwan within 10 days of their submission date, compared with the usual three to four weeks.
The targets of the program are holders of People's Republic of China passports who have lived overseas for a year or who hold permanent resident status or student visas in a foreign country.

According to Liu Wen-chang, a TECO immigration clerk, the service has received a good response since it was launched Nov. 8, with many people coming from other nearby U.S. cities to submit their applications with the office.
The opportunity to obtain a visa quickly is especially valuable for time- sensitive business travelers, Liu pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Giga Solar tops Asia-Pacific high-tech ranking: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 14:00:31 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Giga Solar Materials Corp., a Taiwan-based provider of conductive materials for solar cells, topped the Deloitte Technology Fast500 Asia-Pacific 2010 ranking due to its significant sales growth, the accounting firm said Friday.
According to Deloitte, Giga Solar posted a 24,694-percent increase in sales for 2009 compared with 2007, the highest growth among the 500 Asia-Pacific high-tech firms surveyed.
In addition, Taiwan's Microview Technology Corp. a flat panel module OEM service provider, and Young Fast Optoelectronics Co. Ltd., which produces touch panels, ranked in the top 20 rankings.
Microview's 2009 sales rose 1,877 percent from 2007, while Young Fast witnessed its 2009 sales grow 1,773 percent from 2007.
Deloitte said a total of 86 Taiwanese high-tech companies are included among the top 500 enterprises in the survey, down 99 from 2009.

However, the 86 Taiwanese firms enjoyed an average growth of 498 percent in sales from 2007 to 2009, higher than the average increase of 377 percent over the 2006-2008 period, according to the accounting firm.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's 498 percent growth was also higher than the average increase of 322 percent among the 500 firms in the Asia-Pacific region, it added.

The survey shows that the CEOs of the 86 Taiwanese companies had mixed sentiments about the outlook for the global high-tech sector over the next year, while the CEOs of the 147 Chinese counterparts among the 500 firms showed optimism.
The Taiwanese and Chinese executives cited rising raw material prices as a concern for the future development of the global high-tech industry in the coming year.
It was Deloitte's ninth annual survey on the topic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.44 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 16:09:13 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.44 percent Friday, led by high-tech stocks, as investors witnessed strong overnight performances by their counterparts in the United States, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 38.24 points to 8,624.01, after moving between 8,618.26 and 8,659.62, on turnover of NT$158.25 billion (US$5.21 billion).
The market opened up 0.53 percent after a surge on the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index overnight, with buying focused on IC and related large-cap stocks, the dealers said.
However, profit-taking emerged to drag down old-economy stocks and erode the gains after the market moved to the day's high, they said.
A total of 2,079 stocks closed up and 2,195 were down, with 354 remaining unchanged.
The machinery and electronics sector scored the highest gains, up 1.2 percent, while plastics and chemicals closed up 0.1 percent.
Affected by the profit-taking, construction stocks fell 2.0 percent, paper and pulp shares lost 1.0 percent, foodstuffs shed 0.9 percent and textiles lost 0.8 percent.
Both the cement and financial sectors closed down 0.3 percent.
"It seems that sentiment toward the global foundry business improved to some extent after a strong showing by the U.S. semiconductor sector," TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.
Shih said the IC sector had previously been overshadowed by pessimism that demand for IC and related products would weaken in the fourth quarter.
"It turns out that global demand appears better than expected. An upbeat mood has triggered buying at home and abroad," Shih said.
Earlier in the week, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. forecast that the foundry industry is likely to grow 14 percent next year.
TSMC rose 3.17 percent to NT$68.30 and rival United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) gained 1.86 percent to NT$16.40. TSMC and UMC are the world's top two contract chip makers.
However, Shih said after the market breached the key 8,600-point level, technical pressure accumulated, prompting many investors to stay on the sidelines.
"Investors had better exercise caution at the moment," he said.
Among the property developers, Prince Housing shed 2.65 percent to NT$25.70 and Cathay Real Estate fell 2.49 percent to close at NT$17.65.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government studying ways to tax property profiteering
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 16:27:29 (By Lin Ye-fong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is studying measures to levy land transaction taxes on real estate that changes hands several times within a year, in an effort to stem profiteering in the housing market, MOF officials said Friday.
The ministry is considering drafting a law to regulate and permit such a tax, which will not apply to real estate purchased for self-use, the officials said.

The government was prompted to try harder to crack down on rampant profiteering in the real estate market after a housing unit of the Hung Sheng Treasure Palace residential complex on Renai Road in downtown Taipei was sold at an astronomical price of NT$206 million (US$6.79 million) per ping (3.3 square meters) during a foreclosure auction Nov. 30.
Treasure Palace is one of the most expensive residential complexes in the capital and home to many celebrities.

The deal is, however, almost tax-free, with the government able to obtain just NT$72,000 from the housing tax based on the housing unit's publicly assessed land value, which is just NT$6 million, according to a report by the United Daily Evening News on Wednesday.
MOF officials explained Friday that under the existing income tax laws, the capital gains from land transactions are tax-free, and that the government only levies taxes on land value increment.

Furthermore, under the existing regulations, an assessment of the land value is renewed once a year. If a plot of land changes hands many times within a year, the new owners do not have to pay the land value appreciation tax because the land value is still at the same level, the officials said.
"This means tax-free for all land transactions," they said.
This phenomenon indirectly encourages profiteering trading, the officials added.
Vice Premier Sean Chen has revealed that in principle, the government will levy taxes on real estate "trading" rather than on purchases of real estate for personal use in the future.

Meanwhile, asked about media reports Friday that said the MOF will levy a so- called "windfall profit tax" of as high as 30 percent on transactions for real estate that is purchased and sold within one year, MOFA officials denied that the ministry is planning to impose such a high tax.
If new taxes are levied, their target will be land speculators, not those who buy houses to live in themselves, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Several Silicon Valley firms express interest in Taiwan OTC listings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 16:55:28 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Several firms in California's Silicon Valley have expressed interest in listings on Taiwan's over-the-counter (OTC) market, the GreTai Securities Market (GTSM) said Friday.
A delegation organized by the GTSM, which operates the OTC market, and the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) are visiting the U.S. high-tech hub to encourage firms there to go public in Taiwan.

The delegation conducted two roadshows in Silicon Valley Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 to brief U.S. attendees about Taiwan's business environment and regulations related to fundraising and listings by foreign companies, the GTSM said.
It said the two conferences received a warm response, with attendance by more than 100 representatives from Silicon Valley firms.
In addition to the roadshows, the GTSM delegates also visited nine Silicon Valley companies in the biotech, electronics, Internet and communications sectors.
According to the GTSM, several companies expressed interest in listing on the OTC market.

It is the third consecutive year the GTSM has organized roadshows in Silicon Valley to attract high-tech firms there to list in Taiwan, as the TWSE has an ambition of transforming itself into a tech-heavy NASDAQ-like market in the region.
The TWSE said that due to the presence to boost Taiwan's international visibility, Silicon Valley already has a better understanding of the local capital market.
The delegation is scheduled to conclude its visit Friday and to return to Taiwan the following Monday, the GTSM said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animal protection activists press for ban on seal oil
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 17:22:47 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Animal protection activists again urged the government Friday to ban the import and sale of seal oil in Taiwan to help stop the slaughter of the marine mammal.
The Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) has since April been promoting a campaign calling for the boycotting of seal and sea lion products.

The drive has succeeded in getting the products off the shelves of retail chains including Cosmed, Watsons, Pxmart and Wellcome. The online health product seller Holy Dot Com has also stopped supplying the products, EAST officials said in a news conference held in Taipei Friday.
However, the products are still being sold by online retailers including Momo Shop, ETmall and PChome Online, they said.

Rebecca Aldworth, executive director of the Canada chapter of Humane Society International, noted at the news conference that the United States, European Union, Mexico and Croatia have all banned imports of seal oil and she expressed hope that Taiwan will follow suit.
With Canada's annual seal hunt set to kick off in four months, imposing the ban will allow Taiwan to contribute to seal protection, Aldworth said.
According to EAST, Taiwan is the fourth-largest market for Canadian seal products. From 2003 to 2009, it imported 431,364 kg of seal oil, an amount requiring the killing of 120,000 seals.
In a shocking video shown at the news conference, a Canadian hunter was seen bludgeoning a defenseless seal pup with a cudgel before throwing the dying animal onto a boat.

A Council of Agriculture (COA) official said an EAST-backed petition calling for the ban on seal oil has been signed by 160,000 people. After the petition is submitted to the COA, the council will consider the proposal and notify the Bureau of Foreign Trade of any decision made, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 17:39:52 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.043 to close at NT$30.745.
Turnover totaled US$740 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.788 and moved between NT$30.290 and NT$30.815 before the close.

Dealers said that as foreign institutional investors moved more funds into Taiwan, hunting for high-tech bargains on the stock market, the New Taiwan dollar got further support against the U.S. dollar in the local foreign exchange market.
The benchmark weighted index rose 0.44 percent to 8,624.01.

A weaker greenback against other Asian currencies in the region amid lingering concerns over the debt problems in Europe added downward pressure on the U.S. currency in the local market, dealers said.

Anticipating that the weakness of the U.S. dollar against the local currency will continue, foreign banks kept cutting their greenback positions in the local market, driving the currency to fall to the day's low, they said.

The central bank stepped in again in late trading to buy into the U.S. currency, boosting its value above NT$30.50 in its continued efforts to prevent a rapid appreciation of the local currency and protect Taiwan's exports, they added.
The dealers said the market is expected to remain quiet in thin trading, despite the New Taiwan dollar's strength, as many foreign traders leave the trading floor for the upcoming Christmas holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to unveil first locally produced cycle for disabled
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 18:21:42 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A government-funded research center based in central Taiwan will unveil the country's first cycle especially designed for people with physical disabilities Saturday, after which it will donate 10 prototypes of the machine to local charities.
The three-wheeled tricycle is powered not with the feet but with the hands and users can carry crutches or walking sticks on the bike, according to the Cycling and Health Tech Industry R&D Center.
"When the bike is not in motion, the user can apply a safety brake to stop it from rolling away, " the Taichung-based center said in a statement.
"The bike can also go backward to allow greater flexibility in parking and general maneuverability," it said.
The center created the cycle, named "Freedom, " to help people with disabilities take part in the increasingly popular trend of cycling.

"Although I am physically disabled, I actually also want to come out and enjoy the sunshine and the natural environment (by riding a bicycle), " said Chen Jen- hao, one of the first members of the public to road-test the Freedom.
"I think it would be great if such cycles can be widely available for rental at local tourist attractions," he added.
In Taiwan, there are more than 1 million people with physical and mental disabilities.

The prototype, which the center said has passed safety tests, is the result of a one-year research project funded by the Ministry of Economic Affair's Department of Industrial Technology with NT$10 million (US$330,000).
A number of companies have expressed interest in the cycle, but so far, there is no finalized project for mass production, the center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX to hit 10,000 points by next Oct. 10: Morgan Stanley
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 18:48:05 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange Index (TAIEX) is expected to hit 10,000 points before the Republic of China's next national day Oct. 10, 2011 as its economy has entered a "super cycle" that will extend over the next decade, Morgan Stanley said Friday.

In a research report, Morgan Stanley said that over the next 10 years, Taiwan will aim at creating a "golden decade" by forging closer business ties with China and positioning itself to become a greater China research and development center.

On his second anniversary in office in May this year, President Ma Ying-jeou of the China-friendly ruling Kuomintang outlined his vision of a "golden decade" for Taiwan's economic development through innovation, culture and environmental protection.
Ma has also promised to enhance social welfare and promote peace with China to protect the nation.
The government "should stay market-friendly with more cross-strait policies coinciding with a global economic recovery ahead of the 2012 presidential election," the brokerage said.
Morgan Stanley said the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) means growth and is "a starting point to drive growth for cross-strait trade."
The ECFA Taiwan and China signed in late June has become effective, granting preferential tariff status and easy market access to 539 items of Taiwanese products and services.

According to the brokerage, on the improving cross-strait relations, Taiwan is expected to generate "peace dividends" and "demographic dividends" and to see many opportunities coming from China's growth.
"We believe our 2011 TAIEX target will be realized by National Day 2011 on capital repatriation with increased confidence," it said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.44 percent at 8,624.01 Friday.
Morgan Stanley said that with more and more Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, the local retail, property and tourism sectors are expected to enjoy booming business.

Among the brokerage's top picks are AU Optronics., Acer, Epistar, Richtek Technology, Ralink, WPG Holdings, President Chain Store, Yulon Motor, Huaku Development, Taiwan Fertilizer, Cathay Financial and Yuanta Financial.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese doctor writes book about Yemen experience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:34:34 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The first Taiwanese doctor to work with the humanitarian organization Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has published a book that documents his experience serving in a war-torn Middle East country.
The book, which was launched in Taiwan Friday, is titled "The Route Home" and features the 45-day journey of surgeon Raymond Soong to Yemen on an MSF mission.
Soong, 35, was a general surgeon at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Keelung when he decided in August 2009 to team up with MSF, also known as Doctors Without Borders, on a Yemen mission.
During his period of service in the war-torn state, he performed dozens of operations on patients injured in air raids and bombardments.
"I have always thought that I need to travel to far away places to really help people, " said Soong, who signed up for his first MSF mission in Liberia in 2004.
At the book launch, Soong's father, who is also a doctor, spoke with pride of his son's contribution.

"Although my son was not trained as an orthopedist or a gynecologist, he had to operate with whatever resources he had, using courage and wisdom, " said Soong Yung-kuei, Vice President of Linkou Medical Center. "This is experience that cannot be gained in medical school."
Jeffrey Chih-fu Chen, a doctor with 15-some years experience in mobile medical missions, said decisions such as the one Soong made could make a huge difference to people in conflict zones.
"It doesn't make much of a difference if we have one doctor less in Taiwan, but it is a matter of life and death for people in war-hit areas," he said.

Although there is a huge demand for doctors in MSF, there are only two Taiwanese doctors, including Raymond Soong, who are registered as MSF volunteers, according to MSF Hong Kong, which is responsible for medical recruitments in East Asia.
Raymond Soong said that there are many reasons why the participation rate in Taiwan is low compared with other countries.
"Many Taiwanese doctors have the dream and passion to work with MSF, but some hospitals are unable to guarantee them their positions when they return," he said.
Two other factors are family responsibilities and the high professional standards required by MSF, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seeking election-eve shooting mastermind: interior minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:44:35 (By Kuang Juei-ping, Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The most important task in case of the Nov. 26 election-eve shooting that caused one death and injured a former vice president's son is to find out whether there is a mastermind behind the incident, the minister of the interior said Friday.

The investigation should focus on determining "whether there is an individual mastermind or a ring behind the perpetrator, " since prosecutors have obtained concrete evidence on the shooting thanks to the arrest of the assailant on the spot and the seizing of the murder weapon, Jiang Yi-huah told reporters.
Asked whether there is a deadline for solving the case, Jiang said there is no deadline, but spelled out the government's hope that investigators will uncover the truth as soon as possible.
Sean Lien, the son of former Vice President Lien Chan, was shot in the face while stumping for a city councilor candidate during a campaign rally in Xinbei City on the eve of the municipal elections.
Lien is in stable condition at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , but a bystander who was also shot in the head died of injuries soon after the incident.
NTUH said Friday that Lien is recovering and that his facial nerves are functioning normally.
The gunman's bullet pierced the left side of Lien's face and exited near his right temple, causing fractures of his cheekbones and two open wounds.
The shooting had a great impact on the fairness of the elections and on social order, Jiang said, pledging reinforced efforts to prevent possible election- related violence in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forex reserves shrink more than US$4 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:49:45 (By Kao Chao-fen and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$379.26 billion in November, which marked the first drop since November 2008, the central bank announced Friday.
The nation's foreign exchange reserves were down US$4.58 billion at the end of November from the month-earlier figure, according to the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan).
Depreciation of the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar contributed to the decrease, the bank said.
Despite the drop, however, the nation's foreign exchange reserves were still fourth-highest in the world, behind only China, Japan and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Tourist taxis' expected to help foreign visitors: travel agency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:58:32 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A total of 100 tourist taxis in eight urban areas of Taiwan are offering foreign travelers another choice for experiencing the country through customized travel routes, a local travel agency said Friday.

The organizer of the service, ezTravel, said its cooperative venture with local taxi companies launched that day will benefit in particular backpackers from China once the authorities give a green light to entry to Taiwan by independent travelers.

Currently, Chinese tourists are only allowed to travel in Taiwan as part of a tour group. In an interview in July, however, Premier Wu Den-yih said the additional opening measures will take effect late this year or early in 2011, to coincide with the Lantern Festival.
"We are expecting two-thirds of our future clients to be Chinese," said Jack You, CEO of the agency.

He said the 36 designated sightseeing routes connect with major traffic systems such as the Taiwan High Speed Railway and the regular rail network operated by the Taiwan Railway Administration to make traveling more convenient.
In the initial stage, You said, contracted taxi drivers will guide tourists around cities such as Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung at an hourly rate.
A four-hour trip in Taipei City, for example, costs NT$2,500 (US$82).
The travel model is expected to draw 400,000 tourists over two years and to generate NT$1 billion in revenue, You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hungarian museums to host works by Taiwanese artists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 20:16:03 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The works of Taiwanese artists will reach a wider audience in Eastern Europe when an exhibition titled "Taiwan Calling" opens in two Hungarian museums later this month, the organizer announced at a press conference in Taipei Friday.

According to the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts (NTMFA), the main organizer, 44 works by 25 local artists, covering painting, video and installation art, were chosen to be displayed in two separate exhibitions at the Mucsarnok museum and in the Ludwig Museum, both in the Hungarian capital of Budapest.

Viewers will see two different displays. The one in the Mucsarnok, running from Dec. 17-Feb. 13 next year, will feature 24 pieces centered more on how Taiwanese artists see themselves and on Taiwan society and identity, while in the Ludwig, 20 pieces will show the multi-faceted Taiwan that is undergoing massive change in the fields of history, society, race, politics and culture.
The Ludwig exhibition also opens Dec. 17, but will remain on view until March 6, 2011.

Huang Tsai-Lang, director of the NTMFA, said in the press conference that the Muscarnok and Ludwig museums are two of the most important contemporary museums in Eastern Europe and that he hopes the exhibition will bring more exchange opportunities between Taiwanese and European artists.

In addition to Chang Chien-chi and Yuan Guang-min, who have already established themselves in international art circles, he said the works of the younger generation in the two exhibitions account for the majority of the exhibits, which he said show the diversity and vitality of Taiwan's art scene.

Mia Liu, an emerging artist, will present five works made of admission tickets to the Guggenheim Museum. She said the idea of using the tickets to create art was born when she studied in New York two years ago, during which she had a part-time job and worked as a ticket-seller at the famed museum.
She bought 120,000 unused tickets from the Guggenheim before she quit her job, and turned what is normally trivial into intricate paper artworks.
Tsui Kuang-yu, who has contributed four video works, said that as an artist, he keeps asking questions and is continuously in search of finding a way to express "the invisible."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic human rights decline in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 20:51:46 (By Tang Hsiao-tien and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: More than half of the respondents to a recent poll described themselves as satisfied with human rights in Taiwan, seeing progress in the rights of women and indigenous people, but feeling that their economic and judicial human rights have declined, according to the survey results released Friday.

The Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) conducted the survey from September through November this year, collecting 1,084 effective samples on their views of the human rights situation in 11 areas, including politics, judicial affairs, women, children, indigenous people, the disabled, the environment and economics.
In addition, the association gathered opinions from 180 scholars and academics on the same questions.
The survey found that 66.8 percent of the respondents gave a negative evaluation of their economic rights, the highest ratio among all the negative views.

Of the three questions in the economic rights category, "government role and economic human rights" got a lower score than last year, while "consumer rights" and "production and employment" were given better grades than in last year's survey.

Professor Chu Mei-li of National Chengchi University said most scholars also give a minus score for the government's role in protecting people's economic rights, and she further said it is time that the government put forward a viable economic policy to address people's worries.

Another area that received poor comments was the judicial category, with 44.9 percent of those surveyed saying people's judicial human rights have declined compared with last year and only 24.6 percent feeling that they have improved.
Chen Jung-chuan, professor of law at National Taipei University, said that although people can feel the government's determination to reform the judiciary, its efforts still got negative comments.

He cited for example that jailed former President Chen Shui-bian is incarcerated in a 1.2-ping (one ping is equal to 3.3 square meters) cell with another jailbird, which he said shows that there is a shortage of prison facilities.
About half of the respondents gave a positive comment on their political rights, while the other half gave exactly the opposite view, indicating the polarized nature of the country's politics.
All other areas, such as labor, culture and education, and senior citizens, received overall positive comments.
The CAHR was set up in 1979 to secure, facilitate and promote human rights based on the respect of their values acknowledged in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: China may jump ahead Taiwan to publish Chiang diaries: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:02:21 (By Lin Szu-yu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: China may jump ahead of Taiwan to publish late President Chiang Kai-shek's diaries as his descendants have yet to reach aconsensus over who has the right to authorize the use of the historical documents, scholars said Friday.

Chinese scholars are known to have been copying Chiang's diaries at the Hoover Institution of Stanford University and, according to a professor of history at National Chengchi University, Liu Wei-kai, if China has organized a "group effort, " it could publish what its scholars have handcopied from the U.S. ahead of Taiwan.

Without coordination over this matter, Liu said Taiwan may lose its advantage in the research of modern Chinese history, Liu said. "If mainland China wins over the right to interpret history, Taiwan may be further marginalized," he said.

Huang Ke-wu, director of the Institute of Modern History of Academia Sinica, agreed, saying if the research community here cannot have an easy access to the historical materials, "how can we fight an academic warfare?"
He urged the government to get the Chiang house in order and publish the late president's diaries quickly, so that local students will be able to use the historical data more conveniently.
The academic circle here has called for an early publication of Chiang Kai- shek's diaries, but Chiang's offsprings could not reach a consensus on the right to authorize.

Starting in 2006, Hoover Institution opened the microfilms of the diaries to the academic community on the condition that students can only use pencils to copy the text or key in their notebook computers.

It's naturally not an easy task for individual scholars to copy so many volumes of the diaries. And yet Chinese scholars have gone to California in groups, some staying as long as three months on a single visit, just to get as much of the content as they could.

DOC.HEADLINE: Task force formed to monitor Wikileaks documents: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:04:08 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A special task force has been established by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to monitor Taiwan-related documents expected to be released soon by the whistle-blowing website Wikileaks, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang told CNA Friday.
"We have been in close contacts with the United States and we believe that the leaked classified documents will not jeopardize bilateral relations, " Yang said.

Wikileaks announced on its website that over the next few months, it will release in stages 251,287 cables originating from 274 U.S. embassies between Dec. 28, 1966 to Feb. 28, 2010 of the total 3,456 that were sent between the U.S. State Department and the American Institute in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. representative office in Taiwan.
The MOFA has set up a task force under its Department of North American Affairs which has held meetings since last week to gauge and manage possible impacts of Wikileaks' release, Yang said.
Yang declined to comment on the authenticity of the documents, though Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu has said in the legislature that information unveiled by the website "was not necessarily true."
It would be more appropriate to let the U.S. make comments on the case, given that those hacked documents were U.S. government properties, Yang said.

According to Kao, a special task force under the Ministry of National Defense headed by Vice Minister Andrew Yang has been set up to follow future leaks by the website and analyze and verify any details that were related to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human rights museum to open in 2012
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:16:42 (By C. W. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A national human rights museum under the planned ministry of culture is scheduled to open on Jan. 1, 2012, Council for Cultural Affairs Chairman Emile Sheng said Friday.

According to Sheng, two major historical sites related to the development of Taiwan's democracy and human rights -- Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park in suburban Taipei and the outlying Green Island Human Rights Memorial Park -- will be made part of the "human rights museum" under the jurisdiction of the future ministry of culture.

"Although Taiwan has made noticeable progress in politics, the country has not made an organized effort to promote education in human rights and the museum will be established to serve that end, " he explained.
"The major purpose of the museum is to increase the people's awareness of human rights," he said.

Before being turned into a memorial facility, the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park was used to be called Jingmei Detention Center, where political prisoners were detained during the White Terror era in Taiwan, while convicted political inmates were kept on the Green Island off Taitung County.

The Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park is currently overseen by the council's Headquarters Administration of Cultural Heritage, and the Green Island park is under the management of the National Taitung Living Art Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrochemical developers promise to protect dolphins
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:19:26 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Developers of a controversial naphtha cracking plant in central Taiwan made concessions Friday by promising to establish exclusive agencies and funds for the protection of endangered dolphins, other wildlife and the environment, as well as residents' health.

The promises, however, were not met favorably by environmental activists and wildlife conservationists, who insisted that the development project of Taiwan's eighth naphtha cracker by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. (KPTC) in Changhua County must stop.

KPTC Chairman Chen Pao-lang promised during a preliminary environmental impact assessment meeting at the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) in Taipei that day that KPTC will establish a foundation exclusively for the protection of Taiwan's indigenous pink dolphins, which are facing extinction, and their natural habitat.

Chen also pledged to initially allocate NT$100 million (US$3.33 million) as a fund to finance environmental protection in the area in which KPTC hopes to locate the naphtha cracker complex and to pay for health insurance for residents living in the immediate vicinity of the proposed petrochemical complex.
Chen, said, however, that it is unrealistic for the protesters to demand that the foundations of the proposed naphtha cracker and a seaport be built 10 meters off the coast.

He argued that moving the project's foundation 10 meters offshore would increase the development cost by at least NT$190 billion and prolong the development period to 15 to 20 years -- an over-long development period that would deal a fatal blow to the pink dolphins in the area.

Rebutting Chen, Lee Pei-fen, professor and director of the Institute of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology under National Taiwan University, said KPTC was wrong in the first place to choose the location -- a 200-hectare stretch of wetland at the mouth of the Jhuoshuei River that is also home to the pink dolphins, whose population is believed to number fewer than 100.
Saying that pushing the naphtha cracker's base -- to be built on reclaimed land -- 10 meters further offshore is technically feasible, she questioned why KPTC deems the idea "unrealistic."

Meanwhile, Tsai Chia-yang, chairman of the Changhua Coast Conservation Action, said the development project will not only destroy the dolphins' migration route and their habitat, it will also pose a threat to the migratory Euroasian curlew (Numenius arquata), a bird that serves as an index species for wetland ecosystems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT upgrades bike service; opening date of Nangang extension unknown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:48:11 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) officials said Friday that another seven Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) stations will be opened on holidays to bicycles from Dec. 4, adding to the existing 33 stations that allow bicycles.

The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) said that besides Nangang and Qiyan stations, the stations newly opened to bicycles are mostly along the recently inaugurated Luzhou Line -- the Luzhou, St. Ignatius High School, Sanchong Elementary School, Minquan West Road and Songjiang Nanjing stations.
The existing ticket fare for cyclists entering, exiting or transferring on the MRT system is NT$80 (US$2.6).

In another development that day, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said during an inspection of the Nangang eastern extension work at the MRT's Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Station that there is no timetable for the line to begin operating.
"We declined to specify the date as we do not want the construction to be rushed," Hau said.

His remarks appeared to be in stark contrast to the website of the Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS), however, which says that the line is expected to be open for commercial service within the next month.

The transfer service at Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Station has been highly anticipated, as it will connect the Taipei World Trade Centers' venues in suburban Nangang and in downtown Taipei. At present, passengers wishing to travel between the two venues are forced to use a combination of MRT and shuttle bus to make the journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's air quality made worse by dust storm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:53:52 (By Lee Shien-feng, Johnson Sun and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was enveloped by a sandstorm from Mongolia, northern China on Friday, which resulted in an increased amount of particulates in the air, the environment monitoring agency said.

A total of 33 weather stations reported suspended particulates of more than 200 micrograms per cubic meter, about four times the normal amount, according to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

The sandstorm from inner Mongolia has arrived in Taiwan as the northeast monsoon came, said Shen Chih-hsiu, deputy director of the environment monitoring and information management department under the EPA.
The dust, the first wave to have obvious influence on Taiwan this winter, affected Korea and Japan the other day.
The storm, which is expected to move on to southern Taiwan later in the day, will abate after Dec. 4, Shen added.
The dusty air throughout the island is mainly caused by local air pollution, which could not disperse due to the current air conditions, the department said.
Sandstorms from the deserts in northern China usually blow between November to May every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local companies bid for AIG's Taiwan unit (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:15:03 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A number of local companies tendered their bids to buy the Taiwan unit of American International Group (AIG) Friday after the indebted insurance giant vowed to complete a new sale following a failed one earlier this year.

Chinatrust Financial Holding Co.'s "board of directors decided to take part in the bidding for the sale of AIG's 97.57-percent stake in Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., " the would-be buyer said in a statement to the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
The statement did not offer further details.

Ruenchen Investment Holding Co., a new joint venture created by Ruentex Industries Ltd., Ruentex Development Co. and Pou Chen Corp. for the bid, also said in a filing to the stock exchange that they joined the bidding process Friday.
A spokesman for Ruentex refused to give details, citing a confidentiality agreement.
Cathay Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's largest financial services provider, also confirmed its bid for the purchase in a stock exchange statement.

Fubon Financial Holding Co., the country's second largest financial services provider that is widely expected to make a similar move, declined to comment on whether the company tendered its bid Friday.
Both AIG's media contact in Taiwan and Nan Shan's spokeswoman told CNA by telephone that they cannot confirm the total number of companies that have submitted the bid earlier in the day.
In a Nov. 5 statement, AIG said it believed a sale would be completed "within 12 months."

On Aug. 31, Taiwan's regulators rejected the sale of the unit to a Hong Kong consortium comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings, over concerns about the buyer's long-term financial capability and the rights of Nan Shan's workers.

On Nov. 23, Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Pan Meng- an urged Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), the country's top financial regulator, to list the protection of employees' rights as one of the criteria in reviewing the planned sale of Nan Shan.
Wedding Lan, a spokesman for Nan Shan's trade union, has repeatedly urged new bidders to strike a deal with the trade union over the protection of employees' rights.
Lan is a former Nan Shan executive who was demoted to sales agent earlier this year for "speaking to the press about Nan Shan without the prior consent of the company."
Lan told the CNA that none of the companies that openly identified themselves as bidders had approached the trade union.
He said, however, that another bidder had promised the trade union that it will ensure the workers' rights if it wins the bid. But Lan said he was not authorized to identify the bidder.
Local news reports said that AIG will hold a second round of bidding after this round to choose between two final bidders before unveiling the new buyer in mid- or late December.
The bidding prices range from US$2 billion to US$3 billion, according to the reports.
Established in 1963, Nan Shan has a net worth of NT$140.3 billion (US$4.63 billion), accounting for over one-third of the local life insurance market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Speaker vows to push through health insurance bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:31:05 (By Kelvin Huang, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng vowed Friday to push through a bill next week to facilitate the introduction of a second-generation national health insurance (NHI) premium system.

After lengthy debate, legislators across partisan lines reached a preliminary consensus on the second-generation NHI, agreeing that consultations on the issue should be completed by Dec. 6, paving the way for the line-by-line reading of the bill before putting it to clear the legislative floor the next day.
"Whatever it takes, the bill must be passed into law Dec. 7, " a determined Wang said.
The package of legal amendments proposed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to resuscitate the debt-laden NHI failed to clear the floor of the Legislative Yuan in August.
The legislature has thus set a Dec. 7 deadline for completing the final round of debate on the amendments.
One of the disputes surrounding the second-generation NHI involves its premium system, which was recalculated with the goal of controlling the program's deficit.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said that the lawmakers had reached consensus on most of the clauses in the bill, except for 20 that are still in dispute.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue-ying said the version put forth by the Executive Yuan is not efficient enough to solve disputes.
"Disputes will remain despite the bill's passage by the Kuomintang-dominated Legislative Yuan," Huang said.

The bill mainly involves a new scheme for calculating premiums based on total household income rather than the existing system, which considers only individuals' salaries and wages. The change is considered essential to keep the cash-strapped program operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still unsure about taking taekwondo case to CAS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:45:14 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Almost one week after the 2010 Guangzhou Asiad, Taiwan government could not decide whether to take the case of a controversial disqualification of a Taiwanese female taekwondo athlete in the event to an international sports arbitration institution.

An inter-agency meeting headed by Vice Premier Sean Chen failed to come to a conclusion Friday on whether to appeal to Lausanne-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) about the case of Yang Shu-chun, who was disqualified during her first-round bout in the women's taekwondo under 49-kilogram weight division on Nov. 17 after she scored a 9-0 lead over her Vietnamese opponent.

According to World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) Secretary-General Yang Jin-suk, who did not have any role in the actual decision but served as the main spokesman for the taekwondo world in the incident's aftermath, said Yang was disqualified for wearing extra sensors on her socks in an attempt to score more points, which was an act of cheating.
All video evidence and witness accounts show that Chen had taken off the sensors before going into the ring.

The task force, which included government agencies such as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Justice and the Sports Affairs Council, was still unsure about the CAS' jurisdiction on the case and what remedy it is seeking, said Sung Yao-ming, a lawyer hired by the Taiwan government to handle the case.
The CAS is established to handle sports disputes, but "we should first clarify whether this case fits the definition of a 'sports dispute', " Sung told reporters in a post-meeting press conference.

"We are now waiting for further information from a Swiss-based lawyer who is familiar with sports arbitration matters to have better assessment of our next move, " he said, adding that the decision "should come within days."

However, it appeared that Taiwan is not likely to file a lawsuit against taekwondo officials in a Guangzhou court, a suggestion made by Sung after the incident, which has ignited public outrage and an anti-Korea sentiment in Taiwan and has received coverage from international media.

The controversy was so high-profile that Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih had personally addressed the incident as "unfair" and had described it as damaging Taiwan's national pride.

Citing an interpretation by China's supreme people's court during the 2008 Beijing Olympics stating that the court did not accept sports-related lawsuits, Sung said that a Guangzhou court could reject the case with the same reason.
SAC Chairwoman Tai Hsia-ling said that while Taiwanese fans and Taiwan government could not accept the accusations against Yang, the task force will appeal the case via legal channels.
"We're going to approach this dispute in the same way we were trained on the sports field -- to play it by the rule, " Tai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indian director brings ancient story on stage in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:53:54 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Indian stage director Chongtham Jayanta of the Ex Theatre on Friday presentedNumit Kappain Taipei on Friday, a work adapted from an ancient story which he said showcases how tradition can survive in modern theatres.
Numit Kappa, meaningshooting the sunin the Indian language, is an age-old literary work which dates back to A.D. 32, according to the Indian director.

Jayanta told Central News Agency in an interview that he first read the story when he was a college student and found that the story has a universal appeal, for it deals with power struggle and the suffering of the common people under tyrannical rule.
Comparing good leaders to the sun, he said an orderly society would fall into chaos if there were no good rulers.

Political unrest in Taiwan has nothing to do with the play, because this is not a political drama. All the countries are facing similar problems, and everyone watching the play can relate to it in their own way,he said.
To recreate an atmosphere of the old Indian society, the director incorporated elements of Taiwans aboriginal music and there will be live dances and singing throughout the performance.

Borrowing the form of the classical story, Jayanta said he hoped the audience will be rediscovering the charm of tradition through his approach to modern theatrical forms, for he found that many of the younger generation now feels disconnected with tradition and old values.

Jayanta is considered one of the most promising stage directors in India. He founded the Ex Theatre in Taiwan in 2006.Numit Kappa will have two more showings at the Experimental Theatre on Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Washington Nationals may bring back non-tendered Taiwanese pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 23:11:49 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese baseball pitcher Chien-Ming Wang has become a free agent after the Washington Nationals chose not to offer a new contract to him but might try to keep him at a cheaper price, the U.S. media reported Friday.

The Nationals was more inclined to sign a contract worth less than US$2 million, what they paid Wang this season, or even a Minor League Baseball deal, the online CSNwashington reported. The news of the non-tender was confirmed later by Octagon Baseball, which represents Wang.

In addition to Wang, the team also non-tendered reliever Joel Peralta and catcher Wil Nieves. If the Nationals had tendered the 30-year-old Wang, they would have had to pay him US$1.6 million, the amount Wang could get in arbitration.

Wang will negotiate with other clubs, including the Nationals, said Octagon Baseball. Wang respected the decision and thanked the Nationals for their assistance and support in the past year, it quoted Wang as saying, adding he would continue to train and rehabilitate by himself to return to his best as early as possible.
The former Yankees sink-baller failed to play in the MLB since he injured his shoulder and underwent a surgery last year. He spent all year rehabbing, which made him a not-surprizing non-tender.
Meanwhile, the Los Angeles Dodgers tendered another Taiwanese pitcher Kuo Hong- chih, whose US$950,000 contract could jump to as much as US$2 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX to hit 10,000 points by next Oct. 10: Morgan Stanley
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 18:48:05 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange Index (TAIEX) is expected to hit 10,000 points before the Republic of China's next national day Oct. 10, 2011 as its economy has entered a "super cycle" that will extend over the next decade, Morgan Stanley said Friday.

In a research report, Morgan Stanley said that over the next 10 years, Taiwan will aim at creating a "golden decade" by forging closer business ties with China and positioning itself to become a greater China research and development center.

On his second anniversary in office in May this year, President Ma Ying-jeou of the China-friendly ruling Kuomintang outlined his vision of a "golden decade" for Taiwan's economic development through innovation, culture and environmental protection.
Ma has also promised to enhance social welfare and promote peace with China to protect the nation.
The government "should stay market-friendly with more cross-strait policies coinciding with a global economic recovery ahead of the 2012 presidential election," the brokerage said.
Morgan Stanley said the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) means growth and is "a starting point to drive growth for cross-strait trade."
The ECFA Taiwan and China signed in late June has become effective, granting preferential tariff status and easy market access to 539 items of Taiwanese products and services.

According to the brokerage, on the improving cross-strait relations, Taiwan is expected to generate "peace dividends" and "demographic dividends" and to see many opportunities coming from China's growth.
"We believe our 2011 TAIEX target will be realized by National Day 2011 on capital repatriation with increased confidence," it said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.44 percent at 8,624.01 Friday.
Morgan Stanley said that with more and more Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, the local retail, property and tourism sectors are expected to enjoy booming business.

Among the brokerage's top picks are AU Optronics., Acer, Epistar, Richtek Technology, Ralink, WPG Holdings, President Chain Store, Yulon Motor, Huaku Development, Taiwan Fertilizer, Cathay Financial and Yuanta Financial.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese doctor writes book about Yemen experience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:34:34 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The first Taiwanese doctor to work with the humanitarian organization Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) has published a book that documents his experience serving in a war-torn Middle East country.
The book, which was launched in Taiwan Friday, is titled "The Route Home" and features the 45-day journey of surgeon Raymond Soong to Yemen on an MSF mission.
Soong, 35, was a general surgeon at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Keelung when he decided in August 2009 to team up with MSF, also known as Doctors Without Borders, on a Yemen mission.
During his period of service in the war-torn state, he performed dozens of operations on patients injured in air raids and bombardments.
"I have always thought that I need to travel to far away places to really help people, " said Soong, who signed up for his first MSF mission in Liberia in 2004.
At the book launch, Soong's father, who is also a doctor, spoke with pride of his son's contribution.

"Although my son was not trained as an orthopedist or a gynecologist, he had to operate with whatever resources he had, using courage and wisdom, " said Soong Yung-kuei, Vice President of Linkou Medical Center. "This is experience that cannot be gained in medical school."
Jeffrey Chih-fu Chen, a doctor with 15-some years experience in mobile medical missions, said decisions such as the one Soong made could make a huge difference to people in conflict zones.
"It doesn't make much of a difference if we have one doctor less in Taiwan, but it is a matter of life and death for people in war-hit areas," he said.

Although there is a huge demand for doctors in MSF, there are only two Taiwanese doctors, including Raymond Soong, who are registered as MSF volunteers, according to MSF Hong Kong, which is responsible for medical recruitments in East Asia.
Raymond Soong said that there are many reasons why the participation rate in Taiwan is low compared with other countries.
"Many Taiwanese doctors have the dream and passion to work with MSF, but some hospitals are unable to guarantee them their positions when they return," he said.
Two other factors are family responsibilities and the high professional standards required by MSF, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seeking election-eve shooting mastermind: interior minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:44:35 (By Kuang Juei-ping, Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The most important task in case of the Nov. 26 election-eve shooting that caused one death and injured a former vice president's son is to find out whether there is a mastermind behind the incident, the minister of the interior said Friday.

The investigation should focus on determining "whether there is an individual mastermind or a ring behind the perpetrator, " since prosecutors have obtained concrete evidence on the shooting thanks to the arrest of the assailant on the spot and the seizing of the murder weapon, Jiang Yi-huah told reporters.
Asked whether there is a deadline for solving the case, Jiang said there is no deadline, but spelled out the government's hope that investigators will uncover the truth as soon as possible.
Sean Lien, the son of former Vice President Lien Chan, was shot in the face while stumping for a city councilor candidate during a campaign rally in Xinbei City on the eve of the municipal elections.
Lien is in stable condition at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , but a bystander who was also shot in the head died of injuries soon after the incident.
NTUH said Friday that Lien is recovering and that his facial nerves are functioning normally.
The gunman's bullet pierced the left side of Lien's face and exited near his right temple, causing fractures of his cheekbones and two open wounds.
The shooting had a great impact on the fairness of the elections and on social order, Jiang said, pledging reinforced efforts to prevent possible election- related violence in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forex reserves shrink more than US$4 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:49:45 (By Kao Chao-fen and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$379.26 billion in November, which marked the first drop since November 2008, the central bank announced Friday.
The nation's foreign exchange reserves were down US$4.58 billion at the end of November from the month-earlier figure, according to the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan).
Depreciation of the euro and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar contributed to the decrease, the bank said.
Despite the drop, however, the nation's foreign exchange reserves were still fourth-highest in the world, behind only China, Japan and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Tourist taxis' expected to help foreign visitors: travel agency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 19:58:32 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A total of 100 tourist taxis in eight urban areas of Taiwan are offering foreign travelers another choice for experiencing the country through customized travel routes, a local travel agency said Friday.

The organizer of the service, ezTravel, said its cooperative venture with local taxi companies launched that day will benefit in particular backpackers from China once the authorities give a green light to entry to Taiwan by independent travelers.

Currently, Chinese tourists are only allowed to travel in Taiwan as part of a tour group. In an interview in July, however, Premier Wu Den-yih said the additional opening measures will take effect late this year or early in 2011, to coincide with the Lantern Festival.
"We are expecting two-thirds of our future clients to be Chinese," said Jack You, CEO of the agency.

He said the 36 designated sightseeing routes connect with major traffic systems such as the Taiwan High Speed Railway and the regular rail network operated by the Taiwan Railway Administration to make traveling more convenient.
In the initial stage, You said, contracted taxi drivers will guide tourists around cities such as Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung at an hourly rate.
A four-hour trip in Taipei City, for example, costs NT$2,500 (US$82).
The travel model is expected to draw 400,000 tourists over two years and to generate NT$1 billion in revenue, You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hungarian museums to host works by Taiwanese artists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 20:16:03 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The works of Taiwanese artists will reach a wider audience in Eastern Europe when an exhibition titled "Taiwan Calling" opens in two Hungarian museums later this month, the organizer announced at a press conference in Taipei Friday.

According to the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts (NTMFA), the main organizer, 44 works by 25 local artists, covering painting, video and installation art, were chosen to be displayed in two separate exhibitions at the Mucsarnok museum and in the Ludwig Museum, both in the Hungarian capital of Budapest.

Viewers will see two different displays. The one in the Mucsarnok, running from Dec. 17-Feb. 13 next year, will feature 24 pieces centered more on how Taiwanese artists see themselves and on Taiwan society and identity, while in the Ludwig, 20 pieces will show the multi-faceted Taiwan that is undergoing massive change in the fields of history, society, race, politics and culture.
The Ludwig exhibition also opens Dec. 17, but will remain on view until March 6, 2011.

Huang Tsai-Lang, director of the NTMFA, said in the press conference that the Muscarnok and Ludwig museums are two of the most important contemporary museums in Eastern Europe and that he hopes the exhibition will bring more exchange opportunities between Taiwanese and European artists.

In addition to Chang Chien-chi and Yuan Guang-min, who have already established themselves in international art circles, he said the works of the younger generation in the two exhibitions account for the majority of the exhibits, which he said show the diversity and vitality of Taiwan's art scene.

Mia Liu, an emerging artist, will present five works made of admission tickets to the Guggenheim Museum. She said the idea of using the tickets to create art was born when she studied in New York two years ago, during which she had a part-time job and worked as a ticket-seller at the famed museum.
She bought 120,000 unused tickets from the Guggenheim before she quit her job, and turned what is normally trivial into intricate paper artworks.
Tsui Kuang-yu, who has contributed four video works, said that as an artist, he keeps asking questions and is continuously in search of finding a way to express "the invisible."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic human rights decline in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 20:51:46 (By Tang Hsiao-tien and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: More than half of the respondents to a recent poll described themselves as satisfied with human rights in Taiwan, seeing progress in the rights of women and indigenous people, but feeling that their economic and judicial human rights have declined, according to the survey results released Friday.

The Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) conducted the survey from September through November this year, collecting 1,084 effective samples on their views of the human rights situation in 11 areas, including politics, judicial affairs, women, children, indigenous people, the disabled, the environment and economics.
In addition, the association gathered opinions from 180 scholars and academics on the same questions.
The survey found that 66.8 percent of the respondents gave a negative evaluation of their economic rights, the highest ratio among all the negative views.

Of the three questions in the economic rights category, "government role and economic human rights" got a lower score than last year, while "consumer rights" and "production and employment" were given better grades than in last year's survey.

Professor Chu Mei-li of National Chengchi University said most scholars also give a minus score for the government's role in protecting people's economic rights, and she further said it is time that the government put forward a viable economic policy to address people's worries.

Another area that received poor comments was the judicial category, with 44.9 percent of those surveyed saying people's judicial human rights have declined compared with last year and only 24.6 percent feeling that they have improved.
Chen Jung-chuan, professor of law at National Taipei University, said that although people can feel the government's determination to reform the judiciary, its efforts still got negative comments.

He cited for example that jailed former President Chen Shui-bian is incarcerated in a 1.2-ping (one ping is equal to 3.3 square meters) cell with another jailbird, which he said shows that there is a shortage of prison facilities.
About half of the respondents gave a positive comment on their political rights, while the other half gave exactly the opposite view, indicating the polarized nature of the country's politics.
All other areas, such as labor, culture and education, and senior citizens, received overall positive comments.
The CAHR was set up in 1979 to secure, facilitate and promote human rights based on the respect of their values acknowledged in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: China may jump ahead Taiwan to publish Chiang diaries: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:02:21 (By Lin Szu-yu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: China may jump ahead of Taiwan to publish late President Chiang Kai-shek's diaries as his descendants have yet to reach aconsensus over who has the right to authorize the use of the historical documents, scholars said Friday.

Chinese scholars are known to have been copying Chiang's diaries at the Hoover Institution of Stanford University and, according to a professor of history at National Chengchi University, Liu Wei-kai, if China has organized a "group effort, " it could publish what its scholars have handcopied from the U.S. ahead of Taiwan.

Without coordination over this matter, Liu said Taiwan may lose its advantage in the research of modern Chinese history, Liu said. "If mainland China wins over the right to interpret history, Taiwan may be further marginalized," he said.

Huang Ke-wu, director of the Institute of Modern History of Academia Sinica, agreed, saying if the research community here cannot have an easy access to the historical materials, "how can we fight an academic warfare?"
