He urged the government to get the Chiang house in order and publish the late president's diaries quickly, so that local students will be able to use the historical data more conveniently.
The academic circle here has called for an early publication of Chiang Kai- shek's diaries, but Chiang's offsprings could not reach a consensus on the right to authorize.

Starting in 2006, Hoover Institution opened the microfilms of the diaries to the academic community on the condition that students can only use pencils to copy the text or key in their notebook computers.

It's naturally not an easy task for individual scholars to copy so many volumes of the diaries. And yet Chinese scholars have gone to California in groups, some staying as long as three months on a single visit, just to get as much of the content as they could.

DOC.HEADLINE: Task force formed to monitor Wikileaks documents: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:04:08 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A special task force has been established by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to monitor Taiwan-related documents expected to be released soon by the whistle-blowing website Wikileaks, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang told CNA Friday.
"We have been in close contacts with the United States and we believe that the leaked classified documents will not jeopardize bilateral relations, " Yang said.

Wikileaks announced on its website that over the next few months, it will release in stages 251,287 cables originating from 274 U.S. embassies between Dec. 28, 1966 to Feb. 28, 2010 of the total 3,456 that were sent between the U.S. State Department and the American Institute in Taiwan -- the de facto U.S. representative office in Taiwan.
The MOFA has set up a task force under its Department of North American Affairs which has held meetings since last week to gauge and manage possible impacts of Wikileaks' release, Yang said.
Yang declined to comment on the authenticity of the documents, though Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu has said in the legislature that information unveiled by the website "was not necessarily true."
It would be more appropriate to let the U.S. make comments on the case, given that those hacked documents were U.S. government properties, Yang said.

According to Kao, a special task force under the Ministry of National Defense headed by Vice Minister Andrew Yang has been set up to follow future leaks by the website and analyze and verify any details that were related to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human rights museum to open in 2012
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:16:42 (By C. W. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A national human rights museum under the planned ministry of culture is scheduled to open on Jan. 1, 2012, Council for Cultural Affairs Chairman Emile Sheng said Friday.

According to Sheng, two major historical sites related to the development of Taiwan's democracy and human rights -- Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park in suburban Taipei and the outlying Green Island Human Rights Memorial Park -- will be made part of the "human rights museum" under the jurisdiction of the future ministry of culture.

"Although Taiwan has made noticeable progress in politics, the country has not made an organized effort to promote education in human rights and the museum will be established to serve that end, " he explained.
"The major purpose of the museum is to increase the people's awareness of human rights," he said.

Before being turned into a memorial facility, the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park was used to be called Jingmei Detention Center, where political prisoners were detained during the White Terror era in Taiwan, while convicted political inmates were kept on the Green Island off Taitung County.

The Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park is currently overseen by the council's Headquarters Administration of Cultural Heritage, and the Green Island park is under the management of the National Taitung Living Art Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Petrochemical developers promise to protect dolphins
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:19:26 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Developers of a controversial naphtha cracking plant in central Taiwan made concessions Friday by promising to establish exclusive agencies and funds for the protection of endangered dolphins, other wildlife and the environment, as well as residents' health.

The promises, however, were not met favorably by environmental activists and wildlife conservationists, who insisted that the development project of Taiwan's eighth naphtha cracker by the Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. (KPTC) in Changhua County must stop.

KPTC Chairman Chen Pao-lang promised during a preliminary environmental impact assessment meeting at the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) in Taipei that day that KPTC will establish a foundation exclusively for the protection of Taiwan's indigenous pink dolphins, which are facing extinction, and their natural habitat.

Chen also pledged to initially allocate NT$100 million (US$3.33 million) as a fund to finance environmental protection in the area in which KPTC hopes to locate the naphtha cracker complex and to pay for health insurance for residents living in the immediate vicinity of the proposed petrochemical complex.
Chen, said, however, that it is unrealistic for the protesters to demand that the foundations of the proposed naphtha cracker and a seaport be built 10 meters off the coast.

He argued that moving the project's foundation 10 meters offshore would increase the development cost by at least NT$190 billion and prolong the development period to 15 to 20 years -- an over-long development period that would deal a fatal blow to the pink dolphins in the area.

Rebutting Chen, Lee Pei-fen, professor and director of the Institute of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology under National Taiwan University, said KPTC was wrong in the first place to choose the location -- a 200-hectare stretch of wetland at the mouth of the Jhuoshuei River that is also home to the pink dolphins, whose population is believed to number fewer than 100.
Saying that pushing the naphtha cracker's base -- to be built on reclaimed land -- 10 meters further offshore is technically feasible, she questioned why KPTC deems the idea "unrealistic."

Meanwhile, Tsai Chia-yang, chairman of the Changhua Coast Conservation Action, said the development project will not only destroy the dolphins' migration route and their habitat, it will also pose a threat to the migratory Euroasian curlew (Numenius arquata), a bird that serves as an index species for wetland ecosystems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT upgrades bike service; opening date of Nangang extension unknown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:48:11 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) officials said Friday that another seven Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) stations will be opened on holidays to bicycles from Dec. 4, adding to the existing 33 stations that allow bicycles.

The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) said that besides Nangang and Qiyan stations, the stations newly opened to bicycles are mostly along the recently inaugurated Luzhou Line -- the Luzhou, St. Ignatius High School, Sanchong Elementary School, Minquan West Road and Songjiang Nanjing stations.
The existing ticket fare for cyclists entering, exiting or transferring on the MRT system is NT$80 (US$2.6).

In another development that day, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said during an inspection of the Nangang eastern extension work at the MRT's Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Station that there is no timetable for the line to begin operating.
"We declined to specify the date as we do not want the construction to be rushed," Hau said.

His remarks appeared to be in stark contrast to the website of the Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS), however, which says that the line is expected to be open for commercial service within the next month.

The transfer service at Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Station has been highly anticipated, as it will connect the Taipei World Trade Centers' venues in suburban Nangang and in downtown Taipei. At present, passengers wishing to travel between the two venues are forced to use a combination of MRT and shuttle bus to make the journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's air quality made worse by dust storm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 21:53:52 (By Lee Shien-feng, Johnson Sun and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was enveloped by a sandstorm from Mongolia, northern China on Friday, which resulted in an increased amount of particulates in the air, the environment monitoring agency said.

A total of 33 weather stations reported suspended particulates of more than 200 micrograms per cubic meter, about four times the normal amount, according to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

The sandstorm from inner Mongolia has arrived in Taiwan as the northeast monsoon came, said Shen Chih-hsiu, deputy director of the environment monitoring and information management department under the EPA.
The dust, the first wave to have obvious influence on Taiwan this winter, affected Korea and Japan the other day.
The storm, which is expected to move on to southern Taiwan later in the day, will abate after Dec. 4, Shen added.
The dusty air throughout the island is mainly caused by local air pollution, which could not disperse due to the current air conditions, the department said.
Sandstorms from the deserts in northern China usually blow between November to May every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local companies bid for AIG's Taiwan unit (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:15:03 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A number of local companies tendered their bids to buy the Taiwan unit of American International Group (AIG) Friday after the indebted insurance giant vowed to complete a new sale following a failed one earlier this year.

Chinatrust Financial Holding Co.'s "board of directors decided to take part in the bidding for the sale of AIG's 97.57-percent stake in Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., " the would-be buyer said in a statement to the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
The statement did not offer further details.

Ruenchen Investment Holding Co., a new joint venture created by Ruentex Industries Ltd., Ruentex Development Co. and Pou Chen Corp. for the bid, also said in a filing to the stock exchange that they joined the bidding process Friday.
A spokesman for Ruentex refused to give details, citing a confidentiality agreement.
Cathay Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's largest financial services provider, also confirmed its bid for the purchase in a stock exchange statement.

Fubon Financial Holding Co., the country's second largest financial services provider that is widely expected to make a similar move, declined to comment on whether the company tendered its bid Friday.
Both AIG's media contact in Taiwan and Nan Shan's spokeswoman told CNA by telephone that they cannot confirm the total number of companies that have submitted the bid earlier in the day.
In a Nov. 5 statement, AIG said it believed a sale would be completed "within 12 months."

On Aug. 31, Taiwan's regulators rejected the sale of the unit to a Hong Kong consortium comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings, over concerns about the buyer's long-term financial capability and the rights of Nan Shan's workers.

On Nov. 23, Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Pan Meng- an urged Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), the country's top financial regulator, to list the protection of employees' rights as one of the criteria in reviewing the planned sale of Nan Shan.
Wedding Lan, a spokesman for Nan Shan's trade union, has repeatedly urged new bidders to strike a deal with the trade union over the protection of employees' rights.
Lan is a former Nan Shan executive who was demoted to sales agent earlier this year for "speaking to the press about Nan Shan without the prior consent of the company."
Lan told the CNA that none of the companies that openly identified themselves as bidders had approached the trade union.
He said, however, that another bidder had promised the trade union that it will ensure the workers' rights if it wins the bid. But Lan said he was not authorized to identify the bidder.
Local news reports said that AIG will hold a second round of bidding after this round to choose between two final bidders before unveiling the new buyer in mid- or late December.
The bidding prices range from US$2 billion to US$3 billion, according to the reports.
Established in 1963, Nan Shan has a net worth of NT$140.3 billion (US$4.63 billion), accounting for over one-third of the local life insurance market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Speaker vows to push through health insurance bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:31:05 (By Kelvin Huang, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng vowed Friday to push through a bill next week to facilitate the introduction of a second-generation national health insurance (NHI) premium system.

After lengthy debate, legislators across partisan lines reached a preliminary consensus on the second-generation NHI, agreeing that consultations on the issue should be completed by Dec. 6, paving the way for the line-by-line reading of the bill before putting it to clear the legislative floor the next day.
"Whatever it takes, the bill must be passed into law Dec. 7, " a determined Wang said.
The package of legal amendments proposed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to resuscitate the debt-laden NHI failed to clear the floor of the Legislative Yuan in August.
The legislature has thus set a Dec. 7 deadline for completing the final round of debate on the amendments.
One of the disputes surrounding the second-generation NHI involves its premium system, which was recalculated with the goal of controlling the program's deficit.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said that the lawmakers had reached consensus on most of the clauses in the bill, except for 20 that are still in dispute.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue-ying said the version put forth by the Executive Yuan is not efficient enough to solve disputes.
"Disputes will remain despite the bill's passage by the Kuomintang-dominated Legislative Yuan," Huang said.

The bill mainly involves a new scheme for calculating premiums based on total household income rather than the existing system, which considers only individuals' salaries and wages. The change is considered essential to keep the cash-strapped program operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still unsure about taking taekwondo case to CAS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:45:14 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Almost one week after the 2010 Guangzhou Asiad, Taiwan government could not decide whether to take the case of a controversial disqualification of a Taiwanese female taekwondo athlete in the event to an international sports arbitration institution.

An inter-agency meeting headed by Vice Premier Sean Chen failed to come to a conclusion Friday on whether to appeal to Lausanne-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) about the case of Yang Shu-chun, who was disqualified during her first-round bout in the women's taekwondo under 49-kilogram weight division on Nov. 17 after she scored a 9-0 lead over her Vietnamese opponent.

According to World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) Secretary-General Yang Jin-suk, who did not have any role in the actual decision but served as the main spokesman for the taekwondo world in the incident's aftermath, said Yang was disqualified for wearing extra sensors on her socks in an attempt to score more points, which was an act of cheating.
All video evidence and witness accounts show that Chen had taken off the sensors before going into the ring.

The task force, which included government agencies such as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Justice and the Sports Affairs Council, was still unsure about the CAS' jurisdiction on the case and what remedy it is seeking, said Sung Yao-ming, a lawyer hired by the Taiwan government to handle the case.
The CAS is established to handle sports disputes, but "we should first clarify whether this case fits the definition of a 'sports dispute', " Sung told reporters in a post-meeting press conference.

"We are now waiting for further information from a Swiss-based lawyer who is familiar with sports arbitration matters to have better assessment of our next move, " he said, adding that the decision "should come within days."

However, it appeared that Taiwan is not likely to file a lawsuit against taekwondo officials in a Guangzhou court, a suggestion made by Sung after the incident, which has ignited public outrage and an anti-Korea sentiment in Taiwan and has received coverage from international media.

The controversy was so high-profile that Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih had personally addressed the incident as "unfair" and had described it as damaging Taiwan's national pride.

Citing an interpretation by China's supreme people's court during the 2008 Beijing Olympics stating that the court did not accept sports-related lawsuits, Sung said that a Guangzhou court could reject the case with the same reason.
SAC Chairwoman Tai Hsia-ling said that while Taiwanese fans and Taiwan government could not accept the accusations against Yang, the task force will appeal the case via legal channels.
"We're going to approach this dispute in the same way we were trained on the sports field -- to play it by the rule, " Tai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indian director brings ancient story on stage in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 22:53:54 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Indian stage director Chongtham Jayanta of the Ex Theatre on Friday presentedNumit Kappain Taipei on Friday, a work adapted from an ancient story which he said showcases how tradition can survive in modern theatres.
Numit Kappa, meaningshooting the sunin the Indian language, is an age-old literary work which dates back to A.D. 32, according to the Indian director.

Jayanta told Central News Agency in an interview that he first read the story when he was a college student and found that the story has a universal appeal, for it deals with power struggle and the suffering of the common people under tyrannical rule.
Comparing good leaders to the sun, he said an orderly society would fall into chaos if there were no good rulers.

Political unrest in Taiwan has nothing to do with the play, because this is not a political drama. All the countries are facing similar problems, and everyone watching the play can relate to it in their own way,he said.
To recreate an atmosphere of the old Indian society, the director incorporated elements of Taiwans aboriginal music and there will be live dances and singing throughout the performance.

Borrowing the form of the classical story, Jayanta said he hoped the audience will be rediscovering the charm of tradition through his approach to modern theatrical forms, for he found that many of the younger generation now feels disconnected with tradition and old values.

Jayanta is considered one of the most promising stage directors in India. He founded the Ex Theatre in Taiwan in 2006.Numit Kappa will have two more showings at the Experimental Theatre on Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Washington Nationals may bring back non-tendered Taiwanese pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/10 23:11:49 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese baseball pitcher Chien-Ming Wang has become a free agent after the Washington Nationals chose not to offer a new contract to him but might try to keep him at a cheaper price, the U.S. media reported Friday.

The Nationals was more inclined to sign a contract worth less than US$2 million, what they paid Wang this season, or even a Minor League Baseball deal, the online CSNwashington reported. The news of the non-tender was confirmed later by Octagon Baseball, which represents Wang.

In addition to Wang, the team also non-tendered reliever Joel Peralta and catcher Wil Nieves. If the Nationals had tendered the 30-year-old Wang, they would have had to pay him US$1.6 million, the amount Wang could get in arbitration.

Wang will negotiate with other clubs, including the Nationals, said Octagon Baseball. Wang respected the decision and thanked the Nationals for their assistance and support in the past year, it quoted Wang as saying, adding he would continue to train and rehabilitate by himself to return to his best as early as possible.
The former Yankees sink-baller failed to play in the MLB since he injured his shoulder and underwent a surgery last year. He spent all year rehabbing, which made him a not-surprizing non-tender.
Meanwhile, the Los Angeles Dodgers tendered another Taiwanese pitcher Kuo Hong- chih, whose US$950,000 contract could jump to as much as US$2 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 4, 2010, or the 29th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talks on Taiwan investing in Indonesian island yet to happen: envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 12:07:19 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Recently improved relations between Taiwan and China have enhanced Taiwans trade ties with Indonesia, but no formal talks have been launched on the possibility of Taiwan investing in an Indonesian island, said Andrew Hsia, Taiwans top envoy to Indonesia, last week.

Earlier this year, Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono through his ministers invited Taiwan to invest in Moratai Island, an island one-15th the size of Taiwan, with an area of 2,400 square kilometers on the northern tip of Indonesia.

The proposal was made to Taiwans economics minister Shih Yen-shiang, who led a delegation of over 100 people to Indonesia in October to study the Southeast Asian country's economic and trade environment.

Hsia, who has visited Moratai, said the sparsely populated island of roughly 50,000 people is a prime location for investments in fishery, agriculture, light industry, and tourism because it does not experience typhoons or cold fronts.
Once the former military headquarters for U.S. General Douglas MacArthur during World War II, the remote islet is equipped with a seven-runway airport, which adds to its appeal, Hsia said.
According to some newspaper reports, the deal could be cemented in early 2011. However, Hsia insisted no timeline has been set.

Both sides are carefully evaluating the options. There are still many outstanding issues to be assessed such as what are the collective interests in this project and what mutual benefits might arise from this collaboration, said the former deputy foreign minister, adding that both sides are still mulling over the details.
While crediting warming China-Taiwan relations as a key factor in the improved Taiwan-Indonesia ties, the representative said a formal trade pact with Jakarta still remains in the far distance.
Both sides are very positive about our current trade relationship, but we are still not at a stage where we can even begin to discuss a free trade agreement,he said.

As the largest economy in Southeast Asia, Indonesia has long been viewed favorably by Taiwanese investors, especially after the formation of an ASEAN- China Free Trade Area which went into effect on January 1 this year.
Indonesia is Taiwans 10th largest trade partner. Taiwans investments in Indonesia have amounted to over US$13.9 billion.
Taiwan is also the most popular destination for Indonesian overseas workers due to its higher salary and good benefits, said Hsia.
According to the Council of Labor Affairs, there are around 150,000 Indonesian workers in Taiwan, which accounts for 40 percent of Taiwans foreign labor force.
On a people-to-people level, Taiwan and Indonesia share close ties. Last week, the Indonesia city of Singkawang became a sister city of Taoyuan Countys Yangmei City.

During the initial aftermath of the recent volcanic eruptions in Indonesia's Mount Merapi, Taiwanese compatriots in Indonesia donated blankets, slippers, and T-shirts to the local residents. The combined money donated from the Taiwanese government and Taiwanese public reached over US$370,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Imprisonment based on humanitarian principles

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday began serving his sentence for two corruption cases during his terms in office. He was accorded the same treatment as other prisoners except that he could work and have meals alone and was allowed to share a room with a specially selected inmate with a mild temperament.
Also convicted in the same cases was Chen's wheelchair-bound wife, Wu Shu-jen, who is widely known to be in ailing health.

Authorities must properly arrange her imprisonment based on humanitarian principles. In considering whether Wu could be granted bail for medical reasons or put under home confinement, the authorities do not need to go strictly by the rigid clauses of the law and should not be afraid of making exceptions. After all, this is the country's first imprisonment case involving a former head of state and his wife.

The imprisonment of Chen and Wu is a sad shame for the entire nation. The public should show their sympathy and understanding for the former first lady and allow the authorities greater freedom in dealing with her imprisonment. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 4, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese makers to be No. 1 in non-smartphone handset market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 12:30:08 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Chinese manufacturers of non-smartphones altogether will occupy a bigger market share than Nokia Corp., the world's largest handset maker, for the first time this year, according to a local research firm.
The world will see sales of 1.17 billion non-smartphone units in 2010, with Nokia taking the largest share of 29.4 percent, Digitimes Research forecast Friday.

The company's senior analyst Roger Huang said that if Chinese non-smartphone makers are seen as a collective group, their combined market share, forecast at 34.2 percent, will surpass Nokia's for the first time this year.
He attributed Chinese manufacturers' competitive advantage to their efforts to meet the demands of emerging markets and their ability to turn out low-priced products with good specifications.
In 2011, global shipments of handsets that are not smartphones are likely to reach 1.11 billion units, down 5 percent from this year due to the growth of smartphones, the research company noted.

In terms of companies, Nokia will remain in top place next year with a 29.7 percent market share, while the total market share of Chinese makers will hit a higher 34.8 percent, according to the research firm.

Samsung Electronics will come in second place with a 19.8 percent market share predicted for 2011, down from 20.5 percent in 2010; and LG Electronics will enjoy a 10.1 percent market share, up from 9.9 percent in 2010.

Huang added that Chinese handset makers, Nokia, Samsung and LG will remain major players in the non-smartphone market, while other brand companies have started shifting their focus from non-smartphones to smartphones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sniffer dogs detect drugs worth NT$150 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 13:15:34 (By Y. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Sniffer dogs helped Taiwan's customs agents find narcotics worth a combined NT$150 million (US$4.91 million) in the first 10 months of this year, the Directorate General of Customs (DGC) under the Ministry of Finance reported Saturday.
According to the DGC, 20 cases of intended drug smuggling were detected by the customs authorities with the help of sniffer dogs at major airports and ports nationwide in the January-October period.
Five cases involved heroin weighing 6.62 kg, eight cases involved marijuana totaling 2.11 kg, with the remaining seven cases involving 52.31 kg of ketamine.
The DGC began training narcotics detection dogs in July 2009, with 12 squads of sniffer dogs completing the training and now serving at prime gateways to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: No deal is better than a bad deal
DOC.DATELINE: 12/04/10 14:16:13 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 4, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Due to bottlenecks in the negotiations of an investment protection agreement that Taiwan and China hope to sign in the sixth meeting between their chief negotiators, the two sides are prepared to postpone the meeting to allow more time for discussion.

A cross-Taiwan Strait investment protection agreement is far more complicated than other international investment agreements because of the delicate relationship between the two sides. It is therefore not surprising that the negotiations have not been smooth.

It seems the government was too optimistic about setting a timetable for the completion of the negotiations. The government should learn a lesson from this experience and carefully evaluate other cross-strait agreements to be signed in the future.

As to the investment protection agreement, the government must cautiously deal with the various thorny issues involved, especially the designation of a neutral arbitrator for investment disputes, and follow the principle of "no deal is better than a bad deal."

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Where will the ex-president's wife be jailed?
DOC.DATELINE: 12/04/10 14:33:40 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As the convicted former president Chen Shui-bian settled in a cell smaller than 4 square meters at a prison in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan, it is still unclear where his wheelchair-bound wife Wu Shu-jen, also given a combined 19-year sentence for her roles in two bribery cases that involved her husband, will serve her term.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

The Taiwan High Prosecutors Office will convene a special meeting of several chief prosecutors next Monday to discuss how to carry out Wu's imprisonment. Meanwhile, some said the authorities are inclined to a proposal of sending Wu to the hospital affiliated to the Taichung Prison in central Taiwan.
Under the Prison Act, a prison can refuse to accept an inmate when such a person is old, disabled or cannot take care of himself or herself.
When an inmate is refused by a prison under these regulations, the person has to be sent to a hospital, guardian, or other appropriate institution after a prosecutor considers their condition.

Prosecutors are expected to come up with a solution for Wu's case in a planned special meeting. They will consider options including having Wu stay at the Taichung Prison-affiliated hospital with Wu covering all the medical costs by herself; releasing Wu on bail at a huge sum; or sending the ailment-suffering convicted to a "hospital, guardian, or other appropriate institution" based on the Prison Act.

Now, it is certain that the widely-discussed proposals, such as house confinement or having Wu wear electronic ankle bracelets fetters, will not be adopted because there is no law in the country regulating home confinement and electronic bracelets are only applied to those convicted of sexual assault charges who are released on parole. (Dec. 4, 2010).
United Daily News:

Chen, who is identified by his inmate serial number "1020" at the Taipei Prison, spent his first night peacefully at the prison Friday. He only asked for a small desk for writing from the jail management, to which he had pledged to respect all the rules at jail to avoid the image that he is given preferential treatment due to his status as a former president.

Different from the quiet atmosphere in Chen's cell, it was noisy outside the prison Friday morning, when many Chen supporters waited to visit Chen with food as a gift, which they said are his favorite.

Chen was sentenced on Nov. 11 to a total of 19 years in prison for two bribery charges in the cases involving a land deal in Lungtan, Taoyuan County and the appointment of a chairwoman of the Taipei 101 skyscraper. The court is expected to decide later whether the two sentences will be served consecutively or concurrently or the exact duration of his time behind the bars. (Dec. 4, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Legislator Chen Ting-fei of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) visited Chen at the prison Friday. She said Chen told her that it is the politics, instead of the judiciary system, that put him behind bars.
DPP spokesman Chen Yu-chang reiterated the party's call for a fair trial for Chen, who withdrew from the DPP in August 2008 after being accused of corruption. (Dec. 4, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Switzerland allows value-added tax refund for Taiwanese companies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 14:59:19 (By I. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Companies of Taiwan and Switzerland attending exhibitions or engaging in business activities on either side now can apply for a refund of the value-added tax (VAT) they have paid to the host country, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Saturday.

The MOF announced that from July 1, foreign enterprises with no regular venues to do business in Taiwan are eligible to request a VAT refund with local tax offices, as long as they have paid more than NT$5,000 (US$64) in VAT for goods or services they purchased while attending trade shows or taking part in business activities in Taiwan.
Following in the footsteps of Slovenia and Germany, Switzerland was the third country to have reached agreement with Taiwan on this mutually beneficial measure after the MOF put it in place.

The measure, retroactive to July 1, 2010, was designed to help reduce operating costs for Taiwanese companies and lure more foreign businesses to participate in trade fairs here, MOF officials explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ICT Month' tech fair opens to crowds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 15:39:39 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest consumer electronics show, featuring new products and technologies from companies, government agencies and research institutes, kicked off a month-long run in Taipei Saturday.

The ICT Month fair brings together more than 350 exhibitors from home and abroad in the information and communications technology (ICT) industry every year, creating business opportunities worth more than NT$10 billion (US$331 million), according to the Taipei Computer Association, which is organizing the event.

"During the one-month period, the fair also brings the latest technology trends and applications to the more-than 2 million people who are expected to attend, " said Raff Liu, the head of the event's organizing committee, in his opening remarks.
On the 2010 event's theme, "Embracing a Smart Life, " Liu said this refers to how technological developments can improve the quality of life.
"The products at the fair no longer highlight just enhanced efficiency or specifications, but rather focus on user friendliness," he said.
The public can also learn about how the ICT industry has transformed itself to focus on innovative services, Liu added.
Premier Wu Den-yih, speaking at the opening ceremony, said the government is working to build Taiwan as a base for innovative technology products.

The government's efforts to boost the development of smart handheld devices, cloud computing online technology and wireless broadband services have not only created an "intelligent environment" for local citizens but have also reduced carbon emissions and conserved energy due to enhanced efficiency, he added.
The annual fair, now in its 31st year, will also be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 17-22 and in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Dec. 30-Jan. 4 after running until Dec. 12 in Taipei.

A total of 350 exhibitors, including Acer, Asustek, Sony, HTC and Epson can expect to see their sales during the run in Taipei increase by 20 percent to 30 percent compared to last year's show, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait development should be virtuous cycle: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 16:26:08 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: It is imperative for China to respect the will of the people of Taiwan and make the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations a virtuous, rather a vicious cycle, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang told CNA in an interview Friday.

"China needs to know that both sides of the strait have fought over the issue of sovereignty for decades without a solution. And that's why we say it's time to set the dispute aside and stop touching upon the issue, " Yang said.
"We also think that China should take the passion and consensus of the 23 million Taiwanese people to participate in the international community seriously, " said Yang.

Economically, Taiwan and China have been stepping up efforts to liberalize bilateral trade ties by signing the historic economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) in June. Bilateral personnel exchanges have also increased since the relaxation of regulations, he said.

On the political front, President Ma Ying-jeou has called for rapprochement, flexible diplomacy and a diplomatic truce with China since assuming office in May 2008 to reduce tension and stop a diplomatic war over international allies, which has cost hundreds of millions of dollars under previous administrations.

However, Taiwan's international space is still limited, Yang said. For many Taiwanese, various incidents on international occasions suggest that China is still hesitant to further extend its goodwill.

China has to understand that "cross-strait relations and Taiwan's external relations should go hand-in-hand in a virtuous cycle, " Yang said, so that the Taiwanese people will be more supportive of government policy.
"In the past, it has been a vicious cycle and a relentless diplomatic war, " said Yang.

Taiwan has done its part in extending olive branches, choosing not to escalate tension in its efforts to participate in politically sensitive international organizations, such as the United Nations, asking instead only for meaningful participation, he said.
In the Southeast Asian countries of Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, where Taiwan intends to boost its economic presence, friendly gestures from China are thin on the ground, however, Yang went on.

"Taiwan does not intend to alter these countries' relations with China, nor is it approaching them with hidden agendas, " said Yang, adding that China's diplomatic approach to Taiwan "has not been well thought through."

Looking at the coming year, Yang said Taiwan's diplomacy priorities will focus on consolidating relations with its current 23 diplomatic allies and its relations with the European Union, the United States, Japan, South Korea and Southeast Asian countries.
"Taiwan may not enjoy official diplomatic relations with these countries, but we are allies who share the same values of freedom and democracy, " he said.
Taiwan will also actively seek more meaningful participation in international organizations, as well as international non-government organizations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of marriages registered on `lucky nines' day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 17:03:11 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A total of 6,170 couples filed their marriage registrations Sept. 9 this year, marking the highest daily number recorded over the past 20 years, according to a report released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior.
The date is seen as auspicious in Taiwan because of the series of nines, which in Mandarin Chinese is a homonym for "long-lasting." 2010 is the 99th year of the Republic of China.
On another date that is also considered propitious -- Oct. 10, 2010 -- 2,527 couples registered their marriages, eight times the daily average of 300 couples in 2009, the report shows.
The number 10 implies completeness and perfection in Chinese culture.
The report indicates that 112,020 couples tied the knot during the first 10 months of this year, up 20.5 percent from the same period of 2009.
According to superstition, 2009 was a "lonely phoenix year" unfavorable to the longevity of marriages. Only 117,099 marriages were recorded that year, a decrease of 37,767 from 2008.

During the January-October period, there were 17,534 marriages involving a non- Taiwanese spouse, accounting for 15.65 percent of all the marriages registered. The number represents a drop of 647, or 3.56 percent, from the previous year.
The report also shows that people in Taiwan are getting married later and later in life.
In 2009, the average age of newlyweds was 31.6 for first-time grooms and 28.9 for first-time brides, an increase of 0.5 years from 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars call for more action on human rights education in Asia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 17:18:09 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Human rights education in many parts of Asia is still lacking and needs substantive change, scholars and human rights defenders from Asia said Saturday in a seminar in Taipei.

Organized by the Taipei Municipal University of Education, the scholars and human rights workers from across Asia were participating in the three-day international conference titled "Propagation and Implementation of the Idea of Human Rights."

Jefferson Plantilla, a lawyer and human rights educator based in Japan, noted that there were many cases of human rights violations reported throughout Southeast Asia in the 1970s and 1980s, a time when rulers would put economic growth ahead of raising human rights education awareness and training.

Since 2000, human rights education centers have been established across the region, and as of November this year, 90 such centers were in place to help promote human rights education, he said. The lack of coordination among these centers, however, still poses a big problem for citizens, he went on.
Li Dan, an AIDS activist and human rights defender from China, said that since he was young, he felt strongly deprived of human rights education.

"If you are an optimist, you would say things are gradually changing in China. But the truth is that courses and teaching on human rights education remain very scant, because the last thing the Chinese government wants is to push for the development of human rights," Lee said.
In China, many human rights workers do not tell others what they do for fear of being labeled dissidents, according to Lee.

He said there are only two universities in China that offer lessons that correspond to the universal values of human rights, while the majority of the schools give lessons to brainwash students that Chinese people do not need the kind of human rights education that Western people receive.

Yvonne Liu, a member of Hong Kong's Alliance of Civil Education, said human rights education is not institutionalized in schools at all levels. As a result, human rights education in Hong Kong is very weak. Liu, a teacher, said her students often ask her about the sensational words and pictures carried on the front page of Apple Daily, and that she found it difficult to help change the learning environment for the younger generation.

For Taiwan's part, Professor Tang Mei-ying, who has conducted several surveys on teachers' attitudes on pushing for human rights education, said most of the teachers in Taiwan are supportive of the teaching and promotion of human rights- related educational classes.

She said the responsibility of creating a positive environment to push for human rights education in Taiwan is not just in the hands of educators and that the government and the media should be more actively involved, while not intervening.
"When it comes to human rights education in Taiwan, we need more action and fewer slogans, " she said, adding that "political influence should also be wiped out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Buyers from emerging markets to target Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 17:22:52 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of 13 major companies from emerging countries will attend an investment and procurement seminar in Taipei Dec. 9 that is expected to generate business opportunities worth about US$60 million for local suppliers, organizers said Saturday.

According to the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), the companies, all with annual revenues in excess of US$30 million, are based in Brazil, Indonesia, India, Egypt, Russia and countries in the Middle East, covering a wide range of areas from garments to beauty care products and car components.
They include Ghabbour Group Auto from Egypt, Cia Hering, a garment brand in Brazil, and TV shopping shop Neolab Prima from Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Replica of Ming dynasty ship makes maiden voyage
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Taiwan Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 17:44:20 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A full-size replica of a 17th century Ming Dynasty armed merchant vessel set off on its maiden voyage from Anping Harbor in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan Saturday to re-enact the scene of the arrival of a Chinese general over 300 years ago.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair launched the boat along with Oscar-winning director Ang Lee.

The 29.5-meter wooden replica sailed, escorted by more than 10 modern ships and police helicopters, to the mouth of the Luermen River, the site of the landing of the Ming Dynasty's Cheng Cheng-kung, better known as Koxinga, in 1661.

The replica of the ancient ship is named "Taiwan Cheng Kung" to commemorate the military leader for his success in forcing the Dutch out of Taiwan in 1662 and making Taiwan his base for a campaign against the Manchu-ruled Qing dynasty.

To recreate the ship, the Tainan city government sent officials to Japan in 2008 to obtain a copy of a painting of the vessel kept at the Matsura History Museum in Hirado City, Nagasaki Prefecture, where Koxinga was born in 1624.
Based on the 1706 painting, the 300-ton replica, with a displacement of 150 tons, was completed in 18 months, with funding of NT$80 million (US$2.5 million) from the Council for Cultural Affairs.

Unlike its sail-driven original, the replica is equipped with modern navigation devices and an engine. It will conduct a one-week, round-the-island voyage next year as part of celebrations for the 100th founding anniversary of the Republic of China.

The ship will also sail to Koxinga's birthplace in Hirado, as well as Quanzhou in Fujiang Province, and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Penghu, where Koxinga's army was once based, according to the Tainan city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICT industry plays big role in carbon cuts: Acer head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 18:14:12 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Products or services featuring lower carbon emissions can better appeal to consumers amid rising environmental awareness, and new information and communications technology (ICT) plays a big role in this process, Acer's chairman said Saturday.

"Consumers worldwide are being educated (on the issue) and are changing their values and concepts as they experience the real impact of extreme weather, " said J.T. Wang, the head of the world's second-largest PC brand, at the opening ceremony in Taipei of ICT Month, Taiwan's largest consumer electronics show.
"Consumers are now more willing to pay for products or services that can help reduce energy and cut carbon emissions," he said.
The global efforts to conserve energy can benefit from the technologies and applications of the ICT industry, which can greatly enhance efficiency, Wang said.
Many countries have applied new ICT technologies to city infrastructure, buildings, transport and power systems, he noted.
He estimated that the use of new ICT technologies will make a 15-percent to 20- percent contribution to cutting carbon emissions and energy use.

In addition, Wang said that Taiwan, with its existing technological advantage, will be able to serve as a leader in the new ICT industry that will spawn new services through the integration of computer, communications, consumer electronics and content.
"The mixture of these different technologies and content will create many new products and services that we have never seen before," he said.
"These new markets represent huge opportunities worth hundreds of billions of U.S. dollars, " he said, citing as examples new handheld devices such as tablet computers, e-readers and smartphones.
"This change has just started and is likely to last for more than 10 years," he said.
Taiwan has a good opportunity to come out ahead in these fields, as the country already has a competitive edge in the ICT industry, Wang said, urging the government to invest more in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier eyeing `smart Taiwan'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 18:19:25 (By C.Y. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih vowed Saturday to build a "smart Taiwan" to further sharpen the country's competitiveness and ensure its sustainable growth.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the 31st ICT Month fair in Taipei with the theme of "Embracing a Smart Life, " Wu said that information and communications technology (ICT) has played a pivotal role in Taiwan's transformation into a high-tech power and that the Executive Yuan will continue advocating the application of ICT to a wide range of everyday life situations.

According to the premier, the Executive Yuan will allocate NT$1.69 billion (US$55.41 million) to develop a smart grid network that will accommodate 23,000 major power users, which is expected to considerably reduce carbon emissions and save billions of dollars in operating costs.
A smart green building program recently approved by the Executive Yuan will also help generate hundreds of billions in production value, he added.
A "smart life" is needed for both the government and its people, he explained.
The annual fair will also be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 17-22 and in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Dec. 30-Jan. 4 after it ends its Taipei run Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mass wedding for 100 couples set for New Year's Day 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 18:31:35 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will host a joint wedding for 100 couples Jan. 1, 2011 as part of the New Year's Day flag-raising ceremony, one of a series of events organized by the government to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China.
The couples will also be allowed to have their wedding photos taken in the Presidential Office -- the first time the tightly guarded building will be opened to the public for such an activity.
A pre-wedding briefing was held Saturday for the couples.
Wu Teh-liang, a groom-to-be who was first to register for the mass wedding, said he was encouraged by his future in-laws to take part "to show his sincerity."
He eventually succeeded in getting the No. 1 designation by sending his registration form simultaneously using five different fax machines with the help of his colleagues.

Lee Ming-lung, another groom-to-be, said he had only dated his girlfriend for three months when he saw the mass wedding advertisement in August. He decided to pop the question and became the 70th successful registrant.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan mayor-elect receives election certificate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 18:51:50 (By Yang Sz-ruei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The mayor-elect of soon-to-be-created Tainan municipality in southern Taiwan received Saturday his election certificate issued by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
CEC Chairwoman Chang Po-ya presented the certificate to Lai Ching-te at his campaign headquarters in Yongkang, Tainan County.
Lai was the first of the five winners in the Nov. 27 mayoral elections in Taipei City and other four new special municipalities to receive his election certificate.
According to Chang, the other winners will get their certificates next week.

Tainan City will join Taipei City as a special municipality Dec. 25 after merging with Tainan County. The other new municipalities are Xinbei City (the new name of Taipei County after its upgrade) , Taichung City (an integration of Taichung City and Taichung County) and Kaohsiung City (a merger of Kaohisung City and Kaohsiung County).
Lai, one of two members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party who achieved victory in the elections, will head an administration serving a population of 1.8 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer head forecasts growth in notebook market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 18:58:26 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The global market for notebook computers will grow between 20 percent and 25 percent next year on the back of rising demand in emerging markets, the head of the world's second-largest PC brand Acer said Saturday.
Company Chairman J.T. Wang expressed optimism over upcoming sales for the Christmas holiday season and the first quarter of next year.

During the first three months of 2011, Intel Corp., the world's largest chip maker, will launch several new central processing units (CPUs) , which he predicted will create a new wave of business opportunities.
On market speculation that the emergence of tablet computers will replace personal computers, he said that growing demand in the emerging markets will help drive demand for notebooks.
As a result, he forecast that the compound annual growth rate for global notebook shipments will remain at more than 20 percent for the next few years.
On Dec. 1, Acer joined other high-tech companies in developing a presence in China's vast hinterland by setting up a second operating hub in Chongqing following its first, in coastal Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: No quota on applicants for micro loans: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 19:26:02 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: No quota will be set on the number of applicants for a micro loan from the government as part of its efforts to help startup companies, Premier Wu Den-yih said Saturday.

"I have discussed the issue with President Ma Ying-jeou and we have agreed that no cap will be imposed on the number of borrowers of this kind of government- provided small loan, " Wu said during an address at an award ceremony to honor successful small business startups.

"The government will do its utmost to help as many people as it can, no matter whether it is 10,000 or 30,000, at a time when Taiwan has yet to recover from the blow of the global financial crisis, " he said.

Under the micro loan program designed for women aged 20-65 and men in the 45-65 age group, a borrower can borrow a maximum amount of NT$1 million (US$33,000) from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to build a small business. The funds must be repaid in seven years.
According to the CLA, the measure has benefited more than 6,000 small business startups, helping create some 16,000 jobs since its inception in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICT Month tech fair sees more visitors on opening day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 19:30:45 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: ICT Month, Taiwan's largest consumer electronics show, saw a small increase in the number of opening day visitors this year compared with last year amid the recovering economy.

The annual fair, now in its 31st year, recorded 95,000 visitors on opening day Saturday, up from last year's opening day tally of 85,000 visitors, said the Taipei Computer Association, which is organizing the event.
Digital cameras were the biggest sellers, followed by notebook computers and handheld devices such as tablet computers, e-readers and smartphones, the organizer said,
The packed show features 1,765 booths manned by 350 exhibitors including Acer, Asustek, Sony, HTC and Epson.
The event will also be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 17-22 and in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Dec. 30-Jan. 4 after running until Dec. 12 in Taipei.

"During the one-month period, the fair also brings the latest technology trends and applications to the more-than 2 million people who are expected to attend, " said Raff Liu, the head of the event's organizing committee, in his opening remarks.
On the 2010 event's theme, "Embracing a Smart Life, " Liu said this refers to how technological developments can improve the quality of life.
"The products at the fair no longer highlight just enhanced efficiency or specifications, but rather focus on user friendliness," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mass transport users awarded for traveling around Taiwan creatively
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 20:55:26 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The winners of a contest to use mass transport to travel around Taiwan in creative ways were announced Saturday after a five-month campaign to spread the message of eco-friendliness and to encourage the public to experience "the real Taiwan."

The four winners, each of whom was awarded NT$100,000 (US$3,300) in prize money, carried out their travel projects in four different categories -- most interesting, most economical, most touching and the most mass-transport supportive.
The Directorate General of Highways, which organized the contest, said it was inspired by the total of 133 entries on how to make mass transport systems and transfer services work better.
Meanwhile, a couple in their 70s, whose travel project won the "most economical" category, said they "felt younger as they traveled."
"As you can see, our age has saved us a lot of money since we hardly ever need to pay full ticket prices, " said Chang Ti, who along with his wife spent NT$19,411 (US$636.43) on one week of travel.
"I'd encourage people, old and young, to travel around Taiwan and enjoy themselves, " Chang said. "After all, you can't take it with you when you go."

DOC.HEADLINE: New health insurance system might be implemented in 2012
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 21:03:51 (By Chen Ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang expressed hope Saturday that a second-generation national health insurance (NHI) premium system can be put into practice in 2012.

Speaking at a ceremony to mark the 13th anniversary of the Formosa Cancer Foundation, Yaung said legal revisions to pave the way for implementation of the new premium system are 90 percent complete and that the remaining 10 percent require more work.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT)-controlled Legislative Yuan has set a Dec. 7 deadline for the passage of the DOH-proposed amendments to the existing NHI Act to permit the introduction of the new premium system.

Twenty clauses of the bill, however, have yet to receive majority support from lawmakers. In addition to lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), some KMT legislators also remain skeptical about the fairness of the new premium calculation formula.

Under the new system, the NHI premium will be levied in terms of total household income instead of the individual salaries or wages of the insured as is the case at present. The new system is considered fairer and an essential move if the cash-strapped NHI system is to remain viable.

DPP Legislator Huang Sue-ying said the proposed new system is still flawed because it excludes capital gains, overseas earnings and some other sources of income from the household income that will be used as the basis for health insurance premiums.
According to Ministry of Finance statistics, 56 percent of the total income of Taiwan's richest 1 percent of families comes from stock capital gains.
Against this backdrop, Huang said, the new premium system should not exclude capital gains from the NHI premium levy calculations.
Moreover, she went on, the new system might increase the burden on impoverished families because the DOH-proposed bill does not include clear provisions in this regard.

KMT Legislator Yang Li-huan said the inclusion of capital gains could make the premium calculations too difficult, but she added that the party might come up with a new version of the revised NHI bill to make the new system fairer and to facilitate its passage.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Formosa Cancer Foundation, reaffirmed his confidence that same day that the legislature will finalize the screening of the NHI bill by Dec. 7 as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ang Lee shares filmmaking experience in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 21:54:40 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of students and local citizens streamed into National Chung Hsing University in Taichung on Saturday to listen to a speech by Oscar-winning Taiwanese-American director Ang Lee, who is currently in Taiwan to shoot his latest film creation "Life of Pi."
Lee will shoot the entire movie in 3D and about two-thirds of the film will be shot in Taiwan, mostly in central and southern Taiwan.

According to Lee, the film is still in its early production stage, as he and the screenwriter are still working on the script, but more than 100 international film crew members who he used to work with in the United States have stayed in Taiwan for a while for location scouting.
"I want to find a new way of speaking/narrating in film, and 3D could be a good way," he said.
It's very challenging to shoot a movie in 3D because the technology is still very new and nobody really understands it, he said.
"But I've always wanted to challenge myself, " said Lee. "I may look like a gentle person from the outside, but I like challenges more than anyone else."

"Life of Pi" is a production based on a prize-winning novel with the same name written by Canadian writer Yann Martel about an Indian boy adrift on a lifeboat in the Pacific with a zebra, a hyena, an orangutan and a tiger.
Many Hollywood producers have attempted a film adaptation from the book, yet many give up because it is considered too difficult to visualize the story on the big screen.
Lee said that, during his nearly 20 years of filmmaking experience, he found that it is important to "have faith" and to really believe everything will work out eventually.
"The greatest idea always comes from nowhere, so you have to go to nowhere to get it," he said philosophically.

The 56-year-old filmmaker, who is based in New York, was hailed as the "the pride of Taiwan" after wining an Oscar in 2005 for directing "Brokeback Mountain". He is the first Asian filmmaker to receive the Academay Award for Best Director.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins more gold in Asian Extreme Sports Championships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 22:07:01 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese athlete Hung Chien-kai won a gold medal in the AIL Park event at the 2010 Asian Extreme Sports Championships in Taipei Saturday.
Hung, who has sustained many ligament injuries, said he was grateful for the firm support and encouragement from his friends in his pursuit of excellence in the sport.
In the past two days of the games, Taiwanese athletes have won two gold medals, two silvers and two bronzes in various events. The games are scheduled to close Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dance festival kicks off to enhance Taiwan-Japan tourism ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 22:14:41 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A two-day event showcasing Taiwanese and Japanese folk dance began Saturday in celebration of the friendship between the two countries and the growing bilateral tourism ties.

Now in its eighth year, the dance festival held in Taipei's Xinyi shopping district is aimed at promoting cultural exchanges through performances of drumming, lion dancing and Japanese folk dance, said a Tourism Bureau official.

According to statistics, the total of 10 Japanese dance troupes with a combined 120 performers have also boosted foreign tourism in Taiwan by attracting more than 1,000 Japanese tourists to the annual extravaganza.
"Japan is one of the most important travel markets for Taiwan, " said Chiang Ming-ching, director of the bureau's international affairs division.

He said that in the first 10 months of this year, around 885,000 Japanese travelers visited Taiwan, a 6.5 percent rise compared with the same period of last year. Meanwhile, around 1.11 million Taiwanese travelers visited Japan in the same period, representing a 25.3 percent year-on-year increase.

"As direct flights between Tokyo's Haneda Airport and Taipei International Airport resumed in October, we hope festivals like this can add more incentives for foreign travelers to explore Taiwan, " Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines, Iran among big winners at Asia Pacific Film Fest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 23:24:39 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Veteran Filipino actress Anita Linda, Iranian superstar Hamid Farrokhnezhad, and India filmmakers were the biggest winners Saturday night when they nabbed the top honors at the 54th Asia Pacific Film Festival held in Taipei.
The much beloved Linda touched the hearts of the judges with her portrayal of a determined elderly grandmother inLolawhile Farrokhnezad won for his role inThe Fateful Night.
Farrokhnezad's win dashed Taiwan heartthrob Ethan Ruan's hope to bag two major awards in a row after being named Best Actor in last month's Golden Horse Awards for playing a tough gangster inMonga.
Although it lost out on all the major categories, Monga managed to grab the honors for Best Music and Best Artistic Direction.

Other Taiwanese winners include "Fourth Portrait", which was recognized for its cinematography, and Taiwanese short film "Sleeping With Her", which follows the emotional journey of an Indonesian caretaker. It topped the Best Short Film category.
Indian filmmakers also went home smiling after bagging three awards, making them the most fruitful winners of the night, including Best Feature Film forJanala.

Hosted by Taiwan's comedian guru Jacky Wu and his beautiful sidekick Patty Hou, the three-and-half-hour ceremony had several laugh-out-loud segments that sent the audience into roaring laughters but also some unexpected awkward moments.

One of them was courtesy of the South Korean screenplay writer surnamed Park who surprised everyone when, during his Best Screenplay acceptance speech for "Enlightenment Film", he said to the audience, "please don't hate us".

The nervous-looking writer, who thanked Taiwan several times for hosting the event, was referring to the recent anti-Korean sentiment in the country after a Taiwanese taekwondo athlete was accused of cheating by officials of the Seoul- based World Taekwondo Federation in last month's Asian Games.
But the Korean factor did not stop there.
When Taiwan hosted the Asia Pacific Film Festival last year, the organizing committee received raving reviews for having invited several South Korean entertainers to perform.
In a bid to repeat the same success, the organizers had originally planned to invite other Korean singers and bands but the idea was scrapped at the last minute due the taekwondo row.
The APFF was established in 1954 and is touted as the second-longest running international movie event next to the Academy Awards.
Delegations from 17 countries and regions such as Japan, Iran, Bangladesh, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, Vietnam, Australia, and Indonesia were among the attendees of the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ang Lee shares filmmaking experience in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 21:54:40 (By Hermia Lin)
