DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins more gold in Asian Extreme Sports Championships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 22:07:01 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese athlete Hung Chien-kai won a gold medal in the AIL Park event at the 2010 Asian Extreme Sports Championships in Taipei Saturday.
Hung, who has sustained many ligament injuries, said he was grateful for the firm support and encouragement from his friends in his pursuit of excellence in the sport.
In the past two days of the games, Taiwanese athletes have won two gold medals, two silvers and two bronzes in various events. The games are scheduled to close Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dance festival kicks off to enhance Taiwan-Japan tourism ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 22:14:41 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A two-day event showcasing Taiwanese and Japanese folk dance began Saturday in celebration of the friendship between the two countries and the growing bilateral tourism ties.

Now in its eighth year, the dance festival held in Taipei's Xinyi shopping district is aimed at promoting cultural exchanges through performances of drumming, lion dancing and Japanese folk dance, said a Tourism Bureau official.

According to statistics, the total of 10 Japanese dance troupes with a combined 120 performers have also boosted foreign tourism in Taiwan by attracting more than 1,000 Japanese tourists to the annual extravaganza.
"Japan is one of the most important travel markets for Taiwan, " said Chiang Ming-ching, director of the bureau's international affairs division.

He said that in the first 10 months of this year, around 885,000 Japanese travelers visited Taiwan, a 6.5 percent rise compared with the same period of last year. Meanwhile, around 1.11 million Taiwanese travelers visited Japan in the same period, representing a 25.3 percent year-on-year increase.

"As direct flights between Tokyo's Haneda Airport and Taipei International Airport resumed in October, we hope festivals like this can add more incentives for foreign travelers to explore Taiwan, " Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines, Iran among big winners at Asia Pacific Film Fest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/10 23:24:39 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Veteran Filipino actress Anita Linda, Iranian superstar Hamid Farrokhnezhad, and India filmmakers were the biggest winners Saturday night when they nabbed the top honors at the 54th Asia Pacific Film Festival held in Taipei.
The much beloved Linda touched the hearts of the judges with her portrayal of a determined elderly grandmother inLolawhile Farrokhnezad won for his role inThe Fateful Night.
Farrokhnezad's win dashed Taiwan heartthrob Ethan Ruan's hope to bag two major awards in a row after being named Best Actor in last month's Golden Horse Awards for playing a tough gangster inMonga.
Although it lost out on all the major categories, Monga managed to grab the honors for Best Music and Best Artistic Direction.

Other Taiwanese winners include "Fourth Portrait", which was recognized for its cinematography, and Taiwanese short film "Sleeping With Her", which follows the emotional journey of an Indonesian caretaker. It topped the Best Short Film category.
Indian filmmakers also went home smiling after bagging three awards, making them the most fruitful winners of the night, including Best Feature Film forJanala.

Hosted by Taiwan's comedian guru Jacky Wu and his beautiful sidekick Patty Hou, the three-and-half-hour ceremony had several laugh-out-loud segments that sent the audience into roaring laughters but also some unexpected awkward moments.

One of them was courtesy of the South Korean screenplay writer surnamed Park who surprised everyone when, during his Best Screenplay acceptance speech for "Enlightenment Film", he said to the audience, "please don't hate us".

The nervous-looking writer, who thanked Taiwan several times for hosting the event, was referring to the recent anti-Korean sentiment in the country after a Taiwanese taekwondo athlete was accused of cheating by officials of the Seoul- based World Taekwondo Federation in last month's Asian Games.
But the Korean factor did not stop there.
When Taiwan hosted the Asia Pacific Film Festival last year, the organizing committee received raving reviews for having invited several South Korean entertainers to perform.
In a bid to repeat the same success, the organizers had originally planned to invite other Korean singers and bands but the idea was scrapped at the last minute due the taekwondo row.
The APFF was established in 1954 and is touted as the second-longest running international movie event next to the Academy Awards.
Delegations from 17 countries and regions such as Japan, Iran, Bangladesh, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, Vietnam, Australia, and Indonesia were among the attendees of the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 5, or the 30th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary- general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Three Taiwanese golfers swing to LPGA season finale
DOC.DATELINE: Orlando, Fla., Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/05/10 14:28:25 (By Zep Hu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese golfers have swung to the final round of the LPGA Tour Championship at the Grand Cypress Golf Club in Orlando, Florida.

The 72-hole season-ending event features a total purse of US$1.5 million and a unique two-cut format. The field was reduced to the low-70 players and ties after 36 holes and to the low-30 players and ties after 54 holes.
Taiwanese golfers Yani Tseng, Candie Kung and Amy Hung have managed to make the lowest 30 players and ties list, finishing the third round Saturday at 29th, 16th and 21st, respectively.

Tseng -- who won the Kraft Nabisco Championship in April and the RICOH Women's British Open in August and is considered one of the top five in the field to have a chance to grab the LPGA's Player of the Year Award 2010 -- did not play well in the third round.
Despite her one-under-par shots on the 7th, 11th, 14th and 17th holes, she suffered a tough tee time, with bogeys on the third and 18th holes and agonizing double bogeys on the ninth and 13th holes.

The 21-year-old Tseng, who became the world's fourth-ranked player this year, finished the first three rounds with 222, six shots over par, to a 29th tie -- a narrow escape from being ousted from the lowest 30.
Tseng said the bad breaks were not just mental. "There's something wrong with my technique," she said.
"Luckily, I still have a chance to improve tomorrow, " the undaunted Tseng said.
Meanwhile, Kung, who was comparatively more stable Saturday, finished the third round at a 16th position tie, with three shots over par.
Hung finished with a 21st tie, with four shots over par.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County ceramics museum celebrates 10th anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 14:56:01 (By Sunrise Huang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The Yingge Ceramics Museum invited visitors Saturday to bury a time capsule as part of its 10th anniversary celebration.

Three hundred invited guests, including 20 10-year-olds who receive care or financial support from a local child welfare organization, wrote their wishes on cards and put them in a huge ceramic time capsule.
One fourth-grade girl who studies at a school in nearby Sansia Township wrote: "I wish I can become a doctor in 10 years."

Another local schoolchild's card said: "I hope I can help those who have been very kind to me once I grow up, " which Chou Ta-yao, director of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families' Taipei County branch, said made him very happy.
The museum provided acid-free paper and pens for archival use to ensure that the cards will stay legible until 2020, when the participants plan to gather at the museum again to open the capsule.

In a speech at the event, the museum's director, Yu Jan-chi, lauded the memory of her predecessor, Wu Chin-feng, and his devotion and hard work to make Taiwan's only ceramics museum able to connect with the international ceramic community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most office workers want to visit flora expo, but fear crowds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 16:05:29 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 75 percent of office workers in a recent survey said they want to visit the 2010 Taipei Flora Expo but have yet to do so, mainly because the crowds and long waiting lines have put them off, according to the poll results released Sunday.
The survey, conducted by the online job bank 1111.com, found that 73 percent of the respondents said they had yet to visit the expo, compared with 8.6 percent who said they had visited.

In a multiple choice series of questions, up to 82.7 precent said they were most concerned about the crowds, followed by long waiting lines (66.4 percent) and a dirty and chaotic environment (29.8 percent).

Among the respondents who have already visited the expo, most said it is attractive because of the high-tech planning in the exhibition halls (58.1 percent) , because it is an international extravaganza (50.5 percent) , and because it is a hot topic (37.1 percent).
Further analysis found that those who have already visited the expo gave it a score of 73.2 points, higher than the 68.9 points given by those who have not actually seen it.

With five months to go before the expo closes in April next year, over half of those polled said they will visit the show between February and April next year, mainly because they want to avoid the crowds (39.4 percent) , or because they have holidays at that time (38.0 percent).

However, 18.4 percent have no intention of visiting the show, mainly because they do not like the crowds (29.9 percent) , they do not feel it to be anything special (23.2 percent) , or they are not interested in flowers or gardening (17.1 percent).
The survey was conducted between Nov. 22 and Nov. 30, collecting 1.147 effective samples with a margin of error of 2.9 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIFA talks can be broken down
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 16:45:45 (By Lin Shen-hsu, Emmanuelle Tzeng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) talks between Taiwan and the United States can be broken down to make them more manageable if the negotiators from the two sides find it difficult to complete them in one shot, Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

Taiwan and the U.S. can resume the long-stalled TIFA talks topic by topic if the two sides have problems reaching consensus on certain issues, Wu said during a function to mark International Migrants Day in Taipei.
The U.S. is close to signing a free trade agreement (FTA) with South Korea and the premier was asked by a reporter how Taiwan will face the issue of a U.S.-South Korea FTA.
The signing of such an FTA will mean that South Korea -- Taiwan's major rival in the global market -- will be in a better position to compete against Taiwan.
Wu responded that South Korea was alarmed and felt pressure after Taiwan concluded the landmark Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China earlier this year.
The signing of a U.S.-South Korea FTA, therefore, would also cause Taiwan to feel pressured, the premier said.
Most importantly, Taiwan should take the approach that is most conducive to protecting the people's interests when restarting the TIFA talks with the U.S., he said.
"Just sitting at the negotiating table is easier than working out an agenda and sorting out barriers beforehand," Yang said.
The new round of TIFA talks will most likely take place in Taipei, according to the foreign minister.

The TIFA framework, signed in September 1994, provides an official channel for Taiwan-U.S. dialogue on trade and economic issues, but the two sides have not held any talks since 2007 due mainly to conflict over a Taiwanese ban on U.S. beef imports.

Meanwhile, on the prospects of the U.S. granting Taiwanese passport holders visa-free treatment, Yang said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been working toward that goal, but so far, "there is no timetable for its implementation."

The MOFA has recently launched a trial drive to get more Taiwanese citizens to apply for their passports in person, as part of efforts to persuade the U.S. to grant Taiwanese passport holders visa-free treatment, according to Yang.

The U.S. wants Taiwan to increase the percentage of in-person passport applications and to make applicants have their ID photographs taken when they apply, on the grounds that Taiwanese passports are easily misused at present because applicants do not need to present themselves in person for positive identification.
From January 2011, at least one household registration office in each city and county will be opened to in-person passport applications on a trial basis, Yang said.

He quoted the results of a recent opinion poll as indicating that nearly 90 percent of Taiwanese citizens are prepared to visit household registration offices in person to file their passport applications if the move is conducive to the U.S. visa-waiver policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled Swedish artist presents video to president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 16:58:44 (By Garfie Li and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Disabled singer Lena Maria Klingvall from Sweden, who has been invited to visit Taiwan to attend the Republic of China centennial celebrations next year, presented a video to President Ma Ying-jeou in which she expresses her appreciation for the invitation, the Presidential Office said Sunday.
The singer said in her 90-second clip that she is very willing to accept the invitation and is greatly looking forward to attending the celebration.
Ma officially extended the invitation in a message broadcast in September on Swedish TV during a program about Klingvall.
Although the singer and artist was born without arms and her left leg is only half the length of her right, she enjoys life just like normal people.
She writes, cooks, drives, dances and is an excellent swimmer -- in fact, Ma lost a swimming race with her on one of her visits to Taipei between 2001 and 2005.
"I am a better swimmer now, but still nowhere near as good as you. I can only guarantee that next time, I will not lose again at the very beginning, " Ma said in his taped message.
"I see in Lena a real passion for life and extraordinary willpower", Ma said, adding that "she has not allowed her disability to get in the way of fulfilling her dreams."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor has no worries about visitor numbers at flora expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 17:33:43 (By Chen Hung-ching and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bian said Sunday that with the steady increase in the number of visitors to the 2010 Taipei Flora Expo, he is no longer worried about too few visitors, but rather about too many visitors.
Hau said that at present, visitor numbers at the expo are increasing rapidly.

The mayor said that contrary to allegations, he is not concerned about too few visitors. "In fact, I am more worried that too many visitors each day could compromise the quality of the experience," he said.

Hau was responding to reports by the Liberty Times newspaper citing parents who said their children's school have arranged for students to have two outdoor education sessions at the expo twice each semester and who questioned whether the expo wants to "make use of school students to help boost the number of visitors."

Asked if he is satisfied with the results of a survey showing that office workers who have visited the expo gave an average of 73.2 out of a perfect 100 points on the expo, Hau said that he accepts the views of the public.
But he also said he is gratified that most of the people are satisfied with the expo.

The expo kicked off its six-month run Nov. 6 with an opening ceremony in which Doeke Faber, president of the International Association of Horticultural Growers (AIPH) , praised it as the best he has seen in 50 years.
As of noon Sunday, the number of visitors to the expo had broken 1.4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top chefs to show tastes of Taiwan to Europeans
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 18:12:22 (By Tso Yu-fan and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Six award-winning Taiwanese chefs will visit Belgium to showcase some of the country's delicacies later this week, the Taipei Representative Office in the European Union and Belgium said Saturday.

The six chefs, who won a team award at the Food and Hotel Asia (FHA) Culinary Challenge (FCC) in Singapore in April, will present cuisine that integrates Taiwanese and local ingredients at a Brussels hotel Dec. 8-10.
The first dish on their scheduled menu is rice wine chicken soup, which is believed to warm the body and improve the circulation and energy flow.

For appetizers and cold dishes, the chefs will prepare drunken chicken with goji berries, mussels in five-flavor sauce, tomato slices in ginger thick soy sauce and celery salad with sesame sauce and wasabi.
Soybean crumbs, an ingredient unique to Taiwan, will be spread on steamed cod from northern European waters in a combined taste of Taiwan and Europe. Matrimony vine
To display the diversity of Taiwanese food, traditional Hakka dishes including sliced pork with preserved mustard greens and salt pork will also be on the table.
Taiwan's globally known drink, pearl milk tea, as well as pineapple cakes, will top off the feast.
The representative office said it has posted up posters at major subway stations and on trains around the city to promote the gourmet event, hoping to increase Taiwan's visibility in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taiwanese people acknowledged as low-income
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 18:24:40 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More people in Taiwan have been acknowledged as low-income following a law amendment to lower the property value threshold for public assistance, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Sunday.

Huang Pi-hsia, director of the MOI's Department of Social Affairs, quoted MOI tallies as indicating that the number of low-income households totaled 110,055 at the end of September this year, accounting for 267,717 people, marking a year-on-year increase of 10,000 households and 20,000-odd people, respectively.

The Public Assistance Act was amended in 2005 and again in 2008, relaxing the eligibility requirements for public assistance, including relaxing property assets calculation criteria and adjusting income calculation methods for indigenous households.

From this year, Huang said, the government has pushed the poverty line higher, allowing low-income households in Taiwan Province, Taipei County and Kaohsiung City with homes worth up to NT$3 million (US$100,000) to be entitled to public assistance, compared to the previous NT$2.6 million.

Meanwhile, the allowable level in Taipei City -- which has a much higher cost of living than other parts of the country -- was adjusted to NT$5.5 million, up from the previous NT$5 million, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- More people willing to tie knot

TEXT.P: Figures released by the Ministry of the Interior Saturday show that the number of couples tying the knot in the first 10 months of this year reached 112,020, an increase of nearly 20,000 from the same period of last year.
Among these couples, 15 percent were comprised of a local and a spouse from China, Hong Kong, Macao or other foreign country.

The figures also show a trend of people getting married later in life. In 2008, the average age of brides and bridegrooms was 29.5 and 32.9, respectively. By 2009, the average age for both had reached 30.3 and 33.9, respectively.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said that looking ahead, he is sure the number will set a new high in 2011.

Jiang said next year will be a good year for marriage, given the fact that local residents prefer to have "dragon boys" or "dragon girls" -- the next Year of the Dragon falls in 2012 according to the Chinese calendar.
This, coupled with the centennial anniversary of the Republic of China, as well as a steady economic recovery, means that Jiang "can hardly wait to see the record being broken."
The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has launched a series of campaigns and activities this year to encourage people to get married and have more children, which Jiang said have borne fruit.

Jiang said that local people usually get married according to traditional customs, noting that last year was a "lonely bird year, " considered inauspicious for marriage, so that the number of couples tying the knot decreased markedly.

However, Sept. 9, which translates to "everlasting" in Chinese, was an auspicious day, so that on that day, more than 6,000 couples took their vows, setting a single-day record for the last two decades.
Oct. 10 also conveys the sense of "a perfect 10" and on that day, 2,500 couples registered their marriages, far outnumbering last year's daily average of 300 couples.
Meanwhile, 100 couples will hold a mass wedding on the first day of the centennial of the Republic of China.
The mass wedding will be presided over by President Ma Ying-jeou, with Vice President Vincent Siew acting as a matchmaker. Commercial Times:

Although the MOI estimates that the number of couples getting married could reach over 140,000 this year, an increase of 20 percent from last year, it will still lag far behind the 170,000 couples annually prior to 2003.

An MOI official said that in addition to the custom factor, the drop in the marriage rate is related to the younger generation's ideas about the institution, while economic factors are also a major reason.
Due to the soaring cost of housing and declining wages, young people are more reluctant to tie the knot, the official said.
They simply cannot afford houses, spouses or children, he said.
The official said that the ministry has put a lot of effort into encouraging marriage and childbirth, but Taiwan's marriage rate is still slipping, while its birthrate is the lowest in the world.
"It is indeed a difficult problem to solve," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: On-screen 'post-it note' debuts at tech fair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 19:28:37 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Just as post-it notes are used by many people in daily life, it is now possible to use a modern version with a computer, a Taiwanese optronics company said Sunday.
Tainan-based U-PAX unveiled its flexible writing pad that day for the first time at the ICT Month fair in Taipei.

The "Paste and Play, " made of thin-film material that can be bent and cleaned with water, allows consumers to draw or sign signatures on computers using simply a USB connection to connect the device, U-PAX Manager Jason Yu told CNA at the fair.
"It is an environmentally friendly product that can be attached to a computer screen and removed repeatedly, like a post-it note," Yu said.

The paper-thin pad, sized from 3.5 to 7 inches, can also work with a micro- projector -- another emerging technology -- applying the use of an image projector in a handheld device to create a virtual keyboard or touch pad, he added.

The company is now in talks with buyers from Japan, India, Germany, New Zealand, Italy and Australia, and expects to sell the product in the first quarter of 2011 for a minimum price of NT$500 (US$16.55).
Coming on the heels of the increasing use of multi-touch tablet computers, the writing pad is expected to attract application developers to meet consumers' emerging demands, Yu said.
A local consumer surnamed Lee said he would like to buy a larger model of the product if it was available.
"It is interesting. I would stick one to my 12-inch notebook if there was a larger size," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials decline to speculate on combined elections

TEXT.P: Both Premier Wu Den-yih and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah declined to speculate Sunday on the probability that the next presidential and legislative elections will be held on the same day.
They said it is up to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to determine whether the next presidential poll should be combined with the next legislative elections.
The next presidential poll is scheduled to take place in March 2012 and the next legislative elections are likely to be held in December 2011 or January 2012, if the existing rules are followed.

Some ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators are planning to propose a combination of presidential and legislative polls in a bid to save electoral costs and reduce the impact of excessive social movement caused by people returning to their registered residences to vote.

CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you said the commission has decided to convene a meeting in January to discuss the matter, in the hope that a consensus can be reached in the first half of 2011 and the issue finalized by June at the latest.
CEC Chairwoman Chang Po-ya said the combined poll initiative involves many issues that will need to be addressed and deliberated over.

She said that if the government's proposed absentee voting system is introduced for the 2012 presidential election only, the holding of the next presidential and legislative polls in tandem will be impossible.
Lin Yi-shih, executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, called on the government to consider the issue with prudence.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has yet to put forward any concrete ideas about the issue. Nevertheless, Hung Yao-fu, a DPP vice secretary- general, said it would not be a blessing for society if the KMT schemes to implement combined presidential and legislative polls simply for its own political gains. (By Lin Shen-hsu, Hsieh Chia-chen, Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese calligrapher supports president's proposal on characters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:01:32 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A well-known Chinese calligrapher offered his support Sunday for President Ma Ying-jeou's advocacy of "understanding Chinese characters in general but using the simplified form for writing."

"As literate people, we should not abandon the traditional or complicated Chinese characters, as they are the best means of passing Chinese culture down through the generations, " said Lu Zhangshen, curator of the Beijing-based National Museum of China.
Lu, who is well-known for his calligraphy, was in Taiwan to hold an exhibition of his works at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei City.

Scholars in Taiwan and China have long argued over the merits of the two writing systems. Traditional characters are prevalent in Taiwan and Hong Kong, while simplified characters are used in China and Singapore.
Describing simplified characters as mostly adopting "a cursive form of writing, " Lu added that more and more people in China are getting to know traditional characters.
He also called on Taiwan and China to increase cultural exchanges, since they share the same cultural roots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan celebrates International Migrants Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:22:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The government pledged Sunday to protect the rights of migrants in the country and to promote cultural diversity, because Taiwan itself has always been a migrant country.

"From the days of Koxinga to 1949, when millions of people from China came here, to the present, when there are about 910,000 migrants in Taiwan, this place has always been a country of migrants, " Premier Wu Den-yih said at the opening ceremony of the International Migrants Day Carnival that was held in the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza.

The carnival wrapped up a series of events organized by the National Immigration Agency (NIA) to celebrate International Migrants Day Dec. 18, which was appointed in 2000 by the United Nations General Assembly to take into account the large and increasing number of migrants around the world.

The migrant population in Taiwan consists mainly of foreign spouses, of whom a large number come from Southeast Asian countries and China, and foreign workers, most of whom came from Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines.

"Being a stranger in a country one hardly understands can be frightening, " Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said, adding that "this is why new migrants in Taiwan need as much help as physically handicapped or under-privileged people."
In the past, the biggest challenges for migrants were the language barrier and adapting to a different culture and society, said Hsieh Li-kung, NIA director- general.
Thanks to the help and assistance of hundreds of local non-government organizations (NGOs) and local government agencies, those issues have become of less concern, he said.

With one in six marriages being transnational and one in eight babies born to families in which one spouse is a migrant, Hsieh said, the new challenges for Taiwan in the future will be creating jobs for migrants and providing help to children of migrant families in terms of education and development.

Citing the example of 12-year-old Penny Hsieh, who won the national women's tennis title in the age-12 group and whose mother is originally from Cambodia, the director-general said his agency has helped Hsieh to secure local sponsorship to cover her training expenses.

Hsieh, who comes from the central county of Changhua, attended the carnival, which had more than 100 booths, including food stands and stalls run by local government agencies and NGOs to promote awareness of cultural diversity.
Foreign representatives from the Marshall Islands, Peru, Haiti, The Gambia and the Philippines also attended the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired Taiwanese runners attend Singapore marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:41:11 (By Tang Pei-chun and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A group of visually impaired runners from Taiwan completed a marathon in Singapore Sunday, the first group of visually impaired Taiwanese runners to formally participate in an international race.
A team of 33 people, including 11 runners and their sighted guides, as well as 11 support personnel, took part in the Standard Chartered Marathon Singapore.

The group led by Chang Yuan-lung, director of the Exercise Association of the Visually Impaired in Taiwan, challenged themselves in either the 42-km full marathon or a half marathon that took place at the same time.
Undaunted by the scorching sun, the 11 pairs of runners, two of which ran in the full marathon and the other nine of which ran the half marathon, completed the races about six hours later.

TEXT.P: blue camp kept its grip on central and northern Taiwan in the Nov. 27 municipality elections, but the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) green camp grabbed more votes than the KMT. What does this election outcome mean?
It reflects the gap in economic and social development between northern and southern Taiwan, but it also reflects the manipulation carried out by politicians.
This regional divide has provoked unease because it has led to stereotypical political party choices by voters according to the region in which they live, resulting in an increasing rift in society.

In every election, we see voters who want to break the mode of either green or blue camps and try to inject new thought into politics, and although the number of so-called swing voters is not as great as the supporters of the two camps, they sometimes play a pivotal role.

The narrowing gap between the number of votes garnered by the two camps in two of the municipalities -- Taichung (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County) and Xinbei (an upgrade of Taipei County) -- reflects such a sentiment.

Yang, a former DPP member who ran as an independent after failing to get his party's nomination, has been recognized for his top performance in many polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preventive health care important in NHI reform: organization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 21:14:03 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Preventive health care is to be highlighted to ensure the sustainability of the national health insurance (NHI) system, a reform organization said in a public forum attended by Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang Sunday, two days before the second-generation NHI is expected to clear the legislative floor.

The fundamental problems of the NHI lie not only in the balance of revenue and expenditure, but also in payment models and the way the system is used, according to the Taiwan Association for Promoting Public Health (TAPPH), which organized the forum.

"The public and the media tend to be keeping a keen eye on the premium increases that will be brought in under the new system, while overlooking other more important issues in our health care system, " said Liu Mei-chun, chief executive officer of the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation.

Liu cited as an example the fact that many doctors take advantage of the current model of payment -- fee-for-service -- by offering unnecessary services to patients and then billing the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) for reimbursement, wasting medical resources.

In response to Liu's concerns, Yaung, who has an academic background in public health, said the NHI is planning to adopt a new capitation payment model next year in which health care providers will be paid a set amount for each insured person assigned to them, encouraging hospitals to place greater emphasis on preventive health care.

"It makes more sense if doctors can earn more by keeping people away from disease, " said Yaung, who was quoted in a media report in November as advocating that bonuses be paid to hospitals that successfully administer preventive health care.
So far, four hospitals have applied to join the new system.

Liu also noted that the existing system is overly hospital-centric. "We should focus on how well-trained public health nurses can work in partnership with the hospitals in terms of preventive health care," he said.

Chen Meei-shia, TAPPH president and a professor at the public health department of National Cheng Kung University's College of Medicine, said that as the objective of national health insurance is to keep everyone healthy, it is logical that more budget should be spent on preventive health work.

"At present, only about 3 percent of the national health and medical expenditure is allocated to preventive health care. However, 54 percent is spent on medicines and treatments for patients who are already sick, " said Chen, noting that most of the diseases can be prevented with appropriate measures.

Agreeing with the concept that "prevention is better than cure, " BNHI Director- General Day Guey-ing said that regrettably, there is no law that regulates how much resources should be distributed to preventive health work, making budget allocation difficult.

Acknowledging the plight and complexity of the NHI system, Yaung concluded that although the system in Taiwan is already much better than that in some other countries, it still needs to undergo constant reform.

The Legislative Yuan has set a Dec. 7 deadline for the passage of the second- generation health insurance system in which premium will be levied according to total household incomes instead of the individual salaries of the insured as is the case at present.

Although the new system is considered fairer and an essential move to make the cash-strapped NHI viable, there remain concerns as to whether the new system can actually address the core problems in the health system.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taiwanese people acknowledged as low-income
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 18:24:40 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More people in Taiwan have been acknowledged as low-income following a law amendment to lower the property value threshold for public assistance, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Sunday.

Huang Pi-hsia, director of the MOI's Department of Social Affairs, quoted MOI tallies as indicating that the number of low-income households totaled 110,055 at the end of September this year, accounting for 267,717 people, marking a year-on-year increase of 10,000 households and 20,000-odd people, respectively.

The Public Assistance Act was amended in 2005 and again in 2008, relaxing the eligibility requirements for public assistance, including relaxing property assets calculation criteria and adjusting income calculation methods for indigenous households.

From this year, Huang said, the government has pushed the poverty line higher, allowing low-income households in Taiwan Province, Taipei County and Kaohsiung City with homes worth up to NT$3 million (US$100,000) to be entitled to public assistance, compared to the previous NT$2.6 million.

Meanwhile, the allowable level in Taipei City -- which has a much higher cost of living than other parts of the country -- was adjusted to NT$5.5 million, up from the previous NT$5 million, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- More people willing to tie knot

TEXT.P: Figures released by the Ministry of the Interior Saturday show that the number of couples tying the knot in the first 10 months of this year reached 112,020, an increase of nearly 20,000 from the same period of last year.
Among these couples, 15 percent were comprised of a local and a spouse from China, Hong Kong, Macao or other foreign country.

The figures also show a trend of people getting married later in life. In 2008, the average age of brides and bridegrooms was 29.5 and 32.9, respectively. By 2009, the average age for both had reached 30.3 and 33.9, respectively.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said that looking ahead, he is sure the number will set a new high in 2011.

Jiang said next year will be a good year for marriage, given the fact that local residents prefer to have "dragon boys" or "dragon girls" -- the next Year of the Dragon falls in 2012 according to the Chinese calendar.
This, coupled with the centennial anniversary of the Republic of China, as well as a steady economic recovery, means that Jiang "can hardly wait to see the record being broken."
The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has launched a series of campaigns and activities this year to encourage people to get married and have more children, which Jiang said have borne fruit.

Jiang said that local people usually get married according to traditional customs, noting that last year was a "lonely bird year, " considered inauspicious for marriage, so that the number of couples tying the knot decreased markedly.

However, Sept. 9, which translates to "everlasting" in Chinese, was an auspicious day, so that on that day, more than 6,000 couples took their vows, setting a single-day record for the last two decades.
Oct. 10 also conveys the sense of "a perfect 10" and on that day, 2,500 couples registered their marriages, far outnumbering last year's daily average of 300 couples.
Meanwhile, 100 couples will hold a mass wedding on the first day of the centennial of the Republic of China.
The mass wedding will be presided over by President Ma Ying-jeou, with Vice President Vincent Siew acting as a matchmaker. Commercial Times:

Although the MOI estimates that the number of couples getting married could reach over 140,000 this year, an increase of 20 percent from last year, it will still lag far behind the 170,000 couples annually prior to 2003.

An MOI official said that in addition to the custom factor, the drop in the marriage rate is related to the younger generation's ideas about the institution, while economic factors are also a major reason.
Due to the soaring cost of housing and declining wages, young people are more reluctant to tie the knot, the official said.
They simply cannot afford houses, spouses or children, he said.
The official said that the ministry has put a lot of effort into encouraging marriage and childbirth, but Taiwan's marriage rate is still slipping, while its birthrate is the lowest in the world.
"It is indeed a difficult problem to solve," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: On-screen 'post-it note' debuts at tech fair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 19:28:37 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Just as post-it notes are used by many people in daily life, it is now possible to use a modern version with a computer, a Taiwanese optronics company said Sunday.
Tainan-based U-PAX unveiled its flexible writing pad that day for the first time at the ICT Month fair in Taipei.

The "Paste and Play, " made of thin-film material that can be bent and cleaned with water, allows consumers to draw or sign signatures on computers using simply a USB connection to connect the device, U-PAX Manager Jason Yu told CNA at the fair.
"It is an environmentally friendly product that can be attached to a computer screen and removed repeatedly, like a post-it note," Yu said.

The paper-thin pad, sized from 3.5 to 7 inches, can also work with a micro- projector -- another emerging technology -- applying the use of an image projector in a handheld device to create a virtual keyboard or touch pad, he added.

The company is now in talks with buyers from Japan, India, Germany, New Zealand, Italy and Australia, and expects to sell the product in the first quarter of 2011 for a minimum price of NT$500 (US$16.55).
Coming on the heels of the increasing use of multi-touch tablet computers, the writing pad is expected to attract application developers to meet consumers' emerging demands, Yu said.
A local consumer surnamed Lee said he would like to buy a larger model of the product if it was available.
"It is interesting. I would stick one to my 12-inch notebook if there was a larger size," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials decline to speculate on combined elections

TEXT.P: Both Premier Wu Den-yih and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah declined to speculate Sunday on the probability that the next presidential and legislative elections will be held on the same day.
They said it is up to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to determine whether the next presidential poll should be combined with the next legislative elections.
The next presidential poll is scheduled to take place in March 2012 and the next legislative elections are likely to be held in December 2011 or January 2012, if the existing rules are followed.

Some ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators are planning to propose a combination of presidential and legislative polls in a bid to save electoral costs and reduce the impact of excessive social movement caused by people returning to their registered residences to vote.

CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you said the commission has decided to convene a meeting in January to discuss the matter, in the hope that a consensus can be reached in the first half of 2011 and the issue finalized by June at the latest.
CEC Chairwoman Chang Po-ya said the combined poll initiative involves many issues that will need to be addressed and deliberated over.

She said that if the government's proposed absentee voting system is introduced for the 2012 presidential election only, the holding of the next presidential and legislative polls in tandem will be impossible.
Lin Yi-shih, executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, called on the government to consider the issue with prudence.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has yet to put forward any concrete ideas about the issue. Nevertheless, Hung Yao-fu, a DPP vice secretary- general, said it would not be a blessing for society if the KMT schemes to implement combined presidential and legislative polls simply for its own political gains. (By Lin Shen-hsu, Hsieh Chia-chen, Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese calligrapher supports president's proposal on characters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:01:32 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A well-known Chinese calligrapher offered his support Sunday for President Ma Ying-jeou's advocacy of "understanding Chinese characters in general but using the simplified form for writing."

"As literate people, we should not abandon the traditional or complicated Chinese characters, as they are the best means of passing Chinese culture down through the generations, " said Lu Zhangshen, curator of the Beijing-based National Museum of China.
Lu, who is well-known for his calligraphy, was in Taiwan to hold an exhibition of his works at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei City.

Scholars in Taiwan and China have long argued over the merits of the two writing systems. Traditional characters are prevalent in Taiwan and Hong Kong, while simplified characters are used in China and Singapore.
Describing simplified characters as mostly adopting "a cursive form of writing, " Lu added that more and more people in China are getting to know traditional characters.
He also called on Taiwan and China to increase cultural exchanges, since they share the same cultural roots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan celebrates International Migrants Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:22:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The government pledged Sunday to protect the rights of migrants in the country and to promote cultural diversity, because Taiwan itself has always been a migrant country.

"From the days of Koxinga to 1949, when millions of people from China came here, to the present, when there are about 910,000 migrants in Taiwan, this place has always been a country of migrants, " Premier Wu Den-yih said at the opening ceremony of the International Migrants Day Carnival that was held in the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza.

The carnival wrapped up a series of events organized by the National Immigration Agency (NIA) to celebrate International Migrants Day Dec. 18, which was appointed in 2000 by the United Nations General Assembly to take into account the large and increasing number of migrants around the world.

The migrant population in Taiwan consists mainly of foreign spouses, of whom a large number come from Southeast Asian countries and China, and foreign workers, most of whom came from Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines.

"Being a stranger in a country one hardly understands can be frightening, " Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said, adding that "this is why new migrants in Taiwan need as much help as physically handicapped or under-privileged people."
In the past, the biggest challenges for migrants were the language barrier and adapting to a different culture and society, said Hsieh Li-kung, NIA director- general.
Thanks to the help and assistance of hundreds of local non-government organizations (NGOs) and local government agencies, those issues have become of less concern, he said.

With one in six marriages being transnational and one in eight babies born to families in which one spouse is a migrant, Hsieh said, the new challenges for Taiwan in the future will be creating jobs for migrants and providing help to children of migrant families in terms of education and development.

Citing the example of 12-year-old Penny Hsieh, who won the national women's tennis title in the age-12 group and whose mother is originally from Cambodia, the director-general said his agency has helped Hsieh to secure local sponsorship to cover her training expenses.

Hsieh, who comes from the central county of Changhua, attended the carnival, which had more than 100 booths, including food stands and stalls run by local government agencies and NGOs to promote awareness of cultural diversity.
Foreign representatives from the Marshall Islands, Peru, Haiti, The Gambia and the Philippines also attended the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired Taiwanese runners attend Singapore marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/10 20:41:11 (By Tang Pei-chun and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A group of visually impaired runners from Taiwan completed a marathon in Singapore Sunday, the first group of visually impaired Taiwanese runners to formally participate in an international race.
A team of 33 people, including 11 runners and their sighted guides, as well as 11 support personnel, took part in the Standard Chartered Marathon Singapore.

Chang, who is himself visually impaired, expressed hope that more people like him in Taiwan will participate in outdoor activities.
Despite being blind, taking part in the race was like being fully sighted, said Lee Kun-ming, who completed the race in 4.5 hours.

All of the runners paid for the trip to Singapore out of their own pockets at a cost of more than NT$30,000 (US$990) per person. They voiced hope that their action will draw more attention to the visually impaired from the government and society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 6, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."
