DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Yani Tseng clinches LPGA Player of the Year award
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/06/10 12:16:54 (By Zep Hu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Yani Tseng won the LPGA Player of the Year 2010 award in Orlando, Florida Sunday, becoming the first golfer from Taiwan to do so.
Tseng said she was overwhelmed when the announcement was made at the end of the LPGA Tour Championship at the Grand Cypress Golf Club.

"I never thought I would be holding this trophy, " she said. "I was always holding the trophy in a tournament, but just one week, but this feels like I'm holding for a year. I've been working so hard to chase this title."

Tseng won three titles this year -- the Kraft Nabisco Championship in April, the RICOH Women's British Open in August and the LPGA Northwest Arkansas Championship in September. Two of them were majors.

The 21-year-old was a front-runner for the Player of the Year award coming into this week, but had to look over her shoulder at Cristie Kerr of the United States and Na Yeon Choi of South Korea who were both close contenders.

Teeing off early on Sunday, Tseng managed a 1-under-par 71, but was relegated to spectator status as Kerr and Choi came down the stretch with opportunities to win the LPGA Tour Championship and stand in line for the Player of the Year award.
However, Tseng, who finished 21st on 293, took the award as neither Kerr nor Choi could edge past her despite their top-six finishes.
"It's my honor to be the Player of the Year and when it was announced that 'Yani Tseng is Player of the Year, ' the emotion just -- it's kind of overwhelming," a teary-eyed Tseng said.
In an interview after receiving the award, Tseng said that 2010 was a fabulous year for her and that she was most grateful for the firm support of her parents in her pursuit of career excellence.

"I really love them and want to thank them for supporting me... It's very tough for them to stay here with me, but they are always supporting me. They never say they are tired of anything. They just care about me," an emotional Tseng said.
On her off-season plans, Tseng said she will take part-time English classes.
"I need to improve my English. I will go to English class in the morning and practice (golf) in the afternoon," she added.
Sweden's Maria Hjorth fired a par-72 final round on Sunday to capture her first LPGA title since 2007, winning the season-ending LPGA Tour Championship by one stroke from South Korean Amy Yang.

Tseng said earlier this year that winning a career grand slam is her next goal. Of her five LPGA titles won during her career, three have been majors -- the LPGA Championship in 2008, the Kraft Nabisco Championship and the RICOH Women's British Open, leaving the U.S. Women's Open as the one major she has yet to win. According to the LPGA website, only seven players in history have completed career grand slams.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Fire & Marine outlook stable: Taiwan Ratings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 12:58:49 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Ratings on Monday confirmed its "twAA-" rating for Taiwan Fire & Marine Insurance Co. Ltd. (TFMI) , based on the insurer's financial strength and counterparty credit, and said the outlook on the rating is stable.
This is a reflection of the insurance company's strong capitalization and its above-average underwriting performance, Taiwan Ratings said.
The stable outlook on the company was based on the anticipation that its strong capitalization will enable it to maintain its current profile, Taiwan Ratings said.
The ratings agency said it also expects the insurer will continue with its prudent business growth strategy in a highly competitive environment.

"We may raise the rating if TFMI can continue to expand its franchise to personal lines and at same time maintain its above-average performance along with a more prudent investment mix, " Taiwan Ratings said.
However, TFMI is also faced with some counterbalancing factors, including its sensitivity to market risks as a result of its aggressive investment allocation in the local market.
According to Taiwan Ratings, TFMI has allocated massive funds in the property and stock market, which are generally exposed to higher risks that other investments.
In 2009, investments in the property and stock market accounted for more than 50 percent of TFMI's total investments, the ratings agency said.
Taiwan Ratings said there have been concerns that such an aggressive investment allocation may compromise TFMI's performance.
"We may lower the ratings if the insurer pursues a more aggressive investment strategy, which could eventually hurt its capitalization," Taiwan Ratings said.
TFMI, capitalized at NT$3.64 billion (US$119 million) , posted NT$809.41 million in net profit in 2009, compared with NT$138.42 million recorded in 2008.
Taiwan Ratings is a subsidiary of Standard & Poor's in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largan Precision November sales hit record high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 13:00:25 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Largan Precision Co. Ltd., the world's largest cell phone camera lens maker, said Monday its sales in November hit a record high for the sixth consecutive month on an increase in shipments.
Last month, Largan posted NT$1.29 billion (US$42.61 million) in sales, up 2 percent from October and up 37 percent from a year earlier.
In the 11 months to November, Largan said, it recorded NT$11.03 billion in sales, up 52 percent year-on-year.
"Demand for consumer electronic products, in particular smartphones, remained strong," Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
"Companies like Largan are no doubt the beneficiaries of the market trend," he said.
In addition to the rising shipments, Chiang said, Largan has also seen benefits from its strategy to develop high-end products, which refer to 5 megapixel lenses or more advanced models.
"The high-end products have boosted the company's average sales price. I expect Largan will again break its monthly sales record in December," Chiang said.

At an investors conference in late October, Largan Chairman Chen Shih-ching said 5-8 megapixel lenses accounted for more than 50 percent of the company's total sales in the third quarter, and that the ratio was expected to rise in the fourth quarter.
Eight megapixel lenses alone account for almost 10 percent of the company's sales, market observers said.

They said investors have been upbeat about the company's earnings outlook on high hopes that the second generation of Apple's iPad will be equipped with a camera, which will further boost Largan's shipments.
"Such optimism has largely factored in Largan's share price as the stock has had a strong showing recently," Chiang said.
Since the end of October, Largan shares have risen more than 20 percent.
However, Chiang said due to the significant gains, investors had better exercise caution when trading the stock as there is limited room for upside.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president has to stay behind bars for 17.5 years: court
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 13:23:56 (By Lai Yu-chia and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: In a High Court ruling Monday, it was decided that former President Chen Shui- bian's prison term should amount to 17 and a half years.
In addition, the court has determined that the fines on Chen, who has been convicted and jailed on corruption charges in two separate cases, would total NT$154 million (US$5.05 million).

On Nov. 11, the Supreme Court sentenced the former president to 11 years in prison for taking bribes in a land deal during his time in office and also gave Chen an eight-year sentence in another bribery case. The rulings were the first final convictions in a string of corruption cases implicating Chen and his wife.
According to the current law, the Taiwan High Court is authorized to determine whether the combined 19-year sentence should be served concurrently or consecutively.
After careful review, a collegial panel at the high court ruled that Chen's total prison time should be 17 and a half years, a court spokesman said.

Chen, the first president from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, began serving his prison sentence at a jail in Taoyuan County Dec. 2, making history as Taiwan's first former head of state to be jailed.

His wife Wu Shu-jen has also been given a combined 19-year sentence in the same two bribery cases. Judicial authorities will decide later today how and where the wheelchair-bound former first lady should serve her time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Contradiction in cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: 12/06/10 14:34:48 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Issues relating to medical cooperation between Taiwan and China will be on the agenda of the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks scheduled for late December in Taipei.

The Taiwan government has said that the agreement will be negotiated on the understanding that Chinese medical personnel will not be allowed to practice in Taiwan and Chinese investment in Taiwan hospitals will not be permitted.

However, in the cross-strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement that was signed in June, China agreed to allow Taiwanese doctors to practice on the mainland and to permit Taiwanese investment in new hospitals in its territories.
This lack of balance in the negotiations between the two sides has occurred from time to time in recent years.

Besides that, the cross-strait talks have often hit a wall on topics that involve international regulations because China insists that any agreement between the two sides should not be regarded as a pact between two countries, in line with its "one-China" policy.
Moreover, many of the cross-strait agreements exist only on paper and do not actually benefit the people on the two sides.

For example, Taiwan signed a food safety agreement with China in 2008 and a pact for cooperation on safety checks on agricultural products in 2009. However, to date, few people in Taiwan have confidence in the safety of food and agricultural products from China. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close above 8,700 points
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 15:35:17 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.90 percent to stand above 8,700 points Monday on expectations that the United States will further ease its liquidity to boost its economy, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 78.22 percent to 8,702.23, after moving between 8,675.45 and 8,718.53, on turnover of NT$140.95 billion (US$4.66 billion).
The market opened up 0.60 percent and the momentum extended throughout the trade as investors held high hopes that foreign funds will keep flowing into the region, dealers said.
U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke said Friday more
quantitative easing is "certainly possible."

Buying focused on old economy stocks as investors are anticipating that further fund inflows will lift the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar and in turn boost value of their domestic assets, the dealers said.
A total of 2,387 stocks closed up and 1,885 down, while 351 remained unchanged.

The textile sector scored the highest gains, rising 4.3 percent. Financial firms rose 2.2 percent, paper and pulp stocks added 1.8 percent, foodstuffs gained 1.6 percent and construction shares closed up 1.5 percent.
The plastics and chemical sector rose 1.2 percent, the cement sector gained 0.6 percent and the machinery and electronic sector closed up 0.3 percent.
"Judging from the rise of the New Taiwan dollar, I suspect foreign institutional investors moved more funds into the bourse today," Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said.
"Basically, we are in a liquidity-driven market," he said.
Huang said the market could challenge the 8,800 point mark soon.

Bernanke's comments on the U.S. possible easing of liquidity prompted investors at home and abroad to leave behind the sluggishness of the U.S. economy, which reported a rise in unemployment for November, dealers said.
"What's on investors' minds now is that higher liquidity will boost share prices. Such sentiment is simply a knee-jerk reaction to Bernanke's comments," Huang said.

"In the short term, the local market is expected to continue to ride the upside wave until investors calm down and start to think about how bad the U.S. economy could be and why it needs further fund injections," he said.

Among the old economy stocks, the textile firm Far Eastern New Century rose 6.18 percent to NT$49.00, Wei-Chuan Foods increased 3.22 percent to NT$35.30 and Shihlin Paper gained 3.21 percent to reach NT$77.20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan thorniest issue in U.S.-China ties

TEXT.P: Classified U.S. government documents newly released by the whistle-blowing website Wikileaks said Taiwan was the biggest issue holding up the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and China 30 years ago.
They also show that Taiwan continues to remain the toughest issue between the two countries despite improving cross-Taiwan Strait ties since the election of President Ma Ying-jeou in March 2008.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Among the leaked files was a classified document dated Jan. 6, 2009 from the U.S. embassy in Beijing, titled "Looking at the Next 30 years of the U.S.-China relationship."
The document said Taiwan would remain a delicate topic in U.S.-China relations for the foreseeable future.

"We should continue to support Taiwan and Mainland efforts to reduce tension by increasing Taiwan's 'international space' and reducing Mainland's military build-up across from Taiwan, " read the document, which was classified by then-U.S. Ambassador to China Clark T. Randt.

Another document from the U.S. embassy in Beijing, titled "Hu Jintao in charge of Tibet policy; leadership unified, buoyed and constrained by nationalist sentiment, " said that in the years to come, U.S. defense experts would need to closely monitor China's contingency plans.
The U.S. also needed to use every diplomatic and strategic tool it had to prevent China from making moves to intimidate Taiwan, the document advised. (Dec. 6, 2010).
China Times:
The leaked document regarding Tibet said Chinese President Hu Jintao had "great confidence" when it came to Tibet, putting him in a virtually unassailable position.

There might be room within the Chinese leadership to express differences with Hu on issues such as Taiwan, economic development or political reform, but not on Tibet, according to the leaked files posted on the Wikileaks website.

The document further stated that a range of contacts had acknowledged that there were differences of opinion within the Communist Party of China and among elites regarding Tibet, though none believed this reflected any disagreement among the top leadership.
Hu Jintao was "completely" in charge of China's Tibet policy, it said.

The document further revealed that Tibet policy was more sensitive for China's leadership than even Taiwan, noting that despite its rhetoric, Beijing had tacitly accepted the involvement of the United States in Taiwan but could never accept the "interference" of foreign powers in Tibet. (Dec. 6, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy tops Taiwan's seven core interests: MAC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 16:59:25 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Democracy, sovereignty, security and the right of free choice on the future of cross-Taiwan Strait relations rank among Taiwan's seven core interests in engaging with China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Monday.

The right to meaningful participation in the international community, the right not to be discriminated against, and the right of the disadvantaged to survive were also key interests, said Taiwan's top China policy-maker at an international symposium on "Cross-Strait Interactions and Power Relations in East Asia."
Democracy is Taiwan's "basic prerequisite in addressing cross-strait relations, " said Lai at the seminar, organized by the MAC and the Institute for National Policy Research.
"We are absolutely adamant that no development in cross-strait relations and no connection between us will or can be allowed to harm the democratic way of life of the Taiwanese people."
That is why Taiwan's people should be able to freely decide their own future, she said.

Commenting on discrimination against the country, Lai said that Taiwan, as a major trading nation and member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , had the right to enjoy fair competitive trade conditions.
"That includes the right to participate in regional economic integration and the right to negotiate and sign economic agreements with our main trading partners," she said.
Lai highlighted two significant factors that have made an impact on East Asia's situation -- China's rise and U.S. President Barack Obama's strategy of renewed U.S. engagement in Asia.
"Compared to the exchanges of artillery fire between the two Koreas, the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait stands out as all the more precious an achievement."
But that achievement has not come easily, she contended.

"We consider the people to be the main actors in cross-strait relations. Only if we understand, respect and safeguard the core interests of Taiwan's people will cross-strait relations be able to develop in a more stable forward direction, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese scholar sees signs of shift in China-DPP relations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 17:27:18 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Chinese expert on Taiwan affairs said Sunday there are "signals" of what he called positive development of relations between Beijing and Taiwan's pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The comment by Liu Guoshen, head of the Taiwan Research Institute of Xiamen University, came in the wake of a recent statement by DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen that her party will establish a think tank with the primary aim of engaging in dialogue with China,
The DPP, Taiwan's main opposition party, has since its establishment in 1986 advocated independence for Taiwan and refused to have any official dialogue with Beijing on China's terms.
The Kuomintang (KMT), which returned to power in 2008, has since adopted a more China-friendly policy.
Lin said on the sidelines of a symposium in Shenzhen that in order to play a bigger role in the development of cross-strait relations, the DPP has to "reposition" itself.

This is imperative in light of the fact that the KMT's shift from hostility towards China to rapprochement has contributed greatly to maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Straits and bringing greater prosperity to the people on both sides, he said.
The DPP needs to rationally talk with the Communist Party of China (CPC), said Liu, whose institute is regarded as an authority on Taiwan affairs.

However, it does not necessarily mean that the CPC and DPP would have to agree on matters of mutual concern in the short term, he said. Rather it calls for contact between the CPC and the DPP and "exploration," sooner rather than later, he said.
He added that it would be a blessing for the people of both Taiwan and China if the DPP think tank could engage in talks with Beijing soon to discuss how CPC- DPP exchanges should be conducted.
Political pundits have said that the DPP will have to adjust its China policy prior to Taiwan's 2012 presidential election in order to win the support of an increasing number of swing voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election-eve shooting linked to land deal dispute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 17:33:41 (By Lin Shen-hsu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A dispute over the profits from land deals was the main reason behind an election-eve shooting late last month, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Monday.

The minister, who oversees the National Police Agency, told lawmakers that police investigators have found that the suspect intended to kill Kuomintang (KMT) Xinbei City Council candidate Chen Hung-yuan but ended up shooting two other people.

The assailant, Lin Cheng-wei, fired a single shot from a handgun, injuring Sean Lien, son of the KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan, and killing a bystander, Jiang said in a briefing to legislators on the investigation into the Nov. 26 shooting at a campaign rally.
Lin, whose nickname is Horse Face, told investigators that he had a dispute with Chen's father, Chen Ming-hsiung, over commissions for brokering land transactions.
Lin reportedly told the police that he tried to shoot Chen Hung-yuan in a fit of anger because the candidate's father had refused to settle the dispute.
Because Lien is a member of the KMT Central Committee and is from a prominent family, it was widely speculated that the incident was politically motivated.

According to the police investigation report, the right-handed Lin grabbed Sean Lien's right collar with his left hand and fired the gun with his right. Sean Lien tried to duck when he was grabbed but the bullet entered his left cheek and exited near his right temple.
A 29-year-old man Huang Yun-sheng, who was sitting 31 meters from the campaign stage, was hit in the right eye by the same bullet, the investigators reported.
Jiang said the bullet found in Huang's head was fired from Lin's German-made P220 .90 handgun.
When Chen was immediately arrested on the scene of the shooting, he was found to be carrying the gun and 48 rounds of ammunition in two cartridges.
The findings of the investigation were confirmed by video footage from the scene of the incident, the police said.
Jiang quoted the police report as saying that based on Lin's cell phone records and witness accounts, it was determined that the assailant had no accomplices on the scene of the crime.

The police are now examining Lin's bank records and those of the Chen family and checking the inter-personal relationships among the people concerned to try to determine whether the shooting was instigated by someone other than the suspect.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 17:38:36 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, dropping NT$0.12 to close at NT$30.625.
Turnover totaled US$643 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.745 and moved to a low of NT$30.110 before rebounding.

Dealers said the Taiwan dollar was boosted by gains in the local stock market, which were driven by high hopes that the U.S. Federal Reserve would engage in an additional round of quantitative easing to boost the economy.
Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke said in an interview with CBS's 60 Minutes that further quantitative easing was "certainly possible."
Quantitative easing refers to the practice by governments of creating money out of thin air by buying back debt that they have issued.
The Fed has opted for the unorthodox tactic because it has already lowered interest rates -- its normal policy tool -- to near-zero levels.
Dealers said that once the U.S. central bank pumped more funds into the economy, foreign institutional investors were expected to move money into Asian markets, including Taiwan.
The benchmark weighted index rose 0.90 percent in heavy trade to close above the 8,700 point level Monday.
Taiwan's central bank intervened again in late trading to help the U.S. dollar regain most of its early losses and send its value above NT$30.50, dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical school students know little about risks of smoking: DOH poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 17:42:21 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Medical school students in Taiwan lack proper knowledge about the risks associated with smoking and how to help people quit the habit, according to the results of a survey released by the Department of Health (DOH) Monday.

The survey, conducted in 2009 among university juniors in the departments of medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, and nursing, found that although 83.5 percent of them learn in school about the health risks of smoking, only 35.2 percent are aware of the effects of second-hand smoke.
Furthermore, 28 percent are under the false impression that lighter brands of cigarettes are less dangerous to human health, according to the poll conducted by the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion.
The survey also found that medical school students are being poorly trained to help patients quit smoking, said BHP's director-general Chiou Shu-ti.
Only 11.6 percent of the respondents had attended formal courses on how to help people quit, she said.
"This is a wake-up call for us, " said Lai Chi-wan, chairman of the Ministry of Education (MOE)'s Medical Education Committee.
Lai said that he was previously not aware of the issue but will present the problem to other members of the committee and devise a comprehensive smoking education plan for medical school students.
Doctors should serve as role models for their patients and have a social responsibility to take care of their patients' health as well as their own, he said.
His point of view was shared by Huang Song-lih, secretary-general of Taiwan International Medical Alliance, who said that doctors play an important role in preventive medicine.
"If they can approach patients who smoke and offer immediate help, there would be fewer smoking-related illnesses, he said.
As of June 25 this year, 73 of the 163 university campuses in Taiwan were smoke- free, thanks to the joint efforts of the MOE and DOH, according to Lai.
The rate of smoking among students is expected to drop as a result of this policy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA Air to launch flights to more Chinese cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 18:07:00 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, one of Taiwan's leading international carriers, said Monday it will launch flights to more destinations in China later this month to capitalize on the booming cross-Taiwan Strait tourism business.

Along with its subsidiary Uni Airways, EVA Air said it would fly between Taipei and Zhengzhou in Henan Province twice a week from Dec. 10 and between Taipei and Jinan in Shandong Province once a week from Dec. 18, the carrier said.

Starting from Dec. 20, EVA Air will also operate one flight a week between Taichung and Ningbo in Zhejiang Province to add to its two flights per week between Taipei and Ningbo and one flight a week between Kaohsiung and Ningbo.
The carrier said it would become the first Taiwanese airline to fly between Taipei and Jinan once the new services are launched.

In an initial phase, the Taipei-Jinan route will be operated on a charter flight basis, offering all of the seats to travel agencies located in China, because of the strong interest people in the province have shown toward visiting Taiwan, the carrier said.
EVA Air added that it could increase the number of charters in the future and eventually operate the route on a regularly scheduled basis.
The airline expected the load factors on the Taipei-Jinan and Taipei-Zhengzhou route to both be at least 80 percent.
Zhengzhou, which ranks among China's top eight ancient cities, has long been a tourism attraction, but EVA Air also anticipates interest from business travelers.

Many major Taiwanese companies, such as Formosa Plastics, Want Want Holdings, Uni-President Enterprises and Hon Hai Group, have set up footholds in Henan, leading the carrier to forecast that business passengers will account for about 20 percent of the customers on the route.
The new flights will expand EVA Air's cross-Taiwan Strait service to 77 round- trip flights between Taiwan and 17 destinations in China per week.

DOC.HEADLINE: After 'miracle,' shooting victim gives thanks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 18:14:54 (By Li Shu-hua and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee member Sean Lien, who was shot in the face during an election-eve campaign rally on Nov. 26, thanked doctors and others Monday for saving him after he came within 0.5 centimeters of being killed.

In a statement released by Lien the morning after being discharged from the hospital late Sunday night, he expressed his gratitude to all those who helped him miraculously get through "a life-threatening crisis, " in which the distance between life and death was less than 0.5 cm.
"It was in such a narrow space that I felt the greatest warmth and caring in my life, " the son of former Vice President Lien Chan said in the statement.

Lien was shot while stumping for a KMT Xinbei City Council candidate at a campaign rally on the eve of the Nov. 27 municipality elections. Another victim died from the same bullet that traveled through Lien's face.

The bullet entered Lien's left cheek and exited from below his right temple, fracturing his cheekbone, said National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , where he was treated until being discharged Sunday night.
The high-profile shooting has drawn considerable media attention because it is believed to have had an impact on some of the five mayoral races being contested, of which the KMT won three.
Though the shooting suspect was immediately apprehended, the police have yet to determine his true motive for shooting Lien or whether Lien was even his intended target.

Besides offering his thanks to NTUH's medical team and well-wishers, Lien specifically thanked Liu Chen-nan, a former leader of a gang who was on hand to stop the gunman from firing a second shot at Lien, saving his life.
"Now that the heavens have ordained that I live on, I think it means I should be a good man who helps others. I promise I will work hard toward that goal," he said in the statement.
Lien arrived home at midnight Sunday. He has to go back to the hospital for follow-up checkups and medication.

DOC.HEADLINE: HTC November sales hit record high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 18:26:36 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: HTC Corp, a Taiwan smartphone maker, said its sales in November hit another record high as global demand remained strong.
In November, HTC posted NT$38.48 billion (US$1.27 billion) in sales, up 18.65 percent from October and up 168.39 percent from a year earlier.
In the first 11 months of this year, HTC's sales rose 88.43 percent year-on-year to NT$245.68 billion.
Market observers noted that the company's November sales were higher than a previous market estimate of NT$35 billion.
They said that with the strong global demand likely to continue, it is very possible that the company will meet its goal of generating NT$100 billion in sales for the fourth quarter of this year.
In addition, HTC also expects its shipments to rise to 9 million units in the October-December period from 6.8 million units in Q3 when it recorded sales of NT$75.85 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health insurance premiums will drop for 60% of insured: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 18:51:27 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: About 60 percent of the people covered by national health insurance (NHI) will have lower premiums when a second-generation NHI system is implemented, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Monday.
"The new system will be to the advantage of more instead of fewer people" since most people in Taiwan have dependent family members and are salaried employees, Yaung said.
According to DOH data on NNI premium rates in the past two years, some 60 percent of the insured would have lower payments once the new insurance system is introduced, he added.
The NHI system proposes that insurance premiums be calculated based on total household income instead of individual salaries of the insured, as is the case at present.
However, opposition party lawmakers have raised concerns that the majority of people would have to pay higher premiums under the new system.
The Legislative Yuan has set Dec. 7 as its deadline for passing the DOH-proposed amendments to the existing NHI Act, which would allow for the new premium system to take effect.

But there are 20 clauses in the bill that have not yet been put to a vote. In addition, lawmakers from across party lines have expressed reservations about the fairness of the proposed formula for calculating premiums.

At a press conference held Monday by KMT lawmakers, Yaung said the amendments are aimed at expanding care for the disadvantaged, and include a premium exemption for severely disabled people and unemployed aboriginal people over 55 and under 19 years of age.
In addition, the number of people who would be exempt from premium payments would increase further if the proposed amendments to the Public Assistance Act are also passed, Yaung noted.
Under the amendments, low-income households are not required to pay health insurance premiums and the bar for being defined as a low income family has been lowered, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-NSC head calls for 'Taiwan consensus,' cross-party dialogue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 19:03:41 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Su Chi, a former secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), called for a "Taiwan consensus" and much-needed dialogue between domestic and cross-Taiwan Strait political rivals Monday.

Su, who resigned from the NSC in February but remains a close confidant of President Ma Ying-jeou, encouraged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to engage in dialogue with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to form a Taiwan consensus that could enable Taiwan to negotiate with China boldly and confidently.

Speaking on Taiwan's external and internal relations at an international symposium, Su said the Taiwan-China-United States triangular relationship, which he called the "Big Triangle," had been stable over the past two and a half years under Ma.

But the "Small Triangle" -- describing relations among the KMT, the DPP and China's Communist Party -- had not been as stable mainly because "the DPP has not been talking to the KMT and the CPC" at all, he said.

Part of the problem, he said, was that the DPP's elite had yet to forge a consensus on the pro-independence party's China policy, with some insisting on anti-China positions and others taking more moderate stances.

He contended that incumbent DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and former President Chen Shui-bian had not made a big enough effort to forge a consensus on the issue, and he said the lack of a DPP consensus was "actually dragging Taiwan down."

Su, who coined the formula for dealing with China as the "1992 Consensus" -- also known as "one China, different interpretations" -- advised the DPP to form a party consensus before eventually communicating with China's Communist Party.

He acknowledged that internal dialogue between the KMT and DPP could be difficult because of Taiwan's domestic political past and the level of politicization, but he still expressed a certain level of optimism.
Some DPP elites have begun to realize that the world was changing and that people's needs were changing as well, he said.
"They also have realized that Taiwan independence may be desirable, but not plausible, " said Su, now a professor at Tamkang University.

The KMT and the DPP might not agree on everything, "but at least we can agree on something, " Su said, adding that the lack of communication will be dangerous because it could cause misunderstandings.
Su said that while the two parties have not talked to each other or respected each other in the past, Taiwan's democracy has matured, making dialogue possible.
He welcomed Tsai's plans to establish a think tank to help formulate the DPP's China policy and policies on external relations.

Looking at future cross-strait development, the former national intelligence chief said he had four major concerns -- the "one-China" principle, Taiwan's international space, confidence-building measures and a peace agreement.
The "one-China" principle, he said, would be the key because the other three issues were all related to it.
Taiwan's engagement with China before the critical 2012 presidential election is expected to remain focused on economic issues, with political issues unlikely to move onto the agenda, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's consumer prices up 1.53 percent in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 19:38:11 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index in November saw its biggest year-on-year leap in nine months, driven largely by higher food prices, the government said Monday.

Inflation rose 1.53 percent in November compared with the same month a year earlier, the largest gain since a rise of 2.34 percent posted in February, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said.
November's CPI also rose 0.21 percent from October largely on higher clothing costs and transportation spending, the DGBAS said.

In November, food prices rose 3.65 percent from a year earlier, with vegetable prices up 26.21 percent year-on-year, fish prices up 7.54 percent, and the prices of milk and related products up 5.45 percent, the DGBAS said.
The prices of eggs and fruit, however, fell during the same period by 2.06 percent and 1.42 percent respectively, it added.

Last month, the core price index, which excludes vegetables, fruit, fish and energy prices, rose 0.91 percent from a year earlier, while the wholesale price index (WPI) gained 2.43 percent year-on-year on higher chemical, base metal and iron ore prices, the agency said.
Month-on-month, the November core price index rose 0.21 percent from October, while the WPI fell 0.04 percent from a month earlier due to a rising Taiwan dollar, it said.
In the first 11 months of this year, the CPI rose 0.94 percent from a year earlier, the core price index added 0.40 percent and the WPI gained 5.76 percent, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Airlines to add New Zealand as destination next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 19:59:42 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: China Airlines said Monday that it will become Taiwan's only carrier serving New Zealand next year when it launches flights to Auckland, after rival EVA Airways canceled its service there two years ago.

China Airlines currently operates three flights a week between Taipei and Brisbane, Australia, using an Airbus 330-300, and the airline will add New Zealand to its list of destinations by extending the route to Auckland on Jan. 1, 2011.
Traveling to New Zealand became easier for Taiwanese nationals in 2009 after Taiwanese nationals were granted visa-free treatment to the country.

China Airlines will offer special travel packages to mark the launch of the new route, including trips in Auckland, New Zealand's largest city, and Rotorua, a tourist attraction known for its native Maori culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: After close loss in Taichung, Su back as DPP secretary-general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 20:27:36 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Su Jia-chyuan, who was narrowly defeated in the Taichung mayoral race on Nov. 27, agreed to serve again as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's secretary general as part of the party's post-election shake-up of key posts on Monday.

Su, whose showing against incumbent Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu of the Kuomintang exceeded expectations, will assume his "old post" on Dec. 13, DPP spokesman Lin You-chang said. Su was the party's secretary-general before he entered the mayoral race.

Su replaces Wu Nai-jen, who tendered his resignation after the DPP lost three of the five mayoral races being contested in late November. Wu will become the chief executive of the DPP's think tank under the New Frontier Foundation.

The think tank will focus its efforts on preparing a set of policy proposals that will likely become the party's platform in the 2012 presidential election. Tsai has said that to win the presidential election, the party will need a China policy that stabilizes Taiwan's relations with China.
Six senior DPP officials are expected to step down from their posts to run in the next Legislative Yuan election, setting the stage for Tsai to recruit new blood into the party's key positions.

Those said to be eyeing legislative seats include Lee Kun-tse, Tsai's special assistant; party spokesmen Tsai Chi-chang and Lin You-chang; Department of International Affairs Director Hsiao Bi-khim; and Department of Hakka Affairs Director Yang Chang-chen.

Tsai will also have to find a new director of the Department of Organizational Development after Liu Chao-hao's departure and a new director of the Department of Indigenous People's Affairs after incumbent Icyang Parod won a seat on the Taipei City Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges lenience in jailing of former first lady
DOC.DATELINE: Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 21:17:22 (By Lee Ming-tsung, Lai Yu-chia & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called for leniency Monday in carrying out the sentence of wheelchair-bound former first lady Wu Shu-jen.
"The prison authorities should refuse to jail Wu in accordance with Article 11 of the Prison Execution Act, " said Guan Bi-ling, head of the DPP caucus, at a press conference.
Guan asked that Wu, who has been paralyzed from the waist down for over 20 years, serve her sentence by remaining confined at her home rather than be sent to a local jail.
Guan's call came hours before the Justice Ministry convened a special meeting to address the thorny issue of how Wu should be jailed.
Citing statistics, Guan said that over the past five years, around 760 seriously ill convicts were not kept behind bars under the act.
Wu and her husband, former President Chen Shui-bian, were each sentenced to a total of 19 years in jail last month by the Supreme Court for taking bribes while Chen was president.
They were found guilty of having taken bribes in two separate cases, one involving a land acquisition deal, the other involving the appointment of the Taipei 101 chairperson.

Chen, who had been held at a detention center since late 2008, was moved to Taipei Prison in Taoyuan County on Dec. 2 to serve his time. Prison authorities are now considering how Wu should be jailed, given her condition.
When asked to comment, Premier Wu Den-yih said the government should take into account the principles of fairness and justice as well as Wu's health in handling the case.

Lin Pang-liang, the chief secretary of the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, the agency responsible for jailing the former first couple, said Wu would be kept at the Pei Teh Hospital affiliated with Taichung Prison if prosecutors decided to have her serve her jail term.
Chen Hsing-yu, the daughter of the former first couple, urged the authorities to decide her mother's fate based on doctors' assessment of her health.
Chen Hsing-yu, now a dentist, was quoted by a local newspaper days ago as threatening to sue the government "if something undesirable happened to her mother in person."
"We are not asking for any special privileges, but the same treatment as other convicts, " Chen Hsing-yu said Monday in Kaohsiung.
"Even just helping her (Wu) go to the bathroom would be troublesome, " Chen Hsing-yu said, questioning the ability of Pei Teh Hospital to take care of her mother.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trade deal with South Korea puts pressure on Taiwan: officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 21:47:58 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should step up its efforts to sign trade agreements with other countries to cope with the threat from South Korea, which could soon complete a free trade deal with the United States, Taiwanese officials said Monday.

"Taiwanese products in the U.S. market are likely to be replaced with South Korean ones when the free trade agreement (FTA) between South Korea and the U.S. takes effect, " the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Office of Trade Negotiations said in a statement.
Taiwan and South Korea share similar industrial development patterns and often compete head-to-head in the United States market and elsewhere around the globe.
If the parliaments of the U.S. and South Korea ratify the deal recently concluded by negotiators from the two countries, South Korea could be in a better position to compete against Taiwan.
The U.S. was Taiwan's third largest export market and South Korea's second largest in 2009, according to the office.
The U.S. imported US$39.22 billion in goods from South Korea and U$$28.36 billion in goods from Taiwan that year.
The U.S.-South Korea trade agreement, which had been stalled over the past three years, will likely be implemented in mid-2011 and trigger phased-in tariff reductions.
Taking TV products as an example, the U.S. will eliminate tariffs of between 3.9 percent and 5 percent on South Korea-made products, threatening similar items made in Taiwan, the office noted.

"However, whether Taiwanese products will be completely replaced by South Korean items will still depend on how Taiwan's industries enhance their competitiveness and how they differentiate their markets from those of South Korea," the office said.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Francis Liang told the Central News Agency on Saturday, however, that the U.S.-South Korea FTA would only have a limited impact on Taiwan because of the nature of the country's trade with the U.S.

Liang said Taiwan's information and communications technology products, which comprise the majority of the country's exports to the U.S., already enjoy duty- free treatment from the U.S. under the World Trade Organization's Information Technology Agreement.
For other items where Taiwan could stand at a disadvantage, it hopes to negotiate such issues with the U.S. under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA).
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said on Dec. 4 that talks under the deal would resume soon.

The TIFA deal, signed in September 1994, provides an official channel for Taiwan-U.S. dialogue on trade and economic issues, but talks have been suspended since 2007 due mainly to a conflict over a Taiwanese ban on imports of some U.S. beef products.
Though Liang believed that Taiwan's trade with the U.S. would not suffer too much from the U.S.-South Korea deal, he did say that the FTA could have a negative impact on U.S. investment in Taiwan.

The U.S. is the largest source of Taiwan's foreign investment and after inking the free trade deal, South Korea will be better positioned to attract investment from many U.S. companies, particularly in the fields of finance and other services, Liang predicted.
To cope with this possible impact, Taiwan needed to ease limits on foreign investment in its service sector, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Screening of 1st nuclear plant's extension put off by a year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 21:52:28 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A review of a plan to extend the operating life of Taiwan's first nuclear power plant will be put off for another year because Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) has asked to increase the plant's power generation, a request that could take up to 18 months to evaluate.

According to information presented at a Legislative Yuan Education and Culture Committee meeting Monday, the nuclear power plant, located in Shihmen Township, Taipei County, has been in operation for 30 years and is scheduled to be shut down in 2018.

In answer to a lawmaker's question, Atomic Energy Council Chairman Tsai Chuen- horng said his agency started a review of the plant's application to extend its operations in September 2009 and had hoped to come to a conclusion in two years.
"We may not be able to make a decision (regarding the extension request) when the two-year deadline comes, " Tsai said after Taipower's request to increase the plant's generating capacity.
A decision on the extension application will now not likely be made until 2012, officials said.

Chen Yi-pin, an AEC official in charge of nuclear energy policy, explained that Taipower, which operates the power plant, has filed a new request to raise the plant's power-generating capacity -- called a stretch power uprate -- by 3 percent.
The need to prolong the plant's operation and to raise its power generation apparently reflected concerns that the fourth nuclear power plant cannot be ready for commercial operation in time.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang Legislator Kuo Su-chun said that if the first nuclear power plant eventually extends its operations beyond 2018, then a new lease would have to be negotiated because the original 40-year lease between Taipower and local landowners would expire at around that time.

Tsai said his agency was not responsible for reaching a deal with local landowners, but he agreed it would be reasonable for Taipower to negotiate a new deal, including funds the power plant would contribute to local development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exiled Tibetans to stage parade in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 21:57:59 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Exiled Tibetans in Taiwan and abroad will launch a march from northern to southern Taiwan on Friday to raise the public's awareness of China's suppression of the region.

The 13-day event will be part of the "Walk for Tibet" global campaign aimed at "sharing our message of world peace, human rights, and the Tibetan struggle for independence, " according to the organizers.

Jigme Norbu, nephew of the Dalai Lama and son of the late Taktser Rinpoche, who supported Tibet independence, will join the activity, said Regional Tibetan Youth Congress Taiwan (RTYC-Taiwan) Chairman Tashi Tsering in a statement Monday.
Under the campaign, Norbu has organized 19 activities in the United States and elsewhere in which he walked or cycled a total of 6,500 miles (10,461 kilometers).
The walk in Taiwan will cover over 250 miles and 10 counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Year's concert on northern coast to welcome first sunlight
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:13:18 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Pop singers and bands will perform on Taiwan's northeast coast early January 1 to celebrate the new year and the centennial of the Republic of China, a national scenic area administration said Monday.

The concert, being held for the third time, is scheduled to start at 3: 30 a.m. and play through the first ray of sunlight at Fulong Beach in Taipei County's Gongliao Township, the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area Administration said at a press conference.
Administration Director Lin Kun-yuan said 20,000 people attended the event last year, and organizers were hoping for a crowd of 30,000 this year.
Three hundred visitors from Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia will be invited to board a free train between Taipei and Fulong that day to join the New Year's celebration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S. intelligence cooperation not part of leaked files: NSB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:17:24 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Classified U.S. documents released by the whistle-blowing website Wikileaks will not include information about intelligence cooperation between Taiwan and the United States, a National Security Bureau (NSB) official said Monday.

"U.S. intelligence authorities have assured us that no intelligence related to our bilateral intelligence cooperation projects have ever been leaked, " Chang Wei-ming, an NSB division chief, said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee.

Fielding questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chang Hsien-yao about the possible fallout on Taiwan's intelligence network, Chang Wei-ming said the leaked files were mainly from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Wikileaks announced on its website recently that over the next few months, it will release 251,287 cables originating from 274 U.S. embassies and consulates between Dec. 28, 1966 to Feb. 28, 2010.
Of the total, 3,456 were sent between the U.S. Department of State and the AIT, and 136 of them were classified as "secret."

The NSB official said AIT-related documents had yet to be released, but to his knowledge, the list included memos regarding AIT staff's code of conduct and Taiwan-U.S. cooperation in preventing weapons proliferation.
He said the NSB has joined an interministerial task force to monitor future leaks by the website and analyze and verify any details related to Taiwan.

On Monday, the Wikileaks released a U.S. State Department document dated February 2009 that listed some critical infrastructure facilities or telecommunication hubs whose destruction might seriously disrupt global communications.

The document, titled 2008 Critical Foreign Dependencies Initiative (CFDI) , listed landing sites for major Taiwan-related undersea cable networks, including Fangshan in southern Taiwan and Danshui in the north for C2C (city-to-city) cable network undersea cable landings.
It also cited Bali for Taiwan EAC undersea cable landings, Fangshan for Taiwan- China-U.S. undersea cable landings, and Toucheng for Taiwan FLAG/REACH North Asia Loop undersea cable landings.

The A to Z list documented undersea cable landing sites from Austria to New Zeland as well as major communication hubs, ports, minerals and strategic industrial companies critical to the functioning of the global supply chain.
KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang said he was worried the list was just the beginning of the release of classified documents.

He urged relevant government agencies to take precautionary measures to contain possible damage from the release of more information about Taiwan's sensitive military and civic infrastructure facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT proposes to eliminate copayments on drugs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:30:11 (By Chou Yung-hsieh, Justin Su and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: In their latest version of proposed amendments to the National Health Insurance Act, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators have eliminated patient copayments on drugs covered by the country's compulsory health insurance system, according to the new plan released Monday.

The proposal comes as legislators consider amendments to the National Health Insurance Act to introduce a second-generation health insurance system that would primarily change the way health insurance premiums are calculated.

On the issue of drug copayments, the version of the amendments proposed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) would still require the insured to bear a proportion of the cost of some NHI-covered drugs whose prices exceed the amount the NHI system is willing to cover.
KMT Legislator Yang Li-huan explained that the proposal to remove the caps on NHI payments for some expensive medications was made mostly to help patients suffering from rare or acute diseases.
Under the existing system, those patients have to make high copayments on new drugs that are usually priced expensively when first launched in the market.

Expressing support for the proposal that allows all the insured, regardless of their income, to have the same access to NHI-covered drugs, KMT lawmaker Hou Tsai-feng said the current system prevents poorer patients from using better drugs that are only partially covered by the health insurance system.

National Health Insurance Civic Surveillance Alliance spokeswoman Eva Teng touted the KMT proposal because it would help ease the financial burdens of cancer patients who need expensive target therapies.

Though the drug benefit would give the insured greater access to medications, the added cost could make it more difficult for the second-generation system to achieve its goals: increase premium revenue and narrow the financially ailing system's growing deficits.
Legislators did not offer any estimates of how much the new drug benefit would cost.

The legislature set Tuesday as the deadline for passage of the new amendments, but lawmakers across party lines continued to wrangle over the various versions of the revisions making their way around the legislative body, making it unclear if the deadline will be met.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tablet to fuel Taiwanese battery makers growth: researcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:54:08 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese battery makers are well positioned to benefit from the growing tablet computer market due to an increasing demand for the lithium cells that power them, a local researcher said Monday.

The emerging market of tablet devices, with projected sales of 54.8 million units in 2011, will strengthen demand for the lithium cells that are mostly made by Taiwanese companies, said Tung Chung-ming, a researcher with Taiwan's semi- official Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), at a seminar in Taipei.
Two Taiwanese cell makers alone, Simplo Technology Co. and Dynapack International Technology Corp., supply 60 percent of the lithium polymer batteries Apple Inc. uses to power its popular iPad.
"As the major suppliers to Apple, Taiwanese cell makers have been acknowledged as quality firms, helping them compete for more battery orders from other tablet brands," Tung said.

But the smaller and lighter battery type used in tablet PCs have a lower average price than those used in regular notebooks, and they will likely hurt Taiwanese battery makers' gross margins, he said.
"It depends on if the tablets will replace the use of notebooks or create a new market for cell manufacturers," he said.

International PC vendors such as Acer, AsusTek, Samsung, ViewSonic, Dell and HP have unveiled or are ready to launch their own tablet devices to grab a slice of the potential boom started by Apple's iPad.

The ITRI expects that Apple will continue to dominate the global tablet market in 2011 with a 70 percent share, followed by smartphone brands with 20 percent and regular notebook makers with 10 percent.

Meanwhile, global shipments of the tablet device will reach 12.28 million units before the end of this year, then grow by 183 percent to 34.81 million units in 2011 and by 45.7 percent to 50 million units in 2012, according to a study by the Market Intelligence and Consulting Institute (MIC).

The rapid growing popularity of tablet computers since the launch of iPad will make them the third biggest mobile device segment in the final quarter of 2010 and for all of 2011, said market tracker Digitimes Research.

However, the world's No. 2 PC maker Acer Inc. said on Saturday the global market for notebook computers will grow between 20 percent and 25 percent next year on the back of rising demand in emerging markets.
On market speculation that the emergence of tablet computers will replace personal computers, Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said growing demand in emerging markets will help drive demand for notebooks.
As a result, he forecast that the compound annual growth rate for global notebook shipments would remain at more than 20 percent for the next few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan issues travel alert for Ivory Coast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:00:46 (By Emannuele Tzeng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a "red" alert Monday advising people not to travel to Ivory Coast, where tensions were rising after the government declared a curfew in the wake of a presidential election dispute.
Following a runoff vote on Nov. 28, Ivory Coast's incumbent President Laurent Gbagbo and rival Alassane Ouattara both declared themselves winners of the election and swore themselves in as president.
Many of the country's residents are fleeing the country over fears that a civil war will erupt.

The MOFA said its red alert means the country is "unfit to be visited" for the time being. As to those Taiwanese already in the western African country, the MOFA advised them to contact, if necessary, the Far East Trade Service Inc.'s branch office there.
The office's director is Liu Wei-na, who can reached at 225-202-16396.
The ministry's hot line for Taiwanese traveling abroad -- 0800-085-095 -- can also be dialed for emergency services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment pact not ready for next round of Taiwan-China talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:05:13 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A proposed cross-Taiwan Strait investment agreement will not be signed as scheduled at the next meeting between the top negotiators of Taiwan and China, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
"No consensus has been reached in this regard after three rounds of pre-meeting consultations between the two sides, " said MAC Vice Minister Kao Charng at a press briefing.
Kao refused, however, to elaborate on why no agreement on the scheduled pact had been reached, saying that "the accord will be signed whenever both sides come to terms."

The two negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundations, and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Associations for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- were originally expected to sign pacts on cross-Taiwan Strait medical cooperation and investment protection at their next meeting before the end of the year.
Chiang and Chen have met five times over the past two and a half years and have reached 14 agreements, mostly aimed at boosting cross-strait trade and economic cooperation.
Vice Economics Minister Francis Liang said it was not unusual for trade partners to take a lot of time to reach bilateral investment protection agreements.
He said that it took at least one year of negotiations before Taiwan was able to conclude even one of the 29 investment pacts Taiwan has signed.
According to an official who took part in the pre-meeting consultations, however, the main hitch was China's opposition to Taiwan's proposal to have an international organization arbitrate disputes.

The official, who asked for anonymity, said late last week that Taiwan preferred to have the Washington-based International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) act as an arbitrator in any investment-involved dispute settlement.
China objected to the idea because it feared that cross-strait relations would be "internationalized" by doing so.

The ICSID was an institution founded under the World Bank in 1966 pursuant to the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States (the ICSID Convention or Washington Convention).

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity bazaar to solicit funds for premature children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:11:53 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The personal belongings of Taiwanese baseball celebrities will go on sale at a charity bazaar this week to raise money for premature children, the Premature Baby Foundation (PBF), the organizer of the event, said Monday.

Though national health insurance (NHI) subsidizes 80 to 90 percent of the medical care expenses for premature babies, some families still find it hard to afford extra treatments and counseling services that are not reimbursed by the insurance system, said PBF President Lee Hung-chang.
"I hope to raise public awareness about the needs of families with premature children through the sale," Lee said.
Yuki Huang, the mother of two premature babies born at 28 and 26 weeks, respectively, said she was thankful for the financial and mental support offered by the foundation.

"Preemie parents have constant doubts about the babies' well-being after being discharged from the hospital, " said Huang, whose worries gradually eased after enrolling in the foundation's free follow-up program that tracked the infants' developmental progress.
Profits from the charity sale will go to the foundation, which is dedicated to improving medical care for the premature.
According to PBF statistics, there are about 200,000 newborn infants in Taiwan each year, of which 8.5 to 8.9 percent are born prematurely.
