"U.S. intelligence authorities have assured us that no intelligence related to our bilateral intelligence cooperation projects have ever been leaked, " Chang Wei-ming, an NSB division chief, said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee.

Fielding questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chang Hsien-yao about the possible fallout on Taiwan's intelligence network, Chang Wei-ming said the leaked files were mainly from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Wikileaks announced on its website recently that over the next few months, it will release 251,287 cables originating from 274 U.S. embassies and consulates between Dec. 28, 1966 to Feb. 28, 2010.
Of the total, 3,456 were sent between the U.S. Department of State and the AIT, and 136 of them were classified as "secret."

The NSB official said AIT-related documents had yet to be released, but to his knowledge, the list included memos regarding AIT staff's code of conduct and Taiwan-U.S. cooperation in preventing weapons proliferation.
He said the NSB has joined an interministerial task force to monitor future leaks by the website and analyze and verify any details related to Taiwan.

On Monday, the Wikileaks released a U.S. State Department document dated February 2009 that listed some critical infrastructure facilities or telecommunication hubs whose destruction might seriously disrupt global communications.

The document, titled 2008 Critical Foreign Dependencies Initiative (CFDI) , listed landing sites for major Taiwan-related undersea cable networks, including Fangshan in southern Taiwan and Danshui in the north for C2C (city-to-city) cable network undersea cable landings.
It also cited Bali for Taiwan EAC undersea cable landings, Fangshan for Taiwan- China-U.S. undersea cable landings, and Toucheng for Taiwan FLAG/REACH North Asia Loop undersea cable landings.

The A to Z list documented undersea cable landing sites from Austria to New Zeland as well as major communication hubs, ports, minerals and strategic industrial companies critical to the functioning of the global supply chain.
KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang said he was worried the list was just the beginning of the release of classified documents.

He urged relevant government agencies to take precautionary measures to contain possible damage from the release of more information about Taiwan's sensitive military and civic infrastructure facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT proposes to eliminate copayments on drugs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:30:11 (By Chou Yung-hsieh, Justin Su and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: In their latest version of proposed amendments to the National Health Insurance Act, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators have eliminated patient copayments on drugs covered by the country's compulsory health insurance system, according to the new plan released Monday.

The proposal comes as legislators consider amendments to the National Health Insurance Act to introduce a second-generation health insurance system that would primarily change the way health insurance premiums are calculated.

On the issue of drug copayments, the version of the amendments proposed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) would still require the insured to bear a proportion of the cost of some NHI-covered drugs whose prices exceed the amount the NHI system is willing to cover.
KMT Legislator Yang Li-huan explained that the proposal to remove the caps on NHI payments for some expensive medications was made mostly to help patients suffering from rare or acute diseases.
Under the existing system, those patients have to make high copayments on new drugs that are usually priced expensively when first launched in the market.

Expressing support for the proposal that allows all the insured, regardless of their income, to have the same access to NHI-covered drugs, KMT lawmaker Hou Tsai-feng said the current system prevents poorer patients from using better drugs that are only partially covered by the health insurance system.

National Health Insurance Civic Surveillance Alliance spokeswoman Eva Teng touted the KMT proposal because it would help ease the financial burdens of cancer patients who need expensive target therapies.

Though the drug benefit would give the insured greater access to medications, the added cost could make it more difficult for the second-generation system to achieve its goals: increase premium revenue and narrow the financially ailing system's growing deficits.
Legislators did not offer any estimates of how much the new drug benefit would cost.

The legislature set Tuesday as the deadline for passage of the new amendments, but lawmakers across party lines continued to wrangle over the various versions of the revisions making their way around the legislative body, making it unclear if the deadline will be met.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tablet to fuel Taiwanese battery makers growth: researcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 22:54:08 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese battery makers are well positioned to benefit from the growing tablet computer market due to an increasing demand for the lithium cells that power them, a local researcher said Monday.

The emerging market of tablet devices, with projected sales of 54.8 million units in 2011, will strengthen demand for the lithium cells that are mostly made by Taiwanese companies, said Tung Chung-ming, a researcher with Taiwan's semi- official Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), at a seminar in Taipei.
Two Taiwanese cell makers alone, Simplo Technology Co. and Dynapack International Technology Corp., supply 60 percent of the lithium polymer batteries Apple Inc. uses to power its popular iPad.
"As the major suppliers to Apple, Taiwanese cell makers have been acknowledged as quality firms, helping them compete for more battery orders from other tablet brands," Tung said.

But the smaller and lighter battery type used in tablet PCs have a lower average price than those used in regular notebooks, and they will likely hurt Taiwanese battery makers' gross margins, he said.
"It depends on if the tablets will replace the use of notebooks or create a new market for cell manufacturers," he said.

International PC vendors such as Acer, AsusTek, Samsung, ViewSonic, Dell and HP have unveiled or are ready to launch their own tablet devices to grab a slice of the potential boom started by Apple's iPad.

The ITRI expects that Apple will continue to dominate the global tablet market in 2011 with a 70 percent share, followed by smartphone brands with 20 percent and regular notebook makers with 10 percent.

Meanwhile, global shipments of the tablet device will reach 12.28 million units before the end of this year, then grow by 183 percent to 34.81 million units in 2011 and by 45.7 percent to 50 million units in 2012, according to a study by the Market Intelligence and Consulting Institute (MIC).

The rapid growing popularity of tablet computers since the launch of iPad will make them the third biggest mobile device segment in the final quarter of 2010 and for all of 2011, said market tracker Digitimes Research.

However, the world's No. 2 PC maker Acer Inc. said on Saturday the global market for notebook computers will grow between 20 percent and 25 percent next year on the back of rising demand in emerging markets.
On market speculation that the emergence of tablet computers will replace personal computers, Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said growing demand in emerging markets will help drive demand for notebooks.
As a result, he forecast that the compound annual growth rate for global notebook shipments would remain at more than 20 percent for the next few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan issues travel alert for Ivory Coast
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:00:46 (By Emannuele Tzeng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a "red" alert Monday advising people not to travel to Ivory Coast, where tensions were rising after the government declared a curfew in the wake of a presidential election dispute.
Following a runoff vote on Nov. 28, Ivory Coast's incumbent President Laurent Gbagbo and rival Alassane Ouattara both declared themselves winners of the election and swore themselves in as president.
Many of the country's residents are fleeing the country over fears that a civil war will erupt.

The MOFA said its red alert means the country is "unfit to be visited" for the time being. As to those Taiwanese already in the western African country, the MOFA advised them to contact, if necessary, the Far East Trade Service Inc.'s branch office there.
The office's director is Liu Wei-na, who can reached at 225-202-16396.
The ministry's hot line for Taiwanese traveling abroad -- 0800-085-095 -- can also be dialed for emergency services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment pact not ready for next round of Taiwan-China talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:05:13 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A proposed cross-Taiwan Strait investment agreement will not be signed as scheduled at the next meeting between the top negotiators of Taiwan and China, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
"No consensus has been reached in this regard after three rounds of pre-meeting consultations between the two sides, " said MAC Vice Minister Kao Charng at a press briefing.
Kao refused, however, to elaborate on why no agreement on the scheduled pact had been reached, saying that "the accord will be signed whenever both sides come to terms."

The two negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundations, and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Associations for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- were originally expected to sign pacts on cross-Taiwan Strait medical cooperation and investment protection at their next meeting before the end of the year.
Chiang and Chen have met five times over the past two and a half years and have reached 14 agreements, mostly aimed at boosting cross-strait trade and economic cooperation.
Vice Economics Minister Francis Liang said it was not unusual for trade partners to take a lot of time to reach bilateral investment protection agreements.
He said that it took at least one year of negotiations before Taiwan was able to conclude even one of the 29 investment pacts Taiwan has signed.
According to an official who took part in the pre-meeting consultations, however, the main hitch was China's opposition to Taiwan's proposal to have an international organization arbitrate disputes.

The official, who asked for anonymity, said late last week that Taiwan preferred to have the Washington-based International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) act as an arbitrator in any investment-involved dispute settlement.
China objected to the idea because it feared that cross-strait relations would be "internationalized" by doing so.

The ICSID was an institution founded under the World Bank in 1966 pursuant to the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States (the ICSID Convention or Washington Convention).

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity bazaar to solicit funds for premature children
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/10 23:11:53 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The personal belongings of Taiwanese baseball celebrities will go on sale at a charity bazaar this week to raise money for premature children, the Premature Baby Foundation (PBF), the organizer of the event, said Monday.

Though national health insurance (NHI) subsidizes 80 to 90 percent of the medical care expenses for premature babies, some families still find it hard to afford extra treatments and counseling services that are not reimbursed by the insurance system, said PBF President Lee Hung-chang.
"I hope to raise public awareness about the needs of families with premature children through the sale," Lee said.
Yuki Huang, the mother of two premature babies born at 28 and 26 weeks, respectively, said she was thankful for the financial and mental support offered by the foundation.

"Preemie parents have constant doubts about the babies' well-being after being discharged from the hospital, " said Huang, whose worries gradually eased after enrolling in the foundation's free follow-up program that tracked the infants' developmental progress.
Profits from the charity sale will go to the foundation, which is dedicated to improving medical care for the premature.
According to PBF statistics, there are about 200,000 newborn infants in Taiwan each year, of which 8.5 to 8.9 percent are born prematurely.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 7, 2010, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 09:32:04 (By Y.F. Low)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Set up a joint arbitration center

TEXT.P: With the chief negotiators of Taiwan and China set to hold their sixth round of talks since June 2008 later this month, an issue of concern is whether a cross- Taiwan Strait investment protection agreement can be signed at the meeting as planned.

A major bone of contention in the deal involves the designation of a neutral arbitration organization to settle disputes. With the lack of any arbitration organizations that can truly be considered neutral in China, Taiwan has hoped to introduce a mechanism of "international arbitration" to protect Taiwanese investors.

Possibilities included the International Center for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) under the World Bank and the Paris-based International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) . These proposals, however, have proven infeasible because of the sensitive sovereignty dispute across the strait.

To resolve the deadlock, we suggest that the two sides seek to set up a joint arbitration center dedicated to the settlement of cross-strait investment disputes. The center would be run by qualified arbitrators from the two sides and other countries and operated according to rules that are mutually accepted as fair and neutral. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay to grant Taiwan visa-waivers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 12:17:12 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Paraguay will soon grant visa-waiver status to Republic of China passport holders, a visiting high-ranking Paraguayan official said in Taipei Tuesday.

Cesar Aquino, executive secretary of the National Anti-Drug Secretariat of Paraguay, disclosed the news during a meeting with President Ma Ying-jeou, according to a statement released by the Presidential Office.
Aquino said that right before his departure for Taiwan, President Fernando Lugo told him that an order would soon be signed to allow Taiwanese citizens to travel to Paraguay visa free.
Lugo also indicated his intention to visit Taiwan upon receiving a formal invitation, Aquino told Ma.
On his part, Ma said he welcomed this friendly decision by Paraguay on behalf of the ROC government and its people.
Ma noted that the European Union recently also included Taiwan in its visa waiver program, with the policy expected to officially become effective in mid- January.
The president expressed confidence that the number of countries that Taiwanese citizens will be able to visit without needing a visa will exceed 100 by 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek sales in November down 0.19 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 12:30:47 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Integrated circuit designer MediaTek Inc. said Tuesday that its sales in November fell 0.19 percent from October to NT$7.36 billion (US$244 million) , compared with a 25.16 percent month-on-month decline recorded in the previous month.
In the first 11 months of this year, MediaTek's sales totaled NT$105.52 billion, down 0.36 percent from a year earlier.
Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said the much narrower month-on-month fall in November sales resulted from recovering demand in China.

"But the higher demand came after the company aggressively slashed the prices of its cell phone chips to secure orders amid fierce competition in the mainland market, " said Hsu, who put the cut in the company's average selling price up to around 20 percent.

With demand in China expected to continue to rise in December ahead of an anticipated buying spree during the Lunar Chinese New Year holiday, MediaTek's sales in December are expected to rise substantially to about NT$8.5 billion.

Hsu added that due to higher shipments in December, MediaTek is expected to meet the guidance it gave in October when it said the company's sales for the fourth quarter could fall 15-20 percent below third quarter sales.
"Although the company's sales have stabilized, the lower product prices may further erode its gross margin, " Hsu said. "I expect its gross margin will fall below 50 percent in the fourth quarter."
In the third quarter of this year, MediaTek's gross margin fell 2.81 percentage points from the second quarter to 52.22 percent.
Cell phone chips account for about 75 percent of the company's total sales, but its major customers are producers of "bandit, "or unbranded, Chinese cell phones, whose products are price-sensitive.
Due to the price competition, MediaTek's cell phone chip market share in China fell to below 80 percent in the third quarter from more than 90 percent in the first quarter, according to the analyst.

Hsu said that unless MediaTek makes a breakthrough in its technology upgrade to 3G chips from the current 2.5-2.75G to take on competition, downward pressure on its gross margin will continue to exist.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Canada working holiday quota raised to 1,000: CTOT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 12:44:07 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: More Taiwanese will be able to take a working holiday in Canada in 2011 after Canada raised the quota for Taiwanese participation in the program from 700 to 1,000, the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) said in a statement Tuesday.
"The Canadian Trade Office in Taipei is pleased to announce that we have increased our quota for the 2011 International Experience Canada initiative to 1,000 for Taiwan, " the office said.

Taiwan and Canada signed an agreement earlier this year to launch the working holiday program on July 1. Under the program, people aged 18-35 from the two countries are allowed to travel and work in each other's territory for up to one year.
The original annual quota of 200 was raised to 700 on July 27 because of an enthusiastic response from local youth.
The CTOT said it will be accepting applications for the program postmarked on or after Jan. 10, 2011.
Taiwan has signed working holiday agreements with six countries -- Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Germany and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- FSC gets tough on foreign insurer pullouts
DOC.DATELINE: 12/07/10 12:59:19 (The Taiwan Banker, November 2010) (Translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's financial regulator is applying stricter standards to the sales of domestic insurers by their foreign parent companies after three European financial institutions unexpectedly sold their Taiwan units between 2008 and 2009.

Though the global financial crisis was one of the main reasons behind the pullouts, which began with Netherlands-based ING Group in October 2008, the exodus has cast a shadow over Taiwan's insurance sector and alarmed the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).

ING Group's sale of its life insurance unit was followed in February 2009 by British insurer Prudential Plc's sale of its Taiwan unit to China Life, in which it transferred 11,000 sales agents and 1 million policies to the buyer. Prudential held on to only its banking channels and telemarketing business.
Then, in April 2009, Netherlands-based Aegon Group sold its Taiwan operation.

Six months later, American International Group announced that it had found a buyer for its subsidiary, Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., prompting the FSC to unveil a month later five principles to be used in reviewing such cases.

Due to public concern that Chinese investors were behind the consortium vying for Nan Shan, and that the consortium consisted of a company set up for the sale and a group whose core business was batteries, the deal was carefully scrutinized.

Before regulators rejected the sale on Aug. 31, 2010, the consortium had been asked to submit supplemental information 13 times over a nine-month period to clarify its shareholder structure, which was constantly changing.

While the Council of Labor Affairs was against the deal because the prospective buyer was not committed to protecting Nan Shan employees' rights, the commission said the buyer did not meet two of the five criteria it had established -- showing long-term commitment and the ability to raise capital in the future.

Another proposed deal, American insurer Metropolitan Life Insurance Co.'s proposed sale of its Taiwan unit announced in April, also came under careful scrutiny and was rejected by the commission in early October, one month after the deal was sent for regulatory approval.

The deal failed to meet the same two criteria that killed the Nan Shan sale, and regulators also questioned the ability of the prospective buyer -- Waterland Financial Holdings -- to run an insurance business because of disagreement among Waterland shareholders over the purchase.

One reason behind the European insurers' desire to sell was the European Union's adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards for the industry, which aim for more transparency in financial reporting and also require higher reserves for policies.

But U.S. insurers, who do not have to follow the accounting standard, are also pulling out of Taiwan, and European insurers are holding on to their other subsidiaries in Asia, despite the more stringent accounting guidelines. The moves indicate that in fact specific conditions in Taiwan's market, such as cutthroat competition, are driving foreign companies away.

With New York Life now putting its units in Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea up for sale and MassMutual Financial Group said to be pulling out from its joint- venture with Taiwan's Mercuries Life, Taiwan should look into the issue and try to find market-based reasons to stop foreign insurers from leaving.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st Gourmet Taiwan International Conference opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 13:03:51 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Food business operators from Taiwan and the United States exchanged ideas on how to break into each other's market on the opening day of the Gourmet Taiwan International Conference in Taipei Tuesday.

The opening ceremony was attended by more than 200 participants, including a group of 30 people from the U.S. engaged in the food and hotel sectors, according to the ROC-USA Business Council, the main organizer of the four-day conference.
Chen Fei-lung, executive supervisor of the business council, said he hoped that with the support of the government, Taiwan's foods and food businesses would be able to go international.
Working with overseas compatriots and exploring global markets will be a positive force for Taiwan's food industry because more jobs and business opportunities will be created, he said.
The conference will include a series of keynote speeches, and Taiwan's food business operators will have the opportunity to hold discussions with their counterparts from the U.S.
Among the other topics of discussion will be visas for chefs specializing in Chinese food.
Helen Hwang, commercial chief of the American Institute in Taiwan, said the U.S. has many restaurants serving Chinese food, but only a few mainstream restaurants there have achieved success.
She believed that the market for Chinese restaurants in the U.S. has not yet reached a saturation point.
"America is open for business, " said Hwang. "The U.S. is still the land of dreams and goals."

DOC.HEADLINE: Temperature drops sharply throughout Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 13:27:56 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A cold front moving across Taiwan will send temperatures plunging to a low of 9 degrees Celsius in northern and central Taiwan by early Wednesday morning, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) warned Tuesday.

All areas in Taiwan will experience a sharp drop in temperature from Tuesday until Wednesday afternoon, the CWB said. After that, temperatures in regions north of the Chiayi area are expected to rise to between 15 and 18 degrees, the bureau said.
The cold weather will last until Friday, with a small chance of rain and snow in the mountainous areas of country, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranking in climate change performance remains unchanged
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/10 14:17:45 (By Lin Yu-li and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 47th among 57 high-carbon dioxide emitting countries in the Climate Change Performance Index (CCPI) , placing at the bottom of the index's "poor" performer category, a report released on Monday by Germanwatch and Climate Action Network (CAN) Europe showed.

According to the report, Taiwan scored 50.2 points in the performance index, lagging behind India, Thailand, Singapore, South Korea and Japan but ahead of Malaysia and China among Asia countries assessed.
Taiwan was also ranked 47th in the index in 2009.

Despite the poor overall ranking, Taiwan rose two notches to 13th in the climate policy category, indicating the government's measures to cut carbon dioxide emissions have worked to improve the environment, the report said.

The climate policy category accounted for 20 percent of the overall index score. The emissions level category and emissions trend category account for 30 percent and 50 percent respectively of the overall index.

According to the report, Taiwan made improvements in road and air transportation emission reductions, but failed to lower emissions generated in the energy, manufacturing and construction sectors and by private residences.
The report also showed Taiwan needed to work harder to cut its carbon dioxide emissions per primary energy unit and lower its primary energy consumption.

The world's two biggest carbon emitters, China and the United States, dropped a few notches compared to last year, with China ranking 56th and the U.S. 54th, the report said. They were placed in the "very poor" performer category.

Germanwatch was founded in 1991 to promote global equity and the preservation of livelihoods, while CAN Europe is the European node of CAN International, a global coalition representing millions of citizens worldwide united in the fight against climate change.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan lists TEM, visa-waivers as priorities in Europe in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 15:25:16 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to take an initial step toward signing a Trade Enhancement Measures (TEM) deal with the European Union (EU) and secure more visa-exemptions in the region next year, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official in charge of European affairs said Tuesday.

Negotiating TEM and pushing for visa waivers from 24 European countries or territories were the priorities on the country's European affairs agenda for 2011, James Lee, director-general of the ministry's Department of European Affairs, said at a regular press briefing.

Taiwan already secured a breakthrough in Europe on Nov. 25 when the Council of the European Union approved visa exemptions for Taiwanese citizens in 35 European countries, including the 25 in the Schengen Area. The new visa-waivers will take effect in January 2011.

Lee said Taiwan will now turn to six Balkan countries -- Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia -- and 18 British and French overseas territories, such as Tahiti in French Polynesia, to push for visa exemptions.

As for the Trade Enhancement Measures, Lee said negotiating them was a natural priority after Taiwan signed the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China in June, because the EU is Taiwan's fourth largest trade partner.
"We would like to take the first step of a feasibility study (for a TEM) next year. After that a joint study," Lee said.
The European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT) has actively urged the EU to initiate talks with Taiwan on the trade liberalization measures, according to Lee.

Taiwan's government has been in regular contact with the EU on the issue and has advocated a "block-building" approach to lowering Taiwan-EU trade barriers if a package deal were not plausible, he said.
An inter-agency task force consisting of the MOFA and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has been established to work on Taiwan-EU trade liberalization issues, he added.
"We think that more urgent issues, such as investment, tariffs and standards, could be negotiated in separate agreements to benefit Taiwanese and European businesses, " he said.

Lee was not optimistic that negotiations on the issues could begin immediately, however, because the EU is engaged in free trade agreement (FTA) negotiations with South Korea, India and Brazil, and he was not sure the EU would have other teams to work with Taiwan on the TEM.
That is why the possibility of doing separate and then joint feasibility studies were more realistic goals in 2011, Lee said.

Looking back at 2010, Lee listed the passage of visa exemptions in the Schengen Area as one of Taiwan's biggest accomplishments last year. Taiwan also signed a new aviation agreement with the United Kingdom and a double taxation avoidance agreement with Hungary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Former first lady assigned to prison hospital

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Prosecutors Office decided Monday that former first lady Wu Shu- jen, who is a wheelchair user, will be confined to a prison hospital in central Taiwan for medical evaluation, after which a final decision will be made on where she would serve her 19-year jail sentence.
Pei Teh Hospital, where she will be evaluated, is part of Taichung Prison.
Wu and former President Chen Shui-bian were each sentenced in November to a total of 19 years in jail for corruption during Chen's term in office between 2000 and 2008.
They were both found guilty of accepting bribes in two separate cases, one involving a land acquisition deal and the other involving the appointment of the Taipei 101 chairperson.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials and prison authorities said that they are doing their best to make special arrangements for Wu.
Wu could be given parole for medical treatment at other hospitals if the Taichung prison hospital cannot handle her health problems, the officials said.
As a district hospital, Pei Teh has links with China Medical College Hospital in central Taiwan and is well equipped to treat prisoners who are wheelchair users, the MOJ said.
Wu's daughter Chen Hsing-yu said she respected the decision to keep her mother at Pei Teh, but was skeptical about the hospital's ability to care for her sick mother.
Chen Hsing-yu said she hopes other prisoners will not be assigned to tend to her mother and that she is very worried about the toilet arrangements.
"The hospital may think the problem can be dealt with by simply carrying her to the toilet, but it can't, " Chen Hsing-yu said.
"You can shoot a person to death if the penalty is death, but you can not abuse her to death with lack of proper toilet facilities and nutritional care, " Wu's daughter said. (Dec. 7, 2010).
China Times:

Asked to respond to Chen Hsing-yu's recent statement that she will take legal action against the government if her mother dies in jail, Yen Da-ho, chief prosector of the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, said he cannot comment on "something that has not happened."
The office explained that the decision to confine Wu to Pei Teh hospital was based on "humanitarian concerns and fairness in carrying out penalties."
The decision leaves open the possibility that the 57-year-old former first lady would not be put behind bars if it is found that she is too ill to be held in prison, the office said.
The best-case senario is that Wu will be confined to Pei Teh for a period of time then released on parole, based on the hospital's medical evaluation, the office said. (Dec. 7, 2010).
Liberty Times:
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Guan Bi-ling accused the Ministry of Justice of interfering in the issue of Wu's confinement.

Guan said it is a matter that should be decided by Kaohsiung Women's Prison, which is in charge of implementing Wu's prison sentence. The ministry's decision to assign Wu to Pei Teh Hospital in Taichung City overrode the Kaohsiung prison's authority, Guan argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Guard against inflation

TEXT.P: According to the latest forecast by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's economic growth is expected to reach 4.5 percent in 2011, with the consumer price index rising moderately by 1.85 percent.

Although the government is optimistic about the economic situation, the rally in global commodity prices -- fueled by the quantitative easing policy in the United States -- will be a major source of uncertainty for the economy next year. Rising import prices will inevitably push up consumer costs.

The soar in domestic real estate prices, meanwhile, will likely increase inflationary pressure. Inflation expectations could encourage people to buy property to preserve the value of their assets, which might in turn worsen the inflation situation.

Under these circumstances, the government must seek to cool the housing market by strengthening credit controls on housing speculators and imposing heavy taxes on speculative transactions. The central bank should also consider significantly raising key interest rates. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close flat
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 17:14:01 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Tuesday after a tug of war between follow-through buying in select old-economy stocks and selling in the high-tech sector that was overshadowed by a rising New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 2.16 points or 0.02 percent to 8,704.39, after moving between 8,654.49 and 8,716.00, on turnover of NT$123.50 billion (US$4.10 billion).

The market opened up 0.16 percent at the day's high amid ample liquidity, while concerns over Taiwan's global competitiveness on the New Taiwan dollar's appreciation dampened investor sentiment toward the bellwether electronics sector, the dealers said.
A total of 1,949 stocks closed up and 2,072 were down, with 440 remaining unchanged.
The cement sector posted the highest gains, up 1.4 percent. Foodstuffs rose 1.0 percent, construction, and financial stocks added 0.2 percent, while the paper and pulp sector closed unchanged.
However, the textile sector fell 1.3 percent and the machinery and electronics sector lost 0.2 percent.
"Following a recent strong showing, the market needs some time to consolidate before another take-off, " Horizon Securities analyst Benson Huang said.
Huang said a lackluster showing on Wall Street overnight also pushed many investors to the sidelines.
After the removal of political uncertainty caused by the Nov. 27 municipal elections, further inflows of foreign funds have boosted the index by more than 4.7 percent.
"Some profit-taking emerged during the trading session to erode some of the gains after the index breached the nearest technical resistance at the 8,700-point level," Huang said.
Huang said investors are watching closely how China will report its November inflation data after a 25-month high of 4.4 percent recorded in October.
"There are fears that China will further tighten liquidity to fight inflation, which could prompt foreign funds to leave the markets in the region," he said.
Among the high-tech heavyweights, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. fell 0.73 percent to close at NT$68.00 and PC vendor Asustek lost 1.92 percent to end the day at NT$281.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan and Canada sign communications technology MOU
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/10 17:41:50 (By Paul Chang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada signed a communications technology cooperation memorandum of understanding (MOU) in Ottawa on Monday to pave the way for the joint development of a wireless sensor network.

The MOU was signed by Communications Research Centre (CRIC) of Canada President Veena Rawat, Taiwan's representative in Canada David Lee, National Science Council Minister Lee Lou-chuang, and the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT).
National Science Council chief Lee said his agency and the CRIC have had a long- term partnership and had cooperated successfully on a number of projects in the past.

The two institutions previously completed projects to develop monolithic microwave integrated circuits and satellite antenna systems, and they are now working on wireless sensors for biomedical and environmental applications, Lee Lou-chuang said.

Taiwan and the Canadian research center will also focus on new generation cognitive radio technology, which could have a number of applications, including in high definition and 3D television and even biomedicine, Lee said.

The communications industry is one of Taiwan's most important economic sectors, with an output value of NT$1 trillion (US$33.2 billion) in 2009, said David Lee, who heads the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Taiwan's de facto embassy, in Ottawa.
The industry's shipments could rise by 30 percent in 2010, Lee added, citing a forecast by the Market Intelligence and Consulting Institute, a leading ICT industry research organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vincentians debut in Taiwan's top collegiate basketball division
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 18:11:40 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Two students from the Caribbean country of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines made their debut this week as the first foreign players in Taiwan's top collegiate basketball division.

As of Tuesday, Craiglee Sam, 23, and Cregg Friday, 21, of Ming Chuan University had helped their school to a 1-1 start in its first two games in the preliminary round of the University Basketball Association Division 1 competition.

Sam and Friday have made history not only as the first foreign players to appear in the UBA Division 1, but also as the first foreign students to receive sports scholarships from Ming Chuan University in 2009.
The two players are from the Grenadine island of Bequia and are both majoring in tourism at Ming Chuan University, which has campuses in Taipei and Taoyuan cities.
Sam, who is 198cm tall, had eight points and nine rebounds in his first Division 1 game Sunday, which Ming Chuan lost 80-54 to defending champion National Taiwan Normal University.
In his second game Monday, Sam scored three points and grabbed nine rebounds to help Ming Chuan to its first ever victory in a Division 1 game -- a 60-50 win over Taipei Physical Education College.
Friday, who also stands 198cm, had 18 points, 15 rebounds and an impressive eight blocked shots in the two games.
The pair led Ming Chuan to a fourth place finish in the UBA Division II last year as freshmen. The school was promoted this year to Division I, which has been expanded from 12 to 16 teams.

Sam has won several Most Valuable Player awards in his home country and received an American basketball scholarship from Portland Community College in 2007. He spent a year in the United States before returning to his hometown.

Sam's cousin Alexus Foyle, also of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, played last year in Taiwan with the Taiwan Mobile Leopards, one of the seven professional teams in the Super Basketball League, Taiwan' top basketball competition.
Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is one of Taiwan 23 diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consensus before speed: premier on NHI amendments
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 18:15:54 (By Lee Ming-tsung, Chou Yung-chieh, Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that the administration respects the Legislative Yuan's mission to screen and legislate amendments to the National Health Insurance (NHI) Act that would allow for a new premium system to take effect, but added that consensus must not be sacrificed for speed.

The legislature had set that day as the deadline for passage of the new amendments, but lawmakers across party lines continued to wrangle over various versions of the revisions, making it unclear if the deadline will be met.
Wu expressed hope that the lawmakers will pass the amendments into law with the greatest possible consensus.
"Nobody wants to see it passed rashly just because we have a deadline to meet," the premier said.

Meanwhile, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang denied accusations that the DOH is issuing a "blank check" to a soon-to-be established committee that will determine the premium calculation formula by proposing the amendments.

Even the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators lambasted the revisions to the premium rates and a plan to calculate premiums based on "presumed income, " under which the very poorest sector of society will be charged according to the premise that they are earning at least NT$17,280 per month, whether they are actually earning money or not. The lawmakers therefore refused to endorse the amendments.
Yaung said the premium rates to be proposed in the new NHI system would be controlled at under 3.5 percent of household income and that the DOH is not issuing any "blank check."
Responding to the idea of a 2 percent rate that has been put forward by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Yaung said that "that is absolutely impossible."
The new premium calculation formula is devised in part to revitalize the cash- strapped NHI system.
"Where will the money come from if the premiums are lowered so sharply across the board?" he asked.

Yaung said that neither the DOH nor the National Health Insurance Bureau (NHIB) will determine the premium rates once the new NHI premium system is passed and put into practice, but by a yet-to-be-organized, independent NHI committee.

On criticism lodged by DPP lawmakers on the plan to calculate premiums based on presumed income, Yaung said the plan was devised because more than 40 percent of the Taiwanese public did not pay income tax.
The new NHI system proposes that insurance premiums should be calculated based on total household incomes instead of the individual salaries of the insured, as is the case at present.
The new, or second-generation NHI system, if passed soon, is expected to be implemented in 2013, according to NHIB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prison hospital capable of jailing ex-first lady: jail official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 18:23:23 (By Justin Su, Lin Chung-sen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Pei Teh Hospital of the Taichung Prison said Tuesday that it is capable of jailing the wheelchair-bound former first lady Wu Shu-jen if it is instructed to do so.
Lin Chih-hsiung, chief secretary of the Taichung Prison, said that in cooperation with the China Medical University Hospital, Pei Teh can jail seriously ill convicts, including amputees.

Lin's comment came on the heels of questions asked by Chen Hsing-yu, Wu' daughter, that the Pei Teh may not be an ideal place for Wu to serve her sentence, given the fact that Wu has been paralyzed from the waist down for over 20 years.
The Pei Teh can offer the same level of medical services as any other top-notch hospital, according to Lin.
The Taichung Prison hospital was selected by the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office as the facility in which Wu will serve her time if prosecutors decide to carry out the sentence.
Wu and her husband, former President Chen Shui-bian, were each sentenced to a total of 19 years in jail last month by the Supreme Court for taking bribes while Chen was president.
Chen and Wu were found guilty of having taken bribes in two separate cases, one involving a land acquisition deal and the other involving the appointment of the Taipei 101 chairwoman.

Chen, who had been held at a detention center since late 2008, was moved to Taipei Prison in Taoyuan County Dec. 2 to serve his time. Prison authorities are now considering how Wu should be jailed, given her condition.
Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu said that whether the former first lady will serve her time in the Pei Teh Hospital will depend on a medical assessment of her condition.

Lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have called on the government to be lenient toward Wu by either allowing her to remain confined under house arrest or releasing her on medical bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy to see 4 percent growth in 2011: ADB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 18:28:49 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) forecast on Tuesday that Taiwan's economy will expand by 4.0 percent in 2011 as its growth momentum moderates after a strong showing in 2010.

In its Asia Economic Monitor report, the ADB said Taiwan's exports will likely see its exports affected by weaker global demand, and growth in other areas, including industrial production and retail sales, is expected to moderate.

The report also expected Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) to rise 9.8 percent for all of 2010 after the economy posted 13.2 percent growth in the first half of the year and 9.8 percent growth in the third quarter.

The report assesses the outlook for emerging East Asia, which comprises the 10 economies of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations along with China, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan, which is classified by the ADB as a newly industrial economy (NIE).
The other NIEs analyzed in the survey -- Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore -- are also expected to experience a similar slowdown in economic momentum next year, according to the report.
Hong Kong is expected to grow 4.3 percent clip in 2011, while South Korea and Singapore are seen as growing by 4.6 percent and 5.0 percent respectively, the report said.
China's economy is expected to remain strong, though signs exist that exports, industrial production, and fixed asset investment will moderate to some extent in 2011, the bank said.
The ADB projected China's economy to grow 10.1 percent in 2010 and 9.1 percent in 2011.
Average growth in emerging East Asia is likely to be 7.3 percent in 2011 after growing 8.8 percent in 2010, the bank said.

"Emerging East Asia's large, long-standing trade surpluses against developed economies' increasing debt have raised tensions culminating in calls for emerging East Asia to allow its currencies to appreciate to match its growing economic strength, " the report said.

"Rapidly growing interdependence in trade and finance and the increasing importance of spillovers and contagion effects within the region make regional exchange rate cooperation essential," the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 18:45:07 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$30.630.
Turnover totaled US$563 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.675 and moved between NT$30.080 and NT$30.685 before the close.

Further inflows of foreign funds lent support to the New Taiwan dollar and raised the local currency above the previous closing level during most of the trading session before Taiwan's central bank intervened, dealers said.

Foreign banks remained the major buyers of the New Taiwan dollar. They cut their U.S. dollar positions as they were betting that the local currency would extend its momentum once the U.S. engaged in further quantitative easing to boost its economy by pumping funds into the market, dealers said.

Despite the gains posted by the New Taiwan dollar, the daily trading volume remained moderate as many traders took to the sidelines, waiting for China to release its November consumer price index, the dealers said.
There have been fears that once China takes further steps to fight inflation by tightening liquidity, foreign funds may flee the markets in the region, they added.
The moderate turnover made it easier for central bank's intervention to push up the value of the U.S. dollar above the NT$30.50 level again, dealers said.
They said the central bank's efforts to prevent rapid appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar are expected to continue in a bid to protect Taiwan's exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amendments to NHI law unlikely to be passed before deadline
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 20:11:14 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Kelven Huang, Sophia Yeh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: It was uncertain Tuesday whether amendments to the National Health Insurance (NHI) Act would clear the floor of the Legislative Yuan that day as scheduled, after ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers refused to endorse the bill.

"It is the most ridiculous bill I have ever reviewed, " blasted Legislator Yang Li-huan at a KMT caucus meeting earlier in the day, accusing the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) of failing to establish a clear premium calculation base and premium rates when trying to introduce a second-generation NHI system through the amendments.
Yang said the DOH has merely drawn lines to divide employers, the government and the rest of the public into three groups, but has failed to clearly define their individual premium payment rates.

The DOH hopes to leave that problem for a planned NHI committee in charge of the review of premium rates to decide, a move that Yang said is like offering a blank check allowing the committee to do basically as it pleases.

Regardless of an order from the party to support the amendments, several KMT lawmakers, dissatisfied with some clauses in the bill, refused to attend a plenary meeting of the Legislative Yuan that day. Their absence threatened the fulfillment of the Dec. 7 deadline set by the legislature for the passage of the NHI Act amendments.

Under the DOH-promoted second-generation NHI system, which it says is designed to achieve fairness in the calculation of premiums, the insurance premiums are calculated based on total household incomes instead of the individual salaries of the insured.
However, disputes have been raised on many controversial issues, including how household incomes should be calculated and how much the government should pay in its premium subsidies.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) also raised concerns that the new compulsory health insurance system will increase the financial burden on most of the insured.

Releasing the results of a survey on the second-generation system, the DPP said it found that 76.8 percent of the respondents have no idea about the content of the new system, while 22.3 percent said they do.

Asked whether the government can achieve the goal of "having the rich people pay more for their premiums to allow the poor to pay less" that it has set for the introduction of the new NHI system, only 25.8 percent of the respondents said the government can do this, while 58.9 percent said it cannot, DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang said.
Lin said that 56.8 percent of the people surveyed assessed that they will have to pay a higher premium once the new health system is implemented, while 17.1 percent said their premiums will drop.
While the DOH says that over 60 percent of the people will enjoy lower premiums, the survey results show that most of the respondents have a different view, Lin said.
The survey was conducted Monday with a total of 548 valid samples collected. The margin of error was plus or minus 4.27 percentage points, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seals of 100 train stations to honor Taiwan's 100th birthday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 20:17:26 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A seal designer showcased 100 of his works Tuesday that capture the beauty of 100 railway stations around Taiwan, part of the Taiwan Railway Administration's (TRA's) efforts to encourage the public to take the train to celebrate the nation's 100th founding anniversary next year.

Chen shih-chu, a 42-year-old who has been an engraver since he was 19, presented the seals to the TRA at the launch of a railway travel journal dedicated to the Republic of China's 100th founding anniversary.
The seals are printed in a "passport" introducing 219 train stations around the country, with spaces for 100 of the stations in which train-lovers can mark a space proving they have been there.

To get a feeling for each station, Chen said he spent more than six months discussing with historians and visiting local areas before engraving his passion for the railway into three-square-centimeter "canvases."
"Trains are like birds to me, " Chen said. "They bring you to secret corners that people don't know about."

To create a nostalgic ambiance, Chen used cypress and rubber to first draft 200 samples and then whittled the number by half to select the 100 official symbols. The remainder of the 219 stations featured in the "passport" are described only in writing.

"Coming up with 100 snapshots of 100 train stations requires much effort," Chen said. "It's not only about the buildings themselves but also about the surrounding streets, the cultures and the people."
According to the TRA, the "passports" will be available in the stations they represent throughout next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passage of NHI amendments hits snag

TEXT.P: Legislative proceedings on amendments to a bill that will allow the introduction of a second-generation national health insurance (NHI) system hit a snag Tuesday amid widespread uproar from lawmakers across party lines, mainly because of the proposed premium calculation formula.

The legislators did not let the Department of Health (DOH)-proposed amendments to the NHI Act clear the legislative floor, nor did they review most of the 20 clauses in the bill that are still in dispute.
They resolved that the disputed clauses should be debated during the next legislative session on Friday.

Responding to the impasse, President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , said a well-designed and operated national health insurance is a must for the country, meaning that the second-generation NHI system must clear the legislative floor, according to KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin.

The president, nevertheless, stressed that while seeking to have the amendments passed into law, the KMT and its legislative caucus should handle it carefully and try to avoid creating negative implications for society, according to Su.

The development was a disappointment for Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who vowed the previous week to push through the bill and who said that "whatever it takes, the bill must be passed into law Dec. 7."
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang was apparently also disappointed with the development, saying that "the legislators were too calculating."

The bill mainly involves a new scheme for calculating premiums based on total household income rather than the existing system, which considers only individuals' salaries and wages. The change is considered essential to keep the cash-strapped program operational.

The KMT legislators lambasted the revision to the premium rates and a plan to calculate premiums based on "presumed income, " under which the very poorest sector of society will be charged according to the premise that they are earning more than NT$17,280 per month, whether they are actually earning money or not. The KMT lawmakers refused to endorse the amendments.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spelled out its opposition to the plan to calculate premiums based on "presumed income" and a plan under which salaried workers will be required to pay higher premiums.
The DPP lawmakers also suggested that a health insurance donation be included in the land value increment tax as a means of making the wealthy pay more for health insurance.

They also suggested that the new premium rates to be stipulated in the second- generation NHI system should be capped at under 2.7 percent of household income -- compared to a figure of 3.5 percent put forward by the DOH.

Also Tuesday, the non-profit Consumers' Foundation opposed the proposed amendments, saying that they will end up causing the health insurance system to "rob the poor to help the rich." (By Lee Shu-hua, Justin Su, Chen Ching-fang, Ho Meng-kuei and Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: China wireless communications service provider seeks TDR listing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:02:23 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: SIM Technology Group Ltd, a China-based provider of handsets, wireless communication modules and related applications, is seeking to list Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) on the main board, the Taiwan Stock Exchange said Tuesday.

SIM, which has submitted an application to the TWSE for approval, is planning to raise about NT$1.85 billion (US$61.36 million) by issuing up to 165 million TDRs, each of which will represent two common shares of the company, according to its prospectus.

The Chinese company, which has production facilities and research and development centers in Shanghai, Beijing, Shenzhen and Shenyang, will use the proceeds to expand its production capacity and purchase production equipment, the prospectus said.
The company has been listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2005.
After more than 20 years of providing mobile communications products, SIM said, it has established close business ties through strategic alliances with cell phone makers in Japan and South Korea.
It said it has also built partnerships with three major telecom operators in China -- China Telecom, China Mobile and China Unicom.

"We believe that the TDR Issue will not only broaden the shareholder base of the SIM Group, but will also increase public awareness and promote the group's corporate image internationally, " Executive Director of SIM Wong Cho-Tung said in a statement on the company's website.
"Our competitive advantages will hence be enhanced, benefiting our overall business development and ultimately maximizing returns for our shareholders," Wong added.
In the first half of this year, SIM posted about NT$419 million in net profit, up 248 percent from a year earlier.
Yuanta Securities has been appointed as the underwriter of the TDR listing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asustek's LCD shipments expected to surge in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:21:02 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Asustek Computer Inc., the world's fifth-largest PC maker, said Tuesday that it plans to sell 4.5 million LCD monitors next year, representing better-than- expected growth in a saturated market.

The Taiwan-based company, with shipments that grew by 12.1 percent from 3.3 million LCD monitors in 2009 to an estimated 3.7 million units this year, aims to strengthen its global ranking in 2011 with a year-on-year growth of 21.6 percent, said Asustek Sales General Manager Kevin Du at a press conference held for the ICT Month tech fair.
Asustek expects a 2.5 percent share of the 2010 LCD market globally, increasing to 3 percent in 2011, Du said.

"It is not easy to record growth in the LCD market, as it is saturated. Therefore, we plan to introduce a series of products that will meet consumer demand, such as 3D built-in and super-thin models," he added.

Meanwhile, the company will still top the local LCD market with an estimated 500,000 units shipped this year, about 28 percent of the total shipments in Taiwan, followed by Acer Inc., ViewSonic Corp. and Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., said Vincent Chiou, associate vice president of Asustek's display business unit.

Unlike personal computer and cellphone markets, in which the top three brands have a nearly 70 percent-80 percent share, Taiwan's LCD market is better distributed, despite a combined total of 49 percent market share by Asustek and Acer, he said.

Asustek also plans to launch more monitors with the energy-saving LED technology before the end of the year, as the company forecast its penetration rate of LED monitors in Taiwan will grow from 30 percent in 2010 to 45 percent-50 percent next year, Chiou noted.
In addition to monitors, Asustek will begin to sell a handheld LED projector in the second half of 2011, targeting business workers holding 10-member group meetings, he said.
"With the advantages of quick booting and low-cost components, LED projectors are a better choice for consumers compared to the traditional models that use incandescent lightbulbs," Chiou said.
He said the company will then launch larger-sized LED projectors for use in offices and homes, respectively, but he declined to reveal a timetable for this plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Performance artist to stage show in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:33:47 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A performance artist who spent five months taking pictures of himself doing handstands in various unusual locations will present a solo performance Dec. 9-11 in Taipei to share "a different Taiwan" through his less-familiar artform, the artist said in Taipei Tuesday.

Huang Ming-cheng, a renowned stuntman and a dancer with the Lafa Dance Company who has been nicknamed "Mr. Candle, " spent almost half of this year traveling around Taiwan and the outlying islands taking more than 1,200 pictures and 250 video clips from his unusual vantage point.
From March to August, Huang took photos of himself standing upside down at locations such as near cliffs, on rocks in the sea, on top of roofs, even on the back seat of a scooter.

He told reporters at a press conference that he suffered extreme pain from the handstand project, but carried on with the mission because he wanted to show the beauty of Taiwan to more people and because it was something he had wanted to do since the age of 13.
He said the solo performance is inspired by what he saw and heard during his journey.
"Taiwan is a place full of quiet heroes, as well as those who do not care too much about the environment, and I would like to show the two forces in my production," he said.

Huang said performance art shows, particularly those performed by a single artist, are not a mainstream thing in Taiwan, but he promised that his performance is fun, entertaining, and at the same time offers something that is close to "our collective memory."

He said he knows the secret of how to make audiences laugh and enjoy the show, as he staged more than 500 performances across Taiwan working as a street entertainer for eight months prior to the launch of his handstand project.
In the solo performance titled "Transparent Kingdom, " he will play six roles, portraying various personalities including politicians, ordinary men and a young man in search of freedom.
Projections of the pictures and videos of the artist doing handstands will be included in the one-hour performance, and Huang will also demonstrate his amazing vocal mimicry and acrobatic skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan telecom companies to expand wireless coverage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:49:21 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Two of Taiwan's major wireless service providers said Tuesday they plan to expand their paid wireless coverage, amid the growing popularity of wireless- based smartphones and tablet computers.

Chunghwa Telecom Co., Taiwan's largest telecom service operator, said in a statement that by the end of this year it will provide wireless access at some 4,700 convenience stores in the 7-Eleven chain, which is operated by President Chain Store Corp.
This will increase the number of Chunghwa Telecom "hotspots" to 6,000, allowing its mobile device subscribers more opportunities for wireless connection, the company said.
"Chunghwa Telecom will continue to invest more than NT$3 billion (US$99.6 million) per year in the expansion and upgrade of its Internet infrastructure," company president Chang Shaio-tung said.
By next year, the number of hotspots is expected to exceed 10,000, he added.

At present, Chunghwa Telecom has 5.26 million third-generation (3G) wireless service subscribers, some of whom will have free access to the wireless service at 7-Eleven stores, depending on their telecom packages.

James Hsieh, chief operating officer of President Chain Store, said that the introduction of wireless hotspots at 7-Eleven stores will be an expansion of the role the chain now plays in the lives of consumers.
He added that 7-Eleven is working to turn itself into a "cloud convenience store" aimed at meeting consumers' mobile Internet needs.
Meanwhile, Q-ware Communications Co., a Taipei-based company that operates the largest wireless Wi-Fi service network in Taiwan under the brand WIFLY, also plans to broaden its coverage.
"The number of WIFLY service spots will be doubled from the existing 5,000 to nearly 10,000 by the end of this year, " the company's Product Manager Yu Chih- ming told CNA in a telephone interview.
"Right now, we have already achieved 70 percent of that target, " he said, adding that the goal for next year is 15,000 hotspots.
Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., the country's third largest telecom service provider, is a major shareholder of Q-ware Communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banker denies charges in 2nd trial of financial scandal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:58:26 (By Lai Yu-chia and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A prominent local banker denied Tuesday his involvement in an offshore paper company's buying and selling of structured notes or in Chinatrust Financial Holdings Co.'s bid to take over Mega Financial Holdings Co.
Jeffrey Koo Jr., former vice chairman of Chinatrust Financial, read his appeal before a second trial of what Taiwan media are calling the "Red Fire case" after the name of the paper firm.
"I did not have any role in making those investment decisions. Both were made based on the professional judgment of my managers, " Koo told the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 22:16:22 (By Lin Chang-shun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Prosecutors Office appealed Tuesday the High Court's acquittal ruling in November of three suspects in a high-profile murder case known as the "Hsichih Trio" that has been going on for nearly 20 years.
