DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to stage design expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 22:43:23 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest design exhibition will open in Taipei Dec. 11, featuring 1,764 works from 630 exhibitors, including designers and design companies, on this year's theme "beneficence," the organizers said Tuesday.

The theme of the 2010 Taiwan Design Expo is aimed at urging designers to minimize the hazards of the products they design and to use local resources and techniques, said the Ministry of Economic Affairs' (MOEA's) Industrial Development Bureau, which is co-organizing the event along with the Taipei City government.
The Theme Pavilion, one of 10 pavilions at the expo highlighted by the organizers, will showcase works from 51 local designers in a variety of fields, such as fashion designer Johan Ku.
Products on display will include a flashlight and a notebook computer that both make use of bamboo, as well as an interactive coin donation box.
The annual expo has attracted more than 2 million visitors over the past seven years, according to the organizers.
The event, which will be open to the public free of charge, will run through Dec. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese athletes to compete at Para Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 22:50:40 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou presented a Chinese Taipei flag Tuesday to a team of physically challenged athletes who will take part in the 2010 Asian Para Games in China's Guangzhou.
A total of 77 Taiwanese athletes will compete in 12 events during the Asian Para Games to be held Dec. 12-19, according to the Sports Affairs Council.

Taiwan won 18 gold medals at the Far East and South Pacific Games for the Disabled (FESPIC) in the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur in 2006. That competition was replaced by the Asian Para Games this year, Ma noted at the presentation ceremony.
Depression and obesity, two of the major diseases of the 21st century, can be cured by participating in sports, Ma said, adding that "it is the best time to prove ourselves and honor Taiwan."
Visually impaired javelin thrower Chiang Chih-chung, who won two medals at the 2006 FESPIC, said he will try his best despite missing some training due to an ankle injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: Switzerland returns more of ex-president's deposits to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 22:53:12 (By Lin Chang-shun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Swiss authorities remitted US$82,075 from former President Chen Shui-bian's bank deposits to the prosecution authorities in Taipei Tuesday, the special prosecutors team said later that day.

To date, the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) of Switzerland has returned CHF20 million -- part of the money deposited by the former president in that country -- to the Supreme Prosecutors Office, the prosecutors said.

"This move once again demonstrates Switzerland's resolve to take action against those who use its financial centers for criminal purposes, and its intention to restore the assets of criminal origin to their rightful owners, " the OAG said in a press release that day.
The OAG noted that Chen was recently convicted of corruption. He is serving a 19-year jail term at the Taipei Prison in Guishan, Taoyuan County.

The special prosecutors team, which is responsible for tracking down the public assets hidden by the Chen family abroad, said that because of currency fluctuations, the money that was deposited by Chen and his family in the Swiss banks is worth less today than it was several years ago.

For instance, it said, on Nov. 15, the money was worth NT$667.31 million. As of Tuesday, the Swiss authorities had returned CHF20 million (some NT$620 million) to Taiwan. Based on Tuesday's exchange rate of NT$30.075 to the U.S. dollar, Taiwan has "lost" over NT$30 million.
Meanwhile, according to the OAG release, proceedings are continuing in order to establish the origin of the remainder of the Chen assets frozen in Switzerland.
Some CHF37 million has been seized in response to a request for mutual assistance filed by the Taiwanese authorities, said the release.
The prosecution said that only some US$493,000 of the US$21 million seized by the Swiss authorities remains to be returned to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek awarded for industrial achievements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 23:10:02 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: MediaTek Inc., Taiwan's No. 1 handset chip designer, has been awarded a special prize that encourages industrial firms to improve their achievements in environmental protection and energy-saving, the organizer of the award said Tuesday.

The Industrial Sustainable Excellence Award, known as Taiwan's Nobel Prize for the industrial sector, received 48 entries this year, from which seven winners were selected, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
MediaTek, which was the only winner awarded the special prize, represents the country's outstanding IC design ability, or "hard power," making it deserving of the honor, the MOEA said.
"It is gratifying to receive the prize, but it also puts us under pressure, " said MediaTek Chairman Tsai Ming-kai, who attributed the company's success to the correct policies of the government.
He also noted that Taiwan is going to have big opportunities in the emerging markets such as China, India and Southeast Asian countries.

About 1,000 Taiwanese companies have applied for consideration for the award since it was founded in 2000, 123 of which have been selected as winners and only nine of which have received the special prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asustek's LCD shipments expected to surge in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:21:02 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Asustek Computer Inc., the world's fifth-largest PC maker, said Tuesday that it plans to sell 4.5 million LCD monitors next year, representing better-than- expected growth in a saturated market.

The Taiwan-based company, with shipments that grew by 12.1 percent from 3.3 million LCD monitors in 2009 to an estimated 3.7 million units this year, aims to strengthen its global ranking in 2011 with a year-on-year growth of 21.6 percent, said Asustek Sales General Manager Kevin Du at a press conference held for the ICT Month tech fair.
Asustek expects a 2.5 percent share of the 2010 LCD market globally, increasing to 3 percent in 2011, Du said.

"It is not easy to record growth in the LCD market, as it is saturated. Therefore, we plan to introduce a series of products that will meet consumer demand, such as 3D built-in and super-thin models," he added.

Meanwhile, the company will still top the local LCD market with an estimated 500,000 units shipped this year, about 28 percent of the total shipments in Taiwan, followed by Acer Inc., ViewSonic Corp. and Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., said Vincent Chiou, associate vice president of Asustek's display business unit.

Unlike personal computer and cellphone markets, in which the top three brands have a nearly 70 percent-80 percent share, Taiwan's LCD market is better distributed, despite a combined total of 49 percent market share by Asustek and Acer, he said.

Asustek also plans to launch more monitors with the energy-saving LED technology before the end of the year, as the company forecast its penetration rate of LED monitors in Taiwan will grow from 30 percent in 2010 to 45 percent-50 percent next year, Chiou noted.
In addition to monitors, Asustek will begin to sell a handheld LED projector in the second half of 2011, targeting business workers holding 10-member group meetings, he said.
"With the advantages of quick booting and low-cost components, LED projectors are a better choice for consumers compared to the traditional models that use incandescent lightbulbs," Chiou said.
He said the company will then launch larger-sized LED projectors for use in offices and homes, respectively, but he declined to reveal a timetable for this plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Performance artist to stage show in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:33:47 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A performance artist who spent five months taking pictures of himself doing handstands in various unusual locations will present a solo performance Dec. 9-11 in Taipei to share "a different Taiwan" through his less-familiar artform, the artist said in Taipei Tuesday.

Huang Ming-cheng, a renowned stuntman and a dancer with the Lafa Dance Company who has been nicknamed "Mr. Candle, " spent almost half of this year traveling around Taiwan and the outlying islands taking more than 1,200 pictures and 250 video clips from his unusual vantage point.
From March to August, Huang took photos of himself standing upside down at locations such as near cliffs, on rocks in the sea, on top of roofs, even on the back seat of a scooter.

He told reporters at a press conference that he suffered extreme pain from the handstand project, but carried on with the mission because he wanted to show the beauty of Taiwan to more people and because it was something he had wanted to do since the age of 13.
He said the solo performance is inspired by what he saw and heard during his journey.
"Taiwan is a place full of quiet heroes, as well as those who do not care too much about the environment, and I would like to show the two forces in my production," he said.

Huang said performance art shows, particularly those performed by a single artist, are not a mainstream thing in Taiwan, but he promised that his performance is fun, entertaining, and at the same time offers something that is close to "our collective memory."

He said he knows the secret of how to make audiences laugh and enjoy the show, as he staged more than 500 performances across Taiwan working as a street entertainer for eight months prior to the launch of his handstand project.
In the solo performance titled "Transparent Kingdom, " he will play six roles, portraying various personalities including politicians, ordinary men and a young man in search of freedom.
Projections of the pictures and videos of the artist doing handstands will be included in the one-hour performance, and Huang will also demonstrate his amazing vocal mimicry and acrobatic skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan telecom companies to expand wireless coverage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/07/10 21:49:21 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Two of Taiwan's major wireless service providers said Tuesday they plan to expand their paid wireless coverage, amid the growing popularity of wireless- based smartphones and tablet computers.

Chunghwa Telecom Co., Taiwan's largest telecom service operator, said in a statement that by the end of this year it will provide wireless access at some 4,700 convenience stores in the 7-Eleven chain, which is operated by President Chain Store Corp.
This will increase the number of Chunghwa Telecom "hotspots" to 6,000, allowing its mobile device subscribers more opportunities for wireless connection, the company said.
"Chunghwa Telecom will continue to invest more than NT$3 billion (US$99.6 million) per year in the expansion and upgrade of its Internet infrastructure," company president Chang Shaio-tung said.
By next year, the number of hotspots is expected to exceed 10,000, he added.

At present, Chunghwa Telecom has 5.26 million third-generation (3G) wireless service subscribers, some of whom will have free access to the wireless service at 7-Eleven stores, depending on their telecom packages.

James Hsieh, chief operating officer of President Chain Store, said that the introduction of wireless hotspots at 7-Eleven stores will be an expansion of the role the chain now plays in the lives of consumers.
He added that 7-Eleven is working to turn itself into a "cloud convenience store" aimed at meeting consumers' mobile Internet needs.
Meanwhile, Q-ware Communications Co., a Taipei-based company that operates the largest wireless Wi-Fi service network in Taiwan under the brand WIFLY, also plans to broaden its coverage.
"The number of WIFLY service spots will be doubled from the existing 5,000 to nearly 10,000 by the end of this year, " the company's Product Manager Yu Chih- ming told CNA in a telephone interview.
"Right now, we have already achieved 70 percent of that target, " he said, adding that the goal for next year is 15,000 hotspots.
Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., the country's third largest telecom service provider, is a major shareholder of Q-ware Communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 8, or the third day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. reaffirms defense commitment to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/10 10:22:02 (By Zep Hu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: United States Deputy Secretary of State James Steinberg reaffirmed Tuesday Washington's commitment to help Taiwan meet its defense needs while at the same time calling for continued dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.
Steinberg stressed that promoting cross-strait stability remained a policy of the United States.

"We continue to believe that appropriate defensive arms sales to Taiwan gives Taiwan the confidence to engage the mainland, " Steinberg said in a speech on the future of the U.S.-China relationship at the Center for American Progress.

He said Washington was encouraged by the positive steps that have been taken between Taiwan and China and urged the two sides to continue to take steps to build trust to contribute to regional stability.
In particular, he said, China's decision to support Taiwan's participation as an observer in the World Health Assembly was an encouraging development.
Washington believes there are other opportunities for Taipei and Beijing to work together in places where statehood is not required for membership, such as climate change issues, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
AU Optronics November sales boosted by higher China demand
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 12:20:19 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Higher demand from China helped flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) post a month-on-month increase in sales in November, reversing a double-digit fall in the previous month, an analyst said Wednesday.
AUO on Tuesday reported November sales of NT$36.87 billion (US$1.23 billion), up 5 percent from October, after October revenues dropped 16.3 percent from September.
In the first 11 months to November, AUO's sales totaled NT$436.55 billion, up 35.4 percent from a year earlier.

In November, AUO's shipments of large-sized panels -- panels 10 inches or larger used to produce desktop computers, notebook computers and TVs -- rose 6.3 percent from October to about 9.72 million units.
During the same period, its shipments of small- and medium-sized panels rose 1.5 percent from a month earlier to exceed 18.04 million units.
"Ahead of the anticipated buying spree for the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday, many Chinese buyers are raising their inventories to meet demand," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
"AUO is simply one of the beneficiaries of the positive seasonal factor, in particular as China has accounted for more than 20 percent of the company's sales," Hsu said.
It remains to be seen, however, whether AUO's sales are stabilizing, Hsu said.
"As TV panel prices continue to fall amid fierce competition, AUO may feel the pinch from the lingering impact," Hsu said.

In the third quarter of 2010, panels used in TVs accounted for 56 percent of AUO's total sales, up from the 51 percent recorded in the second quarter, leaving the company more vulnerable to price volatility in the TV market.
A report released by Taiwan-based Topology Research Institute in late November said flat panel display prices are expected to bottom out in the first quarter of 2011 after inventory adjustments.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Stop, look and listen

TEXT.P: A bill that would introduce a second-generation national health insurance system did not clear the legislative floor Tuesday as previously expected, mainly because of differences between ruling and opposition lawmakers.

The greatest controversy surrounding the bill involves the income base used to calculate premiums. The new system would refer to personal income tax data of all individuals insured under the program to determine the income on which premiums would be charged.

This is a questionable concept because the existing tax system is widely considered to be unfair, with salary earners contributing 75 percent of personal income tax revenue. Capital gains and transitory income (gifts, inheritances) are not taxed and would be excluded.

Also, the bill does not specify the premium rate and the share of the premium to be paid by the government, employers and insured persons, which would be tantamount to giving administrative agencies a blank check to arbitrarily set premium rates and distribute the burden of paying premiums.
In addition, the bill barely addresses the issue of waste of medical resources, the most serious component of the system's huge deficit.

It is perhaps not a bad thing for the bill to get cut down. Stopping to look and listen before moving forward will increase our chances of creating a sustainable health insurance system. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold front continues to affect Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 12:52:52 (By Chen Shun-hsieh, Lin Heng-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan remained under the influence of a cold front Wednesday, with temperatures dropping as low as 9.4 degrees Celsius in Danshui in northern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
The cold front, which the CWB expects to keep a chill in the air until Friday, sent the mercury falling to its lowest level in Taiwan since temperatures began to cool.

The CWB said temperatures would range between 11 degrees and 21 degrees on Wednesday, and the skies over most parts of the country would remain clear because of the dry air brought to Taiwan by the cold front.
Hualien and Taitung counties along Taiwan's eastern coast were expected to see more clouds than in other areas, forecasters said.
The CWB predicted temperatures for Wednesday of 11-16 degrees in northern Taiwan, 12-18 degrees in central Taiwan, and 13-21 degrees in southern Taiwan.
The mercury should fall below 10 degrees overnight in areas north of Chiayi County and along the northeastern coast.
The cold weather will last until Friday, according to the bureau.
A low temperature warning has been issued to remind people and fish breeders to take necessary precautions, the bureau said.

Meanwhile, on Jade Mountain, also known as Yushan, temperatures fell as low as minus 8.3 degrees early Wednesday morning, the lowest reading seen anywhere in Taiwan since temperatures started to cool.
After the sun came out, temperatures warmed to minus 4-5 degrees, according to the staff manning a weather monitoring station on the mountain in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan's soft power

TEXT.P: Joseph Nye, a Harvard University professor, said in an interview with a local newspaper Tuesday that the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in June is the best testament to Taiwan's soft power.

Nye, a former dean of Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government who served as assistant secretary of defense during the Bill Clinton administration, is considered one of the 10 most influential international relations scholars in the United States.
He was scheduled to deliver a public speech in Taipei Wednesday.
The following is an excerpt of a United Daily News report of an interview with Nye:
Nye said Taiwan has deftly used its soft power and hard power to improve cross- strait relations and its own international standing over the past two years.
He especially lauded President Ma Ying-jeou's move to sign the ECFA with China, describing it as a very important step and the best testament to Taiwan's soft power.
Nye said he believes the ECFA, which lays out provisions for mutual tariff concessions and easier market access to boost bilateral trade and investment, will definitely benefit Taiwan.
Acknowledging that he noticed there are still doubts and criticism about the pact in Taiwanese society, Nye said a smart leader should deal with such differing views properly.

Nye pointed out that the procurement of weapons from the United States is no longer Taiwan's only bargaining chip in negotiations with China. Soft power is a more effective and enduring way to solve cross-strait disputes, he said.

For instance, he went on, Taiwan's democratic system and free market economy can not only win recognition from the United States and European countries but can also attract the admiration of Chinese young people.
Nye, who has also served as a deputy assistant secretary of state, said that at present, China's People's Liberation Army still cannot take over Taiwan easily.

Noting that U.S. arms sales to Taiwan are aimed primarily at increasing Taiwan's bargaining power in negotiations with China, Nye said military might has never been the only choice and that Taiwan has better options.

He recognized Taiwan's launch of peaceful dialogue with China while striving to beef up its self-defense capability, saying that the practice provides the best model for the exercise of smart power that he has been advocating.
Nye further said he looks forward to seeing Taiwan and China kick off political talks following the smooth start of their economic dialogue.

Even though China is not expected to recognize Taiwan's sovereign status, Nye said, Taiwan should still endeavor to assert its cause and should at least try to have its voice heard in the international arena.
Nye also said that Beijing should allow Taiwan to have its own international space.
Although it might take time for Beijing to change its position, Nye said, Taiwan will be able to realize that goal through negotiations.

Nye also said that if anybody were to think the U.S. will "abandon" Taiwan because of the cross-strait detente, it would be a misconception or misplaced worry, because Taiwan has used its soft power, such as culture and economy, to win itself a spot on the international stage. (Dec. 8, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, South Korea can learn from each other: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 15:26:10 (By Emmannuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang said Wednesday that he had not received any information of a reported planned visit by South Korean military personnel to the Taiwan-controlled former frontline island of Kinmen, but that if the report is true, the two countries can learn from each other.

"The Defense Ministry will do whatever it can about promoting military diplomacy, " Chao told reporters in response to foreign wire reports that according to South Korean President Lee Myung-bak, a South Korean military delegation may visit Kinmen this month.

It was reported that South Korea wishes to gain knowledge about the establishment of the Kinmen fortifications as a reference for its own efforts to fortify its five western border islands, including Yeonpyeong, which was attacked by North Korea last month.

Asked what Kinmen -- a military outpost now transformed into a tourist attraction following improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- can teach, Chao noted that the military controlled the outlying island just off the coast of southeastern China for many years.
As a result, there is still a solid underground infrastructure on the island that survived many Chinese strikes, including extensive shelling in 1958, Chao said.

Responding to the report, Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang suggested that the Defense Ministry should ask South Korea to allow Taiwanese officials to inspect South Korean military facilities in return, since the two countries are not diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Canada ink cancer research cooperation deal
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/10 15:46:04 (By Paul Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) signed a memorandum of understanding Tuesday for cooperation on cancer research with Canada's Terry Fox Research Institute (TFRI).
The agreement was signed by NSC Minister Lee Lou-chuang and TFRI Scientific Director Victor Lin.

David Tawei Lee, Taiwan's representative to Canada, who was also present at the ceremony, said the TFRI has contributed considerably to cancer research through its sponsorship program and that Taiwan hopes cooperation with the TFRI will allow the country to do its part to help enhance human health.
The TFRI, launched in 2007, is the brainchild of the Terry Fox Foundation, which supports cancer research through the annual Terry Fox Run fundraising campaign.
According to Lin, who is also an academician of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the TFRI is mainly involved in collaboration with cancer hospitals and research organizations.
The Terry Fox Foundation has committed a minimum of C$50 million (US$49.42 million) over five years to support the work of the TFRI, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lien's office denies receiving Chinese peace award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 16:04:38 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The office of ruling Kuomintang honorary Chairman and former Vice President Lien Chan dismissed on Wednesday an Associated Press report that a nongovernmental Beijing-based committee had picked him as this year's recipient of the "Confucius Peace Prize."
"There is absolutely no such thing as Lien receiving such an award. We have never heard of it, " said Ting Yuan-chao, the director and spokesman of Lien's office.
Another person in Lien's office also said the office had not received any information related to the news.

According to the AP report, the award was first suggested by a Chinese tabloid last month as an answer to the Nobel Peace Prize won by Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo for his struggle to implement democracy in the People's Republic of China.
What started as a semi-farce reportedly became a reality three weeks later, as AP said it has received a statement from the committee confirming the award and the name of the honoree.

"Named after the famed philosopher, the new prize was created to interpret the viewpoints of peace of (the) Chinese (people) , the awards committee said in a statement it released to the AP on Tuesday," the story said.
The article also cited the chairman of the award committee, Tan Changliu, as saying his group was not an official government body but did work closely with China's Ministry of Culture.

Lien, 75, was reportedly chosen from among a number of nominees, including Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, former South African President Nelson Mandela, former U.S. President Jimmy Carter, and the China-appointed Panchen Lama, the second highest figure in Tibetan Buddhism.
The report quoted the award committee as saying that Lien was selected for "having built a bridge of peace between the mainland and Taiwan."
In 2005, Lien became the first Kuomintang chairman to set foot in China since 1949 when he met with Hu Jintao in Beijing, who received him in his capacity as the head of the Communist Party of China.
The following year, as his term as KMT chairman was ending, Lien led a group of prominent Taiwanese business figures to China for an economic forum.
Since 2008, he has been named by President Ma Ying-jeou to represent the country in three APEC leadership summits.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU visa waiver signals improving Taiwan-Europe ties
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 16:59:19 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: When the Council of the European Union unanimously finalized the inclusion of Taiwan in its visa-waiver program in late November, local travelers were the main winners, but it also highlighted Taiwan's improving ties with Europe.

President Ma Ying-jeou hailed the EU approval as "an important accomplishment in the diplomatic history of the Republic of China, " one that he said also showed that Taiwan is a "respectable" country.

The visa exemption was another sign of progress in Taiwan's relations with European countries, following its signing of a new aviation agreement with the United Kingdom and a double taxation avoidance agreement with Hungary earlier this year.

Chen Chien-jen, a former foreign affairs minister who served as Taiwan's representative to the EU from 2004 to 2006, attributed the breakthrough and improving ties with Europe in part to Ma's "flexible diplomacy" policy aimed at reducing tensions with China.
Chen said the EU has always hoped for peace across the Taiwan Strait and that the two sides become more engaged with each other.

The confrontational relations between Taiwan and China that existed when the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was in power from 2000 to 2008 and its advocacy of "one country on either side" limited to some extent progress in negotiating the visa-waiver issue with the EU, Chen said.

"The success in securing visa exemptions for the Schengen Area is a positive result of improving cross-strait relations, " said Chen, who was Taiwan's representative to the United States from 2000 to 2004.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials echoed Chen's view. They said that getting the EU visa exemption was once considered a "mission impossible" because Taiwan's relations with Europe have traditionally not been as close as its ties with the United States and Japan.

But Ma's conciliatory approach and pragmatic efforts to improve relations with China drew public recognition from EU authorities on many occasions, the officials said, and MOFA diplomats at home and in Europe took advantage of the new atmosphere to push for the goal.
The drive finally took off in July when the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, put forth a concrete bill to include Taiwan in the visa-waiver program.

The proposal then went through a 15-step process and is now waiting only to be signed by the European Parliament speaker and rotating EU president on Dec. 15, considered to be a formality, before taking effect in January 2011.

After the proposal cleared its last hurdle in the Council of the European Union on Nov. 25 by unanimous consent without discussion, Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy C.T. Yang said it was great news that Taiwan had long waited for.

The visa waiver means that Republic of China (Taiwan) passport holders will be able to enter the 35 European countries included in the program visa-free and stay for up to 90 days within a six-month period.

The exemption will apply to 25 Schengen Area countries, comprising 22 EU member states and three non-EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland -- and three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
It also includes seven smaller European countries and territories -- the Vatican, Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.

"The EU inclusion marks a giant step toward our aim to boost the number of countries that grant Taiwan visa-waiver privileges to 100 by 2011, when we celebrate our country's 100th anniversary, " Yang said.

There are now 96 countries and territories offering Taiwanese citizens visa exemptions, with 75 granting local passport holders visa-waiver privileges and 21 others allowing travelers to pick up visas on arrival.
In the two and a half years since Ma launched his "flexible diplomacy" approach, 43 more countries or territories have granted visa-free access to ROC passport holders.

The EU exemption came three days after Canada granted Taiwan the same privilege on Nov. 22. Yang said the EU and Canada exemptions would save Taiwan people visa application fee of around NT$1.5 billion (US$49.18 million) every year, including more than NT$ 1 billion for the Schengen visas. An average of 310,000 Taiwan nationals visit Europe every year, according to MOFA statistics.

In the coming years, Yang said, Taiwan will be exploring visa-free opportunities in countries such as the United States, Australia, Malaysia, Vietnam, Myanmar, the Philippines and 18 oversea territories of the United Kingdom, France and the Netherlands.
Taiwan will also keep seeking visa exemptions in six Balkan countries -- Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia, the minister added. margiem/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: Public Art Work of NCKU Hospital Clinic Building Inaugurated

TEXT.P: The opening ceremony of the public art work Window of Firmamentby artist Aso Hideho is held at 8:30am, December 8th, in the Culture Hall of the Clinic Building of NCKU Hospital, where President Michael Ming-Chiao Lai, Senior Executive Vice-President Hwung-Hweng Hwung, Superintendent Pin-Wen Lin of NCKU Hospital, Dean Chyi-Her Lin of College of Medicine, artist Aso Hideho and creator Lin Shuen-Long from DADA Art, as well as teachers, students and personnel from NCKU Hospital have attended the event.

NCKU President Michael Ming-Chiao Lai expressed,I believe art can cultivate our mind and change ones temperament. For the past few years, National Cheng Kung University has undergone artistic transformation, and today, NCKU Hospital is undergoing an artistic transformation as well. Patients who enter the hospital need physical treatment and also psychological treatment. Thus, I believe it is a wonderful thing that a piece of artwork can reside in a hospital. It is a historical moment for National Cheng Kung University and a new milestone for the Hospital.

Superintendent Pin-Wen Lin of NCKU Hospital revealed,Many people have spared time to attend this significant event and observe the public art work.Window of Firmament,located at the top ceiling of the Culture Hall, can elevate space aesthetics and urban environmental quality to reduce the gloominess and sadness of the Hospital, without affecting the work space and the treatment operations. In the future, I hope the Hospital can install a telescope for the visiting guests, patients, colleagues as well as citizens to appreciate and observe the beautiful piece of artwork in greater detail.

Artist Aso Hideho said,I am extremely pleased to be here to observe my work with all the guests. It has taken me about one year of efforts to get here, as I have traveled back and forth between Japan and Taiwan for 9 times and stayed in Taiwan for approximately 180 days. The artwork formed by La Mosaique and La Fresque is the efforts of more than one thousand people, and I want to express my gratitude particularly toward DADA Art.

He stated,In the past, I have always completed my artwork from a compilation of thoughts, but this time is different. When I explored NCKU Hospital one year ago, the image of theWindow Firmamentalready appeared before my eyes.

He further explained,The creative concept of a window slowly descending on the land from the sky has always been on my mind, and this piece of artwork is one of the realizations of my idea. The original semantics of the word La Mosaique is the same as the word music. Ancient Greeks believed that besides stars, there were also beautiful melodies in the sky. The shiny stars are small pieces of work, representing colors and shapes, in La Mosaique, just like the notes which compose melodies. Thus, La Mosaique has been considered a work to be presented to the goddess.

Aso Hideho added,Inheriting the classical vocabulary and re-performing in the modern space, one can see dots of stars shining in the Window of Firmament.I hope my work can trace back to the origin of life, remind people of the old banyan trees most commonly seen in Tainan, the ancient capital, allow people to experience the mysteries and wonders of the universe, and integrate into peoples lives and bring new hope.

TheWindow of Firmamentis a large dome with a circular arch, which is 10m in diameter and 80cm in concave and made up of Glass Fiber Reinforced Cement as its base, and it resembles a starry sky painted in constellation myths with marble lines, hiding the origin of human life and capturing the hymns for human life.
