DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China seek to narrow differences on investment pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 17:11:06 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is continuing to negotiate with China on an investment protection agreement with the goal of narrowing the remaining differences between the two sides, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Wednesday.

According to Shih, the talks have not been easy because the government needs to ensure that the agreement is in line with internationally accepted practices, takes into consideration the special status of cross-Taiwan Strait ties, and meets the needs of Taiwanese investors in China.
"We would rather be cautious than sign the agreement in haste, " said Shih.

The failure to reach consensus has led the two sides to postpone the signing of the deal, which was originally scheduled for the next meeting between the chief negotiators on each side slated to take place later this month.

The deadlock is mainly because of China's opposition to Taiwan's proposal to have an international organization settle cross-strait investment disputes, out of fear that cross-strait relations would be "internationalized" as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to help flat panel makers after EU hands down fines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 18:02:09 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) expressed concerns on Wednesday over potential fines the European Commission could slap on several Taiwanese flat panel makers for alleged price fixing and said the government would provide any assistance necessary.

Duh Tyzz-jiun, director general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, told the Central News Agency that as long as the accused companies needed assistance when facing disciplinary action, the government would try its best to help them.

In July last year, the European Commission brought charges against four Taiwanese firms -- Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., AU Optronics Corp. Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. -- along with LG Display of South Korea for price fixing.
Samsung Electronics, the world's largest flat panel maker, was not charged since it alerted the European Commission to the price-fixing practices.
Chi Mei merged with Innolux Display Corp. to form Chimei Innolux Corp. in March.

The EU antitrust regulator accused these firms of violating EU laws through a conspiracy to engage in unfair price fixing practices to hurt flat panel buyers in the production of products such as computers, mobile phones, TVs, digital watches and MP3 players.

The European Commission is expected to issue a decision Wednesday against the five manufacturers, which could face total fines ranging between 600 million euros (US$801 million) and 700 million euros.
Duh said the MOEA has made contact with the four local companies and offered its help that will be based on the decision laid down by the European Commission.
He said the companies have told the ministry they will carefully study the decision and figure out the impact it will have on them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 18:20:26 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.076 to close at the day's high of NT$30.706.
Turnover totaled US$532 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.680 and moved to a low of NT$30.115 before rebounding.

Dealers said the U.S. dollar regained steam against other Asian currencies in the region, in particular against the South Korean won, amid escalating tensions on the Korean Peninsula after reports of an artillery drill by North Korea.
The strength of the greenback in the region offset selling of the currency to some extent in the Taiwan foreign exchange market, the dealers said.

The New Taiwan dollar has been boosted by continued inflows of foreign funds, prompting investors, in particular foreign banks, to buy into the local currency while cutting their U.S. dollar positions, dealers said.

Foreign traders are betting that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will adopt further measures to ease liquidity to boost the U.S. economy and that the liquidity will spill over to the markets in Asia, including Taiwan, to shore up the value of the New Taiwan dollar, the dealers said.

A stronger U.S. dollar in the region has made it easier for Taiwan's central bank in its intervention efforts on the Taiwan foreign exchange market to boost the U.S. dollar to above the NT$30.50 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry denies plan to acquire submarines from Russia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 18:42:47 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's defense ministry on Wednesday denied a news report that it is exploring the possibility of collaborating with Russia to build and acquire submarines to boost the island's defense capabilities.
"There is absolutely no such plan, " Vice Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang said while fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee.

The Chinese-language Next Magazine reported that a task force comprising officials of the Navy and the CSBC Corp. Taiwan visited Russia in October to discuss the possibility of collaborating with shipbuilders there to build submarines for Taiwan.
The Navy Command Headquarters also rebutted the report in a statement.
"The Navy has no plans to acquire submarines from sources other than the United States," the statement said.
The U.S. has been the biggest supplier of defense weapons to Taiwan.

The administration of former U.S. President George W. Bush announced a robust arms sale package to Taiwan in 2001, including eight conventional submarines, but the submarine deal has yet to be substantiated.

The Navy Command Headquarters said that the submarine procurement deal is being screened by the U.S. Department of State and other related agencies and that it will make every effort to prompt the U.S. authorities to speed up the sale of the vessels to Taiwan.

Taiwan currently has four submarines but only two of them -- the Swordfish models purchased in 1980s from the Netherlands -- are in active service. The two other, which have been in service since World War II, are used mainly for training purposes.
Meanwhile, CSBC Corp Taiwan did not deny the reported trip to Russia but said "it had nothing to do with the Navy."
"No naval officers were part of the team that visited Russia last October for business purposes, " said Ying Tze-hsiang, a ranking CSBC official who led the delegation.
Ying said the CSBC delegation was seeking to tap into business opportunities in Russia on one hand and to try to strike technical cooperation deals with Russian builders on the other.
He explained that his corporation needs to expand its overseas market to cope with the increasing competition from shipbuilders in South Korea, Japan and China.

In addition, CSBC plans to acquire Russian expertise in building ice-breaking ships, as part of CSBC's efforts to meet increasing demand for transportation on the route between the North Pole and Shanghai, China, Ying said.

Besides, Russia, with its rich in marine resources, is in urgent need of financial support to build fishing vessels -- another reason for the leading Taiwan shipbuilder to consider partnerships with shipbuilders there, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese students interested in Taiwan's food culture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 18:57:50 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fruit and its food have become major attractions for Japanese students in Taiwan, according to a student delegation from Japan that visited the Ministry of Education (MOE) Wednesday.

The 24-member student group from Japan's Fukuoka Girls' High School arrived in Taiwan Dec. 6 and attended a presentation introducing Taiwan's education system that was held by the MOE's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations.

One of the students, Yamauchi Rikako, expressed her interest in studying in Taiwan and said Taiwan's fruit is well-known in Japan and that her motivation for visiting was to sample the food and experience the culture.
Bureau Director Lin Wen-tong noted that every year, Taiwan invites groups of high school students from Japan to get a taste of local school life and help improve their understanding of the country.

This year's delegation is staying with host families and will visit four schools, the Lungshan Temple and various night markets in Taipei, with eight Taiwanese high school students fluent in Japanese accompanying the delegates to assist with interpretation.
The girls will wind up their visit Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC November sales down on stronger New Taiwan dollar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 19:05:08 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , the world's second largest contract chipmaker, said Wednesday it saw a slight drop in sales in November as a result of the New Taiwan dollar's surge against the U.S. dollar.
Last month, UMC posted NT$10.44 billion (US$347 million) in sales, down 2.43 percent from October, but 14.03 percent higher than the previous year.
In the first 11 months of this year, UMC's sales totaled NT$110.25 billion, up 38.99 percent year-on-year.
However, in October, the foundry operator's sales fell 2.23 percent from September to NT$10.7 billion on appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar.
"The export oriented electronic sector is sensitive to exchange rate changes," Horizon Securities analyst Benson Huang said.
"The recent significant gains posted by the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback has affected the revenue of many local high tech firms, and UMC is no exception," Huang said.
Since the end of August, the New Taiwan dollar has risen more than 4 percent against the U.S. dollar as foreign funds continue to flow into Taiwan.
UMC said if the New Taiwan dollar gains 1 percent against the U.S. dollar, its quarterly sales can be expected to fall by 1 percent.
In the third quarter of this year, UMC recorded NT$32.65 billion in sales, up 19.10 precent from the second quarter.
Huang forecast that UMC's sales in December will continue to be affected by the foreign exchange factor unless the New Taiwan dollar turns weaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister defends new health insurance system proposal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 20:08:54 (By Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) chief defended his department's proposed amendments to the National Health Insurance (NHI) Act Wednesday, saying that even among single-person households, 30 percent of such households will have lower national health insurance (NHI) premiums.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang made the statement to reporters after the amendments failed to clear the legislative floor the previous day.

Many lawmakers refused to endorse the amendment bill, which mainly involves a new scheme for calculating premiums based on total household incomes instead of personal salaries, until disputes over some controversial clauses have been resolved.

The disputes mostly focus on the new premium calculation formula and a plan to calculate premiums based on so-called "presumed income" that is proposed to be used for those who have no income records, such as dependent housewives.

The idea of "presumed income" drew strong opposition from lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , as well as from a handful of ruling Kuomintang legislators, who argued that it is unreasonable to treat people with no income as earners.

Under the concept of "presumed income, " people without income records on their annual tax reports will be charged an NHI premium calculated on the national minimum wage of NT$17,880 (US$590) per month.

The DPP and some civic groups have accused the concept of violating the spirit of the planned new NHI system -- which is supposed to pursue social equality by making the rich pay more to allow the poor to pay less.
Yaung explained that statistics show nearly 40 percent of the population have no income records. In fact some of these people have been found to have "hidden incomes, " he said.
In addition, under the DOH's preliminary calculation, some housewives without a job will have even lower premiums than under the existing system, he added.

Yaung said households can roughly calculate their new monthly NHI premiums by multiplying their gross composite household income in 2009 by a roughly assessed rate of 2.5 percent to 2.7 percent, and then dividing the result by 12.
The DOH is considering setting up a telephone hotline to answer questions on the second-generation NHI system, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'I have no enemies:' Nobel Peace Prize winner
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 20:32:19 (By Kuo Mei-lan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Jailed Chinese dissident Liu Xiaopo, winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, will make what he calls his "last statement" titled: "I have no enemies" at the Dec. 10 award ceremony, although he will be unable to attend in person, an overseas friend of Liu said over the weekend.

Xu Wenli, an exiled Chinese dissident, told CNA that an American actor will read the statement for the prisoner of conscience, as neither he nor his wife Liu Xia will be allowed to accept the prize in the Norwegian capital of Oslo.
In the statement, Liu Xiaopo says he has fulfilled a Chinese citizen's social responsibility by carrying out his constitutionally protected right of freedom of speech.

Liu is serving an 11-year sentence after being convicted of sedition. His "crime" is advocating freedom of speech and drafting a new Chinese constitution that has been endorsed by many other Chinese intellectuals -- the so-called "Charter 08."
"What I have done is innocent. I have no complaints, even though I have been accused [by the state]," Xu quoted Liu's statement as saying.

Freedom of expression is the foundation of human rights; it is the basis of human nature and the mother of truth. Suppressing freedom of speech is tantamount to trampling on human rights, stifling human nature and oppressing the truth, Liu says in the statement.

He says hatred erodes a person's wisdom and conscience, and hostility poisons the spirit. "Once a cruel, life-or-death struggle has been fanned, a society's spirit of tolerance and human nature will be destroyed and a nation's progress toward freedom and democracy will be hindered," he adds.

Xu said the award ceremony will be held at 1 p.m. local time and that as no one will be accepting the prize in person, "it is believed that a two-to-three- minute silence will be observed before a foreign dignitary makes a speech."
Xu, who himself was nominated for the prize in 1999, has been invited to witness the award ceremony honoring Liu.

Yang Jianli, another Chinese dissident currently living in the United States, said he has been trying to help arrange for Liu Xia to attend on behalf of her husband, but that the Chinese authorities will not allow her to go.
"I'm sure no-one will accept the prize and that it -- along with the cash award -- will likely be kept by the Nobel Prize Committee, " Yang said.

Yang said he does not see any possibility of the Chinese government softening its stance on this issue in the near future. But within one year, he predicted, China will take a more conciliatory approach by putting Liu under house arrest and incommunicado in the Beijing area rather than keeping him in jail.

Wang Dan, another well-known Chinese dissident and a student leader during the 1989 Tiananmen protests, told CNA that if precedent is any indicator, Liu will likely be sent abroad into exile "on medical grounds."

DOC.HEADLINE: First suspected human mad-cow disease death reported in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 20:41:29 (By Chen Ching-fang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man, who spent eight years in the United Kingdom before returning home, died earlier this year from what appeared to be mad-cow disease, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Wednesday.

The man, who was in the UK from 1978-1986, died in May 2010 at the age of 36. In 2008, he began to show symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD) such as memory loss and hypersomnia, and was reported as a suspected CJD case in March 2009, the CDC said.
However, the man's family refused to provide tissue for testing or to give permission for an autopsy, therefore, it is difficult to confirm the cause of his death, said CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting.
"We cannot exclude this as a CJD case either," Lin said.
Based on the patient's symptoms and his MRI and EEG records, a medical team has determined this was an "extremely likely case" of CJD, the CDC said in a press release.

Furthermore, judging from the fact that the patient was studying in the UK during the peak period of mad-cow disease there, his death could be counted as an imported case of CJD that, however, will not pose any threat to Taiwan's disease control network, the CDC said.

Medically known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE, mad-cow disease causes spongy holes in the brain. In people, a rare but fatal form of the disease called variant Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (vCJD) has been linked to eating infected tissue from cows.
Taiwan does not import beef from the UK.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibit in Tainan to spotlight life and work of Balzac
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 20:59:36 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A rare exhibition featuring the work of the prolific French novelist Honore De Balzac will open at National Museum of Taiwan Literature in Tainan Dec. 15, the organizers said Wednesday in Taipei.

The exhibition comprises more than 300 items borrowed from public and private collections around the world in the largest ever Balzac display outside of France, according to one of the organizers, Maison Balzac Director Yves Gagneux.

It will be a very visual experience, for it not only displays many original manuscripts written by Balzac, but also brings under a single roof a number of paintings, sculptures, pictures, sketches and woodcuts created in tribute to the famous 19th century writer and reveals much about his life, Gagneux said.
Manuscripts by authors from the same period as Balzac, including George Sand, Eugene Sue, Victor Hugo and Alexandre Dumas, will also be on display.
Gagneux said Balzac, who wrote more than 120 novels before his death at the age of 51, was an accomplished craftsman in his field.
"To really understand Balzac, one has to understand the ideas of tradition and innovation, because Balzac's work is a combination of the two," the director said.
Balzac's ability to blend realistic details, acute observation and visionary imagination made him unrivaled in his time, he added.
One of the items on display is the manuscript of "Illusions perdues, " written by Balzac between 1837 and 1843, with a preface by Hugo.
Gagneux said Balzac and Hugo had a cat-and-dog friendship. Balzac was fond of Hugo's poems and theatrical works, but thought Hugo's novels were "not worth mentioning," he said.
The Balzac exhibition will be run at National Museum of Taiwan Literature until Feb. 15 next year and at National Taiwan Museum in Taipei from March 3 to April 5, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Production of indigenous missile systems going smoothly: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 21:23:03 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The mass production of two missile systems developed by Taiwan has been proceeding smoothly, Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang said Wednesday.

Chao was referring to the Hsiungfeng IIE (HF-2E) surface-to-surface cruise missile system and Hsingfeng III supersonic anti-ship missile, both of which were developed by the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology.

During a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee, Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang asked Chao about the production of several indigenous weapon systems which is scheduled to peak in 2011.
In response, Chao said the problems of acquiring key components for the indigenous missile systems have been resolved and production is now going smoothly as scheduled.

Moreover, mass production of several new indigenous weapon systems, such as the Leiting 2000 multiple rocket launcher, an unmanned aerial vehicle and the Yunpao (Cloud Leopard) armored vehicle, will soon begin, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. agencies should start hiring Taiwanese: ex-U.S. envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 21:27:37 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should negotiate with China to lift a ban on the employment of Republic of China (Taiwan) nationals at UN-affiliated agencies as relations between the two sides have improved recently, the former top U.S. diplomat in Taiwan said Wednesday.

The People's Republic of China signed memoranda of understanding (MOUs) that barred the agencies from hiring people from Taiwan after it joined the United Nations in 1971 by replacing the Republic of China, Taiwan's official name, said Douglas Paal, who was director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) office in Taipei until 2006.
The AIT is the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
"Why should that be the case now? " he said, referring to the 39-year-old ban in an interview with the Central News Agency during a visit to Taipei.
His remarks came at a time when Taiwan enjoys a much warmer relationship with China after Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008.
Taiwan signed a pact with China earlier this year to further liberalize two-way trade and has opened itself to more tourists from China.
Nevertheless, it remains difficult for Taiwan to take part in U.N.-related activities due to Beijing's obstruction.
Paal, who is now vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a Washington think-tank, suggested that Taiwan should try to have the ban removed.
"I am not asking for Taiwan to be officially represented, " he said. "But Taiwan has lots of good people."

Taiwanese people should be allowed to compete for jobs at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , the International Energy Agency (IEA), the World Health Organization (WHO) and others, he said.

"Put people forward and have the SEF negotiate with China, getting rid of these MOUs, " he said, referring to Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, a semi- official body charged with handling daily affairs with China.
"Make a clear understanding [to China]. This will not be our effort to represent ourselves. But we think we can play a role, " he added.
With time, he said, Taiwan will become an "indispensable" part of the world that way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breast cancer rehab center adopts multimedia technology
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 21:59:46 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The introduction last month of a state-of-the-art multimedia physical treatment center in Taipei called Smart Ambience has taken the drudgery out of the rehabilitation routine, according to some users.
"I was amazed when I first set foot in the center, " said Liu Yu- yuan, a 51 -year-old mastectomy patient.
The aesthetics include walls of aquariums with tropical fishes swimming around and colorful bottles that are meant to produce a healing and calming effect on the mind.
The center offers six different rehabilitation training programs that feature LEDs, sensors and newly developed software.
Patients can go through a one-hour exercise routine that is based on high-end computer technology and is tailored to individual needs, all free of charge.

In the diaphragmatic breathing program, for example, a sensor band attached to the patient tells the therapist whether or not the exercise is being done correctly, said Chien Chu-chun, a nurse at the Taiwan Breast Cancer Foundation (TBCF) that founded the center.
"To help the patients relax, we have an overhead projector that displays videos of a figure doing the breathing exercise in a forest to soft relaxing music," said Chien.
The forest scene turns into a night sky with stars that brighten or dim depending how deeply the patient breathes during the exercise, she said.
Diaphragmatic breathing can calm the mind, Chien explained, adding that this is a state most cancer patients find difficult to achieve.
At the center, patients can concentrate fully on the rehabilitation routines since the space is used by one person at a time, with an assigned therapist offering assistance, she said.

"When I can't fall asleep at home, I would picture the forest and practice the breathing method I learned here," said Liu. " Although I knew the breathing method before, my technique was wrong. The therapist corrected me and demonstrated it for me, which was nice and thoughtful."
The center, a brainchild of TBCF and National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia (GINM) , took two years to complete.
Hung Yi-ping, a GINM professor and leading researcher, said that the biggest challenge on the project was the synchronization and integration of all the multimedia resources.
"There was a lot of trial and error. Sometimes we had to toss out what we had done and build something better,"said Hung.
The project experience was presented at an international conference in Italy last year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: National debt clock not accurate: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:28:47 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party on Wednesday accused the Ministry of Finance (MOF) of hiding the country's real debt problems from the public, claiming that the newly launched national debt clock is "seriously delayed and inaccurate."
The MOF on Tuesday night officially launched the national debt clock, a web- based system that publishes national debt situation on the seventh day of each month.

According to the figures released on the webpage, as of the end of November, the nation's outstanding debt totaled NT$4.328 trillion (US$141 billion), and the short-term loans stood at NT$235 billion -- meaning an average debt burden of NT$197,000 for each citizen.

DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling said that the information carried on the net is false, because the hidden debt -- mainly debt incurred to cover deficits in pensions programs for civil servants and social security programs -- is not included in the government statistics.
She said if the hidden debt were added, the average debt every citizen has to shoulder would reach NT$900,000, four times more than the MOF debt clock indicates.

Lee Chun-yee, another DPP Legislator, criticized the MOF's debt clock as a "seriously delayed, inaccurate clock, " saying the national debt has increased dramatically since President Ma Ying-jeou was sworn into office on May 20, 2008.
The current debt to GDP ratio surged 4 percentage points to 34 percent, compared with 30 percent recorded in 2008 before the DPP transferred power to KMT, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businessman offers ideas for building on flora expo's success
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:33:12 ( By Johnson Sun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Flora Expo should be converted into a cultural creative center when the exhibition ends, in light of its great success, a local business leader said Wednesday.

Kenneth Lo, chairman of the Industrial Bank of Taiwan and president of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, made the suggestion while leading a group of more than 30 representatives from the association on tour of the expo's Pavilion of Dreams and Pavilion of Future.
A night market highlighting the fine restaurants from the exhibition venue could be a new attraction for tourists, Lo said.
The flora expo, which opened Nov. 6 and will run until April 25 next year, is a combination of horticulture and high technology and reflects the characteristics of Taiwan, Lo added.
"I am proud that this expo was designed by a cadre of outstanding local talent, " said Liu Chao Kai, Chairman of Tecom Co. Ltd., who was part of the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer, Samsung to launch netbooks with Google Chrome OS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:46:09 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. said Wednesday that it is set to launch netbooks running Google's newly unveiled operating system, Google Chrome, in 2011.

Acer's netbooks with the Chrome OS will be available in March or April next year, company Chairman J.T. Wang told reporters on the sidelines of a conference at which he was re-elected as chairman of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA).
"There is still a demand for netbooks in developing countries despite the impact of tablet computers," Wang said.

He forecast that global shipments of netbooks will slide to 30-40 million units in 2011, dropping from this year's 20 percent to 25 percent share of the personal computer market to around 15 percent to 20 percent.
Meanwhile, Samsung Electronic Co. will also be using the Chrome OS, but it will fall into a special category of a competitor with Acer, Wang said.

"Samsung will be a special case in the field because it is a brand vendor and also a key component supplier to other brands, which makes it hard for the company to manage customer relations, " Wang said.
He said Acer will keep an eye on the business strategy of the South Korean-based company now that it has a new general manager.
The Chrome OS is designed to expand the use of the Chrome browser and web-based services, according to Google.

Earlier Wednesday, Google unveiled a Chrome-based prototype notebook "CR-48" used in a testing program for limited applicants, in a move to attract about 120 million active users of the Chrome browser.

The all-black notebook, with a 12.1-inch screen and 3G connectivity, does not have a brand logo on it as part of Google's effort to strengthen its ties with manufacturers, said Sean Lien, head of Google's business development division, at a press briefing to introduce the product.
"We will not launch Google-branded computers with the Chrome OS as manufacturers can decide to install the system on any kind of device, including notebooks, netbooks and tablets," he added.
Lien noted that the company is in contact with all Taiwanese original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) and original design manufacturers (ODMs), but he declined to name any apart from Samsung and Acer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy is Taiwan's best form of 'soft power': U.S. scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:54:56 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's democracy and emphasis on human rights are its most effective forms of 'soft power, ' and its adherence to these values will influence China positively in the long run, Harvard professor Joseph Nye said in Taipei on Wednesday.

Praising Taiwan's democratic development and its efforts to achieve warmer cross-strait ties in the past two years, the former Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs said Taiwan is a model worthy of emulation in Asia, particularly by China.
"My feeling is that China is going to change and Taiwan can be part of that change, " he said in a speech, describing Taiwan as a "success story."

President Ma Ying-jeou's recent public call for Beijing to release Chinese dissident and Nobel Prize winner Liu Xiaobo is indicative of Ma's sound leadership and his dedication to preserving Taiwan's democracy, Nye said.

Comparing the current administration to the previous one under former President Chen Shui-bian, Nye said that Taiwan-U.S. relations are in much better shape now than before when some of the actions by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, such as a constitutional amendment, agitated Washington.

He said that while U.S. arms sales would give Taiwan more bargaining chips in its engagements with China, Taiwan's best defense is not a strong warfare capability but rather its commitment to democratic values that are shared by the American people.
"Taiwan needs to keep itself attractive to the U.S. by appealing to American values, and a military solution would be a mistake, " he added.

Earlier in the day, Nye met with Ma at the Presidential Office where he lauded the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , a landmark trade pact signed between Taiwan and China in June, as a crucial tool to ensuring Taiwan's benefits.
The agreement, coupled with Taiwan's steps to hone its military strength, is an example of Taiwan exercising "smart power" to advance its interests, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete headed for Korea over disqualification row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:07:52 (By P. H. Shiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun will go to Seoul, South Korea next week to give an explanation to the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) over her disputed disqualification at a recent Asian Games event in Guangzhou, China, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Wednesday.

The SAC said in a press release that the WTF has already informed the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) of its decision to hold a disciplinary committee meeting in Seoul on Dec. 18 over Yang's disqualification.

The decision was made after Vice Premier Sean Chen called a task force meeting the previous night with Yang, SAC Minister Tai Shia-ling, Sung Yao-ming, a lawyer in charge of handling the case, and Liu Ching-wen, the chief referee of the CTTA, according to the SAC.

Yang, 25, was disqualified over allegations that she wore two extra electronic sensors in her socks during her first-round bout in the Asiad women's taekwondo under 49-kilogram division on Nov. 17, after having scored a 9-0 lead over her Vietnamese opponent.

The incident created a shock wave around Taiwan as all video footage of the match and witness accounts in a news conference sponsored by the Executive Yuan showed that Yang had taken off the sensors before going into the ring.

An online accusation against Yang by the Asian Taekwondo Union the following day prompted Taiwan's sports and taekwondo authorities to file a complaint with the Olympic Council of Asia. The sports council also threatened to appeal the case to the Lausanne-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) to pursue justice for the athlete if it is not fairly handled by the WTF.

In response to public concerns that the Seoul meeting might result in disciplinary measures against Yang, Tai said "we will collect all evidence, favorable or unfavorable, and assess all possible scenarios in advance in a bid to serve our best interests."

At a news conference later Wednesday, SAC Vice Minister Steven S.K. Chen said the council is prepared to bring the case to the CAS or take action via legal channels if WTF comes up with a verdict that jeopardizes Yang's rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecommunications break down in Kinmen for hours
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:13:49 ( By Ni Kuo-yen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The telecommunication network was disrupted in Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen for four hours Wednesday due to machine failure, the Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd said Wednesday.

An optical amplifier in one of the company's exchanges in the county started to malfunction at 2: 28 p.m., causing a suspension of all mobile services, internet and long distance telephone services around the island.
The amplifier is a signal-strengthening device used in optical telecommunication networks.

A telephone and online flight booking service for the lunar new year holidays, originally due to begin at 6 p.m., was delayed although telecommunications were resumed at 6: 45 p.m after engineers flew in from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung to the offshore island for repair work.
The booking service would begin on a later date, said Lin Cheng-cha, director of Kinmen's Transportation and Tourism Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to sue four KMT lawmakers on charges of breaking election law

TEXT.P: In the aftermath of an election-eve shooting, Taiwan's major opposition party said Wednesday it will take four ruling party lawmakers to court for slander and intent to make opposition candidates lose votes.

Tsai Chi-chang, a spokesman for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that soon after the Nov. 26 shooting at a Kuomintang (KMT) campaign rally, Chiu Yi, Lu Hsiu-yen and two other KMT legislators purposely tried to mislead the public into thinking that the shooting of KMT Central Committee member Sean Lien was somehow linked to the DPP.
For example, KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng openly called on the electorate to "use your ballots to reject violence," insinuating that the DPP was linked to the shooting, Tsai said.

Wu's statements violated the criminal code on public insult and defamation, as well as the election law which lays out penalties for those "intending to make certain candidates fail in the elections, " said the spokesman.
Tsai said his party has decided to file lawsuits against Chiu, Lu, Wu and Kuo Su-chun on charges of breaching the criminal code and the election law.
A DPP lawyer, Chang Tien-chin, said the party will file the lawsuits and then decide whether to seek compensation or a public apology.
In response, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said his party had called for calm immediately after the shooting incident and restrained its politicians from making too many speculations.
On the other hand, Su said, "DPP has changed its statements so often that no one knows what its position is regarding the shooting incident."
"We did much more than the DPP" to minimize the effects of the incident on the elections, he said.
The KMT's Wu denied the DPP charges, saying he simply called on the public to remain calm and rational and to use their votes to reject violence.
"I did not insinuate or suggest that the shooting may have been a political assassination attempt, " he said. "The DPP should not make that claim."
Kuo Su-chun said that the opposition party is not broad-minded enough to accept its defeat in the election and she would gladly "play the DPP's legal game to the end."
Meanwhile, Sean Lien, who was shot in the face at the election-eve rally, said he cannot accept the suspect's statement of "having misidentified the target."
Through his special assistant Hsu Hung-ting, Lien said he is more eager than anyone else to help clear up the truth about the shooting.
Hsu said that in the coming days, Lien will likely explain in person how he felt about being shot on the night before the election.
(By Yeh Su-ping, Lee Shu-hua, Chou Yung-chieh, Huang Ming-hsi and S.C. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan panel maker to appeal EU price-fixing fine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:44:27 (By Tsao Yu-fan, Lin Shu-yuanm Pan CHih-yi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. of Taiwan said Wednesday night that it will appeal a European Commission decision to slap heavy fines on it and three other Taiwanese flat panel makers and a South Korean manufacturer for allegedly fixing prices on the EU market.

AUO, Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. were fined a total of 433.92 million euro (some NT$17.3 billion) for violating EU's competition rules and trying to hide their "law-breaking behavior."
An AUO spokesman said it has cooperated with EU authorities over the past four years in their investigation into industry practices regarding the production and marketing of TFT-LCD products.
The company, which was fined 116.8 million euro, has decided to file an appeal with the General Court in Luxemburg and vigorously defend its business practices, the spokesman said.

Chi Mei and Chunghwa said they are taking a closer look at the EU decision before taking their next steps. A Chi Mei executive said the fine on his company, 300 million euro, is "really too harsh." Chunghua was fined 9.02 million euro.
HannStar Display Corp., which got a fine of 8.1 million euro, would not comment on the EC action.
Market analysts said the Taiwanese manufacturers are not making big profits and the fines are "simply too heavy."
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the government would provide all necessary assistance to the manufacturers.

Duh Tyzz-jiun, director general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, told the Central News Agency that as long as the accused companies need assistance when facing disciplinary action, the government would try its best to help them.
Duh and other economics officials admitted the heavy fines will have impacts on Taiwan's flat panel industry.
LG Display of South Korea was also on the hitting list, being given a 215 million euro fine.
Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the world's largest flat panel maker, was not charged since it alerted the European Commission to the price-fixing practices.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:28:47 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Hermia Lin)

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:33:12 ( By Johnson Sun and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Flora Expo should be converted into a cultural creative center when the exhibition ends, in light of its great success, a local business leader said Wednesday.

Kenneth Lo, chairman of the Industrial Bank of Taiwan and president of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, made the suggestion while leading a group of more than 30 representatives from the association on tour of the expo's Pavilion of Dreams and Pavilion of Future.
A night market highlighting the fine restaurants from the exhibition venue could be a new attraction for tourists, Lo said.
The flora expo, which opened Nov. 6 and will run until April 25 next year, is a combination of horticulture and high technology and reflects the characteristics of Taiwan, Lo added.
"I am proud that this expo was designed by a cadre of outstanding local talent, " said Liu Chao Kai, Chairman of Tecom Co. Ltd., who was part of the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer, Samsung to launch netbooks with Google Chrome OS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:46:09 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. said Wednesday that it is set to launch netbooks running Google's newly unveiled operating system, Google Chrome, in 2011.

Acer's netbooks with the Chrome OS will be available in March or April next year, company Chairman J.T. Wang told reporters on the sidelines of a conference at which he was re-elected as chairman of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA).
"There is still a demand for netbooks in developing countries despite the impact of tablet computers," Wang said.

He forecast that global shipments of netbooks will slide to 30-40 million units in 2011, dropping from this year's 20 percent to 25 percent share of the personal computer market to around 15 percent to 20 percent.
Meanwhile, Samsung Electronic Co. will also be using the Chrome OS, but it will fall into a special category of a competitor with Acer, Wang said.

"Samsung will be a special case in the field because it is a brand vendor and also a key component supplier to other brands, which makes it hard for the company to manage customer relations, " Wang said.
He said Acer will keep an eye on the business strategy of the South Korean-based company now that it has a new general manager.
The Chrome OS is designed to expand the use of the Chrome browser and web-based services, according to Google.

Earlier Wednesday, Google unveiled a Chrome-based prototype notebook "CR-48" used in a testing program for limited applicants, in a move to attract about 120 million active users of the Chrome browser.

The all-black notebook, with a 12.1-inch screen and 3G connectivity, does not have a brand logo on it as part of Google's effort to strengthen its ties with manufacturers, said Sean Lien, head of Google's business development division, at a press briefing to introduce the product.
"We will not launch Google-branded computers with the Chrome OS as manufacturers can decide to install the system on any kind of device, including notebooks, netbooks and tablets," he added.
Lien noted that the company is in contact with all Taiwanese original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) and original design manufacturers (ODMs), but he declined to name any apart from Samsung and Acer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democracy is Taiwan's best form of 'soft power': U.S. scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 22:54:56 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's democracy and emphasis on human rights are its most effective forms of 'soft power, ' and its adherence to these values will influence China positively in the long run, Harvard professor Joseph Nye said in Taipei on Wednesday.

Praising Taiwan's democratic development and its efforts to achieve warmer cross-strait ties in the past two years, the former Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs said Taiwan is a model worthy of emulation in Asia, particularly by China.
"My feeling is that China is going to change and Taiwan can be part of that change, " he said in a speech, describing Taiwan as a "success story."

President Ma Ying-jeou's recent public call for Beijing to release Chinese dissident and Nobel Prize winner Liu Xiaobo is indicative of Ma's sound leadership and his dedication to preserving Taiwan's democracy, Nye said.

Comparing the current administration to the previous one under former President Chen Shui-bian, Nye said that Taiwan-U.S. relations are in much better shape now than before when some of the actions by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, such as a constitutional amendment, agitated Washington.

He said that while U.S. arms sales would give Taiwan more bargaining chips in its engagements with China, Taiwan's best defense is not a strong warfare capability but rather its commitment to democratic values that are shared by the American people.
"Taiwan needs to keep itself attractive to the U.S. by appealing to American values, and a military solution would be a mistake, " he added.

Earlier in the day, Nye met with Ma at the Presidential Office where he lauded the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , a landmark trade pact signed between Taiwan and China in June, as a crucial tool to ensuring Taiwan's benefits.
The agreement, coupled with Taiwan's steps to hone its military strength, is an example of Taiwan exercising "smart power" to advance its interests, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete headed for Korea over disqualification row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:07:52 (By P. H. Shiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun will go to Seoul, South Korea next week to give an explanation to the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) over her disputed disqualification at a recent Asian Games event in Guangzhou, China, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Wednesday.

The SAC said in a press release that the WTF has already informed the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) of its decision to hold a disciplinary committee meeting in Seoul on Dec. 18 over Yang's disqualification.

The decision was made after Vice Premier Sean Chen called a task force meeting the previous night with Yang, SAC Minister Tai Shia-ling, Sung Yao-ming, a lawyer in charge of handling the case, and Liu Ching-wen, the chief referee of the CTTA, according to the SAC.

Yang, 25, was disqualified over allegations that she wore two extra electronic sensors in her socks during her first-round bout in the Asiad women's taekwondo under 49-kilogram division on Nov. 17, after having scored a 9-0 lead over her Vietnamese opponent.

The incident created a shock wave around Taiwan as all video footage of the match and witness accounts in a news conference sponsored by the Executive Yuan showed that Yang had taken off the sensors before going into the ring.

An online accusation against Yang by the Asian Taekwondo Union the following day prompted Taiwan's sports and taekwondo authorities to file a complaint with the Olympic Council of Asia. The sports council also threatened to appeal the case to the Lausanne-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) to pursue justice for the athlete if it is not fairly handled by the WTF.

In response to public concerns that the Seoul meeting might result in disciplinary measures against Yang, Tai said "we will collect all evidence, favorable or unfavorable, and assess all possible scenarios in advance in a bid to serve our best interests."

At a news conference later Wednesday, SAC Vice Minister Steven S.K. Chen said the council is prepared to bring the case to the CAS or take action via legal channels if WTF comes up with a verdict that jeopardizes Yang's rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecommunications break down in Kinmen for hours
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:13:49 ( By Ni Kuo-yen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The telecommunication network was disrupted in Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen for four hours Wednesday due to machine failure, the Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd said Wednesday.

An optical amplifier in one of the company's exchanges in the county started to malfunction at 2: 28 p.m., causing a suspension of all mobile services, internet and long distance telephone services around the island.
The amplifier is a signal-strengthening device used in optical telecommunication networks.

A telephone and online flight booking service for the lunar new year holidays, originally due to begin at 6 p.m., was delayed although telecommunications were resumed at 6: 45 p.m after engineers flew in from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung to the offshore island for repair work.
The booking service would begin on a later date, said Lin Cheng-cha, director of Kinmen's Transportation and Tourism Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to sue four KMT lawmakers on charges of breaking election law

TEXT.P: In the aftermath of an election-eve shooting, Taiwan's major opposition party said Wednesday it will take four ruling party lawmakers to court for slander and intent to make opposition candidates lose votes.

Tsai Chi-chang, a spokesman for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that soon after the Nov. 26 shooting at a Kuomintang (KMT) campaign rally, Chiu Yi, Lu Hsiu-yen and two other KMT legislators purposely tried to mislead the public into thinking that the shooting of KMT Central Committee member Sean Lien was somehow linked to the DPP.
For example, KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng openly called on the electorate to "use your ballots to reject violence," insinuating that the DPP was linked to the shooting, Tsai said.

Wu's statements violated the criminal code on public insult and defamation, as well as the election law which lays out penalties for those "intending to make certain candidates fail in the elections, " said the spokesman.
Tsai said his party has decided to file lawsuits against Chiu, Lu, Wu and Kuo Su-chun on charges of breaching the criminal code and the election law.
A DPP lawyer, Chang Tien-chin, said the party will file the lawsuits and then decide whether to seek compensation or a public apology.
In response, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said his party had called for calm immediately after the shooting incident and restrained its politicians from making too many speculations.
On the other hand, Su said, "DPP has changed its statements so often that no one knows what its position is regarding the shooting incident."
"We did much more than the DPP" to minimize the effects of the incident on the elections, he said.
The KMT's Wu denied the DPP charges, saying he simply called on the public to remain calm and rational and to use their votes to reject violence.
"I did not insinuate or suggest that the shooting may have been a political assassination attempt, " he said. "The DPP should not make that claim."
Kuo Su-chun said that the opposition party is not broad-minded enough to accept its defeat in the election and she would gladly "play the DPP's legal game to the end."
Meanwhile, Sean Lien, who was shot in the face at the election-eve rally, said he cannot accept the suspect's statement of "having misidentified the target."
Through his special assistant Hsu Hung-ting, Lien said he is more eager than anyone else to help clear up the truth about the shooting.
Hsu said that in the coming days, Lien will likely explain in person how he felt about being shot on the night before the election.
(By Yeh Su-ping, Lee Shu-hua, Chou Yung-chieh, Huang Ming-hsi and S.C. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan panel maker to appeal EU price-fixing fine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/10 23:44:27 (By Tsao Yu-fan, Lin Shu-yuanm Pan CHih-yi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. of Taiwan said Wednesday night that it will appeal a European Commission decision to slap heavy fines on it and three other Taiwanese flat panel makers and a South Korean manufacturer for allegedly fixing prices on the EU market.

AUO, Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. were fined a total of 433.92 million euro (some NT$17.3 billion) for violating EU's competition rules and trying to hide their "law-breaking behavior."
An AUO spokesman said it has cooperated with EU authorities over the past four years in their investigation into industry practices regarding the production and marketing of TFT-LCD products.
The company, which was fined 116.8 million euro, has decided to file an appeal with the General Court in Luxemburg and vigorously defend its business practices, the spokesman said.

Chi Mei and Chunghwa said they are taking a closer look at the EU decision before taking their next steps. A Chi Mei executive said the fine on his company, 300 million euro, is "really too harsh." Chunghua was fined 9.02 million euro.
HannStar Display Corp., which got a fine of 8.1 million euro, would not comment on the EC action.
Market analysts said the Taiwanese manufacturers are not making big profits and the fines are "simply too heavy."
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the government would provide all necessary assistance to the manufacturers.

Duh Tyzz-jiun, director general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, told the Central News Agency that as long as the accused companies need assistance when facing disciplinary action, the government would try its best to help them.
Duh and other economics officials admitted the heavy fines will have impacts on Taiwan's flat panel industry.
LG Display of South Korea was also on the hitting list, being given a 215 million euro fine.
Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the world's largest flat panel maker, was not charged since it alerted the European Commission to the price-fixing practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 9, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti- communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."
