DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Pay hikes for civil servants

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth for 2010 is forecast to rise to 9.98 percent, the highest since 1987. However, the vast majority of people, whose main source of income is salaries, have not benefited from this economic growth because salaries have only risen by an average 0.78 percent per year over the past decade.

That's why the issue of hiking pay for civil servants has come up once again. Supporters of the proposal believe that hiking salaries would allow government employees to enjoy the fruits of economic growth and encourage the private sector to raise the pay of its workers as well.
It is also believed that adjusting the pay of civil servants would prevent the country's wealth disparity from widening further and stimulate private consumption.

A 3 percent rise in the salaries of civil servants is likely to increase the government's expenditure by NT$21 billion a year. However, this would not exert much financial pressure on the government because revenues are expected to rise as the economy recovers.

The government should stop making excuses for not going ahead with the plan and should think about the intangible benefits that could be created by hiking employee salaries. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 9, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't bury the truth behind Lien's shooting

TEXT.P: Even after two weeks, little progress has been made in the investigation into the election-eve shooting of Kuomintang politician Sean Lien, despite the fact that the gunman had been arrested quickly. Indeed, during this time, speculation and conspiracy theories have only continued to grow.
It is strange that the police have allowed such an uncomplicated case to fall prey to such vicious speculation.
In fact, all the speculation can be brought to a halt with some simple reasoning, yet both the green and blue camps have kept encouraging unfounded theories in a vicious manner.

If this situation continues, even a simple incident of public disorder could quickly turn into a political issue. The way things are going, even if the case is eventually resolved, we believe that there will be many skeptics. Unfortunately, this will not bring true justice for the victims and neither will it help in regaining public confidence in Taiwan's democracy and social order. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 9, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of Chimei Innolux sharply lower on EU fine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 12:14:29 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of flat panel maker Chimei Innolux Corp. were sharply lower in Thursday morning trade after the European Commission slapped a heavy fine on the company for alleged price fixing, dealers said.

Underperforming the broader market, Chimei Innolux fell 4.70 percent to NT$38.55 (US$1.28) with 47.45 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index was up 0.57 percent at 8,753.80.

The European Commission Wednesday imposed a total of 433.92 million euros in fines on four Taiwanese flat panel makers for violating the EU's competition rules. The companies include Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., which merged with Innolux Display Corp. to form Chimei Innolux in March.

Chimei Innolux got the heaviest fine of 300 million euros among the four companies, while AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) was fined 116.8 million euros, Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. was fined 9.02 million euros, and the fine for HannStar Display Corp. was 8.1 million euros.
A Chimei Innolux executive said the punishment was "really too harsh."
"Yes, the fine is heavy. That's why investors rushed to dump their Chimei Innolux shares this morning, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Jeff Chang said.
Chimei Innolux said it will take a close look at the EU decision before deciding how to react to the punishment.
"If Chimei Innolux decides to assign a provision in the fourth quarter to cover the loss from the fine, I expect the impact on its bottom line cannot be ignored," Chang said.
Chang said the fine could cut the company's earnings per share by NT$1.64 for 2010.
The analyst had previously expected the company would post an EPS at NT$0.4 and the fine could make Chimei Innolux post a loss per share at NT$1.24.

For AU Optronics, Chang said the fine is expected to cut the company's EPS to NT$0.98 for 2010 from the previously estimated NT$1.50 if it also assigns a provision to cover the fine in the fourth quarter.
However, AUO has said it will file an appeal with the General Court in Luxemburg and vigorously defend its business practices.
AUO shares fell 1.79 percent to NT$30.25 in Thursday morning trade.
For Chunghwa Picture Tubes and HannStar Display, the impact on their bottom lines could be limited due to the relatively small amounts of fines, Chang said.
The European Commission also slapped a fine of 215 million euros on LG Display of South Korea for the same accusation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preparatory talks for 6th Taiwan-China meeting slated for Dec. 14
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 13:30:06 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Preparatory talks for the sixth high-level cross-Taiwan Strait meeting will be held in Shanghai Dec. 14, a senior Taiwanese negotiator with China said Thursday.

"The Shanghai talks will set the date, venue and agenda for the new round of institutionalized high-level cross-strait talks to be held in Taipei in the second half of this month, " said Kao Koong-lian, deputy chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

As in the past, Kao will head the Taiwanese delegation to the Shanghai preparatory talks with its Chinese counterpart to be led by Zheng Lichong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Speaking at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Interior Affairs Committee, Kao said that the main agenda for the sixth round of cross-strait meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin will be signing a bilateral medical cooperation agreement.
Through five rounds of intensive negotiations between working-level officials, Kao said, the two sides have reached consensus on key provisions of the medical cooperation pact.

As to a proposed cross-strait investment protection agreement, it will be excluded from the agenda for the sixth round of "Chiang-Chen meeting" because the two sides have yet to come to terms on certain clauses, Kao said.

"The investment protection accord covers many complicated issues on which we need more time to hammer out an investment dispute solution mechanism, "he explained, adding that both sides have agreed not to seal the pact at the upcoming round of Chiang-Chen meeting.
The exact date for the sixth Chiang-Chen meeting will be announced at the end of the Shanghai preparatory talks next Tuesday, Kao added.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said at the same occasion that it was a common decision not to sign the investment protection agreement at the sixth Chiang-Chen meeting.
She denied speculations that talks in this aspect were hindered by a sovereignty dispute, saying arbitration of investment disputes does not involve sovereignty issues.

According to Lai, the snag mainly lies in protection of the safety of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and their dependents, compensation for property expropriation and technical details regarding the dispute settlement mechanism.

"Some of these issues involve different legal provisions of our two sides which need more time to address, " Lai noted, adding that the MAC hopes globally applicable standards will be adopted to better protect the rights and interests of Taiwanese investors in China.
"In cross-strait talks, any deal or agreement to be sealed with China must meet our interests and expectations, " Lai assured lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration agency cracks fake ID ring
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 14:01:05 (By Lin Shen-hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Thursday it has cracked a counterfeit ring that was producing almost flawless identification cards for illegal foreign workers in Taiwan.

The ring is probably the country's largest fake identification syndicate targeting runaway foreign workers as its clientele, the NIA said. It was cracked after more than five months of investigation, and should help cut down on the incidence of runaways in Taiwan, NIA officials said.
In a joint operation launched by the NIA and police early Thursday, 15 suspects were arrested at various locations in Taipei City, Taipei County, Hsinchu County and Miaoli County.
Computers, printers and thousands of completed and partly completed fake Alien Resident Certificates, work permits and national health insurance cards were seized.

The lead suspect, identified by his surnamed Hsiao, told police that the fake documents were intended for sale to labor brokers, insurance agents, foreign workers, and contractors of major construction projects where foreign labor might be needed.
Hsiao was also found to have set up a dormitory to hide and control runaway foreign workers, the NIA said.
Official statistics show that there are around 34,000 runaway foreign workers in Taiwan.
The issue has drawn much attention in the wake of the deaths of six illegal foreign workers in an accident at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway on Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official Facebook page for president to be launched in 2011: aide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 14:24:45 (By Garfie Li and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office spokesman opened an official Facebook page Wednesday to expand the scope of communication with the public as a similar page for President Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to be launched next year.
Presidential Office Spokesman Luo Chi-chiang said Thursday he will gather online comments and opinions via his own page about the plan to launch an official page for President Ma in early 2011.
Luo said the purpose of his official Facebook page is to interact with netizens directly as a presidential spokesperson and convey the president's ideas more accurately.
Unlike the traditional media, there are no limits to the scope of Internet coverage, and the online space allows for the government to more freely send comprehensive messages to the public, he said.
One of Luo's first posts on his Facebook page was a video clip of Ma being interviewed by teenagers from the China Youth Corp, a local organization.
Luo said on his page that he will post non-classified information about the president's activities, video talks and policy presentations later on.
On his private Facebook page, which appears under a pseudonym, Lo has more than 4,000 friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Despite China's rise, it must not underestimate U.S.: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 16:22:54 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: China's booming economy and military strength has dramatically expanded its clout in Asia but its rise will not threaten U.S. influence in the region, particularly in the short term, Douglas Paal, an expert on U.S.-Asia relations, said in Taipei Thursday.

Speaking at the 39th Taiwan-American Conference on Contemporary China, Paal said Beijing should not underestimate the resilience of the U.S. or assume that the world will sit idly by as China continues to profit from a heavily subsidized market share.

Quoting U.S. Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, Paal said China's fast growing prowess on all fronts has already "ended the sanctuary status of the Western Pacific, which the U.S. enjoyed for the previous six decades."

Beijing's bullish growth brings to the fore the question of whether the U.S.' partners in the region can trust Washington's ability to deliver the right forces, at the right time, to deter or defeat aggression, Paal said.

"For the near term, the answer is clearly yes. Just look at the scale and intensity of the recent exercises conducted with South Korea and Japan," he said, adding that these events have reinforced alliances that had been wobbling in the last few years.

The joint foreign ministers meeting that took place on Monday and was attended by U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Japan's Seiji Maehara, and Kim Sung- hwan of South Korea is another example of firmly anchored ties, Paal said.

Furthermore, the Obama administration is now engaged in quiet "strategic rebalancing" as it gradually extracts itself from the Middle East, and is relocating resources to the Pacific because it recognizes the growing strength of the region, Paal said.
Paal however, was cautiously optimistic about Washington's grip on the region in the long term.
"My honest answer to the question of U.S. sustainability has to be, I don't know, but don't be too quick to count the U.S. out, " he said.
After two exhaustive wars, it would be "unsurprising if Americans were to turn to a more non-interventionist foreign policy," he said.

Paal recounted the history of the U.S.' success in bouncing back from different political and financial setbacks in the past, stressing that despite the current global economic woes, there are grounds to be optimistic that Washington will do the same again.

"The U.S. still has the competitive advantage in innovation, demographics, technology savvy, quality universities, a diverse and enterprising population and a Constitution that abhors and punishes failure," he said. "Massive correctives have already been applied to industries that engaged in the excess in the past decades."
On the other hand, while China is becoming a top investor, practices such as distorting pricing in the global marketplace are not welcome, Paal said.
"In my view, China has a worrisomely premature sense that its moment of destiny has arrived. It underestimates the U.S. and fails to see that underestimation may also be premature," he said.
China may think now is the moment to secure its interests, but it lacks the strength to succeed through direct confrontation, he said.
And "if it waits for a few years to build its strength, it may discover that the U.S. is back, and a tougher potential adversary, " Paal said.
If Beijing thinks the world will sit by and permit market share to be taken by a heavily subsidized China, without resistance, "it is likely to be surprised, sooner rather than later," he said.
Paal served as the director of the American Institute in Taiwan, Taipei Office, from 2002 to 2006. He now is the vice-president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to toughen penalties for illegal labor brokering
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 16:30:30 (By Lee Shien-feng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will toughen the penalties for illegal labor brokering, as part of its effort to resolve the problem of runaway foreign workers, an official said Thursday.
At present, the maximum fine for the brokering of illegal workers is NT$500,000, and repeat offenders within a five year period could be sentenced to one year in jail and a fine of up to NT$600,000.

The CLA is planning to raise the maximum fine for the first offense to NT$1.5 million, and for repeat offenses to a maximum prison term of five years and a fine of up to NT$2.4 million, said Tsai Meng-liang, chief of the foreign workers management division at the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training.

As to measures targeting the more than 1,000 registered labor brokers in the country, brokers will have their license revoked if it is found that there is an excessively high runaway rate among the workers they bring in, Tsai said.
He added that the government believes brokers must take major responsibility for the problem of runaways because brokers are the suppliers of foreign labor.
The official was responding to the National Immigration Agency's recent crackdown on a fake identification ring that targeted runaway foreign workers as its clientele.

CLA statistics show that there are around 34,000 runaway foreign workers in Taiwan. The issue has drawn much attention in the wake of the Sept. 6 deaths of six runaway foreign workers, who were illegally employed at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks international arbitration of taekwondo dispute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 16:48:09 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has filed an appeal with the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) in the case of the disqualification of taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun at the 2010 Asian Games, sports authorities said Thursday.

The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) , via a law firm, filed the appeal Wednesday with the CAS, which is based Lausanne, Switzerland, asking for an arbitration in the matter of Yang's controversial dismissal from the women's under 49-kilogram division at the Asiad in Guangzhou, China on Nov. 17, said SAC Minister Tai Shia-ling.

The appeal was filed by Lee and Li Attorneys-at-Law on behalf of the council, which fears it would be too late if Taiwan waited until after Dec. 18, the date when the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) is expected to convene a disciplinary committee meeting in Seoul to discuss Yang's case.
According to SAC officials, Taiwan could withdraw the arbitration appeal if the WTF issues an acceptable statement after its Dec. 18 meeting.
However, Taiwan will proceed with the case in the international court if the WTF comes up any statements that would jeopardize Yang's rights, SAC officials said.

Yang, who was one Taiwan's main contenders for a gold medal at the Asian Games, was disqualified during her opening bout of the tournament for allegedly wearing extra sensors in her socks in an attempt to score more points.

Video footage of the match, which was released later, showed that Yang was not wearing the sensors during the bout. Inconsistent explanations by WTF and Asian Taekwondo Union (ATU) officials of why Yang was disqualified have added to the controversy.

Taiwan filed a protest over the decision with the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) but also vowed to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if other appeals failed to provide a satisfactory outcome.

In response to public concerns that the Seoul meeting might result in disciplinary measures against Yang, Tai said "we will collect all evidence, favorable or unfavorable, and assess all possible scenarios in advance, in an effort to protect our best interests."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.57 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 17:26:11 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.57 percent Thursday as buying rotated to the high-tech sector after its recent consolidation, boosting the index to a 30-month high, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 50.05 points to 8,753.84, the highest level since May 27, 2008, after moving between 8,736.77 and 8,782.82, on turnover of NT$159.63 billion (US$5.29 billion).

The market opened up 0.79 percent and moved to the day's high as buying focused on integrated circuit (IC) stocks on optimism over their earnings outlook in 2011, but profit taking set in to compromise the gains, dealers said.
A total of 2,227 stocks closed up and 1,944 down, while 383 remained unchanged.
The machinery and electronic sector scored the highest gains, rising 0.9 percent. Financial stocks gained 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks added 0.1 percent.
However, the construction and foodstuff sectors fell 1.0 percent, the textile sector shed 0.7 percent and the paper and pulp sector lost 0.2 percent.
Earlier this month, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker, said sales of the global foundry business in 2011 is expected to rise 14 percent from 2010.
The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose almost 1 percent overnight in the U.S. market.
"Sentiment toward the IC sector improved, so interest rotated to the bellwether electronic sector to push the index higher, " Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.
TSMC rose 2.94 percent to NT$70.00 and rival United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) increased 3.73 percent to NT$16.70.
"Today's gains remained liquidity-driven as many investors tended to park their funds in safe havens," Miao said.
However, as the market moved closer to 8,800 points, investors tended to pocket their gains, which limited the upside, Miao said.

Miao said profit was concentrated in the old economy sector, which had been significantly boosted by a rising New Taiwan dollar, on hopes that the value of their domestic assets would rise accordingly.
Among the old economy stocks, food maker Uni-President Enterprises fell 1.15 percent to NT$43.10 and Cathay Real Estate dropped 1.13 percent to NT$17.35.

DOC.HEADLINE: Independent Chinese tourists predicted to benefit smaller hotels
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 18:04:05 (By Lin Ye-fong and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Small and medium-sized hotels in northern Taiwan, where Chinese tour groups usually base themselves, and their neighboring shops, are forecast to see a further business boom upon the anticipated opening to independent tourists from China, according to a local real estate broker.

Unrestricted by the constraints of traveling in tour groups, individual Chinese travelers can move around Taiwan more freely, which will help boost business for shops and malls near the hotels in which they stay, said Bright Lee, Evertrust Rehouse Co. company communications manager.

At present, Chinese nationals can only visit Taiwan as part of a tour group. Chinese business travelers from Shanghai and Beijing could be the first group to be allowed to visit the country on their own in the first quarter of 2011 at the earliest, the local media has reported. Details regarding the exact date of opening and the cap on the number of visitors are still under discussion.

The hotels in Taipei that focus on receiving Chinese tour groups are very likely to maintain their business once individual tourists come, because their names are already known to travel agencies and travelers from China, Lee noted.
On the other hand, hotels in Taoyuan, the site of Taiwan's main international airport, have been a top choice for Chinese tour groups since the country opened its doors to Chinese visitors in 2008.
In addition to Taoyuan's convenient location, the lower hotel prices are also a reason for its popularity, Lee said.

A total of 135,334 Chinese visitors stayed at hotels in a special art and culture district of Taoyuan in the first nine months of the year, the largest number of all the hotels in Taiwan, Lee went on, citing statistics released by the Tourism Bureau.
Hotels in Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli in northern Taiwan saw the biggest surge in the number of visitors from China, Lee added.

In a related development, meanwhile, direct flights between Taipei International Airport and Hefei Luogang International Airport in China's Anhui Province began operating Dec. 7, which is expected to further benefit commercial districts around the airport in downtown Taipei, Lee said.
The number of travelers to Taiwan in the first eleven months of this year reached 5 million, up 27 percent from a year earlier, according to statistics.
More than 1.34 million Chinese nationals visited Taiwan in the first 10 months of 2010, making China surpass Japan as the country's biggest source of visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Influential figures poll abandoned amid protest

TEXT.P: Academia Historica terminated an Internet poll Wednesday to select the 100 most influential figures in the history of the Republic of China after the campaign drew criticism from lawmakers and military officials.
In addition to celebrating the ROC's 100th founding anniversary in 2011, the activity was also aimed at enhancing local people's interest in history, said Academia Historica Director Lin Man-houng.
The program, however, came under fire due to its poor planning and the inclusion of some highly controversial figures on its candidate list.

For instance, the institute-selected candidates included Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping -- top leaders of the Communist Party of China, which defeated Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in a bloody civil war in China in the 1940s and forced the KMT-led ROC government to retreat to Taiwan.
Critics said the biggest flop lies in the institute's failure to uphold the principle of picking candidates who had contributed to the ROC's cause of bringing democracy and prosperity to its people.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the event:
United Daily News:

The controversy came to light Wednesday when KMT Legislator Justin Chou asked Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting about the propriety of listing Deng in the military category for the top 100 influential figures in ROC history.
In response, Chao said the listing was absolutely inappropriate.

Academia Hisotrica Deputy Director Chu Chung-sheng, previously said that Deng was chosen because, during the War of Resistance against Japan, he lead areas of resitance behind enemy lines in northern China, which qualified him for the title.

But shortly after Chao's criticism, Academia Historica removed Deng and Mao from the online list. Before their removal, Mao ranked No. 3 in the category of political leaders, ahead of his longtime enemy -- the late ROC President and KMT leader Chiang Kai-shek, while Deng ranked first as the most influential figure in the military category with 90 votes.

The website carrying the poll was shut down later that day. Presidential Office sources said President Ma Ying-jeou ordered the closure. Academia Historica is under the direct jurisdiction of the Presidential Office.
Ma was very concerned about the controversy and demanded the institution deal seriously with the matter, the sources said.
Academia Historica said in a press statement that the online poll was flawed and was therefore closed.
"We sincerely apologize for any controversy caused by the voting program," the statement said.

According to Chou, the list of candidates was decided by a panel of Academia Historica experts. Only ROC citizens who died before 2010 are qualified for listing. The panel chose 100 candidates in eight categories -- politics, military, finance and economy, diplomacy, social service, religion, academic, and arts and literature.
The candidates comprise 40 figures famous during the ROC's years in China and 60 prominent figures during its years in Taiwan. (Dec. 9, 2010).
Liberty Times:
Hsueh Hua-yuan, a professor at National Chengchi University's Graduate Institute of Taiwan History, noted that when the ROC was established in 1911, Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule.

As the KMT-dominated ROC government moved its seat to Taiwan from China in 1949 after being defeated by the Chinese communists, Hsueh said, it is understandable that Academia Historica included pre-1949 communist figures in the list.
Lee Hsiao-feng, a professor at the Graduate Institute of Taiwanese Culture at National Taipei University of Education, however, said the inclusion of communist figures was absurd.
"Academia Historica's move serves only to highlight its lack of Taiwan identity," he added. (Dec. 9, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises premier for reducing unemployment rate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9(CNA) 12/09/10 18:38:13 (By Li Ming-chung, Garfie Li and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou praised Premier Wu Den-yih for his achievement in reducing the unemployment rate to less than 5 percent in October at a presentation of the Manager Excellence Awards in Taipei Thursday

The unemployment rate has dropped over the last 14 months, from a peak of 6.13 percent in August 2009 to 4.92 percent in October this year, Ma said, adding that this shows that the economic rebound has gained greater strength.
Wu said in March that he would resign if he failed to bring down the unemployment rate to below 5 percent before the end of the year.
The public should be able to enjoy the fruits of the economic recovery next year, as "this year was a year of investment, which will be followed by a year of consumption," according to Ma.
Taiwan's Consumer Price Index is also the lowest and most stable among the four "Asian Tigers" even though the unemployment rate is the highest, Ma added.

Meanwhile, Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecasted that Taiwan's economic growth would reach 9.98 percent for the whole of 2010, the highest in nearly 21 years, while per capita GNP (gross national product) is expected to exceed US$20,000 next year for the first time in history.

Wu said Thursday that attracting foreign investors is a long- term effort that could create even more jobs and that Taiwan will focus on improving its soft power and hardware facilities to build a better investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance Ministry mulls higher tax rates on high-value housing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 18:47:29 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is considering imposing different tax rates on residential properties based on their value, in an effort to narrow the widening gap between the rich and the poor, FInance Minister Lee Sush-der said Thursday.
In addition, the MOF is planning to have home values assessed every year instead of every three years as is currently the case, Lee said in a report to the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee.

Under the existing House Tax Act, the tax rate -- which currently stands at 1.2 percent -- applies to all residential properties regardless of their value. The change will be intended to subject high-price housing to higher tax rates than average-value homes.
Lee said the ministry is also seeking to amend the Land Tax Act to forbid married couples and their adult children to register their dwellings at different addresses.

This is aimed at preventing people who own more than one home from using the method to take advantage of the preferential 0.2 percent land tax rate on property for self-residing purposes, Lee explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-China group plans Oslo protest against Nobel Peace Prize award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 19:01:57 (By Tseng Chih-yuan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A pro-China group, composed mainly of restaurateurs in Norway, will stage a protest in that country to show their disapproval of the Nobel Prize Committee's decision to honor a leading Chinese dissident with this year's Peace Prize, according to a Voice of America report Thursday.

On the eve of the award ceremony, more and more voices are being heard in support of Liu Xiaopo, the dissident who has been imprisoned in China for demanding freedom of expression in the communist country, VOA reported.
But at the same time, the Chinese Association in Norway is planning a march in Oslo on Dec. 10 in protest against the Nobel Peace Prize Committee's decision, VOA said.

The members of the association are mostly people in the restaurant business who, according to the association's president Yuan Yaming, "did not know who Liu Xiaopo was when his name was announced as the winner of the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize."
"When we found out who he was from the Web, we disapproved of his ideas and proposals," Yuan was quoted by the VOA as saying.
The report quoted Amnesty International workers as saying Beijing has been pressuring Yuan's group to stage a protest rally on the day of the ceremony.

Although Liu's seat will be empty at the Nobel Prize ceremony, ambassadors from more than 20 countries, including Russia, will boycott the occasion at the request of -- or under pressure from -- China.
China has done its best to limit media exposure of Friday's award ceremony and the possible effects of the event on China's international image.
According to Ming Pao Daily News of Hong Kong, at least 722 people were arrested, put under house arrest or banned from leaving China because they had voiced support for Liu.

Liu's wife, Liu Xia, was under constant surveillance in her Beijing residence and security guards were trying to deter journalists and photographers getting a glimpse of her, Hong Kong's Sing Tao Daily News said.
Liu Xia could not be reached on landline or cell phone, and her Twitter web page had not been updated for quite a long time.
The VOA has published a long list of dissidents and academics who, it said, are being persecuted in China simply because the Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony is approaching.
Part of the list is as follows:
--Wang Zhongxia and Liu Shasha, human rights activists, were taken away in Beijing. No one knows where they were being kept;
--Tang Jitian, human rights lawyer, was forced back to his hometown in Jilin province;
--Wang Lixiong, famous writer and expert on Tibet, and his wife Wei Se were kept under house arrest;
--Qin Yongmin, founder of the Democratic Party of China, was detained.
However, there are several Chinese nationals who will not succumb to explicit or implicit pressure from Beijing on the matter of Liu's award, according to reports.
In Hong Kong, a number of Legislative Council members, including Emily Lau, Lee Cheuk-yan and Albert Ho Chun-yan, and leaders of civilian groups departed Wednesday for Oslo.
They will attend the award ceremony as "representatives from the Chinese territory," supporting Liu Xiaopo.
As they witness a historic moment in Oslo, they are likely to hear another voice of support, in the form of music, from Chinese American violinist Lynn Chang.
Chang told the BBC that he is honored to have a chance to perform "Jasmine" (Mo Li Hua in Chinese) and other songs at the ceremony.
He said he will try to use music to interpret what a pity Liu's absence is from the award ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 19:13:51 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.151 to close at NT$30.555.
Turnover totaled US$609 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.706 and moved to a low of NT$30.081 to close at NT$30.555.
Dealers said the New Taiwan dollar extended its momentum as other Asian currencies rose against the U.S. dollar.
The local bourse hit a 30-month high, lending further support to the New Taiwan dollar. Foreign banks still served as the major buyer of the local currency, the dealers said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.57 percent at 8,753.84 Thursday.

Taiwan's central bank again intervened in the local foreign exchange market in late trade to boost the value of the U.S. dollar to above the NT$30.50 level but lower than NT$30.70, a level the market believes the central bank has tried hard to maintain in recent sessions, the dealers said.
They said it appeared that the central bank had lessened its grip on the exchange rate to some extent as foreign funds continued to enter the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government concerned over EU flat panel fines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:03:33 (By Lin Shu-yuan, Ho Meng-kuei, Hsieh Jiun-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government expressed concern Thursday over heavy fines the European Commission has slapped on four Taiwanese flat panel makers for alleged price- fixing.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said the government will provide any assistance necessary if the fined companies ask for help.

Shih said, however, that the government should have confidence in the companies' ability to deal with international lawsuits, as all of them have multinational operations and have their own legal teams.

In July last year, the European Commission -- the European Union's top decision- maker -- brought charges against Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp., along with LG Display of South Korea, accusing them of price-fixing.
Samsung Electronics, the world's largest flat panel maker, was not charged, since it blew the whistle to the European Commission on the price-fixing.

The EU antitrust regulator accused the firms of violating EU law through a conspiracy to engage in unfair price-fixing practices to hurt flat panel buyers in the production of products such as computers, mobile phones, TVs, digital watches and MP3 players.
The European Commission issued its decision Wednesday against the five manufacturers, which could face combined total fines to the tune of 649 million euros (US$862 million).
Of the five, Chi Mei -- which merged with Innolux Display Corp. to form Chimei Innolux Corp. in March -- received the heaviest penalty, with a fine of 300 million euros.
Meanwhile, Sun Li-chun, a commissioner with the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission, said the agency is willing to extend a helping hand if the government is allowed to intervene.
Sun noted that based on past experience, the amounts of that fines are negotiable if the accused companies appeal and explain their situations.
AUO, which was fined 116.8 million euros, has already said it will appeal.
An AUO spokesman said it has cooperated with the EU authorities over the past four years in their investigation into industry practices regarding the production and marketing of TFT-LCD products.
Meanwhile, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairwoman Christina Liu also said the government will try its best to help if the four companies ask.
Liu attributed the EU move -- a repetition of a similar antitrust case in the United States -- in part to the economic downturn in Europe and the U.S.
"These two areas tend to take more aggressive approaches when their economies are not in good shape," she said.
Chi Mei and Chunghwa said they will examine the EU decision more closely before taking their next steps. A Chi Mei executive said the 300 million-euro fine is "really too harsh."
Chunghua was fined 9 million euros, while HannStar got a fine of 8.1 million euros.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei will make strong bid for 2019 Asian Games: mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:16:46 (By Chen Hung-chin and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei City will make an all-out effort to host the 2019 Asian Games, using the momentum of its success in winning the bid Wednesday for the Asia Masters Athletics Championships, the city's mayor said Thursday.

The experience gained in organizing the championships, scheduled for 2012, will help Taipei in its efforts to bid for other big international games, including the Asiad and the East Asian Games, said Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

It was confirmed Wednesday that Taipei had won the bid to host the 17th Asia Masters Athletics Championships, dubbed "the senior Olympics," Hau told a group of athletes who competed in this year's Asiad and were visiting the Taipei International Flora Exposition.

"The senior Olympics" are being held this year from December 6-12 in Malaysia. Athletes aged 35-95 from 24 Asian countries affiliated to the Asia Masters Athletics (AMA) association are competing in 25 events.
Hau said the bid for the 2019 Asian Games will be submitted next February, and if Taipei wins, it will have adequate time to prepare.
The plan is to make Guandu in suburban Taipei the main venue and to build sports stadiums in the adjoining Taipei County, Hau said.
The 2014 Asiad will be held in Incheon, South Korea.
On a different occasion Thursday, Hau said the 2009 Summer Deaflympics in Taipei represented a milestone in Taiwan's history of hosting international sports events.
That experience also contributed to the successful opening on Nov. 6 of the Flora Expo, and must be built on, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA, DOH censured over problems relating to pig blood cakes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:19:40 (By Sophia Yeh, Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's highest watchdog body on Thursday censured two government agencies for failing to ensure that a local snack called pig blood cake is produced under sanitary conditions.
The Control Yuan passed a motion moved by two of its members, Cheng Jen-huang and Yang Mei-lin, to censure the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Department of Health (DOH).

Cheng said the COA had failed to formulate a standard hygienic procedure for collecting pig's blood, while the DOH had neglected to make it mandatory for pig blood cakes to be subject to health inspections.
According to Cheng, pig's blood is collected at 45 of the 59 legal pig abattoirs in Taiwan for use in food recipes.
"Because the COA has not stipulated a standard method for pig's blood collection, there have been incidents of stool contamination of the blood during the collection process," he said.
In response, a COA official said that a standard operating procedure for pig's blood collection will be introduced at abattoirs from next year.

Huang Kwo-ching, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said the bureau will select several abattoirs at which to run a pilot project for blood collection, and if it proves feasible, all abattoirs will be required to adopt the procedure.
The procedure will involve the use of a hollow knife to collect blood from sedated pigs and the blood will collected in special bags to avoid contamination, he explained.
Meanwhile, another problem is the storage of the blood once it has been collected, according to Cheng.

Pig's blood contains about 17-18 percent protein and it decomposes fast at room temperature, he noted. But according to COA statistics, 73.3 percent of the abattoirs in Taiwan store the blood in an environment warmer than 5 degrees Celsius, he added.

He said that neither the COA nor the DOH have kept track of where pig's blood goes from the abattoirs, let alone monitor the conditions under which pig blood cakes are made for sale in night markets and on the Internet.
When asked whether pig blood cakes were being exported to the United States, the two government agencies gave conflicting responses, he said.

The DOH's reply was that no pig's blood products had been exported to Europe or the United States since an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Taiwan in 1997, while the COA said its data showed that 28,960 kilograms of pig blood cakes had been exported to the United States between 2003 and 2006, Cheng said.

The issue of pig blood cakes first came to the forefront earlier this year when a local newspaper reported that the U.S. Department of Agriculture had banned the production and sale of the product throughout the U.S. because it was being made in unsanitary conditions.
In Taiwan, pig blood cake is usually eaten as a steamed snack served on a wooden stick or cooked as a hot-pot ingredient. .

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese cellist to perform with National Symphony Orchestra
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:25:05 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Famed Chinese cellist Jian Wang will join Taiwan's National Symphony Orchestra (NSO) in two concerts in Taipei on Friday and Saturday, an experience he said will be "inspiring and very exciting."

The cellist, born and raised in China, gained worldwide attention at the age of 10 when he was discovered by Ukrainian-born violin virtuoso Isaac Stern, whose encouragement and support paved the way for Wang to study music in the United States.
Wang has performed with many of the world's top symphony orchestras, including the Philadelphia Orchestra, Berliner Philharmoniker and NHK Symphony Orchestra, to name a few.

At a press conference Thursday, he said he was very excited about the two concerts because he would be performing under the baton of NSO resident maestro Lu Shao-chia. Wang described Lu a real friend and a conductor with an outstanding sense of music style and a clear beat.
"Lu is 10 times better than any of other foreign conductors I have worked with in the past," Wang told reporters.
Lu, who is based in Germany, returned to Taiwan in September and took up the position of music director and principal conductor of the NSO.
He will perform with Wang for the first time in Taiwan at the weekend concerts. They have performed together once in Germany.

The first part of the Friday's program at National Concert Hall will open with Sibelius's Pohjola's Daughter, Op. 49, followed by Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta, and Dvorak's Cello Concerto in B minor, Op. 104.

On Saturday, the concert will be held at Palm Trees Boulevard at National Taiwan University. Wang will perform Dvorak's Cello Concerto of 1896 with the NSO in the free concert. Sibelius' Finlandia, Op. 26 and Beethoven's symphony No.9 Mov. 3 & 4 are also on Saturday's program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Quanta November sales hit record high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:26:03 (By Han Ting-ting and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Quanta Computer Inc., the world's largest notebook computer ODM service provider, said Thursday that its sales hit a record high in November on an increase in shipments of high-end products.
In November, Quanta posted sales of NT$100.28 billion (US$3.32 billion), up 11.3 percent from October and up 7.5 percent from a year earlier.
In the first 11 months of the year, the company's sales totaled NT$995.85 billion, up 42.15 percent from a year earlier.
Market observers said it is very likely that Quanta will reach its goal of more than NT$1 trillion in sales for 2010, thanks to November's strong showing.
They said the company is also very likely to realize another goal of shipping a total of 50 million notebook computers this year after selling 47.10 million units in the first 11 months.
Local media reported that Quanta has secured orders from Apple to manufacturer iPads, but the company declined to comment on any specific customers.
The company said the guidance it gave in October that its sales in the fourth quarter of this year will rise by as much as 5 percent from the third quarter remained unchanged.
Encouraged by the November sales figure, buying in Quanta shares resumed to boost its share price to close at NT$63.50 Wednesday, up 4.10 percent from a day earlier, dealers said.
They said the buying largely came from foreign institutional investors in an optimistic mood about the company's earnings outlook.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global foundry capacity to rise 8 percent in 2011: industry group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:29:37 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Production capacity of the global foundry business is expected to grow 8 percent in 2011 from this year after an estimated 8 percent increase in 2010, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International (SEMI), an industrial group, said Thursday.
Production capacity in 2012 is expected to rise another 9 percent year-on-year, the group said.
SEMI is a global industrial association for the microelectronic, display and photovoltaic industries.
The group said the estimates are based on the input of announced capacity plans and other analyses about foundry investments.
Despite the expansion, the increases over the three years are modest compared to the double-digit growth seen each year from 2003 to 2007, according to SEMI.

In the past, the memory chip segment led growth in the foundry business, with growth rates twice as high as the growth in the industry as a whole, but memory chip production capacity is expected to increase at only the same rate as the rest of the foundry industry through 2012, SEMI said.
SEMI said spending on new wafer plant construction projects for 2011 is expected to fall 11 percent from a year earlier and that the trend might accelerate in 2012.
Despite the falls in spending on construction projects, spending on chip production equipment is expected to rise 23 percent from 2010 to hit about US$40 billion in 2011, according to SEMI.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwanese rely on selves for retirement funds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:41:48 (By Kao Chao-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: More than 66 percent of Taiwanese who responded to a recent survey said they rely on themselves to prepare their retirement funds, while the rest said they rely on their employers or the government to provide a pension, according to the poll results.

HSBC bank commissioned the Nielsen market survey company to interview bank clients aged between 25 and 65 in Hong Kong, India, South Korea, China, Malaysia, Singapore and Taiwan in July and August. A total of 516 Taiwanese were polled.

The results show that Taiwanese provide for their retirement mainly by saving cash and buying term deposits, with 58 percent of the respondents saying their retirement will be financed mainly by such means.
Not only are Taiwanese not good at planning for retirement, according to the survey, they are also not good at saving for their children's education, according to the survey results.

The survey found that only 43 percent of those polled pay for their children's kindergarten and primary school tuition with cash while setting aside some money for their high school and university education.

Two factors have affected the long-term financial plans of the Taiwanese respondents: job security and fear of losing money on their investments, the survey shows, with 59 percent expressing worry about losing their jobs and 65 percent saying they lack confidence in the investment market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to ink investment protection pact with China in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:44:24 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to conclude an investment protection agreement with China in the seventh round of high-level negotiations that will be held between the two sides in the first half of next year, Taiwan's top China policy planner said Thursday.

Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the cross-Taiwan Strait investment protection pact involves many issues that are not only complicated but also wide-ranging and far-reaching.

Therefore, there will not be enough time to sort out all the related issues and sign the agreement in the upcoming round of talks between the two sides this month, Lai said during a meeting of the legislature's Interior Affairs Committee.

The next round of institutionalized talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is scheduled to be held in Taipei in the second half of December.
The main item on the agenda for the sixth "Chiang-Chen meeting" will be the signing of a bilateral medical cooperation agreement.

Lai told the lawmakers that the proposed investment protection agreement will be excluded from the agenda for the sixth "Chiang-Chen meeting" because the two sides have not yet come to terms on certain issues.
These issues include the personal safety of Taiwanese businessmen in China, compensation for land expropriation and the technical details of a dispute settlement mechanism, she elaborated.
Besides, she said, the two sides need more time to formulate a set of investment protection regulations that would be in line with world standards and acceptable to both sides.

Noting that China has signed investment protection accords with 130 nations while Taiwan has concluded 29, Lai said each side has a certain formula for protecting the overseas investments of its citizens.
The cross-strait investment protection accord is relatively complicated because of the unique relationship between Taiwan and China and their different legal systems, she added.
However, she denied rumors that the talks on the agreement were being hindered by a sovereignty dispute, saying that the arbitration of investment disputes does not involve sovereignty issues.
According to SEF statistics, in the period from January 1991 to October 2010, it had received 3,969 complaints filed by Taiwanese doing business on the Chinese mainland.
Of that number, 2,250 cases involved danger to personal and financial safety, and 1,719 involved breaches of financial rights and interests.
Only about 30 percent of those cases have been settled, according to SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lian.

DOC.HEADLINE: Royal Ballet to perform in Taiwan during centennial celebrations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 20:55:28 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The Royal Ballet, a world-class classical ballet company based in London, will perform in Taiwan over a four-day period as part of the country's 100th anniversary celebrations next year, one of the cultural organizers said in Taipei Thursday.

In its first ever performance in Taiwan, the world famous ballet company will present two dance programs to the accompaniment of the National Symphony Orchestra, according to the National Theatre and Concert Hall (NTCH).
The first piece comprises three short dances and the second features the full- length romantic ballet "Giselle, " the NTCH said. They will be staged Jun. 30 to July 3 at National Theatre Hall.
Kevin O'Hare, administrative director of the Royal Ballet, said at a promotional press conference in Taipei that the two programs will give Taiwan audiences a chance to see the range of the company.
In "Giselle, " there will be four movements and they will be led by four sets of principal dancers.
"No role is too small, " O'Hare said. "Everyone in the company is very involved in the performance, and whenever you look, you will see the story continue."
He said the Royal Ballet always brings the full company -- 92 dancers and more than 50 technical personnel -- when it is on tour.
"If you come to see a ballet, and you don't know anything about ballet, you still will be moved by the performance, because the whole company is telling the story," he added.
Coincidentally, the Royal ballet will be celebrating its 80th founding anniversary next year, he said.

Huang Pi-twan, artistic director of the NTCH, said at the press conference that the Royal Ballet presentation is one of the 20 top-notch performances that will be held, along with 100 free cultural activities, as part of the NTCH's efforts to encourage public participation in the centennial celebrations next year.
Starting from the last day of this month and running through the last day of 2011, there will be a number of exciting performances in Taiwan, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sales of Acer smartphones to reach 2 million in 2010

TEXT.P: Acer Inc. said Thursday that the company will meet its goal for smartphone shipments by the end of this year and expects to sell more Android-based models in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Extra cross-strait flights for Lunar New Year to be discussed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 21:48:48 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday it will seek during Dec. 27 negotiations to add an additional 120 flights on cross-Taiwan Strait routes to all Chinese destinations for the coming Lunar New Year holiday.

However, as Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen remain the most popular cross-strait destinations, Taiwan's proposal to increase flights to these cities might not be fully realized, since the Chinese government has set quotas for all four destinations, said CAA Director-General Yin Chen-pong.
During the one-month Lunar New Year holiday in 2010, Taiwanese carriers offered an additional 88 flights -- 32 to Shanghai, 20 to Beijing, 20 to Guangzhou and 16 to Shenzhen.

Even if red-eye flights are inevitable, Taiwan-based carriers have agreed that fares for such flights will be slashed by at least 40 percent if customers buy their tickets online.
"At least half of the tickets will be available online, " Yin said. "The public are welcome to report to us should any of the carriers break this deal," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air passenger returns `stolen' property 10 years later
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:13:50 (By Cheng Chi-feng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Ten years after stealing a cup, a blanket and a set of dining utensils from a Cathay Pacific plane, the repentant passenger sent them back to the airline, along with NT$900 (US$29.82), airline sources said Thursday.
The airline's Kaohsiung office received the package July 19, but as they were unable to contact the sender, who called himself Chiu Chan-ho, they initially did not open it.
Finally, a female staffer's curiosity got the better of her and she opened the package.

Lee Hsiung-ta, a manager in charge of the carrier's business in southern Taiwan, speculated that Chiu might be a frequent flyer who pilfered the objects a long time ago and was now sending them back after being struck with remorse.
Lee told CNA that all the items were no longer in production and should be seen as collector's items.
Since the staff could not reach the sender, they decided to donate that NT$900 "interest payment" to the United Nations Children's Fund.
Lee further reported that this year alone, Cathay Pacific has lost 1,000 of the life vests that are placed under passengers' seats, a big loss to the company since each is worth around NT$1,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Korean TV crew visits Kinmen
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:18:35 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A production crew from South Korea's public television broadcaster, the Korean Broadcasting System (KBS), visited Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen Thursday to get a glimpse into the underground military bases and facilities there.

The four-member KBS crew, including journalist Park Sang-min and Lee Chang- heung, a retired researcher with South Korea's Defense Ministry, visited a deep underground military base (DUMB) tunnel and two fortifications on Little Kinmen -- a smaller islet to the west of Kinmen.
The crew also visited Chiunglin Village on Kinmen to film DUMB tunnels there.

The group is on a three-day tour of Kinmen to find out how Kinmen survived the many Chinese communist strikes against it in years gone by, including extensive shelling in 1958, and how it has been transformed from a frontline anti- communist bastion into a tourist attraction.

The group also visited the island's Shuitou Wharf to see how Kinmen serves as a gateway between Taiwan and China's nearby Fujian Province, allowing people from the two sides to exchange visits freely via ferry.
According to a Kinmen military source, the Korean visitors showed great admiration for the close and peaceful interaction between the people on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
The KBS crew made the visit as a planned trip to Kinmen by South Korean military personnel hit a snag after news of the visit was disclosed.
Foreign wire reports quoted South Korean President Lee Myung-bak as saying two days earlier that a South Korean military delegation might visit the island this month.

According to the reports, South Korea wishes to gain knowledge about Kinmen's DUMB facilities and fortifications as a reference for its own efforts to fortify its five western border islands, including Yeonpyeong, which was attacked by North Korea last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH denies concealing suspected human mad-cow disease case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:21:53 (By Chen Ching-fang, Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) denied Thursday that it tried to conceal information about a suspected human mad-cow disease case in Taiwan.

Responding to questioning from the Consumers' Foundation about its handling of the first suspected human mad-cow disease death in Taiwan, the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said in a statement that the center has never tried to keep any information about the case secret.

The CDC was referring to a 36-year-old man who died in May this year from what appeared to be human mad-cow disease, medically known as Creutzfeldt-Jacob Disease (CJD), a rare but fatal form of disease linked to eating infected tissue from cows.
The man, who lived in the United Kingdom from 1978-1986, began to show symptoms of CJD such as memory loss and hypersomnia, and was reported to the CDC as a suspected CJD case in March 2009.
The CDC statement said that because the man's family refused to provide tissue for testing or to give permission for an autopsy, it is difficult to confirm the cause of his death.
Based on the patient's symptoms and his MRI and EEG records, a medical team determined it was an "extremely likely case" of CJD, the CDC statement said.

Judging from the fact that the patient was studying in the U.K. during the peak period of mad-cow disease there, the center said, his death could be counted as an imported case of CJD and unlikely to pose any threat to Taiwan's disease control network.
Moreover, the center added that it has carefully tracked the patient's medical and blood donation records and has adopted precautionary measures to prevent any spread of the disease.
Medically known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE, mad-cow disease causes spongy holes in the brains of infected cattle. Taiwan does not import beef from the U.K.

The CDC said its CJD reporting and monitoring system has been functioning well since 1997 and that it has also commissioned the Taiwan Neurological Society to form a special panel to screen reported CJD cases and train relevant medical staff and epidemiological personnel.
The CDC did not reveal information about the case until Wednesday, when a local financial biweekly published an article about the death in its latest issue.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday that the DOH should have released information about the case as soon as it was reported by a local medical institution to the Centers for Disease Control in March 2009.
Perhaps, the minister in charge at the time felt there was no need to release relevant information since the case did not originate in Taiwan, Yaung said.

"Nevertheless, I think otherwise. Since we are an open and pluralistic society, our people have the right to know. We should have informed the public of the case as soon as we received the report, regardless of whether the patient contracted the disease at home or abroad," Yaung said.
Responding to Yaung's remarks, then-DOH Minister Yeh Chin-chuan said that during his tenure, the patient's symptoms were not clear enough to make a positive CJD diagnosis.

"Given the fact that his family declined to provide tissue for testing or allow the patient to have advanced examinations, there was no way to confirm the case, " Yeh said, adding that this was why he did not inform Yaung of the case during the changeover of the post.

On speculation that the case had not been revealed mainly because the DOH was afraid the exposure would inspire opposition to the government's plan to end a ban on U.S. beef imports, Yeh said the speculation is unfounded and that the case had nothing to do with U.S. beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man thanks 'jigsaw expert' for saving shredded cash
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:28:37 (By Lin Chang-shun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A man who accidentally shredded NT$200,000 (US$6,600) thanked a government forensic expert for saving his money Thursday after the Central Bank decided to honor the notes.
The man, identified only by his surname of Lin, inadvertently put 200 NT$1,000 notes into a shredder last month. Through a lawmaker, he requested help from Ministry of Justice forensic experts.
Liu Hui-fen, a 30-year government employee who trained herself as a "jigsaw expert, " spent seven days, including four nights of overtime, piecing the notes back together.

Liu said it took patience and skill to complete the puzzle of the shredded notes. As each note needs to be just 75 percent complete to be recognized by the central bank, however, she did not finish the remaining 25 percent in order to save time.
Since 2006, Liu has been asked by the Central Bank to look into 247 cases of damaged banknotes, involving a total of NT$7.57 million.

She joined the government as a handwriting analyst and later passed internal exams to become a forensic scientist. She is now the only "jigsaw expert" for restoring bank notes at the ministry's Bureau of Investigation.
Lin, who runs a plastics factory in Taipei County, visited the bureau Thursday to say a personal thank you to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-corruption agency might be set up next April at earliest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:50:14 (By Lai You-chia and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu said Thursday that an anti-corruption agency could be set up next April at the earliest after a draft organic law of the agency passed an initial screening by a legislative committee that day.

The Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee of the Legislative Yuan passed the draft law proposed by the Ministry of Justice, but not without expressions of concern that its functions could overlap with existing organizations.

Ker Chien-ming, caucus whip of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, pointed out that currently, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) and the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office are already cracking down on corruption.
In response, Tseng said the proposed agency would be used to prevent and act against corruption, with the actual cracking down on corruption only a last resort.

According to the draft law, the agency will be in charge of the nation's anti- corruption policy, the formulation, coordination and promotion of related statutes, corruption prevention and related crime investigation, as well as the supervision and assessment of the government's various ethics bodies.

"The Investigation Bureau has to handle other cases in addition to cracking down on corruption, " Tseng said, adding that if the MJIB and the proposed agency end up probing the same case, the prosecutors will decide which will lead the investigation.
Tseng also said that if the draft law can clear the legislature during the current session that closes at the end of the month, the agency can be launched next April at the earliest.
Calls for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption agency mounted after the exposure of a high-profile bribery case implicating three senior judges and a prosecutor earlier this year.
President Ma Ying-jeou demanded that the agency be set up as soon as possible to improve the country's crackdown on corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police, legislature most corrupt: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:51:29 (By Lai Yu-chia and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The police is the most corrupt agency in the country, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by Transparency International (TI).

The agency scored 3.9 points on a five-band scale, while the Legislative Yuan was ranked as the second-most corrupt institution, with the score of 3.8, the results show. The scale ranks a score of 1 as least corrupt and 5 as most corrupt.

The survey, part of a global poll on corruption, was conducted online between June and July this year, polling more than 97,000 respondents aged over 15 from 86 countries and territories around the world for TI, the Berlin-based anti- graft group.

The perception of police corruption might be a result of the shooting in May of Weng Chi-nan, a gang leader in central Taiwan's Taichung City who was shot and killed in the presence of several police officers with whom he was drinking and gambling, said Chen Chun -ming, executive director of the TI's Taiwan chapter.
The political parties and the private sector both received the same scores of 3.5, followed by 3.3 points for the judiciary and 3.2 points for the media.

Compared with the results of a similar survey released in 2006, corruption in Taiwan has improved significantly, as the political parties and legislature both received 4.5 points on that occasion, followed by the police, with 4.1, the judiciary with 3.9, the private sector with 3.7 and the media with 3.3.
In addition, some 37 percent of the Taiwanese people polled agreed that the government has made some achievements in fighting corruption.
According to the survey, political parties around the world achieved an average score of 4.2 among the global respondents, making them considered the most corrupt institutions worldwide.

Of the three other "Asian Tigers", respondents in Hong Kong gave the highest score of 3.6 to the private sector and the media in Singapore received 3 points, while South Koreans named political parties and the legislature as their most corruption institutions.

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu said Thursday that an anti-corruption agency could be set up next April at the earliest after a draft organic law of the agency passed an initial screening by a legislative committee that day.

The Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee of the Legislative Yuan passed the draft law proposed by the Ministry of Justice, but not without expressions of concern that its functions could overlap with existing organizations.

Ker Chien-ming, caucus whip of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, pointed out that currently, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) and the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office are already cracking down on corruption.
In response, Tseng said the proposed agency would be used to prevent and act against corruption, with the actual cracking down on corruption only a last resort.

According to the draft law, the agency will be in charge of the nation's anti- corruption policy, the formulation, coordination and promotion of related statutes, corruption prevention and related crime investigation, as well as the supervision and assessment of the government's various ethics bodies.

"The Investigation Bureau has to handle other cases in addition to cracking down on corruption, " Tseng said, adding that if the MJIB and the proposed agency end up probing the same case, the prosecutors will decide which will lead the investigation.
Tseng also said that if the draft law can clear the legislature during the current session that closes at the end of the month, the agency can be launched next April at the earliest.
Calls for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption agency mounted after the exposure of a high-profile bribery case implicating three senior judges and a prosecutor earlier this year.
President Ma Ying-jeou demanded that the agency be set up as soon as possible to improve the country's crackdown on corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police, legislature most corrupt: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/10 22:51:29 (By Lai Yu-chia and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The police is the most corrupt agency in the country, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by Transparency International (TI).

The agency scored 3.9 points on a five-band scale, while the Legislative Yuan was ranked as the second-most corrupt institution, with the score of 3.8, the results show. The scale ranks a score of 1 as least corrupt and 5 as most corrupt.

The survey, part of a global poll on corruption, was conducted online between June and July this year, polling more than 97,000 respondents aged over 15 from 86 countries and territories around the world for TI, the Berlin-based anti- graft group.

The perception of police corruption might be a result of the shooting in May of Weng Chi-nan, a gang leader in central Taiwan's Taichung City who was shot and killed in the presence of several police officers with whom he was drinking and gambling, said Chen Chun -ming, executive director of the TI's Taiwan chapter.
The political parties and the private sector both received the same scores of 3.5, followed by 3.3 points for the judiciary and 3.2 points for the media.

Compared with the results of a similar survey released in 2006, corruption in Taiwan has improved significantly, as the political parties and legislature both received 4.5 points on that occasion, followed by the police, with 4.1, the judiciary with 3.9, the private sector with 3.7 and the media with 3.3.
In addition, some 37 percent of the Taiwanese people polled agreed that the government has made some achievements in fighting corruption.
According to the survey, political parties around the world achieved an average score of 4.2 among the global respondents, making them considered the most corrupt institutions worldwide.

Of the three other "Asian Tigers", respondents in Hong Kong gave the highest score of 3.6 to the private sector and the media in Singapore received 3 points, while South Koreans named political parties and the legislature as their most corruption institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 10, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng- hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."
