DOC.HEADLINE: Golfer returns to share LPGA Player of the Year honor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 10:42:19 (By Chiu Chin-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: LPGA Player of the Year 2010, Yani Tseng, returned to Taiwan from Florida early Friday to share with her friends the joy of winning the coveted golf title.

The 21-year-old was awarded the trophy Dec. 5 at the end of the 2010 LPGA Tour Championship at the Grand Cypress Golf Club in Orlando, which made her the first golfer from Taiwan to ever clinch the prize.
Looking stylishly casual in an orange-colored jacket, Tseng was all smiles when she arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
She told reporters that she felt lucky to be able to capture the LPGA Player of the Year award and would like to share the glory with all her friends in Taiwan.
On her career goal for the coming year, Tseng said she will continue working hard to pursue excellence in her sport.
Asked if she had any advice for other Taiwanese professional golfers, Tseng said tenacity is most important in the pursuit of career excellence.

"Professional sports are highly competitive and uncontrollable. You must be firmly and constantly committed to your goal when you find your direction, " she said. "No one knows what the result will be until the game is over. I hope none of our golfers will ever give up their career goals."
Tseng performed well this year, winning three titles, two of which were majors.

She said earlier this year that winning a career grand slam is her next goal. Of the five LPGA titles won during her career, three have been majors -- the LPGA Championship in 2008, the Kraft Nabisco Championship in April 2010 and the RICOH Women's British Open in August 2010. The U.S. Women's Open is the only major she has not yet won.
According to the LPGA website, only seven players in history have achieved career grand slams.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Cross-strait factors in elections

TEXT.P: Despite its achievements in smoothing relations with China, the ruling Kuomintang won 1.5 million fewer votes in the Nov. 27 elections in the five special municipalities than it did in the 2008 presidential election.

This may be an indication that although the people recognize the peace and economic benefits brought by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, they believe the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should play the role of a buffer in cross-Taiwan Strait political ties.

Probably realizing this problem, Mainland Affairs Council Minister Lai Shin- yuan on Wednesday openly outlined "the seven core interests of the Taiwanese people, " including the freedom to choose the future of cross-strait relations.

The next day, however, China's foreign affairs ministry posted on its website an article by state councilor Dai Bingguo stating that Taiwan is China's inviolable "core interest" and that China will never renounce the use of force. Dai's statement was probably in anticipation of Ma's possible backtracking and the DPP's possible return to power in 2012.

To create a cross-strait policy that is convincing and profound, the Ma administration needs to perform better in terms of interpreting "the Republic of China, " "the one-China based Constitution, " and "one China, respective interpretations." He also needs to strike a balance in cross-strait economic and political relations.
The hostile remarks by Beijing, however, could ruin the opportunity for cross- strait peace that has emerged in the past two years. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 10:45:42 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$30.088 at 9:45 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.467 from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lien makes first public appearance since election-eve shooting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 11:36:09 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Sean Lien, son of former Vice President Lien Chan, appeared in public Friday for the first time since he was shot at an election-eve rally in Taipei County on Nov. 26.
Lien was swamped by reporters as he stepped out of the building where he lives in downtown Taipei. He was on his way to hospital for follow-up treatment of his bullet wounds.
He said he was grateful for all the concern shown to him by society since he was hurt.
"I'm happy to be alive to meet all of you," he told reporters.
On the night of the incident, he was shot in the face at close range by a man who jumped out of the crowd at the campaign rally and accosted him.
The bullet hit Sean Lien in the left cheek and exited near his right temple. The same bullet killed a bystander, according to police reports.
Lien underwent emergency surgery at National Taiwan University Hospital and has since been in stable condition, his doctors said.
The bullet did not damage his brain or any vital nerves in his face, the doctors said.
He was discharged from hospital on the night of Dec. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of AsusTek sharply higher on share buyback plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 11:49:46 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc. were sharply higher in Friday morning trade after the company announced a share buyback plan, dealers said.
Investors ignored the fact that the company posted a 6 percent decline in sales for November from October due to inventory adjustments, the dealers said.
AsusTek rose 3.42 percent to NT$287.50 (US$9.52) , with 3.57 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index was down 0.35 percent at 8,723.56.
The company announced Thursday it will buy back 10 million shares at a price ranging from NT$240 to NT$300 per share between Dec. 10, 2010 and Feb. 9, 2011.

The number of buyback shares during that period will account for 1.59 percent of the company's total outstanding shares and the maximum fund for the repurchase will represent 3.11 percent of the company's liquid assets.
"The buyback plan shows AsusTek's intention to support its share price," Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said.
"Judging from the buyback price range, I expect the stock may see support at NT$240 and go higher to challenge the NT$300 mark in the near term," Lin said.
Lin said foreign institutional investors have turned optimistic about AsusTek's earnings outlook as the growing global tablet market is expected to boost the company's bottom line.
The market has also embraced high hopes that the global PC market will recover next year, Lin said.

"The fall in November sales was widely expected on high inventories, " Lin said. "It needs some time for the market to digest the inventories, and I do not expect AsusTek will see an immediate turnaround in terms of sales in December."
After a spinoff of its manufacturing arm earlier this year, AsusTek has concentrated its efforts on building its own brand in the global market, Lin said.
He said investors appeared to like the way AsusTek approached its operation restructuring by letting go the manufacturing segment whose profit margin was being squeezed by fierce global competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Health insurance can be made better

TEXT.P: A bill to introduce a second-generation national health insurance system was blocked by legislators Tuesday because of its many controversial aspects. On Thursday, the Cabinet decided to scrap the plan and promote a so-called 1.5-generation scheme instead.

The Department of Health (DOH) must take the largest share of responsibility for the turn of events. Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang may have succeeded in using his well-known bullishness to squeeze the long-stalled reform onto the legislative agenda, but he obviously did not pay much attention to whether the details were well thought out or reasonable.
The DOH must use its wisdom to clear up the doubts surrounding the reform and set up a health insurance system that is truly acceptable to the majority of people.
The Cabinet should also seek to make the existing income tax system fairer before allowing it to be used as a reference in the calculation of insurance premiums. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for release of Nobel Peace Prize winner
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 12:10:22 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou again urged China Friday to release jailed human rights activist Liu Xiaobo who has been awarded the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize.
Ma made the call at the presentation ceremony of the 2010 Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award held by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Liu will not be able to attend the Nobel Peace Prize Award Ceremony, also scheduled for Friday, in the Norwegian capital of Oslo because he is in prison in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins first medal at Asian Beach Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 13:05:38 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan won its first medal at the 2010 Asian Beach Games in Muscat, Oman with a third place finish by Pan Kai-wen in the men's 5-kilometer marathon swimming Friday.

Pan, 21, won a bronze medal, completing the event in one hour and 54.9 seconds, behind Saleh Mohammad of Syria who won in a time of 1: 0: 14.4 and Xu Wenchao of China who finished in second place in 1:0:19.5.
According to the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, Pan's bronze was Taiwan's first medal in long-distance swimming at the Asian Beach Games.
The second edition of the Asian Beach Games is being held in Muscat, Oman from Dec. 8-16, with more than 1,000 athletes from 45 Asian countries participating in 52 categories in 14 sports.
Taiwan sent a team of 38 athletes -- 24 men and 14 women -- to Muscat to compete in beach handball, beach volleyball, beach woodball, marathon swimming, sailing, triathlon and water skiing.
The Asian Beach Games is a biennial multi-sport event regulated by the Olympic Council of Asia. The inaugural games were held in Bali, Indonesia in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Taiwanese graduate from Honduran military academies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 13:12:28 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three cadets from Taiwan graduated from Honduran military academies recently with remarkable academic performances, the Republic of China Embassy in Honduras said Friday.

Tien Chien-min, Chang Shuo-fang and Chi Fei were among 89 military school graduates who were awarded bachelor's degree diplomas and the rank of second lieutenant or ensign during a ceremony on Dec. 8, the embassy said.

Honduran President Porfirio Lobo Sosa, who presided at the graduation ceremony, congratulated the new officers on their achievements and praised the Taiwanese graduates for their outstanding performance in school.
He also expressed the hope that the Taiwanese graduates would help in the future to promote military interaction between Taiwan and Honduras.
ROC Ambassador to Honduras Lai Chien-chung and Col. Yen Chung-hsiao, a military attache at the embassy, also attended the graduation ceremony.
The three new Taiwanese officers were exchange students. Tien was studying at the Military Academy, Chang at the Academy of Aviation and Chi Fei at the Naval Academy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Will health insurance reform backpedal?
DOC.DATELINE: In a surprise twist, the Department of Health (DOH) 12/10/10 13:46:47 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: reportedly has agreed to abandon its long-held plan to calculate health insurance premiums on the basis of overall household income, in order to win legislative support for reform of the debt-laden national health insurance (NHI) system.

It was decided at a meeting late Thursday of DOH officials and leading members of the ruling Kuomintang legislative caucus that premiums will be calculated based on regular salaries of the insured, as is the case at present, but that high earning individuals will be required to pay higher premiums under the revised system, major local newspaper reported Friday.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Speaking at the meeting chaired by Premier Wu Den-yih, KMT legislative whips asked that the DOH scrap its plan to calculate health insurance premiums on the basis of "presumed income" for individuals with no regular salary. The lawmakers also requested that the premium rates for people in that category be lowered further.

It was also tentatively decided that service revenues of highly paid people such as top entertainers, lawyers and accountants will be incorporated into their regular salaries in the calculation of their health insurance premiums.
During the meeting, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang promised that the DOH will come up with a new version of the health premium reform plan that would incorporate these suggestions.

Some KMT lawmakers also suggested at the meeting that the stock transaction tax rate be raised from the current 0.3 percent to 0.35 percent, a move that they said would generate an additional NT$20 billion (US$655.74 million) in tax revenues to help keep the cash-strapped national health insurance system afloat.

Finance Minister Lee Sush-teh, however, was quite unenthusiastic about the proposal, saying it should be a last resort. Lee agreed only to assess the pros and cons of the proposal, financial officials said. (Dec. 10, 2010).
China Times:

KMT Legislator Yang Li-huan said after the meeting that the DOH-proposed premium system based on overall household income will be abandoned and that the new system will be based on the current formula of calculating premiums on the basis of regular salaries or wages of the insured.

But she added that under the new system, year-end bonuses, service revenues, capital gains and overseas earnings that are easy to assess with the use of existing tax levy techniques should also be included.
"Anyway, the common consensus reached at the meeting was that the new system should not increase financial burden on salaried people, " Yang said. (Dec. 10, 2010).
Liberty Times:
Major civic watchdog bodies said the ruling party's plan to scrap the proposed system of calculating health premiums based on total household income was unacceptable.

"Eight years have been spent drafting the new system. How can it be abandoned so lightly? The ruling party's frivolous attitude in dealing with the serious matter of reform is unacceptable," said Teng Hsi-hua, spokesman for the NHI Civilian Surveillance Alliance.

Health Minister Yaung said late Thursday that the DOH has not yet decided to give up its second-generation health insurance premium proposal and will continue working to modify it to satisfy as many as people as possible. (Dec. 10, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for release of Nobel Peace Prize winner (Update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 14:47:08 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou again urged China Friday to release jailed human rights activist Liu Xiaobo, who has been awarded the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize.

Liu will not be able to attend the Nobel Peace Prize Award Ceremony, also scheduled for Friday, in the Norwegian capital of Oslo because he is in prison in China, where he is serving 11 years for sedition.
Ma reiterated that Taiwan supports the Nobel Committee's decision to present the prize to Liu because the country attaches great importance to human rights.

"Our concern for human rights acknowledges no nationality or territorial boundary, " Ma said at the presentation ceremony of the 2010 Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award held by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

After ratifying the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights in 2009, Taiwan is spending two years conducting a comprehensive review of existing laws and regulations to ensure that they comply with the two agreements.
This will keep Taiwan abreast of world standards in terms of human rights protection, he said.

The Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award is awarded annually to an individual or organization that has made significant contributions to the advancement of democracy or human rights in Asia through peaceful means.

This year's award was presented to Triveni Balkrishna Acharya, president of Rescue Foundation, an Indian non-government organization devoted to the rescue and rehabilitation of victims of human trafficking and the sex industry in South Asia.
Archarya said at the ceremony that democracy can only be realized when human rights are protected.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP proposes 'human rights clause' in cross-strait agreements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 17:07:06 (By Sophia Yeh, Justin Su and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the government Friday to include a "human rights clause" in the planned agreements between Taiwan and China as an indication of Taiwan's concern for the universal issue.
According to the DPP, democracy and human rights should be put on the agenda of the cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges because they are Taiwan's most important assets.

"The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou must take concrete action to show its support for China's democracy activists and show the world that Taiwan stands firmly behind the pursuit of democracy and human rights, " said DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang at a news conference held to mark Human Rights Day.
Lin urged Beijing to respond to the international community's call for the release of 2010 Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo from prison and an end to the house arrest of his wife Liu Xia.

Also on Friday, DPP Legislator Chen Ting-fei suggested that immigration authorities refuse to admit Beijing Deputy Mayor Ji Lin, who is scheduled to visit Taiwan Dec. 13, on grounds that he has persecuted Falun Gong followers.

The proposal was made based on a resolution adopted by the Legislative Yuan Tuesday asking authorities to list Chinese government officials who violate human rights as personas non grata, which means they will be refused entry to Taiwan.

In response, Shih Chen-chia, an official of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior, said the NIA attaches great importance to the legislature's resolution and has included the issue on the agenda of an intra-ministerial meeting scheduled for Dec. 14.
Shih said he will also pass on to his superiors Chen's proposal that Ji be denied entry to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.39 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 17:37:30 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.39 percent Friday, dragged down by construction shares on fears that the government would impose a new tax to curb speculation in the property market, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 35.01 points to 8,718.83, after moving between 8,684.05 and 8,744.67, on turnover of NT$143.34 billion (US$4.75 billion).
The market opened down 0.57 percent and moved to the day's low as investors pocketed the gains posted in the previous session, dealers said.
However, after the index fell below the 8,700 point mark, bargain hunting emerged to help the market to recoup some of its losses, they said.
A total of 2,848 stocks closed down, 1,438 finished up, and 308 remained unchanged.

The construction sector suffered the heaviest selling, falling 3.0 percent. Paper and pulp stocks fell 1.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares lost 1.1 percent, foodstuffs shed 0.9 percent and cement shares closed down 0.8 percent.
The financial sector lost 0.6 percent and the textile sector fell 0.5 percent, while machinery and electronics shares closed up 0.1 percent.

The local media reported on Friday that the government is planning to introduce an additional tax on sales of properties being sold for the second time within a year to cap market speculation and prevent an asset bubble.
"Although the report has not been confirmed, investors used it as an excuse to lock in gains posted on Thursday, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said.
In addition to the construction sector, other old economy stocks also came under pressure after being significantly boosted in previous days by the rising local currency, Chiang said.
"After the market hit a 30-month high yesterday, today's correction came as no surprise," Chiang said. "It was quite technical in nature."

Chiang said, however, that the downward pressure was not too strong, as many investors appeared willing to hang on to their stocks because of expectations that additional foreign funds would enter the local market to push share prices higher.
Among downward moving construction shares, Cathay Real Estate lost 4.90 percent to NT$16.50 and Kuo Yang Construction fell 4.59 percent to NT$23.90.
However, PC vendor AsusTek outperformed the broader market, closing up 1.80 percent at NT$283.00 after a share buyback announcement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Taiwan's disappearing middle class
DOC.DATELINE: 12/10/10 17:41:28 (CommonWealth 461)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's political map is changing, with the green camp led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party gradually eclipsing the ruling Kuomintang's blue camp.
The trend, evident in the recent municipal elections in which the green camp overtook the blues in total vote count, is closely related to the shrinking of Taiwan's middle class.

The phenomenon has already emerged in Western countries, as they have been encouraging economic activities that bring in capital gains on the assumption that if it is good for the stock and property markets, it is good for the economy.
However, industrial reforms and innovation, which are required if real progress is to be made, have been neglected.
Booming stock and property trade has only served to widen the wealth gap in advanced countries, and Taiwan is following suit.
Compared to the soaring stock and property prices, slipping salaries have given the middle class an increasing sense of being exploited and pushed toward poverty.
In the past, over 80 percent of Taiwan's people considered themselves middle class, which helped the country achieve its democratic development in a stable environment.

Today, the wealthy's pursuit of luxury goods and mansions has created an atmosphere of extravagance that makes even the richer section of the middle class, defined as those with an annual income of NT$1 million (US$33,036) , feel poorer and discontented with the situation.

As democracy theories point out that people's desire for aggressive change intensifies without the middle class, and Taiwan has entered a phase that requires overall structural reforms, the government must find a solution to prevent the social unrest that has surfaced in Western countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges Tokyo to pass law on NPM exhibitions in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 17:51:28 (By Lee Shu-hua, Sophia Yeh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on Japan Friday to pass and enact as soon as possible a law that will protect collections of the National Palace Museum (NPM) in Taipei from being seized by a third country if they are exhibited in Japan.
Ma made the call during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Hatakenaka Atsushi, visiting chairman of the Interchange Association of Japan.
The organization serves as Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Ma said he hopes the widely acclaimed national treasures that are kept at the NPM can be exhibited in Japan, since such a show would help boost the cultural interaction between the two countries.

At present, items in the NPM collections cannot be shipped to Japan for exhibitions because the country has no law banning a third country from seizing such items by claiming ownership of them. Beijing considers the artifacts in the NPM to rightfully belong to China.

Ma noted that various NPM artifacts have been exhibited in countries such as the United States, France and Germany, all of which have laws protecting Taiwan's ownership. These exhibitions have been very successful, he said.
Ma asked Atsushi to wield his political influence in prompting Japanese lawmakers to pass a law guaranteeing the safety of NPM collections while they are in Japan.
Atsushi was visiting Taiwan for the 35th Taiwan-Japan Economic and Trade Forum that took place Dec. 9-10 in Taipei.
Earlier in the day, he signed an agreement with his Taiwanese counterpart, East Asian Relations Commission Chairman Peng Run-tsu, on cooperation in the prevention and control of natural disasters.

Under the terms of the agreement, the two countries will share data and information on damage caused by earthquakes, typhoons and destructive landslides; natural disaster prevention strategies; and experience in post- disaster reconstruction.
Both Taiwan and Japan are located on the earthquake belt on the rim of the Pacific Ocean and sustain frequent typhoons and earthquakes every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 18:07:25 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.03 to close at the day's high of NT$30.585.
Turnover totaled US$712 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.555 and moved to a low of NT$30.030 before rebounding.

The local currency continued to steam ahead right after the market opened on additional foreign fund inflows, and the momentum extended throughout almost the entire session before the central bank intervened in late trade, dealers said.
Despite a fall in the local bourse, buying in the New Taiwan dollar remained strong during the session, with foreign banks and exporters the major buyers, they said.

These buyers were betting that the local currency will rise against the U.S. dollar on hopes that a spillover effect of excessive liquidity will spread to the Asian markets from the U.S., which is easing its monetary policy to boost its economy, they added.
The benchmark weighted index closed down 0.39 percent at 8,718.83.
A weaker U.S. dollar against other Asian currencies in the region added downward pressure on the greenback in the local foreign exchange market, the dealers said.

The central bank again entered the trading floor to shore up the U.S. dollar and push the value of the currency above NT$30.50, a level the market believes the bank has tried hard to maintain, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan negotiator to visit Shanghai in preparation for talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 18:48:50 (By Charles Kang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The deputy chairman and secretary-general of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will fly to Shanghai on Dec. 14 for preparatory talks ahead of the sixth round of high-level negotiations between Taiwan and China, the SEF said Friday.

Kao Koong-lian and his Chinese counterpart Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will finalize the date, venue and agenda for the new round of talks between the heads of the two organizations scheduled for late December in Taipei.

They will also complete the draft of a cross-strait agreement on medical cooperation that is expected to be sealed in the upcoming meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin.
In addition, Kao and Zheng will discuss follow-up talks on a proposed investment protection agreement that Taiwan hopes can be worked out soon, the SEF said.

The proposed investment protection agreement, which is of interest particularly to Taiwan businessmen operating in China, was excluded from the agenda of the sixth round of cross-strait talks after the two sides failed to reach consensus on certain clauses.
The exact date of the sixth Chiang-Chen meeting will be announced at the end of the one-day preparatory talks in Shanghai, the SEF said.
The SEF and ARATS were established to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal relations between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC November sales down 4.1 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 19:11:55 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, said Friday that its November sales fell 4.1 percent, ending an eight- month upward streak in monthly revenue.

Last month, TSMC posted NT$36.85 billion (US$1.22 billion) in sales, compared with NT$38.43 billion recorded in October. The November figure represented a 21.5 percent increase from a year earlier, the company said.
In the first 11 months of this year, TSMC's sales totaled NT$384.67 billion, up 45.6 percent year-on-year, the company added.

"The decline largely reflected a slowdown in the global personal computer market," TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said. "TSMC started to feel the effect of a slow season in the fourth quarter for the global foundry business."
He said outsourcing from fabless IC designers is on the decline as these firms are adjusting their inventories, adding that they will need some time to lower the inventories.
Shih said a rising New Taiwan dollar also put downward pressure on TSMC's revenue.
Since the end of August, the local currency has risen 4.6 percent against the U.S. dollar.
However, TSMC is taking advantage of its relatively advanced production process to offset the weakening global demand and has secured orders for higher-end products, Shih said.
In the third quarter, products on the advanced 40 nanometer production process accounted for about 17 percent of the company's total sales.
TSMC expects the ratio of the 40 nm production process to rise to 20 percent in the fourth quarter.
Shih said that while it is unlikely TSMC will see a sales turnaround in December, the decline should be limited.
"It is possible for the company to achieve its goal of generating NT$109 billion in sales in the fourth quarter," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's appeal to sports court could be accepted: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 19:11:39 (By Pasan Hsiao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan believes an appeal it has filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) related to the disqualification of one of its taekwondo athletes at the 2010 Asian Games will be accepted by the court, an official said Friday.

Steven S. K. Chen, vice minister of the Sports Affairs Council (SAC), said the council had received a notice from the Lausanne-based tribunal asking it to remit to the court a sum of money as an arbitration fee.
"This action should serve as an indication that the international court is determined to accept the case," Chen said.

The Cabinet-level council filed the appeal via a law firm on Wednesday. It has asked for arbitration in the case of Yang Shu-chun's controversial dismissal from the women's under 49-kilogram division in the taekwondo competition at the Asiad in Guangzhou, China on Nov. 17.

The appeal was filed by Lee and Li Attorneys-at-Law on behalf of the council, which feared it would be too late if Taiwan submitted the appeal after Dec. 18, when the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) is scheduled to convene a disciplinary committee meeting in Seoul to discuss Yang's case.

"In the past two days, we have not received any information signaling that the CAS would not take the case. Instead, it has asked us to remit an arbitration fee to facilitate follow-up procedures, " Chen said.
Taiwan could withdraw the arbitration appeal if the WTF issues an acceptable statement after its Dec. 18 meeting.
However, Taiwan will proceed with the case in the international court if the WTF makes any decision that would jeopardize Yang's rights, he added.
WTF Secretary-General Yang Jin-suk said in Seoul Friday he was unaware of any attempt to have the dispute brought to the CAS.
Under most circumstances, a case can only be arbitrated by the CAS if both parties to the dispute agree to do so. It is unclear if the WTF would accept taking the case to the arbitration court.

CAS Secretary-General Matthieu Reeb told the Central News Agency in an e-mail on Nov. 26 that the WTF did not seem to recognize the jurisdiction of the court in disputes similar to incidents such as Yang Shu-chun's disqualification.

Yang, her coaches Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, and Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association President Chen Chien-ping, will all travel to Seoul next week to attend the WTF disciplinary committee meeting and present written testimony in hopes of getting a fair solution to the dispute.
Local media have speculated, however, that Yang could face a ban from the sport for failing to leave the ring after she was disqualified.

The 25-year-old athlete, who was one Taiwan's hopefuls for a gold medal at the Asiad, was disqualified during her opening bout of the tournament for allegedly wearing extra sensors in her socks in an attempt to score more points.

Video footage of the match released later showed, however, that Yang was not wearing the sensors during the bout. Inconsistent explanations by WTF and Asian Taekwondo Union (ATU) officials of why Yang was disqualified have added to the controversy.

Taiwan filed a protest over the decision with the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) but also vowed to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if other appeals failed to provide a satisfactory outcome.

In response to public concerns that the Seoul meeting might result in a disciplinary measures against Yang, SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said Thursday that her agency had collected all the evidence related to the case -- favorable or unfavorable -- and assessed all possible scenarios to protect Yang's interests and rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel maker Chimei Innolux owner protests over fines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 19:33:49 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Terry Gou, chairman of Hon Hai Group, which owns Taiwanese flat panel maker Chimei Innolux Corp., protested strongly Friday against the European Commission over huge fines slapped on the flat panel maker for alleged price-fixing.
After meeting with Taipei-based European officials, Gou told reporters that Chimei will wait until it receives formal notice of the fines before deciding whether to file an appeal.
The head of the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer
urged the commission to explain how the commission came up with the amount of the fine -- 300 million euros (US$397.76 million).

The business tycoon also blasted the commission for not charging Samsung Electronics, the world's largest flat panel maker, since it "blew the whistle" to the European Commission on the alleged price-fixing.
Gou said that he was not aware of any meetings between Samsung and Taiwanese flat panel makers that resulted in the alleged price-fixing.
However, he suggested that Samsung could have played a bigger role than the Taiwanese makers in the case.

In July last year, the European Commission -- the European Union's top decision- maker -- leveled charges against Chimei, AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp., along with LG Display of South Korea, accusing them of price-fixing.

The EU antitrust regulator accused the firms of violating EU law through a conspiracy to engage in unfair price-fixing practices to hurt flat panel buyers in the production of products such as computers, mobile phones, TVs, digital watches and MP3 players.
The European Commission issued its decision Wednesday against the five manufacturers, which could face combined total fines to the tune of 649 million euros.
Of the five, Chimei -- which merged with Innolux Display Corp. to form Chimei Innolux in March -- received the heaviest penalty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inter-agency mechanism needed to combat wildlife crime: NGO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 19:43:45 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: An inter-agency government unit and a central database system should be established in Taiwan to better combat wildlife crime, Mark Bowman, director of field operations of the Freeland Foundation, said in Taipei Friday.
The foundation, established in 2002 and based in Bangkok, is an international organization dedicated to ending wildlife and human trafficking and protecting natural habitats and vulnerable people.

Bowman was invited by Taiwan's Green Consumers Foundation to conduct a four-day evaluation and met with 12 government agencies to find out more about Taiwan's current wildlife law enforcement network.

Bowman said in a symposium held Friday that based on his short stay of only four days, Taiwan is committed to eradicating wildlife crime, as the conviction rate of the illegal wildlife trade is high, and that the officials he met with showed professionalism and determination to tackle the problem.
"I'll give Taiwan an 8 out of 10 points on wildlife law enforcement, the highest score I've ever given," he said.
However, illegal shipments still occur in Taiwan, and Taiwan is reported by international groups as a major node for the illegal wildlife trade, he observed.
To build a stronger mechanism to combat this type of crime, he suggested that the government set up an inter-agency mechanism, so that the criminals involved can be better monitored.

Kuan Li-hao, an officer of the Council for Agriculture -- the main government agency responsible for wildlife conservation -- welcomed Bowman's suggestion, but said insufficient manpower is the reason why Taiwan has yet to set up an inter-agency mechanism.

He said despite the fact that Taiwan is barred from joining international organizations due to China's objections, it has taken part in more than 200 international projects to help end the illegal wildlife trade.

Jay Fang, chairman of the Green Consumers Foundation, said most wildlife crime is related to organized crime groups, but in Taiwan, most of the criminals who are prosecuted are individuals, leaving the ringleaders beyond the reach of the law, which suggests that an update of related laws is needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 500,000 more people to get public subsidies under new legislation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 20:05:36 (By Ho Meng-kuei, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More lower-income households will soon be eligible for government subsidies after the Legislative Yuan on Friday passed amendments that change how Taiwan's official poverty line will be defined and who can get access to public assistance.

The amendments to the Public Assistance Act, scheduled to take effect on July 1, 2011, should add 588,000 people to the number of households eligible for public aid, said ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hou Tsai-feng after the passage of the revisions.
The bulk of those newly eligible to receive aid will be near poor households with average income per household member no more than 1.5 times as high as the poverty line.
That group was previously excluded from public assistance provisions, but the amendments passed Friday incorporated them among those eligible for financial aid.
Other new recipients will receive assistance by falling under a higher poverty line, or "minimum cost of living."
At present, the minimum cost of living is defined as 60 percent of average per capita consumption expenditures, but the new revisions change that to 60 percent of median disposable income per capita.

The minimum cost of living, which will vary from region to region, will be set at NT$14,794 (US$493) in Taipei City, NT$11,146 in Kaohsiung City, NT$11,832 in Xinbei City, NT$10,303 in Taichung City, NT$10,244 in Tainan City, and NT$10,244 in other cities and counties around the country.
Households with levels of average income per household member lower than the minimum cost of living can apply for public subsidies.

The new formula raises the poverty line by roughly 5-10 percent, although the minimum cost of living in Taipei City remained unchanged because of a provision that caps any region's minimum cost of living at 70 percent of the country's median disposable income per capita.
Without that cap, Taipei City's new minimum cost of living would have risen to NT$16,739.

Meanwhile, according to Hou, members of low-income households who are 65 or over, at least three-months pregnant, or physically or mentally challenged, are entitled to receive an additional three-months worth of subsidies per year.
The new formula ensures that assistance will be available to more disadvantaged families, said Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Chiech-ju welcomed the passage of the amendments because households that would be recognized as poor or near poor in other countries were finally being recognized as such in Taiwan.

Chen said that under the existing regulations, less than 1 percent of Taiwan's population was eligible for government subsidies, much lower than those in neighboring countries and areas such as South Korea and Hong Kong.
The amendments will help Taiwan narrow that gap with other countries to some extent, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers push for merger of three northern cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 20:13:48 (By Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) submitted a proposal Friday to have northern Taipei City, Taipei County and Keelung City merged into a single administrative district in a bid to upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness.

KMT Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, one of the authors of the proposal, said the merger of the three northern cities into a metropolis that would have a population of over 7 million was originally part of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign platform in early 2008 but never materialized for a variety of reasons.

Following the Nov. 27 five municipality elections, Taipei County will be upgraded to a municipality and renamed Xinbei City Dec. 25 -- making it part of a twin city with the capital, Taipei City, along with the much smaller neighboring Keelung City, Hsieh said.

He said that renowned metropolises elsewhere in the world, such as Tokyo and New York, are all single administrative districts and that few "twin cities" have been developed into successful world-class metropolises.

If Taipei City, Xinbei City and Keelung City were to be merged into one administrative district, it would have a population of over 7 million, constituting nearly 30 percent of Taiwan's total population. Such a merger would definitely make the northern area, to be known as the Taipei Metropolis, into a world-class conurbation with high competitiveness, according to Hsieh.

The merger proposal, titled "A Special Bill on the Merger of Taipei City, Xinbei City and Keelung City, " was authored and submitted by Hsieh (Keelung City), along with KMT legislators Justin Chou (Taipei City) , Huang Chih-hsiung (Xinbei City) , Wu Yu-sheng (Xinbei City) and Kuo Su-chun (legislator-at-large).
The proposal calls for the Executive Yuan to form a committee to push for the merger, with the deputy premier as the convener and 19-23 people as members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dissident urges Taiwan to pay more attention to China's human rights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 20:17:13 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Chinese dissident Wang Dan urged Taiwan's government and people Friday to pay more attention to the development of human rights in China because the issue will impact Taiwan's own security.

Speaking at an international conference to commemorate Taiwan's human rights development and International Human Rights Day, Wang, a visiting scholar at National Tsing Hua University, said human rights is a universal issue that should not be considered as merely domestic affairs of individual countries.

"The human rights issue is not only a political issue but also an issue of civilization. Whether or not China is a civilized country is related to Taiwan's own security because of the proximity of the two places, " the 41-year-old said during the International Conference on the Centennial of Human Rights in Taiwan: Retrospect and Prospect.
"An uncivilized neighbor is definitely not good news for the people of Taiwan, " he said.

Wang was among the core members of the 1989 student movement in Beijing's Tiananmen Square that led to the Chinese government's bloody massacre of the protesters. He was jailed from 1989-1993 before being allowed to go into exile in the United States and has been advocating democracy and freedom for China abroad ever since.

The dissident-turned-scholar urged Taiwan to establish a platform, especially on the Internet, for dialogue between everyday people in Taiwan and China and called for Taiwan's more experienced non-government organizations to help their Chinese counterparts develop.

He advised the government to invite more overseas Chinese students to visit Taiwan and experience democracy and freedom first-hand, and added that Taiwan should also make its position clear on every reported case of human rights infringement in China, despite the warmer cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Wang said he supports more liberalized cross-strait trade ties and President Ma Ying-jeou's plan to allow more Chinese students to study in Taiwanese universities.

At the same time, he said, if Taiwan can help China develop into a more civilized society with improved human rights, the efforts "will win Taiwanese people goodwill and a favorable impression from the Chinese people."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. governor bows to Chinese pressure, cancels Taiwan trip: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 20:22:22 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Missouri Governor Jay Nixon acknowledged Friday that he canceled his trip to Taiwan over concerns that it would impact his state's relations with China, U.S. media reported.

Nixon was scheduled to lead a trade mission from Dec. 10-16 to Taiwan and South Korea. In Taiwan, he was expected to sign a letter of intent under which Taiwanese businesses would commit to purchasing US$600 million of Missouri products, including corn and soybeans, according to a Dec. 1 statement from Nixon's office.
Nixon was also scheduled to meet President Ma Ying-jeou and Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang during his planned stay, the statement said.

The governor was cited by an AP report as saying Thursday U.S. time that the trip was canceled because it could affect Missouri's efforts to make Lambert-St. Louis International Airport a trade hub for Chinese goods.
The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported Friday that Nixon was forced to cancel the mission last week due to pressure from the Midwest China Hub Commission and the Chinese consulate.
Nixon described his dilemma at a Thursday press conference.

"Leading a delegation of this magnitude, a foreign mission with a number of factors coming into play...as we continue to assess those factors, I just determined it wasn't an optimal time to do that, " Nixon said, according to a St. Louis Public Radio transcript.
The governor said he still planned to reschedule the visit and did not believe that the cancellation had "killed the deal."

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman James Chang told the Central News Agency on Friday that the governor's office expressed gratitude to Taiwan for its assistance in arranging the visit and said the governor could not make the trip due to "other business.".

According to Chang, the governor's office did not mention anything about China in notifying Taiwan that the trip had been canceled. Chang said the MOFA is looking into the matter and has been trying to gather more information.
Nixon's office said previously that Taiwanese businesses had expressed an interest in purchasing an average of US$120 million in Missouri goods per year over the next five years.
Missouri exports to Taiwan totaled US$69.1 million in 2009, and initial projections through the third quarter of 2010 indicated an increase of about 28 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Descendant of ROC founding father's close friend to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec, 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 20:55:01 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A descendant of a close friend of Sun Yat-sen, the Republic of China's founding father, will arrive in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day visit, sources confirmed Friday.

The sources, from the East Asia Relations Commission, said Ayano Kosaka, the great-granddaughter of Umeya Shokichi (1868-1934) , who forged close relations with Sun and provided generous funding during the latter's uprising against the Qing dynasty in the early 20th century, will mainly visit historic places related to Sun.
She will visit the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial House, the Presidential Office, the Taipei Guest House, the National Palace Museum and the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.

When King Pu-tsung, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), visited Japan in September, he called on Kosaka and reviewed many valuable historical documents related to the profound relationship between Sun and her great- grandfather.
King said at the time that he "was deeply moved" by the close friendship between the two men and that he invited Kosaka to visit Taiwan.

The sources said that Kosaka has not ruled out the possibility of a reciprocal visit to King. As the KMT Party Records Archives house many artifacts related to Sun, it could be a place that she would like to visit, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai chairman protests Chimei Innolux fines (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 21:49:25 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Terry Gou, the chairman of Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., strongly protested on Friday the 300 million euro fine slapped on Hon Hai's flat panel subsidiary Chimei Innolux Corp. by the European Commission.

After a two-hour meeting with Taipei-based European trade officials, Gou told reporters that Chimei Innolux would wait until it received formal notification of the fine before deciding whether to file an appeal.
"We will not easily pay the money that we shouldn't have to pay in the first place, " he said. "For our shareholders, we must fight (for our rights) to the end," he added.
The European Commission, the European Union's top decision-maker, fined five flat panel makers a total of 649 million euros on Wednesday for acting as a price-fixing cartel from 2001 to 2006.

Chimei Innolux was fined 300 million euros (US$397.76 million) , the most of any of the five companies, which also included AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp from Taiwan and LG Display South Korea.

Gou's company is being disciplined for actions taken by Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., which was not part of the Hon Hai Group before merging with Innolux Display Corp. in March to form Chimei Innolux.
Standing next to Chimei Innolux Chairman Frank Liao at the press conference on Friday, Gou complained that the company had yet to receive any written notification from Europe of its decision.
"This goes against common legal practice, " he said. "This has compromised the rights of (Chimei Innolux) shareholders."
The head of the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer urged the commission to explain how it figured its fines.
Gou wondered how the company could be hit with the heaviest penalty when Chi Mei Optoelectronics did not have the biggest output during the period.

He suggested that in calculating the fines, the European Commission seemed to have also included the number of flat panels the company sold to Samsung Electronics Inc. and LG, which Gou said would not be acceptable.
In addition, the European Union failed to inform Chimei Innolux of possible fines when it gave its nod to the merger of Chi Mei Optoelectronics and Innolux Display, he complained.

Gou also criticized the commission for not fining Samsung, the world's largest flat panel maker. Samsung was not charged or disciplined because it blew the whistle on the price-fixing arrangement to the European Commission.
The European Commission fined LG 215 million euros, AUO 117 million euros, Chunghwa 9 million euros, and HannStar 8 million euros in the price-fixing case.
Gou said he was not aware of any meetings between Samsung and Taiwanese flat panel makers that resulted in the alleged price-fixing.
But had there been such collusion, Gou believed Samsung could have played a bigger role than the Taiwanese companies in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: New health insurance reform bill to be unveiled next week: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:08:54 (By Chen Ching-fang, Ho Meng-kuei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: No decision has been made on how national health insurance premiums should be calculated in the future as the Department of Health (DOH) is still working on a new version of the reform plan, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative whip said Friday.

Major local newspapers reported Friday that the Executive Yuan and the KMT legislative caucus decided late Thursday to backpedal on a proposed second- generation health insurance reform plan, but Legislator Lin Yi-shih, who also heads the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said the reports missed the mark.
"What the media reports reflected were only our lawmakers' personal opinions and will not necessarily be incorporated into the final version that the DOH is still putting together," Lin said.
The KMT legislative caucus only pushed the DOH to be more inclusive and refer to opinions expressed by various social sectors when revising the reform package, Lin said.

According to the reports, Premier Wu Den-yih chaired a meeting of health and finance officials and KMT lawmakers Thursday night to forge a consensus on the national health insurance (NHI) reform plan.

The meeting came after the DOH-drafted package of amendments to the National Health Insurance Act that would have overhauled how the NHI system gets its revenues failed to clear the legislative floor Tuesday.

The reports said Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang had agreed to scrap the DOH's widely trumpeted plan to calculate health insurance premiums on the basis of overall household income in order to win legislative support for the reform of the debt-laden NHI system.

At the insistence of KMT legislators, it was decided at the meeting that health premiums would still be calculated based on regular salaries of the insured, as is the case at present, but that high earning individuals would be required to pay higher premiums under the revised system, the reports said.
Lin said the DOH is expected to come up with an improved amendment package next week for discussion among KMT legislators.
"Once we reach an internal consensus, we will begin consultations with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus, " Lin said.
He added that the KMT would not set Dec. 14 as a deadline to pass the legislation, countering speculation in local newspapers.

DPP Legislator Liu Chien-kuo said that if the KMT administration indeed reversed its NHI reform plan overnight, Premier Wu and Minister Yaung should step down to assume political responsibility for the policy flip-flop.
"The DOH has spent eight years working on the reform package. How could it backpedal on its own plan under pressure from KMT lawmakers," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Private sector investment surges in 2010: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:09:22 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of investment projects launched by Taiwan's private sector surged in the first 11 months of the year, with the committed investment value reaching 90 percent of the annual target, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.

The number of approved new private sector investment projects totaled 2,078 from January to November and were worth NT$930.5 billion (US$31 billion) , 88.86 percent of the target set by the government for the sector for 2010, according to the latest MOEA statistics.
The amount was NT$79.3 billion more than at the end of October and represented an increase of 29.58 percent year-on-year.
Projects launched by electronics and information technology (IT) manufacturers topped the list with investments worth NT$399.8 billion, according to the ministry.
Meanwhile, the government approved 1,841 direct investment projects in Taiwan proposed by foreign individuals or companies in the first 11 months of the year worth US$3.332 billion.
The volume was up 27.67 percent year-on-year but their value was down 20.01 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO yet to decide on whether to sell Tata cars in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:18:30 (By Maranda Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's TECO Group on Friday publicly displayed two Tata cars that it imported from India Friday, but declined to say whether it will formally distribute what some describe as the world's cheapest car in Taiwan.
Theodore Huang, chairman of the group known for its industrial motors and home appliances, gave the two Tatas to TECO Electric and Machinery Co. for further study.
In introducing the 700 c.c. Tatas, Huang said the mini car accelerated smoothly and could exceed speeds of 105 kilometers per hour.
With a price tag of roughly between US$2,000 and US$3,000, he described it as being particularly suitable for young men and women in Taiwan, adding that "it's at least safer than motorcycles."
It is believed that the TECO Group is not in a hurry to become Tata Motors' sole agent in Taiwan because the mini cars' specifications do not conform to Taiwan's regulations and requirements.
Meanwhile, C.K. Liu, chairman of TECO Electric and Machinery Co., said his company will probably cooperate with Tata Motors in developing motors for vehicles.
Liu said the Tata cars offer the world innovative and inspiring ideas on how vehicles will look and be built in the future.
TECO, which is currently developing wheel hub motors for electric vehicles, will probably pick up some ideas from the Tata cars, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President marks Human Rights Day with new committee and exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:44:25 (By Lee Shu-hua, Garfie Li, and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou apologized to victims of the White Terror era on International Human Rights Day Friday and promised that the government would continue to protect human rights and would never allow a similar tragedy to happen again.

"I fully understand the suffering of the victims of the families. If I were them, I would not have peace and calm, " he said while speaking at a special exhibition at the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial and Cultural Park.
He was met there with several angry protesters who shouted at him and called him a "perpetrator."

The exhibition held at the former prison features the life and works of the victims, who were subject to purges, imprisonment, executions and repression by the authoritarian Kuomintang government from 1949 to 1987, before martial law was lifted.

The president said the government had realized the mistakes it had made in the past, and had offered compensation, restored the victims' reputations, and created a national holiday to recognize them, and he hoped the victims' families would feel its sincerity.
"However, we cannot just look back at history. We have to look ahead," the president said.

Ma said earlier the same day that the government had launched a Presidential Committee on Human Rights led by Vice President Vincent Siew and Chai Sung-lin, honorary president of the Taipei-based Chinese Association for Human Rights.

The committee is comprised of 18 people, including Siew, Vice Premier Sean Chen, Judicial Yuan Vice Minister Su Yung-chin, Control Yuan Vice Minister Chen Chin- li, and 14 people from the private sector.

The human rights committee will propose a report on the country's human rights condition every year, and will review whether the government has fully practiced the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, according to Siew.

"Power corrupts; absolute power corrupts absolutely, " Ma said. "From the history of human rights development, we know it is always the government that tramples on the rights of its people, so we have to be extremely careful."

DOC.HEADLINE: Memorial park for diva to be located in Jinshan Township
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:58:30 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government and the Teresa Teng Foundation agreed on Thursday to build a memorial park dedicated to the late super diva Teresa Teng in Jinshan Township.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and foundation Chairman Frank Teng, one of the singer's brothers, signed a contract to locate the facility on a 1.5-hectare plot adjacent to the Jinshan Hot Springs Education Center -- a 10-minute drive from Teng's tomb.
Taipei County will earmark NT$120 million (US$3.93 million) to build the memorial park, which is projected to be completed in 2013.

Among the exhibits on the grounds will be a building modeled after Teng's private residence in Hong Kong that will be open to the public, allowing visitors to have a touch of Teng in a unique ambiance.
It is expected to include many of her personal belongings and effects, including stage costumes, jewelry, written notes and furniture.

Chou expressed the hope that the park could help preserve cultural assets and become a major tourism attraction to lure more visitors to Taipei County, which will be upgraded to a special municipality and renamed Xinbei City on Dec. 25.
Teng was born on Jan. 29, 1953 in central Taiwan's Yunlin County and died in 1995 from a severe respiratory attack while vacationing in Thailand. She was 42.

Teng's romantic songs and ballads were extremely popular among Chinese around the world, including even in China at a time when it was closed off to much of the world, making her the most representative symbol of Chinese-language pop music.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO yet to decide on whether to sell Tata cars in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:18:30 (By Maranda Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's TECO Group on Friday publicly displayed two Tata cars that it imported from India Friday, but declined to say whether it will formally distribute what some describe as the world's cheapest car in Taiwan.
Theodore Huang, chairman of the group known for its industrial motors and home appliances, gave the two Tatas to TECO Electric and Machinery Co. for further study.
In introducing the 700 c.c. Tatas, Huang said the mini car accelerated smoothly and could exceed speeds of 105 kilometers per hour.
With a price tag of roughly between US$2,000 and US$3,000, he described it as being particularly suitable for young men and women in Taiwan, adding that "it's at least safer than motorcycles."
It is believed that the TECO Group is not in a hurry to become Tata Motors' sole agent in Taiwan because the mini cars' specifications do not conform to Taiwan's regulations and requirements.
Meanwhile, C.K. Liu, chairman of TECO Electric and Machinery Co., said his company will probably cooperate with Tata Motors in developing motors for vehicles.
Liu said the Tata cars offer the world innovative and inspiring ideas on how vehicles will look and be built in the future.
TECO, which is currently developing wheel hub motors for electric vehicles, will probably pick up some ideas from the Tata cars, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President marks Human Rights Day with new committee and exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/10 22:44:25 (By Lee Shu-hua, Garfie Li, and Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou apologized to victims of the White Terror era on International Human Rights Day Friday and promised that the government would continue to protect human rights and would never allow a similar tragedy to happen again.

"I fully understand the suffering of the victims of the families. If I were them, I would not have peace and calm, " he said while speaking at a special exhibition at the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial and Cultural Park.
He was met there with several angry protesters who shouted at him and called him a "perpetrator."

The exhibition held at the former prison features the life and works of the victims, who were subject to purges, imprisonment, executions and repression by the authoritarian Kuomintang government from 1949 to 1987, before martial law was lifted.

The president said the government had realized the mistakes it had made in the past, and had offered compensation, restored the victims' reputations, and created a national holiday to recognize them, and he hoped the victims' families would feel its sincerity.
"However, we cannot just look back at history. We have to look ahead," the president said.

Ma said earlier the same day that the government had launched a Presidential Committee on Human Rights led by Vice President Vincent Siew and Chai Sung-lin, honorary president of the Taipei-based Chinese Association for Human Rights.

The committee is comprised of 18 people, including Siew, Vice Premier Sean Chen, Judicial Yuan Vice Minister Su Yung-chin, Control Yuan Vice Minister Chen Chin- li, and 14 people from the private sector.

The human rights committee will propose a report on the country's human rights condition every year, and will review whether the government has fully practiced the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, according to Siew.

"Power corrupts; absolute power corrupts absolutely, " Ma said. "From the history of human rights development, we know it is always the government that tramples on the rights of its people, so we have to be extremely careful."
