DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 11, 2010, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan- chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Don't be self-righteous
DOC.DATELINE: 12/11/10 13:11:00 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 11, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Control Yuan President Wang Chien-shien recently directed criticism at undergraduates who work, saying that these students are "really stupid" for wasting the gold period of their life on something that is "not cost-efficient."
The remark drew a backlash from labor groups because he seemed unaware of the suffering of common people and was unable to understand the financial restrictions faced by children from poor families.
Still, we think there is a bigger problem with his remark. His way of thinking reflects a lack of imagination, understanding, tolerance and appreciation for the differences between people.

This is reminiscent of comments made earlier this year by neurology professor Daisy Hung criticizing National Taiwan University students who ate and text- messaged in class, and National Chi Nan University President Lee Chia-tung's criticism a few months ago of elementary students who "waste their time" reading comics.

Wang, Hung and Lee are successful opinion leaders. But we should not forget that in every society, there are people who are not as sensible and persevering as they are and who occasionally want to relax.

Wang's statement deserves more comment than those of Hung and Lee because Wang is not a professor. As the head of the government branch monitoring the behavior of civil servants, Wang should make better use of time doing his job instead of criticizing undergraduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A costly lesson

TEXT.P: The European Union recently slapped fines totaling 649 million euros (US$860 million) on four Taiwanese and one South Korean flat panel maker for acting as a price-fixing cartel from 2001 to 2006. Samsung Electronics Co. of South Korea, which blew the whistle on the arrangement, was not charged or disciplined.

The lenient treatment of Samsung has diverted the focus on the case to the company's whistle-blowing behavior. Sharing in the indignation of the flat panel makers, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials vowed to get even with Samsung.

But we must remind the government that the case had been under investigation for four years. During this period, did the government look into the interaction between Taiwanese and South Korean flat panel makers and seek countermeasures? Is the government sure that the manufacturers did not engage in price fixing practices?

Maintaining an environment for fair trading and competition is the cornerstone of a market economy. Neither the government nor the business sector should take the issue lightly. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Chimei Innolux given stiff fine for not cooperating with probe: EU
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 15:30:33 (By Yu-fan Tsao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chimei Innolux Corp. was given a heavy fine by the European Commission for allegedly fixing the price of flat panels because it opted not to cooperate with European authorities in its investigation into the case, a European Union (EU) official said Saturday.

Chimei Innolux was one of five companies fined a total of 649 million euros by the European Commission on Wednesday for operating a cartel that colluded on flat panel prices between Oct. 5, 2001 and Feb. 1, 2006.

Though the company, then known as Chi Mei Optoelectronics, had a lower market share than South Korea rivals LG Display and Samsung Electronics during the period, its 300 million euro fine was the highest among the companies involved in the alleged conspiracy.
LG Display was fined 215 million euros while Samsung, the world's biggest flat panel maker, was not disciplined because it reported the price collusion activities to European authorities.

"Their fine is lower than that of Chimei Innolux because both Samsung Electronics and LG Display have cooperated with the Commission investigation under the Commission's Leniency Notice, " European Commission Competition Policy spokeswoman Amelia Torres wrote in an e-mail to the Central News Agency.
Chimei Innolux also had this option but decided not to avail itself of it, Torres said.

"Chi Mei Optoelectronics had all possibilities to blow the whistle itself between October 2001 when the cartel started until March 2006 when Samsung blew the whistle. If it had done so, it would have received no fine," she said.
Torres added that Chi Mei could have cooperated with the European Commission after March 2006 to obtain a reduction of its fine, but "it has chosen not to do so."
Chimei Innolux did not immediately respond to Torres comments.

Terry Gou, the chairman of Chimei Innolux's parent company, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., strongly protested the fine on Friday, saying his company would not pay money it should not have to pay and questioning why its fine was out of proportion to its market share.

Gou, who was drawn into the case after Hon Hai's Innolux Display Corp. formally merged with Chi Mei Optoelectronics in March of this year, also complained that the company had yet to receive formal notification of how the European Commission calculated the fine.

Torres acknowledged that the full text of the decision with all the reasoning had yet to be sent, but she called it standard procedure and said it would be forwarded to the company in the coming days.

"The company's lawyers were informed one week before of the likely date of the Commission decision, " Torres said. "The full text of the 140 pages long decision will contain a full explanation on how the fines were calculated."
Gou said Chimei Innolux would wait for the document before deciding whether to appeal the case. Regardless of what the company decides, it will have three months to respond.

"Chimei Innolux has three months after the notification of the decision to either pay the fine or, in case the company would appeal, to provide for a bank guarantee or a provisional payment," Torres said.
Gou also said Friday that he was not aware of any meetings between Samsung and Taiwanese flat panel makers that resulted in price collusion.

But Torres made it clear that the European Commission was accusing Chi Mei Optoelectronics staff rather than Gou of having knowledge of the cartel meetings and the price fixing that allegedly occurred.

Aside from Chimei Innolux, three other Taiwanese manufacturers were fined in the case. AU Optronics was fined 117 million euros, Chunghwa Picture Tubes was fined 9 million euros, and HannStar Display was fined 8 million euros.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Hon Hai head protests price-fixing fine
DOC.DATELINE: 12/11/10 15:49:03 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Terry Gou, chairman of the Taiwan-based Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, strongly protested on Friday a 300 million euro (US$397 million) fine slapped on the company's flat panel manufacturing subsidiary Chimei Innolux Corp. by the European Commission.
"We will not easily pay the money that we should not have to pay in the first place, " Gou said after a meeting with Taipei-based European trade officials.

Gou paid the visit to the European Union representative office in Taiwan along with Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiu and Chimei Innolux Chairman Frank Liao, after the European Union's top decision maker fined five manufacturers a total of 649 million euros on Wednesday for price collusion from 2001 to 2006.
In addition to Chimei Innolux, AU Optronics Crop. (AUO), Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. from Taiwan, as well as LG Display from South Korea were also fined.

At a press conference following the Friday meeting, Gou questioned why Chimei Innolux could be hit with the heaviest penalty when its output during the period in question was not as big as that of some of the other companies.
The European Commission fined LG Display 215 million euros, AUO 117 million euros, Chunghwa 9 million euros and HannStar 8 million euros.
Samsung, the world's largest flat panel maker, was not charged or disciplined because it blew the whistle on the price-fixing arrangement to the European Commission.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:
Gou blasted Samsung of South Korea for being a "whistle blower" in the case and accused it of masterminding the price-fixing operations.
He questioned the fairness of the disciplinary action, when Samsung, whom he described as a repeated price-fixing offender, was not punished in the case because it turned itself in.
"It is an economic war between Taiwan and South Korea, Gou said.

"They have (Korean companies) used every means to kill us, but Taiwan cannot go without a flat panel industry, " he said, complaining that the government has not only ignored the battle, but even stands in the way of local flat panel producers' plans to invest in China.
Gou criticized the government's restrictions on the island's panel manufacturing industry, which he said has caused them to lose market share in China to South Korean competitors.
He said he understood that the technology needed to be kept in Taiwan, but the rising trend of environmental protection and capital funding problems were challenging local businesses.

The industry must be located where markets exist to keep its competitiveness sharp, Gou said, referring to the reluctance of the government to pass an investment project proposed by AUO to build flat panel plants in China. (Dec. 11, 2010).
Commercial Times:
The Hon Hai leader issued a six-point statement Friday, in which he questioned how the European Commission calculated its fine on Chimei Innolux, of which Gou said he is the largest shareholder.
Gou wondered why Chimei Innolux drew the biggest fine of the companies involved even though it did not have the biggest market share during the period in question.

He also questioned the legality of the procedure involved in imposing the fine because the company had yet to receive written notification from Europe of its decision, and he complained of the lighter penalty imposed on South Korean manufacturers even though they were the biggest players in the market.

In response to the penalty on AUO, one of Taiwan's largest panel producers, AUO Chairman K.Y. Lee said Friday that his company would do everything it could to fight against the unreasonable treatment.
The case has raised an outcry from local flat panel business, who claim it was South Korean companies that convened the so-called cartel meetings to discuss pricing issues.

Now they have offered United States and European authorities data and information produced in those meetings to burn their competitors, which local manufacturers branded as a "mean" tactic. (Dec. 11, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
Terry Gou, head of the Hon Hai Group, urged the government to fight together with the industrial sector, for the country's economic interests.
He also called for the government to accelerate procedures to allow panel producers to establish a bigger presence in China. "Don't let them die here," he said.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs unveiled a 10-year program on Friday to help promote the development of the flat panel sector, including pushing for zero- tariff treatment for Taiwanese panel exports to China. (Dec. 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 'golden pair' makes Hong Kong Badminton Open final
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 16:05:46 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cheng Wen-hsing and Chien Yu-chin, the world's top-ranked women's doubles badminton team, beat a Russian duo Saturday to advance to the women's doubles finals of the Yonex-Sunrise Hong Kong Open Super Series 2010.
The top-seeded pair rallied from a set down to pull off an 18-21, 21-12, 21-13 win against third seeds Valeria Sorokina and Nina Vislova at Queen Elizabeth Stadium.
Cheng and Chien will meet the winner of the other semifinal being played Saturday night -- an all-Chinese battle pitting Pan Pan and Tian Qing against Wang Xiaoli and Yu Yang -- in Sunday's final.
Chien was also to team with Lee Sheng-mu in the mixed doubles semifinal to be played later Saturday against fifth seeds Zhang Nan and Zhao Yunlei of China.
The "golden pair" regained the top spot in the Badminton World Federation (BWF) women's doubles ranking in early October, the first time they were ranked first in the world since January 2008.
The Hong Kong Open is the last of the 12-tournament Super Series, which compiles a separate Super Series Standings. Cheng and Chien are currently also ranked first in Super Series women's doubles.
The top eight men's and women's singles, doubles and mixed doubles players and teams will be invited to compete in the BWF Super Series Finals 2010, which will be held in Taipei Jan. 5-9, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reported cases of child abuse up 40% in first half of 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 16:39:55 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The number of suspected child abuse cases reported to authorities rose dramatically in the first half of 2010 compared to a year earlier, indicating increased awareness in society on the issue, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Saturday.

A total of 13,130 cases were reported from January to June, 40.4 percent more than during the same period in 2009, and 9,039 of those cases, an increase of 39.77 percent, were confirmed, according to MOI statistics.
Those aged 6-11 accounted for 3,305, or 36.56 percent, of the victims, and those aged 0-5 accounted for 2,262, or 25.03 percent.
On the background of the abusers, 6,512, or 75.02 percent, were the victims' parents or foster parents.

The number of abusers who were live-in partners of one of the parents was up 49.3 percent from last year to reach 212, while the number of abusers who were relatives of the victims but not their parents jumped 42.11 percent to 459.

According to the MOI, people have developed higher sensitivity and paid greater attention to the issue of child abuse following the death of a 13-year-old girl in a filicide-suicide case in April in Taichung County.
Before the tragedy occurred, the sixth grader had told her teachers that her mother was preparing to commit suicide by burning charcoal.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes for improved ROC visibility in centennial year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 17:32:53 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the Republic of China has created political and economic miracles in Taiwan over the past 60 years and is set to play a bigger role on various fronts to further expand its global visibility.

"As the country gets set to embrace its 100th birthday next year, we hope it will display even more charm to the rest of the world through a series of diverse and touching performances and exhibitions that will kick off on Dec. 31, " Ma said when addressing the preparatory committee for the celebration of the ROC's 100th founding anniversary.

"After having walked a long path of calamity and hardship, Taiwan has successfully evolved into a prosperous and stable state, where freedom of speech and cultural, democratic and technological development has taken root, " Ma said.
He added that after receiving the help of the international community for many years, the country is now spreading love to others, providing assistance to many nations around the world.
Looking to the future, the ROC will do its utmost to be a peacemaker, provider of humanitarian aid, promoter of culture, and creator of new technology and commercial opportunity, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan continues to help Vietnam reduce digital gap
DOC.DATELINE: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 18:05:07 (By Tony Fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has increased efforts to help Vietnam improve its digital capability by setting up more digital opportunity centers in the country under the auspices of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Taiwan's de facto ambassador to Vietnam, Huang Chih-peng, presided over a ceremony in Ho Chi Minh City on Friday to open three new APEC Digital Opportunity Centers (ADOCs) in southern Vietnam.
A fourth new ADOC will be opened in Lam Dong Province on Dec. 13, said officials with Taiwan's representative office in Vietnam.

Since the Taiwan-initiated ADOC program, aimed at reducing the digital gap between developed and developing APEC members, began in Vietnam in 2005, Taiwan had opened nine ADOCs in the Southeast Asian country by the end of last year with the cooperation of Vietnam's government.

Encouraged by the successful operation of the facilities, which are all equipped with computers and teaching manuals, the ADOC program decided to inject more resources into the country, the office said.
At Friday's ceremony, Huang said the ADOC program was formed to help improve developing APEC members' data processing and applications capability.
He said Taiwan was willing to help others as long as it was within its capability, he said.
"The ADOC program is Taiwan's realization of its promise, " Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese runners highlight Taiwan's 24-hour ultramarathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 18:07:43 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Japanese runners Ryochi Sekiya and Mami Kudo were both determined to win the 2010 Soochow International 24-hour ultramarathon for good reason when the competition started at 9 a.m. Saturday in suburban Taipei.

Kudo hoped that by the time the race ends on 9 a.m. Sunday, she will have surpassed her own world record of 254.425 kilometers, set in the Taiwan event last year, while Sekiya was aiming for his sixth men's title in Taipei.

Sekiya and Kudo were among 30 runners from around the world participating in the unusual race, a competition organized by Soochow University (SCU) in which all participants run as far as they can over the 24-hour period on the school's 200 meter track.
Whoever runs the farthest is named the winner.

Kudo, 46, won the race last year and set the women's 24-hour marathon world record. She will face a tough challenge from 39-year-old French rival Anne- Celile Fontaine, who has a personal best of 243.644 km.
With a personal best of 274.884 km that outshines his challengers, 43-year- old Sekiya was favored to capture the men's title again.
Martin Fryer of Australia, Ulrich Gross of Italy, Kenji Okiyama of Japan, Lee Dong-mun of South Korea and Taiwan's Chen Chin-tsai were expected to put up a good fight in the men's group.
In addition to the 24-hour competition, competitions in other categories, including the 12-hour competition, the 10-km challenge and half marathon relay, were also being held at the annual event.
The competition, which is celebrating its 10th edition, was first held in 1999 and has been awarded a silver IAU (International Association of Ultrarunners) label.
If five male or female runners surpass minimum distance requirements -- 240 km for men and 220 km for women -- in the same race, the competition will be awarded a gold label, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34% of this year's graduates have yet to find jobs: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 18:12:05 (By Hsieh Jiun-wei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Despite a recent drop in Taiwan's unemployment rate, a high percentage of new graduates have not found their first full-time jobs, according to the results of a survey released Saturday by an online employment broker.
The survey by the 1111 Job Bank found that 33.8 percent of those graduating from university this past summer remained jobless six month after their graduation.
The ratio was higher than the 23.5 percent recorded at the same time in 2009, but lower than the 45 percent in 2008 -- when the global financial crisis erupted.
This indicates that this year's graduates have not benefited from the employment promotion measures launched by the government in 2009, the broker said.
Also, the average job-seeking period among new graduates reached 42 days this year, longer than the average of 36 days in 2009 and 39 days in 2008.
This may be because the new graduates have a lower sense of crisis following the recovery of the economy and the employment market, the company said.
Among those new graduates who have landed jobs, their starting salary averaged NT$27,428, higher than the NT$24,358 in 2009 and NT$25,726 in 2008.
The survey was conducted between Nov. 23 and Dec. 7 on 1,216 graduates. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.81 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIFA, filing taxes top Google most searched list in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 19:15:29 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: "FIFA" and "filing taxes" were the two most searched phrases on Google Inc.'s most searched query list in Taiwan this year, according to Google's Taiwan branch.
The "five special municipality elections, " which were held Nov. 27, "typhoon," and "Flora Expo," an ongoing event in Taipei, rounded out the top five.

The bottom five in the top 10 were transgender model "Alicia Liu, " singer "Lin Yu-chun, " Chinese beggar "Brother Sharp, " the "Asian Games, " and controversial English teacher "Carrie Chen, " Google Taiwan said in a statement on Friday.
Of the top 10, only "FIFA" was searched for in English.
Meanwhile, Google produced another list solely featuring the search queries of smartphone users in Taiwan for the first time.
The new list reflected the growing popularity of smartphones in the country. In contrast to the overall search, only two of the top 10 most popular search queries from smartphones were in Chinese.
"FIFA" placed second behind "HTC, " and was followed by "CNN, " "MLB (Major League Baseball), " "Yahoo, " "Facebook," and "iPhone."

The first Chinese-language query on the smartphone list -- "desktop wallpaper" -- ranked eighth, ahead of "NBA" (National Basketball Association) , and the other Chinese-language entry, "Girls' Generation, " a nine-member girl pop group from South Korea.
These results, Google Taiwan said, showed the effectiveness of online advertising and users' interest in getting real-time scores from big sports events.

The top 10 brand search queries overall were "iPad, " "Google, " "iPhone," "Facebook," "Yahoo," "MSN, " "HTC, " "YouTube," "Tsann Kuen Enterprise Co. (a local electronics retailer) " and "7-Eleven (Taiwan's largest convenience chain store)."
All but Tsann Kuen were entered in English.

The top 10 movies searched by general users on Google in 2010 were "Inception, " "Monga (the Taiwanese gangster movie) , " local climate change documentary "Plus/minus 2 degrees C -- the Truth Formosa Must Face," "Kick-Ass, ""Skyline, " "Aftershock, " "The Hurt Locker, ""Seven Days in Heaven, " "Alice in Wonderland" and "Shutter Island."

For smartphone users, the top 10 most searched films were "Iron Man 2, " "Inception, " "Twilight, " "Monga, " "Toy Story 3, " "Ip Man 2, " "Skyline, " "Alice in Wonderland, " "14 Blades" and "A-Team."
Movie names on both lists were all entered in Chinese.

Google found that the smartphone search keywords better matched Taiwan's top 10 movie list for the year than the general search queries did, as people often search for information about movies just before they go see them at a theater.
Only three movies in the general search list were among Taiwan's top 10 box office successes, compared with eight movies on the smartphone search list, according to Google Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan emerges as top winner in Junior Science Olympiad
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 19:23:55 (By Lee Shien-feng and Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's delegation emerged as the top winner at the seventh International Junior Science Olympiad (IJSO) , capturing a total of four gold medals and two silver medals and the highest accumulated score, the Ministry of Education said in a statement Saturday.
Taiwan was given "the country winner" award for its outstanding performance at the Olympiad in Nigeria, beating out 34 other participating countries, the ministry said.
A total of 180 students aged 15 or younger took part in this year's competition.

Among the six Taiwanese participants, Huang Kai-chi, now in his first year at Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School, collected the most awards. He won a gold medal, "the best theory winner" award, and "the overall winner" award.

Although Huang did not begin to receive training in science until his second year in junior high school, he has shown perseverance in subjects that interest him, said delegation head Lo Pei-hua, an associate researcher in National Taiwan Normal University's Science Education Center.
The IJSO, which test young students in physics, biology, chemistry, and other disciplines, is an annual individual and team competition in natural sciences.
Its aim is to promote the pursuit of excellence in science and stimulate gifted students to develop their interests.

Taiwan has participated in the competition since 2004 and has so far collected a total of 35 golds, seven silvers, and a bronze in the laboratory skills category, six "best theory winner" awards, three "overall winner" awards, and three "country winner" awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sound and history come together in new exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 20:32:23 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of sounds currently being held at the National Taiwan Museum will bring some of the Republic of China's most popular, familiar and forgotten sounds from the last 100 years back on center stage, the event's organizer said Saturday.

Hosted by Radio Taiwan International (RTI), the country's oldest radio broadcasting company, the exhibition titled "100 years of Sounds -- Listening to ROC History" is a collection of recordings that serve to keep the history alive in the minds of Taiwan's people, RTI Chairperson Sunshine Kuang said at the opening ceremony.
The Republic of China was formally established on Jan. 1, 1912 following the fall of the Qing dynasty and encompassed mainland China until 1949.
After losing a civil war to the Communists that year, Chiang Kai-shek and his Kuomintang forces retreated to Taiwan where the ROC has continued to exist.

Recordings of political leaders such as the country's founding father Sun Yat- sen in 1924, late President Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, and interviews with prominent individuals in the fields of economics, education and the arts are covered in the exhibition.

Fan Hsiang-lin, RTI vice president, said the display even included a New Year's talk by Chiang Ching-kuo, recorded on Oct. 20, 1987, that was never made public because Chiang passed away on Jan. 13, 1988 before the arrival of the Lunar New Year.

The exhibition also covers recordings of Taiwan's famous singers, from the early days to more recent years. The voices of Jan Hsiao-lin, Teresa Teng, Louise Tsui, Hong Yi-fong, Kimbo Hu, and A-mei can be heard on the spot.

Recordings of the distinct sounds of some of Taiwan's public transportation systems -- announcements made in MRT stations, the sounds of Alishan's mountain train, a ferry horn in Keelung harbor, and jet skis in Penghu -- are also featured.
Attending the opening ceremony, President Ma Ying-jeou said he was very moved by Sun's talk, and he expressed the hope that the voices of history could be preserved forever.
Asked about the most unforgettable sounds in his life, Ma said he missed the voices of street vendors in the old days.
The sound exhibition will run through Mar. 13, 2011 in Taipei and then tour Tainan, Taichung, Chiayi, and Yilan until Dec. 18, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government preparing to embrace ROC's 100th anniversary
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 21:43:07 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government is gearing up for the arrival of the Republic of China's 100th founding anniversary when the new year kicks in, as a preparatory committee has planned diverse celebration activities across Taiwan.
The first in a string of activities will kick off on Dec. 31 at Dajia Riverbank Park in Taipei City, where a large-scale three-dimensional New Year's Eve countdown will be held.

The year-long celebration will come to a conclusion on Dec. 31, 2011, when 1 million cyclists start riding simultaneously in a clockwise direction from 10 points around the country, according to the committee, which held its third meeting on Saturday.

Vice President Vincent Siew, who heads the preparatory committee, said the year- long celebration is aimed at making Taiwan more visible around the world, cementing national unity and forging harmony in society.

Siew proposed that the four venues of the 2010 Taipei International Flora Exposition being held in Taipei until April 25, 2011 be preserved for one more year to give Taiwan's people more of a chance to visit them.
Prominent events will also be held throughout the year in other parts of Taiwan to promote Taiwan's visibility in the international arena, the vice president added.

Reporting on the same occasion, Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng said a peace ceremony will be held on Aug. 23 on the outlying Kinmen Island to commemorate the 823 Artillery Bombardment that was launched by the Chinese communists in 1958.
On Oct. 10 National Day, an evening party will be organized in central Taiwan's Taichung City to mark the ROC's centennial anniversary.

To give people a clearer picture of the scope of the centennial festivities, Sheng said a virtual "Taiwan museum" has been set up on the Internet that introduces the individual celebration activities.
People interested in obtaining related information about the centennial celebration can log on to the official website -- taiwanroc100.tw -- beginning on Dec. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law needs to be revised if tobacco surcharge to rise: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 22:01:49 (By Chen Ching-fang, Wang Hung-kuo and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Raising the surcharge on cigarettes to generate revenue for the financially ailing national health insurance (NHI) system, as some have proposed, could only be done if the law is revised, a Department of Health official said Saturday.

An amendment to the Tobacco Hazard Prevention Act would have to be proposed and passed if the government wanted to adjust the tobacco health and welfare surcharge higher, said Chiou Shu-ti, director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.
The DOH doubled the tobacco health surcharge to NT$20 (US$0.66) per pack of cigarettes last year by going through that process, she said.

Chiou was responding to a suggestion made earlier in the day by Vice Premier Sean Chen, who believed that increasing the tobacco surcharge would be the best option to bridge the health insurance system's deficits if expanding premium revenues did not fully cover them.

Although the law stipulates that the surcharge can be reviewed every two years and allows it to be raised further, Chiou said she believed another hike would still not be enough to free the health insurance system from its financial woes.

Raising the surcharge again would not necessarily mean that the NHI's revenue would continue to grow, Chiou said, because the resulting higher prices of cigarettes could reduce the smoking population and revenue base.
According to the DOH, the Bureau of National Health Insurance had an accumulated deficit of approximately NT$53.3 billion as of the end of August.

Most of the compulsory system's revenue comes from insurance premiums, but it has also drawn funds from the tobacco surcharge, which raised NT$36 billion a year after the surcharge hike took effect in June 2009, nearly double the NT$20 billion a year it raised previously.
The NHI system received 70 percent of the revenue, or about NT$25 billion, this year to help fund its operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government mulling response to EU fine on local panel makers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 22:09:26 (By Lin Hui-chun, Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will call a meeting next week to discuss how to respond to heavy fines imposed by the European Union on four local flat panel makers for alleged price fixing, the ministry said in a statement Saturday.

The European Commission, the EU's executive arm, announced on Wednesday fines against LG Display of South Korea and four Taiwanese companies -- Chimei Innolux Corp., AU Optronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. -- totaling 649 million euros (US$857.85 million) for fixing flat panel prices between Oct. 5, 2001 and Feb. 1, 2006.
The ministry said that the stiff penalties would have an adverse impact on the development of the local display panel industry.

The four Taiwanese companies have not yet received the formal EU decision detailing the fine. The ministry said it has asked Taiwan's representative office in the EU to get detailed information about the ruling.
"We will also invite executives of the four companies and officials from relevant government agencies to a brainstorming session next week to hammer out response strategies, " the statement said.

On complaints by Terry Gou, chairman of Chimei Innolux's parent company Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., that the government should not continue blocking local panel makers from investing in China, the ministry said the government has adopted regulations that allow high-tech companies, including those in the display panel industry, to invest in China under two principles.
The principles require applicants to preserve their technology lead over China and to promise further investment in Taiwan.
To date, only AU Optronics (AUO) has filed an application with the ministry to build a 7.5-generation flat panel factory in China, the statement said.

Referring to Gou's complaints, Premier Wu Den-yih also said Saturday that the MOEA has finalized screening of the AUO's China investment plan and has decided to give it the green light once certain technical details are completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO's China investment plan to be approved soon: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/10 23:39:04 (By Lin Shu-yuan, Lin Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Flat panel maker Au Optronics Corp.'s application to build a 7.5th-generation plant in China will be approved by the end of this month at the earliest, an official said Saturday.

Fan Liang-tung, executive secretary of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), told the Central News Agency that the company's plan to invest US$3 billion to construct a new factory in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province has passed critical screening of key technology involved in the project.
"The project is now pending screening of certain formality details, " Fan said, adding that the Investment Commission will deal with the case soon.
If all goes smoothly, he said, the case can be approved before the end of December.

Fan's remarks came after local newspapers reported that the world's top two flat panel makers -- Samsung Electronics and LG Display of South Korea -- will set up advanced factories in China to further expand their market shares.
Samsung reportedly will invest US$2.258 billion to build a 7.5th-generation flat panel plant in Suzhou while LG will invest US$4 billion to construct a 8.5th- generation production line in Guangzhou.
The two Korean companies' investment plans have enhanced competitive pressure on their Taiwanese counterparts, such as AU Optronics (AUO) and Chimei Innolux Corp., according to the reports.
Terry Gou, chairman of Chimei Innolux's parent company Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., complained Friday that the government should not continue blocking local panel makers from investing in China.

In response, the MOEA said in a statement Saturday that the government has adopted regulations that allow high-tech companies, including those in the display panel sector, to invest in China under two principles.

The principles require applicants to preserve their technology lead over China and to promise further investment in Taiwan, the statement said, adding that AUO is so far the only panel maker that has filed a China investment plan with the ministry.

LG Display and four Taiwanese panel makers -- Chimei Innolux, AUO, Chunghwa Picture Tubes and HannStar -- were recently given heavy fines totaling 649 million euros by the European Union for allegedly fixing flat panel prices between Oct. 5, 2001 and Feb.1, 2006.
