DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 12, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans- Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Three killed and 26 injured in tour bus crash
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 14:10:12 (By Yeh Tzu-kang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A tour bus drove off a road as it was heading toward Alishan and crashed into an electricity pole on Sunday, leaving three dead and 26 injured.
Four of the injured were in serious condition and rushed to two hospitals in nearby Chiayi City with the other injured passengers.
The three people killed in the accident did not have any vital signs when they were sent to the hospital to see if they could be revived, the police said.

The bus was one of seven vehicles taking a tour group of emergency rescue volunteers and their families from Puzih City in Chiayi to an indigenous cultural park on Alishan, one of Taiwan's prime mountain tourist resorts.
The cause of the accident was still under investigation, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agricultural assistance bears fruit in Vietnam
DOC.DATELINE: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 14:55:37 (By Tony Fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An agricultural assistance project launched by a private Taiwanese group in southern Vietnam in 2007 has begun to bear fruit, drawing praise from a former prime minister of the Southeast Asian country.

A number of the fruits and vegetables being cultivated under the initiative, including Taiwanese guavas, jujubes, bitter melon, eggplants and cucumbers, were on display Saturday at a party in Cu Chi County northwest of Ho Chi Minh City held to celebrate the project's progress.

Former Vietnamese Prime Minister Phan Van Khai, who was born and brought up in Cu Chi, praised the Chinfon Group and Taiwanese agricultural specialists for their invaluable contributions to improving agricultural development in Vietnam.

Phan, who served as prime minister from 1997 to 2006, also expressed high expectations for the Chinfon Project, hoping that it would not only be a model in Cu Chi but also be expanded to the whole of Vietnam.

The agricultural assistance project was started by Taiwan-based Chinfon Group -- one of Taiwan's largest motorbike manufacturers -- in Cu Chi in 2007 to help local farmers improve their techniques, raise output and sharpen their marketing skills.

The Chinfon Group introduced the farmers association strategy that has been successfully applied in Taiwan for decades to Cu Chi and sent Vietnamese "seed farmers" -- many of them university graduates -- to Taiwan to pick up new skills and knowledge.

At the party, the Vietnamese government presented the prestigious Medal of Agricultural Contribution to Chinfon Group Chairman Huang Shih-hui and Hu Chia- chi, one of Taiwan's former representatives in Vietnam, for their efforts in making the project possible and successful.
Later, Huang signed a new agreement with Vietnam's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, committing to a second round of agricultural cooperation from 2011 to 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwan Academy to open in Los Angeles next spring
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/12/10 15:11:21 (By Leaf Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The first academy aimed at promoting Taiwanese culture will open in Los Angeles next spring, Taiwan's office in the West Coast city said Saturday.

Kung Chung-cheng, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles, said that preparations, including planning the courses and hiring teachers for the academy, have largely been completed,
The planned courses will cover calligraphy, glove puppetry, Taiwan's tea culture, and language training.

A crucial feature of the academy will be the teaching of traditional Chinese characters, in contrast with the simplified version used in China and taught in Confucius Institutes set up by China around the world to promote Chinese language and culture.

Hui Ban Giang, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office's Cultural Division, said the Taiwan Academy will be easily differentiated from the Chinese institutes because they will focus more on promoting culture and introduce customs and cultural traits that are distinctive to Taiwan.
Language training will also be available to complement the academy's cultural component, Giang said.
The opening of these Taiwan academies around the world was one of the major campaign pledges of President Ma Ying-jeou during the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stresses fairness, quality, efficiency for NHI reform
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 16:51:40 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that a proposed second-generation health insurance reform plan, which failed to get through the Legislative Yuan last week, should emphasize the principles of fairness, quality and efficiency.

The authorities involved should exchange opinions to fine-tune the technical details of the national health insurance (NHI) reform plan -- mainly on how health insurance premiums should be calculated -- based on those principles, Ma said during a visit to the outlying island of Penghu.

He said Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang has agreed to review the proposed NHI reform plan, after a DOH-drafted package of amendments to the National Health Insurance Act failed to clear the legislative floor Dec. 7.

Yaung will again meet with legislative caucus members of the ruling Kuomintang on Monday to inform the lawmakers how a new version of the amendment package could be modified to forge the widest consensus possible on the issue, the president said.
The plan that failed to clear the legislative body would have calculated health insurance premiums on the basis of overall household income rather than salaries, as is the case at present.

It remains unclear if the modified version Yaung is considering will preserve the household income formula, but Ma stressed that it was more important for the plan to reflect the three principles he articulated rather than apply a specific formula.

In related news, the president reiterated the government's resolve to develop the Penghu Islands (Pescadores) , located to the west of Kaohsiung in the Taiwan Strait, into a low-carbon dioxide emissions island.

He said the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development has given a green light to the building of submarine cables between Penghu and Taiwan proper, which will allow Penghu residents to sell the extra power generated from wind turbines to Taiwan Power Company.

On a complaint raised by Penghu County Councilor Yang Yao that the airfare subsidy the central government gives to Penghu residents is relatively low, Ma said Legislator Lin Ping-kun has submitted an amendment that would raise the subsidy to about 30 percent of airfares.
According to Yang, Penghu residents currently get 20 percent of their airfares subsidized, lower than the subsidies received by Matsu residents that can reach up to 40 percent of the ticket's value.
"All people concerned are still working to at least increase the subsidy to 30 percent," Ma told Penghu residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public hearing on health insurance reform may be held
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 17:11:13 (By Jenny W. Hsu, Garfie Li, Hsieh Chia-chen, and Chen Ching-fang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang will likely hold a public hearing on a hotly debated national health insurance reform package after the Department of Health (DOH) unveils a modified version of the plan on Monday, Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

The government's effort to push a health care overhaul has been fraught with controversy, and on Dec. 7, the plan was rejected by legislators because of concerns over its fairness and lack of details on how health insurance premiums would be calculated.

Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang, who has pledged to step down if the reform backfires, reportedly agreed to scrap his idea of calculating premiums based on total household income, which he argued would have eased the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) financial woes.
It remains unclear, however, how a modified version of the plan would define income on which premiums are calculated. At present, health insurance premiums are calculated as a percentage of salary.
The premier also said that no decision had been made on whether the government would raise a health surcharge on tobacco products that was already doubled only last year.
"It's too early to tell but everything is under discussion," he said.

Although the DOH has been tight-lipped about what it will present Monday, reports have indicated that Yaung plans to expand the definition of "individual salary" to include overtime, year-end bonuses, and other outside incentives as part of overall income.

The speculation has angered a health insurance watchdog group, which worried that such a calculation method might end up hurting wage earners if employers were unwilling to shoulder a larger share of the premiums.
Last Thursday, Wu met with related DOH officials in a bid to salvage the health insurance system.

"During the meeting, we made two preliminary decisions. The new health insurance plan will follow the spirit of the proposed second-generation health plan. Also, many agreed that the suggestion of using total household income as a basis for calculating premiums could be difficult to execute," he said.
Wu rejected reports that Yaung's original proposal had been officially nixed.

He said that once Yaung has presented the modified version to KMT lawmakers, the caucus would discuss the plan among themselves and then hold a public hearing to get outside opinions on the plan before making a final decision.
KMT caucus whip Lin Yi-shih also reiterated that no final plan has been decided, saying that everything was still in the negotiating stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Key to Economic Cooperation Committee's success

TEXT.P: It's almost three months since the historic Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China went into effect. Both parties have agreed to set up a cross-Taiwan Strait Economic Cooperation Committee (ECC) as a platform for further negotiations to make ECFA a success.

To achieve its intended purposes, complementary measures would have to be taken to empower the Economic Cooperation Committee with adequate support and authority. With respect to this, the government needs to clearly define its roles and status so it will operate effectively to achieve the ECFA targets.

What needs to be "adjusted" in this regard is the role of the Mainland Affairs Council, which deals with major policy issues towards China, but not the day-to- day economic and investment exchanges -- what the ECFA seeks to promote.

Because the real issues ECFA seeks to deal with through the Economic Cooperation Committee tend to be complicated and professional, it is questionable whether the MAC has the competency or energy to continue to play its "leading" role here.

Furthermore, probably as a result of the opposition from responsible government ministries and agencies including the MAC, the Economic Cooperation Committee has been excluded from participating in the negotiations with China over intellectual property, medical cooperation or goods and services trade pacts with China.

And it is exactly these "substantive" pacts with China that would benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait in the spirit and letter of the ECFA. It is time indeed that the government authorized the ECC to play its critical role to realize ECFA goals. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: More than half of consumers interested in Internet-based TV: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 17:35:14 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of consumers around the globe, including in Taiwan, use Internet-based television or video services every week, reflecting a growing interest in on-demand content, a study by wireless network maker Ericsson AB has found.

People are spending up to 35 percent of their leisure time on watching various types of content, the study found, with 93 percent of respondents still watching TV every week and more than 70 percent using "time shifting" services, such as streaming, downloading or watching recorded broadcasts.
Over 50 percent of respondents said they wanted to connect their personal computers to televisions to be able to watch online television content with other programming.

Regarding the preferred devices for watching TV, 37 percent of respondents expressed interest in having a touch screen tablet connected to their television, which would allow them to keep an eye on private communications, such as reading e-mails or social networking, while watching TV.
The study collected responses from people in seven major countries with advanced video application development -- the United States, England, Germany, Spain, Sweden, China and Taiwan.

The state-backed Institute for Information Industry (III), which helped Ericsson conduct the study in Taiwan, said user preferences for television or video services in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung differed.

About 71 percent of respondents living in Taipei were interested in time shifting services, while 51 percent of those in Taichung preferred to record TV programs with a timer, and 73 percent of those in Kaohsiung were most interested in having a list of favorite programming that could be accessed on demand.
Despite the differing preferences, the study showed that all respondents were generally willing to try new types of video services, said Benson Chen, a senior analyst with III, in an e-mail.
"All they want is to have more choices and higher quality TV services," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma pledges to make Taiwan global Hakka research center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 18:25:44 (By Angela Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Sunday the government's determination to make Taiwan a global Hakka cultural research and interaction center.

President Ma made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2010 National Hakka Conference in Taipei, showing off his Hakka language proficiency by delivering his eight-minute speech entirely in the dialect.
He received a big round of applause from the conference attendees -- nearly 500 representatives from Hakka communities around the country.

Ma said he is glad that he promulgated the Hakka Basic Law in January, about 10 days after the Legislative Yuan passed it, to allow the administration to use national resources to turn Taiwan into a global Hakka culture research and interaction center.

Under the basic law, Ma said, the administration has and will continue to deliver his campaign platform to accelerate efforts to preserve Hakka culture and language, and to help bolster the development of Hakka industries and innovative businesses.

Also speaking at the conference, Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Minister Huang Yu-cheng said after the Hakka Basic Law was put into effect on Jan. 27, the Hakka affairs administration has been incorporated into the national public servants examination.

The CHA has also finalized opinions and suggestions to determine that Taiwan's Hakka Day will be observed on Jan. 20 on the lunar calendar each year starting from 2011, as part of the efforts to mark the Hakka spirit and culture, Huang said.
Resolutions of the conference will be referred to the CHA to be used as future reference, he added.

Under the Hakka Basic Law, any townships, cities and communities in which Hakka people account for over 33 percent of the population will be listed as key Hakka culture development districts where the Hakka dialect will serve as a required language at official events and in government agencies.
A total of 61 townships, cities and communities around Taiwan are qualified to serve as Hakka culture hubs.

In addition, the law stipulates that the government should promote the circulation of the Hakka language and proficiency certification in the dialect, establish a Hakka language data bank and take measures to encourage Hakka academic research while encouraging local colleges and universities to open departments and institutes focusing on Hakka affairs research.
The law also demands the protection of Hakka media rights and assistance in the establishment of Hakka-language broadcasting and television channels.

According to CHA statistics released in 2008, Hakka people comprise over 25 percent of the country's population, meaning there are 5.88 million people in Taiwan who identify themselves as Hakka people or as having Hakka blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Peace prize winners for ROC's 100th anniversary

TEXT.P: Leading Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo's conspicuous absence from the Nobel Peace Prize awarding ceremony on Friday has caught the attention of many people in Taiwan as its government plans to invite as many previous award winners as possible to join in a celebration of the 100th birthday of the Republic of China (ROC) next year.

According to Emile Sheng, minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, a highlight of the government's celebrations of the ROC's 100th anniversary will be a peace ceremony at the offshore island of Kinmen on Aug. 23, to remember Communist China's 1958 bombardment of the island aimed at staging an invasion of Taiwan.

Sheng said at least one Nobel Peace Prize winner has agreed to attend the ceremony during which a "bell of peace" will be tolled to remind people all over the world of the importance of -- and Taiwan's strong wish for -- maintaining peace and stability.
Following are excerpts of reports from Taiwanese newspapers on the topic.
China Times:

Sheng insisted that he won't publish the names of the guests of honor until June next year in order to avoid political interference that might spoil the holy event at the Peace Plaza on Kuningtou, Kinmen, where a fierce battle between the troops of the ROC and Communist China took place more than a half century ago.
He said the word "peace" will be inscribed around the peace bell in 100 languages to demonstrate the ROC's strong will to work for peace not just across the Taiwan Strait, but also around the globe.
The United Daily News:
The bell tolling activity will be held on the anniversary of the 1958 Communist Chinese bombardment of Kinmen island and in attendance will be Nobel Peace Prize laureates.

The bell will be made from the cannons that have fallen on the battleground. Marking the 100th anniversary of the founding of the ROC, the government hopes the ceremony will bring at least 100 years of peace between Taiwan and China.
The Liberty Times:
Who will be invited to the Kinmen bell tolling ceremony is something worth watching now that the government has said it has sent out invitations to as many previous winners as it can.
Would the pro-China Ma Ying-jeou administration invite Liu Xiaobo and the Dalai Lama, whom the Ma government has once obstructed from visiting Taiwan, in disregard of China's angry reaction?

As President Barack Obama was the 2009 winner of the prize, whether he would be present for that occasion would be of great political significance in that it would test the government's ability to score a diplomatic breakthrough.

Indeed, many Nobel Peace Prize laureates have been invited to visit Taiwan and their visits have all aroused great interest here. They include Mikhail Gorbachev, Jimmy Carter, Lech Walesa and the Dalai Lama.

Since its establishment in 1901, the Nobel Peace Prize committee has awarded 91 prizes to 121 individuals or groups, of whom 28 are still living. Among them and also well known to Taiwanese are former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, former South African President Nelson Mandela and Burma's democracy movement leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who was recently released from house arrest.

Since, as Presidential Office officials have pointed out, Ma was the first Asian leader to call on China to release Liu Xiaobo, it would be interesting to see if he would "dare" invite Liu over to the 2011 Peace Bell ceremony on Kinmen, which lies just opposite the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese runners shine in Taiwan's ultramarathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 19:02:14 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Japanese runners on Sunday won the men's and women's titles at the 2010 Soochow International Ultra-Marathon in Taiwan and successfully defended their titles in the 24-hour race.
Ryochi Sekiya, 43, ran a total of 268.1 kilometers in 24 hours to win the men's division in the Taipei competition for the sixth time.
Countrywoman Mami Kudo outran all of her competitors to win the women's division with a distance of 239.3 kilometers, well short of her world record of 254.425 kilometers set last year.
France's Anne-Celile Fontaine finished second.
Taiwan's Luo Wei-ming and 51-year-old Huang Yen-ling took third place in the men's and women's divisions respectively with distances of 229.2 km and 204.4 km.

Luo said the 24-hour ultramarathon, which went from 9 a.m. Saturday to 9 a.m. Sunday, was particularly difficult because there were no breaks, and running through the night interrupted the sleep cycle.

Huang, who participated in the Taitung Super Triathon in October, said the ultramarathon was more challenging than the triathon because runners were easily bored circling the same track around the clock.
The event, which took place on the 400-meter track at Soochow University's Waishuanghsi campus, was held for the 10th time. Thirty runners from around the world participated in the event.
To track the runners' laps and distances run, Soochow University invested more than NT$1 million (US$33,256) on a chip timing system to increase accuracy.
Tied to the runners' legs, the chips automatically sent the data to the computer, which could then be seen in real time on the official website.

But the runners seemed to prefer an old-fashioned system, if for no other reason than to keep them going. Even with the new technology, volunteers would still flip numbered panels to inform runners how many laps they had completed as a form of encouragement.

"Runners can see the number on the panel when they finish a lap, with the student volunteers cheering them on. Such interaction helps the runners keep going and perform better, " said Kuo Fong-chou, deputy director of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association, who persuaded the school to purchase the chip system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Health insurance must be fair and efficient

TEXT.P: The Department of Health's proposed amendments to Taiwan's National Health Insurance (NHI) Act, focusing on the so-called second generation premium system, were lambasted by legislators for good reasons: the policy makers did not fully understand the principles of fairness and efficacy.

While the amendments seek to make the premium-payment scale fairer for all citizens, the proposal for calculating the premium based on a household's total income was seen as potentially leading to even greater unfairness. Little wonder it has been roundly criticized, even by the ruling party's lawmakers.

The government might have thought that it would be fair for higher income earners to shoulder a proportionally greater share of the NHI's financial burden. A more reasonable formula to look at this, according to academics, is to design the premium paying scheme based on the total tax and fees paid to the government so that the national income would be more evenly distributed among all citizens after health insurance premiums have been collected.

One way to achieve fairer income distribution is what the opposition party has proposed, and the government is considering: collect NHI premium from people paying stock and land transaction taxes. Such premium would go a long way to filling in the financial shortages in the NHI program.

Squeezing some money from stock and land transactions would not increase the government's administrative cost. In contrast, the household income method is both complicated and inefficient, increasing administrative cost to boot.

The government should give some serious thought to why its proposal on second- generation NHI reform has been regarded as both unfair and inefficient and make necessary adjustments before putting forward a new set of amendments to the legislature. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 12, 2010) enditem/cs nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Thirteen stray dogs bound for new homes in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 20:49:54 ( By Chang Che-fon and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Thirteen dogs have boarded a flight to the United States to find new homes there, in the latest attempt to save some of Taiwan's many stray dogs, animal rescue workers said Sunday.

The dogs were rescued from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, where they were found to have been abused or suffering from illnesses, rescue workers said. The dogs were first taken by train from Kaohsiung to Taipei before boarding the flight.
There were sad stories behind every abused dog, said rescue worker Chang Ya-hui, who led four volunteers of the non-profit Animal Rescue Team Taiwan, to accompany the dogs on the train.

For example, she said, Andrew, one of the dogs who will be sent to Seattle, was covered with insect bites when he was found in Linyuan Township, while Irene, another abused dog who lost her eye sight, had suffered from serious skin diseases.
The group of U.S.-bound dogs also included eight puppies that were abused by foreign migrant workers and were later rescued from an oyster harbor, Chang said.

While an increasing number of Taiwanese people have become aware of the need to help stray animals, the adoption rate is still low, putting pressure on animal shelters with limited budgets to care for the dogs.
It is hoped that by taking the dogs to shelters in the U.S., their chances of being adopted will increase.

Since 2004, the rescue team has carried out more than 200 such cases, flying a total of 1,470 animals rescued in Taiwan to North America, by cooperating with similar organizations in the U.S and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: School principals to be graded on bullying prevention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 20:58:30 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: School principals' efforts at preventing bullying on campus will become part of their performance review, amid increasing cases of school violence in Taiwan, the Ministry of Education said Sunday.

Under a proposed anti-bullying program, how effective schools are in preventing bullying will be included in principals' evaluations, said Wang Fu-lin, director of the ministry's Department of Military Training Education.
If principals do not properly tackle bullying or report about the problems in time, it could affect their ratings, as well as whether they can serve another term, Wang said.
Wang added that violence on campus often occurs due to insensitivity or indifference on the part of the school administration.
Local governments will also be punished if they are not committed to taking measures to deal with school violence, Wang added.
The ministry is collecting information on bullying prevention programs in other countries to come up with a specific project to tackle this problem, said Wang.
It, however, will not require mandatory separation of bullies from other students, Wang noted.
The minister will preside over a conference next week to discuss the issue.
In the first eight months of 2008, schools in Taiwan reported 4,314 cases of bullying, according to the ministry's survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma: No hurry to ink investment pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 21:35:03 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that both Taiwan and China have agreed that there is no hurry to sign a proposed investment protection agreement between the two sides.

"Since both sides have failed to come to terms with several parts of the proposed agreement, it would be better for the pact to be signed later, " President Ma told reporters while visiting the island of Penghu earlier in the day.

The investment deal was originally scheduled to be signed by the heads of the two organizations in charge of negotiations -- Chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and President Chen Yunlin of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- in their next round of meeting in Taiwan before the end of year.

But the signing of the deal is set to be postponed due to differences in details of the proposed pact, especially with regard to whether any international arbitration mechanism should be introduced in dispute settlement of the trade pact, according to officials involved in the pre-meeting talks.
"It would be good for the proposed pact to be shelved until terms acceptable to both sides are worked out," the president said.

President Ma would not comment on reports that Taiwan's demand for an international arbitration mechanism is the key source of disagreement behind the two sides, saying "the controversies go beyond that and need to be solved gradually."

Taiwan hopes the investment protection agreement will protect Taiwanese investors in China. Investors have invested around US$100 billion in China over the years, but due to tense relations in the past, the two sides have yet to reach an agreement involving business dispute resolution and protection of investors.
Chiang and Chen have met five times and signed 14 cross-strait agreements since President Ma was sworn into office in May 2008.
The agreements are mostly aimed at boosting cross-strait trade and economic exchanges, with the most recent and important one being the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement inked in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitors to ICT Month tech fair hit three-year high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 22:32:36 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The number of visitors to ICT Month, Taiwan's largest consumer electronics show, hit a three-year high after the global financial crisis in 2008, the organizer said Sunday.

The annual event tallied more than 850,000 visitors during the 9-day period, up from last year's 800,000 and 770,000 in 2008, showing that people were more willing to spend money on electronic products, said Kinki Kao, project manager of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), in a telephone interview with the CNA.

Tablet computers became the best seller in the fair, followed by digital cameras, with an average growth of 30 percent compared to last year's show, while sales of notebooks and LED monitors saw a 20 percent growth respectively, the TCA said in an email statement.
On the 2010 event's theme, "Embracing a Smart Life," the TCA said the products at the fair no longer highlighted just enhanced efficiency or specifications, but rather focused on user friendliness.
The tech fair, now in its 31st year, will later be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 17-22 and in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Dec. 30-Jan. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese book studies CNA, media coverage of Nanking Massacre
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 22:38:52 (By Jen Wen-yi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Chinese scholar has released a book about Chinese language media's coverage of the Rape of Nanking in 1937, in which he revealed the news blackout imposed by Japan at the time and Chinese media's, especially the Central News Agency's, efforts to overcome reporting difficulties.

The China News Service quoted Professor Jing Shenghong of Nanjing Normal University as saying at a news conference on Sunday that it was extremely difficult for the media to report about the massacre as the Japanese army had prior to the systemic killings put in place a well-planned news blackout.

The professor at the university's College of Social Development News Service made the remarks while launching his book "Chinese News Media and the Rape of Nanking during World War II" in Nanjing, China Sunday. Nanking is now spelled as Nanjing.
From September through December of 1937, Jing noted, Japan had demanded all foreign diplomats, journalists and expatriates leave Nanking for Wuhan, Shanghai and Hong Kong.

On Dec. 13, when the Japanese troops broke through the city's defense and entered the capital, it immediately cut off the city's communications with the outside world and banned any entry into and exit from the city for more than a month.

It was during that time that Japanese troops carried out the atrocity, butchering hundreds of thousands of unarmed Chinese in Nanking, an incident historians have since called the Rape of Nanking because many women were gang raped before being massacred.

Jing pointed out that in 1938, all Western and Chinese media were prohibited from visiting Nanking while those remaining in the city were all purged, "so that for a long period of time not one single newspaper was able to publish normally, not one single Chinese news worker could work normally, and not one single Chinese media outside the city could acquire any news regarding Nanjing."

Foreign missionaries are believed to have been the first to reveal news about Japan's takeover of Nanking and the subsequent massacre in the city. The missionaries had remained in the city at the time. After they told the outside world what was happening, foreign media reported about it.
A few days later, on Dec. 22, 1937, the Central News Agency (CNA), the biggest news wire service of the Republic of China, became the first Chinese language media to report about it, Jing said.
He praised the CNA for surmounting difficulties to report about the incident.
After the CNA broke the news, other Chinese media quickly caught up by quoting those fleeing the city to tell their horrible stories inside the city.
"The ensuing Chinese media reports about the Rape of Nanking were both emotional and numerous -- far outnumbering those by the Western media," Jing said.
Jing said the subject of the media's coverage of one of the bloodiest incidents in China's history was worth in-depth research, according to the China News Service.
He said a look into how the media worked at that time could bridge a gap in the study of the Rape of Nanking and is thus significant academically.

It is not immediately clear, however, whether Jing was able to learn or reveal in his book what other obstacles Chinese language media faced which kept them from immediately reporting about the invasion of Nanking and the subsequent massacre after foreign media had reported about it. enditem/cs nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwan Academy to open in Los Angeles next spring
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/12/10 15:11:21 (By Leaf Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The first academy aimed at promoting Taiwanese culture will open in Los Angeles next spring, Taiwan's office in the West Coast city said Saturday.

Kung Chung-cheng, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles, said that preparations, including planning the courses and hiring teachers for the academy, have largely been completed,
The planned courses will cover calligraphy, glove puppetry, Taiwan's tea culture, and language training.

A crucial feature of the academy will be the teaching of traditional Chinese characters, in contrast with the simplified version used in China and taught in Confucius Institutes set up by China around the world to promote Chinese language and culture.

Hui Ban Giang, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office's Cultural Division, said the Taiwan Academy will be easily differentiated from the Chinese institutes because they will focus more on promoting culture and introduce customs and cultural traits that are distinctive to Taiwan.
Language training will also be available to complement the academy's cultural component, Giang said.
The opening of these Taiwan academies around the world was one of the major campaign pledges of President Ma Ying-jeou during the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stresses fairness, quality, efficiency for NHI reform
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 16:51:40 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that a proposed second-generation health insurance reform plan, which failed to get through the Legislative Yuan last week, should emphasize the principles of fairness, quality and efficiency.

The authorities involved should exchange opinions to fine-tune the technical details of the national health insurance (NHI) reform plan -- mainly on how health insurance premiums should be calculated -- based on those principles, Ma said during a visit to the outlying island of Penghu.

He said Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang has agreed to review the proposed NHI reform plan, after a DOH-drafted package of amendments to the National Health Insurance Act failed to clear the legislative floor Dec. 7.

Yaung will again meet with legislative caucus members of the ruling Kuomintang on Monday to inform the lawmakers how a new version of the amendment package could be modified to forge the widest consensus possible on the issue, the president said.
The plan that failed to clear the legislative body would have calculated health insurance premiums on the basis of overall household income rather than salaries, as is the case at present.

It remains unclear if the modified version Yaung is considering will preserve the household income formula, but Ma stressed that it was more important for the plan to reflect the three principles he articulated rather than apply a specific formula.

In related news, the president reiterated the government's resolve to develop the Penghu Islands (Pescadores) , located to the west of Kaohsiung in the Taiwan Strait, into a low-carbon dioxide emissions island.

He said the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development has given a green light to the building of submarine cables between Penghu and Taiwan proper, which will allow Penghu residents to sell the extra power generated from wind turbines to Taiwan Power Company.

On a complaint raised by Penghu County Councilor Yang Yao that the airfare subsidy the central government gives to Penghu residents is relatively low, Ma said Legislator Lin Ping-kun has submitted an amendment that would raise the subsidy to about 30 percent of airfares.
According to Yang, Penghu residents currently get 20 percent of their airfares subsidized, lower than the subsidies received by Matsu residents that can reach up to 40 percent of the ticket's value.
"All people concerned are still working to at least increase the subsidy to 30 percent," Ma told Penghu residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public hearing on health insurance reform may be held
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 17:11:13 (By Jenny W. Hsu, Garfie Li, Hsieh Chia-chen, and Chen Ching-fang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang will likely hold a public hearing on a hotly debated national health insurance reform package after the Department of Health (DOH) unveils a modified version of the plan on Monday, Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

The government's effort to push a health care overhaul has been fraught with controversy, and on Dec. 7, the plan was rejected by legislators because of concerns over its fairness and lack of details on how health insurance premiums would be calculated.

Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang, who has pledged to step down if the reform backfires, reportedly agreed to scrap his idea of calculating premiums based on total household income, which he argued would have eased the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) financial woes.
It remains unclear, however, how a modified version of the plan would define income on which premiums are calculated. At present, health insurance premiums are calculated as a percentage of salary.
The premier also said that no decision had been made on whether the government would raise a health surcharge on tobacco products that was already doubled only last year.
"It's too early to tell but everything is under discussion," he said.

Although the DOH has been tight-lipped about what it will present Monday, reports have indicated that Yaung plans to expand the definition of "individual salary" to include overtime, year-end bonuses, and other outside incentives as part of overall income.

The speculation has angered a health insurance watchdog group, which worried that such a calculation method might end up hurting wage earners if employers were unwilling to shoulder a larger share of the premiums.
Last Thursday, Wu met with related DOH officials in a bid to salvage the health insurance system.

"During the meeting, we made two preliminary decisions. The new health insurance plan will follow the spirit of the proposed second-generation health plan. Also, many agreed that the suggestion of using total household income as a basis for calculating premiums could be difficult to execute," he said.
Wu rejected reports that Yaung's original proposal had been officially nixed.

He said that once Yaung has presented the modified version to KMT lawmakers, the caucus would discuss the plan among themselves and then hold a public hearing to get outside opinions on the plan before making a final decision.
KMT caucus whip Lin Yi-shih also reiterated that no final plan has been decided, saying that everything was still in the negotiating stage.

Under the basic law, Ma said, the administration has and will continue to deliver his campaign platform to accelerate efforts to preserve Hakka culture and language, and to help bolster the development of Hakka industries and innovative businesses.

Also speaking at the conference, Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Minister Huang Yu-cheng said after the Hakka Basic Law was put into effect on Jan. 27, the Hakka affairs administration has been incorporated into the national public servants examination.

The CHA has also finalized opinions and suggestions to determine that Taiwan's Hakka Day will be observed on Jan. 20 on the lunar calendar each year starting from 2011, as part of the efforts to mark the Hakka spirit and culture, Huang said.
Resolutions of the conference will be referred to the CHA to be used as future reference, he added.

Under the Hakka Basic Law, any townships, cities and communities in which Hakka people account for over 33 percent of the population will be listed as key Hakka culture development districts where the Hakka dialect will serve as a required language at official events and in government agencies.
A total of 61 townships, cities and communities around Taiwan are qualified to serve as Hakka culture hubs.

In addition, the law stipulates that the government should promote the circulation of the Hakka language and proficiency certification in the dialect, establish a Hakka language data bank and take measures to encourage Hakka academic research while encouraging local colleges and universities to open departments and institutes focusing on Hakka affairs research.
The law also demands the protection of Hakka media rights and assistance in the establishment of Hakka-language broadcasting and television channels.

According to CHA statistics released in 2008, Hakka people comprise over 25 percent of the country's population, meaning there are 5.88 million people in Taiwan who identify themselves as Hakka people or as having Hakka blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- Peace prize winners for ROC's 100th anniversary

TEXT.P: Leading Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo's conspicuous absence from the Nobel Peace Prize awarding ceremony on Friday has caught the attention of many people in Taiwan as its government plans to invite as many previous award winners as possible to join in a celebration of the 100th birthday of the Republic of China (ROC) next year.

According to Emile Sheng, minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, a highlight of the government's celebrations of the ROC's 100th anniversary will be a peace ceremony at the offshore island of Kinmen on Aug. 23, to remember Communist China's 1958 bombardment of the island aimed at staging an invasion of Taiwan.

Sheng said at least one Nobel Peace Prize winner has agreed to attend the ceremony during which a "bell of peace" will be tolled to remind people all over the world of the importance of -- and Taiwan's strong wish for -- maintaining peace and stability.
Following are excerpts of reports from Taiwanese newspapers on the topic.
China Times:

Sheng insisted that he won't publish the names of the guests of honor until June next year in order to avoid political interference that might spoil the holy event at the Peace Plaza on Kuningtou, Kinmen, where a fierce battle between the troops of the ROC and Communist China took place more than a half century ago.
He said the word "peace" will be inscribed around the peace bell in 100 languages to demonstrate the ROC's strong will to work for peace not just across the Taiwan Strait, but also around the globe.
The United Daily News:
The bell tolling activity will be held on the anniversary of the 1958 Communist Chinese bombardment of Kinmen island and in attendance will be Nobel Peace Prize laureates.

The bell will be made from the cannons that have fallen on the battleground. Marking the 100th anniversary of the founding of the ROC, the government hopes the ceremony will bring at least 100 years of peace between Taiwan and China.
The Liberty Times:
Who will be invited to the Kinmen bell tolling ceremony is something worth watching now that the government has said it has sent out invitations to as many previous winners as it can.
Would the pro-China Ma Ying-jeou administration invite Liu Xiaobo and the Dalai Lama, whom the Ma government has once obstructed from visiting Taiwan, in disregard of China's angry reaction?

As President Barack Obama was the 2009 winner of the prize, whether he would be present for that occasion would be of great political significance in that it would test the government's ability to score a diplomatic breakthrough.

Indeed, many Nobel Peace Prize laureates have been invited to visit Taiwan and their visits have all aroused great interest here. They include Mikhail Gorbachev, Jimmy Carter, Lech Walesa and the Dalai Lama.

Since its establishment in 1901, the Nobel Peace Prize committee has awarded 91 prizes to 121 individuals or groups, of whom 28 are still living. Among them and also well known to Taiwanese are former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, former South African President Nelson Mandela and Burma's democracy movement leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who was recently released from house arrest.

Since, as Presidential Office officials have pointed out, Ma was the first Asian leader to call on China to release Liu Xiaobo, it would be interesting to see if he would "dare" invite Liu over to the 2011 Peace Bell ceremony on Kinmen, which lies just opposite the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese runners shine in Taiwan's ultramarathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 19:02:14 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Japanese runners on Sunday won the men's and women's titles at the 2010 Soochow International Ultra-Marathon in Taiwan and successfully defended their titles in the 24-hour race.
Ryochi Sekiya, 43, ran a total of 268.1 kilometers in 24 hours to win the men's division in the Taipei competition for the sixth time.
Countrywoman Mami Kudo outran all of her competitors to win the women's division with a distance of 239.3 kilometers, well short of her world record of 254.425 kilometers set last year.
France's Anne-Celile Fontaine finished second.
Taiwan's Luo Wei-ming and 51-year-old Huang Yen-ling took third place in the men's and women's divisions respectively with distances of 229.2 km and 204.4 km.

Luo said the 24-hour ultramarathon, which went from 9 a.m. Saturday to 9 a.m. Sunday, was particularly difficult because there were no breaks, and running through the night interrupted the sleep cycle.

Huang, who participated in the Taitung Super Triathon in October, said the ultramarathon was more challenging than the triathon because runners were easily bored circling the same track around the clock.
The event, which took place on the 400-meter track at Soochow University's Waishuanghsi campus, was held for the 10th time. Thirty runners from around the world participated in the event.
To track the runners' laps and distances run, Soochow University invested more than NT$1 million (US$33,256) on a chip timing system to increase accuracy.
Tied to the runners' legs, the chips automatically sent the data to the computer, which could then be seen in real time on the official website.

But the runners seemed to prefer an old-fashioned system, if for no other reason than to keep them going. Even with the new technology, volunteers would still flip numbered panels to inform runners how many laps they had completed as a form of encouragement.

"Runners can see the number on the panel when they finish a lap, with the student volunteers cheering them on. Such interaction helps the runners keep going and perform better, " said Kuo Fong-chou, deputy director of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association, who persuaded the school to purchase the chip system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Health insurance must be fair and efficient

TEXT.P: The Department of Health's proposed amendments to Taiwan's National Health Insurance (NHI) Act, focusing on the so-called second generation premium system, were lambasted by legislators for good reasons: the policy makers did not fully understand the principles of fairness and efficacy.

While the amendments seek to make the premium-payment scale fairer for all citizens, the proposal for calculating the premium based on a household's total income was seen as potentially leading to even greater unfairness. Little wonder it has been roundly criticized, even by the ruling party's lawmakers.

The government might have thought that it would be fair for higher income earners to shoulder a proportionally greater share of the NHI's financial burden. A more reasonable formula to look at this, according to academics, is to design the premium paying scheme based on the total tax and fees paid to the government so that the national income would be more evenly distributed among all citizens after health insurance premiums have been collected.

One way to achieve fairer income distribution is what the opposition party has proposed, and the government is considering: collect NHI premium from people paying stock and land transaction taxes. Such premium would go a long way to filling in the financial shortages in the NHI program.

Squeezing some money from stock and land transactions would not increase the government's administrative cost. In contrast, the household income method is both complicated and inefficient, increasing administrative cost to boot.

The government should give some serious thought to why its proposal on second- generation NHI reform has been regarded as both unfair and inefficient and make necessary adjustments before putting forward a new set of amendments to the legislature. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 12, 2010) enditem/cs nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Thirteen stray dogs bound for new homes in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 20:49:54 ( By Chang Che-fon and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Thirteen dogs have boarded a flight to the United States to find new homes there, in the latest attempt to save some of Taiwan's many stray dogs, animal rescue workers said Sunday.

The dogs were rescued from southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, where they were found to have been abused or suffering from illnesses, rescue workers said. The dogs were first taken by train from Kaohsiung to Taipei before boarding the flight.
There were sad stories behind every abused dog, said rescue worker Chang Ya-hui, who led four volunteers of the non-profit Animal Rescue Team Taiwan, to accompany the dogs on the train.

For example, she said, Andrew, one of the dogs who will be sent to Seattle, was covered with insect bites when he was found in Linyuan Township, while Irene, another abused dog who lost her eye sight, had suffered from serious skin diseases.
The group of U.S.-bound dogs also included eight puppies that were abused by foreign migrant workers and were later rescued from an oyster harbor, Chang said.

While an increasing number of Taiwanese people have become aware of the need to help stray animals, the adoption rate is still low, putting pressure on animal shelters with limited budgets to care for the dogs.
It is hoped that by taking the dogs to shelters in the U.S., their chances of being adopted will increase.

Since 2004, the rescue team has carried out more than 200 such cases, flying a total of 1,470 animals rescued in Taiwan to North America, by cooperating with similar organizations in the U.S and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: School principals to be graded on bullying prevention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 20:58:30 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: School principals' efforts at preventing bullying on campus will become part of their performance review, amid increasing cases of school violence in Taiwan, the Ministry of Education said Sunday.

Under a proposed anti-bullying program, how effective schools are in preventing bullying will be included in principals' evaluations, said Wang Fu-lin, director of the ministry's Department of Military Training Education.
If principals do not properly tackle bullying or report about the problems in time, it could affect their ratings, as well as whether they can serve another term, Wang said.
Wang added that violence on campus often occurs due to insensitivity or indifference on the part of the school administration.
Local governments will also be punished if they are not committed to taking measures to deal with school violence, Wang added.
The ministry is collecting information on bullying prevention programs in other countries to come up with a specific project to tackle this problem, said Wang.
It, however, will not require mandatory separation of bullies from other students, Wang noted.
The minister will preside over a conference next week to discuss the issue.
In the first eight months of 2008, schools in Taiwan reported 4,314 cases of bullying, according to the ministry's survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma: No hurry to ink investment pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 21:35:03 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that both Taiwan and China have agreed that there is no hurry to sign a proposed investment protection agreement between the two sides.

"Since both sides have failed to come to terms with several parts of the proposed agreement, it would be better for the pact to be signed later, " President Ma told reporters while visiting the island of Penghu earlier in the day.

The investment deal was originally scheduled to be signed by the heads of the two organizations in charge of negotiations -- Chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation and President Chen Yunlin of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- in their next round of meeting in Taiwan before the end of year.

But the signing of the deal is set to be postponed due to differences in details of the proposed pact, especially with regard to whether any international arbitration mechanism should be introduced in dispute settlement of the trade pact, according to officials involved in the pre-meeting talks.
"It would be good for the proposed pact to be shelved until terms acceptable to both sides are worked out," the president said.

President Ma would not comment on reports that Taiwan's demand for an international arbitration mechanism is the key source of disagreement behind the two sides, saying "the controversies go beyond that and need to be solved gradually."

Taiwan hopes the investment protection agreement will protect Taiwanese investors in China. Investors have invested around US$100 billion in China over the years, but due to tense relations in the past, the two sides have yet to reach an agreement involving business dispute resolution and protection of investors.
Chiang and Chen have met five times and signed 14 cross-strait agreements since President Ma was sworn into office in May 2008.
The agreements are mostly aimed at boosting cross-strait trade and economic exchanges, with the most recent and important one being the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement inked in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitors to ICT Month tech fair hit three-year high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 22:32:36 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The number of visitors to ICT Month, Taiwan's largest consumer electronics show, hit a three-year high after the global financial crisis in 2008, the organizer said Sunday.

The annual event tallied more than 850,000 visitors during the 9-day period, up from last year's 800,000 and 770,000 in 2008, showing that people were more willing to spend money on electronic products, said Kinki Kao, project manager of the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), in a telephone interview with the CNA.

Tablet computers became the best seller in the fair, followed by digital cameras, with an average growth of 30 percent compared to last year's show, while sales of notebooks and LED monitors saw a 20 percent growth respectively, the TCA said in an email statement.
On the 2010 event's theme, "Embracing a Smart Life," the TCA said the products at the fair no longer highlighted just enhanced efficiency or specifications, but rather focused on user friendliness.
The tech fair, now in its 31st year, will later be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 17-22 and in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Dec. 30-Jan. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese book studies CNA, media coverage of Nanking Massacre
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/10 22:38:52 (By Jen Wen-yi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Chinese scholar has released a book about Chinese language media's coverage of the Rape of Nanking in 1937, in which he revealed the news blackout imposed by Japan at the time and Chinese media's, especially the Central News Agency's, efforts to overcome reporting difficulties.

The China News Service quoted Professor Jing Shenghong of Nanjing Normal University as saying at a news conference on Sunday that it was extremely difficult for the media to report about the massacre as the Japanese army had prior to the systemic killings put in place a well-planned news blackout.

The professor at the university's College of Social Development News Service made the remarks while launching his book "Chinese News Media and the Rape of Nanking during World War II" in Nanjing, China Sunday. Nanking is now spelled as Nanjing.
From September through December of 1937, Jing noted, Japan had demanded all foreign diplomats, journalists and expatriates leave Nanking for Wuhan, Shanghai and Hong Kong.

On Dec. 13, when the Japanese troops broke through the city's defense and entered the capital, it immediately cut off the city's communications with the outside world and banned any entry into and exit from the city for more than a month.

It was during that time that Japanese troops carried out the atrocity, butchering hundreds of thousands of unarmed Chinese in Nanking, an incident historians have since called the Rape of Nanking because many women were gang raped before being massacred.

Jing pointed out that in 1938, all Western and Chinese media were prohibited from visiting Nanking while those remaining in the city were all purged, "so that for a long period of time not one single newspaper was able to publish normally, not one single Chinese news worker could work normally, and not one single Chinese media outside the city could acquire any news regarding Nanjing."

Foreign missionaries are believed to have been the first to reveal news about Japan's takeover of Nanking and the subsequent massacre in the city. The missionaries had remained in the city at the time. After they told the outside world what was happening, foreign media reported about it.
A few days later, on Dec. 22, 1937, the Central News Agency (CNA), the biggest news wire service of the Republic of China, became the first Chinese language media to report about it, Jing said.
He praised the CNA for surmounting difficulties to report about the incident.
After the CNA broke the news, other Chinese media quickly caught up by quoting those fleeing the city to tell their horrible stories inside the city.
"The ensuing Chinese media reports about the Rape of Nanking were both emotional and numerous -- far outnumbering those by the Western media," Jing said.
Jing said the subject of the media's coverage of one of the bloodiest incidents in China's history was worth in-depth research, according to the China News Service.
He said a look into how the media worked at that time could bridge a gap in the study of the Rape of Nanking and is thus significant academically.

It is not immediately clear, however, whether Jing was able to learn or reveal in his book what other obstacles Chinese language media faced which kept them from immediately reporting about the invasion of Nanking and the subsequent massacre after foreign media had reported about it. enditem/cs nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 13, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."
