DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Fallacy in 'N minus 1' policy

TEXT.P: Outspoken electronics business tycoon Terry Gou recently blasted the government for what he called its passivism in dealing with the development of the flat panel industry, saying such an attitude could stifle local makers in the sector.
Gou was referring to a government regulation that forbids Taiwanese companies from setting up factories in China using technologies more advanced than those employed at home.

The provision, commonly known as the "N minus 1 principle" in the industrial community, stipulates that Taiwan-funded plants in China must technologically be at least one generation behind their parent firms.
This regulation applies to all high-tech industries, with the aim of maintaining Taiwan's technological edge. However, the policy should not have been implemented across the board.

At a time when the U.S. chip giant Intel Corp. has opened a foundry in China using highly advanced nanometer technology, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) still has only lower level production lines there.

The "N minus 1" principle has hindered TSMC's expansion in the vast Chinese market. The company has so far managed to maintain its leading position in the global contract chip realm mainly because of its superb operational efficiency.

Taiwan's display panel makers, however, do not have such an edge. The two largest Taiwanese makers in the field -- Chimei Innolux and AU Optronics (AUO) -- are lagging behind their South Korean rivals, such as Samsung and LG Display, in terms of global market share.

As China has emerged as the world's largest market for medium-size flat panels, Samsung has stepped up its efforts to gain dominance there. The company's efforts have been boosted by China's recent approval of its application to set up a 8.5th-generation plant in the country.

In line with Taiwan's "N minus 1" principle, AUO has submitted a plan to the government to build a 7.5th-generation flat panel plant in China. Although the government is expected to approve the investment plan soon, how can AUO compete with its Korean rival which is using a higher level of technology?

We share Gou's view that the government should give high-tech firms a freer hand in planning their overseas or China-bound investments to maintain their niches in the highly competitive business world. If the "N minus 1" principle is not scrapped, many industries may not experience the "golden decade" that the government has promised. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 13, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek sells over 10,000 notebook computers at tech fair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 11:58:23 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc. said Monday it sold more than 10,000 notebook computers at ICT Month, Taiwan's largest consumer electronics fair, generating over NT$100 million (US$3.32 million) in sales.
This keeps AsusTek in top place in terms of notebook sales for the eighth consecutive year at the high-tech trade exhibition, the company said.
The nine-day Taipei leg of ICT Month, which ended Sunday, attracted more than 850,000 visitors, up from 800,000 recorded in 2009 and 770,000 in 2008.
According to AsusTek, its selling rate for its newly unveiled U series and A42 of models was close to one unit every 30 seconds at the exhibition.
The company said it also sold about 200 units of its 1215 notebook series and more than 200 units of its Eee Note netbooks in the nine days of the trade show.
The tech fair, now in its 31st year, will move to Taichung City in central Taiwan Dec. 17-22 and to Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan Dec. 30-Jan. 4.
AsusTek said it has scheduled a meeting in Taiwan for Tuesday and Wednesday for its global sales managers to review the company's 2010 sales records and set new goals for 2011.
Company Chairman Jonney Shih is expected to preside at the meeting, it said.
AsusTek said sales in Eastern Europe for 2011 are expected to grow 30-40 percent from 2010, and its sales in China are also expected to grow steadily.
The company said it aims to move up one notch next year to become the fourth largest notebook seller in the world.
AsusTek's sales outlook for the first quarter of next year is optimistic, according to a recent report released by U.S. tech giant Intel.
AsusTek posted NT$12.47 billion (US$414 million) in net profit for the first nine months of this year, with an earnings per share (EPS) of NT$19.88, better than the market had expected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan food fair attracts many high-level officials in Belgium
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/10 12:50:16 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan food festival in Brussels last week attracted Belgian parliamentarians and hundreds of officials from the headquarters of the European Union.

The festival, the first of its kind in the Belgian capital where the EU headquarters is located, opened on Dec. 8 with a grand feast prepared by six award-winning chefs from the Taiwan Formosa Chefs Association.
The association was fresh from its success at an international culinary competition in Singapore at which it won 11 gold medals, three silver and seven bronze.
More than 220 European officials attended the opening-day feast, which was presented like a state banquet and featured gourmet dishes with a distinct Taiwanese flair.
In the following three days, the event also attracted more than 330 other dignitatries, including politicians, prominent educators and medical doctors, as well as Taiwanese living in Belgium.

It was organized by the Taiwan government to say thanks to the Belgian parliament for its support for Taiwan over the past year, according to the Taipei Representative Office in the European Union and Belgium.
Representative Lin Yung-lo said this support helped Taiwan to acquire EU visa- free preferential treatment that will take effect early next year.
The Taiwan food festival will move next to Berlin, Germany as part of Taiwan's efforts to showcase its cuisine and cement its ties with its European friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.2 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 15:19:51 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.20 percent Monday after profit taking emerged to erode early gains led by the high-tech sector, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 17.76 points to 8,736.59, after moving between 8,736.54 and 8,764.51, on turnover of NT$126.63 billion (US$4.20 billion).

The market opened up 0.37 percent and extended the gains to the day's high as buying was ignited by high hopes that the government will soon allow flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) to build a 7.5th-generation plant in China, the dealers said.
However, as the index moved closer to the nearest resistance at 8,800 points, investors tended to pocket their recent gains to compromise the upside, they said.
A total of 2,318 stocks closed up and 1,820 were down, with 405 remaining unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector scored the highest gains, finishing up 0.7 percent. Construction shares rose 0.6 percent, while foodstuffs, textiles, plastics and chemicals, and machinery and electronics stocks all ended up 0.2 percent.
The financial sector rose 0.1 percent but cement shares fell 0.2 percent.

"The flat panel sector has consolidated for the long term and investors just seized the upbeat mood about AUO's China investment proposal to pick up bargains, " Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said.
AUO is seeking approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs to spend US$3 billion to build a flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province.
Last week, the ministry said AUO is expected to obtain approval soon since the project has passed critical screening of the key technology involved in the investment.
AUO rose 2.99 percent to close at NT$31.00, while rival Chimei Innolux rose 0.52 percent to end the day at NT$38.95.

Huang said that as foreign institutional investors kept moving funds into the local bourse to boost their high-tech holdings, it is expected that the bellwether electronics sector will serve as a driver to push the market even higher.
"But, ahead of the 8,800-8,850 point range, the market might face some pressure to limit the gains," Huang said.
Among the old economy stocks, Chung Hwa Pulp added 3.16 percent to finish at NT$16.30 and Prince Housing gained 1.86 percent to close at NT$24.70.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Anti-bullying legislation in the works

TEXT.P: Vice Education Minister Wu Tsai-shun said Sunday his ministry will study the feasibility of introducing legislation to more effectively prevent bullying on school campuses.
Wu's announcement came in the wake of a string of bullying incidents reported in schools across Taiwan. In some cases, the brutality employed gave rise to great concern in local society.
Wu said the Ministry of Education (MOE) began to implement a new program last week that requires school authorities to pay more attention to reports of bullying.

According to the results of a 2008 survey conducted in Taipei City, 3,378 students claimed they had been beaten or blackmailed on school campuses. However, the MOE data showed that only 24 such cases were reported to the ministry that year.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Wu said his ministry convened a meeting of representatives from 25 cities and counties around the country last Thursday, during which a campus bullying prevention program was introduced with immediate effect.

Under the program, school authorities are required to call a meeting whenever they receive a complaint of bullying and seek to determine the facts. Furthermore, professional experts from outside the school should be invited to participate in the evaluation meeting, the new plan specifies.

Once it is determined that the reported incident constitutes bullying, the victims and perpetrators should be referred to a specially established panel within the school for counselling, according to the plan.
In the past, schools tended to deal with such cases by giving the bullies a demerit.
Wu said the MOE has also set up a hotline 0800-200885 for reports of campus bullying.

"We will ask the city and county governments, as well as the schools, to install similar hot lines, " Wu said, adding that school efforts in this regard will be included in the annual review of school administrations and campus management.
School principals who cover up incidents of bullying will be given a lower performance rating, Wu said.
Although Taiwan has a Juvenile Delinquency Act, there is no law that deals exclusively with bullying in schools.

"After studying the measures adopted in 15 major countries around the world, including the United States and Canada, the MOE has decided to draft a bill on the prevention of bullying on school campuses," Wu said.

Many lawmakers from across the political spectrum have voiced support for the proposed bill that would pave the way for for more effective measures against violence in schools, Wu said. (Dec. 13, 2010).
China Times:

Wang Fu-lin, director of the MOE's Department of Military Training Education, said the apathy and insensitivity of school administrators toward the problem of bullying is the main reason why the number of incidents have continued to rise.
Under the MOE's new disciplinary program, the effectiveness of schools' efforts to prevent bullying will be included in the principals' performance evaluations.
If principals do not tackle the problem or report incidents in time, it could affect their ratings and their retention for another term, Wang said.
Local governments will also be punished if they do not take steps to deal with violence in schools, he added.
Lee Ming-shien, project director of the MOE's campus safety enhancement program, said it would require a special law to make it mandatory for bullies to be separated from other students.

However, some education experts have voiced opposition to the mandatory separation proposal. They said education is a "project of hope" that requires schools to help students realize their life dreams.
Mandatory separation would be contrary to the purpose of education, and bullies are the first students that should receive help within the school system, the experts said.
School administrators and faculties should instead put more into helping school bullies, the experts said. (Dec. 13, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO China project approval by year-end: Economics Ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 17:15:18 (By Lin Shu-yuan, Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang confirmed Monday that the government is expected to give the green light to a China investment project by flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) by the end of this year.

"As the project will involve a large amount of investment, the ministry might call a special meeting to review the project before issuing its approval, " Shih told lawmakers in a legislative interpellation session.
AUO has submitted an application with the MOEA and has since March been seeking regulatory approval to build a 7.5th-generation flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province.

To assure the government that the company will maintain its technological lead over its Chinese facility and its long-term commitment to Taiwan, AUO also plans to invest NT$400 billion (US$13.28 billion) in building two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park.
Late last week, the Investment Commission under the MOEA said the project had passed critical screening of the key technology involved in the investment.
The project is pending the screening of various additional formalities before final approval is issued by the commission.

Shih said that as AUO has promised it will invest NT$400 billion in central Taiwan -- a massive investment that is expected to create thousands of jobs -- its China project is unlikely to lead to job losses in Taiwan.
In February, the government relaxed the rules governing high-tech investment in China by allowing flat panel makers to build up to three 6th-generation or above plants there.
However, applicants must assure the authorities that they can maintain a technological lead over any facilities they open in China and they must promise to continue to invest in Taiwan.
Since AUO is operating an 8.5th-generation flat panel plant in Taiwan, its application to set up a 7.5th-generation plant met with the government's requirements, Shih said.
While the government allows flat panel makers to open production facilities in China, Shih said, the government has proposed strategies to expand the local TFT LCD sector over the next 10 years.
Shih said the government remains optimistic about the outlook for the local TFT- LCD business and will not stop its efforts to further develop the sector.

WitsView, a Taiwan-based high-tech research institute, said there is no rush for local flat panel makers to relocate their investments in China at the moment, as the global flat panel sector is still suffering from a production glut.
However, China investments will no doubt help local makers to correctly feel the pulse of the growing Chinese market in the long run, according to WitsView.

DOC.HEADLINE: Auto industries in Taiwan, China eye electronics, new energies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 17:33:10 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The automobile industries in Taiwan and China have formed a special task force targeting the development of automotive electronics and new energy forms as part of their efforts to enter the global market.

The formation of the cross-Taiwan Strait vehicle industrial working group was aimed at intensifying exchanges in the industry, the academic sector and the research and development for automotive electronics and new energy vehicles, Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs' Department of Industrial Technology said in a statement Sunday.

The establishment came at the Dec. 10-11 Cross-Strait Automobile Industrial Cooperation Convention, which was attended by more than 300 experts on policies, technologies and research and development in the industry.
The convention featured discussions on new energy technologies and telematics -- which apply information and communications technology to vehicles for improved safety.

"Through more collaboration in industrial technology, the two sides will be able to enter the world market by jointly focusing on technology upgrading, innovation and branding, complementary relationships and proper division of labor, as well as co-marketing to boost product value, " said Lin Chuan-neng, deputy director of the department, at the event.
The two sides have promised to help Chinese companies invest in Taiwan and to help Taiwan's auto parts companies become part of the supply chain in China.
Last year marked the first time the two sides had held such an event for the automobile industry.

A letter of intent signed at the last year's event paved the way for the establishment of four working groups between Taiwan's Automotive Research and Testing Center (ARTC) and the China Automotive Technology and Research Center in September this year.
The working groups focus on cooperation in regulations, standardizations and testing for regular vehicles and for electric vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 17:43:54 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.015 to close at the day's high of NT$30.600.
Turnover totaled US$480 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.585 and moved to a low of NT$30.030 before rebounding.
Dealers said the value of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar was boosted by further inflows of foreign funds during almost the whole of the trading session.
A rising local bourse lent additional support to the New Taiwan dollar to push the currency to the day's high before the central bank stepped in to cap the appreciation, they said.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.20 percent at 8,736.59 as foreign institutional investors kept moving funds into Taiwan, picking up bargains in the bellwether electronics sector.

Buying in the New Taiwan dollar largely came from foreign banks that were betting on further appreciation of the local currency amid a spillover effect from excessive liquidity in the U.S. market, the dealers said.
With the approach of the Christmas holiday season, more and more foreign traders have retreated from the trading floor, which has pushed down trading volume, they said.
They added that the quiet trade made it easier for the central bank to intervene in late trading to maintain the value of the U.S. dollar above the NT$30.50 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker, officials differ on handling of national holidays
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 17:50:39 (By Justine Su and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Workers in Taiwan do not get extra time off for national holidays if they fall on weekends, but a Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker is hoping to change in legislation that would turn administrative guidelines on holidays into a formal statute.

"It would deprive people of the right to take vacation" if under the new statute people were not given days off to make up for the holidays missed, Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said at a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary, Organic Laws and Statutes Committee.

Wu's view, however, was not shared by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), which said the existing system for civil servants was necessary to avoid creating too big a gap between public and private sector vacation time.
Taiwan's civil servants currently have weekends (Saturday and Sunday) and national holidays off.
But existing guidelines stipulate that if a national holiday (except for the Chinese New Year break) falls on a weekend, it will not be made up. Most companies in Taiwan follow this formula.
The MOI included this stipulation in its draft bill on "commemorative days and holidays, " but Wu and other lawmakers have raised objections to the measure.

Urging the government and companies to stop "taking advantage of the people, " Wu argued that making up a weekend holiday on a Friday or Monday and creating a long weekend would also be good for the local economy.

MOI Vice Minister Lin Tsyr-ling countered, however, that adding more days off for civil servants would only widen the gap in the number of holidays taken between workers in the public and private sectors.

There will be 115 vacation days next year, including weekends, Lin said, and if people wanted more, the government also needed to consider if such a demand would jeopardize the country's industrial and commercial development.
MOI surveys indicate that most people in the country support the idea of maintaining the current practice, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister raps S. Korean company for snitching on Taiwan firms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 18:17:26 (By Lin Shu-yuan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A senior official on Monday accused South Korea's Samsung Corp. of having acted "unethically" by snitching on Taiwanese firms during a European Commission anti-trust investigation.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang made the remark in response to a legislator's question on the European Commission's probe into an alleged price- fixing scheme involving several Asian flat panel manufacturers.
Shih said Samsung's offer to the European investigators to turn "tainted witness" in exchange for immunity was an unethical act.
Four Taiwanese companies and another South Korean enterprise were implicated and fined heavily last Wednesday by the European Commission.

A total fine of 649 million euros (US$857.85 million) was imposed on LG Display of South Korea and Chimei Innolux Corp., AU Optronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes Ltd. and HannStar Display Corp. of Taiwan for fixing flat panel prices between Oct. 5, 2001 and Feb. 1, 2006.
The fine on the four Taiwanese firms amounted to 433.92 million euro (NT$17.3 billion).
According to Legislator Lee Ching-hua of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who raised the question, Samsung and LG of South Korea were the the two companies most likely to manipulate flat panel prices.
"Have you ever watched a Korean TV drama titled 'Sangdo' or 'The Commercial Ethics'?" he asked Shih.
Shih agreed that Samsung's action of turning informant was not in accord with its own commercial ethics.
"This should not have been done," he said.
However, for the time being, Taiwan will not impose any special restrictions on imports from South Korea, he said.
The minister reiterated the government's support for the Taiwanese manufacturers and its willingness to help them deal with the new rules of competition in the world market.

The four Taiwanese firms have not yet received official notice of the EU decision, Shih said, adding that the government will try to help the companies to handle the fallout as soon as they make such a request.
Shih pointed out that the government has drafted a 10-year plan for developing Taiwan's display panel industry, whose global market share is equal to its South Korean counterpart.

"We will invite executives of the four companies and officials from relevant government agencies to a brainstorming session next week to hammer out some response strategies, " the Ministry of Economics Affairs said in a statement last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: No mad cow disease in Taiwan: health minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 18:48:15 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Health minister Yaung Chih-liang reiterated Monday that the government did not try to conceal the case of a Taiwanese man who died in May from what is suspected to have been mad cow disease.

The Department of Health (DOH) has come under fire since last Thursday when it was revealed that the 36-year-old Taiwanese man had died from what appeared to have been Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD).
CJD is a fatal degenerative brain disease linked to the consumption of infected tissues from cattle with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), commonly known as mad cow disease.
Fielding questions from legislators, Yaung said that Taiwan is a BSE-free country and has been vigilant in guarding against the disease, despite the recent fatality.
Taiwan has no cases of mad cow disease so how can we conceal something that doesn't exist," he said.

According to Yaung, the man lived in Manchester, England from 1978 to 1997 during the peak of the mad cow disease outbreak in the UK. The man reportedly displayed symptoms such as hypersomania and memory loss and was reported to the DOH on March 2009 as a suspected case of CJD.
The man died in May of this year and his body was immediately cremated.
An autopsy was not conducted to determine the cause of death because the family of the deceased refused to give consent, Yaung said.

When asked by legislators why the government did not force the autopsy issue, Yaung said even if CDJ was the cause of death, it was not a communicable disease easily transmitted between people through contact.
It is virtually impossible to conclude that the man indeed died of CJD, he said.

Yaung's responses elicited strong criticism from Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers who insisted that the DOH had deliberately concealed the facts of the case to avoid upending a government decision to lift the ban on U.S. beef.

Last October, Taiwan reopened its market to U.S. bone-in beef from cattle under 30 months of age. The decision encountered strong opposition from the DPP and consumer groups, which expressed worry that the government was exposing the public to a serious health risk.
DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin said although the suspected CJD death occurred before Yaung was health minister, the DOH should have kept a record of it.

"It is hard to fathom why such an important case would go unnoticed by the DOH and the Bureau of National Health Insurance, " she said. "If the case had been publicized earlier, the government would have had more bargaining power in the face of U.S. pressure to lift the beef ban."
But Yaung said the man most likely fell ill after the consumption of beef in the UK and therefore the case had nothing to do with U.S. beef.
Taiwan does not import any beef products from the UK, he pointed out.
"We can't control what our people eat when they are in another country. But I can say this was an isolated incident and not a pandemic," he said.
Kuomintang Legislator Cheng Li-wen supported Yaung's arguments, saying that although the case was overblown by the media, there has not been much public reaction.
"If we were to do a survey on the sale of U.S. beef in Taiwan before and after the news (of the man's death) broke, I am quite certain we won't see much of a difference," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu's win over Roddick at Wimbledon biggest upset of 2010: ATP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 18:55:05 (by Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis pro Lu Yen-hsun's surprise victory over former world No. 1 Andy Roddick at Wimbledon in late June was chosen as the Biggest Upset of the Year of 2010 by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) on Monday.

Lu became the first Asian man since Japan's Shuzo Matsuoka at Wimbledon in 1995 to reach the quarterfinals of a grand slam tournament after defeating Roddick, 4-6, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (4), 6-7 (5), 9-7 in four hours and 36 minutes, qualifying the match as the biggest upset of the year.

Lu entered the match ranked 82nd in the world and had done little in the run-up to the tournament to suggest he would challenge Roddick, a finalist at Wimbledon the previous year who was picked by some to win the grasscourt event in 2010.
Lu had also lost all three of his previous meetings with Roddick.

"(But) in an inspired performance from the then-26-year-old, though, Lu struck 83 winners and broke Roddick's serve for the only time in the match in the final game to seal the dramatic victory, which he dedicated to his father who passed away in 2000, " the ATP's website said.
The ATP selected Australian Lleyton Hewitt's victory over Swiss Roger Federer in the Halle Final 3-6, 7-6 (4) , 6-4, as the second biggest upset of the year.

Upon beating Federer, the former world No. 1 Hewitt said he was thrilled to have defeated Federer -- a six-time Wimbledon champion and five-time Halle winner -- as he was getting toward the end of his career, according to the ATP.

Meanwhile, Lu, who broke into the top 50 for the first time in his career after his stunning run in London, is now in Kenya training with other players who are coached or managed by Dirk Hordorff, who has mentored Lu since 2003.

The 27-year-old is expected to return to Taiwan at the end of December and participate in two exhibitions featuring Andre Agassi and Marat Safin in Taiwan in early January before heading to Australia for the first grand slam of the season.
He is currently ranked 35th in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of China-based pneumatic firm rally on TWSE debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 19:06:34 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of AirTac International Group, a China-based pneumatic product maker, staged a rally on the first trading day of its primary listing on the main board of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday amid optimism toward its earnings outlook in the fast-growing China market, dealers said.
AirTac closed at NT$138.00 (US$4.58) , up 56.8 percent from its listing price of NT$88.00, with 8.66 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index rose 0.20 percent to 8,736.59.
"The market expects the company to enjoy about 20 percent growth in its bottom line thanks to strong demand in the huge China market," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
AirTac, which was set up in 1988, runs production facilities in China that churn out a wide range of pneumatic products, including pneumatic control components and actuators.
Its products, sold under the AirTac brand, are used in the production of automation equipment for the electronics, electrical, auto, transport, food and mechanical sectors, the company said.
China accounts for almost of 90 percent of AirTac's total revenue, the company added.

"As China is going to launch its 12th five-year economic development plan next year, which will boost its auto industry, I expect demand from auto makers for pneumatic products to rise significantly," Hsu said.
"The company has great potential for growth," he said.
According to Hsu, AirTac ranks as the second-largest pneumatic product maker in China, commanding a market share of more than 20 percent.
In the first three quarters of this year, AirTac posted an earnings per share (EPS) of NT$6.7 after registering an EPS of NT$7.1 for the whole of 2009.
"The market has a consensus that AirTac will generate an EPS of no less than NT$9.0 for 2010 rising to NT$11 for 2011, " said Hsu.

Hsu said based on the fundamentals, the listing price of NT$88 was relatively low, so it was no surprise that the stock shot up as soon as the market opened, with momentum maintained until the end of the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese urged to learn more about Liu Xiaobo
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/10 19:34:38 (By Lin Yu-li & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The author of a biography on Liu Xiaobo urged people in Taiwan on Sunday to find out more about the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize winner and his extensive connections with Taiwan.
The biography, written by exiled Chinese writer Bei Ling in 47 days, was published in Germany on the eve of the Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony last Friday.
Munich-based publisher Riva Verlag, with the encouragement of European Union authorities, printed 15,000 copies of the biography in its first run.
Although Liu has authored about a dozen books, few of them can be found in bookstores in Western countries, Bei said.
Part of the biography, he said, highlights Liu's connection with Taiwan.

It includes many of Liu's articles written soon after the 1989 Tiananmen Incident that were carried by the Taipei-based China Times newspaper and also tells the story of Yu Chi-chung, the late founder of the daily, giving Liu US$60,000 to help him publish his memoir titled "Monologue: Survivors of Doomsday."
Several of Liu's works related to ideology, including his most recent work -- "Sinking of Big Country: Memorandum to China" -- have also been published in Taiwan.
"Taiwan has served as the most important publishing base for Liu," Bei said.
Liu was arrested in December 2009 on the eve of the release of "Charter 08, " a blueprint Liu co-authored with about 300 people from across all spectrums of Chinese society.

The document called for an end to the Communist Party of China's dominance of the government, military and courts, protection of freedom of speech and religious beliefs, and the implementation of constitutional democracy in China

In interviews with the Central News Agency before the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Liu said he was very interested in Taiwan's democratic development and felt it could serve as "an enlightenment or a model" for China.
"I'm very curious about what the younger generation of Taiwan has been thinking and doing, as this would be a key indicator of the direction in which Taiwan will move," he said at the time.
Bei praised President Ma Ying-jeou's call on the day of the Nobel award ceremony for Liu's early release.

Both Liu, who is being held in a prison in Liaoling Province, and his wife, Liu Xia, were barred from attending the award ceremony held in Oslo, Norway, and the chair where the Nobel Prize winner would normally sit was left empty.

Bei said the "empty seat" signaled the big gap between the " real China and universal values" and would produce "unlimited" influence in the home country of the Nobel laureate, whether he is behind bars or in exile in a foreign country.

Bei, who now lives in Germany, said he planned some additions to the biography that will lengthen it to 200,000 words, and will have it republished in Taiwan with a new title -- "Liu Xiaobo: A Side Profile" -- next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: New buyer for Taiwan's Nan Shan Life possible
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 19:49:19 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., a Taiwan-based subsidiary owned by American International Group (AIG) , declined Monday to confirm the total number of companies involved in bidding to buy the firm after an anonymous buyer was reported to have offered a bid.

According to a report in the Monday edition of the Economic Daily News, the government-funded buyer directly filed a bid of about NT$91.7 billion (US$3 billion) with AIG's headquarters in the United States early this month.

Market sources said the new buyer is likely to be either Taiwan Financial Holding Co. or First Financial Holding Co., according to the newspaper. However, both companies categorically denied being involved.

Nan Shan's spokeswoman, Amanda Chou, told CNA on the sidelines of a charity activity that she could not confirm the total number of companies that have submitted bids due to confidentiality agreements signed between AIG and the potential buyers.
"We have heard many rumors about potential buyers, but we have to stay neutral to make the bid fair to all contenders," Chou said.

On Dec. 3, two of Taiwan's major financial service providers, Cathay Financial Holding Co. and Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., said in a statement to the Taiwan Stock Exchange that they had decided to bid for AIG's 97.57-percent stake in Nan Shan.
Fubon Financial Holding Co., the country's second-largest financial services provider that is widely expected to make a similar move, said it had also tendered a bid.

Ruenchen Investment Holding Co., a new joint venture created by Ruentex Industries Ltd., Ruentex Development Co. and Pou Chen Corp. for the bid, also said in a stock exchange statement that it had joined the bidding process.

Local news reports said that Primus Financial Holdings, a Hong Kong-based firm that tendered the winning bid for Nan Shan in an earlier attempted sale in 2009 but was rejected in October this year by Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), would submit its bid again.
Established in 1963, Nan Shan has a net worth of NT$140.3 billion (US$4.63 billion) , accounting for over 30 percent of the local life insurance market.

DOC.HEADLINE: More steps to be taken to stem campus bullying: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 19:55:36 (By Lin Szu-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Local governments might see their grants cut if they fail to more actively address campus bullying in schools in their districts, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday.
"This is one of the measures being considered amid increasing instances of school violence in our country, " said Wang Fu-lin, director of the MOE's Department of Military Training Education.
Noting that the ministry has set up a hotline to accept reports of campus bullying, Wang said that city and local governments will be required to follow suit.

In an effort to reduce and eventually eliminate bullying in schools, Wang said, Minister of Education Wu Ching-chi will convene a brainstorming meeting later this week to hammer out more effective action plans.

Education department heads in 25 cities and counties around the country, as well as officials from the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Agency and other relevant government organs, will be invited to the meeting, he went on.

The meeting will come in the wake of a string of bullying incidents reported in schools around Taiwan in recent months. In some cases, the extent of the brutality employed has given rise to great concern in local society.
Wang said apathy and insensitivity on the part of school administrators toward the problem of bullying is the main reason why the number of incidents has continued to rise.
Citing the findings of an MOE investigation, Wang said that an estimated 2 percent of junior high school students have been bullied.
Based on this ratio, he went on, more than 10,000 of the country's 950,000 junior high students have fallen victim to bullying.
"We have received, however, only a few score of bullying cases through our campus safety reporting channels," Wang said.

The ministry is now considering implementing a new program that will require school authorities to call an evaluation meeting whenever they receive a complaint of bullying and seek to determine the facts, Wang said.
In addition, education professionals from outside the school should be invited to participate in the evaluation meeting, the new plan specifies.

Once it is determined that the reported incident constitutes bullying, the victim and perpetrator should be referred to a specially established panel within the school for counselling, according to the plan.
If school principals do not tackle the problem or report such incidents in a timely manner, it could affect their ratings and whether they are retained in their posts, Wang said.

On media reports that some lawmakers have proposed that a special law be enacted to make it mandatory for serious bullies to be separated from other students, Wang said feasibility studies should be carried out before such a move can be contemplated.

Many education experts, however, have voiced opposition to the mandatory separation proposal. They said education is a "project of hope" that requires schools to help students realize their life dreams.
Mandatory separation would be contrary to the purpose of education, and bullies are the first students that should receive help within the school system, according to the experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma touts Taiwan's bids for access to international organizations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 19:57:55 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Monday sought foreign allies' support for Taiwan's bids for meaningful participation in activities held by United Nations organizations.
Taiwan hopes it can take part in events hosted by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and in meetings on the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Ma said.
He said participating in international activities helps maintain and promote "the welfare and the safety of the Taiwanese people" and allows Taiwan to stay abreast of world trends.
Ma addressed Taiwan's bids for access to the ICAO and UNFCCC during a meeting at the Presidential Office with visiting U.N. representatives of Palau, Tuvalu, Belize and El Salvador.
Those nations are among the 23 countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Speaking of the ICAO bid, Ma said Taiwan has some of the busiest air traffic in East Asia and that the country should have closer contact with the international civil aviation regulatory body, as such links would facilitate the development of Taiwan's air industry and its efforts to promote aviation safety.

In terms of the UNFCCC, Ma said that in the face of the trend of extreme weather that has made Taiwan the victim of some of the most frequent natural disasters in the world, the country would very much like to have UNFCCC links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese credit cards to feature NBA stars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 20:17:46 (by Tian Yu-pin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Cathay Financial Holding Co. will soon issue credit cards and other financial products and souvenirs featuring top National Basketball Association (NBA) players, the company announced on Monday.

Under an agreement it reached with the league, Cathay Financial Holdings' businesses in the banking, insurance, securities brokerage and venture capital sectors will be the only financial services companies in Taiwan allowed to use pictures of NBA players and team logos on their products or to promote their business.
The Cathay group is expected to pay the NBA over NT$10 million (US$333,000) in royalties over a period of three years for the exclusive rights.

A first set of three Cathay credit cards featuring the NBA logo and six NBA stars is expected to be issued after the 2011 Chinese New Year, said Allen Peng, a senior vice president with Cathay Financial Holdings subsidiary Cathay United Bank Co.

The first six NBA stars to appear on Taiwanese credit cards will be Dwight Howard of the Orlando Magic, Dwyane Wade of the Miami Heat, Kobe Bryant of the Los Angeles Lakers, Kevin Durant of the Oklahoma City Thunder, Carmelo Anthony of the Denver Nuggets, and Taiwanese-American Jeremy Lin of the Golden State Warriors, according to Peng.
Cathay United Bank currently has over 3 million credit cards in circulation, the second highest total of any bank in Taiwan, according to Peng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan student enjoys Israeli hospitality
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 20:25:52 (By Lee Shien-feng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese student who recently completed an exchange program in Israel said on Monday that Israelis were mostly warm and hospital, just like the Taiwanese.

Tang Ko-tien shared her experiences in Israel on the sideline of a ceremony in which officials representing Taiwan and Israel signed a memorandum of understanding on youth affairs between the two countries.

She said she would never forget Israeli shop owners who, after being told by her host family that she was from Taiwan, enthusiastically introduced local food to her and invited her to taste some free of charge.
After experiencing Israelis' lifestyle and culture, Tang, a student of Yang Ming Senior High School in Taipei, said she found that "the Israeli people are warm and hospital like us."
She and Lin Yun, of National Taiwan University, were among 10 Taiwanese students who were part of two groups invited in the past two years to visit Israel.
Simona Halperin, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, signed the MOU on behalf of the Israeli government.
She said her country began hosting an annual International Youth Environmental Leadership Conference last year to which young people from Taiwan, Germany and the Netherlands were invited.
National Youth Commission Minister Wang Yu-ting, also present to witness the signing of the MOU, said the pact turned a new page in youth exchanges between the two countries.

In conjunction with the government's plan to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, she said her commission will invite Israeli youth to experience Taiwan's culture and share with Taiwan's people their love of peace, freedom and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military nixes turning Kinmen tunnel into running race sight
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 21:17:24 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military rejected on Monday a proposal to allow one of its defense installations on Kinmen to be used as a venue for a running race during next year's Republic of China centennial celebration.
The Kinmen County government suggested transforming the world-class Central Tunnel that runs through Mt. Taiwu, the highest mountain on the former frontline island, into a temporary sports venue.
The venue would showcase Kinmen's transition from a military outpost to tourist destination, said Kinmen County Education Bureau Director Lee Tzai-hang.
He also said it would symbolize Kinmen's emergence from the shadow of war into the light of peace.
But Kinmen Defense Command officer Wu Fu-kuo said the tunnel, part of an underground tunnel network, was still a key military installation that was not open to the public.
The underground tunnels played a key role in Kinmen's resistance against Communist China's extensive shelling of the island in 1958.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady's sentence set at 17 1/2 years
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 22:18:43 (by Lin Chang-shun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ruled Monday that former first lady Wu Shu-jen should serve a total of 17 1/2 years in jail after being convicted on corruption charges in two separate cases.
The high court also decided that Wu should be fined a total of NT$154 million (US$5.13 million) for her offenses, which took place while her husband, Chen Shui-bian, was serving as president.
Wu's prison term and fines were identical to those handed down by the high court earlier this month against the former president, who was convicted on the same charges as his wife.

The Taiwan High Court was deciding whether three separate sentences handed down against Wu by Taiwan's Supreme Court on Nov. 11 totaling 19 years and seven months should be served concurrently or consecutively.
The Supreme Court sentenced the former first lady to 11 years in prison for taking bribes in exchange for arranging a favorable land deal for a businessman.

She was also given an eight-year sentence for accepting payments from a businesswoman to help her secure the chairmanship of Taipei 101 owned by the Taipei Financial Center Corporation and a seven-month sentence on a money laundering conviction in connection to the case.
After reviewing the cases, the high court panel of judges combined the three sentences into a 17 1/2-year jail term.
Despite the ruling, a high court spokesman said it had yet to be determined whether the frail Wu, who uses a wheelchair, will actually serve time in jail.
The Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office will refer Wu's medical records to the Ministry of Justice and the Taichung Prison's Pei Teh Hospital to be reviewed before deciding whether she is jailed.
If it is determined that Wu's health allows her to be incarcerated, she would mostly likely end up at the Taichung Prison hospital, the high court spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Moderate growth seen for all-in-one PC shipments: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 22:36:32 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Global shipments of all-in-one computers (AIO PCs) will grow at a moderate pace in the coming years as they command a growing share of the overall personal computer market, market tracker Digitimes Research said on Monday.

Shipments of AIO PCs, which combine monitor and PC components in a single unit, will reach an estimated 10.5 million units this year and 14 million units in 2011, according to a report released by Digitimes Research.
The market researcher projected the penetration rate of AIOs in the personal computer market to grow from this year's 8 percent to 10 percent in 2011, 13 percent in 2012 and 16 percent in 2013.

"AIO PCs are welcomed by mature markets such as Japan, the United States and Europe, because consumers in these countries prefer PC models that look more advanced, " Joanne Chien, senior analyst and director of Digitimes Research, said in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency.

But PC brands apart from Lenovo and Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP) have not yet been very active in developing AIOs, which may lead to stiff competition among Taiwan-based manufacturers for contract orders, Chien said.
Pegatron Technology Corp., a manufacturing arm of Asustek Computer Inc. that was spun off earlier this year, is expected to be one of the main beneficiaries of the growing market, the report said.
It will ship an estimated 2.6 million AIOs in 2011 to gain an 18 percent share of the 2011 contract AIO market, trailing only Quanta Computer Inc., the report said.
"The split will help Pegatron devote itself to contract manufacturing, and more than 40 percent of Pegatron's orders next year will come from HP," Chien said.

TPV-Inventec, a joint venture founded in 2009 by Hong Kong's TPV Technology Ltd. and Taiwan's Inventec Corp., will also increase its shipments from 900,000 units in 2010 to 1.8 million units next year, making the company the third largest AIO contractor in the coming year.
HP and Levono will account for about 50 percent and 25 percent respectively of TPV-Inventec's AIO orders in 2011, enabling the company to double its AIO shipments, Chien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yang Shu-chun to head for Seoul over disqualification row
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 23:01:20 (By Posan Hsiao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation will depart for Seoul Friday to attend a meeting of the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) disciplinary committee on an Asian Games disqualification dispute involving one of Taiwan's top competitors.

Among the delegation members is Yang Shu-chun, who was disqualified from the women's under 49-kilogram division in the taekwondo competition at the Asiad in Guangzhou, China on Nov. 17 for allegedly wearing extra sensors in her socks in an attempt to score more points.
Yang will be accompanied by Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) President Chen Chien-ping and her two coaches, Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, CTTA Secretary-General Ho Feng-yen said Monday.

"They will attend a WTF disciplinary committee meeting scheduled for Dec. 18 and present written testimony in hopes of getting a fair solution to the dispute, " Ho said, adding that the delegation will return to Taipei that same day.
The 25-year-old athlete, who was one Taiwan's top hopes for a gold medal at the Asiad, was disqualified during her opening bout for using the extra sensors, according to taekwondo officials.

Video footage of the match released later showed, however, that Yang was not wearing the sensors during the bout. Inconsistent explanations by WTF and Asian Taekwondo Union (ATU) officials of why Yang was disqualified have added to the controversy.

Taiwan filed a protest over the decision with the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) but also vowed to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if other appeals failed to provide a satisfactory outcome.
The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) commissioned the law firm Lee and Li Attorneys- at-Law to file an appeal with the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) on Dec. 8 for Yang's controversial dismissal.
SAC Vice Minister Steven S. K. Chen said last Friday that Taiwan could withdraw the arbitration appeal if the WTF issues an acceptable statement after its Dec. 18 meeting.
Major South Korean newspapers have prominently covered the disqualification row, which they said has stalked anti-Korean sentiment among ordinary Taiwanese people.

The sentiment was exacerbated by reports over the weekend that Korean electronics company Samsung provided evidence in the European Union's price- fixing probe against four Taiwanese display panel makers that led to stiff fines against them.

Samsung, the world's largest flat panel maker, was also allegedly part of the price-fixing cartel and may have even led the group, but because it tipped off authorities in Europe to the behavior, it was not disciplined in the case.

The Korean news agency Yonhap said in an editorial Friday that Taiwan's anti- Korean sentiment could pose a diplomatic crisis for South Korea. It urged the Korean government to consider how to maintain friendly ties with Taiwan in the wake of these incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics denies 'secret deal' on core leadership
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 23:05:18 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based petrochemical giant Formosa Plastics Group categorically denied Monday that the seven members in its core leadership have signed a secret deal to retire by 2015.
Media reports to that effect were groundless and fabricated by individual reporters, the group said in a statement.
The group's leadership succession recently became a hot issue in Taiwan following three major fires affecting workplace safety in its factories in southern Taiwan.

A media report said Monday that the seven members of the group's "administrative center" or core leadership signed a secret deal agreeing to hand their executive power over to a new generation of managers before 2015.

It said the so-called "seven-member core leadership" was composed of the chairpersons of the group's four major corporations, four members of the Wang family (two of whom also head two of the four major companies) and the general manager of the Group Administration Office.
All of the seven were appointed by Wang Yung-ching and Wang Yung-tsai, founders of the group.

Currently the four Wang family members are Sandy Wang, Susan Wang, Wilfred Wang and Wang Wen-yuan. The latter two serve as the chairmen of Formosa Petrochemical Corp. and Formosa Chemical and Fiber Corp., respectively.
The other three are Nan Ya Plastics Corp. Chairman Wu Chin-jen, Formosa Plastics Corp. Chairman Lee Chih-tsuen, and Yang Chao-lin, the head of the Group Administration Office.
The group said the chairpersons of the four major corporations were all elected by their respective board of directors and supervisors who were voted into office by the shareholders.
If there were any changes of board chairpersons, their replacements would automatically join the seven-member core leadership, the statement said.
Media reports said Wang Yung-tsai did not have a high level of respect for senior staff members, who had worked under the two founders, until the recent safety incidents.

The statement said that after Wang Yung-ching passed away, some senior staff members did try to retire, but Wang Yung-tsai did all he could to retain them as their services were critical to the group.

In the wake of the safety incidents, they no longer indicated an intention to retire as they all wanted to work harder together for the growth and development of the Formosa Plastics Group, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Modified health insurance premium plan to include capital gains
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/10 23:27:48 (By Chen Li-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Monday that capital gains will be included in the formula to calculate premiums under a modified proposal to reform the debt-ridden national health insurance system.

Yaung was reporting to the Executive Yuan and the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang on his modified premium proposal after apparently scrapping a long-held plan to calculate health insurance premiums on the basis of overall household income last week.

Yaung said the modified proposal would preserve the merits of the existing system but would move toward taking care of families and including capital gains to broaden the income base on which premiums are figured.
At present, health insurance premiums are calculated based on an individual's basic monthly salary and wages, with all other forms of unearned income and fees excluded.

According to participants at the meeting, several legislators asked Yaung to not only to broaden the system's revenue base but also work actively to plug losses from medical waste and estimate how much money could be saved each year.
The participants said the capital gains initially targeted would be those that are easily identified and of significant amounts.
Service income and fees earned by professionals such as lawyers, which are currently not classified as salary and are therefore not subject to premium calculations, could be included in the new plan.
But overtime payments or year-end bonuses earned by laborers could be excluded, reflecting the DOH's effort to prevent putting too much of the revenue burden on low-income earners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 14, 2010, or the ninth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."
