DOC.HEADLINE: Shin Kong Bank to open HK branch in six months
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 11:54:12 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shin Kong Commercial Bank, a wholly-owned unit of Shin Kong Financial Holding Co., said Tuesday it plans to open a full-service branch in Hong Kong in six months.
The bank said it was granted a license for the branch by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority on Dec. 10 after submitting an application in November 2009 to enter the territory.
The bank is now gearing up for preparation of the establishment of the Hong Kong branch, including deciding where it will be located, it said.
The Hong Kong branch will become the bank's first overseas outlet. It currently has a total of 105 branches all over Taiwan.
According to the bank, having a presence in Hong Kong is expected to boost the bank's international visibility, because the territory has long been a regional financial hub.

By taking advantage of its geographic proximity to China, the Hong Kong branch is also expected to help the bank continue to serve Taiwanese customers that have established business ties with the mainland, the bank said.

In the initial phase of its Hong Kong operations, the branch is expected to provide deposit, remittance, U.S. dollar settlement, import-export and receivables financing, syndicated loan, and trust services, the bank said.
The Hong Kong branch is also expected to seek approval from Hong Kong authorities to provide Chinese yuan, wealth management and Internet banking services in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Postal Airlines to join cross-strait cargo services
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 11:57:30 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China Postal Airlines has obtained official permission to launch direct cargo flights to Taiwan, with the first run set for Dec. 21 from Fuzhou to Taoyuan, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Tuesday.

The Beijing-headquartered carrier is also planning to operate the Nanjing- Taoyuan route, according to Taiwan's Chunghwa Post Co., which will consign some of the company's cross-Taiwan Strait mail to the airline.
China Postal Airlines was established in 1996 and currently owns 17 Boeing 737 all-cargo aircraft. It is the first Chinese carrier dedicated to express mail and cargo transport services.
The company is one of the five Chinese carriers designated by Beijing to operate cross-strait cargo services.
The other four are Air China Cargo, China Cargo Airlines, China Southern Airlines, and Yangtze River Express. The latter has not filed an application for permission to fly the cross-strait route.
The two Taiwanese carriers operating the services are China Airlines and EVA Airways.
There are six approved Chinese destinations on the cross-strait line: Shanghai, Guangzhou, Chongqing, Nanjing, Fuzhou and Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Political responsibility bill passes first hurdle
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 12:01:47 (By Justin Su and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A bill that would force out of office political appointees who made major policy errors or gaffes that hurt the public interest made it through a legislative committee on Monday.

The draft "Political Appointees Act, " which was approved by the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, must still go through two more rounds of deliberation by the full legislature before it can become law.

The bill aims to force political appointees to take political responsibility for their actions, and should it be enacted, they could be forced to resign their posts under a number of different conditions.

Appointees would have to step down, for example, if there were clear evidence that they committed major policy errors or if major mistakes were found in their line of duty that led to severe damage to the interests of the people or the state.
Negligence in supervising the staff's execution of official duties resulting in the people's welfare being seriously affected would also force a political appointee to leave office.

If appointees engaged in behavior or used language so flawed that it damaged the government's image, or could not achieve an expected performance or carry out a political commitment based on available evidence, they could also be dismissed.

DOC.HEADLINE: IC designer to list on Taiwan exchange Dec. 24: underwriter
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 14:02:44 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: MStar Semiconductor, Inc., a Taiwan-based integrated circuit designer, is scheduled to list on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Dec. 24, underwriter Capital Securities said Tuesday.
The Cayman Islands-registered company will offer a total of 32.2 million shares at an indicative price range of NT$250 (US$8.32) to NT$310, Capital Securities said.
The public subscription period for investors will run from Tuesday to Thursday, and the listing price will be fixed a day later on Dec. 17, the underwriter said.
The funds to be raised from the listing will be used as working capital for future expansion and to repay loans, according to the company's prospectus.
It said MStar, capitalized at NT$4.56 billion, has scheduled an investor conference for Dec. 21 to brief local investors on the company's operations.

MStar, set up in Taiwan in June 2002, moved its headquarters to the Cayman Islands in 2007 and registered its company there to expand globally and operate subsidiaries in Singapore and the Netherlands, the prospectus said.
Chips provided by MStar are used in the production of consumer electronic products, such as flat panel TVs, monitors and cell phones.
The company operates primarily in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and most of its products are sold outside Taiwan to China, South Korea and the United States, the prospectus said.
The company said one of its major rivals in the global market is Taiwan-based IC designer MediaTek Inc.
In the first three quarters of this year, MStar posted NT$4.97 billion in net profit, compared with NT$4.82 billion recorded for all of 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Health insurance plan may target capital gains
DOC.DATELINE: Department of Health (DOH) 12/14/10 15:37:24 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Minister Yaung Chih-liang revealed Monday that the merits of the existing national health insurance (NHI) system will be preserved, but that capital gains will be included in the formula used to calculate premiums.

The inclusion of capital gains in the base of income on which premiums are figured was just one of the proposed changes to amendments to the National Health Insurance Act that failed to pass the Legislative Yuan last week.

The setback in the legislature forced the DOH to change course and shelve its second-generation reform plan that would have collected premiums based on overall household income rather than monthly salary and wages, as is the case at present.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Cabinet officials discussed the premium issue with the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Monday. Those who attended the meeting revealed that Yaung set revenue source priorities for the health insurance system.

Capital gains were at the top of the list, and if they were unable to adequately narrow the system's financial shortfalls, the stock transaction tax would be the next target, said officials attending Monday's meeting.
Raising the tobacco surcharge and including year-end bonuses and overtime payments in the income base for calculating premiums would be the last options, they said.
No final decision was made during the meeting on a proposal to increase the stock transaction tax to boost health insurance revenues, according to Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials.
"It is better for the health system not to rely on external aid," one finance official said. (Dec. 14, 2010).
China Times:
The Monday meeting was convened by Vice Premier Sean Chen and attended by Finance Minister Lee Sush-der, DOH Minister Yaung and KMT lawmakers specializing in financial and taxation issues.
They were all focused on the problem of finding money for the health insurance system.

Lee was said to have presented data and information suggesting to the DOH detailing where potential revenue sources existed. People at the meeting described it as a puzzle of financial resources given to participants to see which pieces were usable. (Dec. 14, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
Both the MOF and the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) opposed the idea of raising the stock transaction tax as part of efforts to collect revenues for the debt-ridden NHI system.

The MOF said the NHI system is a kind of insurance policy that should be viewed separately from the tax system. FSC officials contended that raising the tax would increase investment costs in the stock market.
"Everybody knows what the impact would be," on official said.

Taiwan currently does not tax capital gains on stock transactions but does charge a 0.3 percent transaction tax on transaction turnover. The government earned NT$105.9 billion income from the tax in 2009. (Dec. 14, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close little changed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 15:47:01 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Tuesday after concerns over the country's global competitiveness amid a rising New Taiwan dollar eroded early gains on follow-through buying, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 3.84 points or 0.04 percent to end at 8,740.43, after moving between 8,717.53 and 8,789.25, on turnover of NT$145.89 billion (US$4.86 billion).

The market opened up 0.40 percent and moved to the day's high on ample liquidity, but sentiment turned sour as investors witnessed the New Taiwan dollar extend its gains and breach the NT$30.00 level against the U.S. dollar to hit a high of about 12 years during the trading session, the dealers said.
A total of 1,738 stocks closed up and 2,630 were down, with 330 remaining unchanged.
The textile sector scored the highest gains, closing up 1.5 percent. Construction stocks rose 0.9 percent, foodstuffs added 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemical shares gained 0.5 percent.
However, cement stocks fell 1.0 percent and financial shares lost 0.7 percent, while the machinery and electronics, and paper and pulp sectors both closed down 0.1 percent.
"As the index moved closer to the nearest resistance level at around 8,800 points, investors were pocketing their recent gains, " Horizon Securities analyst Benson Huang said.
"In particular after the New Taiwan dollar extended strength against the U.S. dollar, fears that a rising local currency would hurt Taiwan's exports prompted investors to sell," Huang said.
Huang said selling focused on the bellwether electronics sector, which serves as the backbone of Taiwan's exports.
However, as the index fell to about 8,700 points, bargain hunters became active to lend some support to the market, Huang said.
"After a recent strong showing, the market needs some time to consolidate before another take-off to challenge the 8,800-8,900 point range or even higher," he said.

Among the high-tech stocks, PC vendor AsusTek shed 2.11 percent to close at NT$278.50, United Microelectronics Corp. lost 0.93 percent to end the day at NT$16.05 and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. fell 0.58 percent to finish at NT$69.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Closing wealth gap vs. rampant speculation
DOC.DATELINE: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) 12/14/10 16:07:59 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: is reportedly set to promote legislation that would heavily tax sales of non self-use properties within the first year of ownership, the transfer of pre-sale housing units, and the consumption of luxury items, in a bid to narrow the widening gap between rich and poor.

These sales taxes, however, are indirect in nature and are seldom used to redistribute wealth. If the MOF is serious about resolving the problem, it should not ignore the reforms needed to facilitate the taxing of capital gains.

It appears that the proposed taxes would be more effective at cooling property speculation than closing the wealth divide. Taxing sales of properties within the first year of ownership, for example, would mean that any sale taking place during this period would be subject to a heavy tax, irrespective of whether the sale resulted in a profit or a loss. The tax would not be applicable, however, to highly profitable transactions that occurred beyond the one-year limit.

In addition, for the taxes to produce their desired effect, the government must have the ability to get accurate real estate transaction prices. With the government failing to make any progress in this area, there is reason for skepticism over whether the proposed tax hikes can achieve their goals.

Although President Ma Ying-jeou has vowed to promote tax reform to narrow the country's wealth gap, the MOF must not mistake anti-speculation measures for an effective weapon against the wealth gap. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 14, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Quick recovery does not mean shooting orchestrated: forensic expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 16:42:05 (By Hsu Chih-wei and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Forensic scientist Henry Lee said Tuesday that it is possible for a person to recover soon from non-fatal gunshot wounds, which means a quick recovery does not necessarily mean the shooting was orchestrated.
Lee made the remarks on the sidelines of a ceremony to launch a studio bearing his name at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology.

Replying to questions from the media regarding the Nov. 26 shooting of Sean Lien, a member of the ruling Kuomintang Central Committee, Lee said a person can recover quite quickly from a shooting that does not injure major organs or tissue.

Lien was shot in the face during an election-eve campaign rally in Taipei County. The bullet entered his left cheek and exited from under his right temple. He was discharged from hospital nine days later.
The world-renowned scientist said he would be happy to help Taiwan's police authorities to conduct forensic work on the case.
He said that such a probe would not constitute a criminal investigation and would not be linked to politics.
Chen Shi-shuenn, president of the university, said the Dr. Henry Lee Studio was set up to promote forensic science through boosting cross-campus, cross- discipline and international cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar on Taiwan-Indonesia collaboration opens in Jakarta
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Indonesia, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 17:05:31 (By Nancy Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A second seminar on Taiwan-Indonesia collaboration opened in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta Tuesday to further explore bilateral ties on a wide front ranging from free trade agreements (FTAs) to challenges facing the media and technology sectors.

Andrew Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta, said countries in Southeast Asia now have greater imperative to step up ties with Taiwan after the country clinched an economic cooperation framework agreement with China in June.

As cross-Taiwan Strait trade and tourism continues to grow based on improved bilateral relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, many Southeast Asian countries now want to follow suit, because of the simple question: "If China can do it, why can't we?" said Hsia.

At a time when these countries are seeking to forge FTAs with other countries, Taiwan must not allow this opportunity to slip though its fingers, said, Samuel C.Y. Ku, a professor at the Institute of China and Asia-Pacific Studies at National Sun Yat-sen University, who is one of the 15-member delegation from Taiwan attending the seminar.
The seminar is being hosted by the Indonesian news magazine Tempo, and Edy Putra Irawady, Indonesia's deputy economic minister for trade and industry, attended the opening event.
Much of Taiwan's investment in Indonesia is in metals, minerals and energy, but in the future, Taiwan should also become interested in Indonesia's manufacturing and electronics products, Edy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC, UMC may consider forex factor in pricing decisions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 17:16:34 (By Jackson Chang, Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , the world's top two contract chip makers, said Tuesday they will consider taking into account a rising Taiwan dollar when setting prices.

Taiwan's currency sustained its recent momentum and breached the NT$30 to the U.S. dollar barrier to set a 12-year high in trading on Tuesday, leading to concerns that Taiwan's exporters could see their turnover and margins fall.
The two companies acknowledged that the appreciating Taiwan dollar had an impact on their sales and earnings.

UMC Chief Financial Officer Liu Chi-tung told the Central News Agency that the company would consider negotiating new sales contracts with buyers that had factored in foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
Liu said his company had taken measures to hedge foreign exchange risks, but he admitted it was hard to accurately forecast exchange rate movements.

TSMC said it would continue to adopt measures to hedge currency risks and incorporate foreign exchange factors into its financial plan before opening discussions with customers on new sales agreements.
As for existing sales contracts, TSMC said it would bear the foreign exchange risks on its own and would not renegotiate pricing with its customers.
In November, TSMC and UMC saw their sales fall 4.1 percent and 2.43 percent from October, respectively, on a stronger Taiwan dollar and weakening global demand for PCs.
UMC said that for every 1 percent the local currency appreciated against the greenback, its quarterly sales could be expected to fall by the same 1 percent.
Meanwhile, Acer Inc., the world's second largest PC vendor, said it had a mechanism ready to hedge foreign exchange risks, which was limiting the impact of a rising Taiwan dollar on the company.
Acer said the local currency's strength reflected a spillover effect from excessive liquidity from the United States, which is pumping massive funds into the market in a bid to boost its economy.
The PC vendor said it believes Taiwan's central bank will continue its efforts to prevent rapid appreciation of the Taiwan dollar and protect the island's exports.

The company said the central bank could be expected to continue to boost the value of the U.S. dollar to around NT$30.60 against the New Taiwan dollar at the close of trading sessions, even if the greenback fell below NT$30 during the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Clashes interrupt hearing on Kuokuang Petrochemical Park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 18:05:02 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A hearing held Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs on the planned Kuokuang Petrochemical Park in Changhua County was interrupted by sporadic clashes between supporters and opponents of the controversial project.
The clashes were stopped quickly thanks to the many police officer dispatched to the scene, with no injuries reported.

The event was intended to brief local residents on the plan's details and solicit their opinions on the project, in which Taiwan's eighth naphtha cracker plant would be built by Kuokuang Petrochemical Technology Co. in Changhua County's Dacheng Township.
Clashes were sparked when a supporter of the project took exception to the display of a fake coffin by the protesters and tried to damage it.
After they were separated by police, the two camps continued to trumpet their respective views via campaign trucks sent to the scene.
The park's designated site is a parcel of tidal land that is home to a major wetland.
Environmentalists have argued that the facility would cause irreversible damage to local flora and fauna and endanger marine life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet usage jumps among older people in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 18:11:37 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A growing number of people in Taiwan over the age of 50 are using the Internet, according to an annual survey, released Tuesday, on the country's digital divide.

The survey by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) found that among people in the 50 to 60 age bracket, Internet usage was 47.5 percent, a 10 percent jump from last year.
In the 60 to 64 age group, the rate of increase was about the same, from 22.3 percent last year to 33.1 percent this year, the survey showed.
In the under-40 age group, the rate of Internet usage was 91 percent, the poll found.
According to the survey, 80 percent of households have access to the Internet and the wired population has grown by about 800,000 to 14.46 million in 2010.
Ho Chuan-te, an official with the RDEC, said the increase in Internet usage could be attributed to the government's efforts in recent years to narrow the digital divide by expanding Internet access.
Since last March, the RDEC has installed an additional 100 wireless Internet hotspots in rural areas in Yilan, Nantou and Yunlin, Ho said at a press conference Tuesday.
Furthermore, it has introduced a program at 12 public libraries under which citizens can borrow laptop computers, free of charge, for up to one month, he said.
This year, the RDEC increased the number of laptops for loan from 300 to 865 and expanded the program to another 16 libraries in eight remote areas across Taiwan, he said.
The RDEC continues to offer free computer lessons for senior citizens and immigrants, he said.

The rate of Internet connection in Taipei County, Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, and Taichung City is higher than 85 percent, with Taipei County ranked as the country's most digitalized city, he noted.

However, the rate of Internet connection in many parts of central, eastern, and southern Taiwan and in the outlying islands is still below 75 percent, which means there is plenty of room for improvement, he added.
The survey was carried out by telephone between July and August, among 16,008 people countrywide. It had a margin of error of 0.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan invents world's smallest RRAM architecture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 18:50:48 (RRAM) developed by the National Applied Research Laboratories (NARC) (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A micro resistive random-access memory has a world record 9 nanometer half- pitch, one of its inventors said at a press conference Tuesday.
The functional RRAM has a data storage capacity 20 times larger than flash memory, but consumes 200 times less power, said Ho Chia-hua of National Nano Device Laboratories under the NARC.
The invention is expected to enter the phase of mass production within five to 10 years, Ho said.
He touted the new technology as a new road for the memory industry, as the technology to shrink the size of traditional flash memory is anticipated to reach a bottleneck by 2013.
Flash memory started with 90 nm process technology in 2004, which evolved to 32 nm this year and will shrink further to 22 nm in 2011, Ho said, adding that development is expected to stop there.
His research team, however, has successfully shrunk the size of the RRAM to 9 nm, while greatly reducing the power consumption by changing the chemical composition of the tungsten-oxide layer.
Despite using only a tiny amount of power, the new RRAM can store 500 gigabytes of data on a one-square-centimeter chip, Ho said.
The new technology will allow all kinds of data-processing electronic products to be reduced in size, he added.
Ho predicted that once mass production of the new RRAM begins, it will help promote Taiwan's global memory output from the present less-than 1 percent to 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lottery winner donates NT$120 million to charity groups
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, Dec. 14(CNA) 12/14/10 18:54:45 (By Tyson Lu and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A lottery winner has donated NT$120 million (US$ 4 million) to charity groups around the country, the Taiwan Lottery Co. said at a presentation ceremony in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, Tuesday.

The NT$1.12 billion first prize was drawn in September and was the biggest lottery prize ever to a single winner in Taiwan. The winner was a housewife in her 30s from Taitung, said Taiwan Lottery Chairman Steve Hsueh.
Charity groups in Taitung alone will receive donations totalling more than NT$30 million, he said.
One of the charities, Star Home which houses mentally challenged children, said that the NT$20 million donation it received was its largest in recent years.
Around NT$55 million was given to the Chinatrust Charity Foundation, which is affiliated with the Chinatrust Commercial Bank that operates the Taiwan Lottery, Hsueh said.

In addition, a red envelope containing NT$1.5 million was presented to the owner of the shop where the winning ticket was purchased. Taiwan Lottery, which made the presentation on behalf of the winner, said the woman had been spending around NT$1,000 per week for the last three years in lottery tickets.
It is estimated that more than 56,000 underprivileged children and families in Taiwan will benefit from the donor's generosity, according to Hsueh.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 19:11:20 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, dropping NT$0.15 to close at NT$30.450.
Turnover totaled US$814 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.600 and moved to a low of NT$29.890 before rebounding.
Dealers said the New Taiwan dollar was boosted by further inflows of foreign funds and that at one point it breached the NT$30.00 level during the trade to hit a 12-year high against the U.S. dollar.
They said the strength of the local currency reflected a strong rebound by the local economy from a global financial meltdown in 2008-2009.
Strong domestic fundamentals, coupled with the spillover effect of the high liquidity in the United States market, have promoted many foreign investors to move funds into Taiwan, the dealers said.
Foreign banks remained on the buy side to raise their New Taiwan dollar positions, betting that further appreciation of the local unit is inevitable amid ample liquidity, dealers said.

In late trade, Taiwan's central bank again stepped in to boost the value of the U.S. dollar to above NT$30.00 in a bid to reduce the impact of the New Taiwan dollar appreciation and protect Taiwan's exports, dealers said.

As foreign funds keep flowing into the local market, the central bank's efforts are unlikely to reverse the trend of a rising New Taiwan dollar but are expected to slow down the pace of the appreciation, dealers said.
They said the closing level of the New Taiwan dollar is expected to move closer to NT$30.00 in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-level Taiwan-China talks scheduled for Dec. 20-22 in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 19:33:16 (By Chou Hui-ying, Charles Kang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Top negotiators representing Taiwan and China are scheduled to hold their sixth meeting since 2008 in Taipei Dec. 20-22, during which a cross-Taiwan Strait medical and health cooperation agreement is expected to be signed, officials said Tuesday.

Officials of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) made the announcement after holding a pre-meeting consultation in Shanghai.
The consultation, between SEF Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian and ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, confirmed the schedule and agenda of the Taipei meeting.
The text of the medical and health cooperation agreement was also examined to make sure it meets the targets of both parties.
In terms of a cross-strait investment protection accord, SEF officials said some details remain to be settled and so it will not be ready for inking by the chief delegates during the meeting.

According to the conference schedule, ARATS President Chen Yunlin will head a delegation that will arrive in Taipei Dec. 20. His Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, will greet him and escort him on a tour of the National Palace Museum that same day.
On Dec. 21, Chiang and Chen will sign the medical cooperation pact, the 15th agreement they will have signed since their first meeting in 2008 following the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan will meet Chen and his delegation later that day.
Kao said there are no plans for President Ma Ying-jeou to meet with Chen and his delegation.
On the final day of the visit, the delegates will visit the Flora Expo in Taipei before returning to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paper manufacturer awarded carbon labeling certificate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 19:35:07 (By Wei Shu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Cheng Loong Corp., one of Taiwan's largest paper manufacturers, was awarded a carbon labeling accreditation certificate by the government Tuesday in recognition of its efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions throughout its manufacturing process and supply chain.

The certificate was presented by Stephen Shu-hung Shen, minister of the Cabinet- level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , in recognition of Cheng Loong's production and distribution of a paper towel series made of recycled paper.
The certificate was the first of its kind to be awarded by the EPA to any household paper product in Taiwan.

Upon receiving the recognition, Cheng Loong President Tsai Tong-ho said his company will continue striving to use resources efficiently and contribute to society with the goal of reducing the firm's CO2 emissions by 5 percent in three years.
According to Tsai, Cheng Loong followed carbon footprint verification norms of the British Standards Institution (BSI) to produce and distribute the recycled paper towels.
The company tried to lower CO2 emissions throughout the entire production and distribution process, involving raw material sourcing, towel manufacturing, transport and waste disposal, Tsai said.
The EPA awarded the carbon labeling accreditation certificate to Cheng Loong after the product passed BSI verification, according to Tsai.
Cheng Loong became voluntary carbon standard (VCS) -certified in 2008 and began selling its voluntary carbon offsets in New York's over-the-counter market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Action, not words, to protect environment: president
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 19:51:35 (By Chen Chao-fu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the people Tuesday to take action instead of just talking about his idea of "protecting the environment to save the country."

Ma made the remarks after cutting the ribbon to open a green forum and expo in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung along with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu and American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office Director William Stanton.
He said climate change has created such real-life situations as severe draughts at one extreme to severe flooding caused by torrential rainstorms at the other.
It has become a reality that dry weather has become even drier and that intensified downpours have been bringing even greater amounts of rain, Ma said.

Although Taiwan is not a party to the Kyoto Protocol, he advised the people to cut the country's carbon dioxide emissions and save energy in order not to be condemned or punished by the international community.
Chen for her part said the president's visit to Kaohsiung's green industries shows that he attaches great importance to the local government's green energy projects.
The city government has made good use of the sunshine in southern Taiwan to develop green industries over the past few years, hoping to build Kaohsiung into a "green city," said the mayor.

Ma, Chen and Stanton also acted as "green energy ambassadors" by riding bicycles that use clean energy to power their headlights, symbolizing that the city is entering a new era of green energy and industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka festivals to reach wider Asian audience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 19:59:09 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The rich diversity of Taiwan's Hakka culture will reach a broader audience in Asia when a travel program featuring Hakka festivals premieres Dec. 19 in the Asia-Pacific region, a global lifestyle channel announced Tuesday.

In collaboration with the Council for Hakka Affairs, the Travel and Living Channel (TLC) said in a press conference that it will add a new episode titled Hakka Festivals to its Fun Taiwan series, in which four distinctive Hakka festivals will be introduced for the first time on the channel.

Running for about an hour, the show will reach more than 133 million viewers in 20 countries around Asia, said Tommy Lin, senior vice president and general manager of North Asia, Discovery Networks Asia-Pacific (DNAP).

The four festivals include the Yimin Cultural Festival in Hsinchu County, the Tung Blossom Festival in Miaoli County, the Drum King Competition in Hualien County and the Cloud Dragon Festival in Sanyi Township, also in Miaoli County.
Janet Hsieh, the presenter of Fun Taiwan, said she was touched during the six- month shooting of the Hakka festivals by the strong sense of cultural identity and the hospitality of the Hakka people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese health, well-being rank low: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 20:08:09 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is among the developed nations of the world that rank their health and well-being the lowest, according to a report by the Philips Center for Health and Well-being.

In the report, which analyzed the responses of more than 31,000 people in 23 countries, only 24 percent of the people in Taiwan had a positive view of their well-being and state of health, compared to the global average of 62 percent.
According to the report, financial concerns are key stress factors for Taiwanese, as they are constantly worried about whether they have enough money to pay bills and save for the future.
As a result, Taiwanese have the second highest level of stress among the 23 countries surveyed, the survey found.
According to the report, 94 percent of the Taiwanese respondents said they were under much pressure.
The report found that such stress has led to sleep deprivation, with about 50 percent of the Taiwanese respondents saying they lack sleep, the highest rate among all the countries.
People need to achieve a balance between work and other aspects of life in order to improve their quality of life, said Chen Chien-jen, a scholar at Academia Sinica.
"People are happy when they love others and feel loved, " said Chen, "we should keep building healthy relationships with our family and friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign currency deposits eligible for government guarantee
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 20:13:29 (By Huang Ming-hsi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved a government proposal Tuesday to cover foreign currency deposits and interest income under its deposit guarantee program, a move that is expected to stabilize the local currency's exchange rate.
Under the amendments to the Deposit Insurance Statute that cleared the legislative floor that day, foreign currency deposits and interest generated therefrom will be guaranteed.

According to the government, this will serve as an incentive for people not to move their foreign currency deposits into New Taiwan dollar savings accounts, thus preventing the local currency from dramatic fluctuations on the foreign exchange market.
The amendments do not apply to foreigners, institutional investors, government agencies or banking institutions that have foreign currency deposits in Taiwan.

An exclusion provision is included in the amended statute that stipulates that it aims to protect non-professional depositors only, not institutional investors or government agencies that deposit their foreign currency assets in the international business departments of local banks.

Meanwhile, to assure the public of the safety of their bank deposits, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), the Ministry of Finance and the central bank have jointly announced that from Jan. 1, 2011, the amount of guaranteed bank deposits will be set at NT$3 million (US$33,467).
The announcement came as a 2008 financial crisis measure protecting the full amounts of people's bank savings is going to expire at the end of this year.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan said the government will be able to ensure the safety of people's deposits in private banks despite the expiration of the 2008 measure.

Taiwan is not like the United States, where private banks can manage such huge sums of money that it is beyond the government's ability to guarantee the safety of individual citizens' deposits, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park turns 30
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 20:18:19 (By C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park marked its 30th anniversary Tuesday, with the park's administration Director-General Randy Yen vowing to maintain its role as a bellwether of Taiwan's economy.

Yen, who worked in companies at the high-tech park for 19 years, said the "second energy crisis" in the 1970s paved the way for the establishment of the science park in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu area, which helped Taiwan's economy take off in the 1980s ahead of many neighboring countries.

The park has not only contributed greatly to the nation's technological development, but has also boosted the local economy and helped Hsinchu achieve the lowest jobless rate and the highest per-capita income among similar areas in Taiwan, he said.
Currently, 110 of the companies located in the compound have a combined annual revenue of NT$2.2 trillion (US$73.33 billion) , accounting for 20 percent of the total in Taiwan's manufacturing sector.

Based on the existing scale of the park and its semiconductor and optoelectronic clusters, it is poised to evolve into a nanotechnology hub and will continue to lead Taiwan's economic development, he said.

Looking to the future, Yen said his administration remains committed to improving the investment climate in the park and encouraging more businesses to open shop there as means of contributing to the country.

The Hsinchu Science Park is Taiwan's first science park established in 1980 to introduce and upgrade the high-tech industries of the country as well as to drive its economic developments. There are three science parks in northern, central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Dec. 14

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to create database for restaurants with overseas presence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 20:41:11 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will set up a database to help local restaurants and cafes seeking to expand overseas to better understand regulations and consumers' habits in China, the United States and Europe, an official said Tuesday.

"We plan to establish a database to help local food companies search for information, for example, about U.S. laws and regulations and consumer behavior, " Yeh Yun-lung, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Commerce told CNA at an event featuring popular Taiwanese snacks and award-winning cuisine.
The department will kick off the plan next year, with China the first country featured, he said.
"China shares a similar language and cultural backgrounds with us. It is also the first place outside Taiwan where we can easily see success," Yeh said.
His remarks came amid a growing number of Taiwanese restaurants and cafes -- including cafe and bakery chain 85JC-- that have been extending their presence in China and elsewhere in recent years.
After creating the China database, the government will apply the model to Europe and the United States, the official said.
Meanwhile, he cited the lack of management professionals as one of the other major hurdles facing local restaurants and cafes when they are increasing the number of outlets in other countries.
At the event, Chang Kuo-rong, chairman of the board of the Taipei Bakery Association, said Taiwan has a big pool of specialized bakers due to the competitive local market.

However, he also noted that the country now suffers from a shortage of management specialists for overseas operations and urged the department to allocate funds in this regard as part of the database plan.
Earlier this year, the Cabinet approved a plan to add 3,500 food and beverage outlets at home and abroad and to create 10,000 jobs between 2010 and 2013.
The government also plans to boost the number of international brands to 50 and encourage the private sector to invest a total of NT$2 billion (US$67 million) in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 outbreak unlikely despite growing number of cases: experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:01:52 (By Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of influenza A(H1N1) infections in Taiwan has been rising over the past few weeks, but the situation is not expected to escalate into a full- fledged outbreak, according to health experts.

Deputy Director-General of Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Lin Ting said Tuesday that 43 percent of the flu cases reported in the past three months were caused by the A(H1N1) virus, 33 percent by the A/H3 virus and 23 percent by the influenza B virus.
The ratios have changed, he noted, saying that in the past, 80 percent of flu infections in the country were caused by the A/H3 virus.

The CDC thinks the shift is not a big problem, but is worried that pre-school children could be hit by the current wave of H1N1 as only less than half of them have been inoculated against the virus since a national H1N1 vaccination program was launched in October, Lin said.

Meanwhile, when asked about the increase in the number of H1N1 cases, pediatrician Chen Chih-jung at Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital said he does not expect a major outbreak of H1N1 infections this year.
Taiwan was one of the countries hit by the H1N1 flu virus in 2009. More than 800 people in Taiwan were hospitalized with H1N1 symptoms last year and 35 of them died.
Since then, about one third of the population has acquired immunity to the H1N1 flu virus, either through vaccination or infection, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China joint venture motor firm founded in China
DOC.DATELINE: Hangzhou, China, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:01:57 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Dongfeng Yulon Motor Co., a joint venture between automobile makers in Taiwan and China, was officially opened Tuesday in Hangzhou, in China's Zejiang Province.

The new venture involving Yulon Motor, one of the leading car manufacturers in Taiwan, and Dongfeng Motor, a Chinese state-owned car maker, drew a total capital investment of 3.4 billion Chinese yuan (about US$570 million) , with Yulon and Dongfeng each holding a 50 percent share.
The new company will have an annual capacity of 120,000 cars and 120,000 engines, with both Yulon and Dongfeng jointly holding the Luxgen brand developed by Yulon, in the Chinese market.
A Luxgen SUV, to be built at the Hangzhou plant in the middle of next year, will be the first of eight car models that Dongfeng Yulon plans to produce.

The joint venture will begin commercially producing two models each year beginning from the second year of its establishment, offering customers options for each model of either petroleum-fueled or new energy engines.
Tongfeng Yulon Chairman Zhou Wenjie said the goal of his company is to produce high-priced quality cars and to become one of the top-notch car markers in the world within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to toughen penalties for use of illegal labor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:16:43 (By Lee Shien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will toughen the penalties for the use or brokering of illegal labor, as part of the government's efforts to address the problem of runaway foreign workers, the council said Tuesday.
The CLA is planning to introduce amendments to its existing regulations, specifically to strengthen management of foreign labor and to more effectively prevent abscondence.

The process of enforcing the penalties for hiring runaway foreign workers will be simplified and the fines against employers of such workers will be set at NT$150,000 (US$5,000) to NT$750,000, said Tsai Meng-liang, chief of the foreign workers management division at the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training.
The CLA has also amended one of its regulations to toughen penalties for illegal brokering of runaway foreign workers and has sent the bill to the Legislative Yuan for screening, Tsai said.
The bill is aimed at raising the maximum fine for the first offense to NT$1.5 million, and for repeat offenses to a maximum prison term of five years and a fine of up to NT$2.4 million, Tsai said.
At present, the maximum fine for the brokering of illegal workers is NT$500,000, and repeat offenders within a five year period could be sentenced to one year in jail and a fine of up to NT$600,000.

As to other measures targeting the more than 1,000 registered labor brokers in the country, brokers could have their license revoked if it is found that there is an excessively high runaway rate among the workers they bring in, Tsai said.
He added that the government believes brokers must take major responsibility for the problem of runaways because brokers are the main suppliers of foreign labor.

CLA statistics show that there are around 34,000 runaway foreign workers in Taiwan. The issue has drawn much attention in the wake of the Sept. 6 deaths of six runaway foreign workers, who were illegally employed at a construction site on the No. 6 Freeway.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45,000 families to benefit from rental subsidy program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:21:06 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An estimated 45,000 low-income families will benefit from a government program to subsidize house rentals, the Ministry of the Interior said Tuesday.

The ministry said its integrated housing subsidy program is being expanded to increase the number of families eligible for rental subsidies. Some NT$1.95 billion (US$65.26 million) has been budgeted for the 45,000 families for one year, it noted.
Families whose applications for rental subsidy are approved will receive a maximum of NT$3,600 (US$120) per month for up to 12 months.

The program is also aimed at helping to ease the burden of those who have bought housing over the past two years by subsidizing their mortgage interest repayments. Only first-time owners are eligible for such subsidies.
If they have to borrow money to renovate older houses or apartments, subsidies for those interest repayments are also available, said the ministry.

Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said the housing subsidy program is part of the government's social housing policy that seeks to help the economically or socially disadvantaged improve their living conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial notebook market to grow slightly next year: researchers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:36:26 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The commercial notebook market will experience slight growth in 2011, although demand for consumer notebooks is slowing due to emerging interest in tablet computers and e-readers, market researchers said Tuesday.

Ryan Lee, a researcher with the Topology Research Institute, told CNA in a telephone interview that the commercial notebook market will grow slightly from 35 percent of the total notebook market this year to 37 percent in 2011.

The growth of the commercial market is not expected to surge because most firms still have greater demand for desktop computers than for notebooks, which are mostly used by sales departments, Lee said.

The commercial notebook market will post a higher growth than the consumer notebook market next year because companies have raised their budgets for computer purchases, said Dickie Chang, a senior analyst with global market tracker International Data Corp., in a telephone interview with CNA.

"Corporations need more time than ordinary consumers to plan for their budgets for buying computers, and they have finally decided to expand their hardware equipment after a period of observation that has lasted since 2009," Chang said.

Meanwhile, consumers will be less likely to spend money on notebooks now that they have other options such as tablets, e-readers and smartphones, leading to a slowdown in demand for consumer notebooks, he noted.

However, Asustek Computer Inc. is reported to be shipping an estimated 20 million notebooks in 2011, representing growth of 18 percent from this year's 17 million units, according to the Tuesday edition of Apple Daily, a local newspaper.

The company also expects total revenue of NT$380 billion (US$12.73 billion) in 2011, up 18.8 percent from an estimated NT$320 billion in 2010, as it plans to sell more tablets and e-readers during the same period, the paper said.
Regarding netbook inventories, Chang added, PC vendors like Asustek will have to make efforts in product segmentation, as it plans to launch new tablets early next year.
The software integration of the devices and relationships with retailers will also be important issues for Asustek if the company wants its new products to generate more revenue, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia's largest human trafficking ring smashed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:48:55 (By C.F. Bian and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) announced Tuesday that it has smashed a cross-border human trafficking ring, the largest in Asia, after over a year of cooperation with their counterparts in Hong Kong, Thailand, Britain and the United States.

The NIA said it detained seven suspects and summoned seven others for questioning, all of whom have been handed over to the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office. Ten other members of the ring were still at large.

According to the NIA, the ring made more than NT$100 million (US$3.28 million) in profit from over 30 human trafficking cases, helping one to five illegals from China in each case to enter the United States, Canada, Britain or Holland.
The ring racked up US$50,000 to US$70,000 for every stowaway they smuggled into these countries.

Through advertisements on the Internet or in newspapers, the criminal ring recruited members to serve as middlemen who were responsible for traveling to Hong Kong or Bangkok, where they handed forged Taiwanese passports and boarding passes to the illegal Chinese intending to sneak into these Western countries with doctored documents, it said.

Before traveling abroad on their missions, each member of the ring would receive some NT$60,000, which succeeded in attracting unscrupulous individuals looking for some quick and easy money, the NIA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to set up agri-food promotion center in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 21:58:49 (By Yang Shu-min and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture has commissioned a private company to establish a display and marketing center in Shanghai that will promote Taiwanese agricultural products, officials said Tuesday.

Chang Shu-hsien, director of the COA's Department of International Affairs, said the Shanghai center, to be set up by the Uni-President Dream Parks Corp. before next April, will be the third of its kind, following similar ones established in Hong Kong and Tokyo.

The Shanghai center will try to impress local consumers with heartwarming farming community stories and Taiwan's cultural heritage related to the products on display, which will include tea, wine, fruit, vegetables and fishery products on the "early harvest list" of the cross-strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , she said.
Processed foods and dairy products that have won farming association citations or other government certificates will also be promoted there, she added.

Hsiao Tung-chiung, Chang's deputy, said an online service will be launched so that consumers can order purchases either in China or in Taiwan. The COA will also cooperate with Taiwanese air carriers flying to and from Chinese cities to sell farm produce and other agricultural products, Hsiao noted.

Hsiao said the COA does not expect the Shanghai promotion center to achieve high revenue and that the long-term goal for the center is to match Taiwanese producers with Chinese sellers so that both sides can cooperate in promoting and marketing Taiwan's quality products in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan car sales in early December up 17.3 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:07:34 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Car sales in Taiwan in the first 10 days of December rose 17.3 percent from a year earlier to 7,439 units on rising demand as the local economy staged a strong rebound, a car dealer said Tuesday.

According to Hotai Motor Co., the Taiwanese distributor for Japanese car maker Toyota Motor Corp., Taiwan's auto sales between Jan.1 and Dec. 10 rose 17.7 percent year on year to 304,246 units, surpassing the 294,000 units recorded for the entire 2009.

A market consensus showed the growing domestic economy, coupled with the effects of the auto industry's peak season in the fourth quarter, is expected to boost sales for 2010 to 325,000 units, up about 10 percent from 2009.
Previously, Hotai Motor had forecast sales of 300,000 units for 2010.

In November, the government revised Taiwan's 2010 economic growth to 9.98 percent, from a previous estimate of 8.24 percent, to reflect a strong rebound in the first three quarters of the year on a recovery in private consumption and private investments as well as a strong rebound in exports.
In the first nine months of this year, the island's gross domestic product rose 12 percent from a year earlier.

Earlier this year, Yulon Motor Group Chief Executive Office Kenneth Yen said he was optimistic about the outlook of the local auto market for 2011 and forecast that car sales will range between 320,000 units and 350,000 units.
Meanwhile, a rising New Taiwan dollar is expected to cut production costs for local auto makers as key imported car components have become cheaper, market observers said.

The New Taiwan dollar extended its strength against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday and at one point breached the NT$30.00 mark to hit a 12-year high during the trading session before the central bank intervened to slow down the pace of appreciation.
Due to the central bank's presence, the U.S. dollar closed at NT$30.045, recovering from a low of NT$29.890 Tuesday.
Market observers said the New Taiwan dollar is expected to gain strength, which will continue to lower auto makers' production costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Higher poverty line helps narrow wealth gap: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:25:26 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou acknowledged Tuesday the recent passage of amendments that push Taiwan's official poverty line higher and help narrow the gap between the country's rich and poor.

Speaking at a regular meeting of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), Ma, who doubles as party chairman, said the amendments are a milestone in Taiwan's social welfare system, as it increase the number of beneficiaries to some 3.7 percent of the country's population, according to KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin.
"The increased number of people allowed access to public assistance is conducive to narrowing the wealth gap," Ma said.

More lower-income households will soon be eligible for government subsidies after the Legislative Yuan passed the amendments Dec. 10 that change how Taiwan's official poverty line is defined and who can have access to public assistance.

The amendments to the Public Assistance Act, scheduled to take effect July 1, 2011, should add 590,000 people to the number of households eligible for government assistance, Ma said during the meeting, according to Su.
The bulk of those newly eligible to receive aid will be near poor households with average income per household member no more than 1.5 times as high as the poverty line.
That group was previously excluded from public assistance provisions, but the new amendments incorporated them among those eligible for financial aid.
Other new recipients will receive assistance by falling under the higher poverty line, or "minimum cost of living."

At present, the minimum cost of living is defined as 60 percent of the average per capita consumption expenditure, but the new revisions change that to 60 percent of the median disposable income per capita.

The minimum cost of living, which varies from region to region, will be set at NT$14,794 (US$493) in Taipei City, NT$11,146 in Kaohsiung City, NT$11,832 in Xinbei City, NT$10,303 in Taichung City, NT$10,244 in Tainan City, and NT$10,244 in other cities and counties around the country.
Households with levels of average income per household member lower than the minimum cost of living can apply for public subsidies.
The new formula raises the poverty line by roughly 5 percent-10 percent.

Under the existing regulations, fewer than 1 percent of Taiwan's population is eligible for government assistance, much lower than the percentage in neighboring countries and areas such as South Korea and Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, on controversy over the proposed second-generation health insurance reform plan, which failed to pass the legislature last week, the president said Department of Health officials will continue to communicate with lawmakers until a new version of the amendment package can be modified to forge the widest consensus possible on the issue, according to Su.

The authorities involved should exchange opinions to fine-tune the technical details of the national health insurance (NHI) reform plan -- mainly on how health insurance premiums should be calculated -- based on the principles of fairness, quality and efficiency, Ma said.

The president said the second-generation NHI system is of extraordinary significance to Taiwan society, adding that the NHI system, which covers 99.6 percent of the population compared to 85 percent in the United States, is globally recognized.
"Why don't we take these controversy as an opportunity to better exchange opinions?" Ma was quoted as asking.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Nankang Rubber Tire to raise prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:33:57 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nankang Rubber Tire Co., a major Taiwanese tire maker, announced Tuesday a new round of product price hikes from the start of next month to reflect soaring natural rubber prices.
"Nankang Rubber will have an overall price increase of about 8 percent from January in response to rising raw material costs, " the company said in a filing with the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

The price hikes will come just one month after the Taipei-based company raised tire prices by between 6 percent and 8 percent Dec. 1 to avoid a negative impact on its gross profits for the fourth quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wushantou Reservoir hot attraction for Japanese visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:41:04 (By Huang Po-kai and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Wushantou Reservoir Scenic Area has become a hot tourist spot, with an increasing number of Japanese visitor arrivals, the Siraya National Scenic Administration in southern Taiwan said Tuesday.

The number of Japanese visitors as of November had reached 4,000, achieving the whole-year record of 4,000 in 2009, the administration said, adding that more than 120,000 people in Taiwan and from around the world had visited the scenic area so far this year.

Yoichi Hatta, the Japanese engineer who built the reservoir in 1930 and who enjoyed widespread fame in Taiwan and Japan, could be the major pull for the Japanese, said Huang Ling-ying, a spokeswoman for the Chianan Irrigation Association.

In addition, the fact that Wushantou is recognized as a civil engineering heritage by the Japan Society of Civil Engineering might also help increase the area's popularity among travelers, Huang said.
When the Japanese visitors arrive, they usually arrange in-depth tours with an interpreter and visit the Hatta Memorial Museum and related cultural sites in the area, she went on.
"They are impressed by Hatta's achievements and by how Taiwanese people remember him", Huang added.

Taiwan has filed an application to have Wushantou Reservoir listed as a world- class heritage and the foreign language guide services and visitor facilities will be improved to help with the bid and make it into an international attraction, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Online clothing brand shoots to fame
DOC.DATELINE: 12/14/10 22:48:13 (Business Weekly 1201)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: An online clothing store, dubbed Taiwan's Uniqlo, is enjoying a booming business that can rival the success of those retailers with 200 stores on the streets.
In four years, lativ, founded by Chang Wei-chiang, has seen its revenue grow from NT$10 million (US$331,510) to an estimated NT$1.5 billion this year.
"Many people have said that I imitated Uniqlo, but actually I learned from Jimmy Lai, whose books I have all read two or three times, " said Chang, who has a vocational school degree in electronics.
Chang said he believes that Lai, a media mogul who first made his name in Hong Kong, succeeded by choosing the right mass market and focusing on doing simple things well.

When Chang decided to go into business, his target was the market of affordable quality clothing. He noticed that most of the online clothing stores were selling trendy, fancy and cheap clothes that were of poor quality, he said. He set about learning the basics of the clothing business, studying fabrics, patterns and cut. He also visited textile factories in northern Taiwan, sometimes spending a whole day there just observing.

Although lativ demands high quality from its contract manufacturers, the local industry now runs at full capacity almost all year long to supply the online company. Previously, the contract manufacturers would close during the low season.
Putting most of its spending into maintaining quality, lativ is able to offer affordable prices by keeping its production lines simple, which lowers the cost of large production orders.
In addition, the retailer saves 60 percent in costs because its distribution is done online, which means there are no rent or utility expenses as in a brick- and-mortar shop.
Furthermore, Chang has a unique inventory system that he designed, using his past experience in writing computer programs, which makes the processing of orders more efficient.
The retailer's adherence to quality has gained trust among its customers, which is crucial for an online business. Eighty percent of lativ's 250,000 members are repeat buyers.
In one year, the brand managed to sell 600,000 polo shirts at a price of NT$168 each.
Sunny Huang, executive director of New Wide Group, a Uniqlo supplier, said lativ has achieved a lot.
However, Huang said, the brand's next challenge will be to deal with the limited scale of business in Taiwan and shortfalls in supply that make it difficult to meet market demand.
With persistence and simple product designs, Chang has created a successful clothing brand in Taiwan. But in moving forward, he will have to overcome the challenges of the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese woman to shoot film on ROC founding father
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 23:07:02 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A great-granddaughter of a Japanese close friend of Sun Yat-sen, the Republic of China's founding father, said Tuesday that she plans to shoot a film next year in memory of the friendship between her great-grandfather and Sun.
Her great-grandfather, Umeya Shokichi (1868-1934), forged close relations with Sun and provided generous funding during the latter's uprising against the Qing dynasty in the early 20th century.

Ayano Kosaka, who arrived in Taiwan Dec. 12 for a four-day visit, noted that next year marks the centennial of the ROC and said it would be a good time to shoot a film to mark the close relationship between the two men.

Kosaka, who is visiting Taiwan to see at first hand the country's historic sites related to Sun, made the remarks during a meeting with ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General King Pu-tsun at the party's headquarters.

For his part, King said it would be "significant" if she shoots the film, adding that Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs will also make a movie to depict Sun's life and that both sides could exchange ideas on the projects.
Later in the day, Kosaka visited the KMT Party Records Archives. She is also scheduled to visit the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall and the National Palace Museum Wednesday before returning to Japan.
King called on Kosaka when he visited Japan in September, during which he was shown many valuable photos of Sun and invited the latter to visit Taiwan.
