The minimum cost of living, which varies from region to region, will be set at NT$14,794 (US$493) in Taipei City, NT$11,146 in Kaohsiung City, NT$11,832 in Xinbei City, NT$10,303 in Taichung City, NT$10,244 in Tainan City, and NT$10,244 in other cities and counties around the country.
Households with levels of average income per household member lower than the minimum cost of living can apply for public subsidies.
The new formula raises the poverty line by roughly 5 percent-10 percent.

Under the existing regulations, fewer than 1 percent of Taiwan's population is eligible for government assistance, much lower than the percentage in neighboring countries and areas such as South Korea and Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, on controversy over the proposed second-generation health insurance reform plan, which failed to pass the legislature last week, the president said Department of Health officials will continue to communicate with lawmakers until a new version of the amendment package can be modified to forge the widest consensus possible on the issue, according to Su.

The authorities involved should exchange opinions to fine-tune the technical details of the national health insurance (NHI) reform plan -- mainly on how health insurance premiums should be calculated -- based on the principles of fairness, quality and efficiency, Ma said.

The president said the second-generation NHI system is of extraordinary significance to Taiwan society, adding that the NHI system, which covers 99.6 percent of the population compared to 85 percent in the United States, is globally recognized.
"Why don't we take these controversy as an opportunity to better exchange opinions?" Ma was quoted as asking.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Nankang Rubber Tire to raise prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:33:57 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nankang Rubber Tire Co., a major Taiwanese tire maker, announced Tuesday a new round of product price hikes from the start of next month to reflect soaring natural rubber prices.
"Nankang Rubber will have an overall price increase of about 8 percent from January in response to rising raw material costs, " the company said in a filing with the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

The price hikes will come just one month after the Taipei-based company raised tire prices by between 6 percent and 8 percent Dec. 1 to avoid a negative impact on its gross profits for the fourth quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wushantou Reservoir hot attraction for Japanese visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 22:41:04 (By Huang Po-kai and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Wushantou Reservoir Scenic Area has become a hot tourist spot, with an increasing number of Japanese visitor arrivals, the Siraya National Scenic Administration in southern Taiwan said Tuesday.

The number of Japanese visitors as of November had reached 4,000, achieving the whole-year record of 4,000 in 2009, the administration said, adding that more than 120,000 people in Taiwan and from around the world had visited the scenic area so far this year.

Yoichi Hatta, the Japanese engineer who built the reservoir in 1930 and who enjoyed widespread fame in Taiwan and Japan, could be the major pull for the Japanese, said Huang Ling-ying, a spokeswoman for the Chianan Irrigation Association.

In addition, the fact that Wushantou is recognized as a civil engineering heritage by the Japan Society of Civil Engineering might also help increase the area's popularity among travelers, Huang said.
When the Japanese visitors arrive, they usually arrange in-depth tours with an interpreter and visit the Hatta Memorial Museum and related cultural sites in the area, she went on.
"They are impressed by Hatta's achievements and by how Taiwanese people remember him", Huang added.

Taiwan has filed an application to have Wushantou Reservoir listed as a world- class heritage and the foreign language guide services and visitor facilities will be improved to help with the bid and make it into an international attraction, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Online clothing brand shoots to fame
DOC.DATELINE: 12/14/10 22:48:13 (Business Weekly 1201)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: An online clothing store, dubbed Taiwan's Uniqlo, is enjoying a booming business that can rival the success of those retailers with 200 stores on the streets.
In four years, lativ, founded by Chang Wei-chiang, has seen its revenue grow from NT$10 million (US$331,510) to an estimated NT$1.5 billion this year.
"Many people have said that I imitated Uniqlo, but actually I learned from Jimmy Lai, whose books I have all read two or three times, " said Chang, who has a vocational school degree in electronics.
Chang said he believes that Lai, a media mogul who first made his name in Hong Kong, succeeded by choosing the right mass market and focusing on doing simple things well.

When Chang decided to go into business, his target was the market of affordable quality clothing. He noticed that most of the online clothing stores were selling trendy, fancy and cheap clothes that were of poor quality, he said. He set about learning the basics of the clothing business, studying fabrics, patterns and cut. He also visited textile factories in northern Taiwan, sometimes spending a whole day there just observing.

Although lativ demands high quality from its contract manufacturers, the local industry now runs at full capacity almost all year long to supply the online company. Previously, the contract manufacturers would close during the low season.
Putting most of its spending into maintaining quality, lativ is able to offer affordable prices by keeping its production lines simple, which lowers the cost of large production orders.
In addition, the retailer saves 60 percent in costs because its distribution is done online, which means there are no rent or utility expenses as in a brick- and-mortar shop.
Furthermore, Chang has a unique inventory system that he designed, using his past experience in writing computer programs, which makes the processing of orders more efficient.
The retailer's adherence to quality has gained trust among its customers, which is crucial for an online business. Eighty percent of lativ's 250,000 members are repeat buyers.
In one year, the brand managed to sell 600,000 polo shirts at a price of NT$168 each.
Sunny Huang, executive director of New Wide Group, a Uniqlo supplier, said lativ has achieved a lot.
However, Huang said, the brand's next challenge will be to deal with the limited scale of business in Taiwan and shortfalls in supply that make it difficult to meet market demand.
With persistence and simple product designs, Chang has created a successful clothing brand in Taiwan. But in moving forward, he will have to overcome the challenges of the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese woman to shoot film on ROC founding father
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/10 23:07:02 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A great-granddaughter of a Japanese close friend of Sun Yat-sen, the Republic of China's founding father, said Tuesday that she plans to shoot a film next year in memory of the friendship between her great-grandfather and Sun.
Her great-grandfather, Umeya Shokichi (1868-1934), forged close relations with Sun and provided generous funding during the latter's uprising against the Qing dynasty in the early 20th century.

Ayano Kosaka, who arrived in Taiwan Dec. 12 for a four-day visit, noted that next year marks the centennial of the ROC and said it would be a good time to shoot a film to mark the close relationship between the two men.

Kosaka, who is visiting Taiwan to see at first hand the country's historic sites related to Sun, made the remarks during a meeting with ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General King Pu-tsun at the party's headquarters.

For his part, King said it would be "significant" if she shoots the film, adding that Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs will also make a movie to depict Sun's life and that both sides could exchange ideas on the projects.
Later in the day, Kosaka visited the KMT Party Records Archives. She is also scheduled to visit the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall and the National Palace Museum Wednesday before returning to Japan.
King called on Kosaka when he visited Japan in September, during which he was shown many valuable photos of Sun and invited the latter to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 15, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino- American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open modestly higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 10:07:35 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 14.89 points at 8,755.32 on a turnover of NT$2.966 billion (US$97.25 million).
The weighted price index gained 3.84 points, or 0.04 percent, to close at 8,740.43 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 10:12:21 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$29.934 at 9:45 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.516 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
United Daily News: Time to change election subsidy rules

TEXT.P: It is estimated that the Central Election Commission will pay out more than NT$500 million (US$16.42 million) in election subsidies -- based on arate of NT$30 per vote -- to candidates in the Nov. 27 special municipality elections.

The recipients will use the money in different ways after deducting prepaid expenses. Some will donate the balance to charity or set up a fund, but most candidates may simply keep the windfall in their own pocket.

The subsidy was originally intended to help individuals with limited finances have a fair chance to participate in elections. The concept, however, appears unrealistic now that a bipartisan model of politics has emerged in Taiwan, and the Political Donations Act allows every candidate a fair chance to raise funds through normal means.

An adjustment must be made to the simple formula used to calculate the payable subsidy. As prominent candidates in large elections, such as a presidential race, tend to receive huge political contributions, they should obtain lower levels of subsidies to prevent "the wealthy from getting even wealthier."

Different subsidy standards should be set for different elections. And political parties should also require their candidates to contribute any subsidies left after deducting expenses to a party fund to make the politicians understand that they did not "earn" the money by themselves. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 15, 2010)
