DOC.HEADLINE: Flora Expo visitor number breaks 2 million mark
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 12:10:15 (By Lin Shen-hsu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The number of visitors to the Taipei International Flora Expo broke the 2 million mark Wednesday, slightly earlier than the organizers had originally projected.

The 2 millionth visitor was recorded at around 10: 11 a.m., less than three weeks after the 1 millionth visitor was tallied on Nov. 27, the Taipei International Flora Expo Operational Headquarters said.

The visitor total was about 10 percent ahead of the expectations of the Flora Expo's organizers, who had projected a total of 8 million people would visit the fair during its run from Nov. 6 to Arpil 25, 2011.
The organizers could not immediately identify the 2 millionth visitor because the exposition has many entrances and ticket sale venues.
So the Flora Expo organizers gave vouchers to the 1,999,500th visitor and the 999 visitors who followed, from whom the 2 millionth visitor will be chosen in a lucky drawing later Wednesday.
The winner will receive an EVA Airways ticket to an Asian destination.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Foolish to delay AUO China project

TEXT.P: Despite the signing of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement and friendly interaction with China under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, the hostile tone of cross-Taiwan Strait economic ties has not changed much. This is illustrated by the slow screening of flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp.'s (AUO's) plan to invest in China.

In screening the project, which has been under review now for a year, the authorities must understand the coopetitive relationship between the upstream and downstream sections of the flat panel industry.

South Korea, Japan, China and Taiwan are the four major players in the industry. Although Taiwan's AUO and Chimei Innolux Corp. are both large manufacturers, they are obviously inferior to their South Korean counterparts when it comes to vertical integration.

Thanks to a subsidy program promoted by China to encourage consumer electronics purchases by rural residents, Taiwan's flat panel makers received many orders from Chinese consumer electronics manufacturers. Samsung was not chosen as a cooperation partner because the Korean flat panel maker also produces consumer electronics and was thus a competitor to Chinese manufacturers.

Based on this reasoning, China has welcomed the AUO investment project with open arms and is looking forward to cooperation with Taiwan. Such a good opportunity, however, has been delayed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs for a year, a situation made worse by the stupid requirement that Taiwan-funded plants in China must be at least one generation behind their parent firms technologically.

In the context of industrial competition, Taiwan's enemy is not necessarily China, but is most likely South Korea. The Ma administration must come to its senses and not be fooled by those incompetent economics officials any longer. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 15, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: India trade fair reflects MediaTek's diversification goal: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 12:54:18 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The presence of integrated circuit designer MediaTek Inc. at a mobile communication applications exhibition in India reflects the company's effort to diversify its customer base and offset the impact of escalating price competition in China, an analyst said Wednesday.
MediaTek announced Tuesday it had joined forces with the CMAI Association of India to hold a two-day India-China Sourcing Mobile Fair 2010, which will run through Thursday.
The company said it was displaying its latest communication technology and innovative smartphones, as well as its 3G and multimedia solutions, at the trade show.

Co-organizing the event showed MediaTek's "strong commitment to the India market and "its leading position gained through continuous efforts to deliver the best service and wireless platform solutions to local customers," the company said.
The move into India could help the chip designer balance the low margins plaguing its sales to China, which is currently MediaTek's biggest market, an analyst said.

"India is a fast growing market for the global cell phone business. As MediaTek is faced with fierce competition in China, diversification of its customer base is one of the solutions to the problem," Grand Cathay Securities analyst Julian Wang said.
"India is one of the most important emerging markets because of its huge population. MediaTek cannot afford to ignore it, " Wang added.

According to industry market researcher Gartner Inc., India was likely to post the most rapid growth of mobile phone users in the world in 2010, with the number expected to hit 660 million by the end of this year.
Wang said a price war in China dragged down MediaTek's gross margin in the third quarter, and it could further deteriorate in the final three months of the year.

In the July-September period, MediaTek's gross margin stood at 52.22 percent, down 2.81 percentage points from the second quarter, and Wang said the figure might fall below 50 percent in the fourth quarter.
"The company has no choice but to find ways to ease the downward pressure on the gross margin," Wang said.

At the trade fair, MediaTek is showcasing a series of handsets based on its latest single chip -- the MT6253 -- and an Android platform customized for the India market with a wide range of applications, including online games such as Acorn Mafia, Mini Map and Navigation.
The CMAI Association of India is a group that promotes the Indian IT and telecom sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Motech admitted into European solar group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CAN) 12/15/10 14:12:24 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Motech Industries, Inc., a Taiwan-based solar cell maker, said Wednesday it has been accepted as a member by the European Photovoltaic Industry Association (EPIA) , becoming the first Taiwanese solar company to join the group.
According to Motech, the EPIA is the world's largest industry association devoted to the development of the solar photovoltaic (PV) electricity market.
Its main priority is to assist its members in developing their businesses in the European Union and promoting exports in other markets.

"We are taking this opportunity to gain a greater understanding and increase our involvement in the policies that have and will continue to shape this market, " said Motech CEO P.H. Chang in a statement.
"In addition, our membership in the EPIA assures our worldwide partners of our continued presence in the market," Chang said.
Motech's admission into the association follows its establishment of a representative office in Europe at the beginning of this year to provide better service and support to its customers there.
Motech said the opening of the office demonstrated its intention to pay closer attention to its global customers, and the company credited the move with helping it gain admission into the EPIA.

The company has seen its fortunes improve this year, posting NT$2.80 billion (US$93.70 million) in net profit in the first nine months, compared with a net loss of NT$387 million recorded during the same period a year earlier.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the world's largest contract chip maker, currently holds about a 20 percent stake in Motech as part of its efforts to diversify into the renewable energy sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Electronics makers reeling as NT$ rising

TEXT.P: The Taiwan dollar hit a 13-year high of NT$29.89 against the U.S. dollar during trading on the local foreign exchange market Tuesday, but made gains later to close at NT$30.45, a nearly 0.5 percent rise from the previous day's close of NT$30.6.

Although the greenback's value remained above NT$30 in interbank trading, it fell below that benchmark level in transactions between banks and individual customers. At the Bank of Taiwan, regular clients were buying the U.S. dollar at NT$29.98 Tuesday.
The appreciation of the Taiwan dollar has drawn complaints from local export- oriented industries, electronics contractors in particular.

Major notebook contractors, such as Quanta, Compal and Pegatron, said their gross margin for the fourth quarter of this year will drop further below 4 percent because of the local currency's continuing rise.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Commercial Times:

Citing Reuters quotes, local electronics makers said the Korean won has appreciated only about 2.13 percent against the U.S. dollar so far this year, far less than the 7.07 percent surge in the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the greenback.
If the Taiwan dollar were to continue strengthening against the U.S. dollar, local downstream electronics companies could lose their edge in the highly competitive field.

Because of cutthroat competition and currency appreciation, local electronics contract makers saw their gross margins fall below 4 percent in the third quarter for the first time, and those margins would be further eroded by the ongoing appreciation of the local currency.
A Pegatron spokesman said the Taiwan dollar's rise had lowered the company's gross margin by 0.7-0.8 percentage points in the third quarter.

In comparison, upstream vendors were more optimistic about their ability to absorb currency fluctuations. Executives of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronic Corp. and the ASE Group said the currency's appreciation would only have a limited impact on their sales and margins because it would also help lower the costs of production equipment and raw materials. (Dec. 15, 2010).
United Daily News:

The Taiwan dollar surged to NT$29.89 against the U.S. dollar at one point Tuesday, the highest level it had ever attained since Perng Fai-nan took the helm at the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) in February 1998.
Thanks to the central bank's intervention late in the trading session, the Taiwan dollar closed at NT$30.45 against the greenback, which still marked a 28-month high.
The public reacted calmly to the currency's appreciation, however, with no local banks reporting a rush to unload the U.S. dollar.
Senior bankers said that because the greenback's recent roller-coaster slide could severely hurt rash dealers, many potential investors have adopted a wait- and-see attitude.

Acknowledging that the Taiwan dollar faces strong appreciation pressure amid continued money inflows driven in part by the U.S. government's quantitative easing policy, the bankers said the local currency's surge past the NT$30 level would be a long-term trend. (Dec. 15, 2010).
China Times:
Banking sources said the recent surge in the Taiwan dollar's value was mainly fueled by speculative trading by George Soros' Quantum Fund.
In the past, the sources said, hot money destined to speculate on the Taiwan dollar came primarily from the United States and Europe.
But recently, the speculative inflows were coming mostly from Hong Kong, where Soros set up a branch office last month, the sources said.
Soros reportedly lost a lot of money speculating on the Taiwan dollar in 1997, and the sources said he was out for revenge this time around.

Central bank officials would not confirm the report, but they also did not rule out the possibility. They added that the central bank would keep a close watch on the direction of hot money flows and take timely action to avoid having the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate determined by the "Wall Street" gang. (Dec. 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Government denies involvement of VP's sister in espionage case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 15:01:16 (By Garfie Li, Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office rejected Wednesday a media report suggesting that a sister of Vice President Vincent Siew might be involved in an espionage scandal that broke last month.
According to office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, the vice president's sister, Hsiao Ya-wen, is a retired elementary school teacher who leads a simple life.
However, Siew will advise his relatives to pay attention to their behavior and avoid situations that could spark controversy, Lo said.

According to the latest edition of Next magazine issued that day, Lo Chi-cheng, a military intelligence officer who was detained last month for allegedly acting as a double agent for China, told prosecutors that he knew Hsiao Ya-wen and had had work-related contact with her.
Ministry of National Defense spokesman Yu Sy-tue dismissed the report as unfactual.
Although Lo Chi-cheng and Hsiao Ya-wen do indeed know each other, they did not have any work-related contact, according to Yu.
He said his ministry is considering taking legal action against the tabloid for publishing the report.

Meanwhile, Hsiao Ya-wen issued a written statement saying that she only met Lo several times on social occasions. Hsiao said she was unclear about the details of the scandal in which Lo is implicated and that she was not involved in the case.
Hsiao also indicated that she plans to seek legal means to protect her reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan eyeing U.S. visa-free entry in 2011: representative
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 15:20:17 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to be considered eligible for visa-free entry to the United States for its citizens in 2011, Taiwan's representative to the U.S. said Wednesday.

"The signing of three agreements on the exchange of information on stolen or counterfeit passports; the exchange of information on terrorists; and collaboration on combating crime will be crucial for Taiwan to be placed on the visa-waiver program (VWP) roadmap, " Jason Yuan said during a session of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Committee.
With the extensive personnel flow between Taiwan and the U.S., the inclusion in the VWP became a priority after Taiwan was granted visa-free privileges for the Schengen Area of Europe last month.

There are three key factors in terms of Taiwan's VWP inclusion -- visa refusal rates, cases of overstay and a passport application and issuance procedure that requires travelers to apply in person, Yuan said.

Taiwan's U.S. visa refusal rate for fiscal 2010 was 2.2 percent, much lower than the minimum requirement of 3 percent, and few cases of Taiwanese overstays were recorded, Yuan said, adding that new procedures will be tested in Taiwan requiring visa applicants to complete their passport applications in person, starting March 1, 2011.

The signing of the three agreements will also improve Taiwan's chances of satisfying the three factors, according to U.S. recommendations in a meeting between the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and Taiwan's Office of Homeland Security under the Executive Yuan, which took place recently in Washington, Yuan said.
Also speaking at the legislative committee meeting, Deputy Foreign Minister Shen Lyu-hsun reaffirmed that Taiwan intends to be a candidacy country of the VWP in 2011.

The visa-waiver drive, under which 96 countries or regions in the world now grant Taiwan visa exemptions, is part of Taiwan's commemoration of next year's 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.18 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CAN) 12/15/10 16:12:08 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.18 percent Wednesday after seesaw fluctuations between buying in old economy stocks and selling in the bellwether electronics sector, which has been haunted by a rising New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 16.28 points to the day's high of 8,756.71, off a low of 8,698.41, on turnover of NT$136.89 billion (US$4.58 billion).

The market opened up 0.17 percent and kept moving in a narrow range as concerns that a stronger New Taiwan dollar would hurt Taiwan's exports continued weighing on the export-oriented high-tech sector, the dealers said.

However, the New Taiwan dollar appreciation cut both ways, as buying in non high-tech stocks was ignited by hopes that the value of their domestic assets would go up, riding the rising local currency, they said.
A total of 1,585 stocks closed up and 2,683 were down with 344 remaining unchanged.

The plastics and chemical sector scored the highest gains, ending up 1.9 percent. Construction stocks rose 1.1 percent, cement and textile stocks each gained 0.7 percent and the paper and pulp sector closed up 0.6 percent.
The financial sector rose 0.4 percent, while foodstuffs closed unchanged and the machinery and electronics sector fell 0.3 percent.

While many investors remained concerned about Taiwan's global competitiveness amid an appreciating New Taiwan dollar, many others held out hope that a rising local unit would attract more foreign funds, Ta Chan Securities analyst Robin Wu said.
Wu said investors were willing to park their funds to old economy stocks that have been serving as safe havens.
"We have seen technical support after the index fell below 8,700 points," he said.
Wu said that with many foreign institutional investors on the sidelines for the upcoming Christmas holiday, the market drifted without direction throughout the trading session.
"The market is expected to continue to move in a range ahead of the nearest technical resistance at around 8,800 points in the near term," Wu said.

Among the old economy stocks, Kindom Construction added 3.35 percent to close at NT$33.90, Nan Ya Plastics rose 2.13 percent to finish at NT$71.90 and Formosa Plastics gained 1.91 percent to end the day at NT$96.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air force training plane missing
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 16:26:20 (By Hsia Nien-tzu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An air force T34 Mentor training plane crashed in a remote river valley in Kaohsiung County's Liugui Township Wednesday leaving a flight instructor and a cadet missing as of that afternoon.
The county's fire bureau said it began receiving calls from local people at around 2 p.m. reporting an air crash in the vicinity of Butterfly Valley in the township's Xinliao Village.
The Air Force Academy later confirmed that the plane was missing.

Bureau officials said the reported crash site is in a deep valley that is not easily approached. They added that it will take quite some time to determine the exact crash location before starting a rescue mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore to start talks on trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 16:51:13 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore will start talks on the possible signing of an economic partnership agreement early next year, a joint statement released by the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei and the Taipei Representative Office in Singapore said Wednesday.

Taiwan and Singapore, which are both members of the World Trade Organization, have completed their own feasibility studies and concluded that such an agreement "would offer significant mutual benefits," the statement said.

Should the formal negotiations result in a deal, the trade pact would be titled "Agreement between Singapore and the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu on Economic Partnership (ASTEP)," according to the statement.
"Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" is the name under which Taiwan was admitted to the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold, wet weather forecast for Wednesday to Friday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 17:26:43 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A cold front from China will envelop Taiwan from Wednesday to Friday, sending temperatures plunging in areas north of Chiayi County and bringing rain, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
Temperatures will drop sharply Wednesday night to below 12 degrees Celsius in central and northern Taiwan, the bureau said.
By Thursday night, northern Taiwan could expect lows of 9 degrees and the chill will last until Friday, the CWB forecast.
In addition, the CWB issued a heavy rain warning, saying showers can be expected through Friday as the cold front will also bring humid air.
As a result, the CWB said, there is likely to be snow on Hehuanshan and Yushan, also known as Joy Mountain and Jade Mountain, respectively.
However, by Monday, temperatures will return to the current level of between 15 and 23 degrees Celsius, the CWB forecast.
The bureau advised fish breeders and tea growers to take the necessary precautions to prevent damage to their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two killed in air force training plane crash
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 17:34:45 (By Chen Shou-kuo, Hsia Nien-tzu, and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An air force T34 Mentor training plane crashed in Kaohsiung County's Liugui Township Wednesday, killing a flight instructor and a cadet on board, the Air Force Academy said later that same day.
Chi Pei-lieh, director of the academy's Political Warfare Department, said the bodies of instructor Niu Peng-yu and cadet Liu Che-hung had been recovered.
Their T-34 Mentor took off from the academy at 1: 08 p.m. on a routine training mission and disappeared from radar at 2:02 p.m., Chi said.
At around 2 p.m., the county's fire bureau said it began receiving calls from local people reporting an air crash in the vicinity of Butterfly Valley in the township's Xinliao Village.
Bureau officials said the reported crash site is in a deep valley that is not easily approached, making recovery of the bodies difficult.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore to open formal talks on trade deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 17:55:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore will begin formal negotiations on a free trade agreement early next year after completing feasibility studies, representatives of both governments announced in a joint press release Wednesday.

If a deal were reached, it would be titled "Agreement between Singapore and the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu on Economic Partnership, " or ASTEP, the Taipei Representative Office in Singapore and the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei said in the statement.
"Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" is Taiwan's official name at the World Trade Organization, of which Singapore is also a member.

The decision to launch formal negotiations came after both sides completed feasibility studies and concluded that an economic cooperation agreement would offer significant mutual benefits, the statement said.
Delegations from both sides met for the first time in Singapore from Dec. 9-10, according to the statement, but it did not specify when formal talks would begin.
The statement left open the possibility that priority areas could be accorded expedited treatment in the negotiations.

The much-anticipated deal is seen as a stepping stone for Taiwan to seek more free trade agreements (FTAs) with major trading partners after signing an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China in June to liberalize bilateral trade.

Prior to signing the ECFA, which so far has provided for tariff reductions or exemptions on only a limited basket of goods, Taiwan had only concluded four FTAs with five of its diplomatic allies in Latin America that accounted for less than 0.2 percent of Taiwan's total external trade.
A trade deal with Singapore would be significant because it is Taiwan's fifth largest export market and one of its top 10 trading partners, with bilateral trade reaching US$13.4 billion in 2009.

Singapore became the first country to express interest in signing an FTA with Taiwan following the signing of the ECFA. The two countries first issued a joint press release on Aug. 5 saying they were exploring the feasibility of signing an economic cooperation agreement.

Taiwan has had trouble signing free trade deals with non-allied countries in the past because of China's obstruction. But the government has argued that after the signing of the ECFA, other countries would be more open to negotiating trade pacts with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 18:35:51 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.05 to close at NT$30.500.
Turnover totaled US$881 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.500 and moved between NT$29.800 and NT$30.550 before the close.
Dealers said the New Taiwan dollar continued its momentum from the previous day, rising above NT$30.00 against the U.S. dollar during most of the trading session before the central bank intervened.
Further inflows of foreign funds drove the New Taiwan dollar higher against the U.S. currency as buying came largely from foreign banks, the dealers said.

In late trade, the central bank pumped funds into the market to buy the U.S. dollar and reverse the early upside of the New Taiwan dollar, pushing the local currency to below the NT$30.00 level, dealers said.
It seems that at the moment the central bank can tolerate nothing stronger than the NT$30.00 level in its bid to protect Taiwan's exports, the dealers said.
With the approach of the Christmas holiday and many traders on the sidelines, turnover remained moderate despite the central bank's intervention, dealers said.
The relatively quiet trade has made it easier for the central bank to intervene, they said.

With foreign funds continuing to flow into the local market, the the closing level of the New Taiwan dollar is expected to gradually move closer to NT$30.00 against the U.S. dollar in the near future, the dealers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitor arrivals to Taiwan from North America up 9 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/15/10 18:52:06 (By Leaf Yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will launch a new promotional program to encourage more visits to the country by people from North America, after arrivals from the region have increased by 9 percent so far this year, a Taiwanese official said Tuesday in Los Angeles.

The number of visitors from North America so far this year has totaled around 412,000, including 360,000 from the United States, according to Liu Hsi-lin, visiting deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau.
The U.S. visitor arrivals represent a rise of 8.98 percent from last year, he said.

To further boost tourism, the bureau will provide 10,000 US$100 discount coupons that will be made available to travelers who book flights to Taiwan or hotels in Taiwan through contracted travel agencies or airline companies, Liu went on.

A Taiwan section will also be set up on the online travel agency website Travelocity, he continued, adding that any foreign passport holders who make reservations at designated hotels via the site between January and May 2011 will enjoy "book one night, get one free" rates.

In light of the success of a "Taiwan Day" activity promoted earlier this year through a partnership with the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team, the bureau is planning to launch a similar program in cooperation with the U.S. National Football League next year to further boost Taiwan's visibility in North America, according to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice ministry censured for failing to punish prosecutor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 18:58:39 (Bu Sophia Yeh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan censured the Ministry of Justice Wednesday for failing to punish a prosecutor for misconduct in accordance with a request by the watchdog body.
The Control Yuan in 2002 asked the ministry to deal with a matter of Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen abusing his power by suing the head of the Tai Ji Men Qigong Academy for fraud and tax-evasion.
According to the Control Yuan, Hou violated the Code of Criminal Procedure by illegally searching Hong Shih-ho's property, freezing his assets and prosecuting him in 1997.

Hong was accused by a group of his former students of taking money from them by claiming to be a god and possessing miraculous powers, and Hou, who was working at the Taipei District Prosecutors Office at that time, indicted Hong based on the allegations of the students.

The Justice Ministry however, did not punish Hou for misconduct but instead assigned another prosecutor to carry out an "administrative investigation" into Hou's actions. The investigation concluded that Hou was not guilty of any wrongdoing in Hong's case.
In 2007, more than 10 years after the lawsuit was filed, the Supreme Court acquitted Hong of all the charges brought against him by Hou.
The Control Yuan said that the Justice Ministry's reluctance to punish the prosecutor has substantially "undermined" the credibility of the country's judiciary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air quality in Kaohsiung City shows improvement
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 19:11:42 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The air quality in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City has shown a marked improvement, with the ratio of Pollution Standard Index (PSI) decreasing to a record low of 3.76 percent as of November, the city's Environmental Protection Bureau said Wednesday.
The average PSI of the city in 2009 was 4.9 percent -- meaning that the PSI exceeded 100, a standard for unacceptable air quality, on only 4.9 percent of the days in the year.
The figure is in stark contrast to highest PSI since records began -- 12.48 percent in 1994.
The improvement is a result of a series of air pollution control measures that have helped reduce carbon emissions, said Lee Mu-sheng, director-general of the bureau.

For example, he said, the city government has encouraged citizens to use public transport and has conducted thorough inspections to prevent factories, the city's harbor and construction sites from emitting heavy pollutants.
In addition, a subsidy program to promote eco-friendly electronic vehicles was implemented as part of these efforts, Lee added.
The Environmental Protection Bureau uses the PSI to measure major pollutants, including sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, lead and ozone, as an indicator of air quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO receives R&D achievement award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 19:17:10 (By Pan Chi-i, Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Science Park officials said Wednesday that flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) has received the 2010 Science Park R&D Accomplishment Award because of the great number of patents it has been granted.
It is the eighth consecutive year AUO has been awarded the prize by the science park, the officials said.

As of the end of November, AUO had been granted more than 7,400 patents worldwide, while the flat panel maker is seeking an additional 15,000 patents for which applications have already been submitted, according to the company.
In 2009, AUO filed the largest number of patent applications of any local optoelectronics firms, the flat panel maker cited the Intellectual Property Office as saying.

In addition to the efforts to obtain patents, the annual awards also evaluated the amount of funds a company assigns to research and development, as well as the amount of manpower devoted to technological R&D, the park officials said.
Realtek Semiconductor Corp., Elan Microelectronics Corp., Microelectronics Technology Inc. and ISSC Technologies Corp. were also awarded, the officials said.

Meanwhile that same day, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the Investment Commission under the MOEA is expected to approve a US$3 billion China investment proposal from AUO by Friday.
AUO has submitted an application with the MOEA and has since March been seeking regulatory approval to build a 7.5th-generation flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province.

The investment project has passed critical screening of the key technology involved in the investment, but is pending the screening of various additional formalities before final approval is issued by the commission.

A day earlier, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said that as the project will involve a large amount of investment, the ministry might call a special review meeting before issuing its approval.

To assure the government that the company will maintain its technological lead over its Chinese facility and its long-term commitment to Taiwan, AUO also plans to invest NT$400 billion (US$13.39 billion) in building two 11th-generation flat panel plants, as well as solar energy facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan attends trade fair in Cambodia after five-year hiatus
DOC.DATELINE: Phnom Penh, Cambodia, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 19:29:21 (By Tony Fang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 40 Taiwanese firms made their debut appearance at an international industrial machinery fair in Cambodia Wednesday in an effort to expand trade and economic ties between the two countries.

The group of 44 companies, led by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), attended the Cambodia Machine Tech 2010 in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh, the first time Taiwan has been represented in five years.
Cambodia is an emerging market, particularly in consumer product development, said Yeh Chi-ling, head of the TAITRA exhibition department.
In addition, there is increasing demand in Cambodia for various products, including food- and produce-wrapping facilities, plastics and rubber, Yeh added.
Yeh said she expects Taiwan's exhibits of machinery, components, information and communications technology and consumer products will find their way into the Cambodian market.

The two sides' trade value was more than US$372 million in 2009, compared with US$354 million in the first eight months of this year alone, according to statistics, which suggest that this year's total is likely to exceed that of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. urged not to jeopardize Taiwan's interests in dealings with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 19:40:43 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has urged the United States not to put Taiwan's interests at risk in its engagements with China, Taiwan's foreign ministry said Wednesday, ahead of a visit to the U.S. in January by Chinese President Hu Jintao.

"We have advised the U.S. not to jeopardize Taiwan's interests" in its dealings with China, Deputy Foreign Minister Shen Lyu-shun said in a meeting of the legislature's foreign and national defense committee.
Taiwan has also requested an immediate briefing after Hu's visit to the U.S. and has asked to be informed ahead of time of important U.S.-China meetings in the future, Shen said.
Legislators expressed disappointment over a joint statement issued last November by the U.S. and China during U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to Beijing.

In the statement, the two countries underscored "the importance of the Taiwan issue in U.S.-China relations." China further emphasized that "the Taiwan issue concerns China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, " and expressed the hope that the U.S. would "honor its relevant commitments and appreciate and support the Chinese side's position on this issue."
Referring to three communiques that the U.S. and China signed in 1972, 1979 and 1982 and which helped to normalize U.S.-China relations, Shen said a fourth communique was unlikely.
"But another joint statement is possible," he said.
Shen and Jason Yuan, Taiwan's representative to the U.S., both said that currently Taiwan-U.S. relations are "the best in 60 years," as described by former U.S. Ambassador to China Winston Lord.

Taiwan's diplomats now have greater access to the U.S. executive and legislative branches as well as to important figures in the White House, Shen said. This can be attributed to President Ma Ying-jeou's "surprise-free" approach, which has won praise in Washington and has helped to stabilize bilateral relations, he added.

Yuan said the U.S. has briefed Taiwan on a scheduled visit to China by a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State James Steinberg. In meetings scheduled for Dec. 14-17, the delegation is expected to discuss with China the North Korea issue and Hu's state visit to the U.S. in January, he said.
The delegation includes Jeffrey Bader, National Security Council senior director for Asian affairs, and Kurt Campbell, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, Yuan said.

Yuan, who returned to Taiwan to report to the legislature, said that he was hopeful that next round of U.S.-Taiwan talks under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) would take place before the Lunar New Year next February.
A visit to Taiwan by former U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is also in the works, Yuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman receives big prize as 2 millionth visitor to Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 20:10:12 (By Lin Shen-hsu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A woman residing near the Taipei International Flora Expo received two free flight tickets Wednesday after a lucky draw determined that she was officially the 2 millionth visitor.

Chang-Liu Tsai-lien, 60, also received a certificate allowing her to visit five of the expo's most popular exhibition halls -- the Pavilion of Dreams, the Pavilion of Regimen, the Taipei Story House, Expo Theater and Celebrity's House -- without having to wait in line.
The flight tickets, provided by EVA Airways, allow the winner and her companion to travel to any of the Asian destinations the carrier serves.

The 2 millionth visitor was recorded at around 10 a.m. that day, but the Taipei International Flora Expo Operational Headquarters could not immediately identify who the visitor was because the exposition has many entrances and ticket sale counters.

The headquarters awarded vouchers to the 1,999,500th visitor and the 999 visitors who followed, from among whom the 2 millionth visitor was chosen in the lucky draw presided over by Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.
Chang-Liu said she and her husband have toured the expo almost every day since its opening because it is only a 10-minute walk from their home.
"Both of us have bought season tickets for the event and we like every exhibit on display," she said.

Four other visitors were also chosen in the lucky draw, each of whom was given a season ticket for the expo as second prize. Five more visitors were chosen as third prize-winners, each of whom received a collection of Flora Expo souvenirs.
The operational headquarters said the arrival of the 2 millionth visitor came earlier than expected.

The organizers had originally projected that a total of 8 million people will visit the fair during its run from Nov. 6 through April 25, 2011. It took 22 days for the visitor number to reach 1 million -- on Nov. 27 -- and only a further 18 days to tally the 2 millionth visitor.
"The figures indicate that the number of visitors is increasing at an ever faster pace, " a spokesman for the headquarters said, adding that the daily visitor number has hit an average of 50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT, Chinese visitors drive up Taipei land prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 20:52:36 (By Sun Cheng-wu, Lin Yi-feng, Hao Hsue-ching and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Average land prices in Taipei City's 12 districts have gone up 12.08 percent from a year ago, thanks in large part to the expected completion of several new mass rapid transit (MRT) lines and increasing tourist visits from China, officials said Wednesday.

The city's Department of Land released the 2011 "officially assessed" land prices for the city's 12 districts that same day, pointing out that the average 12.08 percent year-on-year increase was the largest in nearly 10 years and the first double-digit growth since 2005.

The city's Zhongzheng District saw the biggest yearly increase of 12.59 percent, followed by Xinyi District at 12.57 percent and Daan District at 12.51 percent, with Wenshan District trailing at 10.76 percent.
The department's director, Huang Jung-feng, said real estate prices in the city started to fly in March 2010 and continued to rise in spite of central bank measures in June to dampen the market.

Other factors contributing to the soaring land prices include the record-setting high bids for public land, more and more visits by Chinese tourists, and the gradual completion of the MRT system -- the Xinzhuang, Songshang and Xinyi lines are scheduled to be launched in the coming years, Huang noted.

According to the latest government figures, the most expensive real estate in Taipei is in the Shin Kong Life Tower near Taipei Main Station, at NT$3.64 million (US$122,200) per ping (one ping equals 3.3 square meters).

Shin Kong Life Tower has thus become the most expensive property in Taiwan -- the 13th year it has held that title. The vicinity enjoys the privileges of being a traffic hub combining railway, high speed rail and MRT services.

Looking ahead, though, it might not keep that honor for long. Taipei 101 Building in the east of the city is fast catching up. Now valued at NT$3.35 million (US$112,500) per ping, second only to the Shin Kong Life Tower, real estate agents say Taipei 101 might become Taiwan's "king of land" -- as local media like to call it -- by 2016.

In comparison, the most expensive land in Taichung City, central Taiwan, is worth an official price of NT$660,000 per ping. It is owned by the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store, according to Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi.

The government releases its officially assessed land prices not for the sake of collecting more taxes but rather for the sake of narrowing the gap between officially announced prices and market prices, Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ready to sign medical cooperation agreement with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 21:21:15 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to sign a medical cooperation agreement with China, which is expected to benefit the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, in the latest round of bilateral negotiations next week, Taiwanese officials said Wednesday.

With preparatory talks having been completed, the heads of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) should have no problem signing the deal in their sixth round of bilateral negotiations scheduled to be held Dec. 20-22 in Taipei between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin.

The agreement will be the 15th and one of the the most wide-ranging agreements between the two sides since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008, Lai Shin-yuan, minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said in a joint press conference held by the MAC and the Department of Health (DOH).

Prevention of epidemics, management of research and development of medical products, management and research of traditional Chinese medicine, and first aid and emergency medical treatment, will be included in the agreement, according to the DOH.
Among them, prevention of epidemics and management of traditional Chinese medicine are considered the most urgent items, said Deputy Health Minister Hsiao Mei-ling.

With a platform for information-sharing and a mechanism for pandemic notification established, Taiwan's health authorities will be better able to deal with severe epidemics and outbreaks of contagious diseases such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome and H1N1 influenza, according to Chang Feng-yee, director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control.

The DOH said China has agreed to a "five noes" principle that stated Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to take local licensing exams; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese medical professionals to practice here; that Taiwan will not allow Chinese investment in building and running local hospitals; that Taiwan's national health insurance program will not pay for medical bills incurred by its citizens in Chinese medical facilities; and that the agreement will not contain any provisions regarding joint efforts to educate and cultivate medical professionals.

However, not everything went smoothly in the negotiations, as both sides confirmed that an investment protection agreement will not be signed as planned due to disagreement over trade dispute settlement measures and human safety protection.
In addition to the signing ceremony, Chen is scheduled to visit the Taipei International Flora Expo, but he will not meet with President Ma, MAC Deputy Chairman Liu Te-hsun told reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most of IBM's widely-used servers designed in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 21:44:41 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: IBM said Wednesday that the staff at its Taiwan-based research center is creative in terms of product ideas, as evidenced by the fact that most of the company's widely used x86 servers were designed in Taiwan.

"The team in Taiwan is very aggressive in terms of exploring ideas, in terms of how we develop the product, in terms of the ideas around the product. They bring a different perspective from the team in the U.S., " Chris Verne, director of IBM Taiwan System and Technology Laboratory (TSTL), told CNA in an exclusive interview.

Verne said he was impressed by the willingness of the Taiwan team to work in a different discipline and the way the team pulled together to tackle different types of situations or schedule challenges.
The staff at TSTL is now 10 times bigger than it was when the laboratory was established in 2006, he said.

Regarding IBM's system business, there are only two countries -- the U.S. and Taiwan -- that have x86-based product development centers providing end to end project management, including marketing, product design, manufacturing and sales, he said.
According to Verne, the TSTL is responsible for 65 percent of IBM's designs for its x86-based servers.

"We think Taiwan is well positioned within this industry for technology leadership, thought leadership and skills leadership, " he said. "That's how we tie the global competitiveness at this point to what we are doing here in Taiwan."

Asia Pacific server shipments grew 13.4 percent year-on-year in the third quarter of 2010, while revenue expanded 25.7 percent year- on-year, according to the global technology research and advisory firm Gartner.

IBM led the Asia Pacific server market based on revenue of US$928.4 million and a 43.1 percent market share in the third quarter this year, an increase of 3 percent from the same period in 2009, the research firm said.

Meanwhile, investment in mainframes helped to drive robust revenue growth in the Asia Pacific during the third quarter of 2010 along with continued strength in the x86 segment, which has consistently grown in double digits for four consecutive quarters, Gartner said.

"One of the things that make Taiwan very attractive is that Taiwan is sort of the door to China, and Taiwan has established an ecosystem in the industry which is supported by the government, " Verne said.

Asked about the company's plans regarding the China market, Verne said that IBM has already built a laboratory in Shanghai, and the two teams in Taiwan and China will work more closely to expand the business in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fugitive gunman escorted back to Taiwan from China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 21:58:01 (By Bien Chen-feng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A fugitive gunman who fled Taiwan eight years ago was escorted back from Macau Wednesday by armed law enforcement officers, Taiwan police said.
The suspect Chen Yung-chih, in his early 40s, was arrested in Shenzhen City Dec. 6 by Chinese police.
Chen was wanted in Taiwan in connection with five shooting incidents in which four people were killed, the police said. The incidents took place in central and southern Taiwan between 1998 and 2004.
One of the victims was a pregnant woman who was shot outside the SOGO department store in Taichung. She has been in a vegetative state since.
The arrest is considered one of the successes of a Cross-Strait Joint Crime- Fighting and Judicial Mutual Assistance Agreement that was signed between Taiwan and China in 2009, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore prepare to forge economic partnership (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:17:29 (By Kuo Wu-huan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Talks will begin early next year between Taiwan and Singapore on an economic partnership agreement that both countries have determined will bring "positive and conspicuous" benefits, Taiwan's representative in that Southeast Asian country said Wednesday.

In a telephone interview with the CNA, Vanessa Shih said both parties have completed their respective feasibility studies on signing such an agreement and have concluded that it would offer significant mutual benefits.
However, she admitted that such an agreement could negatively affect some sectors of Taiwan's economy.
"Our negotiators will make sure the negative effects will be minimized and benefits maximized, as they work hard to expand business opportunities for Taiwan," she stressed.

Many industries in the two countries are complementary, sharing an industrial chain relationship marked by up-stream and down-stream cooperation that eventually will create a win-win situation for both sides, Shih said.

Less than two months after Taiwan signed a historic Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China, Taiwan and Singapore jointly announced on Aug. 5 they were interested in negotiating a similar deal.
Following that announcement, delegations from the Singapore Trade Office (STO) in Taipei and the Taipei Representative Office (TRO) in Singapore met for the first time in Singapore December 9-10.

Formal negotiations under the title "Agreement between Singapore and the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu on Economic Partnership" (ASTEP) are scheduled to begin early next year, the two offices said in a joint press release Wednesday.
Both sides agreed that priority areas may be accorded expedited treatment in the negotiations, the joint statement added.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang welcomed the latest development, saying ASTEP is a good name, as partnership has become a trend.

Calling the economic partnership agreement a kind of free trade agreement, the minister said ASTEP also means "An important STEP" for Taiwan, which is seeking to forge more regional economic cooperation pacts in an effort to integrate into the regional economy.

Both Taiwan and Singapore are members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) . Two-way trade between them in 2009 totaled US$13.4 billion, as Singapore was Taiwan's 6th largest trading partner after China, Japan, the United States, Hong Kong and Korea.
Singapore is also the sixth largest source of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency response system on Suhua Highway to be upgraded: authorities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:24:50 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: More monitoring and communication devices will be installed along the Suhua Highway to make road condition information and rescue facilities more easily available to drivers, the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) Wednesday.

A total of 21 emergency telephones will be set up along the coastal highway where cell phone signals are weak, while 35 closed-circuit televisions (CCTVs) and three content management systems (CMS) will be installed to display real time road conditions on billboards, the DGH said.
In addition, the DGH will construct another five open tunnels at points along the 118 km highway and will extend the tunnel at the 112.8 km mark from 30 meters to 100 meters, the DGH said.

These tunnels could serve as temporary shelters in case of sudden rock falls, said Liao Wu-chang, deputy director of the DGH's fourth maintenance office. The emergency response system is expected to be completed by April 2011, he said.
In late October, 26 people were killed by a mudslide on the Suhua Highway as northeastern Taiwan was being battered by heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi.
The DGH said its warning system did not work efficiently at that time since it failed to assess the high volume of rainfall in time to issue an alert.
However, the accident has prompted the DGH to improve its communication networks, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International sports court agrees to hear Taiwan's case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:34:14 (By Y. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has agreed to hear Taiwan's appeal against the disqualification of a Taiwanese taekwondo athlete in the recent Asian Games, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Wednesday.
SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the CAS might issue a ruling within three months of its decision to hear the appeal, which was filed on Dec. 8.

Yang Shu-chun, 25, was disqualified in her opening match in the Asiad women's under 49-kg division on Nov. 17 in Guangzhou, China. She was accused of wearing two extra electronic sensors in her socks to increase her chances of scoring. At the time, Yang was leading in the bout 9-0 and was seen as one of Taiwan's top contenders for a gold medal at the games.
Video footage of the bout, which was released later, showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before going into the competition area.

Taiwan's sports council and taekwondo bodies subsequently lodged complaints with the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) and the Olympic Council of Asia, and said it would seek CAS arbitration if the WTF failed to settle the matter fairly.

Meanwhile, the WTF's disciplinary committee is scheduled to hold a meeting in Seoul on Dec. 18. to discuss the issue. Yang, her coaches Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, and President of the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association Chen Chien- ping are expected to attend.

"We will assign an interpreter with legal skills to assist them at the Seoul meeting, which is expected to be conducted in English, " Tai said. "We will also ask for assistance from Taiwan's diplomatic mission in Seoul."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Minor Leaguers to enter Taiwan professional baseball draft
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:41:22 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Three baseballers from the United States Minor League were among the 88 players who applied to enter the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) next year, the domestic league said in a press release Wednesday.

Kuo Yen-wen, Chen Yung-chi and Tseng Sung-wei, who were all released by their teams in the U.S. this year, have submitted applications for the annual draft to be held Dec. 21 in Taipei, according to the press release.
Kuo, 22, who played for the Cincinnati Reds from 2007-2010, is known for his strong defense. He is capable of covering three infield positions -- shortstop, second baseman and third baseman.
With a 156 km per hour fastball, right-hander Tseng, 26, spent three years with the Cleveland Indians from 2007-2010 before heading home.

Four CPBL teams -- Uni-President Lions, La New Bears, Sinon Bulls and Brother Elephants -- will make their picks in that order, according to the league office. The draft will automatically end after all the teams renounce their rights to make picks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two killed in air force training plane crash (add more details)
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:47:07 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Two pilots were killed Wednesday when an Air Force Academy T-34 Mentor trainer plane crashed in southern Taiwan during a routine training mission.
It was the second crash this year involving a T-34 Mentor. In January, a trainer of the same type went down during a training flight in southern Taiwan, also killing two pilots aboard.

In the latest accident, the 49-year-old flight instructor, Niu Peng-yu, and Air Force Academy cadet Liu Che-hung, 25, were killed when the aircraft went down in Liouguei Township, Kaohsiung County, Air Force officials said.
The plane took off from the academy in the county's Gangshan Township at 1:08 p.m., but disappeared from radar at 2:02 p.m., the officials said.

The bodies of the two pilots have been recovered, but the cause of the crash was not immediately clear, the officials said. A special team has been formed to investigate the cause of the crash, they said.
It was the eighth T-34 Mentor to crash since the U.S.-made trainer aircraft was introduced in Taiwan in 1985.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who is familiar with defense affairs, said the aircraft in Taiwan's T-34 fleet are only midway through their operating lifespan and that more than 20 other countries around the world also use this type of plane for air force pilot training.

However, after the two crashes this year involving that aircraft model, the military should ground the rest of the fleet for thorough safety and maintenance checks to prevent other tragedies, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Houston Children's Chorus performs in ROC centennial warm-up
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:49:59 (By Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: An American children's chorus performed recently at the Culture Center of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Houston, Texas, as a warm -up for the centennial celebration of the Republic of China, the office said Wednesday.

The Houston Children's Chorus, founded in 1989, sang several songs in its Dec. 11 performance that included the Chinese folk song titled "Jasmine Flowers, " impressing an audience of more than 500 people, mainly from the Chinese American community in the area.
The chorus, comprising more than 250 2nd-8th graders, has performed for former U.S. presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, as well as for the United Nations Children's Fund.
TECO Director in Houston Joseph Chen presented a gift to chorus conductor Stephen Roddy to express appreciation for the performance.
He also invited the audience to attend a series of events to celebrate the upcoming ROC centennial in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court rejects request to seize ex-president's assets in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 23:10:16 (By Lai Yu-chia and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court on Wednesday turned down a request by prosecutors to seize the family assets of former President Chen Shui-bian, who is in prison on conviction of bribery.
The court said that some of the assets itemized were already on a list submitted earlier by prosecutors for seizure.
Chen is serving two jail sentences after being convicted of accepting bribes in connection with a land deal and a personnel appointment. He is facing other charges.

The special prosecutors team, which successfully indicted the former president and his wife Wu Shu-jen, had asked the court for permission to seize land, houses, term deposits and stocks in Taiwan owned by the couple and their immediate family members.
The prosecutors said seizure of the family's assets was part of the legal obligations linked to the conviction of the couple.

However, a High Court collegial panel ruled that the sum of more than NT$600 million in overseas bank deposits that has already been confiscated by prosecutors is sufficient to pay back Chen's illegal gains and there is therefore no need to seize his assets in Taiwan.

Also, the panel said, some of the Chen family assets that the prosecutors were seeking to confiscate had already been listed in an earlier request in connection with a financial reform kickback case, which is still being handled by the court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most of IBM's widely-used servers designed in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 21:44:41 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: IBM said Wednesday that the staff at its Taiwan-based research center is creative in terms of product ideas, as evidenced by the fact that most of the company's widely used x86 servers were designed in Taiwan.

"The team in Taiwan is very aggressive in terms of exploring ideas, in terms of how we develop the product, in terms of the ideas around the product. They bring a different perspective from the team in the U.S., " Chris Verne, director of IBM Taiwan System and Technology Laboratory (TSTL), told CNA in an exclusive interview.

Verne said he was impressed by the willingness of the Taiwan team to work in a different discipline and the way the team pulled together to tackle different types of situations or schedule challenges.
The staff at TSTL is now 10 times bigger than it was when the laboratory was established in 2006, he said.

Regarding IBM's system business, there are only two countries -- the U.S. and Taiwan -- that have x86-based product development centers providing end to end project management, including marketing, product design, manufacturing and sales, he said.
According to Verne, the TSTL is responsible for 65 percent of IBM's designs for its x86-based servers.

"We think Taiwan is well positioned within this industry for technology leadership, thought leadership and skills leadership, " he said. "That's how we tie the global competitiveness at this point to what we are doing here in Taiwan."

Asia Pacific server shipments grew 13.4 percent year-on-year in the third quarter of 2010, while revenue expanded 25.7 percent year- on-year, according to the global technology research and advisory firm Gartner.

IBM led the Asia Pacific server market based on revenue of US$928.4 million and a 43.1 percent market share in the third quarter this year, an increase of 3 percent from the same period in 2009, the research firm said.

Meanwhile, investment in mainframes helped to drive robust revenue growth in the Asia Pacific during the third quarter of 2010 along with continued strength in the x86 segment, which has consistently grown in double digits for four consecutive quarters, Gartner said.

"One of the things that make Taiwan very attractive is that Taiwan is sort of the door to China, and Taiwan has established an ecosystem in the industry which is supported by the government, " Verne said.

Asked about the company's plans regarding the China market, Verne said that IBM has already built a laboratory in Shanghai, and the two teams in Taiwan and China will work more closely to expand the business in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fugitive gunman escorted back to Taiwan from China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 21:58:01 (By Bien Chen-feng and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: A fugitive gunman who fled Taiwan eight years ago was escorted back from Macau Wednesday by armed law enforcement officers, Taiwan police said.
The suspect Chen Yung-chih, in his early 40s, was arrested in Shenzhen City Dec. 6 by Chinese police.
Chen was wanted in Taiwan in connection with five shooting incidents in which four people were killed, the police said. The incidents took place in central and southern Taiwan between 1998 and 2004.
One of the victims was a pregnant woman who was shot outside the SOGO department store in Taichung. She has been in a vegetative state since.
The arrest is considered one of the successes of a Cross-Strait Joint Crime- Fighting and Judicial Mutual Assistance Agreement that was signed between Taiwan and China in 2009, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore prepare to forge economic partnership (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:17:29 (By Kuo Wu-huan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Talks will begin early next year between Taiwan and Singapore on an economic partnership agreement that both countries have determined will bring "positive and conspicuous" benefits, Taiwan's representative in that Southeast Asian country said Wednesday.

In a telephone interview with the CNA, Vanessa Shih said both parties have completed their respective feasibility studies on signing such an agreement and have concluded that it would offer significant mutual benefits.
However, she admitted that such an agreement could negatively affect some sectors of Taiwan's economy.
"Our negotiators will make sure the negative effects will be minimized and benefits maximized, as they work hard to expand business opportunities for Taiwan," she stressed.

Many industries in the two countries are complementary, sharing an industrial chain relationship marked by up-stream and down-stream cooperation that eventually will create a win-win situation for both sides, Shih said.

Less than two months after Taiwan signed a historic Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China, Taiwan and Singapore jointly announced on Aug. 5 they were interested in negotiating a similar deal.
Following that announcement, delegations from the Singapore Trade Office (STO) in Taipei and the Taipei Representative Office (TRO) in Singapore met for the first time in Singapore December 9-10.

Formal negotiations under the title "Agreement between Singapore and the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu on Economic Partnership" (ASTEP) are scheduled to begin early next year, the two offices said in a joint press release Wednesday.
Both sides agreed that priority areas may be accorded expedited treatment in the negotiations, the joint statement added.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang welcomed the latest development, saying ASTEP is a good name, as partnership has become a trend.

Calling the economic partnership agreement a kind of free trade agreement, the minister said ASTEP also means "An important STEP" for Taiwan, which is seeking to forge more regional economic cooperation pacts in an effort to integrate into the regional economy.

Both Taiwan and Singapore are members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) . Two-way trade between them in 2009 totaled US$13.4 billion, as Singapore was Taiwan's 6th largest trading partner after China, Japan, the United States, Hong Kong and Korea.
Singapore is also the sixth largest source of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency response system on Suhua Highway to be upgraded: authorities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:24:50 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: More monitoring and communication devices will be installed along the Suhua Highway to make road condition information and rescue facilities more easily available to drivers, the Directorate General of Highways (DGH) Wednesday.

A total of 21 emergency telephones will be set up along the coastal highway where cell phone signals are weak, while 35 closed-circuit televisions (CCTVs) and three content management systems (CMS) will be installed to display real time road conditions on billboards, the DGH said.
In addition, the DGH will construct another five open tunnels at points along the 118 km highway and will extend the tunnel at the 112.8 km mark from 30 meters to 100 meters, the DGH said.

These tunnels could serve as temporary shelters in case of sudden rock falls, said Liao Wu-chang, deputy director of the DGH's fourth maintenance office. The emergency response system is expected to be completed by April 2011, he said.
In late October, 26 people were killed by a mudslide on the Suhua Highway as northeastern Taiwan was being battered by heavy rains brought by Typhoon Megi.
The DGH said its warning system did not work efficiently at that time since it failed to assess the high volume of rainfall in time to issue an alert.
However, the accident has prompted the DGH to improve its communication networks, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International sports court agrees to hear Taiwan's case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/10 22:34:14 (By Y. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has agreed to hear Taiwan's appeal against the disqualification of a Taiwanese taekwondo athlete in the recent Asian Games, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Wednesday.
SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the CAS might issue a ruling within three months of its decision to hear the appeal, which was filed on Dec. 8.

Yang Shu-chun, 25, was disqualified in her opening match in the Asiad women's under 49-kg division on Nov. 17 in Guangzhou, China. She was accused of wearing two extra electronic sensors in her socks to increase her chances of scoring. At the time, Yang was leading in the bout 9-0 and was seen as one of Taiwan's top contenders for a gold medal at the games.
Video footage of the bout, which was released later, showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before going into the competition area.

Taiwan's sports council and taekwondo bodies subsequently lodged complaints with the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) and the Olympic Council of Asia, and said it would seek CAS arbitration if the WTF failed to settle the matter fairly.

Meanwhile, the WTF's disciplinary committee is scheduled to hold a meeting in Seoul on Dec. 18. to discuss the issue. Yang, her coaches Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, and President of the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association Chen Chien- ping are expected to attend.

"We will assign an interpreter with legal skills to assist them at the Seoul meeting, which is expected to be conducted in English, " Tai said. "We will also ask for assistance from Taiwan's diplomatic mission in Seoul."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 16, or the 16th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar canlendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Bostonians creep onto British ships in Boston Harbor and dump cargoes of tea overboard.
1922: Tu Tsung-ming is granted a medical doctorate at the Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to gain the doctorate during the Japanese colonial period.
1949: Chinese Communist Chairman Mao Zedong visits Soveit Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite into orbit.
1975: Chinese Communist Central Committee Vice Chairman Kang Sheng dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1978: The United States and mainland China announce that they will establish diplomatic relations from Jan. 1, 1979.
1988: The United States and the Palestinian Liberation Organization hold a meeting in Tunis, Tunisia, for the first time.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lien Chan presides over a ceremony to inaugurate the South-Link Line of Taiwan's railway system.
1991: The Association for Ralations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), mainland Chinese quasi-official organization responsible for talks with Taiwan on cross- strait issues, is formed in Beijing.
1996: Former South Korean Presidents Chuan Doo Huan and Roo Tae Woo are sentenced life imprisonment and 17-year jail term, respectively.
