DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: The 'big mouth' clause

TEXT.P: According to a so-called "big mouth clause" included in the draft Political Appointee Act, which was cleared by a legislative committee this week, appointees could be forced to resign if they used language so flawed that it damaged the government's image or affected the government's policy-making process.

Of course, no one doubts that there is a need to improve the language skills of our political appointees. But the problem is, who will determine whether a politician has a "big mouth"? Also, is it really a good idea to restrict government officials from saying what they think?

For years, Taiwan has been promoting freedom of speech. Now, this clause could restrict the speech of political appointees and also give the public the impression that the government is back-pedalling on its commitment to democracy.

Certainly, political appointees who are reticent and uncommunicative no longer meet modern requirements. In fact, officials who speak improperly should step down voluntarily and not wait for the law to push them out. Instead of introducing a legal clause, would it not be a better idea to give them some time to step down? (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 16, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Resignation of head of Academia Historica approved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 13:03:16 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has approved Academia Historica Director Lin Man-houng's resignation due to a controversial online poll regarding the most influential figures in the country's history, the Presidential Office said late Wednesday.

Lin, an expert in the history of Taiwan and the Chinese Qing Dynasty, tendered her resignation to assume political responsibility for the controversy caused by the "influential figures" poll, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said.
After accepting Lin's resignation, Ma simultaneously appointed Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Liu Pao-kuei to serve as acting head of the history institution, Lo said.
The president will look for a suitable replacement to fill the vacancy left by Lin, he added.

The history institution, under the direct jurisdiction of the Presidential Office, last week terminated an Internet poll to select the 100 most influential figures in the history of the Republic of China after the campaign drew the ire of lawmakers and military officials.

The poll was designed as part of celebrations of the ROC's 100th founding anniversary in 2011. The inclusion of some highly controversial figures in the institute-selected candidates list, however, made it a target of criticism.

Most controversial was the inclusion of Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping -- two late leaders of the Communist Party of China, which defeated Taiwan's current ruling Kuomintang in a bloody civil war in China and forced the KMT-led ROC government to retreat to Taiwan in 1949.

In addition to shutting down the official website carrying the survey, a senior official at Academia Historica was also demoted over the incident, which reportedly earned the institution a rebuke from President Ma.

Lin, 59, was a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Modern History before taking the helm at Academia Historica in 2008. She was the history institution's first female head since its inception in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA Air to take 16% stake in China Cargo Airlines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 13:07:58 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, one of Taiwan's leading international carriers, said Thursday that it will take a 16 percent stake in Shanghai-based China Cargo Airlines.
Through its wholly-owned subsidiary Concord Pacific Ltd, EVA Air plans to invest 328 million Chinese yuan (NT$1.47 billion) in the Chinese air cargo company, the Taiwanese carrier said.
EVA Air said that the investment is part of restructuring efforts made by China Cargo, which is expected to merge with its Chinese counterpart, Shanghai Airlines Cargo International Co. Ltd.

Earlier, EVA Air had taken a 25 percent stake in Shanghai Airlines Cargo by investing 166 million Chinese yuan, but because of the restructuring, EVA Air has withdrawn from Shanghai Airlines Cargo and, instead, opted to invest in China Cargo.
Shanghai Airlines Cargo was set up in 2006 and EVA Air is one of its founding shareholders.

EVA Air said that China Cargo is one of the large-sized air cargo companies on the mainland and also had a strong global operations network. It is also expected to expand operations further, EVA Air added.
In addition, China Cargo is among the seven carriers from China and Taiwan which have been allowed to engage in air cargo operations across the Taiwan Strait.
The Taiwanese company said that it has high hopes for China Cargo's potential for growth.
China Cargo, which was set up in 1998, operates two hubs -- one in Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport and another at Shanghai Pudong International Airport. It owns a fleet of 13 aircraft.
China Eastern Airlines, one of China's largest carriers, currently owns 70 percent of China Cargo.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Guard against possible disorder following upgrade
DOC.DATELINE: 12/16/10 13:33:09 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 16, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei recently reminded the mayors-elect of the soon-to-be-established special municipalities of Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung to prepare for possible disorder in the municipalities' first year of existence.

Speaking from experience, Chou said, the problems that might emerge include personnel organization, budget planning and team adaptation. Taipei County, which became a quasi-special municipality in 2007, has been preparing for more than three years for its official upgrade to a special municipality on Dec. 25, when it will be renamed Xinbei City.

The other three municipalities will become effective on the same date through mergers of the existing Taichung City with Taichung County, Tainan City with Tainan County, and Kaohsiung City with Kaohsiung County.
It is foreseeable that after the mayors-elect assume office on Dec. 25, all sorts of problems linked to resource distribution between the central and local governments will erupt.

In Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung, personnel expenses are expected to soar when the pay grades for their employees rise. It will require major reform to integrate existing county and city staff. There is also the question of who will mediate the disputes that could arise in the process of the integration.

Prior to the inauguration of the mayors-elect, President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih should display leadership and look into the local government needs. Even if those needs cannot be met because of limited resources, Ma and Wu should use their powers of persuasion to gain understanding among the local government chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU signs bill on Taiwan's visa-waiver privilege
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 13:50:40 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese travelers will be able to visit the Schengen Area of Europe visa-free from mid-January next year as the European Union (EU) has formally signed a bill to that effect.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a statement late Wednesday that European Parliament Speaker Jerzy Buzek and Belgian Secretary of State for EU Affairs Oliver Chastel signed the bill on Taiwan's inclusion in the EU visa- waiver program in Strasbourg, France earlier in the day.

The signing in the European Parliament was considered a formality that marked yet another step toward Taiwan's goal of acquiring wider visa exemption privilege for its passport holders, the ministry said.
Following the signing, the bill will be translated into 23 official EU languages for publication in the EU Official Journal and will formally take effect 20 days after its publication, the MOFA said.
The visa waiver means that ROC (Taiwan) passport holders will be able to enter 35 European countries visa-free and stay for up to 90 days within a six-month period.

The exemption will apply to 25 Schengen Area countries, comprising 22 EU member states and three non-EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland -- and three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
It also includes seven smaller European countries and territories -- the Vatican, Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.
The MOFA said that if all goes well, the visa-waiver bill will come into effect in mid-January, but that the exact date will depend on when it is published in the EU journal.
Once the bill takes effect, Taiwan will become the sixth Asian country to acquire EU visa-waiver privilege, the MOFA statement said.
The visa exemption drive took off in July when the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, put forth a concrete bill to include Taiwan in the visa-waiver program.
The proposal then went through a 15-step process and cleared its last hurdle on Nov. 25 when the Council of the European Union passed it unanimously without debate.

The EU inclusion brings the number of countries and territories offering Taiwanese citizens visa exemptions to 96, with 75 granting Taiwan passport holders visa-waiver privileges and 21 others allowing travelers to obtain visas at their ports of entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: AsusTek aims to sell 20 million computers in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 14:10:21 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Personal computer vendor AsusTek Computer Inc. said Thursday that it has set a goal of shipping 20 million notebook computers in 2011, up from the estimated 17 million units shipped in 2010.

The 20 million units will include 14 million notebook computers, demand for which is expected to rise by about 30 percent from a year ago, and about 6 million netbook computers, demand for which is expected to remain similar to 2010, AsusTek said.
The forecasts were made at the company's two-day meeting of global sales managers, which concluded Wednesday.
At the meeting, company Chairman Jonney Shih reviewed 2010's operations and set new goals for 2011.
In addition to notebook shipments, AsusTek predicted that shipments of its servers for 2011 will grow by 5 percent over 2010 figures.
AsusTek is also gearing up to penetrate the expanding global tablet computer market; in addition, it plans to claim a double-digit stake in the non-Apple tablet computer market in 2011.

According to a recent research report, shipments of non-Apple tablet computers globally are expected to range between 10 million and 15 million units next year and AsusTek's shipments are likely hit no less than 1 million units.
AsusTek also intends to launch a premium 12-inch tablet computer model, running on the Windows 7 operating system, in the first quarter of 2011.
Earlier this week, AsusTek said that sales in Eastern Europe for 2011 were expected to grow 30-40 percent from 2010; sales in China were also forecast to rise steadily.
With the help of increasing sales, the company said that it hoped to move up one spot next year and become the fourth-largest notebook seller in the world.
AsusTek posted NT$12.47 billion (US$417 million) in net profit for the first nine months of this year. Its earnings per share (EPS) of NT$19.88 was better than market expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices post small gains
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 15:38:36 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.29 percent Thursday amid ample liquidity as investors parked their funds to safe havens such as property stocks, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 25.49 points to 8,782.20, after moving between 8,767.44 and 8,797.98, on turnover of NT$123.38 billion (US$4.13 billion).
The market opened up 0.16 percent and moved to the day's high as investors expected a rising New Taiwan dollar to boost the value of assets owned by property developers, the dealers said.
Meanwhile, bargain hunters picked up bellwether semiconductor shares on their relatively low valuations, they said.
A total of 2,343 stocks closed up and 1,819 were down, with 395 remaining unchanged.

The construction sector posted the highest gains, ending up 1.7 percent. Paper and pulp stocks rose 0.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares gained 0.4 percent, while the cement, textile and financial sectors closed up 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff stocks fell 0.5 percent and the plastics and chemical sector closed unchanged.

Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said that although the room for further increases is limited ahead of the nearest resistance point at around the 8,800-8,900-point range, a medium- and long-term uptrend remained intact as the market is flush with high liquidity.
"Foreign institutional investors remained on the buying side, hunting bargains," Hsu said.
"While some profit-taking emerged during the trade, the market still held itself well above 8,700 points at the close," Hsu added.

According to Hsu, as the results of the Nov. 27 municipal elections -- in which the ruling Kuomintang maintained its status quo -- promoted investors to buy, the property sector has scored significant recent gains.
"As the buying was further escalated by the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, I am afraid that the property sector will encounter a technical pullback in the short term," he said.
In the construction sector, New Asia Construction rose 6.71 percent to close at NT$15.10, while Cathay Real Estate gained 2.08 percent to end the day at NT$17.15.
Among the integrated circuit stocks, Advanced Semiconductor Engineering rose 3.32 percent to finish at NT$34.20 and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. added 1.71 percent to a close of NT$71.20.

DOC.HEADLINE: President denounces North Korea's actions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 15:56:29 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou again condemned North Korea Thursday for the Nov. 23 artillery attacks on a South Korean island, which has caused an escalation of regional tensions over the past three weeks.
Ma expressed hope that stability and prosperity will be restored soon in Northeast Asia.
The president raised the issue while receiving Eustace John, deputy governor- general of Saint Kitts and Nevis.
According to Ma, as a Northeast Asian country, Taiwan has an obligation to promote regional peace.

Describing the Republic of China (Taiwan) as a country that wants freedom, democracy and peace, he said the government has been working to improve cross- Taiwan Strait relations over the past two years because it is well aware that prosperity and freedom can only be achieved if there is peace.
Taiwan and China have signed 14 agreements during that period, which have helped ease tensions across the strait and benefited the people on both sides, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense Ministry apologizes for flight incidents
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 16:00:58 (By Kelven Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang apologized Thursday for a string of flight mishaps involving military planes in recent years.
"We should apologize for the occurrence of flight safety problems, " Chao said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Defense Affairs Committee.
His apology came a day after an Air Force Academy T-34C trainer plane crashed in southern Taiwan during a routine training mission, killing a flight instructor and a cadet.
It was the second crash this year involving a T-34C trainer plane. In January, a trainer of the same type went down during a training flight in southern Taiwan, also killing the two people on board.

Speaking at the session, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said that since the U.S.-built T-34Cs were introduced in Taiwan in 1985, eight of the rudimentary trainer planes have crashed, leaving 14 dead and three injured.
In just the past three years, Tsai went on, flight mishaps in the military have left 10 servicemen dead, three missing and two injured.
"Should the Defense Ministry not apologize for all these tragedies?" Tsai asked Chao.
In response, Chao said the ministry feels deep regret and sincerely apologizes for the incidents.
He further said the military attaches great importance to flight safety and has conducted in-depth probes and reviews of each of the crashes.
"In the wake of the latest incident, we will redouble our efforts in flight safety control, including reinforcing risk management and intensifying monitoring and supervision," Chao said.
On the causes of the eight T-34C-related accidents, the first four were caused by human error, while the fifth was caused by engine problems and the sixth was the result of a bird strike.
"The cause of the seventh, which occurred early this year, is still being investigated and we have not yet found the reason, " Chao said.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang said that with a T-34C attrition rate of 19 percent, the military should approach the U.S. maker for assistance in determining the cause of the crashes.
As Taiwan's T-34C fleet is only midway through its operating lifespan, Lin said, its relatively high attrition rate deserves careful study.
Chao said the military has formed a special task force to investigate the cause of Wednesday's crash and will conduct an overall review of flight safety measures.

Meanwhile, in response to Lin's concern about the safety of the AT-3 advanced jet trainer planes that have been in commission for 28 years, Chao said the aircraft for higher-level flight skill training has been structurally reinforced and can be safely used until 2017.
He also said the Air Force has begun collecting market information in preparation for the procurement of a new generation of trainer planes.

Chao said the military will offer the best possible compensation for the two pilots killed in Wednesday's crash -- 49-year-old flight instructor Niu Peng-yu and Air Force Academy cadet Liu Che-hung, 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER raises 2010 GDP growth forecast to over 9 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 16:12:06 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) on Thursday raised its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for 2010 from 8.91 percent to 9.64 percent.

It forecast that private-sector investment in 2010 will jump by 31.55 percent from the 2009 level, reaching a 45-year high. In addition, private-sector consumption will increase 3.36 percent year-on-year, while outbound and inbound shipments will rise by 24.71 percent and 28.33 percent, respectively, CIER said.

CIER also predicted that Taiwan's economy will grow by a more moderate rate of 4.55 percent in 2011 and that private-sector consumption and investment next year will increase by 2.21 percent and 2.45 percent, respectively.
Imports and exports will expand by 2.51 percent and 6.26 percent, said CIER, a major private economic think tank.

Regarding the local currency, CIER said the New Taiwan dollar will stand at an average of 31.66 against the U.S. dollar this year, an appreciation of 4.23 percent compared to the 2009 average of 33.06, and will continue to strengthen to an average of 30.43 against the greenback for the whole of 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 17:28:34 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, gaining NT$0.045 to close at NT$30.545.
Turnover totaled US$794 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.550 and moved between NT$29.815 and NT$30.560 before the close.
Dealers said foreign institutional investors continued moving funds into the local bourse to further boost the value of the New Taiwan dollar during most of the trading session.

While most of the other currencies in the region weakened against the U.S. dollar, the New Taiwan dollar maintained its strength to rise above the NT$30.00 level again before the central bank intervened, they said.
Exporters joined foreign banks during the session to lower their U.S. dollar positions on hopes that ample liquidity would push the New Taiwan dollar even higher, the dealers said.

In addition to further inflows of foreign funds, the momentum of the local currency reflected a strong rebound of Taiwan's economy after the government raised its forecast for the country's 2010 economic growth to 9.98 percent from an earlier estimate of 8.24 percent, they said.
In late trade, the central bank jumped into trading again to shore up the U.S. dollar and lift its value above the NT$30.00 level against the New Taiwan dollar, the dealers said.
In the short term, the central bank is expected to keep intervening to prevent the U.S. dollar from falling below NT$30.00 in a bid to protect Taiwan's exports, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regulator sets guidelines for Nan Shan Life sale
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 17:44:38 (By Lin Ye-fong, Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (SFC) issued five guidelines Thursday that American International Group (AIG) must follow when it holds a second round of bidding to sell its Taiwan-based subsidiary, Nan Shan Life Insurance Co.

FSC Chairman Chen Yuh-chang said the successful buyer of Nan Shan Life must promise to protect the rights and benefits of the policy holders of the issuer and its employees, and must abide by Taiwan law when raising funds for the acquisition.
Chen said the buyer then must show its ability to run an insurance company and must live up to its commitment to operate Nan Shan Life in the long term.
The buyer must also have the ability to raise funds in the future, as necessary, to run Nan Shan Life.
Nan Shan Life will be up for sale in a second round of bidding after the government in August rejected AIG's proposed sale of the unit to a Hong Kong financial consortium.
The authorities cited concerns over the Hong Kong consortium's long-term commitment to run Nan Shan Life and the bidder's long-term financial capacity.

The Hong Kong group, comprising Primus Financial Holdings and China Strategic Holdings, beat out Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. in the bid to buy Nan Shan Life for US$2.15 billion last year after a U.S. government bailout of the financially troubled AIG.

Chinatrust Financial and Cathay Financial Holding Co. as well as Ruenchen Investment Holding Co., a new joint venture created by Ruentex Industries Ltd., Ruentex Development Co. and Pou Chen Corp., have expressed interest in bidding to acquire Nan Shan Life.
Local media have also reported that Fubon Financial Holding Co. is a potential bidder, although the company refused to comment on the matter.
However, as Cathay Financial shoulders a higher debt-asset ratio, Chinatrust Financial is more likely to become the successful buyer, according to the Merril Lynch brokerage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volkswagen business in Taiwan booming: dealer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 17:54:52 (By Chao Hsiao-hui & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: German car maker Volkswagen (VW) is enjoying a booming business in Taiwan, having reached its 2010 sales target of 8,000 units at the beginning of December, its local dealer said Thursday.
Talkoo Motors said that almost all of its 8,000 Volkswagen vehicles have been sold and that it has orders for an additional 200 to be delivered by year end.
The total sales of 8,200 units will be the highest annual record in Taiwan for the German brand, Talkoo said.
According to the dealer, seven new VW models will be put on the Taiwan market next year in line with the car manufacturer's cyclic remodeling policy.
Analysts in the automobile industry have estimated that total car sales in the local market will reach 300,000 units for this year, up 23 percent year-on-year on the recovering economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Evidence proves Lien shooting was not self orchestrated: investigators
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 18:12:49 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The shooting incident last month involving the son of a former vice president was not self-orchestrated but the motive remains unclear, the Banciao District Prosecutors Office said Thursday.

A spokeswoman for the prosecutors office, Chen Cheng-fen, said at a press conference that investigators have gathered a huge volume of evidence that includes the footage from surveillance cameras near the scene and at two media outlets, the suspect's phone records, and recent bank transactions by nine people.
"The possibility that the shooting incident may have been orchestrated by the victim himself has been completely eliminated, " Chen said.
Chen was reporting on the progress of the investigation, following recent complaints that it was moving too slow.
Sean Lien, the son of a former vice president, was shot in the face in Taipei County at a campaign rally on the eve of the municipality elections that were held on Nov. 27.
Lien, who is seen as a rising star in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), was on the stage at the rally getting ready to make a campaign pitch for a KMT city councilor candidate.
Lin Cheng-wei, an alleged gangster nicknamed "Horse Face," was arrested on the spot. He has failed one of two lie detector tests administered by investigators, according to the prosecutors office.
A preliminary investigation confirmed that Lin shot Lien in the face at a close- range, Chen said.
However, "we are still trying to determine the gunman's motive and where he obtained the weapon," she said.

Investigators have also confirmed that the bullet which struck Lien in the left cheek and exited near his right temple area was the same one that killed a bystander surnamed Huang, the spokeswoman said.
"We can confirm that there was one gun, one bullet, one death, and one injury," Chen said.
She declined to say whether investigators thought the gunman was hired by a crime ring.
On the night of the shooting, Lien was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital where he had emergency surgery. He was discharged 10 days later.
Some political commentators and members of the public have raised doubts about the authenticity of Lien's injuries, saying his quick recovery was "unfathomable."
However, the speculations were strongly rebutted by Lien, as well as his attending physician who went on record to vouch for the authenticity of Lien's injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Screening of parole applications by sex offenders to be tightened
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 18:43:28 (By Sherry Tang, Lai Yu-chia and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu pledged Thursday to tighten the screening of parole applications by sex offenders after his ministry was held accountable for a serial sex offender who was caught repeating the same offense shortly after his second release.
Tseng said the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will carefully assess parole applicants' risk of recidivism before making a decision on whether to approve their applications.
In addition, those who are put back in jail for committing the same type of crime after being released on parole will not be granted parole again, Tseng said.
He said the MOJ is also prepared to require that sex offenders be subject to electronic monitoring around the clock, instead of during night time only as is the case at present.

The Ministry of Justice, the Taipei Prison, and the Taipei District Prosecutors Office were censured a day earlier by the Control Yuan, the country's top government watchdog, over the latest release of Ting Ta-lun Aug. 21, 2009.

The Control Yuan discovered that the MOJ did not assess Ting's risk of recidivism before granting him parole, while the Taipei Prison only determined after Ting's release that the man was "at higher-medium risk" of repeat offenses. The Taipei District Prosecutors Office, meanwhile, did not issue an order to put him under electronic monitoring until November 2009.
Ting, 32, first committed rape in 1995 when he was 17 and was sentenced to five years in jail. He was released on parole in 2000.
He was jailed again in 2002 after being convicted of another rape and sentenced to 10 years behind bars.

He sexually assaulted a woman Sept. 7, 2009, just 17 days after his second release, and committed another sex offense in November of that year. Although he was wearing a night-time electronic tag at the time of the second offense, the offense took place during the day, when he was not being monitored.
Ting was sentenced to nine years by the Taipei District Court in July 2010 for his two latest offenses, reduced to seven years Thursday upon appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan dollar may rise to NT$29.70 next year: think tank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 19:02:25 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Polaris Research Institute said Thursday the average value of the New Taiwan dollar is expected to rise next year to NT$29.70 against the U.S. dollar from the estimated NT$31.60 in 2010, largely on further inflows of foreign funds.

The local currency, along with those in the other Asian economies that have rebounded strongly from the recent global financial meltdown, is expected to face pressure to extend its upward momentum, the institute said.

Liang Kuo-yuan, president of the think tank, said that with the United States easing its monetary policy to boost its economy, more foreign funds are expected to enter the Asian markets, including Taiwan.

Riding the wave of ample funds, the local currency is likely to become volatile, Liang said. However, the central bank will most likely try to maintain the value of the New Taiwan dollar at a "certain level" to stabilize the local financial market, he said.

In the past three trading sessions, the U.S. dollar fell below the NT$30.00 level against the New Taiwan dollar before the central bank intervened late in the trade to boost the U.S. dollar above the NT$30.00 mark at the close.
Market observers said that the central bank can tolerate NT$30.00 in the short term, but high liquidity is expected to push the closing of the U.S. dollar below that level.

Compared with other Asian currencies, the New Taiwan dollar's appreciation has been relatively limited because of the central bank's intervention and there is room for further rise, according to Liang.
Meanwhile, the research institute has raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 economic growth from 8.52 percent to 10.05 percent, mainly on strong exports.
However, the economic growth in 2011 will be moderate compared to the previous year, the think tank said, predicting a 4.62 percent rise in the gross domestic product (GDP) next year.
In November, the government also raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 economic growth to 9.98 percent from 8.24 percent.
It said growth in 2011 will be slower, with a 4.51 percent increase in GDP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Road-based driving test to be introduced next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 19:16:43 (By Wang Shu-fen and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: An experimental new road-based driving test will be introduced by a driving school in northern Taiwan next year in an effort to test local drivers' ability to use the roads in the proper manner, a transport official said Thursday.

Prospective drivers will need to take a road test on real roads in addition to a track at a test center from next July in the Northern Region Training Institute, said Wu Meng-fen, director of the Directorate General of Highways.
Testing on real roads will allow learner drivers to gain real-life experience, said Wu, adding that it can also boost new drivers' confidence.
In an agreement between the Directorate General of Highways and insurance firms, drivers on real roads with a learner's license will be fully insured against accidents, Wu said.

The new road test will be implemented in other regions of the country if the trial proves successful, said Wu, who added that private driving schools will be encouraged to offer the new road test over the next three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice minister vows to continue executing death row inmates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 19:20:38 (By Tang Hsiao-tien & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu said Thursday that the government will definitely carry out executions of death row convicts once all their legal avenues have been exhausted.

"We will carry out the executions if no requirements for retrials, extraordinary appeals, or Constitutional interpretations are involved, " Tseng said while fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee.

Legislator Wu Yu-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang said executions of death row inmates should begin right after the Lunar New Year holiday at the latest, to convince the public that the government has no plans to stop executions.
The Justice Ministry executed four death row convicts April 30, the first executions since 2005. Since then, none of the country's 44 death row inmates have been executed.

The lack of executions since 2005 drew attention earlier this year when then Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng insisted on promoting the abolition of capital punishment and refused to sign death warrants.
Wang was forced to resign March 11 following an outcry from victims of violent crime and their families.
Tseng, however, said he is not sure "when and where the next executions will take place."
Wu also demanded that death row inmates and criminal felons should not be included on any list for sentence commutations.
As the Republic of China will celebrate its centennial anniversary next year, there have been calls for penalty reductions as part of the celebrations.

Tseng said his ministry "has not received any instruction from President Ma Ying-jeou for such a sentence commutation program, " and he added that it would take four to five months for his ministry to work out coping measures should the president decide to issue such a directive.
Sentence reduction or amnesty falls under the jurisdiction of the president under Taiwanese law.

DOC.HEADLINE: British theater company to present 'Shun-kin' in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 19:26:22 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The internationally renowned director Simon
McBurney of the British theater company Complicite will present "Shun-kin" in Taipei this weekend, a work he says presents a moral ambiguity and allows for audience participation.

"Shun-kin" is the story of a servant's masochistic love for his beautiful blind mistress, who is a music teacher. It was inspired by two classic texts by 19th century Japanese writer Jun'ichiro Tanizaki -- "A Portrait of Shunkin" and "In Praise of Shadows."
According to the storyline, Sasuke is so devoted to his mistress Shun-kin that he would do anything to share her world.
He takes his devotion so far as to blind himself, claiming that the loss of his sight is the happiest moment in his life.

"One of the very interesting things aboutShun-kinis that it presents a moral ambiguity -- what is right and what is wrong -- because it places the audience in a state in which they have to participate and say what they think about it, " McBurney said at a press conference Thursday in Taipei.

The director said he first attempted the play 10 years ago, but realized that the texts were too complicated and he did not really understand what was going on. Instead, in 2003, he created a theatrical adaptation of Haruki Murakami's "The Elephant Vanishes, " which is a portrayal of modern Japanese society.

He said he is always interested in the question of "who we are, " and that the long process of making Shun-kin was also a personal journey of trying to learn about Japan and what constitutes Japanese thoughts and language.
Artists can look at the stories in different cultures from different points of view, he said.
"The danger in this world is that we think there is only one point of view that is right," he said.
"Shun-kin" is an international collaboration between McBurney, Japanese actors from Tokyo's Setagaya Public Theatre, and the Barbican, London.
The play will be presented in Japanese, with English subtitles, from Friday to Sunday in Taipei.
Complicite, under McBurney's leadership, has won more than 50 international awards since it was established in 1983.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- First surprise of centennial celebrations

TEXT.P: Two prominent business executives -- Uni-President Enterprises Corp. General Manager Alex Lo and Yahoo Asia Managing Director Rose Tsou -- have been invited to co-host a flag-raising ceremony at the Presidential Office plaza on New Year's Day.

Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng said at a news conference Wednesday that the surprise arrangement underscores the government's determination to celebrate the country's 100th founding anniversary next year with creativity.

In addition, famous indigenous composer Lee Tai-hsiang has been invited to provide a special arrangement of the National Anthem to further highlight the uniqueness of the flag-raising ceremony on the first day of the Republic of China's centennial year.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

The marvelous team-up of Lo and Tsou to host the first flag-raising ceremony at the Presidential Office square on the first day of the new year will be the first surprise in the celebrations of the ROC's centennial founding anniversary, said Sheng, who concurrently heads the ROC (Taiwan) Centenary Foundation.

In an effort to inspire all ROC citizens to commemorate the country's 100th founding anniversary with jubilance, Sheng said, both the Presidential Office and the foundation have "racked their brains" to design interesting and meaningful programs.

Tsou, who played the female lead in various theater shows while studying at National Taiwan University, is no stranger to hosting public events. The upcoming New Year's Day flag-raising ceremony, however, will be the first of its kind she has ever emceed, Sheng said.

As for Lo, Sheng went on, it came as some surprise that Lo accepted the invitation without hesitation. "Lo tends to keep a low profile and at first, we were afraid he might be reluctant to step into the limelight," he said.
Lo said he regards the offer as a great honor. "This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and I treasure it greatly, " he said. (Dec. 16, 2010).
China Times:
Lee, who suffers from Parkinson's disease, presented his newly completed musical score to Vice President Vincent Siew at the Presidential Office Wednesday.
A feeble Lee told Siew that he endured great physical pain while trying to inject new life into the National Anthem. "I worked my heart out. Every note required great effort, " he recalled.
According to Lee, the new orchestration makes the National Anthem sound more lively and theatrical.
More than 200 musicians selected from private and public music ensembles and orchestras will play the piece at the New Year's Day flag-raising ceremony, said Sheng.
He added that the year-long celebration is aimed at making Taiwan more visible around the world, cementing national unity and forging harmony in society. (Dec. 16, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: First snow of the year falls in central Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 19:46:45 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan saw its first snowfall of the year Thursday at Siyuan Yakou in the central region, where the Chungyang Mountain Range joins the Xueshan Range.

Snow began falling around 2 a.m. Thursday and by 4 p.m. three to six centimeters had accumulated in the 1,948-meter mountain pass, said Jungle Chen, Dulishan branch chief of the Directorate General of Highways (DGH).
"We started traffic control early so there are not many sightseers trying to get up there," he said.
However, people began to rush to Hehuanshan, a famous scenic spot also known as Joy Mountain, at midnight and they reported that a snowfall had started there at 2 p.m., Chen said.
Sightseers on Yushan, known as Jade Mountain, also reported a snowfall that began there around the same time, he said.
However, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said that what the sightseers observed at Hehuanshan and Yushan was most likely sleet because it was not cold enough in either location for snow.

Weathermen said the weather is expected to turn dryer from Thursday evening, but the cold front will push the mercury down to seven degrees Celsius Friday morning in northern Taiwan and the cold snap will last until Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 ready to welcome 2011 with fireworks spectacular
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 20:14:49 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The highly anticipated annual Taipei 101 New Year's eve pyrotechnics display is ready to blow spectators away this year with a record-breaking number of fireworks transforming the world's second-tallest skyscraper into a silver waterfall, a glowing pagoda and a ferocious dragon.

This year's show, which will last for 288 seconds and will use more than 30,000 fireworks costing over NT$60 million (US$2.01 million) is being touted as the "longest, biggest and most expensive" of the last six years, said Michael Liu, the building's spokesman.

As the nation celebrates its 100th founding anniversary next year, the show will focus on that theme. Exactly 100 extra seconds will be added to the duration of the show, compared with the standard 188 seconds in previous shows, Liu said.

This is also the first time the organizers have collaborated with international groups such as Grucci, a New York-based pyrotechnic company with over 150 years of experience in firework shows and the pyrotechnician Tsai Kuo-chiang, who is the main creative force behind the show.

"We are confident that spectators are in for a great show. By using high-quality fireworks, we have reduced the likelihood of smoke clouds to the minimum, " Liu said, adding that the show will take place as scheduled unless there is torrential rain.
Six other New Year's Eve fireworks displays will take place around the country.

Besides the one at Taipei 101, the capital will also have two other shows to ring in the new year, including one sponsored by the Council of Cultural Affairs to be held at Dajia Riverside Park and another one at the Miramar shopping center in the Neihu District.

In central Taiwan, in addition to a show at the Taichung Stadium, Janfusun Fancy World amusement park in Yunlin County will also light up the sky with 15,000 fireworks in 11 minutes and will turn its Ferris wheel into the world's biggest "smiley face."

In southern Taiwan, the newest entertainment landmark -- E-da World in Kaohsiung County -- is preparing to wow spectators with 50,000 fireworks, while Dream Mall in Kaohsiung City will also hold its annual display after a massive New Year's Eve count-down party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic policy planner indicates shift to local demand
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 20:42:53 (By C.W. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government's top economic policy planner unveiled a blueprint Thursday indicating a shift to the local demand-driven market in its pursuit of sustainable economic growth.

Reporting to a 2011 economic and investment seminar sponsored by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) , Christina Liu, minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said China and the whole of Asia should be viewed as Taiwan's local demand market at a time when Asia is rapidly emerging from the 2008 economic crisis.

According to Liu, Taiwan's periodic per-capita income has reached an average monthly historic high of NT$44,453 (US$1,455) this year, and the country should further explore the local market to make it and the export sector the dual engines of its economic expansion.

Export-oriented Taiwan should shift its attention to China and the rest of Asia from the U.S. and European markets, which are still affected by the global financial crisis, as part of its efforts to maintain economic development, particularly since Taiwan clinched the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China in June.
Liu reported that the CEPD will launch a program next year to balance development in various regions and pave the way for Taiwan's progress in the coming decade.

Under the program, she said, the CEPD will suggest "three businesses suitable for each area's development" and make it possible for potential foreign companies to have at least three locations to choose from when deciding to invest in Taiwan.

For instance, she said, Hualien and Taitung counties in eastern Taiwan will be ideal for promoting the green energy industry and biotechnology. Greater investment in that part of Taiwan will help create jobs and increase the income of people living there, she explained.

From January next year, the CEPD will also organize large investment seminars in cities and counties around Taiwan, and will send trade promotion missions to Japan and India to lure investment and seek business opportunities, she added.

"The regional development plan will be high on the CEPD's agenda for the coming two years, under which each special area, to be formed by three cities and counties, such as Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli or Taipei, Xinbei and Keelung, will be made into venues available for investment from three to five select industries," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Winners of 'Make a Wish' sponsorship to hitchhike around Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 20:59:15 (By Chen Ching-ping and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Two young women have been granted sponsorship of NT$500,000 (US$16,000) by shop owners in Shinshe township, Taichung County to go on a 100-day trip around Taiwan, the Shinshe Township Recreation and Agriculture Development Association said Thursday.

Huang Wei-ting and Tseng Wan-ching, who became friends when they were students at Nanhua University in Chiayi County, will hitchhike around the country, hugging everyone they meet and encouraging them to pursue their dreams.
At the end of the trip, they will upload 18 videos of their experience to a number of social network sites, they said.
The women have already started to shoot a video featuring the 50 shop owners who are supporting the "Make a Wish" initiative and who have fulfilled their dreams by creating their own business.
Huang and Tseng will begin the tour on Jan 1, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chrome OS market unaffected by netbook decline: Google
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 21:28:26 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Google Inc. said Thursday that its newly launched Chrome operating system will not be affected by a predicted decline in netbook shipments next year, due to the openness of the platform.

The search giant said Chrome OS, which originates from the web-based Chrome browser, provides users with a faster and easier access to the Internet on all kinds of devices, including notebooks, netbooks and tablets.

"People will feel the same experience no matter what kind of device they are using, which is why Google offers open sources of the system to OEM and ODM vendors, " John Liu, Google corporate vice president of greater China operations, told reports on the sidelines of a celebration of the 10-year anniversary of the launch of the company's AdWords, a targeted advertising system.
Chrome OS, Liu added, stands for a vision that Google will meet consumer demand, although the development of the system still has a long way to go.
Earlier this month, Google unveiled a Chrome-based prototype computer, the "CR-48, " used in a beta testing program in a move to attract about 120 million active users of the Chrome browser.
The all-black device, with a 12.1-inch screen and 3G connectivity similar to netbooks, does not bear a brand logo, as part of Google's efforts to strengthen ties with manufacturers.
"Our manufacturing partners and consumers will be free to select the devices they prefer, " Google Taiwan's head of communications, Caroline Hsu, said on the same occasion.
She said consumer demand in different situations will also increase the growth of different devices running Chrome OS.

However, local reports said a day earlier that Asustek Computer Inc. will see zero growth for its netbook EeePC family for the first time next year, shipping about 6 million units -- similar to this year's figure.

Acer Inc. Chairman J.T. Wang also forecast Dec. 8 that global shipments of netbooks will slide to 30-40 million units in 2011, dropping from this year's 20 percent to 25 percent share of the personal computer market to around 15 percent to 20 percent.

Meanwhile, global shipments of tablet computers are expected to reach 12.28 million units before the end of this year, making them exceed netbooks to become the third-largest mobile device category in the final quarter of 2010 and for all of 2011, said market tracker Digitimes Research.

Media tablet capabilities are expected to become more PC-like in the coming years, luring consumers away from PCs and displacing a significant volume of PC shipments, especially netbooks, according to a recent statement by global research firm Gartner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait publication association established in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16. (CNA) 12/16/10 21:38:33 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait publishing association has been set up in Taipei with the aim of finding cooperation opportunities and boosting cross-strait publishing exchanges, the association's management announced at a launch ceremony Thursday.

Richard Huang, vice director-general of the newly established Cross-Taiwan Strait Publication and Distribution Association, told CNA that the organization's main mission is to reinvigorate Taiwan's publishing sector by promoting the sale of Taiwanese books in China and introducing books published in China to Taiwan.
"Books printed in traditional Chinese characters are considered imported goods and they have an appeal for the younger generation in China," he said.

Although China forbids the establishment of foreign publishing houses on its soil, the related laws have been loosened in recent years and Huang expressed confidence that increasing spending power of Chinese consumers will mark a new era for Taiwan's publishing industry.

Working with Chinese publishers and companies, he went on, the association will establish a promotion center in Hebei Province and another in Tianjin City next month to market books that have been published in Taiwan over the last two years.
The association currently has more than 300 members from the local print and digital publishers, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan reports two more influenza deaths
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 22:02:39 (By Chen Ching-fang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Two more people in Taiwan have died of influenza, the Department of Health (DOH) said Thursday.

Two women, one 58 and the other 38, died in the past week, about seven days after falling ill with symptoms that included coughs and fever, said Lin Ting, Deputy Director-General of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH.
The younger woman tested positive for the A/H3 flu virus, while the virus strain in the other infection has not yet been determined, Lin said.

The deaths could have occurred as a result of other existing diseases, Lin added. The two women were not in the priority groups to receive free flu vaccines and they had not been inoculated, he said. The priority groups include people over 65, patients in care homes, and children aged six months to 10 years.
Further tests are needed to determine whether the women had developed bacterial infections after they contracted the flu virus, Lin said.
As of July, a total of 34 people in Taiwan had died of influenza this year, Lin said.
Over the last three months, the A (H1N1) virus has replaced the A/H3 strain as the most common cause of flu infections in the country, according to Lin.
He said Tuesday that 43 percent of the flu cases reported in the last three months were caused by the H1N1 virus, 33 percent by the A/H3 virus and 23 percent by the influenza B virus.
Studies have shown that the elderly and children are the most vulnerable to H1N1 and that seriously ill patients and people with existing diseases are more likely to develop severe cases of H1N1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Arbitration court verifying jurisdiction on taekwondo case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 22:15:34 (By Oscar Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) said Thursday that it has officially registered Taiwan's appeal against the disqualification of one of its taekwondo athletes in the recent Asian Games.

The court in Lausanne, Switzerland further said it has initiated an arbitration procedure to verify that its jurisdiction is established on the appeal jointly filed by Yang Shu-chun and Taiwan's Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC).

Yang, 25, was disqualified from her opening bout in the women's under 49-kg division in the taekwondo event of the Asiad in Guangzhou, China Nov. 17 for allegedly wearing extra sensors in her socks in an attempt to score more points.

Video footage of the match released later appeared to show, however, that Yang was not wearing the sensors during the bout. Inconsistent explanations from World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) and Asian Taekwondo Union (ATU) officials for why Yang was disqualified added to the controversy.
Taiwan filed a protest over the decision with the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) . Yang and the SAC also filed an appeal with the CAS Dec. 8.

CAS Secretary-General Matthieu Reeb said in a written reply to Central News Agency inquiries that the appeal has been transmitted to the three organizations involved in the arbitration procedure -- the WTF, the OCA and the Guangzhou Asian Games Organizing Committee.
The three parties "will have the opportunity to express their positions in a written submission at a later stage," Reeb said.
As a general rule, he added, the CAS must ascertain that it has jurisdiction to render a final ruling.

Although SAC Vice Minister Steven S.K. Chen said earlier this month that the appeal does not require the consent of the other parties involved in the dispute, Reeb said the CAS jurisdiction must be established by written agreement from all the parties involved in the process.
"In the present case, it will be also one of the CAS duties to verify that its jurisdiction is established," Reeb said.
Meanwhile, a Taiwanese delegation will depart for Seoul Friday to attend a WTF disciplinary committee on the disqualification dispute scheduled for Saturday.
The delegation members will include Yang, Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) President Chen Chien-ping and Yang's two coaches, Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta.
They will present written testimony at the WTF disciplinary committee meeting in the hope of getting a solution to the dispute that they feel is fair, said a CTTA official.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for speedy amendments to health-care bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 22:23:02 (By Garfie Li, Chen Li-ting, Chou Yung-chieh, Justin Su and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Thursday for the early passage of amendments to the national health-care program bill now that the ruling party's legislative and executive branches have almost reached consensus on the hot issue.

Speaking to the leaders of the five yuans, or branches of government, at the Presidential Office, Ma expressed hope that Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will talk soon with the opposition parties over a package deal acceptable to a majority of the people.
At issue is the premium rate for the national health insurance system, which is facing a financial crunch.

The latest near-consensus among the ruling party's power groups, including its legislative caucus and the Executive Yuan, is to collect 5.17 percent, or slightly less, of an individual's salary, up from the previous rate of 4.55 percent, to strengthen the program's finances.

Caucus leader Lin Tsang-min said the caucus and the Executive Yuan have agreed to the 5.17 percent rate, "although the exact number needs to be further confirmed" -- meaning that it could be set a bit lower.
In fact, from April 1, the system has already been collecting 5.17 percent of an individual's salary to keep the system running.

On Thursday, the ruling camp proposed another source of finances for the program -- to collect 2 percent of stock dividends, deposit interest, professional income and "high bonuses" as a supplement for the program's financial resources.
By "high bonuses" Lin meant the total bonus a wage earner gets in a year that is four times as much as or higher than his monthly salary.

However, a NT$1 million limit might be set on this "single bonus" provision, meaning that those who get a bonus exceeding NT$1 million would need to contribute a maximum of an additional NT$20,000 to the program, he noted.
No consensus was reached on drawing more resources from capital gains or stock exchange taxes, according to Lin.

Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said that under the latest proposal, well-paid entertainers, lawyers, real estate agents or those with high-interest incomes will have to pay more into the program.
On the other hand, Yaung said, the salaried class, whose main income comes from wages or salaries, might get a minor reprieve because the premium rate might be set a bit lower than 5.17 percent.
Lin said KMT legislators have talked to the caucus members of other political parties in the hope of securing their support.

The KMT caucus itself was slated to hold a meeting the following day to finalize the amendment proposal before talking with the opposition parties, in the hope that it will pass the legislative floor that same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait committee subject to legislative supervision
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 22:45:53 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation committee will be subject to supervision by the Legislative Yuan, an official in charge of China policy said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the committee will be established according to the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) that went into effect in September.

Under Article 11 of the agreement, the committee will conduct necessary consultations to achieve the goals of the ECFA and will supervise and assess the implementation of the agreement, among other things, Liu said.
However, he went on, "the committee will not be able to make any decisions after consultations."
It will operate under the framework of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on the Taipei side and the Beijing -based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , Liu said.

He noted that after consultations have taken place, the matter will be turned over to the SEF and ARATS for discussion and signing and then sent to the Legislative Yuan for review, in line with the Statute Governing Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Liu made the remarks in a rebuttal of allegations by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that the committee will attempt to circumvent supervision by the nation's executive, legislative and judicial branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL to add additional China route in January
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 22:55:51 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) will open a new service to central China's Wuhan in January, as the Asia market is expected to continue to grow fast next year, a senior CAL official said Thursday.
Besides launching the Taiwan-Wuhan flights, the carrier will from January also offer direct flights to Auckland, New Zealand, said Han Liang-chung, CAL's deputy chief financial officer.

Meeting the press after celebrating the 51st anniversary of the airline's founding, Han said his company will introduce five Airbus 330's to its fleet by 2012, as well as renovating nine Boeing 747 jumbo jets to better serve passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan, National Palace Museum censured
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/10 23:11:19 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, censured the Executive Yuan and the National Palace Museum (NPM) Thursday for irregularities over the years.
The Control Yuan faulted the Executive Yuan for not clearly defining the role of the NPM during its many structural reform plans over the years.

The Control Yuan also found that the intervention of political factors have resulted in frequent changes of the NPM chief, which it said has also led to low staff morale, and that the competitive edge of the NPM has failed to be upgraded.

As of June 2010, the NPM had 679,855 items in its collection, but from 1989 until now, there has been no overall inventory taken. Although from 2001, the NPM has conducted only irregular checks, involving several thousand items every year, this has been "hardly enough," according to the Control Yuan.
The NPM should work out a complete overall inventory and publish the results, along with reports on the condition of the items, the Control Yuan said.

It also took to task what it described as the rash decision in 2001, when the now-opposition Democratic Progressive Party was in power, to build a southern branch of the NPM in Chiayi, resulting in contract disputes, a waste of taxpayers' money and loss of faith of Chiayi people in the government -- after a decade, construction of the museum is still incomplete.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 17, or the 12th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

The weighted price index gained 25.49 points, or 0.29 percent, to close at 8,782.20 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang re-signs with Nationals for one year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 11:25:25 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese right-hander Chien-Ming Wang has signed a one-year, US$1 million contract to rejoin the Washington Nationals that could also earn him US$5 million in incentives, Wang's agent Alan Chang announced in a press release early Friday.
Wang joined the Nationals on a one-year deal prior to the 2010 season but never pitched for the team because his recovery from shoulder surgery took longer than had been expected.
Reports indicate that the Texas Rangers were also in the market for Wang, who won 38 games for the New York Yankees in 2006 and 2007 but has struggled with injuries since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Health insurance as a welfare program

TEXT.P: Although efforts by Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang to push through a bill introducing a second-generation national health insurance system were thwarted by legislators last week, Yaung, nevertheless, should be applauded for sparking widespread debate on the issue.
Had he not made that attempt, the current health insurance system, with its several flaws, would not have been so closely scrutinized.

The program, which calculates premiums based on salaries, is, by its very nature, a kind of social insurance system under which high-income earners subsidize low-income earners. The biggest problem with the existing system is that it spares those at the tip of the wealth pyramid, who generate huge fortunes from capital gains, while burdening the salaried class with premiums. The second-generation insurance system hopes to remedy that by allowing the calculation of premiums to be based on total household income.

In fact, there are several principles that we could follow while trying to fix the system. First, in order to maintain health insurance as a social welfare program, a "basic premium" should be collected from every person insured.

Second, in line with the spirit of mutual benefit, the rich should pay a "supplementary premium" based on their total income, which should include stock dividends, interests, service revenues, bonuses and prizes.

Third, as asset ownership is an important reference point to define whether an individual is rich or poor, the weight of "basic premium" should be adjusted according to the total worth of assets, including real estate and securities, owned by the insured. This will ensure that people who own numerous properties or shares worth tens of millions of New Taiwan dollars are not considered poor just because they do not receive salaries. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang re-signs with Nationals for one year (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 13:18:59 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese right-hander Chien-Ming Wang has signed a one-year contract to rejoin the Washington Nationals that will guarantee him a base salary of US$1 million and give him a chance to earn another US$4 million in incentives, Wang's U.S.-based agent Alan Chang said in a statement early Friday.

"Wang has expressed gratitude to the Nationals for its recognition and confidence in his ability. He is currently working on individual training in Taiwan and is scheduled to be back in the U.S. early next year, " Chang said in the press release.
Wang, who played for the New York Yankees for nine years before being released in late 2009, signed with the Nationals in February for one year with a guaranteed US$2 million salary.
However, he has been in rehabilitation for the past 15 months and has not pitched for the Nationals in a Major League Baseball (MLB) game, only appearing in two instructional league games in October.
Wang was not offered a contract by the Nationals before the deadline of Dec. 3 and therefore became a free agent.

According to an MLB report published early Friday, Wang had indicated to his agent that he wanted to stay with the Nationals because of the way it treated him while recovering from surgery to his right shoulder.
Although Wang will receive only half the guaranteed salary of his previous contract, he can secure up to US$4 million in incentives next season.

Wang will be paid US$250,000 if he stays on the 25-man roster for more than 30 days, a further US$250,000 if he stays for 30 more days, and an additional US$250,000 if he stays for another 30 days after that, according to the contract.

The incentives will be based on how many games in which Wang appears as a starting pitcher. He will earn an extra US$100,000 between 10-19 games, US$150,000 between 20-21 games, US$200,000 for his 22nd starting job and US$300,000 for between 23 and 27 games.
Wang will receive as much as US$600,000 if he wins any MLB award, including US$200,000 for the Comeback Player of the Year award.
Wang won more games than any other big league pitcher (38) between 2006 and 2007, but his injuries have limited him to just 27 appearances over the past two years.
In 2009, when he earned US$5 million with the Yankees, Wang was 1-6 with an atrocious 9.64 ERA before being shut down for the season because of his shoulder.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's premier to visit Burkina Faso
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/10 13:20:33 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Premier Wu Den-yih will arrive in Burkina Faso soon to attend a ceremony marking the inauguration of President Blaise Compaore for a new term, Taiwanese diplomats stationed in the West African country said Friday.
Wu will attend the ceremony scheduled for Dec. 19 on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou, the officials said.

Wu's visit has drawn the attention of the Burkina Faso diplomatic community because he will be Taiwan's first premier to visit since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994, according to the officials.

His visit, as well as a visit by Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu in August this year for the country's 50th independence anniversary, show that Ma attaches importance to ties with Burkina Faso, the officials said.
According to Taipei sources, Wu will start his trip Saturday and is scheduled to return home Dec. 25.
Burkina Faso is one of the 23 countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: A correct historical perspective

TEXT.P: Academia Historica Director Lin Man-houng resigned Wednesday over a controversial online poll to select the 100 most influential figures in the history of the Republic of China, designed as part of the celebrations of the ROC's 100th founding anniversary in 2011.
It would be meaningful if this incident could help us establish a correct historical perspective on the ROC and consolidate consensus on the national identity.

As the institution responsible for compiling the country's historical data, Academia Historica needs to judge historical facts and define the country's status in history. Holding an online poll is not a serious method of doing this.

The survey sparked controversy mainly because the late Chinese communist leader Deng Xiaoping was polled in the top spot in the military category. But Deng's historical status lies in his contributions to the reform and openness of the People's Republic of China, which is unrelated to the ROC. Although he fought in the Battle of Da Bie Shan against the Kuomintang during the civil war in China, Deng was not even on the list of the top 10 Chinese communist military leaders.
Lin's resignation deserves our approval. We hope her successor will learn a lesson from the incident. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: TWSE to launch Twitter service
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 14:04:22 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) said Friday that it will launch Dec. 20 its own Twitter service, a global social networking and microblogging platform, to provide English-language market information to foreign investors.

According to TWSE, as social networking services have become an important marketing tools for the global business sector, the exchange will ride the wave of the high-tech advance by using Twitter as a channel to disseminate market information in English.

In the initial phase of the new service, the TWSE will provide content comprising English-language captions of the exchange's news releases with a link to TWSE's English-language website so that Twitter users will be able to gain access to the TWSE's website to see the full details of the news releases.

The TWSE expects that through the speedy, simplified and real-time information delivered by Twitter, foreign investors will be well-informed of critical market information released by the TWSE, the exchange said.
In recent years, the TWSE has made great efforts to boost its international visibility by raising foreign investors' awareness of the local bourse.

These efforts include various roadshows abroad to brief foreign companies about the local business environment and relaxed regulations to encourage them to issue Taiwan depositary receipts or launch primary listings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local, French firms to jointly launch investment company in April
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 14:17:53 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Cooperative Bank said Friday that a joint investment trust company planned by the bank and France's BNP Paribas Investment Partners is scheduled to begin operations in April.
The bank said that the two partners obtained approval from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) for the proposal Thursday and are gearing up to launch operations.

The joint venture, which will be named BNPP TCB Asset Management Co., will have a paid-in capital of NT$300 million (US$10.05 million). The Taiwanese bank would hold a 51 percent stake, while the French partner would own the remaining 49 percent.
According to Taiwan's regulations, before beginning operations, the joint venture would have to raise money, no less than NT$3 billion, for a mutual fund targeting the Taiwanese stock market.
The bank said that the two companies had faith that the fund-raising activity would be completed by April as planned as they both have a good reputation in the local financial markets.
The two companies signed an agreement for launching the joint venture in January before they underwent a wide range of regulatory screening procedures and received the final approval from the FSC.

In the signing ceremony, BNP Paribas Investment Partners' Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Marchessaux, said that the co-operation with Taiwan Cooperative Bank would "reinforce our position as a leader in emerging markets."

BNP Paribas Investment Partners, an investment arm of French banking giant BNP Paribas, was set up in July 1980. It has a strong global presence in the asset management business, according to a statement released by the FSC.
The FSC said that the joint venture is expected to provide a new investment channel for local investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates money to U.K.-based wild bird conservation group
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/10 14:38:18 (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese government has donated US$5,000 to Britain's Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust (WWT) to support its wild bird conservation program in the Russian Far East.

The donation was presented Thursday by Lee Hsian-chang, an official of the Taipei Representative Office in the United Kingdom, to Baz Hughes of the WWT on behalf of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Hughes expressed thanks for the long-term contributions from Taiwan that began in 2006 as support for the conservation of scaly sided mergansers, an endangered species that live on wetlands in Russia's Far East.
The donations have enabled the WWT to continue regular checks and monitoring of the bird's population, as well as relevant research.
Due to the work of the organization, the merganser population has increased to 10,000 head as of 2010, Hughes said.

The population of scaly sided mergansers in the Russian Far East dropped to 4,500 at one point due to fishing and logging activities that damaged the bird's habitat and made it one of the rarest fowl species in the world, Hughes said.

During the donation-presentation ceremony, Lee mentioned that there are 75 protected plots of wetland in Taiwan, and that there are many local civic groups devoted to the protection of endangered birds such as the black-faced spoonbill.

In recent years, Taiwan's government has been working with these civic organizations to promote ecological rehabilitation and it hopes to have closer cooperation with Britain in the field of international ecological conservation, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airport pledges to revamp image
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 15:41:57 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Corporation (TIA) vowed Friday to implement an efficient management model and improve service quality during a lighting ceremony for a giant Christmas tree in the Terminal 2.

In an effort to emerge from the shadows of a series of negative reports over the past year, the TIA's executive team will adopt a "revolutionary method" to save its image, said TIA President Samuel Perng-liang Lin.
In latest evaluations conducted by Airport Council International, the airport ranked 41st in terms of service quality in 2010, a fall from 27th place in 2009.
