"We are going to highlight cultural perspectives at the airport, introduce a new business model and practice organization consolidation," Lin said.
The lighting of the Christmas tree, Lin said, is part of a TIA campaign to connect Taiwan to the world.

"We want to celebrate the holiday season with every traveler, domestic or international, " Lin said. "By sending out the message of 'it's time to go home,' we want people to know that we care," he added.
Lin said the airport will also hold activities on Taiwanese holidays to introduce the country to foreign travelers.
In terms of the new business model, the airport will open lounges selling the same meals as those served in business class so that people can enjoy a "luxury sky kitchen" on the ground, he said.
"The airport must create a customer-friendly environment and respond to customer needs in a timely manner," Lin said.

In the field of service quality improvement, Lin went on, a program that teaches staff to multi-task is expected to be launched by next June so they can become familiar with the overall operation of the country's main gateway and act quickly in case of emergency.
The airport has drawn widespread criticism since June, when a jetway collapsed at the airport's Terminal 2.
In early July, staffers of the airport's central control room were caught partying with alcohol while on duty. Repeated toilet leaks and power blackouts have only compounded the facility's woes.

As a result, the airport, which had been run as a government agency since it opened in 1979, formally began corporate-style operations in November, a move aimed at enhancing the facility's efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's top negotiator with Taiwan to arrive for high-level talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 16:12:52 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan is scheduled to arrive in Taipei next Monday for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, during which a bilateral medical cooperation pact will be signed, officials said Friday.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will be greeted by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , when he arrives at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, according to the itinerary released by the SEF.
Chen's itinerary and the meeting agenda were unveiled at a news conference jointly hosted by the SEF, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the Government Information Office.
The focus of his itinerary will be talks with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung the following day. It will be their sixth formal meeting since 2008 dealing with major issues of mutual concern.

On Dec. 21, Chiang and Chen will sign a medical and health-care cooperation agreement, the 15th accord they will have signed since their first meeting in 2008 following the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

The two top negotiators will also brief the media on the negotiating situation in terms of a cross-Taiwan Strait investment protection accord that was originally scheduled to be signed along with the medical accord at the sixth meeting.
However, the signing of the investment pact will be deferred to a later date because some details remain to be settled, SEF officials said.

During their meeting, Chiang and Chen will also exchange views on the agenda for their next round of talks, expected to take place in the first half of next year, as well as review the enforcement of the previously signed 14 agreements that have paved the way for direct cross-strait air and shipping links and closer commercial exchanges.

Chiang will probably come up with proposals to resolve issues regarding insufficient numbers of flights to certain popular Chinese destinations and the exorbitant prices on some flight routes, as well as passenger and cargo transit flights, SEF sources said.
Chen, meanwhile, is likely to put forward a proposal that the two sides sign a cultural cooperation agreement, the sources said.
During his stay, he is also scheduled to meet with Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan, Taiwan's top China policy planner.
Prior to his departure on Dec. 22, Chen and his entourage will tour the Taipei International Flora Expo, SEF officials said.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized to handle cross-strait talks in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote traditional-character publications at China fairs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 16:36:12 (By Kuo Mai-lan and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will include a book section for the first time next year in trade fairs it organizes in China to promote books printed in traditional Chinese characters, a Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) official said Friday.

The book section, arranged by the Cross-Taiwan Strait Publication and Distribution Association in Taipei, will showcase books in traditional Chinese that were published in Taiwan within the previous two years, said Hou Wen-chin, the deputy director of TAITRA's market development department.

TAITRA will organize at least five trade shows in the Chinese cities of Shenyang, Guangzhou, Tianjin, Nanjing and Wuhan next year. Each fair is expected to have 1,000-2,000 booths displaying Taiwanese goods.

Promoting Taiwan-published books in China's market has been difficult because local publishers often attend shows independently, but Hou said the TAITRA fairs will provide a unique platform that will increase contacts between the publishers and Chinese readers.
The association will join the effort, Hou said, because it is more familiar with regulations governing selling Taiwanese books in China and can select suitable publishers and books for the fairs.
The association currently has more than 300 members in the local print and digital publishing sectors, according to Richard Huang, vice director-general of the recently established association.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC fires employee accused of insider trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 17:25:43 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, said Friday that it has fired an employee of its subsidiary in North America who was arrested the previous day in the United States for alleged insider trading.
TSMC said it will provide necessary assistance to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is conducting an investigation into the insider trading allegations.

Along with four others, Manosha Karunatilaka, a former technical account manager of TSMC North America, is accused of selling business secrets when he worked as a consultant to Primary Global Research, an expert networking company.
TSMC said that as Karunatilaka's conduct has violated the company's internal rules related to business secret protection, TSMC North America fired him when he was arrested Dec. 16.

The five men -- a sales manager at Primary Global and four consultants of the company -- were charged with wire fraud and conspiracy to provide confidential information to Primary Global Research customers between 2008 and early 2010, according to U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara.

An expert networking company hires analysts to provide investors with insightful information, and the charges reveal the relationships among Primary Global Research, its technology analysts and the investors who pay for the information.

According to the FBI, the more-than US$400,000 Primary Global Research paid its consultants in this case, who only participated in phone conversations with clients, is an indication of the value of the information.
TSMC said the company is considering taking appropriate legal action related to the allegations but declined to comment further.

DOC.HEADLINE: AU Optronics permitted to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 18:03:34 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) received government approval Friday for a months-long application to set up its first plant in China, a move that is expected to help the company follow in the recent footsteps of its South Korean rivals.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that AUO can proceed with a plan to build a US$3 billion 7.5th-generation flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province, Vice Economics Minister Hwang Jung-chiou told a press briefing.

AUO submitted the application in March, but did not receive the official approval until Friday after it had met several government conditions aimed at minimizing any negative impact of such Chinese investment projects on Taiwan.
For example, AUO pledged to invest NT$400 billion (US$13.4 billion) in building two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park by 2022.
The flat panel maker will also make additional investments totaling NT$150 billion in other parts of Taiwan, Hwang said.

Since AUO is already operating an 8.5th-generation flat panel plant in Taiwan, its application to set up a 7.5th-generation plant met with the government's requirement that high-tech companies investing in China must maintain a technological lead at home over their Chinese facilities, the official noted.

AUO has also promised to hire 5,000 employees in Taiwan over the next 10 years, as further assurance to the government that it will not slash its local workforce because of the new Chinese investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 18:15:10 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, dropping NT$0.035 to close at NT$30.510.
Turnover totaled US$608 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.555 and moved between NT$29.766 and NT$30.560 before the close.
Dealers said a rising local bourse lent further support to the New Taiwan dollar as foreign institutional investors kept moving funds into the market to pick up select large-cap high-tech stocks.
The benchmark weighted index closed up 0.40 percent at 8,817.90 in expanded trading volume.

Buying by foreign banks and exporters who were betting on further appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar boosted the local unit to a 13-year-high during the trade before the central bank intervened, the dealers said.
In late trade, the central bank stepped in again to shore up the U.S. dollar and push the currency back to above the NT$30.00 level in an effort to maintain Taiwan's global competitiveness.

With the Christmas holiday approaching and many foreign traders away from the trading floor, turnover shrank and the relatively quiet trade made it easier for the central bank to intervene, according to the dealers.

The Polaris Research Institute said Thursday that the average value of the New Taiwan dollar is expected to rise next year to NT$29.70 against the U.S. dollar from the estimated NT$31.60 in 2010, largely on further inflows of foreign funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan to be major Chinese investment target

TEXT.P: China is now awash with cash, and Taiwan will become one of the main destinations for its excess capital, a local securities analyst predicted Thursday.

Lu Zong-yao, managing director of Lu Chang Equity Research, said at a forum on 2011's investment outlook sponsored by the Economic Daily News (EDN) that based on his decades-long research on the local capital market, he believed Taiwan would become one of China's important investment destinations.

According to statistics released by the Financial Supervisory Commission, seven China-based qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) have invested a total of US$163.7 million in the local stock market.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
Addressing the EDN seminar, Lu said there were reports that the recent appreciation of the Taiwan dollar may have been fueled by speculation from George Soros' Quantum Fund.
"I don't think so, " Lu said, suggesting it was more likely related to expectations of capital inflows from China.

According to his study, Lu said China will encourage overseas investment now that it has abundant capital, and Taiwan is a likely target given the ever closer trade and economic ties across the Taiwan Strait.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan meeting about the possible impact of capital inflows from China on the Taiwan dollar's value, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Chen Yu-chang said there were no abnormalities in local currency transactions in recent days.
Under current regulations, Chinese QDIIs are allowed to invest up to US$500 million in Taiwanese securities, with the maximum for any single QDII capped at US$80 million.

Taiwan's central bank, the FSC, and the Mainland Affairs Council reportedly have reached a consensus to raise the maximum a single QDII can invest in local stocks to US$100 million and also allow QDIIs to invest in TDRs (Taiwan depositary receipts) and shares of foreign companies that have their primary listings in Taiwan. (Dec. 17, 2010).
China Times:

Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Thursday that the government may allow well-known Chinese home appliance makers to buy stakes in local flat panel companies under certain restrictions, such as not permitting the Chinese investors to acquire more than half of a local company's shares.
The proposal is aimed at consolidating Taiwanese panel makers' position in the vast Chinese market, which has emerged as the world's biggest consumer of flat panel products.

In the face of strong competition from Japan and South Korea, the officials said, Taiwanese makers must sharpen their competitive edges through cooperation with their Chinese counterparts, the officials said.

Chinese flat panel makers, however, will still be barred from investing in the local flat panel sector, the officials said, because of lingering questions over the size of the stakes that they should be allowed to acquire.
Since Taiwan opened its door for Chinese investment in June 2009, 93 Chinese investment projects with a combined investment commitment of US$127 million have been approved.
The lackluster figures are primarily the result of stringent investment restrictions, particularly those in the high-tech sector, industry sources said. (Dec. 17, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's smart transportation system bridging barriers

TEXT.P: On a hot summer day 13 years ago, Huang Chun-nan hoped to take his son to the Taipei Zoo by bus. For most city residents it would have been a straightforward task, but for Huang, who has been a wheelchair user since childhood, the outing turned into a nightmare.

He was hoping to catch one of only two small No. 277 wheelchair buses that ran each day to get to his destination, and when he saw the bus approaching, he put his son on his lap to get ready to get on.
"But apparently the bus didn't see us and rushed past. I pushed my wheelchair really hard to try to catch it, because it was our only hope to get to the zoo," Huang recalled.

"But we failed, and I was so disappointed and frustrated by the incident that it still lingers in my mind today, " a distraught Huang said. "I didn't want my son to suffer from my disability, because he deserved to have a happy childhood like other children."
The incident left Huang scarred, but for him and many others in Taiwan who have fought similar obstacles, their constant struggles may soon be a thing of the past, especially in Taipei.

The city's government is gradually building a more barrier-free transportation system with "smart" features that has not only greatly improved the quality of life for people with disabilities but also shortened the distance between people.
One of its most important initiatives launched in 2001 has been the introduction of low-floor buses, equipped with ramps and extra space inside to accommodate wheelchairs.

A total of 600 of these buses will be in service in Taipei by the end of 2010, and that number will rise to 1,000, or one-quarter of all buses running in the city, by the end of next year, said Jeffrey Liu, an engineer with the Taipei City Department of Transportation (TCDOT).
More importantly to many wheelchair users, 26 city bus routes will exclusively operate low-floor buses by the end of 2010, providing a degree of predictability that has never existed before.

"We've gotten a lot of positive feedback, " Liu said. "The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) decided to provide another NT$170 million (US$5.6 million) in November to rehabilitate 100 older low-floor buses."

Huang said the buses have provided welcome relief. No longer feeling rushed when a bus driver pulls over, he said he has made friends with many people during his travels because everyone wants to offer help.
"I remember one time when a man volunteered to help me with the driver and all of a sudden the kids from Nangang Vocational High School on the bus began clapping for us," Huang recalled.
The city also has a fleet of wheelchair vans providing door-to-door service for 32,000 passengers a month that has grown to 152 vehicles today from 130 at the beginning of 2010.

Pao Wei-yao, who has driven a wheelchair van for eight years, said he has been inspired by the passion for life shown by some of his passengers. "A regular customer of mine who suffers from cerebral palsy always brings me an extra breakfast and reminds me to watch my health and eat on time," Pao said.

The city also has a fleet of 3,000 taxis dedicated to serving senior citizens and the physically and mentally challenged that has handled 680,000 passenger- trips since the program was launched in 2009.

Aside from its emphasis on barrier-free vehicles, the city has introduced what it calls an "advanced traveler information system (ATIS) , featuring "smart" technologies such as GIS (geographic information system) , which has been installed throughout the transportation network.
Lu Hung-wen, who is visually challenged, said his world has been made better by the GIS-assisted audible system on city buses.
"Back when there was no automatic announcement saying where the bus was as it moved, I had to count off each stop silently to figure out when to get off," Lu said.
To alert visually impaired travelers waiting at a stop that their bus is arriving, 193 buses have been equipped with speaker systems broadcasting drivers' announcements that they're pulling in.

Similar smart devices have also been extended to regular crosswalks in the city, with audible signaling systems emitting sounds that tell the visually impaired whether it is safe to cross the street or not.
The magic of ATIS, according to the city's Liu, is that people with disabilities are now able to decide on and control their journey.
"Everyone can check the whereabouts of our buses online, anywhere at anytime, " Liu said. "Taking a bus no longer means endless waiting, major doubts, or trying one's luck."
The website is www.taipeibus.taipei.gov.tw, which can be more easily accessed by entering "5284" when using Internet search engines. The number sounds like "I love bus" in Chinese.

Despite the technological advances and vehicle upgrades, TCDOT division chief Su Fu-chih said an emotional component is also needed to make the city's transportation system more accessible to people with disabilities.
He said that with an increase in vehicles and facilities that are barrier-free, people have to learn to be sensitive to others' feelings.
"Whether people can tolerate those using different forms of transportation and traveling differently from us determines if a city is great," Su said.

Huang believed that Taipei City residents have risen to the challenge, and he said the transportation network's continuing emphasis on accessibility has connected him to others in a way that has brought down some of the social barriers he and other people with disabilities have faced.
"I've gotten to know people whom I never would have had the chance to know, and I believe it's the same for them," Huang said.
By Lee Hsin-Yin, CNA staff reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved cross-strait ties create win-win-win situation: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 18:28:06 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that improved relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is advantageous not only to Taiwan and China but also to the United States.

Ma noted that the United States has played an important role in the nearly 100-year history of the Republic of China and has provided various forms of support to the country, ranging from economic aid to promoting Taiwan's democratization.
Despite the absence of diplomatic ties over the past 31 years, Taiwan and the United States have continued to maintain close interaction in the political, economic and cultural areas, Ma said.

"With cross-strait ties gradually improving, the government needs to allow its American friends to understand Taiwan's policy and to persuade the U.S. side that the new development is a win-win-win situation, " Ma said while addressing the opening of an art exhibition titled "American Footsteps in Taiwan" organized by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

Speaking of the U.S. role in the fate of the ROC and Taiwan, the president said that had the United States not entered World War II following Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor, the ROC would have had to fight a very hard battle against the Japanese, which was invading China at that time.

After the ROC government was forced to retreat to Taiwan after losing a civil war with the Chinese communists, the United States also protected Taiwan against attack by the communists by sending the U.S. Seventh Fleet to the Taiwan Strait in 1950, Ma noted.
Referring to the theme of the exhibition, William Stanton, director of the AIT's Taipei Office, said that "every step taken leaves a trace."

Although the United States did provide assistance to Taiwan between 1950 and 1980, it is the hard work of the Taiwanese people that has been the most important driving force behind Taiwan's democratization and its economic achievements, said Stanton.
The exhibition is being held until Jan. 24 at the National Central Library in Taipei. Items on display include 180 photos and 68 artifacts and oral history videos.
Patricia Linder, the 84-year-old widow of James Linder, who was the last commander of the U.S.-Taiwan Defense Command, also took part in the opening ceremony.

Linder said she could not believe she was back in Taiwan after being away for 30 years. She said she is proud of Taiwan's democratic development, which she described as history collectively made by all the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese swimmer wins third, fourth golds at Asian Para Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 18:44:20 (By Eric Tseng and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A visually impaired Taiwanese swimmer snatched two gold medals Friday at the Asian Para Games in Guangzhou, China after breaking two Asian records earlier this week.
Eighteen-year-old Lin Shin-wei won the men's 100-meter breaststroke SB13 event in a time of 1: 22.81 before setting a new Asian record of 26.80 in the men's 50m freestyle S13 event on the same day.
The visually impaired swimmer, who cannot see out of his left eye and is legally blind, also broke Asian records in the men's 100m freestyle-S13 and 200m medley- SM13 on Dec. 13 and 14.
S13 is one of three designations, along with S11 and S12, for swimmers with a visual impairment. S11 represents those with the least amount of vision.
As of Friday afternoon, Taiwan ranked sixth among 45 teams with eight gold medals, and had also won five silvers and seven bronzes at the games.
Luo Hsiao-hung from Taiwan also won gold in the women's 100m breaststroke-SB5 and powerlifter Lin Tzi-hui claimed gold in the women's under 75 kg division with a winning lift of 135 kg later Friday.
There are 77 athletes from Taiwan competing in 12 sports at the eight-day event, formerly held under the name of the Far East and South Pacific Games for the Disabled.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAS-labeled agricultural products trade fair opens
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 19:05:20 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait trade fair opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday, in which Taiwan's premium agricultural products bearing the CAS (certified agricultural standards) label were introduced to traders from China.

The Chinese buyers were expected to place a total of US$2.5 million-worth of orders on the first day of the two-day event, which was organized by Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) to promote the country's quality- certified agricultural products, COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said.
After the trade fair, follow-up orders worth many times that amount are expected to be placed, Chen added.

Wang Cheng-yi, chairman of Taipei-based Laurel Enterprises Corp., a frozen food producer with production lines in both Taiwan and China, said at the show he anticipates that CAS products will create NT$700 million to NT$800 million-worth of trade opportunities in China in the first year of going on sale there, expanding to NT$1 billion or higher in the following year.

More than 400 representatives and personnel in charge of procurement from agricultural and food businesses from Shanghai and the provinces of Zhejiang, Hunan and Shandong visited the trade fair on the opening day to see the offerings from 126 Taiwanese traders and producers of CAS products, according to the COA.

Chen noted in the opening ceremony that Taiwan applied in 2008 to register the CAS trademark in China. The application was approved in August this year so that Taiwan will acquire the trademark licence Jan. 20, the minister noted.
After that, CAS will serve as the flagship brand of Taiwanese premium agricultural products in the Chinese market, Chen added.

The COA established the CAS label and certification protocol in 1989 by adopting international standards in the production management and quality control of agricultural goods to ensure food safety and improve the competitiveness of the country's agricultural products.

To qualify for the CAS label, the products must meet four criteria: The raw materials must be from Taiwan; the production processes must be in accordance with approved hygiene and safety standards; the products must be in compliance with established quality specifications; and the packages and product labels must conform with accepted rules.
At present, CAS-labeled agricultural products are classified in 15 categories ranging from meat to rice, processed fresh fruit and vegetables and aquatic products, according to Chen.

The number of certified CAS producers has reached 330, with 6,388 items carrying the label and the total annual output of the companies involved has amounted to NT$45 billion (US$1.5 billion), Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLSA recommends 'buy' on Ambassador Hotel
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 19:19:02 (By Jeff Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: CLSA Asia-Pacific Markets said Friday it issued a "buy" recommendation on The Ambassador Hotel, Ltd. on a "positive" view about Taiwan's tourism sector due to an increase in Chinese visitors to Taiwan.
After initiating coverage of the hotel company, which has three properties in Taiwan, CLSA said it has set a 12-month target price of NT$56 (US$1.88) on the stock.
The hotel company's shares closed up 2.97 percent at NT$48.50 on Taiwan's stock exchange Friday.

"We expect to see further breakthroughs in 2011, given the expected opening toward Chinese visitors not traveling in tour groups and higher daily visa quotas for Chinese tour groups," CLSA said in a research note.
"The new policies could take place before the 2011 Chinese New Year holidays," it added.
Currently, only Chinese traveling in tour groups are allowed to visit Taiwan, but Taipei and Beijing are discussing easing regulatory restrictions to permit independent Chinese travelers to come.
CLSA said it expects talks on the issue to conclude ahead of the upcoming Lunar New Year holiday, which falls in February 2011.
The Ambassador Hotel is expected to post compound average growth rates for sales of 9.8 percent between 2011 and 2015 and 4.5 percent from 2016 and 2020, the brokerage said.
That compound average growth rate during the 2011-2020 period will be substantially higher than the 0.9 percent rise seen from 2006 to 2010, it said.

In terms of operating profit, the hotel is expected to post a compound average growth rate of 25.4 percent from 2011-2015, compared with a fall of 8.1 percent registered between 2006 and 2010, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling party finalizes health-care reform program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 19:25:44 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) finalized its national health insurance (NHI) reform package Friday in its bid to help keep the debt-ridden program afloat.
Under the latest reform package, the NHI premium rate will be slightly less than the current 5.17 percent of an individual's salary, according to Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang.

But the package also calls for a new source of premium revenues that had previously gone untapped. The program will collect 2 percent of stock dividends, interest income, professional income and "high bonuses" as a "supplemental premium" to strengthen the system's finances.
"High bonuses" are defined as total bonuses that are at least four times higher than an individual's monthly salary.
Yaung presented the latest NHI package at a KMT legislative caucus meeting that was also attended by KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung and Vice Premier Sean Chen.
The KMT lawmakers were said to generally agree with the latest package forged after close consultations between the executive and legislative branches.

Though the draft proposal set the maximum premium on monthly salaries at 6 percent -- higher than under the existing system -- Yaung said the actual premium rate should end up below 5 percent once the DOH completes more detailed calculations of potential revenues.
The 2 percent rate used to calculate supplemental premiums will be adjusted from the second year the new plan is in effect, according to the plan.

The final two-track premium system was a compromise after Yaung's plan to calculate NHI premiums based on household income failed to receive the endorsement of KMT lawmakers when it was sent to the legislature for final review earlier this month.

Yaung said after the meeting that his previous proposal was more ideal but would have encountered difficulties when put into practice. He added that the latest package was "the most ideal version that was feasible and acceptable."

Lin Yi-shih, director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said the KMT would send the latest version to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus for its reference later in the day.
Lin expressed the hope that the legislature would discuss the latest NHI reform package as soon as next Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Greenpeace flagship Rainbow Warrior to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 19:36:19 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The Rainbow Warrior, the celebrated flagship of the Greenpeace environmental protection group, will arrive in Taiwan on the first port call of its "Ocean Defenders Tour of East Asia" Jan. 2.

The ship is expected to visit various harbors and outlying islands around Taiwan over the course of the month, including Keelung, Suao, Green Island, Kenting, Kaohsiung and the island of Xiao Liuqiu before heading off Jan. 30 for Hong Kong and South Korea.

The visits are designed to continue spreading the Greenpeace message of the need for marine reserves to protect species facing extinction, Kao Yu-fen, oceans campaigner of Greenpeace in Taipei, said at a press conference in Taipei Friday.

This will be the first time the Rainbow Warrior has visited Taiwan, Kao noted. During its visit, Greenpeace will invite government officials, civic groups and the public to visit the ship, and campaigners will conduct related research on the ecosystem of Taiwan, especially its coral reefs and green turtle population.

The planned visit will coincide with the 40th anniversary of the founding of Greenpeace, an independent international organization dedicated to using non- violent and creative confrontations to expose environmental problems and force solutions, according to Greenpeace website.

Kao told reporters that while Greenpeace has been more focused on Europe and the United States during the last decades, in the coming years it will turn its attention to Africa and Asia, because Asia in particular is a region that faces challenging environmental problems.
"Illegal fishing is still being carried out by Taiwanese longline vessels; Taiwan should stop depleting endangered species such as tuna," she said.

The ship that will visit Taiwan is actually the Rainbow Warrior II. The original vessel was attacked and sunk in 1985 by agents of the French government in an attempt to foil protests against French nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific. The vessel will be retired after its East Asia voyage ends in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gives greenlight to cable TV system sale
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 20:45:36 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The government approved Friday the acquisition of Kbro Co., Taiwan's largest cable TV operator, by Daniel Tsai and his brother Richard, scions of one of Taiwan's richest families, from U.S. private equity firm the Carlyle Group.

The Tsai family's acquisition of Kbro via the recently established Da-fu Media will give it Kbro's 80-percent stake in 12 local cable television systems, said Hwang Jung-chiou, head of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, at a press briefing.
Kbro keeps the other 20 percent share in the deal worth NT$36 billion (US$1.2 billion).

The buyer received key approval from the National Communications Commission (NCC) last month after it clearly outlined its plan for developing a platform for digital TV and providing consumers with better quality programs.

Da-fu will spend NT$5.2 billion investing in digital TV, extending its coverage from the current 10.6 percent to 16 percent next year, 50 percent by 2015 and 74 percent by 2017, a goal set by the government.
Kbro now has more than 1 million cable television subscribers countrywide.
Daniel Tsai is also the chairman of Fubon Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's second-largest financial services provider.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-invoices to be available from stores: Finance Ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 20:52:22 (By Lin Yi-feng and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Electronic invoices will soon be available at bricks-and-mortar stores on a trial basis for the first time in Taiwan, as part of government plans to gradually replace paper bills with e-invoicing by 2012, the Ministry of Finance said Friday.

People who shop at 27 designated 7-Eleven and Hi-Life convenience stores or at the Pxmart supermarket with smart cards or store membership cards from Saturday will have their purchase information and invoice numbers automatically transferred to a database operated by the Financial Data Center under the ministry, said Finance Minister Lee Sush-der at a ceremony to launch the project.
Other devices with built-in chips or radio-frequency identification (RFID) such as watches and cellphones will also be used for e-invoicing in later stages of the project, Lee added.

About 11.5 billion invoices are printed every year, according to statistics. If 8 billion paper bills can be substituted by electronic invoices per year, 80,000 trees could be saved, according to Lee.
In an attempt to conserve resources, the ministry has decided to push for overall e-invoicing to make shopping more convenient and eco-friendly.

The reform is estimated to reduce the invoice process cost by NT$7.4 billion (US$248 million) between 2010 and 2013. The reduction is forecast to reach as much as NT$120 billion once the whole country is using paperless invoices, Lee added.
Two further stages of the e-invoicing trial will take place at more shops and retailers next March and June, the ministry said.
Currently, online shops, TV shopping channels, and business-to-business firms have taken advantage of electronic billing since the ministry set up an e-invoice platform in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-grown premium fruit draws attention of Chinese traders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 20:59:56 (By Cheng Chung-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-grown fresh fruit drew the attention of a number of Chinese buyers at a trade fair that opened Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center to showcase Taiwan's premium agricultural products.
"Taiwanese fruits are considered high-end quality items in my city," said Zhang Xiangfeng from Jinan in Shandong Province.

Zhang, a member of the Shandong Province Federation of Industry and Commerce, praised the quality of Taiwan-grown fruits at the first cross-Taiwan Strait trade fair featuring CAS-labeled agricultural products of Taiwan.
The two-day event was organized by Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture to promote premium agricultural products from Taiwan.
The CAS (certified agricultural standards) label was set up by the council in 1989 to safeguard the safety and quality of food products by local makers.
Zhang, who runs an agricultural development company in Jinan, said an increasing number of consumers in the city of 6 million people demand that their food be of high quality.
Though China has its own food safety certification system, Zhang was more confident in Taiwan's system and food products from the island.

Dai Chengcai, head of the Bureau of Agriculture of Longyan in Fujian Province, said after sampling Taiwan-grown bell fruit, guava and custard apple that he felt the high-quality bell fruit had considerable potential in his market.

Dai said Taiwan-grown bell fruits, also called wax apples, were available in Fujian at a price of 50 yuan per kilogram, but if Taiwan exported the CAS- certified bell fruit he sampled at the show, the price could exceed 80 yuan per kilo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government lauds Red House transformation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 21:07:43 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The Red House, a historical Taipei building that will celebrate the 102nd anniversary of its establishment Dec. 20, has been successfully transformed into a hub for cultural and creative industries, a Taipei city government official said Friday.

Johnson Chiu, chief executive officer of the Taipei Culture Foundation, said at a press conference that the Red House has seen positive changes since the foundation took over the operation of the octagonal brick building three years ago.

From its completion in 1908, the Red House, located in the bustling Ximending area, has stood through the Qing Dynasty, the Japanese occupation, and the influence of Shanghai and Western culture and fashion trends. It gradually lost its cultural significance following the urban development of Taipei in the eastern part of the city in the 1990s.
"Ximending has been a trendsetter in Taipei since 1900, and we have always tried to find ways to make the Red House connect with the area's development," Chiu said.

The last three years saw the Red House turned into a venue for designers to show their creative power, he went on, as the first floor is now occupied by 16 boutiques operated by young Taiwanese designers selling their wares, while the plaza outside the building is a cluster of more than 60 creative booths every weekend.
Moreover, the plaza, also has several gay bars, which Chiu described as a symbol that Taipei is an advanced city.

"Shop owners in Ximending have told me that about 40 percent of their income now comes from tourists rather than locals, meaning that the district is likely to be a major attraction for the capital in the near future," he concluded.
The Red House will celebrate its 102nd birthday by screening several video clips made by local artists from Friday to Jan. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: AU Optronics permitted to invest in China (UPDATE)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 21:47:42 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese flat panel maker AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) received government approval Friday to set up its first plant in China, a move expected to help the company compete with its South Korean rivals in China's market.

The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that AUO can proceed with a plan to build a US$3 billion 7.5-generation flat panel plant in Kunshan, in China's Jiangsu Province, Vice Economics Minister Hwang Jung- chiou said at a press briefing.
The Chinese plant is scheduled to enter mass production in 2012 as part of the company's efforts to cash in on growing Chinese demand.

The approval came weeks after Samsung Electronics Co. and LG Display Co., the world's two largest flat panel makers, were allowed to establish a 7.5-generation and 8.5-generation flat panel plants in China, respectively.

"In a highly competitive international market, Taiwanese panel suppliers now have only very limited time to create the early-mover competitive advantages in mainland China, " AUO said in a statement after learning of the approval.
"We must work much harder to catch up," it added.

AUO urged the government to "consider adopting a more lenient industry policy implemented by Taiwan's competitor countries and lifting the current restriction on fab generation and M&A (merger and acquisition) investments."
The appeal was aimed at providing Taiwanese manufacturers with more flexibility for their global business strategies and raise the local panel industry's global competitiveness, the company said.

AUO submitted its investment application in March but did not receive official approval until Friday after it met several government conditions aimed at minimizing any negative impact of the investment project in China on Taiwan.
AUO pledged, for example to invest NT$400 billion (US$13.4 billion) to build two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park by 2022.
The flat panel maker will also make additional investments totaling NT$150 billion in other parts of Taiwan, Hwang said.

Since AUO is already operating an 8.5-generation flat panel plant in Taiwan, its application to set up a 7.5-generation plant met with the government's requirement that high-tech companies investing in China must maintain a technological lead at home over their Chinese facilities, the official noted.

AUO has also promised to hire 5,000 employees in Taiwan over the next 10 years, as further assurance to the government that it would not slash its local workforce because of the new Chinese investment.

Chimei Innolux Corp., another Taipei-based flat panel maker, reportedly will submit an application to set up a plant in China, but company spokesman Eddie Chen said the plan was still in the pipeline and had no specific timetable.
In February, the government relaxed the rules governing high-tech investment in China by allowing flat panel makers to build up to three 6th-generation or above plants there.
Applicants must assure the authorities, however, that they can maintain a technological edge in Taiwan over any facilities they open in China and must promise to continue to invest at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete heads to Seoul for meeting over disqualification
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 22:23:21 (By C. C. Chiu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun departed for Seoul Friday to attend a meeting that could see her banned from the sport for protesting her controversial disqualification at the Asian Games in November.

Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) President Chen Chien-ping and Yang's two coaches, Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, accompanied her on the two- day trip. The meeting is scheduled for Saturday.

Yang was disqualified in her first match in the Asian Games women's under 49 kilogram division on Nov. 17 after being accused of wearing two extra electronic sensors on her socks to score more points.

Dumbfounded by her disqualification after taking a 9-0 lead against her opponent, Yang remained in the ring for an extended period of time despite requests from officials to leave, unwilling to accept what happened.

Replays of the match showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before her bout began and taekwondo officials gave inconsistent explanations of the reasoning behind Yang's dismissal, sparking questions about the legitimacy of the disqualification.

Speaking prior to her departure at the airport, Yang reiterated her innocence and said she would adopt a "business as usual" attitude at Saturday's meeting, called by the World Taekwondo Federation's disciplinary committee.

Chen said that at the request of the WTF, the CTTA had submitted three written statements from him, Yang, and Liu Tsung-ta, offering detailed evidence to protect the rights and interests of the athlete and coaches.
"There is just one set of facts related to the matter, and we will do our best to restore the truth at Saturday's meeting, " Chen said, expressing hope for "a good outcome."
Although Taiwan has officially registered an appeal with the Court of Arbitration for Sport against the disqualification, he made it clear that "we don't want to see it get to that point."

"The SAC and CTTA have reached a consensus on the issue, which is to maintain the rights of the athletes, coaches, and association and not be banned from competitions or have our rights revoked," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fans join Facebook campaign to help improve bilingual signs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 22:26:32 (By Wang Shu-fen and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A Facebook page set up to encourage Taiwan residents to look for mistakes in bilingual signs in public areas has attracted more than 1,100 fans, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Friday.

A total of 1,168 netizens now follow the page where people can upload photos of mistakes or improper usage of English in local signs and provide corrections to win free gifts, ranging from a Wii to an iPod.

The campaign, launched in September, was an attempt to correct English mistakes on signs seen in facilities or areas under the ministry's jurisdiction, including railway stations, airports, and national scenic areas.
The ministry gave a few examples of some bad English that probably drew a few laughs before being corrected.
A vendor at the Sinying service plaza, for instance, translated "lemon Aiyu jelly" directly from the Chinese to "the lemon loves the jade."
In another case, "watch out for snakes" was mistakenly written as "watch out for snacks" in the Siraya National Scenic Area in southern Taiwan.
Other errors included misspellings such as "mussum" for museum and "champing" for camping, according to the social-networking page.
There have been 38 photos posted by the site's fans so far. The campaign will run to the end of January 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete arrives in Seoul to media blitz
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 23:19:26 (By Chiang Yuan-chen, Flor Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun arrived in Seoul Friday for a meeting the following day that could see her banned from the sport for protesting her controversial disqualification at the Asian Games in November.
Yang was greeted by a crowd of Taiwanese and Korean journalists upon her arrival at Incheon International Airport.

The 25-year-old taekwondo athlete told reporters that she will defend herself at the disciplinary committee meeting of the World Taekwondon Federation (WTF) on her disputed dismissal from the Asiad in Guangzhou, China, on Nov. 17.
"I will take the opportunity to prove my innocence and clear my name," Yang said.
Yang was accompanied by Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) President Chen Chien-ping and Yang's two coaches, Liu Ching-wen and Liu Tsung-ta, on her Seoul trip.
To show their moral support for Yang, a number of senior officials from Taiwan's representative office in South Korea greeted her at the airport.
Yang was disqualified in her opening bout in the Asian Games women's under 49-kilogram division on Nov. 17 for allegedly wearing two extra electronic sensors on her socks to score more points.

Dumbfounded by her disqualification after taking a 9-0 lead against her opponent, Yang remained in the ring for an extended period of time despite requests from officials to leave, unwilling to accept what happened.

Replays of the match showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before her bout began and taekwondo officials gave inconsistent explanations of the reasoning behind Yang's dismissal, sparking questions about the legitimacy of the decision.

Chen said that at the request of the WTF, the CTTA had submitted three written statements from him, Yang, and Liu Tsung-ta, offering detailed evidence to protect the rights and interests of the athlete and coaches.
"There is just one set of facts related to the matter, and we will do our best to restore the truth at Saturday's meeting, " Chen said, expressing hope for "a good outcome."
Although Taiwan has officially registered an appeal with the Court of Arbitration for Sport against the disqualification, he made it clear that "we don't want to see it get to that point."

"The Sports Affairs Council and CTTA have reached a consensus on the issue, which is to maintain the rights of the athletes, coaches, and association and not be banned from competitions or have our rights revoked," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Judge indicted for negligence in leak of informant's identity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/10 23:22:41 (By Lai You-chia and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taipei District Court judge was indicted Friday for negligence after it was found that he failed to keep the identity of an informant confidential.
The Taipei Prosecutors Office indicted Judge Chou Chan-chun, along with court clerk Liu Li-ying, for negligence in allowing secrets to be leaked and asked that both be put on probation.

Chou is a relatively well-known judge whose name again was in the news after serving as the lead judge in a trial of former President Chen Shui-bian, who was charged with taking bribes related to two major mergers of financial institutions during his term in office and laundering the money.
Chou acquitted Chen in the case based on what was seen by some as a controversial argument.
According to Friday's indictment, Chou failed to seal information on an informant who tipped off the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) that Lu Chun-hua was growing marijuana in 2008.
When the CGA asked for a search warrant from the Taipei District Court, Chou did not seal the informant's identity after reviewing all of documents related to the investigation.

Clerk Liu also did not notice that the information she was handling was related to the informant and did not seal his identity, enabling Lu's lawyer to get access to the informant's identity after prosecutors indicted his client in 2009.
The informant and his family members reported to prosecutors that they were frequently threatened by unidentified people after the individual's name got out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 18, 2010, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kuo misses out on MLB's best setup man title
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 10:31:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese baseball pitcher Kuo Hong-chih of the Los Angeles Dodgers failed to win the 2010 Setup man of the Year Saturday in the annual Major League Baseball (MLB) This Year in Baseball (TYIB) awards.

The 29-year-old, who won the award in 2008, ranked third with 20 percent ballots casted behind Joaquin Benoit of Tampa Bay Rays, who is now with the Detroit Tigers, and Mike Adams of the San Diego Padres, who finished with 21 percent.

Benoit, who had a 1.34 ERA (earned run average) , garnered 49 percent of the ballots to win the award, which recognizes the best setup pitcher -- a relief pitcher who usually pitches in the seventh and eighth inning before the closer, while Adams finished second with 21 percent.
The award is one of 19 categories in the annual TYIB awards, which were calculated based equally on votes by fans at MLB.com, media, front-office personnel and retired players.

Kuo finished the 2010 season with three wins, two losses and 12 saves in 56 appearances, his best performance since making his MLB debut with the Dodgers in 2005, and became the first Taiwanese player to earn a spot in the MLB mid-season All-Star Game.

The left-hander, who had four surgeries on his elbow, also broke the Dodgers franchise record of the lowest ERA, finishing the season with an ERA of 1.20. He struck out 73 while yielding only 29 hits and 18 walks in 60 innings.

Aside from his record-setting ERA, he also limited opposing hitters to a .139 batting average during the season. Meanwhile, his WHIP (walks and hits per inning pitched) was an astounding 0.78. Anything below 1 is considered outstanding.

The TYIB Awards, which are also known as the GIBBY (The Greatness in Baseball Yearly) awards honor the 2010 season's top Player, Starter, Rookie, Closer, Setup Man, Defensive Player, Manager, Executive, Breakout Player, X-Factor, Dependable Player and Postseason MVP as well as the year's top Play, Moment, Performance, Oddity, Game, Fan Moment and Postseason Moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete awaits WTF meeting over disqualification
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 12:30:53 (By P.S. Hsiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun urged the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) Saturday to deal fairly with her disputed disqualification at the 2010 Asian Games.

Yang, who arrived in South Korea the previous night, said she believes that the WTF will handle the case with extra caution and reiterated that she will be very careful when attending a meeting to be held by the WTF's disciplinary committee later that day.

Prior to the meeting, Liang Ying-ping, Taiwan's representative to South Korea, hosted a luncheon for Yang and Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) President Chen Chien-ping and her coaches, Liu Tsung-da and Liu Ching-wen in a token of moral support for them.

Yang was disqualified in her first match in the Asian Games women's under 49 kilogram division on Nov. 17 after being accused of wearing two extra electronic sensors on her socks to score more points.
Astonished by her disqualification and unwilling to accept what happened after taking a 9-0 lead against her opponent, Yang remained in the mat for a while despite requests from officials to leave.

Replays of the match showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before her bout began and taekwondo officials gave inconsistent explanations of the reasoning behind Yang's dismissal, sparking questions about the legitimacy of the disqualification.

Speaking prior to his departure at the airport, Chen said that at the request of the WTF, the CTTA had submitted three written statements from him, Yang, and Liu Tsung-ta, offering detailed evidence to protect the rights and interests of the athlete and coaches.
"There is just one set of facts related to the matter, and we will do our best to restore the truth at Saturday's meeting, " Chen said and expressed hope for "a good outcome."

"The Sport Affairs Council and CTTA have reached a consensus on the issue, which is to maintain the rights of the athletes, coaches, and association and not be banned from competitions or have our rights revoked," he added.
Although Taiwan has officially filed an appeal with the Court of Arbitration for Sport against the disqualification, he made it clear that "we don't want to see it get to that point."
The four will fly back to Taiwan Saturday after the WTF meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: School bullying
DOC.DATELINE: 12/18/10 12:42:53 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 18, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is planning to promote a "school bullying prevention law" that would require that the bullies be isolated. The idea has come in the wake of a recent string of shocking bullying incidents, including beating up, taking naked photos of, and gang-raping schoolmates, with the violent acts videoed and posted online by the bullies.
School culture usually reflects social culture. These bullying behaviors are duplicates of some of the current problems in the Taiwanese society.

Surprisingly, many schools were unaware of the bullying problem or never dealt with it. In fact, such deviant behavior can be corrected with proper guidence provided by teachers. The real problem is: when the teenagers need to be advised, school and parents just stand idly by.

There is a need to develop a sense of justice and encourage active participation among teachers and students in order to prevent the bullying problem from further worsening. This is definitely more urgent than enacting a law or setting up a bullying hotline.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese wins silver medal in South Pole ultra-marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 14:52:46 (By C. Y. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tommy Chen, an extreme marathon runner from Taiwan, won a silver medal Saturday in the 100 kilometer ultra-marathon race in the South Pole in a time of 15:15:58.
Chen, widely seen as following in the footsteps of Taiwanese ultra-marathon champion Kevin Lin, was the first Asian to ever complete the race.
Chen, 24, took part in the 2010 North Pole marathon in April and won a bronze medal in the competition, setting a record as the youngest competitor in history to finish in the top three.
His third-place finish among 26 competitors from 10 countries was also the best performance by a Taiwanese marathoner in the North Pole marathon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Pay attention to the plight of the working poor
DOC.DATELINE: 12/18/10 15:26:00 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 18, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Official statistics show that the number of Taiwan workers who earn less than NT$20,000 per month -- roughly the same as the minimum wage -- has now reached 1.38 million. This is an increase of 240,000 compared with the period before the global financial crisis.
Furthermore, if the 600,000 people working without pay in family business are included, the number will be almost 2 million.
These figures tell us that the working poor problem is worsening as the wealth gap continues to widen in the country, and that the high economic growth is benefiting only a tiny minority.

The government should be held accountable for failing to institute an equitable tax system. The progressive rates adopted for income tax, gift tax, inheritance tax and land value-added tax were originally meant to balance the distribution of wealth. However, the system has been damaged by various tax reductions and exemptions introduced under the pretext of promoting investment.

Meanwhile, a task force set up by the Cabinet to address the problem of wealth inequality has not put forward any substantive resolutions in the four months it has been in operation. This is not because our policy makers do not have a clue, but because they are too timid to make critical decisions.
We hope our government officials will think more about the plight of these 2 million workers and their families and make a move soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- AU Optronics gains approval to operate in China
DOC.DATELINE: A leading flat panel maker, AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) 12/18/10 15:33:25 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: , was granted approval by the Taiwan government Friday to set up its first plant in China.
This means that AUO will now be able to commence work on a US$3 billion plant in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province, eastern China, to manufacture 7.5th generation flat panels.

However, the approval for AUO to set up business in China came several weeks after the world's two largest flat panel makers, Samsung Electronics and LG Display of South Korea, obtained permission from Beijing to establish 7.5G and 8.5G flat panel factories in China, respectively.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
For the first time, the Taiwan government gave approval for a large flat panel manufacturer to invest in China. Chimei Innolux Corp., another Taipei-based flat panel producer, is next in line.
With AUO scheduled to begin mass production in Kunshan in 2012, a full-blown flat panel war could erupt by then in the Chinese market between Taiwan and South Korean companies.

Expressing delight and relief at the approval, AUO urged the government Friday to also lift the current restrictions on fab generation and M&A (merger and acquisition) investments in order to give Taiwanese manufacturers more flexibility in their global business strategies.
AUO said that in the face of strong competition from foreign businesses, Taiwanese panel makers have limited time to develop a competitive edge in China. (Dec. 18, 2010).
China Times:

It took the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) nine months to complete its review of AUO's China investment plan. The ministry did not want to approve the project unless the company made a commitment to deliver on its promise to invest NT$400 billion (US$13.4 billion) in two 11th-generation flat panel plants and solar energy facilities in the Central Taiwan Science Park by 2022.
The MOEA wanted AUO to prove "its love for Taiwan" before investing in China. However, AUO has lost time in the race against its South Korean competitors.

In addition, domestic businesses are worried that Taiwanese flat panel makers in China, which is the world's largest market for that product, would not be able to compete with South Korean companies in the fab generation and production process. (Dec. 18, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Addressing rumors that AUO would merge with an optoelectronics company affiliated with the Kunshan City government, Vice Economics Minister Hwang Jung- chiou said that the MOEA has determined that no Chinese capital will be used in the establishment of AUO's plant in Kunshan.
It was because of this issue that the MOEA took as long as it did to approve the project.
Another reason was that the government was also concerned that AUO would not keep its promise to invest NT$400 billion in the Central Taiwan Science Park. (Dec. 18, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County to expand bus service for special needs passengers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 16:08:14 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei accompanied a number of physically and mental challenged people Friday on a trial ride of two new buses for passengers with special needs.
Chou said that by the end of the year, there will be 172 such buses in Taipei County, compared to 20 when he took office in 2005.
The two buses, which were outfitted by the Taipei Bus Co., can each carry 16 standing passengers and are equipped with a wheelchair hoist, six wheelchair slots and 14 regular seats.
According to the Transportation Bureau, the buses will be available for bookings from next year.
The county government will subsidize half of the fare for the disabled.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan prepared to negotiate cultural pact with China: official
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/18/10 16:24:31 (By Leaf Yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is prepared to discuss a cultural agreement with China and hopes that the issue can be put on the agenda for cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations next year, a visiting Taiwanese official said in Los Angeles Friday.

Similar to the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement signed in June, the cultural pact will provide a framework for further negotiations on detailed issues, according to Minister without Portfolio Ovid Tzeng.
Tzeng said "chances are high" that the planned agreement will be included on the agenda of the semi-annual meeting between the chief negotiators of the two sides next year.

The agreement is expected to address problems that have emerged in cross-strait cultural exchanges, such as copyright violations, patent protection and the establishment of independent film production companies, he said.
The idea of a cross-strait cultural agreement was first raised by China's Culture Minister Cai Wu during his last visit to Taiwan in September.
Hou Xianghua, deputy director of the ministry's Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan Office, said Thursday that Beijing will push for an early start of related negotiations next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Results of meeting on Yang issue not likely until Monday: WTF
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 17:36:32 (By P.H. Hsiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The decisions reached at a meeting of the World Taekwondo Federation's (WTF) disciplinary committee over the controversial disqualification of a Taiwanese athlete at the recent 2010 Asian Games will be known Dec. 20 at the earliest, a WTF official said Saturday.

The disciplinary committee has no authority to publicize the decision, which has to be approved by the WTF President Choue Chung-won, WTF Secretary-General Yang Jin-suk told the CNA before the start of the meeting.
In turn, the WTF will directly inform the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) of the outcome, Yang said.
The athlete Yang Shu-chun, her coaches Liu Tsung-da and Liu Ching-wen, and CTTA President Chen Chien-ping traveled to Seoul Friday for the meeting that was held Saturday afternoon.
At the building where the meeting was being held, the group was greeted by two Taiwanese exchange students waving the ROC flag in a gesture of moral support.
According to Chen, the meeting was conducted in a cordial atmosphere and none of the three attending committee members were from South Korea.

He said Friday before the group's departure from Taiwan that the Sport Affairs Council (SAC) and CTTA had agreed on a common position, which was that the rights of the athletes, coaches, and association should be retained and they should not be banned from competition.

Yang was disqualified by officials of the Asian Taekwondo Union (ATU) during her opening bout in the Asian Games women's under 49 kg division on Nov. 17, on grounds that she was wearing two extra electronic sensors in her socks. At the time, she was leading 9-0 in the match.

Video footage of the match later showed that Yang had removed the two sensors before the start of the bout. The ATU's accusation of Yang cheating sparked outrage across Taiwan, and drove the SAC to lodge a protest with the Olympic Council of Asia and to file an appeal with the international Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Huge demand forecast for elderly friendly home environment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 17:57:31 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's rapid advancement toward becoming an aging society will create a huge demand not just for medical care, but also for a safe home environment for the elderly, according to a real estate agency.
"The concept of creating an elderly friendly residential environment is still in its infancy in Taiwan, " said Bright Lee, a spokesman for Evertrust Rehouse Co., in a statement issued Friday.
However, as the society ages, public awareness of this issue will rise and home facilities for the elderly, from bathroom to balcony, will be seen as essential, Lee said.
"As a result, the market demand for such facilities is likely to grow very fast," he added.

The over-65 population in Taiwan is more than 2.3 million, or nearly 11 percent of the total population, according to figures for 2010 compiled by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
In 20 years, the number of people in that age group will surge to 5.73 million, or 24 percent of the country's 23 million population, the CEPD has forecast.

Lee said the steep rise in the number of elderly people in the country, coupled with the disabled population that now stands at 1 million, will drive demand for facilities geared toward creating a more convenient home environment for that demographic.

A recent survey conducted by the real estate agency found that 60 percent of people would prefer to live at home on their own when they grow old, while 15.33 percent would choose a nursing home or an assisted living complex.
That will translate into a market of 4 million people requiring special residential facilities in 20 years, the agency forecast.
The value of this market will amount to NT$3 trillion (US$100 billion) if each household spends NT$850,000 on renovations, Lee estimated.
The NT$850,000 figure was drawn from a recent experimental project by the Taipei City government to convert a small apartment into a home specially designed for the elderly or disabled.
The city government plans to expand the project soon to 50 apartments in public housing complexes, at a total cost of NT$50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors deny being biased against green politicians
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 18:00:54 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Tainan District Prosecutors Office rejected Saturday an allegation by Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih that it was discriminating against politicians in the green camp.

Su of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is under investigation for allegedly soliciting NT$100 million in bribes from a construction company that planned to bid for work in the Southern Taiwan Science Park development project.
Prosecutors raided Su's residence Friday and questioned him for hours before releasing him.
The magistrate reacted with a strong protest, saying that the judiciary was targeting green politicians while sparing those from the ruling Kuomintang.
He also accused the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou of persecuting green politicians to boost Ma's chances of re-election in 2012.

In response, the prosecutors office released a statement Saturday, saying that it is concerned with whether there are irregularities and finding supporting evidence, rather than with the political affiliation of those involved.
The office said that the truth will either be black or white, rather than green or blue, and it urged Su not to overreact.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renovation of century-old assembly hall completed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 18:18:39 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government will hold a ceremony Monday to mark the completion of renovation work on an assembly hall that dates back more than 100 years to the period of Japanese colonialization, the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau said Saturday.
Located in Shenkeng Elementary School, the assembly hall has served as a small forum venue since 1899 and has undergone three renovations -- in 1939, 1969 and 1997.
The hall, which has been listed as a historical site since March 2007, now has a dome, plastic-steel windows, steel doors and concrete walls.

The county government said it hopes that the renovated hall and Shenkeng Huang Yung An's Residence -- another historical heritage site in the township -- will help to attract more tourists to the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan on top-10 list for most improved tax-payment system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 18:31:10 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked ninth among 40 economies that have improved their ease of payment in the past year, according to an annual study released Saturday that measured the ease of paying taxes in 183 economies around the world.

Steve Go, head of the tax and legal services department of PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Taiwan, attributed the result to the government's efforts to slash the Corporate Income Tax to 17 percent from 20 percent, and to streamline tax reporting procedures.
Taiwan and China were the only two Asian economies on the list of the 10 most improved countries in terms of ease of paying taxes, Go noted.
Tunisia topped the list, according to the Paying Taxes 2011 report.

The report, which was jointly compiled by PwC, the World Bank and the International Finance Cooperation (IFC) , measures the ease of paying taxes by assessing the administrative burden for companies to comply with tax regulations, and by calculating companies' total tax liability as a percentage of pre-tax profits.

"Taxes on company profits have fallen each year as governments around the world have reduced their corporate tax rates in an effort to encourage business investment and stimulate growth, " said Susan Symons of PwC UK.

The 2011 report concluded that nearly 60 percent of the world's economies have made significant business regulatory changes to make it easier to pay taxes, despite the impact of the global financial crisis and the sluggish economic recovery.
Taiwan's overall ranking for ease of paying taxes stood at 87th, ahead of Japan at 112th and China at 114th.
However, Taiwan lagged far behind Hong Kong and Singapore, which ranked third and fourth, respectively.
PwC is a global professional services firm, headquartered in London, which provides services in insurance, tax and business consulting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwan Academy units to open in U.S. next year
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/18/10 19:29:53 (By Leaf Jiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two units of a Taiwan Academy will be inaugurated in Los Angeles and Houston next spring to present the country's culture to the American people, Minister Without Porfolio Ovid Tzeng said Friday.

The units in the two U.S. cities are the first two that Taiwan will set up overseas, and their opening will coincide with the start of the Republic of China's centennial celebrations in January 2011, said Tzeng.

Through a digital collection of resources at the academy, the government will show Taiwan's vigor, beauty and diversity to the U.S. people and allow them to really "see" Taiwan, said Tzeng, who arrived here earlier in the day to promote Taiwan's 100th anniversary celebrations.
In response to a question on whether the Taiwan Academy was set up to counter the influence of China's Confucius Institute abroad, Tzeng said the two establishments have different purposes.

Touching on a possible controversy over the traditional Chinese characters used in Taiwan and the simplified Chinese characters adopted by China, Tzeng said it is essential to learn traditional characters in order to grasp the essence of Chinese culture.
The use of traditional characters is an indispensable tool to pass on the culture to younger generations, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier leaves on one-week visit to Burkina Faso
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 19:54:49 (By Garfie Li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih departed Saturday for Burkina Faso, where he will attend the inauguration of that country's president on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Wu will be the first Taiwan premier to visit the West African ally since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994. He will attend a ceremony on Dec. 20 for the inauguration of Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore for a new term.
