It is also Wu's first overseas trip in his capacity as premier.

During his one-week stay in Burkina Faso, Wu will also visit a new hospital that was constructed with a loan from a Taiwan bank, which was guaranteed by the Taiwan government. The national hospital is scheduled to open in 2011.

Wu is heading an 18-member delegation that includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang, Minister of the Council of Labor Affairs Wang Ju-hsuan, and Tao Wen-lung, secretary general of the government-operated International Cooperation and Development Fund.

Earlier in the day, in his last public activity in Taipei before his departure, Wu spoke of Taiwan's "One Lamp in Africa" program, which is aimed at bringing light to the homes of disadvantaged Burkina Faso students.
He said many students in that developing country are forced to study on the streets at night by the light of street lamps because they do not have lights at home.
Under the program, Taiwan has developed a solar-powered LED lamp. It is equipped with a solar cell that lasts up to 4.5 hours and will allow the students to study at home, Wu said.
The children can charge the solar cell during the day and bring it home after school, he added.
The program is being supported by the World Bank, which has placed orders with Taiwanese businesses for the LED lamps for delivery as aid to African countries in need, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should do more for China's human rights: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 20:10:52 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Scholars had mixed feelings about the development of human rights and democracy in China Saturday but agreed that Taiwan could serve as a good example and should do more for its neighbor across the Taiwan Strait.

Various signs showed that some high level officials within the Communist Party of China (CCP) were ready for the introduction of judicial and human rights reforms, but it all came down to the top leader and the implementation of the law, said Jerome Cohen, Co-director of the U.S.-Asia Law Institute of the New York University School of Law.

Cohen, a respected law professor who had spent decades observing Taiwan and China, made the comments in a symposium on China's human rights development, organized by Taipei Bar Association, Lei Chen Human Rights Foundation and Hong Kong-based China Human Rights Lawyers Concern Group.

The Chinese leaders always said they supported human rights, but the human rights they supported were ones with "Chinese characteristics, " which were different from the Western standards, Cohen said.
"I always advised them that Taiwan, South Korea and Japan have all overcome the odds (when promoting human rights)," he said, adding "History is not an excuse for violating human rights."

A self-proclaimed optimist, Cohen said he could not afford to be too optimistic about China's future human rights development before China's political system changes because "within the CCP, it's very hard to tell the real thinking and mindset of the Chinese leader before he seizes the complete power."
Cohen, who met President Ma Ying-jeou -- his student at Harvard University in the 1970s -- yesterday, also said "the Taiwan government should not avoid talking with China about human rights issues".

Taiwan should demand protection of Taiwanese businessmen in China since now the cross-strait negotiations have touched upon the human safety issues, he said, referring to the recently stalled talks of a bilateral investment protection agreement.
Hsu Szu-chien, a researcher at Academia Sinica, urged Taiwan's non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to partner with their Chinese counterparts in offering assistance and sharing experiences.
Hsu also called on authorities on both sides of the strait to launch a human rights dialogue, saying that the move would be helpful to China's grassroot human rights and democracy movement.

"It seems to me that the power of a rising China grows stronger every day. But at the same time, its moral position keeps falling back, " Hsu said, because it can no longer persuade its people with the same excuses and the people of China no longer believe everything the government says.
"What will happen to China in the future? I don't know, " Hsu said.
"I see the potential and momentum right there. What Taiwan can do is to help the Chinese society to be ready for the moment when opportunities come, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Work of two young Chinese artists on display in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 20:50:24 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Two solo exhibitions that are now being held in Taiwan, featuring the paintings and video installation art of Chinese artists Yang Na and Mu Lei, give visitors an insight into how China's younger generation sees itself, the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) said Saturday.
Yang and Mu, both under the age of 30, are known for their distinguishing styles in contemporary Chinese art, MOCA Director Shih Jui-cheng said in Taipei Saturday.
Yang's paintings often portray a character called "Nana," who has a pair of big enchanting eyes, the nose of a dog, full lips and perfect make-up, shih said.
"Nana" is the embodiment of an aesthetic image reflected among the younger generations in Asia, Yang explained.
In Asia, including China, girls, women and even young men, are constantly trying to make their eyes look bigger and their face prettier -- a monotone that is contrary to natural beauty, she said.
Yang said she painted a dog's nose on Nana because many young girls, particularly in China, can "acutely smell" how to get what they want by acting cute and using their beautiful looks.

She said for people in China who were born in the 1980s and 1990s and grew up during the country's rapid economic expansion, life is relatively comfortable. As an artist, Yang said, she would like to portray the characteristics of the people of her time.
"It would be pretentious to say that the younger artists in China still live in agony in order to create," she said.
Mu, on the other hand, said that as a contemporary artist, innovation always comes first.
While painting is a good way to express one's thoughts and show one's techniques, he said, he has now extended his creativity to video installation and animation.
In the exhibition hall where his work is on display, visitors are invited to sit on four toilet seats while their images are projected onto a screen along with pictures of helicopters and bombs.
"Sitting on the toilet in front of others satisfies our secret desire to become the objects of a voyeur's peeking," he said.
The two solo exhibitions will be held at MOCA until Jan. 23, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st case of probable mad cow disease listed posthumously in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 21:14:28 (By Chen ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first probable human case of mad cow disease in Taiwan was listed posthumously Saturday, following the death in May of a man who had symptoms of the fatal brain-wasting illness.

The listing was made after officials and experts on a Department of Health (DOH) panel on Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) held a meeting to determine whether the man had died from the disease as result of eating infected beef.

"We believe it is very likely that the man who died in May this year contracted the disease during his stay in the United Kingdom, " the DOH said in a press statement. "We cannot rule out the possibility that he ate infected beef during that time."

Scientists believe that many years after eating cattle infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , commonly known as mad cow disease, humans can develop symptoms of new variant CJD (vCJD) , also known as human mad cow disease.

The 36-year-old man had lived in the U.K. between 1989 and 1997, when mad cow disease was at its peak in that country. He began to show vCJD symptoms, including memory loss and hypersomnia, in 2008. Doctors reported the case to the DOH's Centers for Disease Control in March 2009.
As his family refused to give doctors permission to perform an autopsy, the DOH said, it could not list the patient as a confirmed case of vCJD. His body has since been cremated.

Though the cause of death could not be determined by means of an autopsy, it was an extremely likely case of vCJD, based on the man's symptoms, travel history and the results of magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalograms, the DOH said.
According to the DOH's CJD advisory panel, it was unlikely that the patient contracted the disease in Taiwan.
"His death could be counted as an imported case of vCJD and unlikely to pose any threat to Taiwan's disease control network," the DOH statement said.
Citing its tracking records, the DOH said the man had donated blood to two patients 10 years ago.

"Neither of them has contracted the disease," the statement said, adding that precautionary measures had been taken to prevent any spread of the disease during the time the man was hospitalized in Taiwan.

According to the World Health Organization, CJD is a fatal human degenerative condition characterized by progressive brain dysfunction and is categorized into four forms -- sporadic, familial, iatrogenic and variant.
The UK Department of Health has said vCJD differs from CJD in that the former is more likely to strike younger people.

Since 1997 when the DOH set up a CJD reporting and monitoring system, 436 suspected CJD or vCJD have been reported in Taiwan, DOH figures show. Of that number, 246 were listed as possible or extremely possible cases of sporadic or familial forms of CJD, five were confirmed as traditional forms of CJD and one was listed as probable vCJD, according to the DOH tallies.
The others were ruled out as possible cases of CJD.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese golfer jubilant over GWAA Player of the Year title
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 21:55:06 (By Oscar Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Yani Tseng of Taiwan said Saturday she felt honored to be selected as the 2010 Female Player of the Year (POY) by the Golf Writers Association of America (GWAA).
"Thank you for your recognition. It is a great honor. I'm excited. I will continue working hard. Thank you, all of you," Tseng wrote in Chinese on her Facebook page.
The association announced Tseng's selection Friday. It was her first GWAA POY award. She will be honored at the GWAA's annual awards dinner slated for April 6, 2011 in Augusta, Ga.
Tseng received 69 percent of the vote (137 votes) for the GWAA's Female Player of the Year award, compared to Cristie Kerr's 32 votes and Ai Miyazato's 31 votes.
Tseng, who returned to Taiwan earlier this month for a brief stay, is now back in the United States to spend Christmas with her parents.
Earlier this week, Tseng, along with retired golf queen Annika Sorenstam, attended an event sponsored by a noted watch company.

The 21-year-old performed well this year, winning three LPGA titles, including two majors -- the Kraft Nabisco Championship and Women's British Open -- and was the winner of the LPGA Player of the Year 2010. She had eight top-10 finishes and ended fourth on the money list.
Tseng said during her stay in Taipei that she was very happy to win the LPGA Player of the Year award and will work even harder next year to pursue excellence.

DOC.HEADLINE: New cross-strait dialogue platform to be formed next month
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 22:34:28 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A new cross-Taiwan Strait civic dialogue platform, initiated by two prominent former student movement leaders in Taiwan and China, will be inaugurated early next year to promote cross-strait cultural exchanges and democratic development.

Lo Wen-chia, a former opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislator who used to be one of former President Chen Shui-bian's aides, said Saturday he will join with Wang Dan, an exiled Chinese pro-democracy activist who was one of the top leaders of the Tiananmen Square protest of 1989, to launch the new dialogue platform in January.
The platform aims to promote grassroots cross-strait exchanges under a democratic framework and transparent system, Lo said.
"We hope our efforts will contribute to cultivation of mutual trust across the Taiwan Strait," he added.
According to their plan, Lo said a forum will be organized once every year to discuss issues related to cross-strait cultural and academic exchanges as well as promotion of democratic development.
The first forum will be held in Taiwan, with the participation of respected scholars in Taiwan, China and overseas, Lo said, adding that the second forum may take place in Japan or South Korea.
In addition, Lo said academics, politicians and journalists from Taiwan and China will also be invited to meet in Taipei once every month to exchange views on topics of mutual interest.
Meanwhile, a quarterly magazine will be published for distribution around the world, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st case of probable mad cow disease listed posthumously in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/10 21:14:28 (By Chen ching-fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first probable human case of mad cow disease in Taiwan was listed posthumously Saturday, following the death in May of a man who had symptoms of the fatal brain-wasting illness.

The listing was made after officials and experts on a Department of Health (DOH) panel on Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) held a meeting to determine whether the man had died from the disease as result of eating infected beef.

"We believe it is very likely that the man who died in May this year contracted the disease during his stay in the United Kingdom, " the DOH said in a press statement. "We cannot rule out the possibility that he ate infected beef during that time."

Scientists believe that many years after eating cattle infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , commonly known as mad cow disease, humans can develop symptoms of new variant CJD (vCJD) , also known as human mad cow disease.

The 36-year-old man had lived in the U.K. between 1989 and 1997, when mad cow disease was at its peak in that country. He began to show vCJD symptoms, including memory loss and hypersomnia, in 2008. Doctors reported the case to the DOH's Centers for Disease Control in March 2009.
As his family refused to give doctors permission to perform an autopsy, the DOH said, it could not list the patient as a confirmed case of vCJD. His body has since been cremated.

Though the cause of death could not be determined by means of an autopsy, it was an extremely likely case of vCJD, based on the man's symptoms, travel history and the results of magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalograms, the DOH said.
According to the DOH's CJD advisory panel, it was unlikely that the patient contracted the disease in Taiwan.
"His death could be counted as an imported case of vCJD and unlikely to pose any threat to Taiwan's disease control network," the DOH statement said.
Citing its tracking records, the DOH said the man had donated blood to two patients 10 years ago.

"Neither of them has contracted the disease," the statement said, adding that precautionary measures had been taken to prevent any spread of the disease during the time the man was hospitalized in Taiwan.

According to the World Health Organization, CJD is a fatal human degenerative condition characterized by progressive brain dysfunction and is categorized into four forms -- sporadic, familial, iatrogenic and variant.
The UK Department of Health has said vCJD differs from CJD in that the former is more likely to strike younger people.

Since 1997 when the DOH set up a CJD reporting and monitoring system, 436 suspected CJD or vCJD have been reported in Taiwan, DOH figures show. Of that number, 246 were listed as possible or extremely possible cases of sporadic or familial forms of CJD, five were confirmed as traditional forms of CJD and one was listed as probable vCJD, according to the DOH tallies.
The others were ruled out as possible cases of CJD.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 19, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Tackling campus bullying professionally
DOC.DATELINE: 12/19/10 15:04:10 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Building a professional support and monitoring network with the participation of parents, school authorities, social workers and the police is the only way to tackle campus bullying.
Dr. Dan Olweus, a pioneer researcher on issues associated with bullying, defined the problem as a school child being exposed to the negative behaviors of his or her peers repeatedly and over time.
Most often, bullying involves a single victim and several perpetrators. Therefore, parents should not only worry about their children being victims but also perpetrators of school violence.

The Ministry of Education (MOE) has been considering a "school bullying prevention law" that would mandate isolation of school bullies. The idea was raised in the wake of a recent string of shocking incidents such as students being beaten up, forced to take nude photos, and gang-raped. The violent acts were even posted online by the perpetrators.

According to an MOE survey of 100,000 junior high school students around the country, 3.23 percent have been beaten by their peers and 1.3 percent have been victims of extortion. Verbal violence and cyber bullying excluded, some 50,000 junior high students in Taiwan have been victims of bullying, according to the survey.
Nevertheless, only a few cases had been reported via campus safety channels, probably because many schools were unaware of the bullying problem or had never dealt with it.

Just like domestic violence, campus bullying is a public issue that requires the effort of all related sectors of society to address the problem. Taiwan society should not leave the resolution of such incidents up to the victims and perpetrators. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County extends child birth subsidy for another year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 15:08:45 (By Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government has decided to extend its child birth subsidy for another year as the policy has proved effective in boosting the birth rate in the county.

Married Changhua residents and single women over the age of 20 are eligible to apply for the subsidy, once one of the baby's parents has household registration in the county and has lived there for more than a year. It is required that the newborn be registered in Changhua as well. The subsidy, which will continue in 2011, is NT$10, 000 (US$335) per newborn.
The number of newborns in the county increased by 99 year-on-year after the government extended the subsidies from low-income families to all residents in 2009, statistics showed.
In 2008, the number of babies born in the county was 12,146.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar appreciates at higher rate than Korean won
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 15:43:11 (By Kao Chao-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan currency closed at NT$30.51 against the U.S. dollar Friday, ending the week with a 0.25 percent gain against the greenback.
The New Taiwan dollar has appreciated 4.98 percent so far this year, far higher than the Korean won which rose only 0.99 percent against the U.S. currency.

Most Asian currencies have risen in value against the U.S. dollar so far this year, led by the Thai baht which has appreciated 10.97 percent, the Japanese yen 10.78 percent and the Malaysian ringgit 9.19 percent.
The New Taiwan is in fourth place, having gained 4.98 percent against the U.S. dollar.

Other Asian currencies that have risen include the Philippine peso in the fifth place with a 6.26 percent appreciation rate, followed by the Indonesian rupiah with 4.08 percent, the Indian rupee with 2.58 percent and the Chinese renminbi or yuan with 2.45 percent.
Reports of U.S. economic indicators turning upbeat have reduced the emerging economies' "defensive demand" for the U.S. greenback, leading to a depreciating trend last week for their currencies.

According to Bloomberg News, of the 10 Asian countries, only the New Taiwan dollar and the Russian ruble rose last week. The ruble ended the week up 0.8 percent at 30.637 against the U.S. dollar as of 5:00 p.m. Friday, Taipei time.
The NT dollar bucked the trend, rising against the greenback on the strength of stock market gains and the inflow of foreign capital, breaking the NT$29.8 mark at one point and closing at NT$30.51.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Korean SK eyeing Uni-President Lions' pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 16:33:39 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A team in the Korea Baseball Organization (KBO) is eyeing Taiwanese pitcher Pan Wei-lun, as he is now free to join professional baseball teams abroad after playing professionally at home for over six years, according to a South Korean media report.
KBO East team SK has contacted Pan's team in Taiwan, Uni-President Lions, to inquire about the right-hander's contract, it was reported in Sports Chosun.
Pan has been playing with Uni-President Lions, one of the teams in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , for eight years.
SK is highly interested in recruiting Pan, but if the cost of trading him is too high, it could prove an obstacle, according to the reporter surnamed Park.

Although the transfer fee would be about NT$15.3 million (US$510,000), there is a good chance he would be traded to SK, as the team had not yet renewed the contracts of its two foreign players, Ken Kadokura and Gary Glover, Park said.
The deadline for SK to renew the two contracts is Dec. 31, Park said.

According to CPBL regulations, SK would have to pay Uni-President Lions a transfer fee of 2.5 times of Pan's current annual salary of NT$6.12 million and start Pan at an annual salary of 1.5 times his most recent pay with Uni- President Lions.

According to Park, an SK official in charge of business operations visited Taiwan last week and told the Korean media upon return that "there is room for Uni-President Lions to lower the transfer fee."
However, Uni-President Lions' President Chen Cheng-nan said that speculations on a lower transfer fee were groundless and the club would follow CPBL regulations on Pan's release.

Pan, 28, who has been with Uni-President Lions from 2003-2010, has been playing international games since he turned 14. He is currently the highest-paid local player in Taiwan, but has never joined a foreign team before.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recalls being labeled 'Red Guard' along with Lee Huan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:10:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday when he worked under then Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary General Lee Huan, both of them were branded as "Red Guards" because they were trying to push for major political reforms.
At a memorial for Lee, who died on Dec. 2 at the age of 93, Ma reflected on the days when the late KMT leader and government official was his boss.

Their main duties at the time were to prepare for the lifting of the martial law, to allow for the formation of political parties, and to replace a whole generation of National Assembly members, Ma recalled.

Because the last task would affect many senior politicians, Ma said, he and Lee were criticized and labeled "Red Guards." The name was drawn from the forces unleashed by Mao Zedong of China to purge his political enemies during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.
Ma praised Lee as having contributed greatly to the process of retiring senior members of the National Assembly, amending the Constitution and pushing through other political reforms.

Acting on a directive by then President Chiang Ching-kuo, Lee also worked to cultivate in particular Taiwan-born political talent, which was a major achievement that helped "build energy" for further development, Ma said.
"It is necessary to illustrate Lee 's important role in helping to achieve the Republic of China's transition to democracy," Ma said.
The president issued a special citation in honor of Lee, which was accepted by Lee Ching -chung, Lee's eldest son.
Lee was born in Hubei province, the Republic of China, on Sept. 24, 1917. In addition to his KMT party posts, he served as education minister and premier before retiring.
Honoring his wishes for no altars, public mourning, condolence committees, obituaries or funeral services, his children held a "non-funeral service" Sunday.

Although it was an informal gathering, it was attended by a number of prominent politicians, including Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Examination Yuan President John Kuan, KMT Honorary Chairmen Lien Chan and Wu Po-hsiung and New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes Taiwan will lead promotion of Chinese culture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:18:43 (By Sunrise Huang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he hopes Taiwan will take the lead in the promotion of Chinese culture and the use of traditional Chinese characters amid a worldwide trend of learning Mandarin.
The president said he is committed to the preservation of traditional Chinese characters and expects Taiwan to play a leading role in this regard.

"I have always wanted to make school campuses more international and make Taiwan a global educational center in East Asia, " the president said at an Annual Conference of Teaching Chinese as a Second Language in Taipei.
Traditional Chinese characters are the essence of the culture and should be preserved and passed down to future generations, he said.
However, currently only 40 million people worldwide use traditional characters, while 1.3 billion use simplified Chinese, he said.
He said that China, which officially uses simplified Chinese, should push for reading ability in traditional Chinese even if it maintains simplified characters for writing.
The president also asked the Ministry of Education to encourage more universities to establish institutions or departments to train Chinese teachers.
About 450 people, including Chinese teaching professionals and students, attended the conference at Fujen Catholic University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low enrollment forcing academic departments to merge: educator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:49:10 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Academic department mergers at tertiary institutions in Taiwan will be unavoidable as the number of high school graduates continues to decline due to a steadily falling birth rate in the country, an educator said Sunday.
The merger trend is likely to escalate in about four to six years time, according to Victor W. Liu, chairman of the non-profit Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation Council of Taiwan.
"Department mergers are expected to peak between 2015 and 2017 when Taiwanese children who were born in 1998 will be entering college," Liu said.
The number of babies born in 1998 was 60,000 fewer than the previous year, Liu said.
In addition to poor academic performance and lack of accreditation, Taiwan's low birth rate has been a major contributing factor to the low enrollment rate at colleges and universities, he said.
However, commercialization and globalization could help Taiwan's tertiary institutions to survive, he said.
For example, he said, further opening to international and Chinese students could help academic departments to remain operational, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice ministers to head cross-strait economic cooperation committee
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 18:15:28 (By Lin Shu-yuan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An Economic Cooperation Committee (ECC) that Taiwan and China have been planning is expected to be formed soon, with a vice minister from each side acting as co- convener, officials said Sunday.

The officials, who asked not to be named, said the announcement will be made at the meeting between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), which will be held Monday to Wednesday in Taipei.
Taiwan's Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Francis Kuo-hsin Liang and China's Vice Minister of Commerce Jiang Zengwei are expected to jointly head the committee.
It will be formed in accordance with the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) that was signed by the chiefs of the SEF and ARATS in Chongqing, China in June.

The cross-strait ECC will be composed of seven panels that will deal respectively with commodities trade, service trade, financial services, intellectual property rights, economic cooperation, dispute settlement, and investment, the officials said.

The panels will be headed by government bureau or department executives. For instance, on the Taiwan side, the commodity trade panel will be headed by Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Bill Cho, while the IPR panel will be led by Wang Mei-hua, director-general of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Intellectual Property Office, according to the officials.
The heads of the panels will be called "conveners," while the ECC leaders will act as "general conveners" under the framework of the SEF and ARATS, the officials said.
The deputy heads of the SEF and ARATS will be named chairpersons of the ECC, the officials added.

SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his ARATS counterpart Chen Yunlin will meet for a sixth round of formal talks Monday. An advance team, led by ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, arrived in Taiwan Sunday to prepare for the Chiang-Chen talks.

Chiang and Chen are expected to sign a medical and health cooperation agreement and announce the formation of the ECC. The agreement will be the 15th signed between the two sides since 2008, when cross-strait relations saw marked improvement after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou on May 20.

With the approach of Jan.1, 2011 when an "early harvest" list of products will begin enjoying preferential tariffs under the ECFA, the ECC is seen as necessary to facilitate working-level talks on the implementation, interpretation and coordination of ECFA-related business.

Also, the ECC panels are expected to do the follow-up work on commodity trade, services trade, dispute settlement and investment protection, which means the two sides would want the committee to be in place before the end of 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese advance team arrives to prepare for cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 18:54:49 (By Charles Kang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A Chinese delegation arrived in Taiwan Sunday for preparatory talks ahead of a high-level meeting between Taiwan and China negotiators that is expected to result in a medical agreement.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is leading the advance team in the meeting with its Taiwanese counterpart, Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Upon arrival, Zheng was greeted by Kao at the Grand Hotel in Taipei, where the negotiations will take place.

The two sides discussed matters related to an investment protection accord and a medical and health-care cooperation pact. The medical pact is expected to be signed when the top-level negotiators from both sides meet Dec. 20-22.

ARATS President Chen Yunlin is expected to arrive in Taipei Monday for his sixth meeting with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung since 2008, when cross-Taiwan Strait relations began to warm up under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Asked why an investment deal will not be signed during the meeting, ARATS Vice President and Secretary-General Li Yafei said the negotiations only began in September and the agreement is not yet ready.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwanese makes ultra marathon history

TEXT.P: Tommy Yen-po Chen, an ultra marathon runner from Taiwan, placed second in a 100-kilometer ultra marathon race in the South Pole Saturday.
Chen finished in a time of 15:15:58, becoming the first Asian to ever complete the grueling race.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Chen, 24, fighting the freezing cold, frostbite and a sprained ankle, made history in the ultra marathon just three days after completing a 42-km marathon in the South Pole.
"I just want the whole world to know how brave Taiwan is," he said.

The Antarctic Ice Marathon presented a truly formidable and genuine Antarctic challenge, with underfoot conditions comprising snow and ice throughout, an average wind chill temperature of minus 20 degrees Celsius, and the possibility of strong Katabatic winds -- winds that blows down a slope because of gravity.
The climax of the marathon, the Antarctic 100-km ultra race, is reserved for only the toughest of endurance athletes.

Six athletes -- five men and one woman -- started the race, but one dropped out halfway through. Brazilian Bernardo Fonseca, 33, finished first in a time of 12: 41: 52, while the only female, 24-year-old Clare Apps of the United Kingdom, finished in third place in a time of 18:58:19.

Chen has won marathons in Japan and Canada and finished third in the 600 km Polar Challenge in 2008. He placed fourth in the 2009 Himalayan 160-km Stage Race and third in the 2010 North Pole Marathon.

He has set an Asian record of running the North and South Pole marathon within nine months of each other, and has become the first Taiwanese to carry the Republic of China's flag in the North and South Poles.
Chen's mentor, Pan Jui-keng, recalled that Chen was the only one that could withstand the rigors of helping to prepare Kevin Lin, another legendary Taiwanese athlete, for a polar ultra marathon.
Liberty Times:
The Antarctic Ice Marathon was first held in 2005. All the runners in the annual event this year were required to train on the precarious terrain for at least five days to acclimatize.
Having completed races in the North and South poles as well in the Himalayan region, Chen will head for Australia next March to take part in a 45-km run through the Blue Mountains.
Chen's parents usually worry about him whenever he is competing, but they know they cannot keep him at home.
Chen's father, Chen Pin, is a senior chiropractor. He is finding that his son's reputation is quickly catching up with his.

Chen's mother Lee Wan-ni said her son was raised by his grandmother in Yunlin, south-central Taiwan, where he lived until five years ago. He developed a love for nature and outdoor activities, Lee said.
"He used to cry a lot when he was a child, but his personality changed after he started training for marathons. He has become more adventurous and more independent," she said. (Dec. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Crowds celebrate 99th anniversary of Alishan rail
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 20:30:45 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The only operational forest railway in Taiwan celebrated its 99th anniversary Sunday with the resumption of service on a segment of line that was damaged during a typhoon last year.
The Chiayi Forestry Area Administration hosted a party to mark the 99th anniversary of the Alishan Forest Railway, which began service on Dec. 25, 1912.
Railway enthusiasts and visitors flocked to Beimen Station, one of the stations along the main line of the unique narrow-gauge railway, in Chiayi City.

Service on the section between Beimen and Jhuci Township in Chiayi County has resumed, while the Zhushan and Divine Tree lines in the Alishan area have re- opened, said Hu Sing-Hwa, deputy minister of the Council of Agriculture.
The 71.4 km railway and three of its branch lines were badly damaged by Typhoon Morakot last August. The other line has been closed since a devastating earthquake in 1999.
The forest administration hopes to extend service to Fenchihu, one of the 15 stops on the route, by next March, Hu said.
The railway was constructed initially to transport wood from the mountains but is now used for recreational purposes, carrying passengers to the popular Alishan resort.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hope remains for a democratic China: Chinese dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 20:45:38 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Despite China's impressive economic boom in recent years, most people in the communist country are still yearning for democracy because no amount of wealth can satisfy people's hunger for basic freedom, said Chinese social activist and dissident Wang Dan on Sunday during a lecture in Taipei.

Wang, a leader during the 1989 Tiananmen Square student freedom movement, said while there are no visible indications that China is becoming democratic, he still has high hopes for its eventual democratization because the younger generation is becoming more aware of equality and human rights.

"I am optimistic about the future of China," Wang told a group of young social activists from Taiwan and Hong Kong. "Much of what we see in China now is nothing but a facade because the entire social structure is based on lies since that is the only way a post-authoritarian regime like China can sustain itself."

The fact that China has a huge exodus of talent each year means that many overseas Chinese understand that an economically advanced China without the protections of basic freedom and human dignity is simply not enough, he said.
"If you can sit down and really talk with a Chinese student, he will most likely tell you that he wants democracy," Wang said.

Wang was an initiator of the 1989 student protest in Beijing that was squelched by the Chinese army in a bloody crackdown. He was imprisoned and arrested several times for leading various democratic movements in China before his eventual exile to the U.S. in 1998.
He obtained a doctorate degree from Harvard University and now teaches Chinese history at National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu.
He told the audience Sunday that to be a social activist, one cannot be afraid of loneliness or failure.

"We can never predict the exact direction of the society, therefore, much of what we do as activists might not prevail as we would wish, but we must be prepared for failures, he said. "Knowing that you might not succeed should never prevent you from trying."
Wang also urged the young social activists to maintain a tight network with other like-minded groups "so that when the time comes, you will be able to move at a quick and synchronized pace."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urged to be more open toward China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 21:04:38 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An exiled Chinese dissident urged Taiwan's leading opposition party Sunday to pay more attention to the views of academics in the formulation of its China policy and to have greater engagement with China's civic society..

"The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should listen more closely to the opinions in academic circles instead of only those in its inner circle," said Wang Dan, who was one of the student leaders in the 1989 Tiananmen Square protest.

The DPP would have a better chance of winning the 2012 presidential election if it developed a sound policy to maintain cross-Taiwan Strait ties, said Wang, who is currently a visiting assistant professor at Taiwan's National Tsing Hua University.
Wang said people in academic circles often come up with good ideas that can be valuable to policy makers in both the DPP and ruling Kuomintang.

Wang and former DPP Legislator Luo Wen-jia will jointly set up the cross-strait democracy and culture offices in both Taipei and New York primarily to push for the establishment of a platform to facilitate private sector dialogue between Taiwan and China.
In response to a reporter's question on whether the office will advise DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to visit China, Wang said that is an issue the DPP itself should assess.
However, he said, "it's better to initiate some kind of engagement than to have none."
If Tsai decided to visit China, one of the issues would be whom she should meet there, he said.
It would be somewhat narrow-minded if she met only with Chinese officials or ranking members of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , he said.
"Tsai should meet with people in China's civic society, " he suggested.
Luo said the DPP should seek closer engagement with China, particularly beyond the Chinese government and the CPC.

Luo said the cross-strait private-sector dialogue platform that the offices are aiming to set up will be completely different from a DPP think-tank and it will not be influenced by elections or people in high office.
One of its tasks will be to change the DPP's anti-China image -- the perception that the party has a closed-door policy toward China and refuses to engage with Beijing, Luo said.
It will also seek to lead the DPP toward closer engagements with China's civic society as means of better understanding the Chinese people and propagating the DPP's ideals, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Sun Yun-suans needed in government service: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 21:28:19 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday he hopes there will be many more Sun Yun- suans in government, who will dedicate themselves to serving the people well.
Ma made the remarks at a Sun Yun-suan Foundation ceremony at which two outstanding public functionaries were each awarded NT$1 million and plaque in recognition of their outstanding contributions.

This is the 15th year the foundation has honored outstanding public functionaries in the spirit of the former premier who many said missed the chance to become president or vice president of the Republic of China due to a stroke. Sun passed away in 2006 at the age of 93.
Calling the award winners "Little Sun Yun-suans, " Ma said they are clean, competent and amicable officials who can help speed up the progress of the country.
Noting that some of the previous 41 winners have become ministers, Ma said the award is not merely an incentive but an indicator that the winners have great prospects.
Public authority in the hands of government officials is a double-edged sword that can cut both ways -- it can promote national development, but it can also hurt the people, the president said.

Reiterating his favorite quote that power corrupts, Ma said an official could make a decision that he or she would regret for the rest of his/her life and that an inadvertent decision could cause the nation's institutions to collapse and could deeply disappoint the people.
This year's awards went to a railway engineering department executive and a local hospital deputy manager.
Wu Sheng-yuan, director of the Department of Southern Taiwan Engineering Projects under the Ministry of Communications and Transportation, has been in charge of many projects in Taipei and elsewhere.

Wu has worked for more than 20 years on a Taiwan Railway project in Sungshan, Taipei and a major project to integrate railway, high-speed rail, mass rapid transit systems and a highway system into a transportation hub.
The other winner, Deputy Director Lee Hsin-min of the Yuli Hospital in Hualien County, earned the prize because of his dedication to improving health care for mentally ill patients.

The hospital, under his management, has treated 2,555 mentally ill patients from 25 counties and cities around the island, and has helped other medical institutions to handle emergency cases involving such patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Home devices for the disabled featured in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 22:01:47 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: For the first time in Taiwan, an exhibition that featured specially designed home facilities for the disabled is being held in Taipei.

On display are hundreds of devices that can be used at home to help the disabled manage their daily lives more independently, according to the real estate agency Evertrust Rehouse Co., that organized the event.

One of the inventions, a hoist, enables wheelchair users to get up and down stairs by themselves. Another one is a computer controller with an eyeball detector that allows the disabled to select items on the screen simply by staring at them.
"If the disabled can take care of themselves independently, they will feel more confident and more valuable, " said Sleeve Yu, a disabled woman who was invited to speak at the event.

Yu was a travel agency employee and a part-time model before she was diagnosed with a mysterious disease in 1998 that rendered her unable to walk. She said she spent a year and a half crying at home but finally came to realize the importance of learning to deal with her disability.
Yu said she was pleased to see that many people were willing to come forward with creative ideas like those on display at the fair, which would make life more convenient for the disabled.
"Sometimes it is just a small and simple idea, but it is what we most need," she added.
The fair is being held December 16-19 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

As of the end of September there were 1.07 million disabled people in Taiwan, representing 4.6 percent of the country's total population, according to figures on website of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure was an increase of about 10,000 year-on-year, the DGBAS site said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crying kid finishes 42-km marathon run in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 22:42:48 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A six-year-old boy started to cry in mid-way through a marathon race in Taipei Sunday, telling reporters at the finishing line that "it was no fun, because it was too far."
The child, surnamed Wu, caught media attention as he ran with adult runners all around him.
As he passed the mid-way point, he suddenly cried out loud because of pain in his knees. However, he stayed on course to finish the 42.195-km run, winning big hands from the crowd.
Though he said it was "no fun," he nodded his head in response to a media question if he would attend the race again next year.
The boy's brilliant performance drew mixed comments from experts, with a majority of them saying it was not fit for a child to run a marathon because it would affect his physical development.

Wang Ching-cheng, secretary general of the Chinese Taipei Track and Field Association, said though the boy's tough will is laudable, "from my professional point of view, I think 15 years of age would be a better time to start marathon run."
Chen Heng-hua, secretary general of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association which sponsored the Fubon Marathon Run 2010, agreed that marathon was not good for six-year-olds.
Chen said he does not encourage kids to run for the prize money. Wu, who loves to run just for fun, has actually passed the 9-km and 21-km tests before joining the 42-km race, he stressed.
Wang Yu-min, chief executive director of the Child Welfare League Foundation, urged parents to get a grasp of their kids' physical limits and watch out for possible sports injuries.
"If a child shows pains or feels unwell during a long run, parents should not allow him to finish the whole race; rather, he should be given enough time to take a break," Wang said.

As usual, the championships of the Taipei marathon race went to foreign runners. Kenya's Yusuf Chango Chebii Songoka clocked 2:14: 04 to win the top prize in men's division and the top woman runner was Yeshi Esayias Tesemma of Ethiopia, who finished the race with 2:30:37, 32 seconds more than her own record last year.
Tesemma thus missed a chance to win NT$1.5 million in "record breaking prize" and settled for the NT$1 million champion award.

The best local runners are Wu Wen-chien, whose 2:26:00 record won him the 8th place, which gave him NT$30,000 plus NT$200,000 as "Taiwan champion;" and Hsu Yu-fang, who was also placed the 8th, in women's division, with 2:54:32.

A whopping 31,000 people registered to join the race, including 1500 foreigners from 47 countries. If the participants of the 3-km amateur run are counted, a total of 110,000 people joined in Sunday's round the city run. enditem nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County extends child birth subsidy for another year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 15:08:45 (By Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government has decided to extend its child birth subsidy for another year as the policy has proved effective in boosting the birth rate in the county.

Married Changhua residents and single women over the age of 20 are eligible to apply for the subsidy, once one of the baby's parents has household registration in the county and has lived there for more than a year. It is required that the newborn be registered in Changhua as well. The subsidy, which will continue in 2011, is NT$10, 000 (US$335) per newborn.
The number of newborns in the county increased by 99 year-on-year after the government extended the subsidies from low-income families to all residents in 2009, statistics showed.
In 2008, the number of babies born in the county was 12,146.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar appreciates at higher rate than Korean won
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 15:43:11 (By Kao Chao-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan currency closed at NT$30.51 against the U.S. dollar Friday, ending the week with a 0.25 percent gain against the greenback.
The New Taiwan dollar has appreciated 4.98 percent so far this year, far higher than the Korean won which rose only 0.99 percent against the U.S. currency.

Most Asian currencies have risen in value against the U.S. dollar so far this year, led by the Thai baht which has appreciated 10.97 percent, the Japanese yen 10.78 percent and the Malaysian ringgit 9.19 percent.
The New Taiwan is in fourth place, having gained 4.98 percent against the U.S. dollar.

Other Asian currencies that have risen include the Philippine peso in the fifth place with a 6.26 percent appreciation rate, followed by the Indonesian rupiah with 4.08 percent, the Indian rupee with 2.58 percent and the Chinese renminbi or yuan with 2.45 percent.
Reports of U.S. economic indicators turning upbeat have reduced the emerging economies' "defensive demand" for the U.S. greenback, leading to a depreciating trend last week for their currencies.

According to Bloomberg News, of the 10 Asian countries, only the New Taiwan dollar and the Russian ruble rose last week. The ruble ended the week up 0.8 percent at 30.637 against the U.S. dollar as of 5:00 p.m. Friday, Taipei time.
The NT dollar bucked the trend, rising against the greenback on the strength of stock market gains and the inflow of foreign capital, breaking the NT$29.8 mark at one point and closing at NT$30.51.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Korean SK eyeing Uni-President Lions' pitcher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 16:33:39 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A team in the Korea Baseball Organization (KBO) is eyeing Taiwanese pitcher Pan Wei-lun, as he is now free to join professional baseball teams abroad after playing professionally at home for over six years, according to a South Korean media report.
KBO East team SK has contacted Pan's team in Taiwan, Uni-President Lions, to inquire about the right-hander's contract, it was reported in Sports Chosun.
Pan has been playing with Uni-President Lions, one of the teams in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , for eight years.
SK is highly interested in recruiting Pan, but if the cost of trading him is too high, it could prove an obstacle, according to the reporter surnamed Park.

Although the transfer fee would be about NT$15.3 million (US$510,000), there is a good chance he would be traded to SK, as the team had not yet renewed the contracts of its two foreign players, Ken Kadokura and Gary Glover, Park said.
The deadline for SK to renew the two contracts is Dec. 31, Park said.

According to CPBL regulations, SK would have to pay Uni-President Lions a transfer fee of 2.5 times of Pan's current annual salary of NT$6.12 million and start Pan at an annual salary of 1.5 times his most recent pay with Uni- President Lions.

According to Park, an SK official in charge of business operations visited Taiwan last week and told the Korean media upon return that "there is room for Uni-President Lions to lower the transfer fee."
However, Uni-President Lions' President Chen Cheng-nan said that speculations on a lower transfer fee were groundless and the club would follow CPBL regulations on Pan's release.

Pan, 28, who has been with Uni-President Lions from 2003-2010, has been playing international games since he turned 14. He is currently the highest-paid local player in Taiwan, but has never joined a foreign team before.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recalls being labeled 'Red Guard' along with Lee Huan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:10:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday when he worked under then Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary General Lee Huan, both of them were branded as "Red Guards" because they were trying to push for major political reforms.
At a memorial for Lee, who died on Dec. 2 at the age of 93, Ma reflected on the days when the late KMT leader and government official was his boss.

Their main duties at the time were to prepare for the lifting of the martial law, to allow for the formation of political parties, and to replace a whole generation of National Assembly members, Ma recalled.

Because the last task would affect many senior politicians, Ma said, he and Lee were criticized and labeled "Red Guards." The name was drawn from the forces unleashed by Mao Zedong of China to purge his political enemies during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.
Ma praised Lee as having contributed greatly to the process of retiring senior members of the National Assembly, amending the Constitution and pushing through other political reforms.

Acting on a directive by then President Chiang Ching-kuo, Lee also worked to cultivate in particular Taiwan-born political talent, which was a major achievement that helped "build energy" for further development, Ma said.
"It is necessary to illustrate Lee 's important role in helping to achieve the Republic of China's transition to democracy," Ma said.
The president issued a special citation in honor of Lee, which was accepted by Lee Ching -chung, Lee's eldest son.
Lee was born in Hubei province, the Republic of China, on Sept. 24, 1917. In addition to his KMT party posts, he served as education minister and premier before retiring.
Honoring his wishes for no altars, public mourning, condolence committees, obituaries or funeral services, his children held a "non-funeral service" Sunday.

Although it was an informal gathering, it was attended by a number of prominent politicians, including Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Examination Yuan President John Kuan, KMT Honorary Chairmen Lien Chan and Wu Po-hsiung and New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes Taiwan will lead promotion of Chinese culture
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:18:43 (By Sunrise Huang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he hopes Taiwan will take the lead in the promotion of Chinese culture and the use of traditional Chinese characters amid a worldwide trend of learning Mandarin.
The president said he is committed to the preservation of traditional Chinese characters and expects Taiwan to play a leading role in this regard.

"I have always wanted to make school campuses more international and make Taiwan a global educational center in East Asia, " the president said at an Annual Conference of Teaching Chinese as a Second Language in Taipei.
Traditional Chinese characters are the essence of the culture and should be preserved and passed down to future generations, he said.
However, currently only 40 million people worldwide use traditional characters, while 1.3 billion use simplified Chinese, he said.
He said that China, which officially uses simplified Chinese, should push for reading ability in traditional Chinese even if it maintains simplified characters for writing.
The president also asked the Ministry of Education to encourage more universities to establish institutions or departments to train Chinese teachers.
About 450 people, including Chinese teaching professionals and students, attended the conference at Fujen Catholic University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low enrollment forcing academic departments to merge: educator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 17:49:10 (By Hsu Chih-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Academic department mergers at tertiary institutions in Taiwan will be unavoidable as the number of high school graduates continues to decline due to a steadily falling birth rate in the country, an educator said Sunday.
The merger trend is likely to escalate in about four to six years time, according to Victor W. Liu, chairman of the non-profit Higher Education Evaluation and Accreditation Council of Taiwan.
"Department mergers are expected to peak between 2015 and 2017 when Taiwanese children who were born in 1998 will be entering college," Liu said.
The number of babies born in 1998 was 60,000 fewer than the previous year, Liu said.
In addition to poor academic performance and lack of accreditation, Taiwan's low birth rate has been a major contributing factor to the low enrollment rate at colleges and universities, he said.
However, commercialization and globalization could help Taiwan's tertiary institutions to survive, he said.
For example, he said, further opening to international and Chinese students could help academic departments to remain operational, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice ministers to head cross-strait economic cooperation committee
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 18:15:28 (By Lin Shu-yuan and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An Economic Cooperation Committee (ECC) that Taiwan and China have been planning is expected to be formed soon, with a vice minister from each side acting as co- convener, officials said Sunday.

The officials, who asked not to be named, said the announcement will be made at the meeting between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), which will be held Monday to Wednesday in Taipei.
Taiwan's Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Francis Kuo-hsin Liang and China's Vice Minister of Commerce Jiang Zengwei are expected to jointly head the committee.
It will be formed in accordance with the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) that was signed by the chiefs of the SEF and ARATS in Chongqing, China in June.

The cross-strait ECC will be composed of seven panels that will deal respectively with commodities trade, service trade, financial services, intellectual property rights, economic cooperation, dispute settlement, and investment, the officials said.

The panels will be headed by government bureau or department executives. For instance, on the Taiwan side, the commodity trade panel will be headed by Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Bill Cho, while the IPR panel will be led by Wang Mei-hua, director-general of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Intellectual Property Office, according to the officials.
The heads of the panels will be called "conveners," while the ECC leaders will act as "general conveners" under the framework of the SEF and ARATS, the officials said.
The deputy heads of the SEF and ARATS will be named chairpersons of the ECC, the officials added.

SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his ARATS counterpart Chen Yunlin will meet for a sixth round of formal talks Monday. An advance team, led by ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, arrived in Taiwan Sunday to prepare for the Chiang-Chen talks.

Chiang and Chen are expected to sign a medical and health cooperation agreement and announce the formation of the ECC. The agreement will be the 15th signed between the two sides since 2008, when cross-strait relations saw marked improvement after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou on May 20.

With the approach of Jan.1, 2011 when an "early harvest" list of products will begin enjoying preferential tariffs under the ECFA, the ECC is seen as necessary to facilitate working-level talks on the implementation, interpretation and coordination of ECFA-related business.

Also, the ECC panels are expected to do the follow-up work on commodity trade, services trade, dispute settlement and investment protection, which means the two sides would want the committee to be in place before the end of 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese advance team arrives to prepare for cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 18:54:49 (By Charles Kang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A Chinese delegation arrived in Taiwan Sunday for preparatory talks ahead of a high-level meeting between Taiwan and China negotiators that is expected to result in a medical agreement.

Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is leading the advance team in the meeting with its Taiwanese counterpart, Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Upon arrival, Zheng was greeted by Kao at the Grand Hotel in Taipei, where the negotiations will take place.

The two sides discussed matters related to an investment protection accord and a medical and health-care cooperation pact. The medical pact is expected to be signed when the top-level negotiators from both sides meet Dec. 20-22.

ARATS President Chen Yunlin is expected to arrive in Taipei Monday for his sixth meeting with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung since 2008, when cross-Taiwan Strait relations began to warm up under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Asked why an investment deal will not be signed during the meeting, ARATS Vice President and Secretary-General Li Yafei said the negotiations only began in September and the agreement is not yet ready.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwanese makes ultra marathon history

TEXT.P: Tommy Yen-po Chen, an ultra marathon runner from Taiwan, placed second in a 100-kilometer ultra marathon race in the South Pole Saturday.
Chen finished in a time of 15:15:58, becoming the first Asian to ever complete the grueling race.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Chen, 24, fighting the freezing cold, frostbite and a sprained ankle, made history in the ultra marathon just three days after completing a 42-km marathon in the South Pole.
"I just want the whole world to know how brave Taiwan is," he said.

The Antarctic Ice Marathon presented a truly formidable and genuine Antarctic challenge, with underfoot conditions comprising snow and ice throughout, an average wind chill temperature of minus 20 degrees Celsius, and the possibility of strong Katabatic winds -- winds that blows down a slope because of gravity.
The climax of the marathon, the Antarctic 100-km ultra race, is reserved for only the toughest of endurance athletes.

Six athletes -- five men and one woman -- started the race, but one dropped out halfway through. Brazilian Bernardo Fonseca, 33, finished first in a time of 12: 41: 52, while the only female, 24-year-old Clare Apps of the United Kingdom, finished in third place in a time of 18:58:19.

Chen has won marathons in Japan and Canada and finished third in the 600 km Polar Challenge in 2008. He placed fourth in the 2009 Himalayan 160-km Stage Race and third in the 2010 North Pole Marathon.

He has set an Asian record of running the North and South Pole marathon within nine months of each other, and has become the first Taiwanese to carry the Republic of China's flag in the North and South Poles.
Chen's mentor, Pan Jui-keng, recalled that Chen was the only one that could withstand the rigors of helping to prepare Kevin Lin, another legendary Taiwanese athlete, for a polar ultra marathon.
Liberty Times:
The Antarctic Ice Marathon was first held in 2005. All the runners in the annual event this year were required to train on the precarious terrain for at least five days to acclimatize.
Having completed races in the North and South poles as well in the Himalayan region, Chen will head for Australia next March to take part in a 45-km run through the Blue Mountains.
Chen's parents usually worry about him whenever he is competing, but they know they cannot keep him at home.
Chen's father, Chen Pin, is a senior chiropractor. He is finding that his son's reputation is quickly catching up with his.

Chen's mother Lee Wan-ni said her son was raised by his grandmother in Yunlin, south-central Taiwan, where he lived until five years ago. He developed a love for nature and outdoor activities, Lee said.
"He used to cry a lot when he was a child, but his personality changed after he started training for marathons. He has become more adventurous and more independent," she said. (Dec. 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Crowds celebrate 99th anniversary of Alishan rail
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 20:30:45 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The only operational forest railway in Taiwan celebrated its 99th anniversary Sunday with the resumption of service on a segment of line that was damaged during a typhoon last year.
The Chiayi Forestry Area Administration hosted a party to mark the 99th anniversary of the Alishan Forest Railway, which began service on Dec. 25, 1912.
Railway enthusiasts and visitors flocked to Beimen Station, one of the stations along the main line of the unique narrow-gauge railway, in Chiayi City.

Service on the section between Beimen and Jhuci Township in Chiayi County has resumed, while the Zhushan and Divine Tree lines in the Alishan area have re- opened, said Hu Sing-Hwa, deputy minister of the Council of Agriculture.
The 71.4 km railway and three of its branch lines were badly damaged by Typhoon Morakot last August. The other line has been closed since a devastating earthquake in 1999.
The forest administration hopes to extend service to Fenchihu, one of the 15 stops on the route, by next March, Hu said.
The railway was constructed initially to transport wood from the mountains but is now used for recreational purposes, carrying passengers to the popular Alishan resort.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hope remains for a democratic China: Chinese dissident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 20:45:38 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Despite China's impressive economic boom in recent years, most people in the communist country are still yearning for democracy because no amount of wealth can satisfy people's hunger for basic freedom, said Chinese social activist and dissident Wang Dan on Sunday during a lecture in Taipei.

Wang, a leader during the 1989 Tiananmen Square student freedom movement, said while there are no visible indications that China is becoming democratic, he still has high hopes for its eventual democratization because the younger generation is becoming more aware of equality and human rights.

"I am optimistic about the future of China," Wang told a group of young social activists from Taiwan and Hong Kong. "Much of what we see in China now is nothing but a facade because the entire social structure is based on lies since that is the only way a post-authoritarian regime like China can sustain itself."

The fact that China has a huge exodus of talent each year means that many overseas Chinese understand that an economically advanced China without the protections of basic freedom and human dignity is simply not enough, he said.
"If you can sit down and really talk with a Chinese student, he will most likely tell you that he wants democracy," Wang said.

Wang was an initiator of the 1989 student protest in Beijing that was squelched by the Chinese army in a bloody crackdown. He was imprisoned and arrested several times for leading various democratic movements in China before his eventual exile to the U.S. in 1998.
He obtained a doctorate degree from Harvard University and now teaches Chinese history at National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu.
He told the audience Sunday that to be a social activist, one cannot be afraid of loneliness or failure.

"We can never predict the exact direction of the society, therefore, much of what we do as activists might not prevail as we would wish, but we must be prepared for failures, he said. "Knowing that you might not succeed should never prevent you from trying."
Wang also urged the young social activists to maintain a tight network with other like-minded groups "so that when the time comes, you will be able to move at a quick and synchronized pace."
