Luo said the cross-strait private-sector dialogue platform that the offices are aiming to set up will be completely different from a DPP think-tank and it will not be influenced by elections or people in high office.
One of its tasks will be to change the DPP's anti-China image -- the perception that the party has a closed-door policy toward China and refuses to engage with Beijing, Luo said.
It will also seek to lead the DPP toward closer engagements with China's civic society as means of better understanding the Chinese people and propagating the DPP's ideals, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Sun Yun-suans needed in government service: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 21:28:19 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday he hopes there will be many more Sun Yun- suans in government, who will dedicate themselves to serving the people well.
Ma made the remarks at a Sun Yun-suan Foundation ceremony at which two outstanding public functionaries were each awarded NT$1 million and plaque in recognition of their outstanding contributions.

This is the 15th year the foundation has honored outstanding public functionaries in the spirit of the former premier who many said missed the chance to become president or vice president of the Republic of China due to a stroke. Sun passed away in 2006 at the age of 93.
Calling the award winners "Little Sun Yun-suans, " Ma said they are clean, competent and amicable officials who can help speed up the progress of the country.
Noting that some of the previous 41 winners have become ministers, Ma said the award is not merely an incentive but an indicator that the winners have great prospects.
Public authority in the hands of government officials is a double-edged sword that can cut both ways -- it can promote national development, but it can also hurt the people, the president said.

Reiterating his favorite quote that power corrupts, Ma said an official could make a decision that he or she would regret for the rest of his/her life and that an inadvertent decision could cause the nation's institutions to collapse and could deeply disappoint the people.
This year's awards went to a railway engineering department executive and a local hospital deputy manager.
Wu Sheng-yuan, director of the Department of Southern Taiwan Engineering Projects under the Ministry of Communications and Transportation, has been in charge of many projects in Taipei and elsewhere.

Wu has worked for more than 20 years on a Taiwan Railway project in Sungshan, Taipei and a major project to integrate railway, high-speed rail, mass rapid transit systems and a highway system into a transportation hub.
The other winner, Deputy Director Lee Hsin-min of the Yuli Hospital in Hualien County, earned the prize because of his dedication to improving health care for mentally ill patients.

The hospital, under his management, has treated 2,555 mentally ill patients from 25 counties and cities around the island, and has helped other medical institutions to handle emergency cases involving such patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Home devices for the disabled featured in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 22:01:47 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: For the first time in Taiwan, an exhibition that featured specially designed home facilities for the disabled is being held in Taipei.

On display are hundreds of devices that can be used at home to help the disabled manage their daily lives more independently, according to the real estate agency Evertrust Rehouse Co., that organized the event.

One of the inventions, a hoist, enables wheelchair users to get up and down stairs by themselves. Another one is a computer controller with an eyeball detector that allows the disabled to select items on the screen simply by staring at them.
"If the disabled can take care of themselves independently, they will feel more confident and more valuable, " said Sleeve Yu, a disabled woman who was invited to speak at the event.

Yu was a travel agency employee and a part-time model before she was diagnosed with a mysterious disease in 1998 that rendered her unable to walk. She said she spent a year and a half crying at home but finally came to realize the importance of learning to deal with her disability.
Yu said she was pleased to see that many people were willing to come forward with creative ideas like those on display at the fair, which would make life more convenient for the disabled.
"Sometimes it is just a small and simple idea, but it is what we most need," she added.
The fair is being held December 16-19 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

As of the end of September there were 1.07 million disabled people in Taiwan, representing 4.6 percent of the country's total population, according to figures on website of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure was an increase of about 10,000 year-on-year, the DGBAS site said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crying kid finishes 42-km marathon run in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/10 22:42:48 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A six-year-old boy started to cry in mid-way through a marathon race in Taipei Sunday, telling reporters at the finishing line that "it was no fun, because it was too far."
The child, surnamed Wu, caught media attention as he ran with adult runners all around him.
As he passed the mid-way point, he suddenly cried out loud because of pain in his knees. However, he stayed on course to finish the 42.195-km run, winning big hands from the crowd.
Though he said it was "no fun," he nodded his head in response to a media question if he would attend the race again next year.
The boy's brilliant performance drew mixed comments from experts, with a majority of them saying it was not fit for a child to run a marathon because it would affect his physical development.

Wang Ching-cheng, secretary general of the Chinese Taipei Track and Field Association, said though the boy's tough will is laudable, "from my professional point of view, I think 15 years of age would be a better time to start marathon run."
Chen Heng-hua, secretary general of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association which sponsored the Fubon Marathon Run 2010, agreed that marathon was not good for six-year-olds.
Chen said he does not encourage kids to run for the prize money. Wu, who loves to run just for fun, has actually passed the 9-km and 21-km tests before joining the 42-km race, he stressed.
Wang Yu-min, chief executive director of the Child Welfare League Foundation, urged parents to get a grasp of their kids' physical limits and watch out for possible sports injuries.
"If a child shows pains or feels unwell during a long run, parents should not allow him to finish the whole race; rather, he should be given enough time to take a break," Wang said.

As usual, the championships of the Taipei marathon race went to foreign runners. Kenya's Yusuf Chango Chebii Songoka clocked 2:14: 04 to win the top prize in men's division and the top woman runner was Yeshi Esayias Tesemma of Ethiopia, who finished the race with 2:30:37, 32 seconds more than her own record last year.
Tesemma thus missed a chance to win NT$1.5 million in "record breaking prize" and settled for the NT$1 million champion award.

The best local runners are Wu Wen-chien, whose 2:26:00 record won him the 8th place, which gave him NT$30,000 plus NT$200,000 as "Taiwan champion;" and Hsu Yu-fang, who was also placed the 8th, in women's division, with 2:54:32.

A whopping 31,000 people registered to join the race, including 1500 foreigners from 47 countries. If the participants of the 3-km amateur run are counted, a total of 110,000 people joined in Sunday's round the city run. enditem nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 20, 2010, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven- member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier arrives in Burkina Faso
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/10 09:28:25 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

Wu is the first Taiwan premier to visit the West African ally since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994. The main purpose of the visit is to attend a ceremony on Dec. 20 for the inauguration of President Blaise Compaore for a new term.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's chief negotiator arrives in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 12:12:39 (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, arrived in Taipei Monday for his sixth meeting with his Taiwanese counterpart since 2008.

Chen, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will hold talks with Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung Tuesday and sign a cross-Taiwan Strait medical and healthcare cooperation agreement.
SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian and ARATS Vice Presideng Zheng Lizhong are scheduled to meet later Monday to put finishing touches to the proposed pact.
Chen will visit the Taipei International Flora Exposition before returning to China Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier proposes shooting film on Africa lamp project
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/10 13:07:37 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Wu Den-yih proposed Sunday that the many stories related to Taiwan's decades-long aid to foreign countries could be adapted for film, including the "A Lamp Lighting Up Africa" program that the country is promoting in Burkina Faso.

The films could be shown in 2011 as part of celebrations for the ROC's 100th founding anniversary, Wu said while hosting a dinner for Taiwanese diplomats and expatriates upon his arrival in the West African ally on a one-week visit.

The "A Lamp Lighting Up Africa" project, for example, could be adapted for a TV drama centered around a leading character who goes to Burkina Faso to carry out the work, blended with subject matter such as kinship and friendship, according to Wu.

The program is aimed at bringing electric light to the homes of disadvantaged Burkina Faso students, who are often forced to study on the streets at night by the light of street lamps because they do not have electric light at home.

Under the program, photovoltaic power-generating systems have been installed in participating schools and each student has been given an LED lighting kit equipped with a rechargeable battery that lasts four-and-a-half hours. The children can recharge their lamps at school and bring them home to use at night.

Wu is the first Taiwanese premier to visit the impoverished West African ally since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994. The main purpose of the visit is to attend the Dec. 20 inauguration of Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore for a new term.

During his stay, Wu will also host the completion ceremony for a Taiwan-funded vocational training center and visit a new hospital constructed with a loan from a Taiwanese bank. The hospital is scheduled to open in 2011.
Immediately after his arrival earlier in the day, Wu had brief discussions with Burkina Faso officials at the airport, in which he expressed hope that bilateral cooperation can be further enhanced.

According to Laurent Sedego, minister of agriculture of Burkina Faso, the rice output of his country has doubled thanks to the assistance of an agricultural technical mission from Taiwan. As a result of the assistance, the minister said, within two years the country will no longer be dependent on imported rice.

Wu is heading an 18-member delegation that includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang, Council of Labor Affairs Minister Wang Ju-hsuan, and Tao Wen- lung, secretary-general of the government-operated International Cooperation and Development Fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Trend Micro founders lead 700 engineers to break Guinness World Record

TEXT.P: In addition to constant innovation in cloud technology, Trend Micro always endeavors to boost employee morale, create a sense of belonging for its employees and encourage team spirit. And this is why Trend's three founders, chairman Steve Chang, chief executive officer Eva Chen, and chief culture officer Jenny Chang, got together at this year's event to cheer their employees up. Featuring various team games and discussions, the two-day engineering camp provided those dedicated IT professionals with a chance to relax and engage in interesting brainstorming and creative thinking. While learning to understand users' needs, participants also developed team spirit and a sense of belonging through each designed activity.

The event reached its climax as three founders and over 700 employees broke the Guinness World Record for the longest mouse trap queue.Trend Micro is big warm family. We are thrilled to see our collaborative effort has made history,Eva Chen said.Creating a pleasant work environment is a commitment we make to our employees so that they can express their creativity openly and innovate freely. The idea of the engineering camp is to make employee training fun and educational. We ask our engineers to put aside their work to learn some soft skills, which are more important and proved to be beneficial to their work later.

As Trend Micro chief culture officer, Jenny Chang spares no effort to enhance and develop the company's culture.One of team games called the balloon tower made a quite an impression on me. While everyone worked as a team to build a tower with eighty balloons and an 80-centimeter long tape, they would learn the skill of balancing groundwork and performance at work and realize how to produce the best result with cross team effort. I believe each Trender benefited greatly from the camp activities. When they are back to work, they will be able to take much broader view of what consumers want and pay attention to details of their work and collaboration. Our great employees are the backbone of our company and we are very confident about setting more world records in the future,Chang said. ###

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: A long-overdue prom

TEXT.P: Two of Taiwan's most prestigious senior high schools -- Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School and Taipei First Girls High School -- jointly held a prom last Saturday as part of celebrations for the girls school's 107th anniversary.

The event was considered groundbreaking given the conservative culture of Taiwan's schools. In the past, male and female students would be punished even for talking to each other, not to mention attending a prom together.

In the Western world, people are taught since they are little how to interact with the opposite sex, with school dances being part of the tradition. Furthermore, boys and girls are allowed to study together from elementary school to university, and in universities, male and female students even share dormitory buildings.
By comparison, there are still many girls-only or boys-only schools in Taiwan, and many restrictions are imposed on students' hairstyles and the way they dress.

At the joint prom two days ago, the boys and girls were shy and awkward while dancing together, a scene made worse by their wearing school uniforms and ugly hairstyles. This shows how unsuccessful our gender education is.
The team-up between the two top schools also reflects the strange concept of class, which is derived from the outdated notion that marriage partners must be from households of equal social standing.

We hope that high school students will be given full freedom to dance and wear the clothes and hairstyles they want in the future, breaking the boundaries between schools. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China set to sign health-care pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 16:19:34 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are set to sign a medical and health-care cooperation agreement during the sixth meeting since 2008 between top negotiators of the two sides slated for Dec. 20-22 in Taipei.

China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , arrived in Taipei Monday to a warm welcome from his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Addressing a welcoming party at Chen's hotel, Chiang said that the two intermediary bodies have been instrumental in concluding 14 cross-strait agreements over the past two years, which have begun to yield dividends.

The landmark cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed in June has contributed to improving Taiwan's investment climate, prompting investments in the private sector to surge by 32 percent year-on-year and the country's foreign trade to exceed US$500 billion this year, an all-time record, Chiang said.
As a result, he went on, Taiwan's economic growth is expected to top nearly 10 percent this year.

He said the SEF and ARATS have agreed to ink a cross-strait medical and health- care cooperation agreement Dec. 21 that will not only help boost health of the people on the two sides but will also benefit the development of related industries.
For his part, Chen said China attaches great importance to the cross-strait health-care agreement, which reflects the two intermediary bodies' values and concern about humanity.

He said it is regrettable that an investment protection agreement that has been talked about since 1993 cannot be concluded in this round of talks, even though "we (China) have maintained a positive and supportive attitude toward the signing of such a pact."

In addition to the signing of the medical and health-care cooperation agreement, the SEF and ARATS negotiators will also exchange views on the much-talked-about cross-strait investment protection pact over the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taipei City announces names for key positions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 16:38:49 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: New Taipei City Mayor-elect Eric Liluan Chu announced Monday that former national police chief Hou Yu-ih will be one of his deputies, saying that the appointment is part of the administration's resolve to ensure public safety.

The announcement was made six days before Chu is to be inaugurated as the first mayor of Xinbei City, which the new administration has decided shall henceforth be known in English as "New Taipei City, " an area that will be formally upgraded from a county into a special municipality Dec. 25.

"Public safety is a foremost concern of the residents, and Hou's appointment is a clear indication that the mayor is determined to maintain social order in the city, " said Lin Chieh-yu, the team's spokesman.

Hou is a highly decorated and respected police officer who shot to fame for his involvement in many high-profile cases, including the kidnapping and murder of a famous entertainer's daughter and the capture of several of Taiwan's most notorious criminals.

In 2006, he was the youngest person in history to assume the position as director-general of the National Policy Agency, which was followed by his appointment as the head of the Central Police University in 2008.
The slots for the other two deputy mayor positions will be filled by Taipei County Deputy Magistrate Lee Shu-chuan and Deputy Finance Minister Hsu Chih- chien.
Former Water Resources Agency Director-General Chen Shen-hsien has been named as the city government's secretary-general.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sedan rams students on campus before driver sets himself on fire
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 17:13:12 (By Sunrise Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A car driver set himself on fire Monday after steering his vehicle onto the campus of an elementary school in Banciao, Taipei County Monday, running over four students before stopping.
The driver and one student stuck under the vehicle were pulled free, while teachers, school guards and parents of the students managed to extinguish the blaze at the Puchien Elementary School.
The driver, identified only by his surname of Wu, and the students who were injured during the alleged suicide attempt, were rushed to nearby hospitals.
Officials at Far Eastern Memorial Hospital, where Wu was taken, said his head, face and hands were badly burned and that he remained in critical condition.
Meanwhile, doctors at the Banciao branch of Taipei County Hospital treating the students who were rammed by Wu, said all suffered wounds to the head and chest, none of which were life-threatening.
Police said they discovered four barrels of gasoline in the car, one of which was half-empty. Police guessed the driver had poured the gas on himself before attempting the self-immolation.
Police also found NT$100,000 and clothing in the vehicle and were continuing to investigate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan forum focuses on disputed Tiaoyutais
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 17:29:58 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Officials and scholars from Taiwan and Japan focused on the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands at an annual bilateral forum on Monday and could agree on only one thing: more discussion is needed on the issue.

In his opening remarks at the one-day 2010 Taiwan-Japan Forum, Vice President Vincent Siew said Taiwan and Japan shared common interests in the maritime sovereignty dispute and in many other areas and urged both sides to cooperate to create a win-win situation.

Speakers from Taiwan expressed considerable interest in the controversial issue, which resurfaced after a Chinese boat collided with Japanese Coast Guard vessels in September in waters off the Tiaoyutais, stirring up a diplomatic row between Tokyo and Beijing.

The islands, which lie about 100 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern tip, are claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan and could have an impact on Japan-China relations and Japan-Taiwan relations at the same time, said Bau Tzong-ho, a political scientist at National Taiwan University.

Because China claims sovereignty over the islands through Taiwan -- which it says it a part of China -- Japan's national interests would be well served if it set aside the sovereignty dispute and negotiated an agreement on fishing in the islands' waters, Bau contended.
"That would deny China an excuse to intervene in the issue, " he argued.

The Tiaoyutais dispute could be the most important issue dividing Japan and Taiwan, said Nobuo Kishi, a member of the House of Councilors in the Diet (Japanese Congress) , but he agreed that handling it as a fisheries dispute could lead to negotiations with Taiwan in the future.
In contrast, it appeared that the Tiaoyutais had become a more intractable territorial dispute between Japan and China, said Kishi, a member of the main opposition Liberal Democratic Party.

House of Councilors member Naoki Kazama of the ruling Democratic Party of Japan said that while Taiwan and China both claim sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais, Japan found that it was easier to talk to Taiwan about the issue.

Yang Yung-ming, a political scientist at National Taiwan University who has served as a National Security Council adviser, proposed an "East China Sea Initiative" that called for all countries involved to pledge to handle the issue through peaceful dialogue.

Yang said China's recent tendency to solve disputes using economic measures -- such as banning rare earth exports to Japan -- posed concerns that it could resort to the same approach in dealing with Taiwan in the future, despite warming cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

Joe Hung, Taiwan's former representative to Italy, suggested that the dispute be solved through Four Party Talks that include the three Tiaoyutai claimants -- Taiwan, China and Japan -- as well as the United States as a mediator.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pay hikes expected in 1st half of 2011: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 18:29:33 (By Justin Su and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: People will begin to see increases in both their pay checks and overall social consumption in the first half of 2011, as Taiwan will likely register a 5 percent annual growth rate, a senior official said Monday.
Christina Liu, minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks as "unfelt economic growth" has been a hot issue in Taiwan for quite some time.
Fielding questions from lawmakers at a legislative committee meeting, Liu said it is taking some time for the general public to feel the benefits of the recent economic growth.

Lee Ching-hua, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator, asked how she is helping to solve the problem of the middle class not being able to enjoy the benefits of the economic growth, as the media has reported that the monthly pay of 3.6 million people is less than NT$30,000 (US$1,002) and that of another 1 million people is below NT$20,000.

Lee quoted some media outlets as predicting that Taiwan will see a gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 4.5 percent next year, and yet only a minority of the public will benefit from this expansion.

In response, Liu said that change can only come from the overall structure of the economy, as Taiwan has in the past relied heavily on exports for its economic growth. As Taiwan's major businesses have moved their production bases abroad, she noted, the real benefits of the increase in the GDP output cannot be felt by the workforce at home.
Liu said the CEPD will try to design a strategy during the first half of the coming year to increase local workers' incomes and balance economic activities in the region.

Under what she described as a policy of creating more jobs by setting up new businesses that is expected to be finalized next June, the government will promote industry around the country so that the fruits of the economic growth can be enjoyed by all the people.

Lee asked if she was as upbeat as some forecasters who say Taiwan's economy might grow by 5 percent next year -- 0.5 percentage points higher than the "mainstream" observers are forecasting, Liu said that "certainly it is likely, as long as we work hard enough."

In a similar vein, Legislator Huang Wei-che of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked how the CEPD is attempting to solve the problem of grass-roots people being left out of the economic growth trend as Taiwan's average wages and salaries rise to a new high and yet the wealth gap is also widening.
KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih pointed out that those whose monthly income falls short of NT$30,000 account for 33 percent of the workforce.

"This is a very serious problem for the national economy. It means economic depression and grass-roots pain. The seriousness is even more striking if those in the public sector payrolls are counted out," Wu said.

Liu said it is meaningless to talk about the average income, as high income earners inflate the figure. She said she would ask government statisticians to provide the average incomes of the top 50 percent and the bottom 50 percent, which, when compared to the total number of people in both income groups, will shed new light on the actual distribution of income.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 18:33:18 (By Hanna Liu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, gaining NT$0.091 to close at NT$30.601.
Turnover totaled US$626 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.610 and moved between NT$29.831 and NT$30.615 before the close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Property magnate to build medical center in hometown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 18:43:13 (By Kuan Jui-ping and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The founder and chairman of the Farglory Group, one of Taiwan's major property development and construction companies, promised Monday to donate NT$10 billion (US$333.33 million) to develop a medical and health-care park in his hometown in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan.

Chao Teng-hsiung, born in Miaoli's coastal township of Houlong into a poor family and who began to serve his apprenticeship as a plasterer aged 15, told Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung that he will make sure the health-care park is developed in Houlong to help Miaoli residents have access to better medical attention.

Construction of the park -- which will feature a 685-bed hospital, a nursing home, a biotechnology research and development center and a cancer research center -- is expected to start in the latter half of 2011 and to become operational in three years, Chao said.
Chao, whose assets exceed NT$200 billion, made the vow during a tea party at the Miaoli Dome Gym to mark the fifth anniversary of Liu becoming magistrate.
The self-made property magnate lauded Liu's administrative team, which has worked to shorten the administrative procedure of the health-care park development project to two years from five years.
In comparison, he said, his group's plan for building a Taipei dome gym has lain stagnant for over a decade with no date in sight for the project to start.
"It is not easy for business corporations to contribute to society because of Taiwan's political and administrative climate," he said.

Despite that, Chao went on, he is determined to build the medical center and health-care park, as around 47,000 Miaoli patients have to travel to the big cities in northern or southern Taiwan for medical treatment, many of whom die while on the road.

About 37,000 of the total check into bigger hospitals in other cities and counties each year, staying for an average of seven days for treatment, prompting him to make the decision to set up the health-care park, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait agreements offer little protection to Taiwan: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 18:48:37 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Ongoing talks with China have been of little benefit to Taiwan, and agreements reached to protect Taiwan's interests have gone mostly ignored, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) charged on Monday ahead of the latest round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said that after five rounds of talks between the heads of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) that began in June 2008, little has been done to protect China-based Taiwanese investors or the general welfare of Taiwanese citizens.

"Out of the 14 agreements signed, many were merely empty contracts because they have not been properly implemented. It is even more regrettable that several key issues have not been discussed at all," Cheng said.

One example he cited was the agreement on direct cross-strait flights. Though the pact mentioned "beyond rights" of Taiwanese and Chinese airlines -- the right to carry passengers from a second country on to other countries -- the issue had yet to be explored further, he said.
Cheng said "beyond rights" should be treated as high priority because they are closely linked to the profitability of Taiwan's airline industry and the convenience of the public.
Another unfulfilled promise was Beijing's inaction on compensating the victims of China-produced tainted milk powder, he added.

Cheng also said that during the last cross-strait talks held in Taiwan -- in Taichung City in December 2009 -- the sides failed to sign an agreement on investment protection, a crucial issue for China-based Taiwanese businessmen and investors, and it was unlikely that the agreement would be forged this time as well.

According to Cheng, the agreement has yet to be concluded because China refuses to negotiate further on the issue unless Taiwan agrees to offer the concession of widening its market to Chinese investment.

"Clearly, the Beijing government is setting up a trap by using the investment protection agreement as a bargaining chip. It is a pity that President Ma Ying- jeou's government does not have a counter-strategy against China's ploy," he said.

ARATS head Chen Yunlin arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport around noon on Monday for a three-day visit that will include the sixth round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung.
Many pro-independence groups have vowed to protest Chen's visit around the clock by setting up various demonstrations in Taipei in the next 72 hours.

A group of over 70 protesters gathered at the National Palace Museum Monday afternoon to oppose Chen's visit and called on Beijing to release Chinese social activist and Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo.
Compared however to the violent street clashes that took place in November 2008 when Chen arrived in Taiwan for the first time, the protests have been relatively level-headed so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC's chairman touts company as `Toyota car'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 19:10:20 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , the world's largest contract chip maker, will likely have better prospects than its U.S. rival, Intel Corp., on the back of a wider usage of TSMC products, Chairman Morris Chang said Monday.

The popularization of notebooks, netbooks and smartphones has generated huge demand for TSMC's IC chips, while Intel's efforts in micro-processors make it more attractive for high-end clients, said Chang in a speech at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.
"TSMC can be likened to a Toyota car with popularized technology and great client demand, while Intel is more like a Mercedes-Benz that is aimed at a smaller, high-end market," he said.

The annual expenditure on research and development for the Hsinchu-based chipmaker, totaled NT$36 billion (US$1.2 billion) in 2010, exceeding the total budget of Taiwan's semi-official Industrial Technology Research Institute, and Chang said the figure will grow to more than NT$50 billion next year, trailing only behind Intel in the global semiconductor R&D sector.

"This is because Intel includes both process technology and design business, while TSMC is devoted to process technology only, " said Chang, adding that TSMC's R&D expenditure would surpass that of Intel if the R&D spending of its IC design partners were included.

Chang said that TSMC, with leading global shipments of logic ICs, has become one of the world's top three semiconductor manufacturers along with Intel and the world's No. 1 memory chip maker in terms of capital expenditure and shipments, Samsung Electronics Co.
TSMC recorded its capital expenditure of NT$180 billion this year, ranking in second place behind Samsung in the global market.
Regarding the company's market value, Chang said TSMC is now worth NT$1.9 trillion, representing the highest value of any single company in Taiwan.

When asked about the rising appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, Chang told reporters that while he appreciates the efforts made by the government, it is having a hard time fighting the appreciation and has been less successful than previously hoped.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo case ruling to be revealed Wednesday at earliest
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 19:34:09 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun will not find out her fate in a case involving her disqualification at the Asian Games until Dec. 22 at the earliest, a World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) spokesman said Monday.

WTF public relations director Kang Seok-jae told the Central News Agency that the WTF would inform the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) of the decision via e-mail first and then send it the ruling via express airmail.

The WTF's disciplinary committee met Saturday to hear the case related to Yang's disqualification at the Asian Games on Nov. 17, and according to Kang, the committee's members delivered their sealed conclusions to the WTF Secretariat after the meeting.
But they did not have the authority to publicize the ruling, which still needed to be approved by WTF President Chungwon Choue before becoming official, Kang said.

The committee, formed by Egyptian, Israel and Turkish officials, reviewed Yang's disqualification in her opening bout in the women's under 49 kg division at the Asiad and Yang's ensuing protest, which could lead to her being suspended from competition.

WTF officials claimed Yang violated the rules by wearing extra electronic sensors on her socks during the bout to score more points, but video footage later showed she did not have the sensors on against her opponent.
A stunned Yang refused to leave the ring after the decision, and the contradictory statements of taekwondo officials in explaining the disqualification sparked outrage in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Christmas lights not affecting electricity supply
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 19:40:38 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Christmas light displays around Taiwan are not putting a burden on the country's electricity supply because many use energy-saving LED lights and are operating at a time when demand for power is not at its peak, the state-run Taiwan Power Co. said Monday.
"Christmas light bulbs are consuming relatively small amounts of power. There is no problem with the electricity supply," Taiwan Power spokeswoman Tu Yueh-yuan told the Central News Agency.

Christmas light decorations have come under fire from environmentalists, with groups in Hong Kong saying that lighting decorations on the walls of buildings in the Victoria Harbor area consumed enough electricity to run 330 four-person households for a year.

Tu dismissed such concerns. She said Taiwan had seen record use of electricity over the summer due to a surge in the use of air conditioners to combat the heat, but that was not an issue during the winter.
Many shopping malls and local governments in Taiwan have put up colored lights on the street or on Christmas trees to mark the arrival of the Christmas season.

Citibank Taiwan, for example, worked with the Taipei City government and the Finland Trade Center, a Taipei-based foreign trade office, to install blue lights covering trees and overpasses in a 400-meter section of the Xinyi shopping district in Taipei on Dec. 18.

The Tainan County government has also installed eight long lines of "light dots" on the square in front of the county government office building, with trees on either side of the square also decorated with lights.
More such celebrations are expected as Christmas approaches.

Administration officials in the Tri-Mountain National Scenic Area in central Taiwan's Taichung County plan to decorate a 20-meter-tall cedar with 90 13 -meter-long LED lights in front of the Lishan Guesthouse on Dec. 24.

The tree, located at an altitude of 2,000 meters above sea level, will become one of Taiwan's highest altitude Christmas trees, along with one at 2,116 meters above sea level on Alishan in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls for Japan-Taiwan free trade agreement
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 19:47:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew called Monday for a Japan-Taiwan free trade agreement (FTA) and closer cooperation between the small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) of the two countries, saying the moves would serve both sides' interests.

"I think the time is ripe for Japan and Taiwan to negotiate an FTA, and I hope Japan will seriously consider the issue, " Siew said in his opening remarks at the 2010 Taiwan-Japan Forum, citing the signing of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China in June and more recent interest in an FTA with Singapore.

Private sector cooperation also has enormous potential, Siew said, because Japanese businesses have long been known for their advanced technology and Taiwanese enterprises excel in manufacturing and exploring new markets.

Siew noted that Japan was Taiwan's second largest trade partner and its largest source of imports in 2009 as two-way trade reached US$50.7 billion and Taiwan's imports from Japan were worth US$36.2 billion.

Yoshio Okawara, a consultant of the Institute for International Policy Studies, agreed that a Japan-Taiwan coalition would be the best way for both countries to tackle East Asia's fast-changing economic climate.

But the former Japanese ambassador to the United States and Australia also warned that the emergence of the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) -- a multilateral free trade agreement that aims to integrate the economies of the Asia-Pacific region -- could create a new economic dynamic in the region.

Scholars and officials also took time at the one-day forum to review the security front in East Asia and addressed the threat of North Korea and a rising China. The U.S.-Japan security pact, they agreed, was one of the pillars of East Asian security.

House of Councilors member Naoki Kazama of the ruling Democratic Party of Japan said Japan welcomed reduced tensions between Taiwan and China but had concerns over a Taiwan-China coalition at the same time.
A Taiwan-China coalition would mean that the East China Sea and the South China Sea could literally become China's "inland waters, " Kazama said.

The scenario would make it impossible for Japan to stop the Chinese Navy from projecting its power to the Pacific Ocean because Taiwan is an integral part of the "First Island Chain, " which is formed by the Aleutians, the Kuriles, Japan, the Ryukyus, Taiwan, the Philippines, and Borneo.

Japan, as one of the major powers in East Asia, could also be crucial to Taiwan in lending its support for Taiwan's participation in the international community, said Bau Tzong-ho, a political scientist at National Taiwan University.
"An isolated Taiwan and the discontent of the people of Taiwan would be detrimental to East Asian stability and does not serve Japan's national interests, " Bau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No `China fever' within party : DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 20:07:46 (By Wen Kuei-haiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that there is no "China fever" within the party and that it will try to face China soberly and calmly.

Cheng Wen-tsang, a spokesman of the party that has long advocated Taiwan independence, was rebutting a new report that "a China fever has been arising within the DPP" after DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen decided to establish a party think tank for research mainly on how the party should engage with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.
"We will face China calmly, in stark contrast to the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), which has been `embracing China' enthusiastically," Cheng added.

He said that although the DPP will not exclude the possibility of dialogue with China, such talks can take place only when the sovereignty of Taiwan and the values of democracy and human rights are fully safeguarded.

After becoming operational, the think tank will work out proposals concerning the DPP's China policy, including exchanges between the governments, civic groups, think tanks and cultural organizations on the two sides of the strait.
"In this way, we (the DPP) will not establish an exclusive DPP-Communist Party of China (CPC) communication platform such as the one between the KMT and the CPC," Cheng added.
Another DPP spokesman, Tsai Chi-chang, said that Tsai Ing-wen has unveiled four principles in the DPP's China strategy:

-- The relationship between China and Taiwan must be mutually beneficial rather than mutually discriminatory, must be peaceful rather than based on conflict, and must be built on an equal footing rather than on a superior-subordinate basis;

-- The DPP will insist on democracy and demand that the formation and implementation of all China policies must follow democratic procedures and that important issues must be decided by the people through referendum; and
-- The DPP will insist on the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights, which make Taiwan totally different from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Expo Taiwan Pavilion making way back to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 20:15:29 (By Claudia Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The first batch of containers carrying parts of Taiwan's Shanghai World Expo pavilion arrived in the northern Taiwan harbor of Keelung on Monday to a warm welcome from a group of officials and shippers.

Shaped like a sky lantern, the Taiwan Pavilion was one of the most visited exhibits at the Shanghai Expo, which concluded on Oct. 31, and it was later sold to the Hsinchu City government for NT$500 million (US$16.66 million).
The Hsinchu City government will have the pavilion reassembled before opening it to the public in October 2011.

Other containers carrying the pavilion's parts are expected to be shipped back to Taiwan in three batches before the end of January 2011, according to Frank F.H. Lu, chairman of Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., the company shipping the pavilion back to Taiwan.

Hsinchu City Mayor Hsu Ming-tsai, who was on hand when the first group of containers arrived, said Hsinchu City is welcoming the Taiwan Pavilion home in the same spirit as it would a new daughter-in-law.

Taiwan Pavilion manager Walter Yeh said the pavilion, which features Taiwan's natural landscape and culture, received 750,000 visits during the Shanghai Expo's 184-day run, and it will now be one of the few national pavilions at the Expo to return to its home country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Do not rely on Central Bank to stop currency appreciation: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 20:27:15 (By Justin Su, Lin Hui-chun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A senior government official advised the nation's businesses Monday not to rely on the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) to fight currency appreciation.
Instead, the official said, they should diversify their export markets away from the United States.

Christina Liu, minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks in response to lawmakers' questions at a legislative committee meeting concerning the impact of the local currency's recent rise in value against the U.S. dollar.

As the exchange rate of Taiwan's currency against the greenback broke through the NT$30 barrier again in mid-session that day, lawmakers asked Liu how the CEPD can help Taiwan's exporters -- major contributors to Taiwan's economy -- who have been complaining about their profits being eaten up by the NT dollar's appreciation against the U.S. unit.

The economist-turned-minister suggested that exporters use some hedging tools that are available on the financial market, rather than looking at the central bank for help to stop currency fluctuation.

If the long-term prospects for the NT dollar is continued appreciation, she said, Taiwan's export industry should no longer concentrate on the U.S. market but "rather, should increase their shares of non-U.S. markets and divert export orders away from the U.S.," adopting the "basket of currencies" model.
Liu also advised local businesses to cut orders from Europe and look at the emerging economies in Asia and elsewhere.

On the propriety of the central bank's policy of "following market principles" in dealing with the currency issue, Liu said that if the market is releasing U.S. dollars and the bank wants to buy them, it must spend New Taiwan dollars, which drives up consumer prices.
This, she pointed out, puts the central bank in a predicament in which it can either allow the currency to rise or face the pressure of increasing consumer prices.
Fortunately, Liu pointed out, the pressure on consumer prices is manageable at the moment, so that the bank can afford to pay the price of stopping the NT dollar from rising too much.
Still, she went on, "we must let the people know that the central bank is paying a price for stopping the NT dollar's appreciation, " a price that eventually will be shared by all tax payers.

Turning to the brilliant performance of Taiwan's economy this year -- which could surge past the 10-percent mark -- and the fact that many people are still unable to discern any improvement, much less enjoy a "share" of the benefits, Liu said she hopes that next year, everyone will be able to feel what it means to have a 10 percent growth in the economy.
She said she expects a majority of the people to see the double-digit growth increasing their incomes, thereby giving an impetus to domestic consumption.
Between 1990 and 2000, Taiwan was leading the pack of Asia's "four dragons" in terms of consumption and investment growth. "Now we are on track to return to that glory," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired student awarded for being enthusiastic reader
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 20:38:42 (By Lin Tzu-yu and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A blind girl from Taichung who loves to read was honored Monday by the Ministry of Education as one of Taiwan's most avid visually impaired readers.
Second-grader Yang Tzu-ling, who read 72 books in two months, received the award for winning the elementary school division of a national reading contest for visually impaired students.
The contest was part of a program launched in September that was the first ever in Taiwan to encourage more visually impaired students to read. More than 200 students participated in the event.

Yang's mother said she used to read to her daughter and her twin brother -- whose eyesight is normal -- every day when they were small because she did not want her daughter to feel she was different from other children.
She even made Braille books by herself to give her daughter more of an opportunity to read.
Yang said she reads books after 4 p.m. every day, mostly picture and audio books.

Eighth-grader Lu Yi-chen, who won a writing contest for an essay she wrote after reading a book, thanked her father at the ceremony for "being her eyes and leading her through the darkness." Lu's father died of liver cancer last year.
A total of 13 students who won either reading or writing contests received awards from Administrative Deputy Education Minister Wu Tsai-shung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Benefits of economic progress to be more obvious in 2011: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 21:51:30 (By Lee Shu-hua and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: More people will experience the benefits of Taiwan's economic growth next year as Taiwan's trade value is expected to hit a new high in 2011, President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.

Taiwan's export-driven economy heavily relies on external trade, and with total trade expected to surpass US$500 billion this year, domestic industries are poised to boom, the president said at a meeting with members of the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International at the Presidential Office.
"I believe spending will pick up next year, " Ma said. "In other words, most of the public will see the benefits of economic expansion."
The president also forecast that Taiwan's national income per capita would increase to US$20,000 in 2011 from US$19,000 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency clarifies reports on 'working poor'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:19:10 (By Lin Hui-chun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A government agency scrambled late Monday to clarify a report that Taiwan had seen an increase in the number of the " working poor, " including a rise in the number of those earning less than NT$20,000 (US$660) per month.

In a front page story Monday, the Liberty Times cited the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) as reporting that the number of employees with monthly incomes lower than NT$30,000 reached 3.597 million this year, accounting for 45 percent of all salaried employees in the country.
Moreover, the number of workers who earned less than NT$20,000 per month climbed to as many as 1.038 million this year, the second consecutive year that it had exceeded the 1 million mark.

The DGBAS said the newspaper based its report on a DGBAS survey conducted in May that only asked employees about their regular monthly income and did not consider income from second jobs, overtime, year-end and other bonuses, and allowances.
"In fact, the survey showed that the average regular salary reached NT$34,431 in May, which was slightly higher than for the same month last year, " said a DGBAS official who asked not to be named.
The survey also found the number of employees earning under NT$30,000 per month had actually fallen year-on-year as a result of the economic recovery, he said.
The official said that according to another DGBAS survey, the average total income for salaried workers was NT$43,106 in September, an increase of 6.4 percent year-on-year.
The regular monthly salary was NT$36,324, representing year-on-year growth of 1.48 percent. It was the 11th month in a row that workers' regular salary showed positive growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO asks authorities to adjust perspective on China investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:32:26 (By Pan Chih-yi, Yang Shu-min and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) urged the government to look at its China investment policy from the industry's point of view rather than from its own "political perspective."

Comparing how officials in Taiwan and China deal with investment proposals by Taiwanese businesspeople, a senior AUO executive said Taiwanese officials would pull out a stack of newspaper clippings and ask them to point out -- based on media reports -- where the government's policy has failed to address their concerns.

In contrast, said Paul S.L. Peng, executive vice president of AUO's display business operations, Chinese officials would have already visited the prospective investor's factory and understood its problems, ready to find solutions.
"They would take the initiative to tell us what kinds of services they can offer, " Peng said.

AUO on Friday received approval from the government to set up a 7.5-generation flat panel fab in China, at a time when its South Korean rival LG Display Corp. (LGD) has already broken ground on an 8.5-generation fab there.

Samsung Corp., another South Korean consumer electronics giant, has bought into the flat panel arm of China's TCL Corp., speeding up the building of plants for manufacturing new-generation display panels.

Relative to AUO's South Korean rivals, Peng said the government's permit for his company's 7.5-generation fab in China "came a bit too late, " and he urged the government to lift the "N-1 generation" limit.
He also suggested that authorities allow AUO and other Taiwanese firms to buy stakes in Chinese panel makers so they could compete with the Koreans on the world market.
Peng said AUO asked the government for permission to buy into Chinese companies when it filed its application to invest in China, but the Ministry of Economic Affairs turned down the request.
In response to Peng's statements, a senior MOEA official said the government did not have any plan to review the policy regarding investing in Chinese panel manufacturers.

As to why the government delayed approval of AUO's plan to invest in China, Industrial Development Bureau Director General Woody Duh said AUO changed the content of its plan while it was being screened.
The government required AUO to submit more information, and the new information and documents needed to be reviewed, so the whole process was slowed down, Duh said.

About one year ago, Peng said, Taiwanese panel makers were badly needed in China. Now that newer-generation panel fabs are already in place, the Chinese authorities are in no hurry to screen AUO's application to set up shop there, he complained.

According to Peng, China at the time had hoped to include five flat panel corporations in its strategic industry development plan -- TCL and BOE Technology of China, Samsung and LGD of South Korea, plus AUO.
"If our proposal had gotten a green light as planned, our Chinese factories would have been completed in early 2012. But now, they won't be in operation until the end of 2012."

MOEA officials were not wrong to do their jobs according to the law, but they demanded that AUO repeatedly submit new information on the same issues while delaying making a decision on the case, Peng said.
"As a result, the best time to build new factories in China has been missed," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan export orders to top US$405 billion in 2010: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:49:47 (By Yang Su-min, Cheng Chung-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite an appreciating currency, Taiwan's export orders continued to grow in November, putting it on course to reach its goal of US$405 billion in export orders for the year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.

Taiwan's export orders in November rose 14.34 percent year on year to a record US$35.74 billion on the back of strong demand for consumer electronic products such as cell phones and computers, the MOEA said.

The November export orders only grew by 7.27 percent year-on-year in Taiwan dollar terms after the local currency rose 5.04 percent against the greenback in November, according to the MOEA's Statistics Department.
The November figure grew 0.27 percent, or US$100 million, from October, department officials said.
In the first 11 months of this year, Taiwan's export orders rose 27.32 percent from the year-earlier level to US$370.15 billion, the officials said.
Export orders in December are expected to top US$35 billion, leaving the department optimistic that the US$405 billion goal for all of 2010 would be attained, officials said.
Export orders indicate deliveries three months in advance and are considered a key economic indicator.

In November, export orders for information and communications products grew 7.67 percent year-on-year to US$9.24 billion, while those for electronic products were up 12.57 percent to US$8.55 billion, and orders for precision equipment were up 8.51 percent to US$3.01 billion, according to the Statistics Department.
Information and communications products, along with electronic goods and precision equipment accounted for over 50 percent of Taiwan's total export orders in November.

Export orders for base metal related products rose 31.01 percent, or US$580 million, from a year earlier as a result of rising sales prices and a low comparative baseline from 2009, according to the department.

In November, export orders placed by China and Hong Kong totaled US$9.19 billion, up 16.56 percent from a year earlier, while export orders from the United States grew 13.48 percent to US$7.8 billion, the department said.

Export orders placed by Europe rose 17.61 percent from a year earlier to US$7.03 billion in November, while orders from Japan totaled US$4.05 billion, up 5.74 percent year on year, the department said.

Meanwhile, Statistics Department Director-General Huang Ji-shih said over half, or 50.95 percent, of the export orders received in November would be produced overseas, a new high, with 83.32 percent of the information and communications products ordered to be produced outside Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan denies dollar diplomacy in settling Palau PSB bankruptcy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 23:28:52 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied Monday that it engaged in "dollar diplomacy" when Palau used Taiwanese government funds to help settle a bank bankruptcy there in late 2006, but it did not address reports that a similar practice was continuing now.

According to the Palau Horizon newspaper, Palau has begun using US$955,000 left over from a previous loan from Taiwan with the government's consent to reimburse depositors of the failed Pacific Savings Bank (PSB) who were not reimbursed when the bank went into receivership in November 2006.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang blasted the government for "footing the bills of a failed foreign bank" and demanded that it ask Palau to return the money to Taiwan.
In a press release, the MOFA said the funds were part of the government's annual assistance to Palau and no new money was used to help relieve the victims of the bankruptcy.

As many as 7,000 account holders were affected in a country with a population of just 20,000, according to the MOFA, which said allowing the ally's government to use that money to stabilize its economy to restore social order at the time was the right thing to do.

The MOFA statement did not directly address, however, the most recent agreement reported by the Palau Horizon allowing Palau the use of the balance of US$955,000 from the 2007 loan to compensate the remaining 641 depositors who never recouped their losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency clarifies reports on 'working poor'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:19:10 (By Lin Hui-chun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A government agency scrambled late Monday to clarify a report that Taiwan had seen an increase in the number of the " working poor, " including a rise in the number of those earning less than NT$20,000 (US$660) per month.

In a front page story Monday, the Liberty Times cited the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) as reporting that the number of employees with monthly incomes lower than NT$30,000 reached 3.597 million this year, accounting for 45 percent of all salaried employees in the country.

The regular monthly salary was NT$36,324, representing year-on-year growth of 1.48 percent. It was the 11th month in a row that workers' regular salary showed positive growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUO asks authorities to adjust perspective on China investment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:32:26 (By Pan Chih-yi, Yang Shu-min and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) urged the government to look at its China investment policy from the industry's point of view rather than from its own "political perspective."

Comparing how officials in Taiwan and China deal with investment proposals by Taiwanese businesspeople, a senior AUO executive said Taiwanese officials would pull out a stack of newspaper clippings and ask them to point out -- based on media reports -- where the government's policy has failed to address their concerns.

In contrast, said Paul S.L. Peng, executive vice president of AUO's display business operations, Chinese officials would have already visited the prospective investor's factory and understood its problems, ready to find solutions.
"They would take the initiative to tell us what kinds of services they can offer, " Peng said.

AUO on Friday received approval from the government to set up a 7.5-generation flat panel fab in China, at a time when its South Korean rival LG Display Corp. (LGD) has already broken ground on an 8.5-generation fab there.

Samsung Corp., another South Korean consumer electronics giant, has bought into the flat panel arm of China's TCL Corp., speeding up the building of plants for manufacturing new-generation display panels.

Relative to AUO's South Korean rivals, Peng said the government's permit for his company's 7.5-generation fab in China "came a bit too late, " and he urged the government to lift the "N-1 generation" limit.
He also suggested that authorities allow AUO and other Taiwanese firms to buy stakes in Chinese panel makers so they could compete with the Koreans on the world market.
Peng said AUO asked the government for permission to buy into Chinese companies when it filed its application to invest in China, but the Ministry of Economic Affairs turned down the request.
In response to Peng's statements, a senior MOEA official said the government did not have any plan to review the policy regarding investing in Chinese panel manufacturers.

As to why the government delayed approval of AUO's plan to invest in China, Industrial Development Bureau Director General Woody Duh said AUO changed the content of its plan while it was being screened.
The government required AUO to submit more information, and the new information and documents needed to be reviewed, so the whole process was slowed down, Duh said.

About one year ago, Peng said, Taiwanese panel makers were badly needed in China. Now that newer-generation panel fabs are already in place, the Chinese authorities are in no hurry to screen AUO's application to set up shop there, he complained.

According to Peng, China at the time had hoped to include five flat panel corporations in its strategic industry development plan -- TCL and BOE Technology of China, Samsung and LGD of South Korea, plus AUO.
"If our proposal had gotten a green light as planned, our Chinese factories would have been completed in early 2012. But now, they won't be in operation until the end of 2012."

MOEA officials were not wrong to do their jobs according to the law, but they demanded that AUO repeatedly submit new information on the same issues while delaying making a decision on the case, Peng said.
"As a result, the best time to build new factories in China has been missed," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan export orders to top US$405 billion in 2010: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 22:49:47 (By Yang Su-min, Cheng Chung-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Despite an appreciating currency, Taiwan's export orders continued to grow in November, putting it on course to reach its goal of US$405 billion in export orders for the year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.

Taiwan's export orders in November rose 14.34 percent year on year to a record US$35.74 billion on the back of strong demand for consumer electronic products such as cell phones and computers, the MOEA said.

The November export orders only grew by 7.27 percent year-on-year in Taiwan dollar terms after the local currency rose 5.04 percent against the greenback in November, according to the MOEA's Statistics Department.
The November figure grew 0.27 percent, or US$100 million, from October, department officials said.
In the first 11 months of this year, Taiwan's export orders rose 27.32 percent from the year-earlier level to US$370.15 billion, the officials said.
Export orders in December are expected to top US$35 billion, leaving the department optimistic that the US$405 billion goal for all of 2010 would be attained, officials said.
Export orders indicate deliveries three months in advance and are considered a key economic indicator.

In November, export orders for information and communications products grew 7.67 percent year-on-year to US$9.24 billion, while those for electronic products were up 12.57 percent to US$8.55 billion, and orders for precision equipment were up 8.51 percent to US$3.01 billion, according to the Statistics Department.
Information and communications products, along with electronic goods and precision equipment accounted for over 50 percent of Taiwan's total export orders in November.

Export orders for base metal related products rose 31.01 percent, or US$580 million, from a year earlier as a result of rising sales prices and a low comparative baseline from 2009, according to the department.

In November, export orders placed by China and Hong Kong totaled US$9.19 billion, up 16.56 percent from a year earlier, while export orders from the United States grew 13.48 percent to US$7.8 billion, the department said.

Export orders placed by Europe rose 17.61 percent from a year earlier to US$7.03 billion in November, while orders from Japan totaled US$4.05 billion, up 5.74 percent year on year, the department said.

Meanwhile, Statistics Department Director-General Huang Ji-shih said over half, or 50.95 percent, of the export orders received in November would be produced overseas, a new high, with 83.32 percent of the information and communications products ordered to be produced outside Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan denies dollar diplomacy in settling Palau PSB bankruptcy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/10 23:28:52 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied Monday that it engaged in "dollar diplomacy" when Palau used Taiwanese government funds to help settle a bank bankruptcy there in late 2006, but it did not address reports that a similar practice was continuing now.

According to the Palau Horizon newspaper, Palau has begun using US$955,000 left over from a previous loan from Taiwan with the government's consent to reimburse depositors of the failed Pacific Savings Bank (PSB) who were not reimbursed when the bank went into receivership in November 2006.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang blasted the government for "footing the bills of a failed foreign bank" and demanded that it ask Palau to return the money to Taiwan.
In a press release, the MOFA said the funds were part of the government's annual assistance to Palau and no new money was used to help relieve the victims of the bankruptcy.

As many as 7,000 account holders were affected in a country with a population of just 20,000, according to the MOFA, which said allowing the ally's government to use that money to stabilize its economy to restore social order at the time was the right thing to do.

The MOFA statement did not directly address, however, the most recent agreement reported by the Palau Horizon allowing Palau the use of the balance of US$955,000 from the 2007 loan to compensate the remaining 641 depositors who never recouped their losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 21, or the 16th day of the 11th month of Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

The weighted price index lost 49.18 points, or 0.55 percent, to close at 8,768.72 Monday.
