DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China negotiators begin talks in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 11:10:47 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Top negotiators from Taiwan and China began a new round of talks in Taipei Tuesday, with the signing of a medical and health care cooperation agreement topping the meeting's agenda.

This is the sixth meeting since June 2008 between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
The meetings between the two negotiators have become part of institutionalized talks between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies in the absence of official ties across the Taiwan Strait.
Chiang and Chen were scheduled to sign an agreement on cooperation in medical and health care services Tuesday afternoon.
During their previous five meetings, Chiang and Chen have signed 14 agreements that have paved the way for the opening of direct shipping and air links, tourist exchanges and closer economic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Trend Micro breaks world record in mousetraps
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 12:03:42 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Trend Micro Inc., a major global content security provider, has successfully released 865 mousetraps in a domino circle, a feat expected to set a new Guinness World Record.

The Tokyo-headquartered, Taiwanese-founded multinational said Monday that it broke the previous record of 200 mousetraps and would submit its claim to the Guinness World Records organization for formal confirmation.

The mousetrap game, which was organized in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City this year, was part of the company's annual engineering camp aimed at further enhancing the team spirit of its 700 engineers from around the world.

"Every year, we want to use the camp, in which people get training and have fun, to have our engineers temporarily stay away from computers and learn more important soft skills, " said Trend Micro CEO Eva Chen.
"We encourage our employees to think how to achieve the best possible result through teamwork (through games like this) , " Trend Micro's chief culture officer Jenny Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier shares Taiwan experience in Burkina Faso
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/21/10 12:43:53 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih, in Burkina Faso to attend the inauguration ceremony of its president, offered advice and Taiwan's help to the West African country as it looks to develop its industrial base and the talent needed to run it.

Taiwan's premier suggested that Burkina Faso first identify the sectors suitable for development in the country before deciding what kind of workforce it needed to cultivate to meet the needs of the targeted industries.

Once the country knew what sectors it wanted to develop, Taiwan would help in building vocational training centers to groom talent, Wu told his counterpart Tertius Zongo at an evening banquet hosted by the Burkinabe prime minister on Monday.
Without going through the process identifying target sectors, there would be no jobs for those who have finished training at the vocational centers, Wu said.
Wu, heading an 18-member delegation, arrived in Ouagadougou Sunday for a one- week visit focused on attending the Dec. 20 inauguration of President Blaise Compaore.
Wu is the first Taiwanese premier to visit the West African ally since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994.
At Monday's banquet, Zongo said he agreed with Wu's thinking and hoped Taiwan could send mission-oriented experts to the country to help manage vocational training facilities in their initial stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: Far Eastern's China plan aimed at vertical integration: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 13:00:10 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The move by Far Eastern Century Corp., one of Taiwan's leading textile makers, to set up a purified terephthalic acid (PTA) joint venture in China reflects the company's ambition to enhance its vertical integration, an analyst said Tuesday.

Far Eastern announced Monday that it would join forces with China's Sinopec Yizheng Chemical Fibre Co. Ltd. to build a PTA firm in Yangzhou, Jiangsu Province. The plant will have an annual capacity of 1 million tons.
The two partners signed a letter of intent for the joint investment, with Far Eastern to hold a 60 percent stake in the new company and Yizheng to own the remaining 40 percent.
The proposed joint venture, which will require an investment of 3.8 billion Chinese yuan (US$569 million) , has been approved by Chinese authorities, the company said.
Far Eastern said construction of the new plant is expected to be competed in two years and production is scheduled to start no later than in 2013.

"PTA is the main raw material of Far Eastern's polyester related products. The investment is expected to help the company secure supply of the raw material, " Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said.
"The investment shows the company's efforts to vertically integrate its business and avoid possible raw material shortages in the future," Hsu said.
At present, Far Eastern produces about 1.6 million tons of PTA a year, of which 1 million tons is made in Taiwan and 600,000 tons in China.
Far Eastern said it expected to add another 600,000 tons from the new plant in Yangzhou.

"The interesting part of the joint venture plan is that Far Eastern will hold a stake of more than 50 percent as a controlling shareholder. It could be another form of China 'granting benefit' to Taiwan's companies," Hsu said.
The phrase "granting benefit" was first used by Wen Jiabao in March to describe China's attitude in negotiating an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with Taiwan.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party described Wen's comments at the time as "lies" and an attempt to make the ECFA more palatable to Taiwan's people.
Led by Far Eastern, the local textile sector rose 1.20 percent in Tuesday morning trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Can government betray public's trust?

TEXT.P: Green energy development and the establishment of a low-carbon homeland are high on President Ma Ying-jeou's master plan to usher in a so-called "golden decade" for Taiwan.
The government's implementation of its renewable energy policy, however, has been plagued by loopholes and contradictions.

Since the Statute on Renewable Energy Development was promulgated in July 2009, many disputes have arisen. In October this year, solar cell makers filed appeals with the Executive Yuan and the Control Yuan to protest what they called the snail's pace at which state-owned Taiwan Power Co. was screening solar power generation applications.

At the time, Premier Wu Den-yih directed the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to push Taipower to cut red tape and speed up the completion of the deals, that would commit Taipower to buy the electricity produced at a set fee.

Just two months later, a new controversy has erupted. On Dec. 17, the MOEA's Bureau of Energy posted a notice on its website saying that the wholesale price to be paid for the power generated by solar projects will be decided on the date of completion of the investors' solar power facilities rather than when the contract is signed.

As Taipower is likely to lower its solar power procurement price by 30 percent next year, the abrupt policy reversal would definitely inflict serious damage on photovoltaic manufacturers and indiviudal investors in the sector.

The policy flip-flop could take the heaviest toll on Pingtung County, where about 100 land owners decided to install solar panels on their aquaculture farms at the encouragement of the county government after Typhoon Morakot wreaked havoc in the region in August 2009.
County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung slammed the MOEA as acting like a fraud ring because its policy reversal betrayed the trust of the people.

According to MOEA statistics, Taipower has signed 166 contracts with electricity suppliers since the beginning of this year based on previous regulations that the procurement price would be calculated based on the rate in place the day the contract was signed. All of these contracts would have to be renegotiated under the new regulations.
How could the ministry have made such a big policy U-turn just 13 days before the end of the year? The move reflects the MOEA's frivolous attitude in dealing with major policy issues.
Moreover, the MOEA's latest decision violated the basic legal tenet that laws should not be retroactive.
We hope the MOEA will reconsider its move in order to regain public trust. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 21, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China negotiators begin talks in Taipei (Update-1)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 13:33:44 (By Charles Kang, Sofia Wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Top negotiators from Taiwan and China began a new round of talks in Taipei Tuesday, with the signing of a medical and health care cooperation agreement topping the meeting's agenda.

In his opening remarks at the meeting, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , touted the new agreement on medical cooperation and previous agreements on food safety and agricultural quarantines, as a cross-Taiwan Strait "safety net."
The agreements safeguard the health of the people on both sides, guaranteeing the quality of their interactions on the basis of a solid system, Chiang said.

Chiang's counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said both sides attached great importance to the agreement, and he hoped it could be sealed at the meeting.

Chiang acknowledged that some of the agreements signed in their five previous meetings had not worked as well as anticipated, citing the inadequate number of cross-Taiwan flights, China's inaction on repatriating suspected economic, and problems finalizing compensation for tarnished food imports.
He said the two sides needed to resolve the problems face-to-face as early as possible, and Chen agreed.
"I would be every supportive" if the two sides could establish some kind of mechanism to check and carry out the signed agreements within a certain period of time, Chen said.
The Chiang-Chen meetings have become part of institutionalized talks between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies in the absence of official ties across the Taiwan Strait.
During their previous five meetings, Chiang and Chen have signed 14 agreements that have paved the way for the opening of direct shipping and air links, tourist exchanges and closer economic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA helping stranded Taiwanese travelers in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 14:01:24 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that Taiwan's representative offices in Europe are doing their best to help Taiwanese travelers stranded around the northern part of the continent due to bad weather.

The ministry confirmed that as of Tuesday morning, more than 100 Taiwanese tourists were stranded in Cologne, Vienna and London after heavy snow caused the cancellation and delay of flights across the European continent.
With the help of Taiwan's representative office, 73 Taiwanese tourists received a temporary visa or a Schengen visa exemption from the immigration office in Vienna, MOFA spokesman James Chang said.

Another group of 54 travelers on a China Airlines flight had arrived in London after previously being kept in Cologne, where the tourists received a group Schengen visa so they could leave the airport during their stay.
Dozens of Taiwanese travelers were also still in London waiting for Heathrow and Gatwick airports to open, Chang said.
The MOFA believed there were other Taiwanese travelers facing problems in Europe, and the Department of European Affairs was still gathering information on their situations, Chang said.

The ministry had a similar experience in helping more than 1,900 Taiwanese travelers get to their destination or apply for temporary travel documents in April, when a volcanic eruption in Iceland disrupted thousands of flights around Europe, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based retailer eyes listing in Q4 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 14:24:40 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Grand Ocean Retail Group, a China-based department store chain, is planning to launch a primary listing on Taiwan's stock exchange in the fourth quarter of next year, its Taiwanese parent company said Tuesday.
First Steamship Co., which holds a 50 percent stake in Grand Ocean Retail, said a board meeting has approved a proposal for the retailer to list on Taiwan's main board.
First Steamship said Cayman Islands-registered Grand Ocean has appointed Yuanta Securities as a financial adviser for the planned listing and is gearing up to prepare for the stock market debut.

Grand Ocean, which opened its first store in Fuzhou in Fujian Province in 2002, currently operates 14 stores in 10 Chinese cities, including Nanjing, Guangzhou, Suzhou and Chongqing, according to First Steamship.

The parent company said the retailer, which has a registered capital of 500 million Chinese Yuan (US$74.9 million) , is expanding its operations and hopes to open four stores a year to take advantage of strong domestic demand in China.
In 2011, Grand Ocean will add stories in Nanjing, Yichang (Hubei Province), Shijiazhuang (Hebei Province) and Hefei (Anhui Province).
In the first three quarters of this year, Grand Ocean had net earnings of US$10.84 million, up 19 percent from a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ju Percussion to celebrate 25th anniversary with four concerts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 15:44:39 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Ju Percussion Group will celebrate its 25th anniversary with four concerts in Taipei, Taichung, and Kaohsiung starting Jan. 2, it said in Taipei Tuesday.
The group, founded in January 1986 by one of Taiwan's most famous musicians Ju Tzong-ching, was the country's first percussion ensemble.
Since then, it has staged more than 2,000 shows in Europe, the U.S. Asia, and Australia, and has composed more than 155 original pieces of music, Ju said.
The 56-year-old musician said the group has encountered many frustrations during the last 25 years, but with the support and encouragement of its audiences, "it has made the impossible possible."
"In Taiwan, sometimes it is difficult for the audience to tell the difference between a mediocre and a good performance, but we always give our audience the best," he said.

Now in its 25th year, the group has "grown up" and will continue to expand the influence of percussion music in Taiwan and give young percussionists a chance to shine on the local and international stage.
Ju, who has not performed in public in Taiwan in the last five years, will take part in the four concerts of classic music that has been tailored for the group by composers at home and abroad.
"Speed Drums, " which caused a sensation when it premiered in Seoul in July, will be on the program.

In 2009, Ju received a lifetime award from the U.S.-based Percussive Arts Society (PAS), which is considered the highest honor in the world of percussion music. He was the first Taiwanese to receive the award from PAS, the largest percussion music organization in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.67 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 16:24:21 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.67 percent Tuesday amid optimism toward cross strait economic exchanges after the sixth-round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China officially opened, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 59.07 points to the day's high of 8,827.79, off a low of 8,772.59, on turnover of NT$99.36 billion (US$3.32 billion).

The market opened 0.39 percent higher and the momentum extended to the end of the trading session, with buying concentrated on the old economy sector on hopes that these stocks would further benefit from the fast growing China market, dealers said.
A total of 2,445 stocks closed up and 161 down with 423 remaining unchanged.

The textile sector scored the highest gains, ending up 2.1 percent, led by Far Eastern New Century, which announced a purified terephthalic acid (PTA) joint venture with China's Sinopec Yizheng Chemical Fibre Co. Ltd..
Foodstuff rose 1.4 percent, financial shares added 0.8 percent, construction, and machinery and electronics stocks rose 0.7 percent, and the cement sector closed up 0.5 percent.
The paper and pulp sector rose 0.2 percent, while the plastics and chemical sector closed unchanged.

"China commands a huge domestic demand market, " Taiwan International Securities analyst Michael Chiang said, "Traditional industrial companies that have a foothold on the mainland are expected to reap gains from closer business ties across the Taiwan Strait."

Among the old economy stocks, Far Eastern New Century rose 3.26 percent to NT$49.15 on a move to take a 60 percent stake in the PTA joint venture that is expected to produce one million tons of PTA a year, starting from 2013.
Shinkong Synthetic Fiber rose 3.87 percent to NT$16.10 and Tung Ho Textile increased 6.77 percent to NT$14.20.
"Investors are also hoping that Taiwan and China will allow individual Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan soon, " Chiang said.
However, as the index moved to the nearest resistance level of 8,900 points, there seemed to be not much willingness to chase prices, Chiang said.
"The turnover was below NT$100 billion today. Such a quiet market needs some consolidation to clear the technical hurdles." he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dairy products found carrying false production dates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:05:05 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Some of the dairy products marketed by three major small- and medium-sized dairy companies in Taiwan have been found with false manufacturing dates or deferred expiration dates, the government's consumer protection agency said Tuesday.

In a recent inspection of products from five mid-sized dairy companies around Taiwan, items from three were found to have manufacturing dates that were up to 67 days after the products were actually made.

According to Wu Cheng-hsueh, a section chief of the Cabinet-level Consumer Protection Commission, juice-flavored preserved milks produced by Tainan County-based Gau Jiann Food Technical, Ltd. carried manufacturing dates that were four and 67 days later than the actual production dates.
The commission ordered Gau Jiann to destroy the products and fined the company NT$40,000 (US$1,333) for its first mislabeling offense, Wu said.
In addition, the commission has asked the Tainan County government to monitor the company's operations and products on a regular basis, Wu said.
Meanwhile, four types of products from the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association Dairy Plant in Taichung were found to carry expiration dates that were deferred by 1-5 days.
Those dairy products with suspect labeling have already been destroyed, and the plant was also given an NT$40,000 fine, according to Wu.

The third company, a Pingtung County-based goat milk company known as Baali Food, was also found to have carried a manufacturing date that was one day after the product was actually produced, Wu said.
The company was told to correct its operations, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China seal pact on emergency information exchange
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:22:20 (By Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A new agreement between Taiwan and China will create a two-way system for the immediate exchange of information on accidents, disasters and epidemics, health officials said Tuesday.
The medical and health care cooperation agreement -- the 15th cross-Taiwan Strait pact since 2008 -- was signed in a meeting between top negotiators from Taiwan and China in Taipei Tuesday.
The agreement opens a window for swift reporting by the health departments on both sides in emergency situations, said the health officials from both sides who were at the meeting.

For example, if a Chinese tour group was hit by a landslide in Taiwan, or Taiwanese tourists were injured in traffic accidents in China, information such as the number of people involved and their names would be relayed immediately to the other side, the officials said.
In addition, the two sides will establish a mechanism for reporting major outbreaks of diseases such as influenza A(H1N1) and enterovirus, the officials said.
Under the medical cooperation agreement, Taiwan and China will also work together on research for an enterovirus vaccine, they said.

The health officials who participated in the meeting between the chief negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- include Hsiao Mei-ling, vice minister of Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH), and DOH officials in charge of food and drug administration and disease control.
On the Chinese side, the officials were from the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine, and the State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
The meeting, which is being held Dec. 20-22, is the sixth between Chiang and Chen since June 2008 when cross-strait relations began to warm up.

The biannual meetings have become part of institutionalized talks between the SEF and ARATS, two quasi-official intermediary bodies designated to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Obstacles in investment protection talks
DOC.DATELINE: 12/21/10 17:36:10 (The Journalist 1240)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have not yet reached common ground on a proposed investment protection agreement since they began talks on the subject in October, because of issues that involve sovereignty and China's request for easing of the restrictions on Chinese investment in Taiwan.
It is the same situation as with the proposed double taxation avoidance agreement that was set aside by Taiwan and China's top negotiators in 2009, but it has greater implications.

"The investment protection agreement is a very urgent issue, especially the aspects concerning compensation for expropriation and protection of personal safety, " said Jack Yun-jie Lee, head of National Open University's Department of Public Administration.
Since Taiwan began allowing companies to invest in China in 1991, the number of disputes and complaints pertaining to property and personal safety risks have increased every year.
From 1991 to 2009, more than 1,700 cases of threats to personal safety and 1,000 instances of breach of financial interest have been reported.
In a survey by Taiwan's General Chamber of Commerce, 70.66 percent of the Taiwanese businesses in China said they were hardly satisfied with China's efforts to resolve investment disputes.

Because Taiwanese companies in China are not categorized as either foreign or domestic, it is difficult for Taiwan and China to work out the basic aspects of an investment protection agreement, such as jurisdiction, investors' nationality, and rules of arbitration, Lee said.

Another issue that has further complicated the negotiations is whether the agreement should include investment promotion, which would allow Chinese companies to invest in areas beyond the current 192 categories in Taiwan, he said.
Taiwan is inclined to set aside the promotion aspect for the time being because it would involve a long legislative process and policy changes, but China remains firm on the issue.

"One of the reasons Taiwan and China have not yet agreed on the issues of foreign exchange and compensation for expropriation is that we lack bargaining chips because so few Chinese companies invest in Taiwan," Lee said.

Because of the political hurdles, the investment protection agreement will not be finalized in the sixth round of cross-strait negotiations from Dec. 20-22, or even in the seventh round, said Kao Charng, deputy minister of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council. In the meantime, Taiwanese companies have no choice but to endure the hardship they face in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lank Bank to open Shanghai branch Dec. 29
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:38:24 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Land Bank of Taiwan said Tuesday it is scheduled to open a Shanghai branch Dec. 29, becoming the first state-owned bank to upgrade its mainland representative office to a branch.
In the initial phase, the Shanghai branch will offer funds in foreign currencies to Taiwanese businesses operating in China, bank spokesman Wu Fu-rong said.
After one year, the bank is expected to begin to show a profit and will expand to Chinese yuan business services for Taiwanese customers, Wu said.
Kuo Chang-lung, who is currently the director of Land Bank's Shanghai representative office, will head the new branch, which will be located in Shanghai's Pudong District.
Land Bank of Taiwan was among the first five Taiwanese banks to gain approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) to open branches in China.

The bank has had a representative office in Shanghai since 2003 and was waiting for a long time to upgrade to a branch. It is planning a grand opening ceremony that will be attended by its chairman Wang Yao-shing and other bank officials.

First Commercial Bank was also given the green light by Chinese authorities to open a branch in Shanghai. Cathay United Bank and Chang Hwa Commercial Bank have obtained approval to set up branches in Kunshan, while Taiwan Cooperative Bank was given permission to open a branch in Suzhou.

Under the recent economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, Taiwanese bank branches in China will be allowed to conduct Chinese yuan business after two years once they are showing a profit following its establishment. For other foreign banks, the requirement is three years in operation.
Taiwanese banks will also be allowed to conduct business in Chinese yuan business with Taiwanese investors in China after one year of operation there.
Wu forecast that his bank's Shanghai branch will double its revenue once it goes into Chinese yuan business.

In an earlier statement, the CBRC said it hopes that the presence of Taiwan's bank branches in China will help promote cross-strait economic and trade relations and maintain the steady development of the cross-strait banking sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China sign medical and health cooperation pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:45:32 (By Charles Kang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan and China signed a cross-Taiwan Strait medical and health cooperation agreement Tuesday to better ensure the safety of medicines and bolster health care cooperation.

The deal was signed by Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, the president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) during their meeting at Taipei's Grand Hotel, the sixth they have held since June 2008.

Under the agreement, Taiwan and China will work together to control the spread of contagious diseases and to strengthen the quality control of medicines, medical equipment, cosmetics and food supplements shipped across the strait.
The agreement will also facilitate joint efforts to handle accidents involving people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, with mechanisms expected to be established to help victims in emergencies.
Another area of cooperation under the agreement will be the research and development of new medicines.

Both sides agreed to establish six working groups to take charge of disease control, drug safety and medical research, traditional Chinese medicine research and herbal medicine safety, emergency relief, and quarantine issues.

These working groups will begin to meet within three months after the agreement goes into effect to exchange information and decide on their modes of operation, including the groups' liaison officers.
President Ma Ying-jeou said an important reason for signing this agreement was to ensure the safety of herbal medicines from China.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said the agreement will effectively stop epidemics originating in China from being imported to Taiwan.
The medical and health cooperation accord was the 15th agreement signed by the SEF and ARATS since June 2008, one month after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment protection to top agenda for next cross-strait meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:50:46 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Investment protection will top the agenda for the next round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China, an official of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday.

The seventh meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will also address issues regarding the creation of a mechanism to deal with trade and investment disputes, said SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian.

"This was the consensus reached at the just-concluded sixth meeting since 2008 between the top negotiators from the two sides, " Kao said at a news conference that was held at around noon after the first session.
The two-hour meeting focused on a bilateral agreement on cooperation in medical and health care services, which would be formally signed later in the day, Kao said.

The two top negotiators also exchanged views on an investment protection agreement that the two sides had intended to sign during the current talks but decided to postpone until they could work out the details, Kao said.
"They agreed that they should continue negotiations on issues regarding investment protection so that a formal accord can be sealed in their next meeting," Kao said.

Meanwhile, he added, the two negotiators agreed that talks should begin as soon as possible on further liberalization of trade and services to substantiate the goals listed in the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that was signed on June 29.

Taiwan and China had agreed that follow-up negotiations on the ECFA should start within six months of it taking effect in September. However, in view of the complexity of the issues involved in the ECFA follow-up accords, negotiations are not expected to be finalized before the next round of Chiang-Chen talks, Kao said.
"But the two sides have agreed to begin consultations on relevant topics," Kao added.
The two sides have also agreed to activate as soon as possible a cross-strait economic cooperation commission that will address ECFA-related negotiations and consultations, as required by the pact.
The meetings between SEF and ARATS heads have become part of institutionalized talks between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies in the absence of official ties across the Taiwan Strait.
During their previous five meetings, Chiang and Chen signed 14 agreements that paved the way for the opening of direct shipping and air links, tourist exchanges and closer economic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Security for visiting Chinese envoy 'overboard': DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 17:52:15 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Many people in Taiwan feel the security for the visit of Chinese official Chen Yunlin has gone "overboard, " the Democratic Progressive Party said Tuesday, and it urged the government not to muffle those who oppose its policies.

"A fundamental tenet of a democratic country is to allow protesting voices to occur naturally and not to eliminate all opposing forces, " said DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang on the same day Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin- kung held their semi-annual meeting.

According to a DPP poll, 61.6 percent of 665 respondents said the security deployment for Chen, the head of the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) who is here for a sixth round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations with Chiang, was "way too much."
Local newspapers said over 2,500 police officers were mobilized to ensure his safety during his three-day visit but the Taipei City Police Department said only 211 officers were dispatched.
A group of DPP Taipei City councilors who staged a sit-in in front of Chen's hotel were forcefully evacuated by the police when they refused to comply with the police request to leave the scene.

The councilors branded their eviction an "injustice" and said their intention was to give Chen a petition asking China to stop using President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to trample on the human rights of Taiwan's people.
A representative from the Taiwan-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) attempted to ease the tension by accepting the letter but was quickly booed away by the protesters.

Members of the Alliance of Referendum for Taiwan also hoisted an oversize banner on a freeway across from the hotel that said Taiwan is an independent state and Taiwan and China are two separate countries.

Accusing the government of removing all Republic of China flags or any national emblems from places Chen might go during his visit, the DPP's Cheng said the purpose of security should be to ensure the smoothness of the trip and the safety of the person.
"But the government's version of security is to eliminate all forms of protests so Chen can't hear or see the demonstrators," Cheng argued.
Chen was in Taiwan for the third time since first visiting in November 2008, when violent clashes and street protests erupted in Taipei between anti-China protesters and the police.
Over 140 policemen and 200 civilians were reportedly injured in the chaos.

For Chen's latest visit, the police set up the usual barbed wire fences and roadblocks to prevent protesters from charging into the Grand Hotel where Chen is staying. So far the protests have been relatively small in scale with no reports of major clashes.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 18:10:40 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, dropping NT$0.001 to close at NT$30.600.
Turnover totaled US$572 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at 30.650 and moved between NT$29.825 and NT$30.655 before the close.
After the market opened, the New Taiwan dollar extended its upward trend to rise above the NT$30.00 level against the U.S. dollar on continued inflows of foreign funds, dealers said.
A weakening U.S. dollar against other Asian currencies in the region added downward pressure on the greenback in the local foreign exchange market, they said.

A higher local bourse buoyed by optimism over cross-Taiwan Strait ties lent further support to the local currency after high-level talks between Taiwan and China officially opened in Taipei Tuesday morning, they added.
The weighted index rose 0.67 percent to close at the day's high of 8,827.79.
In late trade, Taiwan's central bank intervened in the local foreign exchange market again to push the U.S. dollar higher and back above the NT$30.00 level, dealers said.

With the Christmas holiday approaching and many foreign traders sidelined, the relatively thin trading volume made it easier for the central bank to manipulate the value of the local currency, they said.
To protect Taiwan's global competitiveness, the central bank is expected to continue to maintain the U.S. dollar above the NT$30.00 level in the short term, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veterans seek compensation for extra year of service
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 18:33:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A proposal is in the works to request compensation from the Taiwan government for more than 500,000 veterans who served an extra year in the military during the 1960s to 1980s.

According to the draft bill, the government issued an illegal order to force 567,407 soldiers, during the period 1968 to 1986, to serve for three instead of the two years mandated in the Act of Military Service System.

Dozens of veterans, aged 43 to 64, attended a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, saying that the government had treated them unfairly because they had to spend an extra 12 months of their youth in the military.
"I missed a lot of time with my wife and sons, " said Liu Tien-kuei, who was conscripted in 1978 in the military police.

Seeking to maintain troop levels after the retirement of many of its soldiers who came to Taiwan from China, the Kuomintang government in 1966 issued a temporary order for a one-year extension of service in the armored units, engineering corps, missile troops, artillery, airborne troops, signal troops, special forces and arsenal. The order was not revoked until 1986.

According to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai who initiated the bill, the regulations at that time stipulated that the compulsory period of service was two years, therefore, the executive order was a clear violation of the law.
Trong said that the Ministry of National Defense should compensate the affected veterans for the loss of time and money.
The legislature's Rules Committee blocked the draft bill from the legislative agenda Monday, but Chai vowed to forge bipartisan support for the proposal and put the bill on the agenda next week.
Taiwan is aiming to have a fully volunteer military service system by 2014 to replace the current system, which is part volunteer and part conscription.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dengue command center to be closed soon: CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 18:40:19 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The command center for dengue fever set up in southern Taiwan in October is expected to close soon, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Tuesday, following a gradual decrease in the number of patients in Taiwan infected with the mosquito-borne disease.

Although there were 51 new cases of dengue fever originating in Taiwan last week, it was only a third of the peak period when 150 new cases were reported in a single week, said Lin Ting, the CDC's deputy director-general, at the agency's weekly disease monitoring briefing.

"The decision to close the center will be made by command center members, after which a proposal will be passed to the Executive Yuan for approval, " said Lin, expecting the motion to be decided as soon as this Friday.

Despite the likely disbanding of the command center, Lin said the situation in Kaohsiung City remained relatively grave, with 40 new dengue fever cases reported there last week, and would require continued attention.
But he indicated that the closing of the center would not affect dengue epidemic prevention measures or weaken the inter-ministerial endeavor to combat the disease.

"There are rising signs of imported cases of dengue sufferers, and we fear that it would lead to more dengue hemorrhagic fever due to cross-infection, " said Lin, citing a 70-year-old housewife in Tainan County who contracted dengue hemorrhage last week and is still in intensive care.
Although dengue fever has shown signs of easing, Lin reminded people to take precautions against seasonal influenza, which had claimed 261 lives since July.
"With Christmas around the corner and the weather getting colder, we are about to enter the peak period for flu infection," Lin said.

As two more deaths reported were last week, he urged parents to get their children vaccinated with the three-in-one seasonal flu shot, which protects against this year's three prevalent virus strains -- H1N1, H3N2, and influenza B.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete Yang banned from competition for 3 months
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 18:51:08 (By S.C Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun, who was disqualified at this year's Asian Games, was banned from competition for three months and her coach Liu Tsung-ta was suspended for one year and eight months, in a ruling released Tuesday by the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF).
The WTF also fined the Chinese Taipei Taewondo Association US$50,000 because Yang and Liu protested the decision ringside at the Asiad Nov. 17.
A three-month suspension means an admonition to Yang since there will be no major international events in the three months.

Yang was disqualified on grounds that she had violated the rules by wearing extra electronic sensors in her socks during the bout to score more points, but video footage later showed that the sensors were not attached during the match against her Vietnamese opponent.
A stunned Yang refused to leave the ring after the decision and the contradictory statements by the taekwondo officials who were explaining the disqualification sparked outrage in Taiwan.
The WTF's disciplinary committee met Saturday in Seoul to hear the case and the committee's members delivered their sealed conclusions to the WTF Secretariat after the meeting.

The committee, comprising Egyptian, Israeli and Turkish officials, met to review the decision to disqualify Yang in her opening bout in the women's under 49 kg division at the Asiad and Yang's ensuing protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Port celebrates record cargo volume
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 19:13:09 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taichung Port reached a milestone Tuesday, as the total volume of cargo it handled this year exceeded 100 million metric tons, a record that has lifted the port into second place in Taiwan after Kaohsiung Port.
A celebratory ceremony was held at the central Taiwan harbor after 26,681-metric tons of cargo was unloaded from the Wan Hai 305, pushing the cargo volume up to the new benchmark.
"It is the best gift for the new special municipality after the merger of Taichung City and County, " said Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo at the ceremony.

According to the Taichung Harbor Bureau (THB), the total volume of cargo handled by the port between January and November was 97.65 million metric tons, about 21 percent higher than in the same period last year.
THB Deputy Director Chen Yi-hsiung said at the event that huge domestic demand for raw materials was an indicator of economic recovery.
He said the volume of fuel oil and minerals handled at the port has increased by 69.56 percent and 142.28 percent, respectively, year-on-year.
The rising number of imported luxury automobiles unloaded at the port in recent months also indicated increasing purchasing power, he said.
Taichung, one of the four international commercial ports in Taiwan, launched it first shipment in October 1976.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urges faster implementation of cross-strait pacts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 19:27:22 (By Kang Shih-jen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan urged China Tuesday to speed up implementation of the accords signed between the two sides over the past two and a half years.

Addressing the opening of the latest round of highest-level cross-strait meetings in Taipei, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin- kung said the rapprochement that began after President Ma Ying- jeou took office in 2008 has contributed greatly to increasing cultural, scientific, educational, trade and economic exchanges between the two sides.
However, he said, "implementation of some of the accords signed has fallen short of expectations and needs to be enhanced."
Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, have forged a total of 14 cross-strait agreements in their last five meetings.

For example, Taiwan and China have joined forces several times to bust cross- strait fraud rings since a pact on crime-fighting and judicial cooperation was signed April, 2009, but "there is a long way to go to obtain repatriation of Taiwanese economic criminals hiding in China," Chiang said.
Many prominent businesspersons who are listed as wanted in Taiwan for committing serious financial crimes are still in hiding in China.

He also mentioned the cross-strait Air Transportation Agreement inked in November 2008 to open direct air links and expand tourism exchanges between the two sides, saying the number of cross-strait flights needs to be increased to meet market demand.

Over 1.74 million Chinese tourists have visited Taiwan since a tourism deal was concluded in May 2008, but the number is still lower than expected and the measure is yet to be expanded, especially to allow individual Chinese tourist to visit Taiwan, he said.

Currently, a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourists are allowed into Taiwan each day in tour groups. Taiwan's tourism sector has been asking that the number be increased and that the process of allowing individual visits be speeded up.
In response, Chen said that most of the cross-strait agreements have been well implemented but "it would be difficult for all details of the pacts to be implemented 100 percent."
He said he agreed with Chiang that both sides should establish a mechanism to monitor the implementation of the agreements.
In addition, in future negotiations, the two sides should focus more on ways of increasing cultural exchanges, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan invited to join China's new 5-year plan

TEXT.P: China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, said after his arrival in Taipei Monday for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should expand the scale and scope of their economic exchanges and cooperation next year when China's 12th five-year plan will formally kick off.

It marked the first time that Chen, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , has publicly invited Taiwanese investors to take part in China's new development plan.

Also on Tuesday, an economics official warned that Taiwan could become even more reliant on China for merchandise production if Taiwanese companies continue their current practice of "duplicating" their Taiwan-based production lines in China while suspending their development of new production technology.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

In addition to promoting China's economic development, social harmony and stability, the 12th five-year plan is also expected to generate new opportunities for cross-strait economic cooperation, Chen said.
"If our two sides expand the scale and intensity of economic exchanges and cooperation, we will be able to cope with challenges and uncertainty lying ahead in the coming year," Chen said.

According to reports released by Beijing authorities, the 12th five-year plan will focus on developing several key emerging industries, including a new generation of Internet technology, biomedicine and clean energy-powered automobiles. (Dec. 21, 2010).
Commercial Times:

Statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) showed that local manufacturers received US$35.74 billion worth of export orders in November, the second highest monthly record in Taiwan's trade history.
The amount also marked a 14.34 percent year-on-year growth. Export orders from China, which saw a decline in October, registered a double-digit year-on-year growth in November.

Most noteworthy was that the ratio of overseas production in November further expanded to 50.95 percent in November. The ratio in the information and communication technology (ICT) sector even reached 83.32 percent.
"The percentage could surge further in the future, " forecast Huang Chi-shih, director of the MOEA's Statistics Department.
An MOEA official who spoke on condition of anonymity said that in the past, local manufacturers adopt a vertical division of labor model in operating their production lines in Taiwan and China.
The practice has, however, been gradually replaced by the practice of horizontal division of labor with local companies "duplicating" their home-based production lines in China.
If local companies fail to continue developing advanced production technologies, the official said Taiwan could become increasingly reliant on China for merchandise production.
In the past the ratio hovered around 40 percent. Thanks to a worldwide economic recovery, the ratio has stayed above 50 percent since March.

Under this trend, large business groups may continue making money while contributing little to improving domestic job opportunities, the official said, adding that the effective way to resolve the issue lies in upgrading added value of Taiwan-produced products and investing more in research and development. (Dec. 21, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Slower GDP growth of 4.24 percent forecast for 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 19:57:44 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The growth of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) for 2011 is expected to slow down from a year earlier to 4.24 percent largely on slowing global demand, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) said Tuesday.
The institute in June raised its forecast for Taiwan's 2010 economic growth from 5.88 percent to 10.03 percent on strong rebound in exports after the global financial meltdown in 2008-2009.

However, the momentum of exports is likely to fade to some extent next year as global demand could be compromised by a slowing U.S. economy and the lingering impact of the debt problems in Europe, the TRI said.

The institute said the rising price of raw materials due to abnormal global weather is likely to put upward pressure on production costs for local manufacturers, which in turn could undermine Taiwan's exports.

As the U.S. has stepped up with its second round of quantitative easing by pumping funds into the market to boost its economy, idle money is expected to continue to spread to the markets in Asia and further lift the value of Asian currencies, the think tank said.
As a result, the average value of the New Taiwan dollar could rise to NT$29.23 against the U.S. dollar early in 2011 and hover around NT$29.00 in the second half of the year.
A strong New Taiwan dollar is expected to hurt Taiwan's exporters' global competitiveness and further drag down the island's exports.
Earlier this month, another think tank, Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, predicted that Taiwan's 2011 GDP will grow 4.55 percent, slowing from the estimated 9.64 percent for 2010.
In November, the government revised downward its economic growth forecast for 2011 to 4.51 percent from a previous estimate of 4.64 percent.
The government has forecast economic growth of 9.98 for 2010 from the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employees give Taiwan job market barely passing grade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 20:18:50 (By Hsieh hun-wei and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Employees gave Taiwan's job market 64.4 points on a 100-point scale, with more than one third of them scoring it below 60 points and 27.5 percent grading it at 71-80 points, a recent poll showed.

According to the survey released Tuesday by the Yes123.com.tw job service, 16.1 percent of Taiwanese office workers said the only thing that keeps them in their current jobs is the salary "and nothing else."

The most attractive aspects of their jobs include "short distance from home, " according to 17.4 percent of the respondents, "getting along well with co- workers (12.1 percent) and "room for personal development" (11 percent).
What they find most dissatisfying are poor employee benefits (21.5 percent), no room for personal development (14.6 percent) and lousy bosses (12.2 percent).

The survey found that the five leading reasons that prompt office workers to change jobs are good year-end bonuses (59.1 percent) , dividends (48.8 percent) , good bonuses for the three main festivals (48.1 percent), good opportunities for promotion (44. 2 percent), and a good working environment in which they can get along well with co-workers (35 percent).

Chiu Wen-jen, deputy CEO of Yes123.com.tw, said "good pay, little responsibility and short distance from home" have always been the major attractions for Taiwanese office workers and the latest survey shows "good pay" is still the primary motive for job seekers.
However, under the globalization trend, Chiu said, it is no longer practical to expect to land a job that is not time-consuming or not too far from home.

As a consequence, people simply hope to have a job that offers good benefits and a good working atmosphere in which they can get along well with their co- workers, he said. The major attractions have thus become "good pay, good co- workers, and good/caring bosses, " he said.

Yes123.com.tw conducted the survey online from Nov. 29 through Dec. 6, collecting 2,219 valid samples. The poll had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.07 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foxconn chairman most popular boss in Taiwan: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 20:49:42 (By Cheng Chong-sheng and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Terry Guo, chairman of the Foxconn Group, was voted the most charismatic boss by Taiwanese workers, the results of an online survey showed Tuesday.

Twenty-one percent of the respondents in the Yes123 job bank poll said they hoped to work with 60-year-old Guo, head of the world's largest computer and electronic components contract manufacturer whose major clients include Apple and Dell.
Yulong Group Chairman Kenneth Yen was second with 10.9 percent of the votes and Yu Yun-chie, an entertainment agent who is former TV host, was third.

Although Guo is known as a tough boss, his company was voted as the second most attractive corporation in Taiwan because of the generous prize money it gives away at its year-end party, said Chiu Wen-jen, the job bank's deputy CEO.
Last year the top prize was 200,000 shares of the company's stocks, valued at NT$26.9 million (US$900,000).
Guo's personal fame has also helped the company's ranking, Chiu added.

The company that most workers want to get into is the world's largest contract chipmaker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), as indicated by 16.8 percent of the respondents, followed by Foxconn with 15 percent and Google with 8 percent.
The only non-IT company listed in the top five was the Wang Steak Group, which owns 10 brands and nearly 130 restaurant chains in Taiwan.

The survey was conducted online from Nov. 29 through Dec. 6, collecting 2,219 valid samples. The poll had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.07 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trying business-to-consumer promotion in South Asia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 21:01:05 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese brands have been working with partners in South Asian countries for the first time as part of the government's efforts to promote Taiwan's information and communication technology (ICT) products in the emerging market, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Tuesday.

The logo "Taiwan Excellence, " which is being used to brand the unique designs of Taiwan's ICT products, has become more popular in Vietnam, Indonesia and India since the implementation of a new marketing project, TAITRA Vice Chairman Wu Wen-ya said at a press conference.

TAITRA has also recruited three local celebrities -- Indonesian star Cathy Sharon, Indian movie star Lara Dutta and Vietnamese beauty queen Huong Giang -- to serve as spokespersons for Taiwanese products at 18 promotional events in the three countries this year, which attracted a total of 420,000 visitors, Wu said.

According to TAITRA, 19 Taiwanese ICT operators, including Asustek Computer Inc., Micro-Star International Co. (MSI) and BenQ, have taken part in a project to sell their innovative products in local chain stores, shopping malls and retailers in the three countries.

For the first time, Taiwanese brands are selling their products in southeast Asian markets using a business-to-consumer promotional approach instead of the business-to-business model, said the Bureau of Foreign Trade, which is overseeing the project, in a statement.
This gives consumers a chance to see and feel the quality of Taiwanese ICT products, the bureau said.

India has become the largest market in South Asia with a population of 1.2 billion, while the number of consumers in Indonesia and Vietnam have grown to 240 million and 85 million, respectively, which makes these countries attractive to the ICT industry, according to the International Data Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic cooperation body to be formed soon

TEXT.P: A cross-strait Economic Cooperation Committee will be established "very soon, " Vice Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Kao Koong-lian said Tuesday.

"Taiwan and China negotiators are close to agreement with regard to the EEC, and it will be set up within a short period of time," Kao said at a press conference at the end of the sixth top-level cross-strait meeting in Taipei.
Taiwan's Vice Economics Minister Francis Kuo-hsin Liang and China's Vice Commerce Minister Jiang Zengwei will serve as the "general conveners" of the body, Kao said.

The committee will be responsible for interpretation, implementation and coordination with regard to the list of items that are eligible for tariff removal of reduction under the terms of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan and China signed in June, he said.

Kao and his Chinese counterpart, Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will serve as EEC co-chairmen to make sure that the new body operates under the framework of the existing cross-strait exchange platform -- the SEF and ARATS.

Seven panels will be established under the EEC to handle issues involving commodity trade, service trade, the monetary industry, intellectual property rights protection, economic cooperation, dispute settlement and investment, according to Kao.
It is generally believed that the EEC will become operational before the end of this year in tandem with the ECFA's early harvest list that will take effect on Jan. 1. (By Lin Shu-yuan & Bear Lee

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top bookstore eyeing business in Hong Kong and China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 21:25:53 (By Zoe Wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Eslite, one of Taiwan's biggest bookstore chains and selected by TIME magazine as a must-see for visitors to the island, may expand its operations to Hong Kong in 2012, a top corporate official said Tuesday.
The company will likely make a decision on the plan in the first quarter of 2011, said Mercy Wu, vice chairwoman of the company founded by her father, Robert Wu.

Talks have also begun on setting up more branches in major cities in mainland China and the plans are expected to be materialized in three to five years, said Wu when releasing an annual report on the company's operations in 2010 and plans for the future.
Eslite, currently operating 38 bookshops around Taiwan, has regularly carried 90 percent of new books published in Taiwan, putting more than 400 titles on the shelves each week.

She preferred to see a reduction, not an increase, in these figures, said Wu, adding that, in deciding what titles to put on the shelves, the company would choose the really good ones and do a better job promoting them for a longer period of time.
At a time when there are frequent cultural exchanges between Taiwan and China, she said Eslite would stick to its focus on books and culture.
One of the Eslite bookstores in central Taipei is open around the clock and has become an attraction for locals and tourists alike. The company was established in 1989.
Monocle, an international English-language magazine that covers culture and design, has described the Eslite bookshop as "the most advanced and exceptional store in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical pact damaging to Taiwan's Chinese medicine doctors: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 21:27:38 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The freshly inked cross-strait medical cooperation agreement has left many Taiwanese skeptical about its effects, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday.
The DPP claimed most supporters of both political camps are dubious about China' s intention to hold up its end of the deal.

The sixth round of cross-strait negotiation ended in Taipei after Chairman Chiang Pin-kung of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and President Chen Yunlin of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits signed a medical cooperation agreement.

The pact will facilitate exchanges of information on disease outbreak as well as cooperation in the development of vaccines against contagious diseases. The agreement also said based on the same standards, both sides can join hands in the clinical trials of new drugs.
The critics honed in on Chapter Four of the pact which stipulates the burden of quality control on imported Chinese medicines to either side will fall on the importers.

"Such arrangement is dangerous because it contains a loophole to allow a small number of inspection groups in China to monopolize the market and manipulate the prices, " said DPP Spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang, calling for a safeguard measure to be included in the agreement.
According to a survey conducted by the party's own poll center, 88 percent of the 665 respondents do not believe China will meets its commitments as outlined in the agreement, he said.
Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei also slammed the arrangement by calling it a "clandestine scheme" to pave the way for Chinese medicine doctors to open shop in Taiwan.

"The agreement will allow China to send in their own Chinese medicine doctors and medical supplies to Taiwan. By doing so, it will for sure adversely impact the livelihood of the Chinese medicine industry in Taiwan," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan taekwondo athlete Yang suspended for three months (update)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 21:52:00 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun was given a three-month suspension Tuesday by the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) for protesting her disqualification during the 2010 Guangzhou Asian Games, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Tuesday at a press conference.
Yang was punished for staging a sit-in protest in the competition area Nov. 17 after she was disqualified on grounds of wearing extra electronic sensors in her socks.

The WTF ruling means that Yang will not be allowed to compete in any international sports events for the next three months. Her coach Liu Tsung-ta was slapped with a 20-month suspension, effective immediately.
The Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) was fined US$50,000 for "negligence and wrongdoing, " according to an email sent Tuesday by the WTF to inform the CTTA of its ruling.

In the email, WTF President Choue Chungwon also said that the committee had "found evidence of various attempts, in particular in the Taiwan media, to negatively incite and manipulate public perceptions."
According to the WTF, it's Sanctions Committee found Yang guilty of two separate violations -- using illegal equipment and interfering with the management of the competition.

"The suspension is not likely to affect my chances of competing in the 2014 London Olympics, but I feel sorry for my coach because he is obliged to stand up for his athletes, " said Yang, with tears rolling down her cheeks at the hastily called press conference.
Yang, 25, said that despite the "light" suspension, the WTF's accusation of her cheating was hard to swallow. "But it seems that I can't do anything at this moment to prove my innocence," she said.
Yang said she will have to consider whether or not to try to participate in the London Olympics.

CTTA President Chen Chien-ping said at the press conference that the penalty was "harsher than we had expected" but the CTTA was ready to pay the fine before the Jan. 31, 2011 deadline to ensure the participation of Taiwan athletes in future competitions.
SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling said the 20-month suspension against Liu was a severe punishment and the SAC and the CTTA are mulling their next move to overturn the decision.
The WTF's Sanction Committee, comprising Egyptian, Israel and Turkish officials, reviewed the Yang issue Dec. 18 in Seoul, South Korea in a meeting that included Yang, Liu and Chen.

WTF officials said Yang had violated the competition rules by wearing extra electronic sensors on her socks during her opening bout to score more points, but video footage later showed she did not have the sensors on during the match.
After the decision, Yang refused to leave the ring. Contradictory statements by taekwondo officials explaining the disqualification later sparked outrage in Taiwan.
Taiwan has officially filed an appeal with the Lausanne-based Court of Arbitration for Sport against the disqualification.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 more Chinese tourists allowed to enter Taiwan per day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:01:59 (By Charles Kang, Chen Ching-fang, Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Beginning on January 1, 2011, the number of Chinese tourists allowed to enter Taiwan each day will increase by 1,000 to 4,000, according to an agreement reached between the two sides Tuesday.
The increase is part of the agreements sealed in the sixth round of meetings between top negotiators from Taiwan and China since June 2008. The current talks are being held at Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Formal talks between the negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei- based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- began Tuesday.

The two sides also agreed to move quickly on negotiations on Taiwan's plan to allow visits by individual Chinese travelers, saying the plan would be implemented as soon as there is an appropriate date next year.
At a press conference, Chiang said the plan for individual Chinese tourists to visit designated locations would likely materialize around June.
The original target date was around the Lantern Festival on February 17, but there was not enough time for preparations, he said.
With the approach of lunar New Year holidays in early February, both sides agreed to start negotiations in the next few days on a proposal to increase the number of cross-strait flights.
The decision to increase the daily number of Chinese tourists is applauded by local tour operators, some of whom call for a review in six months leading to a further increase.
Hsu Kao-ching, secretary general of the Travel Agent Association of Taiwan, said travel agencies had hoped for the daily quota to be expanded to 5,000.

Lee Kuang-tsai of the Taipei-based Lion Travel Service Co. said, however, after taking into consideration the current capacity of domestic hotels and tour buses, he thinks the ceiling of 4,000 Chinese tourist visits per day is appropriate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chen Yung-chi named top pick in 2010 Taiwan baseball draft
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:08:40 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Former United States minor leaguer Chen Yung-chi was named the top pick by the Uni-President Lions in the 2010 Chinese Professional Baseball League draft Tuesday.

Kuo Yen-wen, 22, who played for the Cincinnati Reds from 2007-2010, was selected at No. 2 by La New Bears. He is known for his strong defense and is capable of covering three infield positions -- shortstop, second base and third base.
Sinon Bulls surprised everyone with its selection of the little-known amateur infielder Huang Chih-pei.

At No. 4 and the last pick of the first round, defending champion Brother Elephants picked 26-year-old Tseng Sung-wei, a right-hander with a 156km per hour fastball who spent three years with the Cleveland Indians from 2007-2010 before heading home.
A record 88 players were selected in the draft of the four-team professional league, which was established in 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: School principal suspended over alleged poor handling of bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:11:18 (By C. W. Hsu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Principal Wu Chia-ku of Bade Junior High School in Taoyuan County was removed from her post by the Ministry of Education Tuesday and ordered to wait for an investigation into her alleged mishandling of a series of bullying incidents at the school.

Yu was suspended from the post after a Ministry of Education (MOE) meeting that was held to discuss the matter. An MOE team is expected to investigate the allegations and submit a report in a week's time.

The principal came under investigation after 64 teachers from the school sent a petition Monday to Legislator Lo Shu-lei, accusing Yu of repeatedly turning a blind eye to campus bullying, and demanding that she be relieved of her duties.
The teachers said they had received death threats from students whom they had disciplined. It was the second report of violence at the school in a week.
Last week, the media reported that a drop-out from the school was being bullied and had been forced to take nude photos. Images of the victim being abused were broadcast on TV.
In an address to students and teachers of the school, Education Minister Wu Ching-ji said Tuesday that "school campuses must not be allowed to become lawless or unsafe environments."
The minister made an urgent visit to the school after the news of the teachers' petition broke Tuesday.

He suggested that schools call in law enforcement personnel if students breach the law. He urged teachers not to shirk their responsibility of educating students, saying students must be taught to have respect for the law, human rights, gender equality and life and this requires the joint efforts of families, schools and society.
"Most of the problematic students have trouble within their families and they tend to misbehave at school and could become lawbreakers when they enter the wider society," he added.

Admitting that campus bullying has grown more serious than he had imagined, Minister Wu said a national meeting of junior high school principals will be held next Monday to discuss ways of dealing effectively with the problem.
"Qualified teachers should have the skills to deal with campus bullying," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hopefuls eyeing Chen's vacant legislative seat
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:15:16 (By Wang Shu-fen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several hopefuls are eyeing a legislative seat to be vacated by Chen Chi-yu, who agreed Tuesday to serve as deputy mayor of the Kaohsiung municipality, which will be formed on Dec. 25 after a merger of Kaohsiung city and county.
Chen said he has accepted an offer by Mayor-elect Chen Chu to serve as her deputy and he will resign from his position in the legislature Wednesday.
Under the Civil Servants Election and Recall Act, a by-election must be held within three months of a regional lawmaker relinquishing his seat.
Local sources said aspirants to Chen's post are from both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Some of those who have shown interest include former DPP lawmakers Lin Tai-hua, Yen Wen-chang and Lee Kun-tse, and the KMT's Niaosong Township head Chang Mei- yao and Wang Yao-yu, who lost his bid last month for a seat on the Kaohsiung City council.

DOC.HEADLINE: New law mandates more female restrooms in public places
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:27:20 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Wang Shu-fen, Johnson Sun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An amendment bill cleared the legislative floor Monday, paving the way for more women's restrooms to be installed in public places.

According to the newly passed amendment to the Building Act, public facilities such as theaters and schools should have separate restrooms for males and females in a ratio of 1: 5, while smaller areas such as offices and restaurants should maintain a ratio of 1:3.
The washrooms are expected to be in place within five years, according to the law.

Commenting on the passage of the bill, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Daniel Hwang said a similar regulation under the Building Act has been in place for the past five years, but since it was an administrative decree, it was not necessarily followed, especially in cases where there were insufficient funds.
However, once the new law takes effect, budgets would have to be allocated for the relevant renovations, Hwang said.

In related news, the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) said a restroom remodeling project is underway at the Taipei Railway Station to change the men's to women's restroom ratio from the current 20: 48 to 23: 61. In addition, two restrooms for families and the disabled will be built and more diaper changing rooms will be added, he said.
The remodeling project is expected to be completed before the end of September 2011, the TRA said.
The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. also said that it will renovate its restrooms in the stations throughout the high speed rail network.

DOC.HEADLINE: Centennial bash to begin with big show on New Year's Eve
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:37:42 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A never-seen-before performance combining music, dance, fireworks, and multimedia technology will take place at Taipei's Dachia Riverside Park on the night of Dec. 31 to mark the beginning of the country's centenary celebrations, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Tuesday.

A brainchild of top artists from Asia including Lin Hwai-min, Lin Keh-hua, Cai Guo-qiang, Leo Cheung, and Wang Chia-min, the New Year's Eve celebration is a 50-minute, four-act show that seeks to "convey the cultural depth of Taiwan and its people, " CCA Minister Emile Sheng said at a press conference.
"This is a performance without any superstars or celebrities," he said. "But nearly 1,000 technical staff and performers will put on a show the likes of which have never been seen before."

The world's largest water screen, which is 200 meters wide, will be set up along the Keelung River and openly viewed for the first time at the performance. The names of 100,000 citizens and the performance of the night will be projected onto the giant screen.
The show will begin with the singing of the mother of aboriginal singer Samingad, followed by a dance, a drumming performance, and an ensemble of 400 children singing with Samingad in act four.
U-Theatre founder-director Liu Ruo-yu told reporters that drummers will have part of their bodies submerged in water for two minutes during their 10-minute segment, creating a very different sound.

Lin Keh-hua, artistic director of the New Year's Eve celebration, said the performance is about the relationship between people, Mother Nature and the universe, and through the combination of technology and art, he promises a splendid and spectacular night on the last day of the year.

Lin said the fireworks designed by Cai is certainly one of the highlights of the show, but when it is time for the final countdown, there will be a climax and "everything happens." Lin refused to give any details.
With only 8,500 seats set up for the outdoor performance, the best way for most people to enjoy it will be sitting at home and watching the live TV broadcast, the CCA advised.
The Republic of China was established on Jan. 1, 1912 following the overthrow of the Ching dynasty and encompassed mainland China until 1949.
After losing a civil war to the Communists that year, Chiang Kai-shek and his Kuomintang forces retreated to Taiwan where the ROC has continued to exist.
