In related news, the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) said a restroom remodeling project is underway at the Taipei Railway Station to change the men's to women's restroom ratio from the current 20: 48 to 23: 61. In addition, two restrooms for families and the disabled will be built and more diaper changing rooms will be added, he said.
The remodeling project is expected to be completed before the end of September 2011, the TRA said.
The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. also said that it will renovate its restrooms in the stations throughout the high speed rail network.

DOC.HEADLINE: Centennial bash to begin with big show on New Year's Eve
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/10 22:37:42 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A never-seen-before performance combining music, dance, fireworks, and multimedia technology will take place at Taipei's Dachia Riverside Park on the night of Dec. 31 to mark the beginning of the country's centenary celebrations, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Tuesday.

A brainchild of top artists from Asia including Lin Hwai-min, Lin Keh-hua, Cai Guo-qiang, Leo Cheung, and Wang Chia-min, the New Year's Eve celebration is a 50-minute, four-act show that seeks to "convey the cultural depth of Taiwan and its people, " CCA Minister Emile Sheng said at a press conference.
"This is a performance without any superstars or celebrities," he said. "But nearly 1,000 technical staff and performers will put on a show the likes of which have never been seen before."

The world's largest water screen, which is 200 meters wide, will be set up along the Keelung River and openly viewed for the first time at the performance. The names of 100,000 citizens and the performance of the night will be projected onto the giant screen.
The show will begin with the singing of the mother of aboriginal singer Samingad, followed by a dance, a drumming performance, and an ensemble of 400 children singing with Samingad in act four.
U-Theatre founder-director Liu Ruo-yu told reporters that drummers will have part of their bodies submerged in water for two minutes during their 10-minute segment, creating a very different sound.

Lin Keh-hua, artistic director of the New Year's Eve celebration, said the performance is about the relationship between people, Mother Nature and the universe, and through the combination of technology and art, he promises a splendid and spectacular night on the last day of the year.

Lin said the fireworks designed by Cai is certainly one of the highlights of the show, but when it is time for the final countdown, there will be a climax and "everything happens." Lin refused to give any details.
With only 8,500 seats set up for the outdoor performance, the best way for most people to enjoy it will be sitting at home and watching the live TV broadcast, the CCA advised.
The Republic of China was established on Jan. 1, 1912 following the overthrow of the Ching dynasty and encompassed mainland China until 1949.
After losing a civil war to the Communists that year, Chiang Kai-shek and his Kuomintang forces retreated to Taiwan where the ROC has continued to exist.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 22, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Shah Jahan, the mighty Mogul emperor of India who built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz-i-Mahal, dies at the age of 74.
1771: Spain agrees to cede the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to Britain.
1775: Andre Ampere, the French physicist and discoverer of electromagnets who gave his name to the "amp" as a unit of electricity, is born.
1901: After a 64-year reign, Queen Victoria, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight at the age of 81.
1905: Tsarist troops fire salvo after close-range salvo into a crowd in St. Petersburg, Russia, leaving the snow red with the blood of at least 500 strikers.
1922: Pope Benedict XV, originally Giacomo della Chiesa, who sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace, dies in Rome. He was succeeded by Pope Pius XI.
1924: Ramsay MacDonald becomes Britain's first Labor prime minister, replacing Stanley Baldwin.
1935: After long negotiations, Japan pays 140 million yen for Soviet interests in the Chinese Eastern Railway, the last legal trace of Russian influence in Manchuria.
1944: Allied landings begin at Arizo, Italy, involving an estimated 50,000 U.S. and British troops.
1945: More than 500 U.S. warplanes launch air-raids on Okinawa and Taiwan.
1945: The land route to China -- the Ledo Road across Burma from India to China -- reopens.
1946: U.S. President Harry Truman orders the establishment of the Central Intelligence Agency.
1949: The guerrilla army of China's Mao Tse-tung marches toward Beijing after crossing the Yangtze River to defeat the Nationalist army at Huai Hai north of Beijing.
1955: Adm. Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, says that the United States will help defend Taiwan if attacked following the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Washington on Dec. 3, 1954.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a professor at National Taiwan University, and two students, are charged with subversion against the government by military prosecutors.
1973: Prince Tuipelehake, C.B.E., prime minister of the Kingdom of Tonga, arrives in Taipei for a one-week visit.
1973: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th U.S. president, who succeeded John F. Kennedy, dies of a heart attack in Texas at the age of 64.
1975: Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper and the Fuji Television Corporation of Japan, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1979: Demonstrations are held at Kaohsiung railway station and Chiaotou township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County against the arrest of Yu Teng-fa for sedition.
1980: Dr. Andrei Dimitrievich Sakharov, the Soviet physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, is arrested, stripped of his honor and banished to Gorky from Moscow. An outspoken advocate of human rights and nuclear disarmament, he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the offshore island county of Penghu, killing 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in 20 years, and the Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help the victims.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives the chiefs of administrative branches under the Executive Yuan, and urges them and other government officials to persevere in discharging their duties and to endeavor to promote political reform.
1990: The Yugoslav Communist Party renounces its monopoly on power after 45 years of rule.
1996: The Pentagon announces for the first time the size of the U.S. chemical weapons arsenal, and says all 3.6 million weapons will be destroyed by 2004.
2000: Taiwan's Wei Yun-chieh shoots a five-under-par 67 to win the Chunghua Cup Women's Golf Tournament, the first leg of the 2000 Women's Asian Circuit, with a three-day total of 213.
2001: ROC Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping conveys his congratulations to Ang Lee, a Taiwan-born director whose "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" won the 58th Golden Globe best director and best foreign film awards.
2002: U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance William H. Lash, III arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
2002: Republic of Chad Ambassador to the Republic of China Hissein Brahim Taha presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Those who know it are not as those who love it; those who love it are not as those who find their joy in it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Dialogue mechanism needs adjustment
DOC.DATELINE: 12/22/10 11:05:27 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 22, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The sixth round of talks between the chief negotiators of Taiwan and China, Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, concluded Tuesday with the signing of a medical and health care cooperation agreement. Though the limited number of agreements reached has drawn much criticism, it nevertheless highlights the necessity to adjust the cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue mechanism.

Negotiations on future agreements are expected to become more and more difficult. Examples are the suspension of negotiations on a double taxation avoidance agreement and the slow progress in negotiations on an investment protection pact. Similar deadlocks are bound to emerge in upcoming negotiations on trade in goods and services.

Under these circumstances, the two sides should stop setting a time frame for completing negotiations, and future dates for the Chiang-Chen talks should be flexibly arranged instead of meeting regularly twice a year.

With a total of 15 agreements having been sealed through six rounds of Chiang- Chen talks, implementing these pacts will be a more important issue than promoting new ones. Using the dialogue platform to regularly review the progress of implementation will ensure that the agreements produce their best results.

Furthermore, cross-strait negotiations on political issues, such as the signing of a peace accord and setting up military confidence building measures, will probably become unavoidable in the future. It is therefore imperative for the government to properly plan and prepare for them. There should be no further delay based on the pretext "the time is not ripe for cross-strait political talks."

DOC.HEADLINE: EU journal publishes notice of Taiwan visa exemption
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 11:59:31 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Union published its decision to include Taiwan in its visa-waiver program in its official journal on Wednesday, confirming that Taiwan passport holders can visit 35 European countries without needing a visa beginning in January.

"The imposition of the visa requirement on the citizens of Taiwan is no longer justified, as, in particular, the territory does not represent any risk of illegal immigration or threat to public policy for the Union," the EU said in justifying the decision.
According to the EU regulations, Taiwan's inclusion in the Schengen Area visa- waiver program will take effect 20 days after the notice was published in the Official Journal of the European Union.
That means Republic of China (Taiwan) passport holders will be able to travel to Europe visa free beginning on Jan. 11, 2011, the country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
The preferential treatment does not extend, however, to the small minority of holders of Taiwan passports that do not have an identity card number.

To include Taiwan in the visa-waiver program, the EU added it to the list of countries eligible for the program in Annex II of the regulations under the category "Entities and territorial authorities that are not recognized as states by at least one member state."
The visa waiver allows local travelers to enter countries covered under the exemption for up to 90 days within a six-month period without a visa.

The exemption applies to 25 Schengen Area countries, comprising 22 EU member states and three non-EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland -- and three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
It also includes seven smaller European countries and territories -- the Vatican, Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.
Because the EU is Taiwan's fourth largest trade partner, the visa-waiver treatment is expected to have a positive effect on bilateral commerce and tourism.

President Ma Ying-jeou said earlier this month that the EU visa exemption is an important milestone in the country's diplomatic history, one that he believed would contribute to bilateral trade and cultural exchanges.
The visa exemption drive took off in July when the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, put forth a concrete bill to include Taiwan in the visa-waiver program.
The proposal then went through a 15-step process and cleared its last hurdle on Nov. 25 when the Council of the European Union passed it unanimously without debate.

European Parliament Speaker Jerzy Buzek and Belgian Secretary of State for EU Affairs Oliver Chastel signed the bill on Taiwan's inclusion in the EU visa- waiver program in Strasbourg, France Dec. 15.

The EU inclusion brings the number of countries and territories offering Taiwanese citizens visa exemptions to 96, with 75 granting Taiwan passport holders visa-waiver privileges and 21 others allowing travelers to obtain visas at their ports of entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Silicon wafer firm could list U.S. unit in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Sherman, Texas, Dec. 21 (CAN) 12/22/10 12:37:30 (By Maranda Hsu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Sino-American Silicon Products Inc. (ASA) said Tuesday it is planning to publicly list Texas-based subsidiary GlobiTech Inc. on the back of the unit's strong profitability and mentioned Taiwan as a possible target.
SAS Chairman M.K. Lu said his company did not rule out having GlobiTech, a provider of silicon epitaxy products, launch a primary listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

Speaking at a ceremony launching GlobiTech's second plant, Lu said the U.S. unit is expected to deliver a return on equity (ROE) of 20 percent in 2010 and 35 percent in 2011, after turning a profit last year.
SAS acquired financially troubled GlobiTech for US$45 million (NT$1.19 billion) in April 2008 and helped turned the company around to post net earnings of about US$1 million in 2009.
Lu said GlobiTech is expecting net income of US$11 million on sales of US$72 million in 2010, and he predicted sales would rise to US$100 million in 2011.
He said the company's sales per employee exceeded NT$20 million (US$669,482) , even higher than SAS's sales per employee of NT$10 million.
According to Lu, because GlobiTech procures 90 percent of its silicon wafer needs from SAS, the acquisition had created synergies for both companies.

GlobiTech President Doris Hsu said GlobiTech will serve as a "golden key" for SAS to gain access to global buyers, as GlobiTech's customers include Texas Instruments, NXP Semiconductor and SoiTech Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to assist Burkina Faso in developing photovoltaic industry
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/22/10 13:10:17 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to share its experiences with Burkina Faso in the development of the photovoltaic industry and work with it to establish the sector in the West African country, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.

Enjoying abundant sunlight, Africa is a good place to develop the industry that creates electricity in the most modern way, Wu said while discussing a visit the previous night to a city road equipped with solar street lamps -- gifts from Taiwan.

Lucas Chiu, the general manager of Taiwan-based Speed Tech Corp. who had accompanied Wu on his trip to Africa, said Burkina Faso has an average of six hours of sunlight per day, higher than in Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and its neighbors and highly favorable for the development of solar power.

With one hour of sunlight, a photovoltaic product can work for three to four hours, said Chiu, who disclosed that his company is preparing to build a factory in Burkina Faso to produce photovoltaic devices and equipment.

Wu, heading an 18-member delegation, is on a one-week visit to the diplomatic ally. He represented President Ma Ying-jeou at the inauguration ceremony of Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore on Dec. 20.
Wu is the first Taiwanese premier to visit the West African ally since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994.
Earlier Tuesday, Wu conferred the Order of Brilliant Star on his Burkinabe counterpart Tertius Zongo, and Zongo awarded him with a medal in exchange.
Wu said he felt honored to receive the award, which he said represented the friendship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's chief negotiator visits Flora Expo amid tight security
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 13:17:37 (By Lin Shen-hsu, Charles Kang, Chou Yung-chieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, visited the Taipei International Flora Exposition Wednesday amid tight security in anticipation of protests by pro-independence groups.

Chen, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, was accompanied by his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.

It was Chen's last stop on his three-day visit to Taiwan, during which he participated in a sixth round of talks with Chiang and signed a medical and health care cooperation agreement with Taiwan on behalf of China.
Chen said he was deeply impressed with the creativity, new technologies and care and concern for humanity displayed by the Flora Expo.
According to Hau, Chen promised to publicize the exhibition's "power of beauty" to the Chinese people after returning to China.
The mayor said Chen was received as an important guest, but no special arrangements were made to prevent him from seeing the Republic of China flag.
A total of 394 policemen were dispatched inside and outside the exhibition areas as well as major road junctions leading to the areas, according to the Taipei City Police Department.
The purpose of the large police force was aimed at protecting Chen's safety and preventing any possible accidents, police said.
Two groups of protesters waited to no avail for Chen on Zhongshan North Road and at the expo's main entrance, because of the tactics adopted by police.

Also Wednesday, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah told legislators that 1,525 policemen were deployed to maintain security during this latest visit by Chen, compared with 6,131 officers during his previous visit in 2009 and 8,752 officers during his first visit in 2008.

The declining need for a huge police deployment indicates that cross-Taiwan Strait talks are becoming increasingly acceptable to Taiwanese society, with protesters gradually replacing violent means of protest with more peaceful ones, Jiang said.

On an incident in which a protester who shouted "Taiwan, China, one country on either side" was moved away by police, the minister explained that the action was taken because the protester was trying to break through a police blockade rather than because he shouted the pro-independence slogan.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Airlines to launch flights to Wuhan Jan. 26
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 14:04:25 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: China Airlines, one of Taiwan's leading international airlines, will launch regularly scheduled flights between Taipei and Wuhan, China on Jan. 26, 2011, the company said Wednesday.
The carrier will operate two round-trip flights a week to Wuhan, which will become its 17th destination in China.

China Airlines said the new route reflected its interest in adding flights to second-tier Chinese cities, such as Wuhan, and in taking advantage of growing demand from the tourism sector for flights between Taiwan and China.
It sees Wuhan, one of China's ancient cities, as an attractive destination because it has long been a tourism center and is the largest city in central China.
The city is also conveniently located and offers quick connections northward to Beijing, southward to Guangzhou, eastward to Shanghai and westward to Chongqing, the carrier said.
China Airlines said it will offer a 12 percent discount on economy class fares on the new route, to be served by Airbus A330-300 aircraft, until the end of February.
Rival EVA Airways launched flights to similar second-tier cities -- Zhengzhou in Henan Province and Jinan in Shandong Province -- earlier this month.
As of Nov. 30, China Airlines operated a fleet of 66 aircraft and offered flights to 94 destinations in 28 countries worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to take measures to stop campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 16:03:22 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has paid close attention to a recently reported case of bullying at a junior high school in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, and has vowed to eliminate violence from the campus, according to a statement released Wednesday.
It has ordered the Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to work out measures and an efficient mechanism to stop campus bullying, the statement said.
Such bullying has undergone a substantial negative change in terms of the behavior, scale and frequency of occurrence in Taiwan, according to the Executive Yuan.
No time should be wasted in resolving the problem, the Executive Yuan said.
Last week, local media reported that a drop-out from Bade Junior High School was being bullied by a group of students and had been forced to pose for nude photos.

The MOE removed school principal Wu Chia-ku from her post Tuesday after 64 teachers from the school sent a joint petition to a lawmaker the previous day, accusing her of repeatedly turning a blind eye to the worsening campus bullying.
The teachers said they had also received death threats from students they had disciplined. It was the second report of violence at the school in a week.

Education Minister Wu Ching-ji said Wednesday that it has instructed the National Police Agency to have local police departments around the country put elementary and middle high schools on the list of their regular patrol checkpoints.
In addition, the MOE has activated a national emergency reporting mechanism for campus bullying to allow the relevant authorities to take immediate response measures, Wu noted.
"Only with determination can we make bullying disappear, " he said while answering questions from reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Cooperation with China in the news

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese LED street lamp alliance reportedly has signed a letter of intent with a Taiwan affairs task force under China's Fujian provincial government on cooperation in building a world-class LED lighting company.

The Taiwan alliance is eyeing the potential 500 billion yuan (NT$2.3 trillion) opportunity in the sector expected to be generated by China's next five-year development plan, which includes upgrading the LED industry as one of its major goals.

Also on Tuesday, China Postal Airlines inaugurated direct flight services between Fuzhou, Fujian Province and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to meet the rapidly growing demand for speedy postal services amid increasing trade and tourism exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, following the signing of an agreement in Taipei on cross-strait medical and health care cooperation on Tuesday, China's Ministry of Health announced that it will unveil a set of regulations in January that will help facilitate the development of Taiwan-funded hospitals in China.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:

Upstream LED company Epistar revealed Tuesday that China's central government held its first-ever open tender for LED products in November. Although all of the 28 winning bidders were Chinese-funded companies, many of them have promised to use Epistar's crystalline grains.
That means that the company will be able to take part in China's government- funded green light projects, an Epistar executive said,

In line with China's new drive to promote energy conservation and carbon reduction, many of China's provincial and city governments have also approached Taiwanese companies in the LED supply chain for possible collaboration, industry sources said.

Besides Epistar, other major LED companies, including Delta, Formosa Epitaxy, UNi LED Desklamp, Everlight and LIGITek, will also benefit from China's new clean energy promotion campaign, the sources said. (Dec. 22, 2010).
China Times:
A China Postal Airlines all-cargo B737 plane landed at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 10:10 a.m. Tuesday, a flight that ushered in speedier postal services across the Taiwan Strait.
Hereafter, the carrier will operate two round-trip flights between Fuzhou and Taoyuan per week using a B737 all-cargo aircraft, its local ground service agent China Airlines said.

The inauguration of the new flight service marks a further improvement in cross- strait postal services since Taiwan and China resumed direct postal links on Dec. 15, 2008 after a decades-long hiatus. (Dec. 22, 2010).
Commercial Times:
China began to promote medical service reform last year, with its government pledging to invest 850 billion yuan over three years to improve the country's medical and health care services.
According to official Chinese estimates, China's medical and health care service market will grow at an annual rate of 24 percent in the coming five years.

China's Ministry of Health said it will help Taiwanese investors get a slice of that big pie. Among the measures will be allowing the establishment of hospitals fully owned by Taiwanese investors in China.

Industry sources said the Taiwan Business Association in Dongguan, Guangdong is planning to acquire the shares held by local Chinese authorities in a hospital in Dongguan once China's new policy is put into force. (Dec. 22, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.37 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 16:20:44 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.37 percent Wednesday as buying ignited by overnight Wall Street gains rotated to the bellwether electronics sector, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 32.70 points to 8,860.49, after moving between 8,834.32 and 8,865.42, on turnover of NT$129.99 billion (US$4.35 billion).

The market opened up 0.22 percent as investors took cues from Wall Street's more-than two-year overnight high and bargain hunting focused on select high- tech stocks to push the index to the day's high, the dealers said.
However, institutional investors cut their holdings in old economy stocks to compromise the early gains ahead of the nearest technical resistance at 8,900 points, they said.
A total of 2,424 stocks closed up and 1,833 were down with 380 remaining unchanged.

The machinery and electronics sector scored the highest gains, ending up 0.7 percent. Cement stocks rose 0.3 percent, financial stocks added 0.2 percent, and the paper and pulp sector closed up 0.1 percent.
However, textile and construction stocks fell 0.5 percent and foodstuffs lost 0.3 percent, while plastics and chemicals closed unchanged.
Horizon Securities analyst Benson Huang said touch-panel makers were highlighted by buying interest after recent consolidation.
"In addition to their attractive valuations, investors have high hopes that their sales will continue to grow next year as these firms are riding rising demand for Apple iPads," Huang said.

However, large-cap old economy stocks suffered heavier pressure after recent significant gains posted by hopes that a rising New Taiwan dollar will boost the value of their domestic assets, Huang said.

"The selling came as no surprise as the index had moved closer to the critical 8,900-9,000 point range, " Huang said. "Unless buying in large-cap high-tech stocks resumes, the market is expected to continue to move in a narrow range," Huang said.
Among the touch-panel stocks, Sintek Photronic gained 2.00 percent to close at NT$25.50 and Young Fast Optoelectronics closed up 1.23 percent to finish at NT$288.00.
In the construction sector, Kuo Yang Construction fell 1.44 percent to end at NT$24.00 and Kindom Construction lost 1.36 percent to finish the day at NT$32.55.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll shows stronger support among Hong Kongers for Taiwan's UN bid
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 16:59:21 (By Wang Man-na and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: More Hong Kong residents have become supportive of Taiwan's efforts to rejoin the United Nations and fewer are now identifying as Chinese since China authorities blocked Liu Xiaobo from accepting the Nobel Peace Prize, according to a survey released this week.

The Hong Kong University poll conducted earlier this month found that 42 percent of Hong Kongers backed Taiwan's bid to become a UN member, which represented a 5 percent increase from similar polls in September.

The increase in support for Taiwan's efforts could have resulted from the fact that China refused to free dissident Liu Xiaobo from prison to attend the Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony in Norway, said Robert Chung, director of the Public Opinion Programme at the university.
The poll also found that 63 percent of Hong Kong residents consider themselves "Hong Kongers" rather than "Chinese, " compared to 57 percent six months ago.
According to the recennt survey, 35 percent see themselves as either "Chinese in Hong Kong" or "Chinese, " a drop of 8 percentage points from a similar survey in June.
Chung said China's treatment of Liu was most likely also responsible for the slide.

In addition, he said, the good performance of Hong Kong athletes at the Guangzhou Asian Games last month and a hostage situation in the Philippines in August involving 15 Hong Kong tourists could have contributed to the stronger sense of Hong Kong identity among residents of the special administration region of China.
The telephone survey collected 1,000 valid samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's chief negotiator wraps up Taiwan visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 17:21:21 (By Feng Chao, Kuo Mei-lan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, left Taipei to return to Beijing Wednesday after wrapping up a three-day visit here.

The main purpose of Chen's visit, the third of its kind since 2008, was to hold the sixth round of talks with his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and sign a medical and health care cooperation agreement with Taiwan on behalf of China.

Chen, the president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said prior to his departure that the ARATS and SEF will continue negotiating a cross-strait investment protection pact, which was expected to be signed at the Chiang-Chen meeting but was delayed because of bilateral differences.
According to Chen, many important issues still await the handling of the two intermediary bodies, with various difficulties and obstacles expected on the road ahead.
But while those obstacles could stall the speed of progress, they will never change the trend of peace across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said.

He said the 15 cross-strait agreements signed by the ARTS and SEF over the past two years have obtained the understanding and support of many Taiwanese people, and he promised to continue to seek to improve the well-being of people on both sides of the strait.
Taiwan's Chiang said the latest medical and health care agreement was aimed at enhancing the physical well-being of the people.

Noting that people on the two sides have exchanged more than 6 million visits so far this year, Chiang said setting up a system for disease reporting and emergency care was essential to protecting people's lives.
The agreement will also allow the health and medical sectors of the two sides to work together to explore new business opportunities, Chiang said.
He said the SEF will continue to promote cross-strait exchanges and negotiations on other agreements.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC approves Japanese company's TDR listing proposal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:09:43 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Wednesday that it has approved an application filed by Japan-based memory chip maker Elpida Memory, Inc. to list its Taiwan depositary receipts (TDRs) on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE).

According to the FSC, the company is planning to issue 180 million to 200 million TDRs, each one of which will represent 0.05 common shares of the company, which has been listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange since November 2004.
If the TDR listing plan is realized, Elpida will become the first Japanese firm to issue depositary receipts in Taiwan.
In November, when the Japanese firm filed an application for the listing, underwriter KGI Securities said it expected the listing to take place in the first quarter of next year.
However, KGI Securities was not immediately available to give further details about the listing after the FSC issued the greenlight to the proposal.
Based on local regulations, the FSC has a final say on TDR listing applications after the central bank and the TWSE.

Elpida, which was set up in 1999 through an integration of the DRAM businesses of NEC and Hitachi, aims to raise up to NT$3.6 billion (US$120 million) from the TDR listing, according to the company's prospectus.

It is planning to use the proceeds for research and development of next- generation DRAM chips, the company said, adding that the new technology is expected to lower production costs and maintain its lead in the business.
Currently, Elpida ranks as the world's third-largest DRAM maker.
Elpida said in an earlier statement that it expects the TDR listing to enhance the company's presence in Taiwan, not only among business clients but also among local investors.

Elpida and Taiwan-based Powerchip Technology Corp. have set up a joint venture called Rexchip Electronics Corp., while the Japanese firm has also built alliances with Winbond Electronics Corp. and ProMOS Technologies Inc. of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Schengen visa waiver to take effect Jan. 11: EETO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:14:20 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The visa waiver privilege for Taiwan passport holders to the Schengen Area and three European Union (EU) member states will take effect Jan. 11, 2011, the EU's representative office in Taiwan said Wednesday.

The decision to lift visa requirements for Taiwan citizens will be published in the Dec. 22 issue of the Official Journal of the EU and will take effect 20 days from that date, said Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) in Taipei.
"We finally know the first day that Taiwan visitors will be able to visit Europe without a visa," he said. "That will be the 11th of January next year."

He said that an expected rise in the number of Taiwanese visitors to the EU signals a need to increase the number of flights between Taiwan and the EU -- the world's largest economy with 500 million inhabitants.
The visa waiver allows Taiwanese travelers to enter countries covered under the exemption for stays of up to 90 days within a six-month period.

The exemption applies to 25 Schengen Area countries, comprising 22 EU member states and three non-EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland -- and three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
It also includes seven smaller European countries and territories -- the Vatican, Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.
Ledoux announced the start date of the visa waiver at the launch of a comic journal, which coincided with the publication of Taiwan's visa exemption in the Official Journal of the EU.

The comic journal was published by Taiwanese cartoonist Wan Wan, who was named Goodwill Ambassador to the EU and was invited by the EETO to visit seven European countries from June 16 to July 5 this year on a 20-day tour. The journal is a humorous account of her trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: November jobless rate falls to 4.73 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:21:33 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate in November fell to 4.73 percent, mainly on a decline in the number of business closures and downsizing under the improving local economic situation, the government said Wednesday.

Last month, the unemployment rate was 0.19 percentage points lower than October and down 1.13 percentage points from a year earlier, according to tallies from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Taiwan's jobless rate fell below 5 percent in October for the first time since November 2008 as the local economy staged a strong rebound from the global financial meltdown.

In November, the number of jobless totaled 527,000, down 19,000 from October, with the number of unemployed affected by business downsizing and closures falling 9,000 from a month earlier, the DGBAS said.
After seasonal adjustments, the jobless rate stood at 4.79 percent in November, down 0.17 percentage points from October and also down 1.14 percentage points from a year earlier, the agency added.
Last month, the jobless rate among people with junior high school education or below was 4.32 percent, and 5.10 percent among those with senior high school education or below, the DGBAS said.
During the same period, the jobless rate among college graduates or above was 4.66 percent, while among university graduates or above it was 5.32 percent, the DGBAS said.
In November, a total of 10.61 million people were on payroll, up 45,000 from September and 236,000 from a year earlier.
In the first 11 months of this year, the average jobless rate stood at 5.26 percent, down 0.60 percentage points from a year earlier.
Earlier this year, Premier Wu Den-yih said the government was determined to reduce unemployment to below 5 percent by the end of this year, or he would step down to assume responsibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Even healthy people should have health checks: doctors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:24:41 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: People should get regular medical check-ups even if they feel they are in good shape, doctors said in a press conference held following the detection of several kidney tumors in healthy persons who had physical examinations.

It is not unusual for people with tumors to feel fit and strong, said Chen Kuo- chiang, a urologist at Cathay General Hospital (CGH) , citing the case of a 56 -year-old male who had a tumor weighing 1.3 kg yet showed no signs of abnormality before undergoing the check-up.

If not removed, it is likely that the man would have suffered from a stroke in the near future, said Chen, referring to the 24cm x 15cm x 14 cm tumor that was pressing against his internal organs and blood vessels.
"I want to stand up and call on people to go for health checks, " said the patient, Hung Chiang-kun, who is slowly recovering from surgery.

Hung's boss had suggested that he to go for a thorough physical examination and would pay for half of the cost. "He thought I had dropped a few pounds, but I was energetic and felt well, " said Hung, who added that he is glad he listened to his employer's advice.

Lin Shing-huey, chief of family medicine at CGH, said that a lot of companies work with hospitals to provide annual health checks for their employees. "Some businesses even cover the whole cost, " said Lin, urging everyone to take the opportunity to look after themselves.

According to Lin, many health problems can be detected through health examinations, including cardiovascular disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol levels and cancer. "We should keep in mind that some of these are among the top 10 causes of death in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Santa Claus has come to town -- from Finland
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:36:42 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Celebrating Christmas has made strides in Taiwan, but it is still rare for the country's children to have their picture taken with Santa Claus, let alone with one coming from Santa's home in Finland.
This year marked the first time that the Finland Trade Center, a Taipei-based trade office, has brought a "genuine Santa from Finland's Lapland" to Taiwan, according to the office.

"The idea is to provide as genuine as possible a Christmas feeling to the people in Taiwan, and also introduce a bit of the Christmas culture, " the center's representative Jari Seilonen told the Central News Agency.

Some 400 groups of families or couples in Taiwan will be able to have their photo taken with the visiting Santa and a magic elf in the Xinyi shopping district's Chanti Square on Dec. 25 and 26, according to the event's sponsor, Citibank Taiwan.
Those who want to do so need to make an appointment at a booth on the square before Dec. 25. A booth employee said the sizes of groups applying have ranged from two to 10 people.
"Some people immediately called their friends after signing up to encourage them to sign up as well," he said.
To welcome the Santa Claus, Citibank Taiwan has built a Christmas City on the square that consists of a post office and a sled pulled by four fake reindeer.
It also features a Christmas tree with two 120-inch LED screens showing text messages sent by the public to convey their best wishes to their loved ones.
Many were already seen gathering at the square, bathed in blue lights, to take photographs of these installations at night.
The Finnish Santa, who arrived in Taiwan on Dec. 18, has come here to do more than pose for pictures. During his nine-day stay, he is also visiting local schools and hospitals.
On Thursday, for example, he will visit children cancer patients at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei and Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.

"Arranging the authentic Santa to go to the hospitals is to inspire all the ill children to have the courage to fight for their lives, " said Louis Ma, general manager of Event Design and Marketing Execution, the organizer of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: President firmly behind disqualified taekwondo athlete
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:41:58 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed his full support for Yang Shu-chun, the taekwondo athlete disqualified at the 2010 Asian Games, and has asked government agencies to do all they can to protect her rights through all possible legal means, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Wednesday.

Yang, who refused to leave the mat after being disqualified for allegedly wearing two extra electronic sensors during a bout in the women's under 49-kg division in November and who later lodged a protest with the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) over the disqualification, was barred from competition for three months Tuesday.
Her coach Liu Tsung-ta was punished with 20-month suspension, while the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) was fined US$50,000.
Yang said Tuesday that she felt sorry about the development and complained about the harsh punishment for Liu but called for an end to the matter.

As to the question of whether she will take part in the 2012 Olympic Games in London, Yang said she needs time to consider, as the WTF verdict has failed to clear her name, which will affect her chances in the games.

Commenting on the WTF ruling, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Tai Hsia- ling said that same day that the council will definitely seek to have Yang's case heard by the Switzerland-based Court of Arbitration for Sports (CAS) , to which the council has already applied for an appeal against the disqualification.
"The Sports Affairs Council does not accept the verdict and will not give up any opportunity to protect Yang's rights," Tai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 18:48:07 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, gaining NT$0.005 to close at NT$30.605.
Turnover totaled US$825 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.650 and moved between NT$29.860 and NT$30.655 before the close.

The New Taiwan dollar increased its strength in early trade from the previous session but the gains were compromised by selling by foreign banks, including Citibank, HSBC and Standard Chartered Bank, dealers said.

It is possible that the bank selling could have been prompted by fund remittances entrusted by Carlyle Group, a U.S. private equity fund, which started to remit funds out of Taiwan after closing a deal to sell a local cable TV operator for a reported NT$65.3 billion (US$2.19 billion), they added.
Taiwan's central bank a day earlier approved an application from Carlyle to send the funds arising from the deal out of the country.
Dealers said the fund withdrawal by Carlyle might continue over the next few trading sessions and is expected to place further downward pressure on the New Taiwan dollar.

Carlyle's move led to a reduction in the central bank's efforts to intervene in the local foreign exchange market in a bid to maintain the value of the U.S. dollar above the NT$30.00 level to protect Taiwan's exports, they said.
Quiet trade in other markets in the region because of the approaching Christmas holiday is expected to keep the New Taiwan dollar in a range trade for the rest of this week, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP criticizes Beijing for employing 'two-faced' strategy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei. Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 19:00:23 (By Wen Kuei-hsiangm Kui Mei-lan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition party criticized Beijing Wednesday for adopting a "two- faced" strategy in its dealings with Taiwan.

"It is a form of political manipulation for China to deploy missiles against Taiwan, on one hand, while asking for talks with Taiwan on removal of the missiles, on the other, " said Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan.
The criticism came one day after Taiwan and China's top cross-strait negotiators met in Taipei and signed a medical and health-care agreement.
It was the 15th pact between the two sides since rapprochement began following the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008.

The missile issue arose when Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, paid a courtesy call Tuesday on Mainland Affairs Council Minister Lai Shin-yuan, whom he refused to call by her official title.

During the meeting, Lai said the missiles that China has deployed along its southeastern coast pose a great threat to the people of Taiwan and should be removed in the interest of good cross- strait relations.
Lai also urged China to pay greater attention to the Taiwan people's deep desire for more international space.

In response, Chen, a former director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said both sides have to "sit down and talk" about removing the missiles as there is no agreement in place that officially allows an end to cross-strait hostility.
He said Beijing "is happy to see Taiwan play a greater role on the international stage, " once it would not lead to the creation of "two Chinas".

The DPP, which has long advocated independence for Taiwan and has been wary of official contact with China, is seen as changing its China policy to increase its chance of winning Taiwan's 2012 presidential election.

A recent announcement by DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen that the party will set up a think tank to study how the DPP should engage with China has given some weight to the perception of a DPP policy change.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for Dec. 22

TEXT.P: bid 12.China's chief negotiator wraps up Taiwan visit 13.FSC approves Japanese company's TDR listing proposal 14.Taiwan's Schengen visa waiver to take effect Jan. 11: EETO 15.November jobless rate falls to 4.73 percent 16.Even healthy people should have health checks: doctors 17.Santa Claus has come to town -- from Finland 18.President firmly behind disqualified taekwondo athlete 19.U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex 20.DPP criticizes Beijing for employing 'two-faced' strategy 21.Cross-strait political talks some way off: MAC 22.Taiwan's book fair to embrace Bhutanese literature 23.Lawmakers concern over Taiwan's FTA strategy, South Korea competition 24.Government aware of price increase of glutinous rice: COA 25.Police should use reasonable force when facing provocation 26.Lawmakers, DPP offer suggestions for preventing campus bullying

DOC.HEADLINE: Police should use reasonable force when facing provocation: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:11:05 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Worthy Shen and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Police have the right to use reasonable force to protect themselves when they encounter deliberate provocation, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday at the Legislative Yuan.

The use of force by the police is necessary when facing assault by gangsters or anyone who refuses to obey the public authorities, Jiang said in response to an incident in which three plainclothes police officers were beaten up by a group of 11 thugs in eastern Taiwan's Yilan County.
One of the officers, Chen Ching-yu, a substitute service draftee, took a photograph of the main suspect, surnamed Chuang, for not wearing helmet while riding a scooter two days earlier.

Chuang, aged 20, later contacted his friends and launched an attack on the officers using knives, police said, adding that the two policemen suffered minor injuries while Chen received lacerations to his head.
One of the officers, Li Chi-nan, said he identified himself as a police officer at the start of the altercation but only managed to halt the assault when he drew his gun.

Police in Yilan County will not tolerate any acts of violence and will strengthen a crackdown on criminal offenses and organizations to improve public safety, Yilan Deputy Magistrate Wu Tse-cheng said while visiting Chen in hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government monitoring price hike in glutinous rice: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:19:11 (By Justin Su and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Prices of sweet rice dumplings, traditionally eaten on the winter solstice in Taiwan, have risen by 10 percent-30 percent this year, but the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday that they are still under control.

The statement was made by COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung after a lawmaker cited complaints from the public about the price increase, which are result of a hike in the price of glutinous rice, one of the main ingredients in the product.

Taiwan produced more than 58,000 metric tons of glutinous rice this year, over 15,000 metric tons short of the amount required to meet demand, Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung said at a legislative yuan session.
The COA should have responded to the situation earlier, according to Ting.
Part of the glutinous rice sold in Taiwan in the past years was imported, said Chen, who added that global prices have gone up because a drought in Thailand has caused a shortage.
However, the COA has been monitoring he increase, which is not out of control, Chen noted.

The council has not yet allowed newly imported glutinous rice to go on sale, as some local farmers are still harvesting their crops and the imports might cause the price of the domestic crop to fall, he added.
This year, the winter solstice falls on Dec. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers, DPP offer suggestions for preventing campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:40:16 (By Hsu Chih-wei, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A lawmaker suggested Wednesday that a formal statute be established to provide guidelines for handling bullying incidents in schools.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kuo Su-chun put forward the proposal at a meeting of the legislature's Education and Culture Committee, saying that the government should assemble an inter-ministerial team to draft the bill.
The problem of bullying in schools cannot be solved by the Ministry of Education alone, Kuo said.

Her views were supported by KMT Legislator Chiang Nai-hsin, who said bullying has become embedded in the social structure and cannot be addressed without the help of the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Agency and the Ministry of the Interior.
There should be a specific statute, modeled the Domestic Violence Prevention Act, to prevent and control campus violence, he suggested.
He said the existing laws related to child and juvenile welfare are inadequate for dealing with the problem of school bullying.
Also on Wednesday, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that the problem lies with the educational system, which has ignored the bullying issue for a long time.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said that when he was a student at Bade Junior High School in Taoyuan County it was a simple and respectable school.
Now the image of the school has been tarnished by a series of bullying incidents that have been widely reported, he said.
He said the problem arose in part from the school administration's ignorance in the face of violence and its leniency toward the perpetrators.
He suggested that the school administration, Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih- yang and county officials in charge of educational affairs engage in deep self- reflection.

Tsai Chi-chang, also a DPP spokesman, urged the government to assign professional student counselors to schools and implement a system for reporting bullying incidents. In addition, campus safety should be one of the indices in the performance assessments of principals and local police chiefs, he suggested.
Last week, the media reported that a drop-out from Bade Junior High School was being subject to severe bullying. Images of the victim being abused were broadcast on TV.
Principal of the school, Wu Chia-ku, was suspended from her post Tuesday and ordered to wait for an investigation into her alleged mishandling of a series of bullying incidents at the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers worried about Taiwan's FTA strategy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:57:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Legislators expressed concern Wednesday about Taiwan's strategy in its efforts to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with its trading partners and to compete with South Korea.

Taiwan is lagging behind South Korea, which signed an FTA with the European Union (EU) in October and is scheduled in January to ratify an FTA that it inked with the United States (U.S.) four years ago, said Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Despite Taiwan's historic trade pact with China and the ensuing FTA negotiations with Singapore, Taiwan has made little progress in terms of its broader FTA drive, Lin said in a session of the Foreign and National Defense Affairs Committee of the legislature.

Taiwan has four FTAs with its five Central American allies. In June this year, it inked an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China and in August began to explore the possibility of an FTA with Singapore.
But compared to South Korea, its toughest economic rival in Asia, Taiwan lacks an effective strategy, according to some of the legislators in the session.
However, Deputy Economics Minister Francis Kuo-hsin Liang said there are other factors that must be taken into account.

"South Korea has always been a threat to us, " he conceded. However, while around one third of South Korean exports to the U.S. overlap with Taiwanese products, the total value of the South Korean products "is not as much as people believe," he said.
In the EU market, the situation is almost the same, he said. In other words, the effect of South Korea's FTAs with the two major economies of the U.S. and EU is not that great, Liang said.
"On the other hand, South Korea is concerned about being at a disadvantage in the Chinese market since Taiwan and China signed the ECFA, "Liang said.
Deputy Foreign Minister Thomas Ping-fu Hou said in the session that it is easier for South Korea to seek FTAs because it has official diplomatic relations with more countries.
The Taiwan government has said that its primary targets for FTAs are the U.S., the EU, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).

But KMT legislators Shuai Hua-min and Liao Wan-ju warned Wednesday against pursuing as many FTAs as possible without employing a strategy that would comprehensively weigh the pros and cons of trade liberalization.
"The FTA drive should not be a game of numbers, " Shuai said.
Shuai also urged the government to use the ECFA to gain a better foothold in China, which does not have FTAs with either South Korea or Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait political talks some way off: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:00:50 (By Feng Chao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must forge an internal consensus and build fully fledged mutual trust with China before it is in a position to start cross-Taiwan Strait political talks, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Wednesday.

Lai's remarks came after the United Daily News reported that same day that Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , told Lai during a meeting in Taipei the previous day that as no concrete agreements have been worked out by Taiwan and China to end their hostilities, the two sides must hold negotiations on that issue.

Lai met Chen during a meeting with delegates from both sides who were holding their sixth round of systematic talks in Taipei. Chen was the top delegate of the Chinese mission, which concluded its three-day negotiation with the Taiwanese delegation led by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung Wednesday.
According to the newspaper, Lai renewed Taiwan's urging for China to remove its missiles targeting Taiwan and to reduce its interference in Taiwan's participation in international activities.
The MAC chief said she raised the issues with Chen in a bid to help him understand that this is an issue of prime concern to Taiwan's people.
"I have repeatedly made it clear in public that China can take the initiative to deal with its missiles aimed at Taiwan, " she said.
SEF and ARATS representatives signed a medical and health cooperation agreement Tuesday in their sixth round of negotiations to better ensure drug safety and bolster two-way health-care cooperation.
It was the 15th agreement signed by the SEF and ARATS since June 2008 after President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency sees more job offers than job seekers in Q4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:10:26 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan had more job vacancies than applicants in the fourth quarter of this year for the first time in four years for the October-December period, Taiwan's largest online manpower agency said Wednesday.
"This year is a special case because there are usually not many job openings in the fourth quarter, " said 104 Job Bank public relations manager Max Fang.

He attributed the reasons to a recovering economy, a surge in the number of temporary jobs in the service sector for the Lunar New Year holiday in February and the government's short-term recruitment measures.

His remarks came as Taiwan reported its latest jobless rate Wednesday, with the November rate falling to 4.73 percent, mainly on a decline in the number of business closures and a reduction in downsizing on the back of the improving economic situation.
According to the agency's figures for December, the number of job offers has hit 359,000 so far, a rise of 10,000 from the previous month.
The number of job seekers in December fell to 278,000, down 37,000 from last month, the figures show.
Fang said the category of finance-related jobs saw the highest supply and demand ratio of 3.4, which means that one job applicant has 3.4 job offers on average.
The beauty salon category came in second at 2.9, followed by the category of construction planning jobs (1.7) and sales jobs (1.7).

DOC.HEADLINE: 154 aboriginal cultural sites to be assessed for heritage value
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:29:21 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) unveiled Wednesday a list of 154 aboriginal cultural heritage sites that will be assessed for potential archaeological value and heritage preservation.
The list comprises 127 tangible heritage sites and 27 intangible heritage items, said Wang Shou-lai, head of the CCA's preparatory office for cultural heritage preservation department.

Aboriginal cultures are an important part of Taiwan's cultural heritage and the CCA attaches great importance to the preservation of heritage sites associated with Taiwan's 14 officially recognized indigenous tribes, he said.

Through site surveys and the compilation of archival documents, professors Kuang Hua-shan of Tungshai University and Wang Sung-shan of Taipei National University of the Arts have compiled the list of Taiwan's aboriginal cultural heritage sites and items in terms of underlying value, belief systems, lifestyles, artifacts and legends, Wang said.

"Their research serves as an important reference for the preservation of our indigenous cultures, " Wang said. "The professors have also drawn up strategies for short-, mid-, and long-term preservation."
The Cabinet-level council will distribute the list to local governments for follow-up survey and research for formal listing as heritage sites or items in the future, he added.
All of the 154 newly recommended heritage sites and items are highly fascinating, Wang said.

Among the intangible heritage items, for instance, is a nose flute, a special musical instrument used by the Paiwan tribe, he said. Traditionally, only male members of the chieftain's family were permitted to play the instrument which has a snake-like sound.

Three aboriginal sites -- the Puyuma tribe relics in Mount Malatan in Taitung County, Tao tribal settlements on Orchid Island and the Paiwan tribe's stone- slab houses -- have been added to a list of 18 items that will be submitted to the United Nations for recognition as world heritage sites.

In October 2009, the council picked 10 non-tangible cultural heritage sites, including Atayal tribal legends, Bunun ballads, Ami tribe's annual harvest festivities and Saisiyat tribe's dwarf spirit ceremony, which will also be sent to the U.N.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek, MStar forecast to face fierce competition for talent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:36:43 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) designers will face fierce competition for skilled workers as more Chinese firms are expected to enter the 3G chip market next year, the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) said Wednesday.

"IC designers such as MediaTek Inc. and MStar Semiconductor Inc. will have to make strong efforts to keep or recruit talent in China's highly competitive 3G chip market, " MIC Industry Consultant Deputy Director Chris Hung told the CNA on the sidelines of a press conference.

This is because the Chinese government is preparing to help local IC designers develop 3G communications, while international chipmakers like Qualcomm have managed to cut their product prices in a bid to strengthen their shares in the China market, he said.

"Chinese IC designers seem to be more attractive to Taiwanese employees because of better wages and benefits, especially as Taiwan workers have not been receiving as big a share of company profits as in the past," Hung said.

On Tuesday, MStar Chairman Wayne Liang said the company plans to launch its first chips for use in 3G mobile phones in the first half in 2011. The move is expected to set the stage for direct competition with the country's biggest handset chip designer, MediaTek, which currently dominates China's 2G handset chip market.
MStar chips are used in the production of consumer electronic products such as flat panel TVs, monitors and cell phones.
The company, which is registered in the Cayman Islands, operates primarily in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and most of its products are exported to China, South Korea and the United States.

According to a study by the MIC, the global semiconductor market will reach an estimated US$291 billion in 2010 with a year-on-year growth of 28.6 percent. But the figure is expected to hit US$308 billion in 2011, representing a moderate year-on-year grow of 5.8 percent due to stabilized demand for consumer devices.

In addition, Taiwan's semiconductor market is forecast to grow by 32 percent to NT$1.6 trillion (US$53.6 billion) this year, but in 2011 the growth will slow down to 6.2 percent with an estimated total value of NT$1.7 trillion, the MIC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Invitation to host flag-raising ceremony an honor: business leaders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:41:47 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Two prominent business executives, Alex Lo and Rose Tsou, said Wednesday they are honored to have been invited to host the flag-raising ceremony at the Presidential Office plaza on New Year's Day.
Lo, general manager of Taiwan's largest food maker Uni-President Enterprises Corp, and Tsou, managing director of Yahoo Asia, promised to deliver a unique performance.
At a press conference in Taipei, they told reporters that the invitation was a surprise because "hosting a national ceremony is not something we are particularly good at."
Tsou said that when she was a university student, she participated in the national flag raising ceremony several times and she is very excited about playing a bigger part in the upcoming one.
For his part, Lo said he is nervous about speaking in front of thousands of people at the ceremony because it is very different from presiding at a company meeting.
"But celebrating the nation's 100th birthday is very meaningful, therefore, I will do my best to make the ceremony interesting and different," he promised.
He said many of his company's employees are planning to attend the ceremony because he will be co-hosting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan journalists hit back at WTF officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 22:46:23 (By Oscar Wu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan journalist association hit back at the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) Wednesday over a comment about sports reporting in Taiwan, advising WTF officials to "watch your words and beware of your behavior."

The Chinese Taipei Sports Journalism Federation was upset by WTF accusations that Taiwanese media were fanning anti-Korean sentiments in their reports about the disqualification of Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun at the Asian Games in Guangzhou, China in November.

In a decision published Tuesday, the WTF slapped a 3-month ban on Yang and a 20-month suspension on her coach Liu Tsung- ta for staging a ringside protest after Yang was disqualified during a match in the 49-kg division event.

Upset by the WTF's implications that the Taiwanese media were manipulating their reports about the controversial event, the Taiwanese sports journalist association lodged a protest with WTF President Chungwon Choue.
The group said Taiwanese journalists have been reporting the controversy over Yang's disqualification on the basis of facts and eye witness accounts.
It is regrettable that the WTF has used biased and provocative language to allude to the Taiwanese media, the sports journalism federation said.
It urged Choue to take note of the fact that Taiwan is a democracy in which all citizens enjoy freedom of expression.
All the Taiwanese media that covered the Yang Shu-chun incident had sent their own reporters to Guangzhou and they worked independently without bias, the federation said.
The group said the Asian Taokwondo Union's accusation against the Taiwanese athlete was wrong and that WTF Secretary General Yang Jin-suk had hurt the Taiwan team at the Asian Games in Guangzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV channel has license revoked over embedded advertising
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 22:47:59 (By C. W. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The National Communications Council (NCC) decided to revoke the operating license for the Comprehensive Channel of the ERA TV over repeated acts of embedded advertising, the official broadcast watchdog announced Wednesday.
According to spokesman Chen Cheng-chang, the NCC decided to make the move -- the first of its kind since its establishment four years ago -- coupled with a fine of NT$2.1 million.
The channel was found to have violated relevant regulations 49 times, with fines totaling NT$167.5 million (US$5.49 million) when it applied for a licence renewal in November last year, Chen said.
The NCC agreed in February to renew the channel's license for one year on condition that there would be no more violation for that period, he said.
Against this backdrop, the NCC decided to withdraw the license for the channel after it was caught engaging in the same practice again.
The NCC demanded the channel stop operations in July after it was found to have breached regulations three times from February to June.
The channel did not comply and has continued its broadcast, forcing the NCC to impose a new fine of NT$2.1 million, Chen said.
The ERA TV said it would file an administrative appeal against the NCC decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to take 40% share of world's large-sized panel market in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 23:06:05 (By Stacey Wu and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese makers of large-sized panel displays are forecast to take 40 percent of the global market next year, the Market Intelligence & Consulting Institute (MIC) said Wednesday.
Local manufacturers of the small and medium-sized panels, however, are expected to adopt a "diversifying" strategy as a result of reduced shipments caused by weak demand, MIC said.

The world market for large-sized panels will increase by 10 percent in 2011, with 85 percent of the total market being shared by the top four markers of the world -- South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co, and LG Display Corp. and Taiwan's AU Optronics Corp. and Chimei Innolux Corp., it added.

Taiwanese providers of the large-sized panels, in the face of sharp competition from their Japanese and Korean counterparts, will likely see a mere 6 percent increase in their shipments, the MIC said.
Shipments of local small- and medium-sized panels, less then 40 inches, will fall by 12 percent due to competition from China, it added.
As a result, providers of the small-sized panels will try to shift to producing such other devices as e-readers, touch panels or active matrix organic light emitting diode (AMOLED), the MIC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to join trial of new drug against oral cancer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 23:16:57 (By Chen Ching-fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will join six other nations that are participating in the third-stage clinical trial of a new drug to treat late-stage oral cancer, a leader of the program said Tuesday.

Hao Sheng-po, president of the Asian Society of Head and Neck Oncology, said that the new drug is meant to work by stimulating the immune systems of patients, before resorting to treatments such as surgery, chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
It is hoped that the patients' own immune systems will suppress the growth of the cancer cells, he said.
Orient Europharma Co., the agent for the U.S.-produced drug, said that in the second-stage clinical trials, the cancer cells in 12 percent of the patients disappeared completely.

On average, the cancer cells in all the patients in the test group shrunk by 50 percent, the agent said. Follow-up tests showed that the patients survival rate increased by an average of 33 percent, it said.
It will be the first large-scale trial that would prioritize immune therapy over other treatments.

Eighty-eight patients in seven hospitals in Taiwan, including Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial hospital, National Taiwan University Hospital, Mackay Memorial Hospital, Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Changhua Christian Hospital, National Cheng Kung University Hospital, Kaohsuung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, will take part in the third-phase trial of the new drug, representing 10 percent of the international test group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regular salary up for 12 consecutive months
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 23:17:26 (By Lin Hui-chun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese wage earners' regular salary rose in October by 1.62 percent from a year earlier to a monthly average of NT$36,480 (US$1,220), marking the 12th consecutive increase, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said Wednesday.
The DGBAS said their average salary -- NT$40,035 (US$1,338 ) in October, was up 0.47 percent but down 7.12 percent from the previous month, when most workers received a Moon Festival bonus.

The government statistics agency said during the first ten months of this year, the average monthly salary was NT$44,919, an increase of 5.87 percent over the same period of last year. Of that amount, the regular salary was NT$36,205, up 1.92 percent from a year earlier.
Taiwan wage earners' average substantive salary from Jan. through Oct. of 2010 grew 4.94 percent year-on-year, the largest growth in 17 years, according to the DGBAS.
Liu Tien-tzu, a bureau director of the DGBAS, said the ten-month average salary was about the same as in 2007, though a bit lower than the 2008 figure of NT$45,290.
During the Jan.-Oct. period of this year, Taiwan wage earners' average monthly salary was NT$36,205, compared with NT$36,279 in 2007 and NT$36,600 in 2008, Liu said.
Asked why most people do not feel they are making as much as NT$44,000, Liu said the average salary includes non-regular income such as year-end bonuses and performance-related bonuses.
"If these bonuses are evened out into each month's income, they would feel their salary is slightly higher," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government monitoring price hike in glutinous rice: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:19:11 (By Justin Su and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Prices of sweet rice dumplings, traditionally eaten on the winter solstice in Taiwan, have risen by 10 percent-30 percent this year, but the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday that they are still under control.

The statement was made by COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung after a lawmaker cited complaints from the public about the price increase, which are result of a hike in the price of glutinous rice, one of the main ingredients in the product.

Taiwan produced more than 58,000 metric tons of glutinous rice this year, over 15,000 metric tons short of the amount required to meet demand, Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung said at a legislative yuan session.
The COA should have responded to the situation earlier, according to Ting.
Part of the glutinous rice sold in Taiwan in the past years was imported, said Chen, who added that global prices have gone up because a drought in Thailand has caused a shortage.
However, the COA has been monitoring he increase, which is not out of control, Chen noted.

The council has not yet allowed newly imported glutinous rice to go on sale, as some local farmers are still harvesting their crops and the imports might cause the price of the domestic crop to fall, he added.
This year, the winter solstice falls on Dec. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers, DPP offer suggestions for preventing campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:40:16 (By Hsu Chih-wei, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A lawmaker suggested Wednesday that a formal statute be established to provide guidelines for handling bullying incidents in schools.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kuo Su-chun put forward the proposal at a meeting of the legislature's Education and Culture Committee, saying that the government should assemble an inter-ministerial team to draft the bill.
The problem of bullying in schools cannot be solved by the Ministry of Education alone, Kuo said.

Her views were supported by KMT Legislator Chiang Nai-hsin, who said bullying has become embedded in the social structure and cannot be addressed without the help of the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Agency and the Ministry of the Interior.
There should be a specific statute, modeled the Domestic Violence Prevention Act, to prevent and control campus violence, he suggested.
He said the existing laws related to child and juvenile welfare are inadequate for dealing with the problem of school bullying.
Also on Wednesday, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that the problem lies with the educational system, which has ignored the bullying issue for a long time.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said that when he was a student at Bade Junior High School in Taoyuan County it was a simple and respectable school.
Now the image of the school has been tarnished by a series of bullying incidents that have been widely reported, he said.
He said the problem arose in part from the school administration's ignorance in the face of violence and its leniency toward the perpetrators.
He suggested that the school administration, Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih- yang and county officials in charge of educational affairs engage in deep self- reflection.

Tsai Chi-chang, also a DPP spokesman, urged the government to assign professional student counselors to schools and implement a system for reporting bullying incidents. In addition, campus safety should be one of the indices in the performance assessments of principals and local police chiefs, he suggested.
Last week, the media reported that a drop-out from Bade Junior High School was being subject to severe bullying. Images of the victim being abused were broadcast on TV.
Principal of the school, Wu Chia-ku, was suspended from her post Tuesday and ordered to wait for an investigation into her alleged mishandling of a series of bullying incidents at the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers worried about Taiwan's FTA strategy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 20:57:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Legislators expressed concern Wednesday about Taiwan's strategy in its efforts to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with its trading partners and to compete with South Korea.

Taiwan is lagging behind South Korea, which signed an FTA with the European Union (EU) in October and is scheduled in January to ratify an FTA that it inked with the United States (U.S.) four years ago, said Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Despite Taiwan's historic trade pact with China and the ensuing FTA negotiations with Singapore, Taiwan has made little progress in terms of its broader FTA drive, Lin said in a session of the Foreign and National Defense Affairs Committee of the legislature.

Taiwan has four FTAs with its five Central American allies. In June this year, it inked an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China and in August began to explore the possibility of an FTA with Singapore.
But compared to South Korea, its toughest economic rival in Asia, Taiwan lacks an effective strategy, according to some of the legislators in the session.
However, Deputy Economics Minister Francis Kuo-hsin Liang said there are other factors that must be taken into account.

"South Korea has always been a threat to us, " he conceded. However, while around one third of South Korean exports to the U.S. overlap with Taiwanese products, the total value of the South Korean products "is not as much as people believe," he said.
In the EU market, the situation is almost the same, he said. In other words, the effect of South Korea's FTAs with the two major economies of the U.S. and EU is not that great, Liang said.
"On the other hand, South Korea is concerned about being at a disadvantage in the Chinese market since Taiwan and China signed the ECFA, "Liang said.
