Deputy Foreign Minister Thomas Ping-fu Hou said in the session that it is easier for South Korea to seek FTAs because it has official diplomatic relations with more countries.
The Taiwan government has said that its primary targets for FTAs are the U.S., the EU, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).

But KMT legislators Shuai Hua-min and Liao Wan-ju warned Wednesday against pursuing as many FTAs as possible without employing a strategy that would comprehensively weigh the pros and cons of trade liberalization.
"The FTA drive should not be a game of numbers, " Shuai said.
Shuai also urged the government to use the ECFA to gain a better foothold in China, which does not have FTAs with either South Korea or Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait political talks some way off: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:00:50 (By Feng Chao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must forge an internal consensus and build fully fledged mutual trust with China before it is in a position to start cross-Taiwan Strait political talks, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Wednesday.

Lai's remarks came after the United Daily News reported that same day that Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , told Lai during a meeting in Taipei the previous day that as no concrete agreements have been worked out by Taiwan and China to end their hostilities, the two sides must hold negotiations on that issue.

Lai met Chen during a meeting with delegates from both sides who were holding their sixth round of systematic talks in Taipei. Chen was the top delegate of the Chinese mission, which concluded its three-day negotiation with the Taiwanese delegation led by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung Wednesday.
According to the newspaper, Lai renewed Taiwan's urging for China to remove its missiles targeting Taiwan and to reduce its interference in Taiwan's participation in international activities.
The MAC chief said she raised the issues with Chen in a bid to help him understand that this is an issue of prime concern to Taiwan's people.
"I have repeatedly made it clear in public that China can take the initiative to deal with its missiles aimed at Taiwan, " she said.
SEF and ARATS representatives signed a medical and health cooperation agreement Tuesday in their sixth round of negotiations to better ensure drug safety and bolster two-way health-care cooperation.
It was the 15th agreement signed by the SEF and ARATS since June 2008 after President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency sees more job offers than job seekers in Q4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:10:26 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan had more job vacancies than applicants in the fourth quarter of this year for the first time in four years for the October-December period, Taiwan's largest online manpower agency said Wednesday.
"This year is a special case because there are usually not many job openings in the fourth quarter, " said 104 Job Bank public relations manager Max Fang.

He attributed the reasons to a recovering economy, a surge in the number of temporary jobs in the service sector for the Lunar New Year holiday in February and the government's short-term recruitment measures.

His remarks came as Taiwan reported its latest jobless rate Wednesday, with the November rate falling to 4.73 percent, mainly on a decline in the number of business closures and a reduction in downsizing on the back of the improving economic situation.
According to the agency's figures for December, the number of job offers has hit 359,000 so far, a rise of 10,000 from the previous month.
The number of job seekers in December fell to 278,000, down 37,000 from last month, the figures show.
Fang said the category of finance-related jobs saw the highest supply and demand ratio of 3.4, which means that one job applicant has 3.4 job offers on average.
The beauty salon category came in second at 2.9, followed by the category of construction planning jobs (1.7) and sales jobs (1.7).

DOC.HEADLINE: 154 aboriginal cultural sites to be assessed for heritage value
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:29:21 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) unveiled Wednesday a list of 154 aboriginal cultural heritage sites that will be assessed for potential archaeological value and heritage preservation.
The list comprises 127 tangible heritage sites and 27 intangible heritage items, said Wang Shou-lai, head of the CCA's preparatory office for cultural heritage preservation department.

Aboriginal cultures are an important part of Taiwan's cultural heritage and the CCA attaches great importance to the preservation of heritage sites associated with Taiwan's 14 officially recognized indigenous tribes, he said.

Through site surveys and the compilation of archival documents, professors Kuang Hua-shan of Tungshai University and Wang Sung-shan of Taipei National University of the Arts have compiled the list of Taiwan's aboriginal cultural heritage sites and items in terms of underlying value, belief systems, lifestyles, artifacts and legends, Wang said.

"Their research serves as an important reference for the preservation of our indigenous cultures, " Wang said. "The professors have also drawn up strategies for short-, mid-, and long-term preservation."
The Cabinet-level council will distribute the list to local governments for follow-up survey and research for formal listing as heritage sites or items in the future, he added.
All of the 154 newly recommended heritage sites and items are highly fascinating, Wang said.

Among the intangible heritage items, for instance, is a nose flute, a special musical instrument used by the Paiwan tribe, he said. Traditionally, only male members of the chieftain's family were permitted to play the instrument which has a snake-like sound.

Three aboriginal sites -- the Puyuma tribe relics in Mount Malatan in Taitung County, Tao tribal settlements on Orchid Island and the Paiwan tribe's stone- slab houses -- have been added to a list of 18 items that will be submitted to the United Nations for recognition as world heritage sites.

In October 2009, the council picked 10 non-tangible cultural heritage sites, including Atayal tribal legends, Bunun ballads, Ami tribe's annual harvest festivities and Saisiyat tribe's dwarf spirit ceremony, which will also be sent to the U.N.

DOC.HEADLINE: MediaTek, MStar forecast to face fierce competition for talent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:36:43 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) designers will face fierce competition for skilled workers as more Chinese firms are expected to enter the 3G chip market next year, the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) said Wednesday.

"IC designers such as MediaTek Inc. and MStar Semiconductor Inc. will have to make strong efforts to keep or recruit talent in China's highly competitive 3G chip market, " MIC Industry Consultant Deputy Director Chris Hung told the CNA on the sidelines of a press conference.

This is because the Chinese government is preparing to help local IC designers develop 3G communications, while international chipmakers like Qualcomm have managed to cut their product prices in a bid to strengthen their shares in the China market, he said.

"Chinese IC designers seem to be more attractive to Taiwanese employees because of better wages and benefits, especially as Taiwan workers have not been receiving as big a share of company profits as in the past," Hung said.

On Tuesday, MStar Chairman Wayne Liang said the company plans to launch its first chips for use in 3G mobile phones in the first half in 2011. The move is expected to set the stage for direct competition with the country's biggest handset chip designer, MediaTek, which currently dominates China's 2G handset chip market.
MStar chips are used in the production of consumer electronic products such as flat panel TVs, monitors and cell phones.
The company, which is registered in the Cayman Islands, operates primarily in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and most of its products are exported to China, South Korea and the United States.

According to a study by the MIC, the global semiconductor market will reach an estimated US$291 billion in 2010 with a year-on-year growth of 28.6 percent. But the figure is expected to hit US$308 billion in 2011, representing a moderate year-on-year grow of 5.8 percent due to stabilized demand for consumer devices.

In addition, Taiwan's semiconductor market is forecast to grow by 32 percent to NT$1.6 trillion (US$53.6 billion) this year, but in 2011 the growth will slow down to 6.2 percent with an estimated total value of NT$1.7 trillion, the MIC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Invitation to host flag-raising ceremony an honor: business leaders
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 21:41:47 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Two prominent business executives, Alex Lo and Rose Tsou, said Wednesday they are honored to have been invited to host the flag-raising ceremony at the Presidential Office plaza on New Year's Day.
Lo, general manager of Taiwan's largest food maker Uni-President Enterprises Corp, and Tsou, managing director of Yahoo Asia, promised to deliver a unique performance.
At a press conference in Taipei, they told reporters that the invitation was a surprise because "hosting a national ceremony is not something we are particularly good at."
Tsou said that when she was a university student, she participated in the national flag raising ceremony several times and she is very excited about playing a bigger part in the upcoming one.
For his part, Lo said he is nervous about speaking in front of thousands of people at the ceremony because it is very different from presiding at a company meeting.
"But celebrating the nation's 100th birthday is very meaningful, therefore, I will do my best to make the ceremony interesting and different," he promised.
He said many of his company's employees are planning to attend the ceremony because he will be co-hosting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan journalists hit back at WTF officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 22:46:23 (By Oscar Wu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan journalist association hit back at the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) Wednesday over a comment about sports reporting in Taiwan, advising WTF officials to "watch your words and beware of your behavior."

The Chinese Taipei Sports Journalism Federation was upset by WTF accusations that Taiwanese media were fanning anti-Korean sentiments in their reports about the disqualification of Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun at the Asian Games in Guangzhou, China in November.

In a decision published Tuesday, the WTF slapped a 3-month ban on Yang and a 20-month suspension on her coach Liu Tsung- ta for staging a ringside protest after Yang was disqualified during a match in the 49-kg division event.

Upset by the WTF's implications that the Taiwanese media were manipulating their reports about the controversial event, the Taiwanese sports journalist association lodged a protest with WTF President Chungwon Choue.
The group said Taiwanese journalists have been reporting the controversy over Yang's disqualification on the basis of facts and eye witness accounts.
It is regrettable that the WTF has used biased and provocative language to allude to the Taiwanese media, the sports journalism federation said.
It urged Choue to take note of the fact that Taiwan is a democracy in which all citizens enjoy freedom of expression.
All the Taiwanese media that covered the Yang Shu-chun incident had sent their own reporters to Guangzhou and they worked independently without bias, the federation said.
The group said the Asian Taokwondo Union's accusation against the Taiwanese athlete was wrong and that WTF Secretary General Yang Jin-suk had hurt the Taiwan team at the Asian Games in Guangzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV channel has license revoked over embedded advertising
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/10 22:47:59 (By C. W. Cheng and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 23, 2010, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar.
Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh cut off one of his ears in an epileptic attack.
1948: Japanese war criminal Eiki Tojo is executed.
1957: Republic of China Premier Yu Hung-chun is impeached by the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower is complete.
1974: The test-flight of B-1 bombers by U.S. pilots proves successful for the first time.
1986: Soviet human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov is released from exile and he returns to Moscow.
1989: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 09:19:05 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 30.92 points at 8,891.41 on a turnover of NT$3.62 billion (US$118.28 million).
The weighted price index gained 32.70 points, or 0.37 percent, to close at 8,860.49 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier wraps up Burkina Faso visit
DOC.DATELINE: Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/23/10 10:43:30 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih left Burkina Faso to return to Taiwan Wednesday after wrapping up a visit to the West African ally to attend the inauguration ceremony of its president.
Prior to his departure, Wu paid a visit to President Blaise Compaore, who was sworn in to a new term Dec. 20.
Compaore reiterated during the meeting his country's friendship with Taiwan and voiced his appreciation for the various development assistance provided by Taiwan.
He also acknowledged the positive contribution of bilateral cooperation in the political and economic areas and expressed hope that the scope of cooperation could be further expanded.
On his part, Wu conveyed congratulations on Compaore's re-election on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou and the Taiwnese people.

Wu said he hopes the two countries will continue their cooperation in areas such as agriculture, medical care, public health, vocational training, human resource development and photovoltaic power generation.
Wu is the first Taiwanese premier to visit the West African nation since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1994.
During his stay, Wu also hosted the completion ceremony for a Taiwan-funded vocational training center and visit a new hospital constructed with a loan from a Taiwanese bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSBC expects Taiwan's economy to grow 4.7 percent in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 12:51:00 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: HSBC said Thursday that it expected Taiwan's economic growth to moderate to 4.7 percent in 2011, after strongly rebounding in 2010, amid uncertainty over global demand.

HSBC has revised downwards the island's gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast for 2011 to 4.7 percent from an earlier estimate of 4.9 percent, while upgrading the 2010 forecast to 9.6 percent from an earlier forecast of 7.3 percent.
Donna Kwok, an economist for the Greater China division at HSBC, said that Taiwan's economy remained heavily exposed to the global tech cycle.
"Western manufacturers have recovered from their summer lull, but new problems in Europe are likely to linger, making 2011 uncertain for Taiwan's exporters," Kwok said.

According to HSBC, Taiwan's exports in 2011 are expected to grow 8.2 percent, compared with an estimated 31.7 percent jump in 2010, when the island benefited from a global economic recovery after a financial meltdown.
However, Taiwan's labor market seems to be recovering as the island's unemployment has declined to a near two-year low, Kwok added.
In November, Taiwan's jobless rate fell 0.19 percentage points from October to 4.73 percent.
In October, the jobless rate also fell below 5 percent for the first time since November 2008.
"Real wage growth has risen since February, helping to keep local commercial sales growth in the black," Kwok said.
"But much of the recovery to date has depended on global manufacturer restocking, which won't last forever," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sales of 3 Taiwan fabless IC firms to top US$1 billion: IC Insights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 14:38:53 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Among the 13 fabless IC suppliers worldwide, three Taiwan-based companies -- MediaTek Inc., Novatek Microelectronics Corp. and MStar Semiconductor Inc. -- are expected to post more than US$ 1 billion in sales each for 2010, IC Insights said Thursday.

According to the semiconductor market research company, MediaTek is expected to generate US$3.61 billion (NT$107.9 billion) in sales for 2010, up 3 percent from a year earlier, making it the fourth-largest fabless IC supplier among the 13 firms.

IC Insights also said that it expected Novatek to become the 11th largest firm among the 13 companies after posting US$1.15 billion in sales this year, up 40 percent from last year, while MStar is expected to become the 13th largest company in the industry after reporting US$1.06 billion in sales, up 75 percent from a year ago.
IC Insights said that the number of fabless firms whose sales were expected to exceed US$1 billion in 2010 will go up to 13 this year from 10 in 2009 and 8 in 2008.

The 13 suppliers are expected to post a combined US$41.4 billion in sales for this year. That amount accounts for 70 percent of sales of all the fabless IC companies in the world this year, the researcher said.
IC Insights said that nine out of the 13 IC firms were based in the United States, while one was headquartered in Europe. There are no Japanese companies on the list.
"It is obvious that the fabless/foundry business model has not significantly caught on in Japan, and, in IC Insights' opinion, is unlikely to do so in the near future," the research company said.
U.S.-based Qualcomm Inc. tops the ranking. It is expected to generate US$7.1 billion in sales for 2010, up 11 percent from 2009, according to IC Insights.

Since Taiwanese and Chinese IC design houses continue to expand, IC Insights said that an increasing number of Taiwan- and China-headquartered companies will eventually make their way into the list of the top fabless suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passport applications to be filed in person from 2011: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 14:58:26 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Starting in 2011, Taiwan citizens will be required to file their passport applications in person to confirm their identity, as part of Taiwan's efforts to be included in the U.S. visa waiver program, Deputy Foreign Minister Shen Lyu- hsun said Thursday.

The new procedure will be introduced on a trial basis between March and June 2011, and if it works well, it will be implemented officially in July, Shen said during a meeting of the legislature's Foreign and National Defense Committee.
Passport applicants will have two options, the first of which will be filing their documents in person at the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), he said.

Alternatively, they will be allowed to take their application forms to a local household registration office to have their identities confirmed before entrusting a travel agency or proxy to file the applications on their behalf, Shen said.

The United States has expressed concern over Taiwan's passport application and issuance procedure, which does not require applicants to appear in person. This loophole has allowed for rampant forgery of Taiwan passports, according to reports.
For this reason, the U.S. has said one of the conditions to inclusion in its visa-waiver program is that Taiwan citizens must file their passport applications in person.
Other factors that will be examined are visa refusal rates and the number of overstay cases involving Taiwan citizens, according to the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- New guidelines for defining death from overwork
DOC.DATELINE: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) 12/23/10 15:20:27 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: announced Wednesday new guidelines for defining "death from overwork" as an occupational disease, as part of its efforts to reduce labor-management disputes and better protect employees' rights and benefits.

The new guidelines will be applied in the case of a 29-year-old engineer at Nanya Technology Corp. who died earlier this year, said Fu Huan-jan, director of the CLA's Labor Safety and Health Department.

The engineer's relatives have been trying to have his case classified as "karoshi, " which means "death from overwork" in Japanese, saying that he had been working constant overtime hours for six months prior to his demise.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Many companies in the high-tech industrial sector often do not keep records of their employees' work hours on grounds that they adhere to a "responsibility system." Under this system, which employees are responsible for completing specific tasks, regardless of the time it takes, and therefore are not eligible to claim overtime.
This practice has caused controversy from time to time in cases of alleged death from overwork.

Fu said Wednesday the CLA has decided to change the guidelines for defining death from overwork and will now place the burden of proof on employers in order to reduce the incidence of occupational injury and death.

Under the new CLA regulations, the employer will be required to pay compensation payment to the family of the deceased if the employer is unable to provide solid evidence that the employee had not been literally worked to death.

The "karoshi" issue was highlighted in January when an engineer at Nanya Technology Corp. (NTC) was found dead in front of his computer at home. His parents said he had been putting in about 80 hours of overtime per month for six months.

Similar cases are not uncommon in the high-tech sector. More often than not, the family of the deceased is unable to claim labor insurance compensation because it is difficult for the courts and labor authorities to determine death as a result of overwork.

The CLA is expected to announce a decision soon in the case of the NTC engineer. If the CLA rules in favor of the family, the Bureau of Labor Insurance and Nanya Technology, a DRAM memory chip maker affiliated with the Formosa Plastics Group, will each have to pay the engineer's family the equivalent of 45 months of his salary. (Dec. 23, 2010).
Liberty Times:
The CLA said Wednesday it has decided to make it easier for doctors and investigators to classify a case as death or injury from overwork.
According to Fu, the CLA will follow the standards used in Japan, which include contributing factors such as abnormal working conditions, heavy short-term overwork, and long-term overwork.
Under these standards, long-term overwork is defined as 92 hours of overtime in the month before death, or 72 hours of overtime per month for two to six months before death.

Based on the new guidelines, the range of conditions that could be attributed to overwork will be expanded to include ischemic heart disease, severe cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac arrest, sudden cardiac death, cerebral hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, acute heart failure and aortic rupture. (Dec. 23, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei book fair to highlight Bhutanese literature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 15:55:33 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: When the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) opens on Feb. 9 next year at the Taipei World Trade Center, the spotlight will be on Bhutanese culture and literature, the organizers said Thursday.

The Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF) said it has invited three renowned Bhutanese writers -- Karma Ura, Kunzang Choden, and Yonden Dargye -- to attend the show, one of the world's largest annual book fairs.

In addition, the book fair will feature more than 300 Bhutanese publications, and for the first time, three of the Himalayan country's national treasures, said TBFF Executive Director Paulina Lin at a press conference.
One of the treasures is the Eight Thousand Verses of Transcendental Wisdom, a major Buddhist classic that dates back to the 12th century, Lin said.
She described Bhutan as a small country with strong faith, a place where people live in happiness and spiritual well-being.
"By showcasing books on Bhutanese culture, we hope local readers will get to know Bhutan better and learn some of its secrets to leading happier lives," she said.

Grace Huang, president of the Bhutan Office in Taiwan, said many people may think that Bhutanese do not read, but the truth is that the country's free education policy has helped to foster a reading habit.
Bhutan also has a thriving publishing industry that includes some 20 publishers, she said.

In total, some 100 international authors and 200 local writers are expected to take part in the 2011 TIBE, which is being sponsored by the Government Information Office. The fair will be held in three exhibition halls at the Taipei World Trade Center from Feb. 9-14.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: DPP's China policy at crucial juncture

TEXT.P: When the chief negotiators across the Taiwan Strait, Chiang Pin-kung of Taiwan and China's Chen Yunlin, first held talks in Taipei two years ago, the pro- independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party led massive protests against the meeting.

But similar scenes did not occur when Chiang and Chen met with each other in Taipei this week. During the run-up to last month's special municipality elections, the DPP did not even challenge the economic cooperation framework agreement signed with China in June, because surveys conducted by the DPP itself revealed that more than 50 percent of the public are in favor of the trade deal.

With two years having passed since cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue was resumed, the two sides have engaged in even closer economic exchanges. Furthermore, the possibility for de jure independence for Taiwan has completely vanished following failure by the pro-independence force to promote a referendum on a new constitution during the former DPP administration.
Under these circumstances, putting forward a pragmatic China policy is a major challenge facing the DPP leadership. This is an issue that the party cannot bypass when bidding for the 2012 presidency.
If the DPP backtracks to its old anti-China line, the party will probably lose the support of swing voters that it has managed to obtain over the past year. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares hit 31-month high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 16:52:33 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed higher Thursday, hitting a 31-month high, amid active rotational buying in a market awash in liquidity, dealers said.

The weighted index closed up 38.38 points, or 0.43 percent, at 8,898.87, the highest level since May 22, 2008, after moving between 8,874.87 and 8,914.34, on turnover of NT$133.62 billion (US$4.47 billion).

The market opened up 0.35 percent after Wall Street recorded a new two-year high, and the momentum pushed the index higher, with buying focusing on select old economy stocks, in particular the paper and cement sectors, dealers said.
A total of 2,210 stocks closed up and 1,961 down, while 437 remained unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector scored the highest gains, closing up 2.8 percent. Cement stocks rose 1.6 percent, construction firms gained 1.4 percent, and the plastic and chemical sector closed up 0.5 percent.
The machinery and electronic sector rose 0.4 percent and the financial sector gained 0.3 percent, while foodstuffs fell 0.2 percent and textile stocks lost 0.1 percent.

"The gains were basically liquidity driven, " Concord Securities analyst Allen Lin said. "With ample funds on hand, investors tended to park their money in those stocks that have a rosy earnings outlook."

The paper and pulp sector was boosted by rising product prices, while investors were upbeat that cement makers will benefit from strong demand in China when it kicks off its 12th five-year economic development plan next year, dealers said.
Lin said investor confidence at home and abroad has been reinforced by the two- year record gains in the U.S. markets.

"Although recent gains in the local bourse have been limited as the index moves closer to the resistance point of 8,900, investors have high hopes that the upward trend will continue in tandem with the foreign markets," Lin said.
In the paper and pulp sector, Yuen Foong Yu Paper rose 5.17 percent to close at NT$15.25 and Taiwan Pulp and Paper gained 2.51 percent to end at NT$18.40.
In the cement sector, Asia Cement closed up 1.86 percent at NT$32.85 and Taiwan Cement ended 1.83 percent higher at NT$33.40.

DOC.HEADLINE: Santa Claus from Finland visits children in Taiwan hospitals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 17:03:33 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Children at National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital in Taipei received a visit Thursday from Santa Claus, who had traveled all the way from Finland to bring them Christmas greetings and candy.
"I wish you all a Merry Christmas, " Santa said to the young patients gathered in the hospital lobby, as he handed them each a Christmas candy bar.
Santa, accompanied by two elves, then went upstairs to bring some cheer to those children who were unable to join the celebrations in the hospital lobby.
Santa and elf friends, who are visiting Taiwan for the first time, are from Santa Claus Village in Lapland, Finland, according to Citibank, the main sponsor of the visit.
Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan was the next stop for the Finland Santa, who will stay in Taiwan until Sunday for several Christmas events, Citibank said.

Over the past 15 years, the bank has been dedicated to charity work in Taiwan, raising NT$1 billion and carrying out more than 6,000 charity projects, according to Citi Foundation public relations officer Liao Li-hsueh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to launch project to stop campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 17:33:38 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Justin Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Sean Chen said Thursday that the Ministry of Education (MOE) is planning to launch a cross-ministerial project aimed at stopping campus bullying, which has come to the forefront in Taiwanese society recently.

The project -- to be supported by the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Justice -- will review and study the core of the campus violence problem, work out a prevention and response mechanism, and seek cooperation with local governments in implementing the project, Chen said.
If necessary, he suggested, the MOE can ask Minister-without-Portfolio Ovid Tzeng to preside over the project as a coordinator, the vice premier said.
Tzeng, a former minister of education, has been known in recent years for his defense of the rights and interests of Taiwanese athletes and students in international competitions.

Noting that bullying has a tremendously negative impact on students' physical and mental development, Chen said the campus violence-prevention project must be carried out efficiently in order to provide the country's youth with a safe environment for education.
The Bade Junior High School in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan was the focus of a series of campus bullying reports in the recent week.

The MOE removed the school's principal, Wu Chia-ku, from her post Tuesday after 64 teachers from the school sent a joint petition to a lawmaker the previous day, accusing her of repeatedly turning a blind eye to the worsening safety situation on her campus.
In related news, a group of human rights activists met Thursday on the issue and offered their opinions and suggestions.

Vita Yeh, secretary-general of the non-profit Taiwan Alliance for Advancement of Youth Rights and Welfare, called for the MOE to increase the number of social workers on campuses and to build a preventive network to solve the bullying problem.

Yeh called for the MOE to appropriate between NT$1 billion (US$33.33 million) and NT$2 billion per year to have social workers posted on campuses as the major pillars of a campus violence prevention drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 17:50:06 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Thursday, dropping NT$0.12 to close at NT$30.485.
Turnover totaled US$540 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.605 and moved between NT$29.807 and NT$30.615 before the close.
Dealers said exporters continued to sell the U.S. dollar, pushing the New Taiwan dollar higher against the greenback during most of the trading session.
A rising local bourse on further inflows of foreign funds added more downward pressure on the U.S. currency during the session, they said.
The benchmark weighted index hit a 31-month high Thursday at 8,898.87, up 0.43 percent from the previous session on active rotational buying, with the market awash in high liquidity.

In late trade, the central bank intervened again in the local foreign exchange market to boost the value of the U.S. dollar back to the NT$30.00 mark against the New Taiwan dollar in its continued efforts to protect Taiwanese exports, the dealers said.
The NT$30.00 level appears to be the central bank's bottom line in the short term, they said.
As the Christmas holiday is approaching, the local foreign exchange market is expected to remain relatively quiet for the rest of the week despite the strength of the New Taiwan dollar, they said.
The quiet market is expected to reduce the central bank's efforts to curb the rise of the local currency, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amphibious electric vehicles to add novelty to flora expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 18:01:32 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Three amphibious vehicles powered exclusively by green energy are expected to test the waters in January and provide more travel fun for visitors to the 2010 Taipei International Flora Expo, the manufacturer said Thursday.
Completely funded, developed and made in Taiwan, the Thru Bus is the first amphibious electric vehicle in the world to use nickel-zinc batteries, said Bob Wong, chairman of CMC Magnetics Corp.
The nine-seater vehicle emits no carbon dioxide during operation and will partially recharge on solar energy, according to the CMC.
After a test ride on the vehicle's maiden trip Thursday morning, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said it was a "very smooth" ride.
"The manufacturing technique used to build the Thru Bus shows Taiwan's creativity and eco-friendliness," Hau said. "It is truly the 'pride of Taiwan.'"

The blue vehicles will soon begin operation on Taipei's "Blue Highway, " taking visitors across Keelung River from the expo's Dajia Riverside Park site to the Miramar shopping mall on the other side, the CMC said.
The one-way fare for the 30-minute trip across the river is NT$250 (US$8.3), it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ten charming harbors announced in tourism promotion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 18:14:13 (By Yang Shu-min and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture announced the 10 most charming harbors around Taiwan Thursday, as selected in an online vote and by local fishery associations.

A total of 47 fishing ports were evaluated in the first stage of the event that was held for the second year in November as part of a government effort to promote tourism and improve the image of Taiwan's fishing ports, the Fisheries Agency said.
Twenty ports ended up in the final 10 categories, described by the agency as "time machine, " "fairyland" and "seafood delicacies, " among others.

Gushan Fish Harbor in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City won the top spot in the category of "time machine," while Yanpu Fish Harbor in Pingtung County was selected as the village with the most delicious seafood delicacies.
Taipei County's Yeliou Fishing Harbor and Tamsui Second Fishing Port won the categories of "geographical wonders" and "fairyland, " respectively, according to the Fisheries Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance minister defends plan to introduce luxury tax
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei. Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 18:21:31 (By Lin Yi-feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Thursday that the government is planning to introduce a "luxury tax, " mainly to satisfy public expectations.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Financial Committee, Lee said that the plan is to levy reasonably higher taxes on "some goods and services." However, it will not necessarily be called a "luxury tax," he said.

But Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the ruling Kuomintang urged the government to give some thought to the proposal, saying that the tax would not add much more to the country's revenues and would prompt consumers to buy their high-priced goods abroad.
For example, because of its lower tax rates, Hong Kong has been more attractive than Japan to buyers of high-priced items, Sun said.
"The luxury tax may not benefit the country much in the long run and may negatively affect the local tourism industry to start with, " Sun said.
The Finance Ministry said in September that it was considering collecting taxes on luxury items at an appropriate time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local companies co-sponsor Taipei 101 fireworks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:21:06 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 10 Taiwanese companies have signed up as sponsors of the highly anticipated annual Taipei 101 New Year's Eve pyrotechnics display, the building's owner, Taipei Financial Center Corp. (TFCC), said Thursday.

The state-owned Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. tops the sponsor list with NT$10 million (US$335,000) , while the country's biggest telecom operator Chunghwa Telecom, and second-biggest shipping line, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., are each contributing NT$4 million, TFCC Chairman Harace Lin said at a press conference.
This is the first year the world's second-tallest skyscraper has received sponsorship for the fireworks from 10 companies, amounting to a combined total of NT$30 million.

"The display has been sponsored by only single companies in the past, so we have tried this year to bring more local firms to the show this year to celebrate the Republic of China's centennial," said Lin.

This year's show, which will last for 288 seconds and will use more than 30,000 fireworks costing over NT$60 million, is being touted as the "longest, biggest and most expensive" of the last six years.

As the nation celebrates its 100th founding anniversary next year, TFCC is also set to feature "ROC 100" in lightbulbs mounted on the building from January 1, 2011, which will be illuminated from 6 p.m.-10 p.m. every night for that month.
"We decided to use English characters instead of Chinese ones because it is expected to be recognized internationally, " said the building's spokesman, Michael Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica: 2011 economy to grow 4.71 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:28:13 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica said Thursday that Taiwan's economic growth for 2011 is expected to be a moderate 4.71 percent from a strong showing in 2010 amid uncertainty over global economic fundamentals.

Academia Sinica, the nation's top research institute, said the moderation also reflects a high comparison base in 2010, when the country's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to rise 10.31 percent, an upgrade of an earlier forecast by the institute of 6.89 percent.
The institute said the recent declines in Taiwan's leading indicators point to the likelihood of an economic growth moderation.

It said the debt problems in Europe, China's move to tighten its monetary policy in a bid to curb inflation and a rising New Taiwan dollar are expected to have an impact on the local economy in the coming year.

The institute said, however, that exporters might benefit from the recent passage of an extension of tax cuts for two years in the U.S. Congress, which is expected to boost demand for consumer electronics and precision machinery.
On the back of the tax cuts in the U.S., it is likely that the 2011 economic growth will top 5 percent, said Ray Chou, an economist at the institute.

While prices of raw materials and crude oil in the international markets are expected to climb in the coming year amid high liquidity, China's efforts to fight inflation and the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar are likely to stabilize domestic consumer prices, Academia Sinica said.
The institute said the consumer price index for 2011 is expected to rise 1.87 percent, compared with an estimated 1.02 percent increase for 2010.

While the New Taiwan dollar is riding the wave of appreciation on continued inflows of foreign funds, Chou said, the central bank is expected to make significant efforts to stabilize the local currency.

Chou said that as Taiwan is an export-oriented economy, it is necessary for the central bank to prevent the New Taiwan dollar from rising too rapidly in a bid to protect the country's global competitiveness.
Chou said it is unlikely that the central bank will allow the New Taiwan dollar to rise to NT$28.00 against the U.S. dollar in 2011.
The institute said private consumption in 2011 is expected to grow 3.54 percent, while private investment is likely to rise 1.57 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premium agriculture product label to enter China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:29:53 (By Justin Su and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Labeling that appears on high-quality Taiwanese produce will become a legal mark in China next year, which is expected to help sales of Taiwanese agricultural and processed goods, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

The Certified Agricultural Standards (CAS) label is set to be officially recognized by the Chinese authorities Jan. 20, said COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung upon being asked by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Te-fu at a legislative session about Chinese consumers' attitudes toward Taiwanese produce.
The label will let Chinese consumers easily recognize premium agricultural products from Taiwan, Chen said.
The value of Taiwanese produce sales in China is estimated to jump from NT$45 billion (US$1.505 billion) to NT$53 billion per year once the label makes its debut there, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker accuses Korean Air of 'discriminating' against Taiwanese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:39:51 (By Kelven Huang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-cher accused Korean Air Thursday of discriminating against Taiwanese and demanded an apology from the company.
Huang said at a press conference that Korean Air charges S$430.30 (US$329.61) per ticket "starting from Taiwan" to Seoul on its traditional Chinese-character website.
But the airline in its simplified Chinese-character websites charges only 1,831 Chinese Yuan (US$275.4) per trip "from Taiwan, China" to Seoul.
According to Huang, the move is "an attempt to downgrade" Taiwanese, as they would only be entitled to the cheaper tickets if they accept Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China.
"Korean Air should immediately make a correction and offer an apology to Taiwan, otherwise we will boycott it," Huang said.

Yeh Yung-ching, a section chief of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Korean Air prices its tickets from Taipei to Seoul at about NT$8,200 on its websites in the United States, Europe and Hong Kong, but charges NT$9,800 on its Singapore website.
Yeh said he is not sure whether the differences are a result of "a tagging mistake " and that the CAA will ask the airline to make improvements and establish a website for Taiwan.

Liang Chao-lin, a senior official with the Foreign Ministry's Department of Asian-Pacific Affairs, said officials at the Taipei branch of Korean Air told him it has already suggested to its headquarters that the website should be revised so that it no longer describes Taiwan as "Taiwan, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: November industrial production index hits fresh high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:55:51 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index hit a new high in November on rising demand from China on a buying spree ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, which will take place in February, the government said Thursday.
The November industrial production index reached 130.34, up 3.08 percent from October and up 19.37 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said.
It is the sixth time the index has hit a high so far this year on the back of a strong showing in export orders and a growing local economy, the MOEA said.

Tsai Mei-na, deputy director of the ministry's statistics department, said growing demand for high-tech products from China and an increase in investment in Taiwan pushed the November industrial production index up further.
After seasonal adjustments, the local industrial production index for November rose 6.61 percent from a month earlier, the MOEA said.

The index of manufacturing production rose 19.94 percent, with production in the electronic component segment rising 28.72 percent after new products hit the market and fresh promotion sales strategies boosted buying interest.
Production of the base metal segment for the month rose 21.73 percent from a year earlier, while production of the chemical segment gained 4.75 percent year- on-year, the ministry said.

A survey conducted by the ministry shows that 14.75 percent of the respondents agreed that December's industrial production will continue to expand, while 8.72 percent of those polled said production will fall. Meanwhile, 76.53 percent said December's industrial production will be little changed from November.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next China leader likely to keep peaceful cross-strait ties: SEF head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 20:12:10 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The next leader of China is likely to continue with a peaceful approach to China-Taiwan affairs, Taiwan's top cross-strait negotiator said Thursday.

Fresh off the sixth round of cross-strait negotiations, Chiang Pin-kung, Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), told CNA in an interview that the peaceful development of cross-strait relations is obviously a vision shared by the two sides.
"Peace" is the key word in cross-strait exchanges because the two sides can only develop and prosper if peace is preserved, he said.

For example, Chiang said, some Taiwanese businessmen in recent years have opted to invest in Vietnam or Indonesia instead of the Philippines, where social order and political stability have been less than satisfactory.
Chiang said that he has not met Xi Jinping, who is scheduled to succeed Hu Jintao in 2012 as president of China, but he expects that Xi will maintain Hu's Taiwan policy.
However, Chiang acknowledged that there has been some inconsistency in China's policies toward direct cross-strait negotiations and Taiwan's international participation.
This is because China's foreign ministry "has its own way of thinking," he said.
Several cases in the past were indicative of China's intolerance regarding Taiwan's participation in the international community, he said.
China's attitude on this issue could affect bilateral relations and the Taiwan people's impression of China since "almost all these cases made headlines in the Taiwanese newspapers," Chiang said.
Taiwan had often reminded the Chinese government that Beijing's foreign embassies "are still acting in the same way," he said.

On Tuesday, Chiang and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, President of the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), signed a medical and health-care cooperation agreement, the 15th pact between the two sides since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008 and began advocating cross-strait detente.

According to Chiang, cross-strait talks have entered a phase of "substance over style, " which he said means the content of the negotiations is more important than the process. In the future, the talks are likely to be more difficult, he said.
Meanwhile, he said, the SEF will focus on the implementation of the existing agreements and will advocate continued and wide bilateral exchanges.
For instance, Taiwan should be more confident and open its doors wider to Chinese students, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prohibitive property prices may cause realty bubble: expert

TEXT.P: Prohibitive property prices in major cities, which have continued to skyrocket despite a wage stagnation, will eventually lead to a bubble in Taiwan's real estate sector, a pundit warned Thursday.

Home-buyers paid an average of NT$7.18 million for a home, according to the survey conducted by the Construction and Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

TEXT.P: Labeling that appears on high-quality Taiwanese produce will become a legal mark in China next year, which is expected to help sales of Taiwanese agricultural and processed goods, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

The label will let Chinese consumers easily recognize premium agricultural products from Taiwan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker accuses Korean Air of 'discriminating' against Taiwanese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:39:51 (By Kelven Huang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Wei-cher accused Korean Air Thursday of discriminating against Taiwanese and demanded an apology from the company.
Huang said at a press conference that Korean Air charges S$430.30 (US$329.61) per ticket "starting from Taiwan" to Seoul on its traditional Chinese-character website.
But the airline in its simplified Chinese-character websites charges only 1,831 Chinese Yuan (US$275.4) per trip "from Taiwan, China" to Seoul.
According to Huang, the move is "an attempt to downgrade" Taiwanese, as they would only be entitled to the cheaper tickets if they accept Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China.
"Korean Air should immediately make a correction and offer an apology to Taiwan, otherwise we will boycott it," Huang said.

Yeh Yung-ching, a section chief of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Korean Air prices its tickets from Taipei to Seoul at about NT$8,200 on its websites in the United States, Europe and Hong Kong, but charges NT$9,800 on its Singapore website.
Yeh said he is not sure whether the differences are a result of "a tagging mistake " and that the CAA will ask the airline to make improvements and establish a website for Taiwan.

Liang Chao-lin, a senior official with the Foreign Ministry's Department of Asian-Pacific Affairs, said officials at the Taipei branch of Korean Air told him it has already suggested to its headquarters that the website should be revised so that it no longer describes Taiwan as "Taiwan, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: November industrial production index hits fresh high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 19:55:51 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index hit a new high in November on rising demand from China on a buying spree ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, which will take place in February, the government said Thursday.
The November industrial production index reached 130.34, up 3.08 percent from October and up 19.37 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said.
It is the sixth time the index has hit a high so far this year on the back of a strong showing in export orders and a growing local economy, the MOEA said.

Tsai Mei-na, deputy director of the ministry's statistics department, said growing demand for high-tech products from China and an increase in investment in Taiwan pushed the November industrial production index up further.
After seasonal adjustments, the local industrial production index for November rose 6.61 percent from a month earlier, the MOEA said.

The index of manufacturing production rose 19.94 percent, with production in the electronic component segment rising 28.72 percent after new products hit the market and fresh promotion sales strategies boosted buying interest.
Production of the base metal segment for the month rose 21.73 percent from a year earlier, while production of the chemical segment gained 4.75 percent year- on-year, the ministry said.

A survey conducted by the ministry shows that 14.75 percent of the respondents agreed that December's industrial production will continue to expand, while 8.72 percent of those polled said production will fall. Meanwhile, 76.53 percent said December's industrial production will be little changed from November.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next China leader likely to keep peaceful cross-strait ties: SEF head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 20:12:10 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The next leader of China is likely to continue with a peaceful approach to China-Taiwan affairs, Taiwan's top cross-strait negotiator said Thursday.

Fresh off the sixth round of cross-strait negotiations, Chiang Pin-kung, Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), told CNA in an interview that the peaceful development of cross-strait relations is obviously a vision shared by the two sides.
"Peace" is the key word in cross-strait exchanges because the two sides can only develop and prosper if peace is preserved, he said.

For example, Chiang said, some Taiwanese businessmen in recent years have opted to invest in Vietnam or Indonesia instead of the Philippines, where social order and political stability have been less than satisfactory.
Chiang said that he has not met Xi Jinping, who is scheduled to succeed Hu Jintao in 2012 as president of China, but he expects that Xi will maintain Hu's Taiwan policy.
However, Chiang acknowledged that there has been some inconsistency in China's policies toward direct cross-strait negotiations and Taiwan's international participation.
This is because China's foreign ministry "has its own way of thinking," he said.
Several cases in the past were indicative of China's intolerance regarding Taiwan's participation in the international community, he said.
China's attitude on this issue could affect bilateral relations and the Taiwan people's impression of China since "almost all these cases made headlines in the Taiwanese newspapers," Chiang said.
Taiwan had often reminded the Chinese government that Beijing's foreign embassies "are still acting in the same way," he said.

On Tuesday, Chiang and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, President of the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), signed a medical and health-care cooperation agreement, the 15th pact between the two sides since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008 and began advocating cross-strait detente.

According to Chiang, cross-strait talks have entered a phase of "substance over style, " which he said means the content of the negotiations is more important than the process. In the future, the talks are likely to be more difficult, he said.
Meanwhile, he said, the SEF will focus on the implementation of the existing agreements and will advocate continued and wide bilateral exchanges.
For instance, Taiwan should be more confident and open its doors wider to Chinese students, he said.

With its proud democracy, Taiwan will be able to "make them pro-Taiwan, " he said. "The more China and the people of China understand Taiwan, the more they will respect us for our democracy, hospitality, courtesy, vibrant culture and way of life."
Chiang lauded the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) move to establish a think tank that will formulate its China policy over the next decade.
He said that the DPP, which was firmly anti-China in the past, had to think about this issue sooner or later.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven people cited with prestigious sports awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/10 22:51:39 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Seven people were presented with Taiwan Sports Elite Awards by the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Thursday for their outstanding contributions to Taiwan's athletic development.
Cyclist Hsiao Mei-yu, who won a gold medal and a bronze medal at the cycling events of 2010 Asian Games in China's Guangzhou in November, was awarded the Best Female Athlete Award.
Tennis player Yang Tsung-hua, who won two gold medals in the men's team and the mixed doubles events in the 2010 Asiad, received the Best Male Athlete Award.
Hsiao's coach, Hsu Jui-teh, was given the Best Coach Award.
The Chinese Taipei men's 400-meter relay team, which won a silver medal at the Asiad, received the Best Sports Team Award.

Taekwondo athlete Huang Hsien-yung, who won a gold medal in the women's under 46-kg division, won the Best Rising Sports Star Award, while Chen Li-hsin, who won a silver medal in pairs figure skating at the games, was given the Best Sportsmanship Award.
Sports professor Chiu Chin-sung, formerly president of National Taiwan Sport University, was awarded a Lifetime Contribution Award, according to the SAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 24, or the 19th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies at the age of 90.
1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.
1999: Taipei's fifth rapid transit line -- the Pangnan Line -- is inaugurated, completing the foundation of the city's rapid transit network.
2000: About 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas take part in a peaceful street march in Taipei to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
2000: Thai Rangsit University confers an honorary doctoral degree on former ROC Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Barriers to investment protection deal
DOC.DATELINE: 12/24/10 10:59:33 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 24, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Due to the various complex and sensitive issues involved, a planned Taiwan-China investment protection agreement was not ready for signing in the sixth round of talks between the chief cross-strait negotiators, Taiwan's Chiang Pin-kung and China's Chen Yunlin.

A major bone of contention is the question of where arbitration proceedings should be held. China rejected Taiwan's proposal that investment disputes be resolved at the Washington-headquartered International Center for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) under the World Bank, or the Paris-based International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) . China expressed concern that this might internationalize cross-strait issues. China saw Hong Kong as the best choice, but Taiwan would not agree because Hong Kong is part of China.
Under these circumstances, we suggest considering Singapore as an alternative.

Beijing is willing to sign an investment protection agreement with Taipei because it expects a large number of Chinese businesses will invest in Taiwan. However, although Taiwan opened its doors to Chinese investors last year, many restrictions remain. If Chinese businesses cannot invest in Taiwan, what is the point of China signing such a deal with Taiwan?
The Taiwan government, therefore, should further liberalize its restrictions on Chinese investors and open up all non-sensitive sectors.
An increased presence of Chinese investors in Taiwan will boost Beijing's interest in negotiating the agreement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
China Times: Is media shutdown reasonable?
DOC.DATELINE: The National Communications Commission (NCC) 12/24/10 11:15:49 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: recently decided to revoke the license of ERA Comprehensive Channel, which will in effect shut down the channel after repeated violations of a ban on embedded advertising. The decision has raised a public outcry.

Over the past six years, the NCC has slapped fines totaling NT$16.75 million (US$558,333) on the channel. We think these penalties are enough. The violations do not deserve such a severe punishment as license revocation. Furthermore, is there a law that stipulates the NCC can "revoke licenses" at its own discretion?

In a broader context, the NCC's action has undoubtedly hurt freedom of speech in Taiwan. Some people may think that this incident is unrelated to freedom of speech because the victim is a news channel. However, if society allows an administrative agency to exercise such great power over the fate of entertainment channels today, this power will probably expanded to news channels tomorrow. In other words, it can become a government tool to control the media.

We believe the power of the market and society will correct any undesirable media trends and we hope that the government will use its regulatory authority with caution and restraint. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon Life's Vietnam unit to begin operations in Q1 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 12:21:00 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Fubon Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of of Fubon Financial Holding Co., said Friday its fully owned unit in Vietnam is scheduled to become operational in the first quarter of 2011.
The life insurer said its Vietnam unit -- Fubon Life Insurance (Vietnam) -- has secured a license from the financial authorities in the country to operate there.
The Vietnam unit will set up a subsidiary in Hanoi and a branch in the Ho Chi Minh City, both of which will open in the first quarter of next year, Fubon Life said.
Before Fubon Life set up its official operations in Vietnam, Fubon Financial had established footholds to develop its banking and non-life insurance businesses in the Southeast Asian country.

Richard Tsai, vice chairman of Fubon Financial and chairman of Fubon Life, said Fubon Financial will be able to provide a wide range of services in banking, life insurance and non-life insurance in the Vietnamese market.
Tsai said Fubon Financial is expected to customize its products to serve the fast-growing market in Vietnam.
According to Fubon Financial, the premium income of the life insurance sector in Vietnam in the first nine months of this year rose 25.1 percent from a year earlier to about US$490 million.
Fubon Life vice chairman Shih Bao-jung said after the opening of the Vietnam unit, the life insurer will become a regional insurance business operator.

Shih said his company will take advantage of its experience in the Taiwan market to penetrate the Vietnamese market, with the aim of boosting its visibility and building a successful brand in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Christmas Eve reflections

TEXT.P: Today is Christmas Eve, a time to celebrate the nativity of Jesus and the heavenly peace it brought.
Therefore, Christmas Eve night is not supposed to be for partying, but rather should be a time for reflecting -- something that our government policy makers, in particular, need to do.

Is there peace in Taiwanese society? The answer is probably 'no.' Today, children are bullied in school, and after graduation, they have to worry about finding a good job. People who want to get married are deterred by skyrocketing housing prices, while those who want to have children are afraid that they cannot afford to become parents.
Although government officials always say they want to boost the country's birth rate, the government's housing policy in recent years in fact has been fueling the already red-hot housing market.

Official statistics show that there are approximately 2 million workers in Taiwan who earn less than NT$20,000 a month, and more than 1 million people are in households affected by unemployment. This problem will never be solved unless the government changes its industrial policy.

Jesus said that "in me you may have peace." We earnestly wish that our policy makers will review their current policies with a compassionate spirit, so as to end the people's suffering and bring them peace instead. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Three measures to stabilize currency market
DOC.DATELINE: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) 12/24/10 13:05:39 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: has tightened monitoring of investment activities of local financial service providers abroad and taken new steps to stabilize the Taiwan dollar amid a global capital overflow.

It has reportedly adopted a "three noes" policy that prohibits financial service companies from remitting their overseas earnings back to Taiwan, increasing their hedged positions or conducting forward foreign exchange trading.

Meanwhile, market sources said Thursday that although the CBC has taken many steps to help cool the local property market, housing prices have continued to rise in metropolitan Taipei and NT$1.3 trillion worth of projects will be tendered throughout Taiwan next year.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issues:
Commercial Times:

The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed at a 31-month high Thursday, which helped drive the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the U.S. dollar up by NT$0.798 to a high of NT$29.807 at one point during the trade.
However, with the central bank's intervention late in the session, the Taiwan dollar closed at NT$30.485 Thursday, up NT$0.12.

With hot money inflows continuing unabated, the central bank remains firm on its goal to keep the Taiwan currency stable. Under this policy, banking sources said, large domestic banks with huge overseas investments and insurance companies have become the CBC's priority watch targets.
According to the sources, the overseas investments of Taiwan life insurers have reach an estimated NT$3.55 trillion (US$118.33 billion).

The central bank has asked life insurance companies not to remit profits from their overseas investments back to Taiwan as this will fuel the Taiwan dollar's appreciation against the greenback, the sources said.
Moreover, the sources said, the central bank has also rejected some commercial banks' applications to increase their hedged positions after they remitted some of their U.S. dollar holdings abroad.

The central bank has also advised local exporters not to engage in forward foreign exchange trading but instead to engage in currency swap to prevent further appreciation of the local currency, the sources said.

Senior bankers said the central bank was forced to adopt these measures to prevent financial services groups from engaging in speculative currency deals under the guise of hedging against risk. (Dec. 24, 2010).
United Daily News:

Despite the government's efforts to stem housing prices, the results of the latest government survey indicated that the home procurement miserable index (the ratio of housing price to household income) in Taipei City surged to yet another high in the third quarter of this year.

The survey conducted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) found that housing prices in Taipei City rose to an average of NT$419,000 per ping (3.3 square meters) in the third quarter -- 11.1 times the city's average household income. In the second quarter, the figure was 10.87 times the average household income.

The home procurement miserable index in the neighboring Taipei County also rose from 7.8 in the first half of this year to 8.9 in the third quarter, while the figure for the whole of Taiwan hit an all-time high of 8, according to the MOI survey.

The poll also found that CBC's selective credit control moves have not cooled real estate investment, as new home trade deals accounted for 18.5 percent of overall transactions around the country, up from 17.3 percent.

Meanwhile, a housing magazine published by PC Home Group said the value of new housing construction projects to be launched next year around Taiwan will reach a historic high of NT$1.37 trillion. (Dec. 24, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Only a tiny fraction of e-passports flawed: foreign ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 14:43:47 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has intimated that the reports of defects in the new Taiwan passports were overblown considering that there have only been a few faulty documents among the 2 million issued.

Since the first biometric passports were issued on Dec. 29, 2008, the Bureau of Consular Affairs (BOCA) has received only 14 requests for changes to the passports based on physical flaws in the documents, the MOFA said in a statement released Thursday.
Given the fact that the BOCA has issued nearly 2.3 million e-passports, it means that only about 6 millionths have defects, the ministry said.
The passports were designed according to strict security and quality standards, the MOFA said.

The state-owned Central Engraving and Printing Plant in Taipei County, which has the contract to print the new passports, was cited by the MOFA in the statement as saying that it had adhered to the standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

The ICAO is a specialized United Nations agency that adopts standards and recommended practices for, among other things, the facilitation of border- crossing procedures for international civil aviation.

The plant, which also prints banknotes and stamps, said that after printing, the blank passports are sent to France for professional quality checks before delivery to the BOCA. The paper quality must meet international standards, it added.
At a Legislative Yuan hearing earlier in the day, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lu Shiow-yen said the new biometric passports were flawed and that the production was sub-standard.
Displaying an e-passport that she said was issued in August, Lu pointed out that the spine was damaged.
"The whole passport is falling apart" and it is basically a new one, she said.
Lu also questioned the quality of the paper used, saying that the pages of the passport were "thin like cicadas wings" and could be easily torn out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan retail sales forecast to hit record high this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 15:19:04 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's retail sales for 2010 are expected to hit a record high on the back of a strong economic rebound, The Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
Beatrice Tsai, deputy director of the statistics department at the MOEA, forecast that retail sales for 2010 will rise 6.4 percent from 2009 to NT$3.49 trillion (US$116.85 billion).

"Retail sales data is one of the major indicators of private consumption, " Tsai told the Central News Agency. " As the local economy is growing, we expect retail sales to hit a record high this year."
In November, retail sales totaled NT$299.9 billion, up 5.46 percent from a year earlier, and the figure in December is expected to reach NT$300 billion, Tsai said.
The falling jobless rate, which was at almost a two-year low of 4.73 percent in November, and a booming local stock market has boosted buying in the retail sector, she said.
Many retailers in Taiwan are expanding their operations by opening new stores, in anticipation of more business as a result of larger numbers of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.
She said the implementation of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed by Taiwan and China in late June has also reinforced consumer confidence.
"With consumer confidence on the rise, sales of big-ticket items are rebounding, in particular car sales," Tsai said.
In the first 11 months of the year, car sales totaled around 297,000 units and the number is expected to reach a four-year high of 325,000 for the entire 2010, Tsai said.
In November, the government raised its forecast for the 2010 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 9.98 percent from a previous estimate of 8.24 percent

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.42 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 15:30:31 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan shares closed down 0.42 percent Friday on profit taking from a previous session as investors took cues from a lackluster performance on Wall Street overnight, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 37.77 points to 8,861.10, after moving between 8,861.01 and 8,911.41, on turnover of NT$120.77 billion (US$120.04).

The market opened up 0.13 percent and moved to the day's high on follow-through buying, but pressure emerged to reverse the gains after the index briefly breached the technical resistance point of 8,900, dealers said.
A total of 2,911 stocks closed down and 1,278 up, while 348 remained unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector suffered the steepest decline, ending down 1.2 percent. Cement stocks fell 0.9 percent, textile firms lost 0.7 percent and the machinery and electronic sector closed down 0.6 percent.
Foodstuffs lost 0.4 percent, construction stocks fell 0.3 percent, and plastic and chemical shares dropped 0.1 percent, while the financial sector closed unchanged.
"As the index moved closer to the 8,900 point mark after recent gains, resistance pressure mounted," TLG Asset Management analyst Arch Shih said.
The local bourse hit a 31-month high Thursday on active rotational buying.
"With turnover remaining moderate ahead of the Christmas holiday, it was not easy for the market to overcome the technical hurdles. That's why it took a pause today," Shih said.
Shih said selling largely focused on old economy stocks that had been boosted by a rising New Taiwan dollar on hopes that the value of their domestic assets would rise accordingly.

"Fortunately, the downside was limited as the market still held itself well above 8,800 points amid ample liquidity," Shih said, "It is possible that the market will move in a narrow range over the next few trading sessions."
Among the old economy stocks, food maker Lien Hwa Industrial fell 2.69 percent to NT$23.50, Prince Housing dropped 2.20 percent to NT$24.40 and Taiwan Pulp and Paper slid 1.63 percent to NT$18.10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist arrivals forecast to hit 6.5 million in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 15:34:41 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tourist arrivals in Taiwan are expected to exceed 5.5 million this year and soar to 6.5 million next year, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo said Friday.

Addressing the opening of a tourism promotion conference, Mao said the number of visitors in 2010 broke the 5 million mark on Nov. 26, surging far past the 4.4 million recorded for the whole of last year.
By the end of this year, Mao said, tourist arrivals could reach 5.5 million.
"It is a remarkable feat to register such a big increase in just one year," Mao said.
Citing an estimate by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, Mao said the number of visitors will continue to rise in the coming year to a new high of 6.5 million.
Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan's tourism industry is now at a critical juncture and needs overhaul and reform.

The tourism conference is being held under the theme "new products, new markets and new trends, " he noted. "It is a brainstorming session to devise innovative and marketable packages to attract more foreign tourists to Taiwan and to offer local and foreign travelers a brand new travel experience, " the minister explained.

He suggested that operators in the cultural, creative, medical, health care, shopping and exhibition service sectors pool their ideas to design attractive tour packages for visitors from around the world and to create new business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold, wet weather forecast for Christmas in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 16:31:32 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Temperatures will begin to drop on Christmas Eve and heavy rains can be expected all day Saturday in northern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Friday.

Areas north of Chiayi County will experience a low of 15 degrees Celsius overnight and the cold weather will last through Christmas, with temperatures ranging from 14 to 18 degrees in northern Taiwan Saturday, the bureau said.
The CWB on Friday also issued a heavy rain warning, saying that strengthening seasonal winds from the northeast will bring moisture.
According to the CWB forecast, Taiwan is likely to see a wet Christmas, with rain clouds covering the whole island.
Later Saturday, the bureau warned, another cold front from mainland China will send the mercury plunging below 10 degrees in areas north of Chiayi County.
The chill will last until Tuesday, but the weather will turn dryer next week, which will reduce the chances of snowfall in the mountainous areas, the CWB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers to press NCC to retract license revocation decision
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 16:51:48 (By Ho Meng-kuei, Amy Huang, Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)
