TEXT.P: Opposition legislators vowed Friday to introduce a resolution demanding that the National Communications Commission (NCC) retract its decision to revoke the license of a cable TV channel, a decision the lawmakers feared would have a chilling effect on other broadcasters.
According to Pan Men-an, a whip of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus, the NCC's decision could be unlawful and may have violated the constitutionally protected freedom of communication.
The caucus would also seek the support of ruling Kuomintang legislators for its action, Pan said.
"The Legislative Yuan, which enacted the NCC's organic law, does not want to become an accomplice in the suppression of the media," he said.

The NCC decided on Wednesday to revoke the license of ERA TV's entertainment channel because it repeatedly violated a ban on embedded advertising. The decision has drawn heavy criticism from media freedom advocates.
NCC spokesman Chen Cheng-chang defended the agency's decision, however, saying that the NCC had given the station a one-year buffer period to improve, but the station obviously failed to do so.

Chen disclosed that a committee reviewing the TV channel's license renewal application a year ago had recommended that the NCC reject the application, but the regulator eventually agreed to renew the station's license on condition that there would be no more violations.
With the channel guilty of several similar violations over the past year, the NCC's latest decision to revoke the channel's license was completely lawful, he insisted.
According to the official, the channel will have to stop broadcasting starting Dec. 30 or Jan. 1.
Also Friday, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said President Ma Ying-jeou will not interfere with any decisions made by the NCC because it is an independent organization.
If the TV channel is not satisfied with the NCC ruling, it can file an appeal, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Luxgen Motor eyeing markets in Middle East, Russia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 17:22:27 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Luxgen Motor Co., a subsidiary of Taiwan's largest carmaker Yulon Motor Co., said Friday that it will work to expand its markets in the Middle East and make inroads into Russia next year.
Luxgen, which was launched in January 2009, has recently signed agreements with dealers in Oman, Bahrain, Vietnam, Qatar and the Dominican Republic.

The company entered these markets after participating in car exhibitions that eventually led to partnerships between the company and its dealers in these countries, Luxgen's Senior Vice President Vincent Tsao told reporters at an auto show in Taipei.
"We plan to expand our market scope in the Middle East to cover Saudi Arabia, Iran and others countries," he said.

The car company will take part in an auto exhibition in Dubai next year, he said. With an eye on entering the Russian market next year, the company is also considering participating an auto show in Russia in the second half of 2011, he added.

On the question of how it plans to market its vehicles to foreign consumers, Tsao said that Luxgen's advantage is its incorporation of Taiwan's information and energy technologies into its vehicle electronic systems.
He added that Luxgen's current marketing strategy is focused on branding rather than quantity.
Luxgen made its first overseas shipment on Dec. 20, sending 100 vehicles to the Dominican Republic. The company has forecast that its overseas shipments will exceed 1,000 units next year.
For the Chinese market, a joint venture formed by Yulon and China's Dongfeng Motor Corp. earlier this month is planning to ship luxury Luxgen models there in the first half of next year, Tsao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan should help U.S. defend Taiwan: Japanese poll
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 17:52:55 (By Chang Fang-ming and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of Japanese agreed to their country offering logistical support to the United States if America had to assist Taiwan militarily in a showdown with China, according to the results of a Japanese poll released Friday.

In the survey conducted by Japanese daily The Asahi Shimbun Dec. 4-5, 57 percent of the 3,000 respondents said Japan's self-defense forces should provide transportation and other logistic support to the U.S. military if war were to break out across the Taiwan Strait.
Only 30 percent of respondents opposed the idea.

On the same question asked in a parallel poll conducted in the U.S. by Harris Interactive for the newspaper Dec. 2-6, 65 percent of the 1,009 respondents said Japanese self-defense forces should assist the U.S. logistically while 23 percent said there was no such need.

The Asahi survey in Japan also found that an increasing number of Japanese feel that China's military poses a threat to their country. Some 32 percent of respondents felt that way in this year's poll, up from 13 percent in 2005 and 8 percent in 2001.
North Korea was perceived as Japan's biggest military threat, with almost half (49 percent) of the respondents citing it as such.

Some 72 percent of the Japanese respondents felt Japan should strengthen cooperation with the U.S., and 61 percent of the Americans felt their country should do the same with Japan, according to the surveys.
The polls also found that 51 percent of the Japanese respondents and 55 percent of the Americans surveyed thought their countries should beef up cooperation with China.
Which country is more important to the Japanese: China or the U.S.? Over two- thirds (68 percent) of Japanese said the U.S. , compared with a mere 15 percent who pointed to China.
But when Americans were asked which country was more important to them, half of the U.S. respondents named China and only 33 percent said Japan.
As many as 78 percent of Japanese respondents said the Japan-U.S. security treaty should be maintained and 68 percent of the Americans agreed.

With China boosting its military capability, 48 percent of those surveyed in Japan said their country should increase its military presence in its southwestern islands to respond to the threat, but 36 percent opposed the suggestion.

Over half (51 percent) of the Japanese polled said U.S. President Barack Obama should visit Hiroshima and Nagasaki, two Japanese cities devastated by U.S. atomic bombs toward the end of World War II, while 36 percent saw no need for him to do so.
The Japanese poll also had a domestic component. It found that 60 percent of those surveyed did not support incumbent Prime Minister Naoto Kan, whose popularity stood at 24 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closed unchanged on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 18:07:54 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar closed unchanged at NT$30.485 against the New Taiwan dollar Friday.
Turnover totaled US$628 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at 30.510 and moved between NT$29.670 and NT$30.525 before the close.

Further inflows of foreign funds continued to boost the value of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar, while quiet trade in other foreign exchange markets in the region ahead of the Christmas holiday offered little direction to the trading session, dealers said.
Foreign banks remained the major seller of the U.S. dollar, betting the New Taiwan dollar would extend its momentum to reflect the island's strong economic fundamentals, they said.

As the U.S. is pumping funds into the market through purchases of treasury bonds to boost its economy, investors have high hopes that more and more idle money will enter the markets in Asia and further lift the currencies in the region, they added.

Dealers said Taiwan's central bank, which has shown a strong will to prevent rapid appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar and protect the island's exports, intervened in the local foreign exchange market again in late trade.
With the central bank's presence, the U.S. dollar staged a rebound from the day's low to above the NT$30.00, a level the market believes is the central bank's bottom line in the near term.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of IC designer close sharply higher on debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 18:24:13 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of integrated circuit designer MStar Semiconductor Inc. closed sharply higher on the first day of its primary listing Friday on the Taiwan Stock Exchange amid optimism toward the company's bottom line, dealers said.

However, the gains of the stock were compromised due to mounting pressure in the broader market as the index moved closer to the nearest technical resistance at 8,900 points after recent significant gains, they said.
MStar rose 10 percent to NT$330.00 (US$11.05) , off a high of NT$347.00, with 17.28 million shares changing hands, while the benchmark weighted index closed down 0.42 percent at 8,861.10.
"MStar is emerging as one of MediaTek Inc.'s rivals in the China market, and the Taiwan market showed enthusiasm toward the stock, " MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
But the strong interest in MStar stalled Friday to some extent as the market was faced with stiff technical resistance, Tang said.
"In addition to the technical factors, investors began to consider whether MStar was too expensive compared with MediaTek, " Tang said.
MediaTek closed the day at NT$423.50, down 1.85 percent.

Tang said MediaTek, which is expected to post an earnings per share of NT$32 for 2010, was traded at a price-earnings multiple of 13 Friday, while MStar was expected to record an EPS of about NT$15 with a PE multiple of 23.
Tang said that both and MStar are MediaTek are facing fierce competition in the China market.
"MediaTek's profit margin has been seriously squeezed, but so has MStar's," he said.
According to IC Insights, MStar is expected to rank as the 13th largest fabless IC provider in the world this year by generating US$1.06 billion in sales, up 75 percent from a year earlier.
IC Insights, a global semiconductor market research firm, said MediaTek is likely to rank fourth, posting US$3. 61 billion in revenue, up 3 percent year- on-year.

MStar, established in Taiwan in June 2002, moved its headquarters to the Cayman Islands in 2007 and registered there with the goal of expanding globally and opening subsidiaries in Singapore and the Netherlands.
The company operates primarily in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and most of its products are sold outside Taiwan to China, South Korea and the United States.
Microchips made by MStar are used in a wide range of consumer electronic products, including LCD-TVs, monitors, set-top boxes, and mobile communications devices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tea expo opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 18:34:50 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Tea Culture Expo opened in Taipei on Friday, with the majority of exhibitors coming from different parts of major tea producing areas in Taiwan.
Exhibitors at the annual event, now in its second year, were offering tea samples and tea snacks to visitors and showcasing various tea pots, antiques and calligraphy.
In his remarks to open the show, Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the Council of Agriculture's Agriculture and Food Agency, lauded the quality and safety of Taiwanese tea.
"Taiwanese tea has been widely regarded as being one of the best quality teas in the world," he said.
"In recent years, we have been intensifying our efforts to test pesticide residues in tea leaves to ensure safety," he added.
The event, which is free of charge to the public, runs until Dec. 26 at the Taipei World Trade Center Hall 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups call for aboriginal townships to retain self-governance
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 19:05:58 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several social groups called Friday for a law revision to deal with the imminent loss of self-governance in five aboriginal townships, which will occur when four new municipalities come into effect on Dec. 25.

The groups, including Citizen Congress Watch, the Green Party and the Alliance to Safeguard Aboriginal Rights after Five Municipalities, held a protest outside the Legislative Yuan to draw public attention to the situation.

Under the Local Government Act, five aboriginal townships -- Wulai Township in Taipei County; Namaxia, Taoyuan, and Maolin Townships in Kaohsiung; and Heping Township in Taichung -- will become districts within the four new municipalities, a spokesman for the groups noted.
The district chiefs will be appointed by the municipality mayors, instead of being selected by the residents, the spokesman said.
"The aboriginal people will lose their administrative and financial management rights," he said.
This will be not only a violation of human rights, but also a contravention of the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law and will result in the extinction of the aboriginal peoples, he said.
The four new municipalities will become effective Saturday with the upgrade of Taipei County to New Taipei City and three city and county mergers in Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung, respectively.

Pan Han-sheng, convener of the Green Party, said at the protest that if the aboriginal people lose their self-governance rights, they could end up like the Pingpu Tribe, which has been assimilated into the general population.
Chen Chien-fu, chairman of the Taiwan Grassroots Alliance for Peace, pointed out that the United Nations has said aboriginal peoples have the right to self- government.
"Taiwan's lawmakers should immediately revise the law to prevent infringement on the aboriginal people's right to self-government, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Physical punishment not a cure for bullying: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 19:15:18 (By Wang Hung-kuo, Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Education Minister Wu Ching-chi ruled out the possibility Friday of reintroducing physical punishment in schools as means of dealing with bullying.

"Physical punishment can't be allowed, but discipline can, " he said in a meeting with more than 500 heads of junior and senior high schools and vocational schools to discuss ways of preventing bullying.
"Zero physical punishment" is still a major policy of the Ministry of Education, Wu said in response to a call to reintroduce physical punishment in schools to deal with bullying.
"Physical punishment would encourage students to meet violence with violence," Wu said.
The meeting was held after a series of bullying incidents at a junior high school were reported in the media in the recent week.
Wu said that every possible means will be used to deal with the problem and its root causes.
"Do not give up on any students," he urged the school principals.
He asked them to encourage their teachers to help guide students onto the right path.
However, bullying cannot be wiped out unless good morals are restored in schools, he said.

Schools should reinforce education in the fields of morals and behavior, judiciary systems, human rights, and gender equality, and should enlist families and the wider community in the efforts to stop bullying, he suggested.

Since the bullying problem was exposed in the media, the Executive Yuan has assigned Minister without Portfolio Ovid Tzeng to host an inter-ministerial forum for the exchange of opinions and suggestions on how to deal with the issue.
Earlier in the day, Tzeng, a prominent educator and former minister of education, suggested that one of the necessary steps is for adults to refrain from violence.
Adults, including politicians across party lines, should be role models for children, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese bank to sign MOU with Bank of China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 19:43:34 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Cooperative Bank said Friday it will sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Bank of China on cooperation between the two banks in the future.

The plan to sign the MOU with the Chinese bank on Dec. 28 was made after Taiwan's financial regulator, the Financial Supervisory Commission, gave the local bank the green light earlier this month, Taiwan Cooperative bank said.

Under the MOU, the two banks will work together in providing several financial services, including foreign exchange, trade financing, syndicated loans, interbank lending, and loans for small and medium enterprises, the bank said.
It also indicated that the two partners would soon launch personnel exchanges to develop better mutual understanding.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank President Tsai Chiu-jung will go to Beijing to sign the accord with Bank of China President Li Lihui, Taiwan Cooperative Bank said.
The Taiwanese bank is also scheduled to open a branch in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, on Dec. 29. The branch is targeted at Taiwanese companies operating on the mainland.
Bank Chairman Liu Teng-cheng will be in Suzhou to preside over the branch's opening ceremony.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank is one of the first five Taiwanese banks to secure approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) to set up branches on the mainland.
The four others are First Commercial Bank, Cathay United Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan.
First Commercial Bank and Cathay United Bank opened branches in Shanghai on Thursday.

In an earlier statement, the CBRC said it hopes that the presence of Taiwanese bank branches in China will help promote cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations and maintain the steady development of the cross-strait banking sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP denies existence of '92 consensus' with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 20:06:08 (By Sophia Yeh and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that it has never acknowledged the existence of the so-called "1992 consensus" or "one-China consensus."

DPP spokesman Lin Yu-chang was responding to President Ma Ying-jeou's challenge to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen in an interview, when he demanded that Tsai clearly state if her party acknowledges the "1992 consensus" between Taiwan and China.

If Taiwan does not recognize the cross-Taiwan Strait consensus, which Ma called a bedrock of the relationship, uncertainty would be created and doubts would arise over cross-strait peace, Ma was quoted as saying by the United Evening News on Thursday.
Lin said that for the DPP, the so-called "1992 consensus" represents a consensus on "one China, " which the party has never agreed to.
Lin said the president should explain first what he meant by the "1992 consensus."

The ruling Kuomintang, which Ma leads, has defined the "1992 consensus" with China as a tacit agreement between Taipei and Beijing that there is but "one China" whose meaning is open for each side to interpret.
The KMT would interpret "one China" as the Republic of China on Taiwan while the Beijing government would define it as the People's Republic of China.

Lin cited recent examples of Chinese officials addressing Taiwanese officials not by their official titles but with "Mr., " "Mrs., " or the honorific form of "you", raising doubts about the government's approach to dealing with China.

While Taiwanese officials call their Chinese counterparts by their official titles, such as "President Chen Yunlin" of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan could only express regret at being addressed by her first name or as "you" by Chen during his recent visit to Taipei, according to Lin.
"Why is it that Chinese officials visiting Taiwan do not show their respect to Taiwanese officials and address them by their official titles?" Lin asked.
"Is that what President Ma has called equality between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait?" he wondered.
The spokesman asked the president to explain this to the people, instead of trying to divert attention to the DPP's position regarding the 1992 consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's family returns more overseas money
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 20:27:56 (By Lai You-chia and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The family of former President Chen Shui-bian has remitted back to Taiwan an additional US$234,036 from their accounts in two Swiss banks, prosecutors in charge of the case said Friday.

The Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said the money -- part of a total of US$21 million held by Chen's family members in Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. and the Royal Bank of Scotland -- was wired to Taiwanese bank accounts designated by the SID earlier that day.
The money in the Swiss banks, which had been frozen since 2007, was held in accounts under the names of the ex-president's son and daughter-in-law -- Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching.
To date, the SID has received US$21,204,313.17 from the two Swiss banks, and only about US$250,000 in the form of mutual funds remains to be remitted, the SID said.
In addition to the US$21 million frozen in the two banks, the former first family also transferred NT$570 million (US$19 million) to Swiss private bank Wegelin & Co. in June 2007.
The funds were drawn from the NT$740 million the family had put in a Cathay United Bank vault in Taipei.

Prosecutors have argued that all the money deposited by Chen's family overseas was illegally acquired and should be confiscated, but Chen and his wife were recently found not guilty of corruption charges related to the money deposited with Wegelin & Co.

Chen, who served as president from 2000 to 2008, and his wife Wu Shu-jen were both sentenced to life in prison and fined NT$200 million and NT$300 milling respectively in September last year on charges of taking bribes, money laundering and forgery.
After two appeals, the sentences for Chen and Wu were reduced to 17 1/2 years.
Chen has begun serving his sentence, but judicial authorities are still determining if Wu, who is a wheelchair user, can serve her sentence without imperiling her health.

DOC.HEADLINE: New exhibition showcases diversity of artist Ni Tsai-chin
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CAN) 12/24/10 20:33:53 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) will soon open its first ever large-scale exhibition dedicated to a Taiwanese artist, as it plans to showcase the versatile Ni Tsai-chin and his 30 years of work that offers a window on the evolution of contemporary Taiwanese art.

MOCA Director Shih Jui-cheng said the solo exhibition titled "Mediaholic: Arts of Ni Tsai-chin, " which opens Saturday, will mark the first time the 10-year- old museum has dedicated the majority of its space to a single Taiwanese artist.
The museum had previously held major solo exhibitions for international artists but not local artist because few of them have been as prolific as the 55-year- old Ni, Shih said.

"Ni is one of the very few interdisciplinary artists working across, and sometimes in between, the boundaries of different art forms, including literature, painting, sculpture, and installation art, and he also teaches art and is an enthusiastic environmentalist and art critic," Shih said.
Ni, whose work has also been shown in Italy, Germany, Korea, and China, describes himself as a "crazy person" who likes to explore different media as vehicles of creation.

In the 1990s, he began his "newspaper creation" series as a means to criticize the mainstream media's lack of interest in reporting on environmental and cultural issues and its overemphasis on politicians' lies during election campaigns.
The seven newspapers he published during the last 16 years, also on display at the MOCA exhibition, copy the format of local newspapers, but the stories carry a sarcastic and even cynical tone.

"In Taiwan, the media creates problems instead of monitoring them. Media workers only run stories that correspond to their own identities and interests; and the more violent or erotic a news story, the bigger the chance it will be carried in the newspaper," he said.

Despite his interest in experimenting with different art forms, he told reporters his favorite pastime remains painting. Ni, who was diagnosed with liver disease some 30 years ago and has battled liver cancer for the past decade, said he forgets about the physical pain whenever he starts to paint.

The solo exhibition, which runs through Feb. 13, 2011, will also showcase Ni's landscape paintings, his involvement in environmental and social issues, his "super flat" series, and his most recent sculptures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four Acer products win iF design award for 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 20:37:14 (By Chang Liang-chi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Acer Group has won four 2011 iF product design awards for two notebooks, a monitor and a projector, the company announced in a statement Friday.
The products gaining recognition were the Acer Aspire 8943G notebook, the Acer C20 pico projector, the Packard Bell EasyNote Butterfly s notebook, and the Gateway FHD2303L monitor, Acer said.

Of those products, the Acer Aspire 8943G, had already won three other prestigious awards -- the Japan Good Design, Computex Taipei Design and Innovation Gold, and Computex Best Choice -- and the Gateway monitor had won the Japan Good Design award, Acer said.
The iF product design awards cover all areas of product design, with entries judged on design workmanship, choice of material, environmental compatibility and functionality. the company said.

The iF awards have been held since 1953 and are recognized as a benchmark for good design. The awards have been presented in many different fields, including product design, communication design, packing design, material, and concept.
This year, 2,756 products from 1,121 contestants in 43 countries joined the contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: China urged to address cross-strait issues with benevolence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 20:38:05 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China should promote a Chinese cultural renaissance and handle cross-Taiwan Strait issues with benevolence if it wants to be a great world power, former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday.

Liu said British historian Arnold J. Toynbee predicted that the only human civilizations that could save the world in the 21st century were the Chinese civilization of Confucianism and the Buddhist civilization of Mahayana Buddhism.
But Liu said Toynbee's prediction could not come true unless today's China made a great contribution to global cultural development.

"While China has emerged as an economic powerhouse and is the world's largest manufacturing center and consumer market, it would not be able to command the same stature or influence as Britain in the 19th century and America in the 20th century if it fails to contribute greatly to human civilization and culture," Liu argued.

Speaking at a ceremony at the Presidential Office in his capacity as president of the National Cultural Association, Liu suggested that China follow the principles of "benevolent rule" preached by Mencius (372-289 B.C.), arguably the most famous Confucianist after Confucius himself.

Moreover, China should initiate a Chinese cultural renaissance and draw on the essence of traditional Chinese culture while learning from the fusion of ancient and modern cultures and Eastern and Western civilizations, Liu said.

On President Ma Ying-jeou's appeal in his 2010 New Year's Day speech that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should seek a pragmatic and feasible solution to their disputes on the basis of traditional Chinese culture, Liu said the first step toward that goal is to address cross-strait issues with a benevolent way of thinking.

Liu cited a media report published during negotiations between Taiwan and China on the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) earlier this year to underscore the importance of Mencius' philosophy of "benevolent rule" in dealing with Taiwan-China affairs.
According to the report, some Chinese officials found Taiwan's call for China to yield further concessions under the ECFA's early harvest program annoying.
But under a benevolent mind-set, Liu said, justice, righteousness or fairness should always take precedence over unilateral interests.
For its part, Liu said, Taiwan can play the role of vanguard and catalyst in the pursuit of a Chinese cultural renaissance.

As an immigrant society, Taiwan is inclusive and innovative in cultural development, and it can use those assets to help shape new rules of the game for the 21st century, such as how to deal with international disputes with benevolence and devise ways to ensure sustainable development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Orchid Island to catch country's first sunrise of 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 20:41:32 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's outlying Orchid Island will be the first location in the country to welcome the sun on New Year's Day, with the first glimpse of the rising sun expected at 6: 33 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Friday.
For those hoping to greet the first sunrise on the main island of Taiwan, the CWB said the top options would be major scenic spots in southern Taiwan.
According to the CWB, Kending in Pingtung County and Sansiantai along the southeastern coast in Taitung County will both see the sunrise at 6: 35 a.m., the earliest anywhere on the island.
In northern Taiwan, the best location will be Sandiaojiao in Taipei County, where the sunrise is expected to take place at 6: 37 a.m.

The CWB's astronomic observatory explained that because the incident angle of the sun (the angle at which it strikes the earth's surface) is steep in the southern hemisphere in December, the further south people go, the earlier they will see the sunrise.

"Daytime in southern Taiwan will be slightly longer than that in northern areas, which explains why the sunrise comes earlier and the sunset later there, " said Ho Pei-li, the observatory's associate technical specialist.

As a result, people who want to waive farewell to the last sunset of 2010 should also head south, where they can see it at 17: 25 p.m. in Cigu in Tainan County and Cijin in Kaohsiung City, according to the CWB forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental groups urge halt to man-made lake plan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 22:03:18 (By Justin Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Environmental groups urged the Executive Yuan on Friday to put a stop to a man- made lake development project in southern Taiwan to prevent the pumping of underground water in a way that would endanger the water rights of over 1 million people.

Members of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) asked the Executive Yuan that it not approve the Jiyang Man-Made Lake Project, which would straddle Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, before a new environmental impact assessment is provided and the project's content is finalized.

Hung Hui-hsiang, chairman of the TEPU's Pingtung Chapter, said he had no idea why the government changed its original plan to use the lakes to conserve surface water from the Laonong River during the rainy season into filling them with groundwater pumped from Meinong, Cishan and Ligang townships.

Under the new plan, expected to be approved at the end of this year, the two man-made lakes will be 12 meters deep and will extract some 200,000 cubic meters of groundwater a day from those three townships to fill the lakes, according to Hung.
"Excessively pumping groundwater is a suicidal and irreversible act," Hung said at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

He suggested that the WRA tackle the water-shortage problem at its root by clearing out the illegal aquaculture ponds along the Laonong River, which regularly use subsurface water flow, and choose other proper locations to build the man-made lakes, if the development of such lakes is absolutely necessary.

TEPU Secretary-General Lee Cho-han said, meanwhile, that he suspected the man- made lake development project was aimed at benefiting gravel industry operators as some 30 million tons of high-quality gravel worth over NT$10 billion would be created by the project.

Wu Li-hui, a spokeswoman for the TEPU's Tainan Chapter, said the development project could bring about a repeat the disastrous digging of 13 groundwater wells by Taiwan Water Corp. in Ligang Township in the early 1990s.
The 13 wells, pumping some 100,000 cubic meters of water per day, drained the township's groundwater, sparking outcries from local residents and aquaculture pond operators.
As a result, the Pingtung County government was forced to order the wells closed, Wu said.

On the environmental activists' suspicions that the project was a pretext to benefit gravel developers, WRA Director-General Yang Wei-fuu said the theory was outdated because gravel has been in abundant supply since Typhoon Morakot hit Taiwan in August 2009.
Since that time, a huge amount of gravel has been dredged from the Cishan and Laonong Rivers, which flow into the Gaoping River, he said.
Yang pledged that the WRA would give top priority to capturing subsurface flow -- the precipitation that penetrates the soil through infiltration -- to supply water in southern Taiwan.
But he said the volume of subsurface flow was inadequate and not consistently available around the year, necessitating the development of the man-made lakes to store water and stabilize supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five special municipalities to begin operation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 22:23:50 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Five special municipalities across Taiwan with 60 percent of the country's population will begin operations Saturday, kicking off a new phase in Taiwan's administrative history.

Taipei, Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung will begin operating as mega cities almost one month after the residents of the five municipalities chose their mayors in high profile elections on Nov. 27.
In addition to Taipei City and Xinbei City, the former Taipei County, the other three cities were expanded through a merger of two administrative districts.
Greater Taichung City is the result of a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County; Tainan a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County; and Kaohsiung a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County.

According to Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah, the change is aimed at making the five mega cities "spearheads of Taiwan's regional development" and "cores of the three living areas of northern, central and southern Taiwan."

The new system is not likely to affect the everyday life of the 13.7 million residents in the five cities, but integrating local governments and administrative branches are likely to present a big challenge in the cities where mergers took place.

Tainan and Kaohsiung both split their agencies into two parts to keep them in their original office buildings while Taichung City opted for three office buildings in different parts of its administrative area.

Effective Saturday, townships and county-administered cities will also be renamed "districts" and villages will be renamed "wards." District chiefs will be appointed by mayors rather than being elected, as was previously the case.
Township councils will be disbanded, which means thousands of township and city councilmen have lost their jobs.

Newly elected mayors have focused on the financial aspects of the new city governments. Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu publicly expressed concerns that the city would be in financial trouble if budget allocating procedures and tax regulations were not reformed.
Xinbei City faced a different problem -- trying to figure out what to call itself in English.
Mayor Eric Liluan Chu wanted to change the new city's name to "New Taipei City," because Xinbei means "new Taipei" in Chinese.
But the move was blocked by the Ministry of the Interior for now, with Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang saying the ministry would discuss the proposal with Chu at a later date.

DOC.HEADLINE: Engineer's death may be re-defined as 'karoshi' under new rules
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 22:48:24 (By Kelven Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) committee is examining whether the death of a Nanya Technology Corp. engineer in January could be defined as related to overwork under newly promulgated rules, an official said Thursday.

If the Occupational Disease Appraisal Committee determines that the engineer died from overwork, the Bureau of Labor Insurance's previous classification of the man's passing as a "non-occupational death" will be revoked, said CLA Vice Minister Kuo Fang-yu.

The 29-year-old engineer, surnamed Hsu, was found dead in front of his computer at home in January. His parents said he had been putting in about 95 hours of overtime per month for six months before his death.
The Bureau of Labor Insurance, however, did not classify it as a case of karoshi -- the Japanese word for death from overwork after an initial examination.

The decision drew criticism from labor rights groups, who were dismayed by the CLA's failure to protect wage earners' legitimate rights and interests because of what they called flaws and deficiencies in existing laws.
Kuo argued at a news conference called by several ruling Kuomintang legislators Friday that there have been regulations governing the appraisal of occupational injury and death.
"Controversies might have risen mainly because relevant provisions were not clear and concrete enough," Kuo said.
Responding to widespread concern, he said, the CLA already announced new guidelines on Wednesday for defining "death from overwork" as an occupational disease.
"The new guidelines will make it easier for doctors and investigators to classify the case as death or injury from overwork, "Kuo said.
The new guidelines follow the standards used in Japan, which include contributing factors such as abnormal working conditions, heavy short-term overwork, and long-term overwork, Kuo said.
Under the new standards, long-term overwork is defined as 92 hours of overtime in the month before death, or 72 hours of overtime per month for two to six months before death.

Based on the new guidelines, the range of conditions that could be attributed to overwork have been expanded to include ischemic heart disease, severe cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac arrest, sudden cardiac death, cerebral hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, acute heart failure and aortic rupture, he added.

The CLA is expected to announce a decision soon in Hsu's case. If the CLA rules in favor of the family, the Bureau of Labor Insurance and Nanya Technology, a DRAM memory chip maker affiliated with the Formosa Plastics Group, will each have to pay the engineer's family the equivalent of 45 months of his salary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks CAS arbitration of taekwondo dispute
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 22:53:26 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has sent a World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) ruling suspending a Taiwanese athlete from competition to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), hoping that it will hear the case, the government said Friday.

The Lausanne, Switzerland-based CAS could be expected to make a ruling on the case in three months if it establishes it has jurisdiction over the case, said Chow Jui, director of the International Sports Department of the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council.

On Dec. 21, the WTF suspended Yang Shu-chun from competition for three months for refusing to leave the mat after she was disqualified from her opening round bout in the women's taekwondo at the under 49 kg division at the Asian Games in Guangzhou in November.
Her coach Liu Tsung-ta, who later lodged a protest after the disqualification, was punished with 20-month suspension, and the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association (CTTA) was fined US$50,000.
CTTA Chairman Chen Chien-ping said the association has not determined when it will pay the fine. The WTF ruled that the US$50,000 fine should be paid by Jan. 31, 2011.

Yang, who was one of the gold medal favorites in the event, was apparently disqualified for wearing two extra electronic sensors on her socks to score extra points, but a replay of the bout showed she did not have them on as she took a 9-0 lead against her Vietnamese opponent.

After hearing she was disqualified for reasons she could not understand, a shocked Yang refused to leave the ring and broke into tears, knowing that her gold medal hopes had disappeared after less than two minutes of action in the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC looks to public for fair judgment on TV license decision
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/10 23:25:31 (By Huang Hui-min and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) said Friday it was following the law in revoking the license of a commercial TV channel, a decision that it believed would be judged fairly by the public.

The NCC's decision on Dec. 22 to not renew the ERA TV's license for its entertainment channel has sparked heated debate, with some opposition lawmakers suggesting that the NCC might have acted unlawfully and expressing concerns that the decision could have a "chilling effect" on the media industry as a whole.

Denying that the NCC was "bullying" the TV station, NCC spokesman Chen Cheng- tsang said the regulator had followed all legal procedures -- including warning, fining and suspending the station's operating permit -- before deciding not to renew its license.

An NCC task force reviewing the application to renew the channel's license found that over the past six years, the channel had repeatedly violated a Satellite TV Broadcasting Act ban on embedded advertising and other provisions of the act, and had fined it a total of NT$16.75 million for 49 violations, Chen said.

The entertainment channel's license should have been revoked in Feb. this year, but the NCC decided at that time to give it a "grace period" in the hope that it would meet the NCC's requirements and earn the right to continue its operations, according to Chen.

One such requirement was quite simple -- not to violate the ban again, he said, but instead of taking advantage of the opportunity, the TV channel broke the ban on March 14 and March 16 by airing programs in which advertisements were mixed into the content.

On July 15, the NCC gave the TV channel a stern warning, effectively withdrawing its operating permit. Still, the channel continued to broadcast programs without permits and violated the rules five more times, which should have resulted in fines totaling NT$3.6 million, Chen said.
The NCC did not fine the entertainment channel until Dec. 22, when it finally decided to reject its application for renewing the license and to fine it NT$2.1 million, the spokesman said.

Observers have wondered why if the NCC felt its decision was legitimate and reasonable did it wait for three days, during which criticism against the decision mounted, before it offered an explanation.
Chen said that just like school authorities who decide to expel a student for good reason, the NCC did not have to say anything about revoking the station's license.
The NCC believes that members of the public will judge its decision fairly, he said, adding that if ERA TV thinks the decision is unfair, it could file a complaint with the administrative court.
As to some media operators' concern that the NCC decision would have a "chilling effect" on them, Chen said, "As long as you abide by the law, you don't have to worry about anything."
Chen said he was aware some suspected that President Ma Ying-jeou might have interfered in the case while others have accused the NCC of having acted out of partisan rather than public interests.

But he rejected the speculation, saying the president "absolutely did not" play any role in the NCC decision on ERA TV and stressed that, "as an independent government agency, our members have acted independently."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 25, 2010, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1915: Tang Chi-yao, Tsai O and others declare independence of Yunnan Province and the establishment of the National Protection Army against self-proclaimed Emperor Yuan Shi-kai.
1926: Japanese Emperor Taisho dies, ushering in a new era of Showa under Emperor Hirohito.
1936: National Government Military Commission Chairman Generalissimo Chiang Kai- shek is freed and flies safely from Xian to Luoyang.
1945: National Taiwan University unveils a list of 36 hopefuls who have passed the school's first ever entrance examination.
1946: The National Constituent Assembly passes the Constitution of the Republic of China.
1947: The Republic of China Constitution goes into effect.
1948: The Mandarin Daily News -- the only paper to use mandarin phonetic symbols along with Chinese characters -- is launched in Taipei City.
1962: The Republic of China government proclaims Dec. 25 as Constitution Day and designates it as a national holiday.
1969: The first Taipei City Council since the city's upgrading to a special municipality is inaugurated, with Lin Ting-sheng elected as speaker; Lo Chia- lun, a national policy adviser to the President, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1975: The first national literary award is introduced in Taiwan, but only Kuo Yi wins a prize, in the photography category; there are no winners in other categories.
1977: Charlie Chaplin, U.S. actor and director, dies in Switzerland at the age of 88.
1986: Sixty-two people killed when a hijacked Iraqi passenger plane explodes during a forced landing at a Saudi Arabia airport.
1989: Romania dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are executed after being sentenced to death by a military court.
1997: The Taipei metro's Danshuei Line opens in full.
2003: A passenger plane bound for Beirut crashes into the sea shortly after taking off from Benin, West Africa, killing 111.
2005: Taiwan Television Enterprise Chairman Lai Kuo-chou, General Manager Cheng Yu-ho, Chinese Television System Chairman Chou Jung-sheng and General Manager Chiang Hsia, as well as the directors and supervisors that represent the government at the two TV stations, resign en masse in line with a government policy on the withdrawal of political, governmental and military influence from the media.
2007: According to the World Economic Forum's "2007-2008 Global Competitiveness Report,"Taiwan has again taken first place in the world in the "state of Cluster Development" index.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Hau kicks off second term as Taipei mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 12:35:04 (By C. W. Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei mayor-elect Hau Lung-bin took the oath Saturday to begin his second four- year term, vowing to invigorate the capital city and strengthen its role as the bellwether of the country's five special municipalities.

Hau said he will do his utmost to sharpen the city's competitiveness amid fierce competition from foreign cities such as Shanghai, Tokyo and Seoul by attracting more young talent and injecting greater vigor into it through a series of development policies focusing on urban renewal, transportation and social housing.
Based on the foundation that he has laid down over the past four years, he promised to turn Taipei into an international metropolis.

Four other new special municipalities -- Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung -- were formed that same day through an upgrade or merger. Total population of the five mega cities account for some 60 percent of the country's total.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor-elect sworn in
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 12:43:40 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Jason Hu was sworn in Saturday as the first mayor of the new special municipality of Taichung, which was officially formed that day by merging Taichung City with Taichung County.
Hu, who had formerly served as mayor of Taichung City for nine years, pledged to assume his new responsibility with caution and care.
"We need to take up this brand-new challenge with brand-new concepts and determination," Hu said during the swearing-in ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lai becomes first mayor of greater Tainan City
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 13:10:03 (By J. H. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lai Ching-te took oath Saturday as the first mayor of the new special municipality of Tainan, which was officially formed that day by merging Tainan City with Tainan County.

Minister without Portfolio Ovid Tzeng presided over the swearing-in ceremony of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rising star. DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen, former Premier Yu Shyi-kun and former Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen also witnessed the event as special guests.
Addressing the ceremony, Lai capitalized on the historical and cultural importance of Tainan and pledged to restore the city's old glory.
"We hereby welcome the new birth of this city, " he said, adding that the merger will allow Tainan to use its special features to transform itself into a unique city.

Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung began operations Saturday as mega cities along with Taipei after the residents of the five special municipalities chose their mayors in high profile elections on Nov. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chu sworn in as Xinbei mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Xinbei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 13:49:38 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Eric Liluan Chu assumed office Saturday as the first mayor of the new special municipality of Xinbei, an upgrade of Taipei County.
Chu said the day marked the beginning of a new age when Xinbei City will compete its municipal governance performance with four other special municipalities in the country.
"There will not be any holidays over my coming four-year term. Every day will be a workday to strive for the development of Xinbei," he said during the swearing- in ceremony.
The city has not figured out what to call itself in English.
Chu wanted to change the new city's name to "New Taipei City, " because Xinbei means "new Taipei" in Chinese.
But the move was blocked by the Ministry of the Interior for now, with Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang saying the ministry would discuss the proposal with Chu at a later date.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Social housing needs public support

TEXT.P: In Taiwan, "public housing" is equal to "slums " and people have the stereotyped impression that building a public housing project in their communities will lower their quality of living and the value of their homes.

No wonder local residents have been protesting against a proposal by the Taipei city government to build a social housing project in the city's Songshan district. A plan by the National Property Administration to build an old-age housing complex in the city's Neihu district was also forced to a halt due to strong opposition by residents.

In promoting the social housing policy, the government should first remove such prejudice from society. It should tell people that social housing is not cheap housing that groups disadvantaged individuals together. Rather, it is mixed- incoming housing intended to allow financially weaker groups such as young people and single parents to rent a proper place to live in at an affordable price.

The government must display its determination and ability to realize the policy. The people, on the other hand, should broaden their horizons and open their minds to help the government achieve the goal. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor takes office
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 15:00:00 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu took her oath and began her four-year term in office Saturday, vowing to build new horizons for the port city that was officially merged with neighboring Kaohsiung County that day in the Kaohsiung special municipality.
Minister without Portfolio Lin Junq-tzer presided over the swearing-in ceremony and handed the official seal over to Chen.

Lin reiterated President Ma Ying-jeou's concern for striking a balanced development between northern and southern Taiwan and noted that many of the central government's 12 major development projects will be carried out in the south.

Former Premier Frank Hsieh, a former Kaohsiung mayor, also took part in the ceremony, which was marred by a tiny group of protesters who demanded that Chen step down over controversy about the construction of a liquid petroleum gas station in the city.
Both Chen and Hsieh are heavyweights of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Immediately following her inauguration, Chen called a meeting with all bureau chiefs and approved several documents, including one to set up a committee to promote reconstruction in areas damaged by Typhoon Morakot in 2009.
She stressed that all resources will be equally shared and fairly distributed and pledged to reduce the gap between the rural and urban areas under her administration.

The economy, flood prevention, public security, green energy and hinterland development will be high on her agenda as part of her efforts to transform the largest port city in Taiwan, according to Chen.
Kaohsiung, along with Xinbei, Taichung and Tainan, was upgraded to the status of a special municipality Dec. 25, following upgrading or mergers of cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Bidding farewell to four counties
DOC.DATELINE: 12/25/10 15:07:30 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Four counties in Taiwan became history Dec. 25, 2010, when they were reclassified as special municipalities as a result of upgrade or mergers.
On the eve of the historic day, many staff of the disappearing Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung county governments shed tears as they watched the signs of their old offices being replaced.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

At 5 p.m. Dec. 24, Taichung County government staff and residents of the central county gathered at County Hall to observe the county flag being lowered for the last time. They sang the county anthem, some in tears.
"I have served in the county government for 30 years, from teenager to middle- aged woman, " said caretaker Lin Mei-fen.

County resident Wang Li-huei traveled from Dali Township to take part in the flag-lowering ceremony. "I have never attended a flag-hoisting ceremony, so I thought I should be here for the last flag-lowering ritual," she told reporters.
In the southern county of Tainan, outgoing Magistrate Su Huan-chih hosted a farewell party at County Hall that evening. He said that "Tainan County" will always stay in the hearts of its residents.
Outgoing Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin bade a weeping farewell to every member of the county government staff before leaving County Hall, established 60 years ago. (Dec. 25, 2010).
China Times:
While the Kaohsiung county government was submerged in sorrow over its closure, street vendors in the county said they sensed no difference in the change of status.
"We still have to do business and live our lives, even though Kaohsiung County is gone," said vendor Hsiao Kuo-yu.
On the eve of its formal upgrading to a special municipality, Taipei County -- which will be renamed Xinbei after the upgrade -- attracted many people to County Hall to capture its last image.
High-ranking staff were busy packing, since the new government has its own administrative team.

Meanwhile, several aboriginal groups staged a protest in front of the Legislative Yuan Friday, voicing fear that their autonomy rights will be harmed after the inauguration of the new municipalities. (Dec. 25, 2010).
Liberty Times:
Taipei County, Taichung County, Tainan County and Kaohsiung County disappeared from the map of Taiwan on Dec. 25, 2010.

While most of the outgoing magistrates appeared to be looking forward to the new era, with their counties upgraded to special municipalities, Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin expressed concern over the possibility that the county will be marginalized after merging with Kaohsiung City.
Many of the county government staff might lose their jobs due to the merger, he said. (Dec. 25, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Death from overwork disgraces employers

TEXT.P: Recently there have been a string of deaths from overwork reported in Taiwan. The increase in these cases means that Taiwan workers have too heavy workloads but too little time to rest.

The work hours of Taiwanese are often rated as the world's longest or second- longest in international surveys. This is not a glorious record, because it shows that Taiwanese do not pay attention to leisure and that there is a lack of care for humanity in the work environment.

This might be linked to the influence of Confucianism, which emphasizes obedience, diligence and compliance with morality. Individuals who work themselves to death are therefore commendable, according to Confucian principles.
It is, however, more important to allow everyone to enjoy proper working conditions, such as reasonable work hours, reasonable workloads, reasonable pay and reasonable benefits.

It is time to change our Confucian way of thinking. What we need are work ethics that are consistent with humanity. Allowing workers to die from overwork is a shame on employers. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP to run Taipei, Kaohsiung city councils together
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 15:44:20 (By Chen Hung-chin, Lee Hsi-chang, Chen Chao-fu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) secured the seats of speaker of the Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils Saturday, but lost to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the elections for deputy speaker.

KMT's Wu Bi-chu was elected speaker with 37 of the 62 Taipei city councilor votes, beating DPP candidate Lee Chien-chang, New Party candidate Pan Huei-chung and Chen Chien-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
It marks the fourth time Wu has been elected to serve in the post.
Chou Po-ya of the DPP won the position of Wu's deputy, garnering one vote more than his KMT rival, Chen Chin-hsiang.
Taipei City was the first of the country's five special municipalities to complete the elections for city council speaker and deputy speaker that began earlier in the day.

Meanwhile, independent Chang Ching-tang, speaker of the just abolished Taichung County Council, was elected speaker of the new Taichung City Council, and Lin Shih-chang of the KMT won the deputy speaker election.
In Kaohsiung City in the south, Hsu Kun-yuan of the KMT beat other contestants to win the speaker post in the 66-seat city council, with Tsai Chang-ta of the DPP as his deputy.
As of press time, the elections for speakers and deputy speakers have not yet completed in Xinbei City and Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight Chinese tourists injured in tour bus accident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 16:35:20 (By T.C. Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Eight Chinese tourists were slightly injured Saturday in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County when their tour bus crashed into a custard apple farm, police said that day.

The tour bus, carrying 36 school principals and teachers from China's Guangdong Province, was traveling from Taitung to Hualien when the accident occurred. A brick cabin, several custard apple trees and roadside trees were damaged.
Some of the tourists jumped out of the tour bus after breaking its windows following the crash, witnesses said.
The driver, who was briefly knocked unconscious, claimed to have no idea how the accident occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: Century-old train station to celebrate ROC centennial
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 16:47:54 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: A railway museum remodeled from the disused Kaohsiung Port Station said Saturday it will celebrate the retirement of date stampers that have been in use since the Japanese colonial period and give away memorial train tickets on the eve of the country's centennial.

The century-old stampers will have to stop being used from 2011, the 100th year of the Republic of China, because the machines were only designed to mark double-digit years on cardboard-style train tickets, according to the Takao Railway Museum.
The museum will extend its opening hours to 9 p.m. on New Year's Eve and invite railway fans to get the historic 99.12.31 stamp on specially designed train tickets to mark the event.
The cardboard tickets, reading "From Kaohsiung Station to Huwei Station," according to the museum, have an interesting connotation.
"Huwei in Chinese means 'tiger's tail, '" explained Hou I-ming, executive secretary of the museum.
"As we are at the end of the Year of Tiger according to the Chinese calendar, we hope the tickets will send a joyful message that Kaohsiung is approaching the end of the Year of Tiger," she said.
Kaohsiung Port Station operated from 1908 to 2008. It was originally named Old Takao Station under Japanese rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier returns home after concluding tour of Burkina Faso
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 16:52:53 (By Bien Chin-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih returned to Taipei Saturday after finishing a tour of Burkina Faso, his first visit to the West African ally as premier.
Wu was greeted by his deputy Sean Chen at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport upon his arrival.
Wu left Taiwan Dec. 18 to attend the Dec. 20 inauguration of President Blaise Compaore for a new term on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Wu was the first Republic of China premier to visit Burkina Faso since the two countries resumed diplomatic relations in 1994.

During his stay, he also hosted the completion ceremony for a Taiwan-funded vocational training center, visited a new hospital constructed with a loan from a Taiwanese bank, and inspected a Taiwan-initiated solar street lamp construction program.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT wins Xinbei speaker seat; DPP seizes Tainan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 17:38:28 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) won the seat of speaker of the Xinbei City Council Saturday but was defeated by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Tainan City Council election.
In Xinbei City, Chen Hsing-chin of the KMT was elected speaker, while Chen Hung- yuan, also of the KMT, was elected vice speaker.

Meanwhile, Lai Mei-hui of the DPP secured the speakership in Tainan City, making her the first ever female speaker in the Tainan area in southern Taiwan. The vice speakership was seized by Kuo Hsin-liang, also of the DPP.
Xinbei and Tainan are two of four new or expanded special municipalities that officially began operations Saturday after their mayors were sworn in.

Xinbei is an upgrade of Taipei County, while Tainan is the result of a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County. The other two are Taichung, a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County in central Taiwan; and Kaohsiung, a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.

According to Ministry of the Interior statistics, the population of the already existing special municipality of Taipei City and the four new special municipalities totals 13.81 million, accounting for 59.63 percent of Taiwan's total.

The city with the largest population is Xinbei, with 3.89 million people. Kaohsiung comes in second with 2.77 million, followed by Taichung (2.64 million) , Taipei (2.61 million) , and Tainan (1.87 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars predict China, DPP engagement in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 18:22:15 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: China will talk more about the "1992 consensus" than the one China principle, while Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will seek dialogue with China without giving up its pro-independence stance in 2011, scholars predicted Saturday.

"China is expected to maintain its support of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and President Ma Ying-jeou. At the same time, it will launch dialogue with the DPP as a hedging strategy, " Lai I-chung, a researcher of the Taiwan Thinktank, said in a symposium organized by the pro-independence Taiwan New Century Foundation.

China is likely to talk more about the "1992 consensus" and anti-Taiwan independence in the coming year rather than its long-standing one China principle, Lai said, because it does not want to jeopardize President Ma Ying- jeou's re-election bid in 2012 with a hawkish position.

The DPP, meanwhile, is expected to show pragmatism in its new China policy, which has not yet been formulated, in order to move to a more centrist position for the 2012 presidential election, according to Lai.

Lai forecast that the DPP, under the leadership of Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, will present its new China policy based on a 1999 resolution stating that the DPP upholds that Taiwan is an independent country named the Republic of China.

The party will likely highlight the risk management of cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges and seek dialogue with China without prerequisites, he said, adding that China will also seek to engage the DPP.
But the engagement will be confined to scholarly exchanges rather than a party- to-party dialogue, since the DPP still advocates Taiwan independence, he said.
Yan Jiann-fa, a professor at Ching Yun University who served in the former DPP government, said the DPP is going through a transformation period, in particular in its China policy.

Citing a public opinion poll conducted by Global Views magazine in May 2009 revealing that 48.5 percent of the respondents favored eventual independence over 16.2 percent who preferred eventual unification, Yang said the DPP had realized a change of direction is needed for the party.

While the independence-unification issue has always been the most sensitive and critical issue in Taiwan's political debates, neither Taiwan nor China are in a hurry to touch upon the issue, Yan said.
"Beijing is not in a hurry to unify with Taiwan as long as Taiwan does not `stray too far, ' because it has its own domestic and exterior problems to handle, " he said.

Yan added that it would be better for Taiwan to focus on solving more urgent domestic issues at present, such as decreasing the wealth gap and improving national spatial planning, both of which affect the everyday lives of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds Chiayi City band festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 18:33:09 (By T.K. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Large crowds of local residents took to the streets of Chiayi City Saturday in a jubilant atmosphere as part of programs of an annual international band festival that opened on Christmas Eve.

In an address to open the large-scale parade, President Ma Ying- jeou said the annual event, coupled with features of the Chiayi area, has become a stage that has helped attract global attention to Taiwan.
"Chiayi serves as the best example of how a city can display its soft power," Ma said.

Chiayi City in southern Taiwan has since 1993 sponsored the band festival every year. This year, 64 bands from home and abroad, including countries such as China, Germany, Japan and Thailand, will stage 73 performances at the festival that will run until Jan. 2.
The festival theme this year will be extended from "festival activities" into five characteristics -- art, education, entertainment, memory and society, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next TV pushes for additional Taiwan presence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 18:48:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Next TV station set up by Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai showed new determination Saturday to reach a wider local audience after its repeated failures to obtain an operating license for its news channel from Taiwan's government media watchdog.

Next TV was slated to give away 2,000 TV set-top boxes worth a combined value of NT$6 million (US$202,800) to a long line of waiting people in Taipei on a cold rainy day before the TV station officially opens Dec. 28.

To help raise publicity, Next TV has been running a series of TV commercials in recent days in which Lai is portrayed as being pregnant, suggesting that he is about to give birth to the Next TV station.

Next TV has been broadcasting news and entertainment programs on the Internet since July this year after the National Communications Commission (NCC) rejected several license applications from the company from late 2009 due to concerns over the sensationalism of its animated news.
Next TV, nevertheless, won approval for movie and sports channels earlier this year.
In an animated video played at a press briefing, Next TV mocked the NCC for "not giving licenses to those it doesn't like."
The TV station's chairman, Chu Wah-hui, said at the press briefing that a new application was submitted to the NCC in late November that is still awaiting a reply.
Next TV has already issued invitations to the subscribers of the Chinese- language Apple Daily and Next Magazine, both owned by Lai, for the free set-top boxes.
Asked how many will be given away, Chu declined to offer a specific number, although media reports put the number at nearly 80,000.
Chen Jeng-chang of the NCC said the council will monitor Next TV's programs and will take action if any of them violate the law.
Also Saturday, Next TV vowed to bring quality digital TV to local audiences while criticizing the government's lack of progress on the development of TV digitization.
"Taiwan has world-leading information technology ability, but it falls far behind China and Hong Kong in terms of TV digitization, " Chu said.
"Taiwan's digital TV penetration rate is 6 percent to 7 percent, which is much lower than in neighboring countries," he said.
The government has vowed to boost the penetration rate to 50 percent by 2015, a goal that is similar to China's current penetration rate, Chu said.
Asked how he sees an upcoming rival in TV digitization, Da-fu Media, Chu said it is good to see more businesses involved in the field.
Da-fu Media has become Taiwan's largest cable TV operator after acquiring Kbro Co. from U.S. private equity firm the Carlyle Group Dec. 17.
TV digitization allows viewers to watch programs on demand, to have interaction with TV presenters or to play games on TV, according to a Next TV executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: CityU head invites Taiwanese young people to study in Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 19:25:27 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The visiting president of City University (CityU) of Hong Kong, Way Kuo, has said that he wants to persuade elite Taiwanese high school students to study at his school.
It is Kuo's second recruitment drive in Taiwan since he assumed office as CityU president in May 2008.

During a meeting with local reporters on Friday, Kuo, who was born and had most of his education in Taiwan before moving to the United States, where he lived for more than three decades, said he "likes Taiwan a lot."
However, practically no high school graduates from Taiwan opt to study at universities in Hong Kong, said Kuo.
Taiwan is close to Hong Kong geographically, but seems nevertheless to be a great distance from the former British colony, he said.

Enrolling Taiwanese students in Hong Kong universities provides advantages for both places since Hong Kong can have more diverse campuses while Taiwanese young people can also see a bit more of the world, according to Kuo.
Advocating the globalization of universities, he said that distinguished professors and teachers can improve a university's environment, while globalization can sharpen its competitive edge.
CityU is the first Hong Kong university to come to Taiwan to recruit students. It has a total of 27 students from Taiwan, 18 of whom were enrolled this year.
Kuo, a fellow of Taiwan's top academic research institute Academia Sinica, received a PhD in nuclear engineering in 1980 from Kansas State University.

Kuo, also an elected member of the U.S. National Academy of Engineering, is renowned for his work in designing and modeling reliability for electronics systems and products, and is a recipient of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers' Reliability Society Lifetime Achievement Award.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan routs Thailand in Asian Little League
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 20:07:28 (By M.C. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei gained its second straight win Saturday at the Asian Little League Championships being held in Japan, triumphing over Thailand 16-0 in a game that ended in the fifth inning.

"All 15 players took part in the game and we scored an overwhelming win, " Kuo Tong-yen, leader and coach of the Taiwanese team, told CNA. "The third hitter, Wang Wei-an, and the seventh hitter, Yeh Huang-you, both turned in outstanding performances," he said.
"In the pitching lineup, five players were called to the mound rotationally in such a way that we totally blocked the strikes of the Thai hitters," he said.
Kuo said he is hopeful the team will get through to the semifinals as long as they can adapt to the weather in Japan, which is much colder than in Taiwan.

The Chinese Taipei team, composed of players from several elementary and junior high schools in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, narrowly defeated China 4-3 the previous day in its opening match of the championships that kicked off earlier that same day in Kurashiki, Okayama Prefecture. Kuo is chief coach at Gueishan Junior High School.
Taiwan, China, Indonesia and Thailand are grouped in the A division, while division B groups Japan, South Korea, Pakistan and Hong Kong.
The top team from each group will compete on the 27th, with the semifinal winners meeting for the championship game the day after that.
The Asian Little League Championships have been held every two years in a country in the region since they began in 2000. Taiwan has won the championship four straight times since 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: Choreographer working with non-dancers for centennial celebration
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 21:14:30 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Audiences will be surprised and touched by an upcoming dance performance by a group of non-dancers whose passion will make their dream of being dancers come true, Taiwanese choreographer Cheng Tsung-lung said Saturday.

Cheng, an emerging choreographer and former dancer with Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, has been working with 60 untrained dancers and 10 professional dancers on a 15-minute dance that will make its debut Dec. 31 as part of the Republic of China centennial celebrations.
The 34-year-old choreographer said that celebrating the country's birthday is a good thing, but that as an artist, he wants to find greater meaning for the celebration.
"The celebration will not be complete without the participation of the public, because the country is made up of each and every individual," he told reporters after a Saturday rehearsal.
With this in mind, he held auditions several months ago to recruit 60 untrained dancers with a passion for dance, and started a three-month training project.

He admitted that there were a lot of frustrations, as it was difficult to get ordinary people to change the way they use their bodies. However, as time went by, he said, he was very touched to see the performersjoy in moving and their willingness to work together to finish the challenge.
"I think I will burst into tears when the dance is presented on stage,he said.
Cheng said the 15-minute dance is about presentingthe struggles, troubles and hopes of everyday life.
The dance includes a two- to three-minute section during which 44 dancers will have part of their bodies submerged in water, which poses an even greater challenge for the non-dancers, he added.
In March 2007, Cheng's Tete Beche won the Bronze Medal of the No Ballet 1st International Choreography Competition in Ludwigshafen, Germany, beating out 300 competitors.

He has since created and restaged works for several international dance companies, including Transitions Dance Company at the Laban Centre, London, Expressions Dance Company in Brisbane, Australia and the Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Applicants for German working visas show creativity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 21:37:06 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Herding sheep. Learning to make German sausage. Working at German theaters. Traveling around Germany to look for suitable schools and thesis instructors for future doctoral study programs.

These are just a few of the proposals presented by Taiwanese applicants for German working holiday visas that have impressed officials at Germany's representative office in Taiwan with their ingenuity.

Heinrich Hubbe, deputy director of the legal affairs division at the German Institute Taipei, said he is often amazed by the diversity and creativity of working holiday programs made up by Taiwanese hopefuls since the office began accepting visa applications Oct. 11.

Some of the applicants used paintings, graphics and diagrams to explain their work and travel plans, Hubbes said, adding that he has been moved by the novelty and lavishness of some of the presentations.

Germany is the first European country to have signed a working holiday agreement with Taiwan, under which up to 200 Taiwanese citizens aged between 18 and 30 are allowed each year to enjoy a maximum one-year stay in Germany and to undertake incidental work to supplement their holiday money. The reciprocal nature of the program offers similar opportunities for young Germans to undertake working holidays in Taiwan.

Hubbe said the local response to the program has been extremely enthusiastic. In the first few days following the announcement of the program, he recalled, phone glitches were reported at the German representative office occasionally because of the number of inquiries being made.

"Moreover, an average of 6,000 people visited our website each day, far outnumbering the average of 1,000 to 1,500 before the program was launched, " Hubbe went on, adding that the significant increase reflects the popularity of the program.

In addition to producing health insurance certificates and proof of financial status, applicants are required to present a report detailing their motivation for applying for working holiday visas and the activities they plan to do during their stay.
The German office also arranges a 15-minute face-to-face interview for a each applicant.
"What we want to see is that the person is really well-planned and wants to achieve something," Hubbe said.
So long as hopefuls present clear plans, their applications will be accepted, he added.
Although language proficiency is not a prerequisite, Hubbe said a good command of English or German will make it easier for applicants to work and engage people in Germany.

The German office has so far issued about 50 working holiday visas to Taiwanese applicants and 100 other hopefuls have been booked for interviews. Because some of them have not shown up for interviews or have failed to present clear programs, the office is still accepting new applicants, he said.
