Tsai Wei-ting, 26, was one of the first local applicants to receive a working holiday visa. She is scheduled to leave for Berlin on New Year's Day.

Tsai, a computer programmer, said she had already contacted several German companies seeking internships or part-time work contracts. But she added that she most wants to improve her German language ability.

Meanwhile, Karen Jasmin, a 30-year-old German citizen, has arrived in Taipei to start a one-year working holiday in Taiwan and has posted a notice at the German Institute seeking work as a babysitter or language teacher.
Jasmin said she has visited Taiwan four or five times because her American boyfriend is in Taiwan. With a holiday working visa, she said, she will be able to travel more extensively around Taiwan.
Taiwan has also signed working holiday agreements with New Zealand, Australia, Japan, Canada and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 municipality mayors, councilors take office (roundup)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 23:21:14 (By Flor Wang, Y. F. Low and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mayors and councilors of Taiwan's five existing and new special municipalities assumed office Saturday, ushering in a new era in the country's grassroots administration.
Councilors from the Taipei, Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung city councils also elected speakers and deputy speakers after being sworn in for a four-year term.

In the hotly contested elections, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) won the top two posts of the Xinbei City Council and the speaker seat of both the Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils as well as the deputy speaker seat of the Taichung City Council.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) garnered both the speaker and deputy speaker seats of the Tainan City Council and deputy speaker spots of both the Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils, while the speaker post of the Taichung City Council was won by an independent.

KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said the party's Taipei City chapter will make a self review after losing the deputy speaker election. KMT city councilors who failed to vote for the party's nominee will also be disciplined, he added.

The KMT controls 31 of the 62 seats in the Taipei City Council, but its candidate Chen Chin-hsiang lost to his DPP rival Chou Po-ya in the second round of vote, 29-30. The DPP only has 23 seats in the council.
Chou said after learning of his surprise victory that he had no idea about the sources of the extra ballots.

Earlier in the day, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin took the oath to begin his second four-year term, vowing to invigorate the capital city and strengthen its role as the bellwether of the country's five special municipalities.

In southern Taiwan, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu also took her oath and began her second four-year term in office, pledging to build new horizons for the port city that saw its administrative district expanded to cover neighboring Kaohsiung County on the same day.
Meanwhile, Eric Liluan Chu assumed office as the first mayor of the new special municipality of Xinbei, an upgrade of Taipei County.
"There will not be any holidays over my coming four-year term. Every day will be a workday to strive for the development of Xinbei," Chu said during the swearing-in ceremony.

Almost at the same time, Lai Ching-te took oath to become the first mayor of the new special municipality of Tainan, which was officially formed Saturday by merging Tainan City with Tainan County in southern Taiwan.
In central Taiwan, Jason Hu was sworn in as the first mayor of the new special municipality of Taichung, which was officially formed by merging Taichung City with Taichung County.
According to Ministry of the Interior statistics, the population of the five special municipality totals 13.81 million, accounting for 59.63 percent of Taiwan's total.

The city with the largest population is Xinbei, with 3.89 million people. Kaohsiung comes in second with 2.77 million, followed by Taichung (2.64 million) , Taipei (2.61 million) , and Tainan (1.87 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Choreographer working with non-dancers for centennial celebration
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 21:14:30 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Audiences will be surprised and touched by an upcoming dance performance by a group of non-dancers whose passion will make their dream of being dancers come true, Taiwanese choreographer Cheng Tsung-lung said Saturday.

Cheng, an emerging choreographer and former dancer with Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, has been working with 60 untrained dancers and 10 professional dancers on a 15-minute dance that will make its debut Dec. 31 as part of the Republic of China centennial celebrations.
The 34-year-old choreographer said that celebrating the country's birthday is a good thing, but that as an artist, he wants to find greater meaning for the celebration.
"The celebration will not be complete without the participation of the public, because the country is made up of each and every individual," he told reporters after a Saturday rehearsal.
With this in mind, he held auditions several months ago to recruit 60 untrained dancers with a passion for dance, and started a three-month training project.

He admitted that there were a lot of frustrations, as it was difficult to get ordinary people to change the way they use their bodies. However, as time went by, he said, he was very touched to see the performersjoy in moving and their willingness to work together to finish the challenge.
"I think I will burst into tears when the dance is presented on stage,he said.
Cheng said the 15-minute dance is about presentingthe struggles, troubles and hopes of everyday life.
The dance includes a two- to three-minute section during which 44 dancers will have part of their bodies submerged in water, which poses an even greater challenge for the non-dancers, he added.
In March 2007, Cheng's Tete Beche won the Bronze Medal of the No Ballet 1st International Choreography Competition in Ludwigshafen, Germany, beating out 300 competitors.

He has since created and restaged works for several international dance companies, including Transitions Dance Company at the Laban Centre, London, Expressions Dance Company in Brisbane, Australia and the Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Applicants for German working visas show creativity
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/10 21:37:06 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Herding sheep. Learning to make German sausage. Working at German theaters. Traveling around Germany to look for suitable schools and thesis instructors for future doctoral study programs.

These are just a few of the proposals presented by Taiwanese applicants for German working holiday visas that have impressed officials at Germany's representative office in Taiwan with their ingenuity.

Heinrich Hubbe, deputy director of the legal affairs division at the German Institute Taipei, said he is often amazed by the diversity and creativity of working holiday programs made up by Taiwanese hopefuls since the office began accepting visa applications Oct. 11.

Some of the applicants used paintings, graphics and diagrams to explain their work and travel plans, Hubbes said, adding that he has been moved by the novelty and lavishness of some of the presentations.

Germany is the first European country to have signed a working holiday agreement with Taiwan, under which up to 200 Taiwanese citizens aged between 18 and 30 are allowed each year to enjoy a maximum one-year stay in Germany and to undertake incidental work to supplement their holiday money. The reciprocal nature of the program offers similar opportunities for young Germans to undertake working holidays in Taiwan.

Hubbe said the local response to the program has been extremely enthusiastic. In the first few days following the announcement of the program, he recalled, phone glitches were reported at the German representative office occasionally because of the number of inquiries being made.

"Moreover, an average of 6,000 people visited our website each day, far outnumbering the average of 1,000 to 1,500 before the program was launched, " Hubbe went on, adding that the significant increase reflects the popularity of the program.

In addition to producing health insurance certificates and proof of financial status, applicants are required to present a report detailing their motivation for applying for working holiday visas and the activities they plan to do during their stay.
The German office also arranges a 15-minute face-to-face interview for a each applicant.
"What we want to see is that the person is really well-planned and wants to achieve something," Hubbe said.
So long as hopefuls present clear plans, their applications will be accepted, he added.
Although language proficiency is not a prerequisite, Hubbe said a good command of English or German will make it easier for applicants to work and engage people in Germany.

The German office has so far issued about 50 working holiday visas to Taiwanese applicants and 100 other hopefuls have been booked for interviews. Because some of them have not shown up for interviews or have failed to present clear programs, the office is still accepting new applicants, he said.
Tsai Wei-ting, 26, was one of the first local applicants to receive a working holiday visa. She is scheduled to leave for Berlin on New Year's Day.

Tsai, a computer programmer, said she had already contacted several German companies seeking internships or part-time work contracts. But she added that she most wants to improve her German language ability.

Meanwhile, Karen Jasmin, a 30-year-old German citizen, has arrived in Taipei to start a one-year working holiday in Taiwan and has posted a notice at the German Institute seeking work as a babysitter or language teacher.
Jasmin said she has visited Taiwan four or five times because her American boyfriend is in Taiwan. With a holiday working visa, she said, she will be able to travel more extensively around Taiwan.
Taiwan has also signed working holiday agreements with New Zealand, Australia, Japan, Canada and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 21st day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Xinbei mayor inspects aborigine communities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 13:48:48 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Xinbei Mayor Eric Liluan Chu visited two aborigine communities in the northern city formerly known as Taipei County Sunday and promised to help residents there.

Chu inspected the Sanying community near the Dahan River and the Sijhou community by the Xindian River, where die-hard aboriginal residents have lived without basic utilities since their dwellings were demolished before 2008.

Chu, on his second day in office after the Xinbei city government began operating a day earlier, promised the residents to try his best to solve the water, electricity, household registration, postal and other problems facing them.

Flanked by deputy mayors Hsu Chih-chien, Hou Yu-ih and Xinbei Secretary-General Chen Shen-hsien, Chu met with Sanying tribal chief Lin Kuang-fu and Chiang Yi- hao, an adviser to the Sanying Tribe Self-Help Association.

Chiang noted that the houses in the Sanying community have been torn down seven times over the past three decades by former Taipei county governments, as the law prohibits people from living in riverside areas.
Members of 42 remaining tribal households are still living on the Sanying site, according to Chiang.
"What they are fighting for are reasonable treatment and respect for different cultures," Chiang said.
On future relocation or settlement, Chiang said, the residents' greatest wish is to have the characteristics and completeness of their cultures kept.
Responding to Chiang's remarks, Chu said he is starting to learn about how to resolve the problems facing urban aborigines, such as those living by rivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Documentary on migrant workers in Changhua shown on TV
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 14:31:33 (By Chung Hsing-hsien and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A documentary commissioned by the Changhua County government was shown on a local TV Dec. 25-26 to improve local people's understanding of migrant workers and their lives in Taiwan.
The 42-minute film features the interaction between four Southeast Asian workers and their employers.
County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan expressed hope in the film that the documentary will help break the barriers of culture and language, and promote the rights of migrant workers.
Migrant workers are of great help to businesses in the county, said Deputy Magistrate Yang Chong.
At present there are 25,865 migrant workers in the central Taiwan county, including caregivers and construction workers, according to the Department of Labor Affairs.
Changhua established in 1995 the country's first service center for migrant workers, providing free consultations for workers and employers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI to upgrade, overhaul public nursing homes: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 15:16:09 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Sunday that the government will upgrade and overhaul Taiwan's three major public nursing homes, as the residents there have grown old and now have different needs.

From 2010, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will spend NT$135.8 million (US$4.53 million) over a period of four years to improve facilities and services at the three education and nursing institutions located in Nantou County, Yunlin County and Tainan City, Jiang said in the central county of Nantou.

Most of the 970 residents at the three MOI-sponsored institutions, who entered the homes decades ago when they were in their teens, have grown old, making it necessary for the MOI to change the homes' services from education- centered efforts to better care for old people, Chiang said.
The minister visited the Nantou Education and Nursing Institute located in the county's Mingjian Township, where he experienced Snoezelen multi-sensory therapy in a ward known as the White Room.

Snoezelen therapy, developed in the late 1970s by two Dutch therapists, can stimulate, relax, calm or energize patients by adapting the lighting, atmosphere, sounds and textures to the specific needs of the patients.
Chiang also visited a vegetable garden at the institution, where he planted asparagus lettuce seeds and told his hosts he will visit the home again when the lettuce has grown.
At a press conference held at the institution, Jiang said that about 1.06 million Taiwanese citizens are holders of the Handbook for the Handicapped as physically or mentally challenged people.
Of the total, about 23,000 suffer from medium or severe handicaps and need to stay at institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Comfort women exhibition sparks fury, disappointment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 16:07:13 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese former comfort women denounced Japan Sunday at the opening of an exhibition that unveils Taiwan's litigation against Japan over the issue of sex slaves used by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War Two.

Chen Tao, one of the 13 surviving comfort women in Taiwan, said she traveled all the way from Pingtung, the southernmost county in Taiwan, to the capital to attend the opening and ask for assistance from President Ma Ying-jeou, who attended the opening, in helping them find justice and dignity.

"We flew to Japan several times but they would not let we victims testify in court, " said Chen, referring to trials that took place between 1999 and 2005, when the Japanese high court ruled against the comfort women in three separate appeals.

"These grandmothers don't want monetary compensation from the Japanese government. They only ask for an official apology, " said Liao Ying-chih, chairwoman of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) , the main support group for the former comfort women in Taiwan and the exhibition organizer.

Commenting on Japan's disappointing attitude toward the comfort women, Ma noted that Germany endeavored to confront its historical trauma and even put details of concentration camps in textbooks. "It is a great pity that there are places or nations that have not achieved this stage," he said.

He added that the events of history should not be forgotten, even though they can be forgiven. "The government must not think of setting up memorial halls and revising textbooks as creating public shame, " said Ma, explaining that such measures can stop the same mistakes from being repeated.

Liao said that over the past year, the TWRF has been seeking assistance from Japan's Diet, or parliament, in hope that laws can be passed to oblige the Japanese government to apologize for the country's treatment of the comfort women.

According to Liao, a rough estimate of the number of comfort women used by the Japanese government during World War II stands at 500,000, including victims from Taiwan, Korea, China, the Philippines and various other countries.
The exhibition displays legal documents, petitions, media reports and videos relating to the decade-long international litigation process between Taiwan and Japan, said the TWRF.
The exhibition is free and will run from Dec. 24 to Feb. 2 at the Datong district headquarters of the Taipei City Police Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia protests against practice of using advertorials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 16:33:24 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Over 100 scholars lodged a stern protest Sunday urging the government to stop the practice of placing advertorials in the media, saying that this trend of purchasing news space distorts the definition of "good reporting."

The protest was sparked by an entry in a popular blog written by Huang Che-ping, a former senior China Times reporter, who slammed the government's practice of placing advertorials in various media outlets such as TV stations and newspapers to further its interests.

Advertorials are a form of paid advertisement masquerading as objective news stories. An example would be a pharmaceutical company paying a reporter to write a story on the company's new painkiller in the form of an objective article.
In his blog entry, titled "Leaving China Times on a Jet Plane, " Huang says the deep-rooted practice of advertorials has eroded local journalism.

"Reporters have turned into advertising salesmen, while public relations firms and advertising companies have become news writers. The government and big corporations have their hands directly in the news desk, dictating the content of the stories," he said.
The effect of advertorials, said National Chengchi University Journalism Department head Lin Yuan-hui, has greatly distorted what "good reporting" means in this country.
"Right now, the definition of good news is no longer based on its content but on its earning power," he said.

Over 128 scholars from the country's leading journalism schools such as National Taiwan University (NTU) National Taiwan Normal University signed a petition calling on the government and the business sector to stop eroding the profession by "buying news."

Touting Huang's courage in speaking up, NTU professor of journalism Lin Li-yun said the main purpose of Sunday's protest was to urge the government to take the problem seriously and stop tainting pure journalism with paid ads posing as hard news.
Media outlets must also practice self-discipline by rejecting advertorials and the Cabinet and legislature should implement measures to improve the media industry in Taiwan, she said.

The National Communication Commission (NCC) , an independent organization, announced Dec. 22 that it would not renew ERA TV's license for its entertainment channel because of the company's repeat offenses under the Satellite Broadcasting Act.
The NCC said that the network has embedded paid advertisements in its programs at least 49 times, for which it has been fined NT$16.75 million (US$560,000).
The station has denied any wrongdoing and is planning to appeal against the decision.
The move, however, has ignited a wave of fear and protest among the media that the case will set a precedent for the government to exert control over the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: ERA TV license revocation not settled: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 16:44:33 (By Andrew Liu and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Premier We Den-yih said Sunday that the Dec. 22 revocation of the operating license of a local TV channel has not been finalized but will depend on the ruling of an administrative appeal.

The premier's response to the case came after the National Communications Commission (NCC) decided not to renew the license for ERA TV's entertainment channel over repeated violations of the Satellite Broadcasting Act by including embedded advertorials.

The decision is not settled but needs to go through legal proceedings to decide whether the NCC's move was completely appropriate, Wu said after attending a folk ritual in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan.
Asked whether the NCC was too arbitrary in its first such move since its establishment in 2006, the premier said he is not in a position to comment on a decision made by an independent body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Boost FSC authority, ability

TEXT.P: The banking industry in Taiwan appears poised to end this year with a shining balance sheet, allowing banks to dole out bounty bonuses to their employees. However, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) should look squarely at the complicated factors leading to this seeming luster and boost its own authority and competence in the face of upcoming challenges.

One reason for the banking sector's "brilliant" 2010 performance is the government's deliberate efforts to create an environment of loose liquidity and low interest rates. As the government is withdrawing its policy of full-amount guarantees for deposits by the year-end, it must get ready for a possible outbreak of systemic risks.

In the event of another financial crisis, will the FSC be able to keep things under control in advance and take quick and decisive action to stem the risks? To do this, the FSC must have enough power and ability.

It is quite well-known that the FSC might not be ready to do a good job in risk control because first, it does not have a strong and competent staff and, second, its leaders do not have strong political will to carry out its legal mandates.

To realize its four core values of independence, responsibility, transparency and integrity, the FSC needs to recruit more talented and competent officials and allow them to do their jobs professionally. For instance, they should be given higher pay and greater authority, as well as better protection that will rid them of the risk of prosecution.

The 2008 financial crisis has shown that chaos in the financial sector can ruin a nation's economy. To prevent systemic risks from erupting, foundation-laying work is required during the "economic peacetime."

Therefore, the FSC should look beyond the banking sector's shining record and look out for any possible cracks in the system. In short, it must prepare itself in such a way that it will be able not only to help the banking industry prosper but also to nip any developing risk in the bud. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Uni-President Lions mum on hitter trade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 17:11:33 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The manager of Uni-President Lions, one of the four clubs in Taiwan's Professional Baseball League (CPBL), said Sunday that he had no idea about news reports that Chang Tai-shan, one of the country's best hitters, will be traded against his will.

Chen Cheng-nan said he had no clues about the reports that Chang, currently with the Sinon Bulls -- another CPBL club -- will be traded from the Taichung-based Sinon Bulls to the Tainan-based Uni-President Lions at a release amount of between NT$2 million (US$66,666) and NT$3 million.
According to the reports, the Sinon Bulls management hopes Chang, 34, will become a coach for the 2011 season and on, while Chang, Taiwan's top homerun scorer, thinks he is still able to be a player.
Dismissing the reports, Chen said the Uni-President Lions has also not been notified officially by the Sinon Bulls about Chang's possible trade.

Chang, with 241 homeruns, high RBIs of 1,030 and 1,622 hits in his 15-year career as a professional baseballer -- all records that have never been broken in Taiwan's professional baseball history -- first joined the now defunct Weichuan Dragons in 1996 at the age of 19 and transferred to the Sinon Bulls in 1999.
He currently earns NT$250,000 per month with the Bulls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students tie with record high in math contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 17:46:01 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 124 Taiwanese students clinched perfect scores in the American Mathematics Contest 8 (AMC 8), one of the best results on record since Taiwan was invited to join the international competition a decade ago, the organizer said Sunday at an award presentation ceremony.

The 2010 AMC 8, a 25-question, 40-minute multiple choice examination designed mostly for junior high school students, was taken by over 152,900 participants from over 20 countries, including the United States, Canada, Singapore, China and Taiwan.

The Taiwan section of the AMC 8 was held Nov. 21, with a record high 9,593 participants who averaged 15.7 in the contest, higher than the global average of 9.98, according to a statement from the organizer, the Nine-Nine Cultural and Educational Foundation.
The 124 Taiwanese students, ranging from 11 to 15 years old, accounted for nearly 25 percent of the competition's 499 perfect score students, the statement said.

"This is because the Taiwanese participants are good at solving most types of this year's questions such as proportions, quadrature and number theory, " said Ho Yang-ming, president of the foundation, at the award ceremony.
Taiwan set the record of 124 perfect score students in 2008 among 9,012 local participants, Ho added. The local part of the competition has been running since 1999.
Hsu Min-heng, a 11-year-old elementary student who entered the contest for the first time this year, was the youngest participant among the local perfect scorers.

The child first showed an interest in math at kindergarten age and then spent most of his time reading math by himself instead of going to cram school, his father Hsu Wen-jong told CNA on the sidelines of the ceremony.

"When he was seven, my wife and I found one day that he had been trying to read his older sister's mathematics junior high school textbook. He really enjoys thinking about mathematical questions, " said Hsu's father, who is dean of academic affairs in a senior high school in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Ho also noted that the foundation subsidizes the application fees for more than 300 students from low-income families to encourage their participation in the competition.

"We will continue our subsidies for those children who have few opportunities to take part in international events and we hope the contest will become another credible channel for talent-selection in addition to the basic competence test held by the government, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT recruitment drive seeking new blood after 10-year hiatus
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 17:53:47 (By Lee Shu-hua and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) first employee recruitment drive in nearly 10 years has attracted more than 300 people as part of the party's attempts to reshape itself, party official said Sunday.
Over 300 college graduates and master's degree holders have signed up for a recruitment exam slated to take place Jan. 2, said Lin Yung-juei, chief of the KMT administration committee.

The party has stepped up its efforts to seek new blood after its narrow victory in last month's five special municipality elections prompted a KMT reshuffle of local branch and headquarters department chiefs.
The 20 people hired through the recruitment drive will have to complete training and pass various tests before being deployed at different branches throughout the country, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Debts driving non-municipalities into pauperism: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 18:30:26 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The mounting debts of Taiwan's local governments are not only marginalizing counties and cities outside of the five special municipalities but are also driving them into pauperism, a politician-turned-scholar said Sunday.

Peng Pai-hsien, who had served as Nantou magistrate and is now a professor of finance at Kainan University in northern Taiwan, made the remarks at a seminar discussing the financial situations faced by the local governments as a new page was turned a day earlier with the launch of Xinbei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung as special municipalities, putting them on an equal administrative footing with Taipei.
He pointed out that both the central and local governments have been piling up debts so high that it is no longer feasible to just amend the tax revenue distribution law or the public debt law.
"The real problem is that the domestic sources of tax are limited," he said.

Recalling a 2008 incident which 12 county or city governments ran out of funds and could not pay salaries to their employees, Peng said the new administrative regions will make non-municipal cities and counties so marginalized they might end up being "beggar" cities and counties.

He quoted the latest amendment to the tax revenue distribution act as reporting that the central government will give the five municipalities NT$60.7 billion out of the NT$98.2 billion budgeted for all local governments.

This will do little to alleviate the total debt burden of NT$803.4 billion in the five municipalities, which includes their shares of the labor and health insurance expenditure, pension payments and subsidies for retired government employees eligible for preferential interest rates for their term deposits, Peng said, quoting 2009 government statistics.

Peng said a fairer -- and more reasonable -- formula to distribute national tax revenues would be to adopt a national "per capita" standard for public services that include teachers, policemen, firefighters and environmental protection officers, based on which tax money is assigned to each local government.

An urgent task to get the nation out of the financial mess is to overhaul the government's finance structure, a task that calls for the newly elected municipal mayors to submit a long-range land-use plan and an administrative rezoning plan by 2014, when their term of office expires, he said.

Echoing Peng's proposal, Chen Chin-chi, a think tank researcher, recommended that the power of the central and local governments should be redefined in such a way as to satisfy the principles of local autonomy and financial autonomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly man suspected of killing bedridden wife
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 18:38:22 (By Lin Seng-hsu and Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: An 84-year-old man has given himself up to the police after killing his bedridden wife, the Taipei City Police Department said Sunday.
According to the police, the suspect, surnamed Wang, phoned police after committing the crime earlier that day.

Wang said he committed the crime as he could no longer bear to see the suffering and pain of his wife, crippled after she broke both legs several years ago and also a victim of Parkinson's disease. He stabbed her through the top of her head with a screwdriver after feeding her sleeping pills, police said.
"I've killed my wife, please send someone to handle it, " Wang told the police. He also called a priest to come to his house to pray for his wife, the police said.
Wang had earlier posted two articles about euthanasia on his blog.
The couple were financially well-off but lonely in Taiwan, as their two sons live in the United States, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen County government scrambles to save wartime tunnel
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 18:58:10 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A historical committee under the Kinmen County government determined Sunday to list the 40-year-old Jincheng Civic Tunnel as an officially-designated historical relic site entitled to special protection.

The Kinmen County Historical Structure Screening Committee, headed by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Wo-shih, decided at a meeting to have the 2,559-meter tunnel, excavated in 1968 and rebuilt in 1978, listed as an officially recognized historical relic.
It is one of the major and longest of the 12 deep underground military base (DUMB) tunnels built as defense installations on Kinmen since the late 1950s.

The tunnels bear witness to how Kinmen survived the many Chinese communist strikes against it in years gone by, including extensive shelling in 1958, and how Kinmen has been transformed from a frontline anti-communist bastion into a tourist attraction in recent years.
The Jincheng Civic Tunnel was opened to the public two years ago after being refurbished.

Located in the center of downtown Jincheng, the tunnel connects Kinmen County Hall, the Kinmen Bus Station, the Kinmen Post Office, the Kinmen Branch of the Land Bank of Taiwan, the ruling Kuomintang's Kinmen Chapter, an elementary school and the Kinmen Senior High School.
The safety of the wartime tunnel, however, has been called into question in recent months after a property developer began building a 10-story building above the underground fortification.
"We will work out measures to ensure the landowners' rights, as well as protect the historical site," Lee said.

If designated as an official historical relic, the Jincheng Civic Tunnel will be the 45th protected historical relic site on the island and the first tunnel to be listed, according the county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- History made in city council elections

TEXT.P: The mayors and city council members in the one existing and four newly formed special municipalities were sworn in Saturday.

In the city council speaker and deputy speaker elections that followed, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) took three speaker seats, two deputy speaker seats, and helped independent Chang Ching-tang win the speaker seat on the Taichung City Council.
The KMT traditionally dominates local city councils, but this time, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the first time grabbed both speaker and deputy speaker seats in Tainan City.
The DPP also won deputy speaker seats in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, meaning that for the first time, the KMT has less chance of having a free hand in running the councils.
The following are excerpts from the local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
With the KMT winning the speaker and deputy speaker seats in Xinbei City, it has total control of the northern city, as Xinbei Mayor Eric Liluan Chu also belongs to the KMT.
In Tainan City, meanwhile, control went to the DPP, which won both the speaker and deputy speaker seats in the southern city headed by Lai Ching-te, also of the DPP.
Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Ching-tang, although an independent, is an ally of the KMT and his election can also be counted as a KMT victory.

But in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, the KMT won the speaker seats while the DPP took the deputy speaker seats, the first in history to see such a division, which could pose a challenge to relations between the city governments and the city councils.

The KMT had expected an easy win in the Taipei City Council elections. The party's Wu Bi-chu did win the speaker seat for a fourth term, but the DPP's Cho Po-ya won the deputy speaker chair by a slim margin of one vote against the KMT's Chen Ching-hsiang, who was seeking re-election. It is the first time the DPP has taken the post. (Dec. 26, 2010)
China Times:
Although the KMT seemed to take more seats than the DPP in the elections, the party faces a serious challenge to its party authority.
With the surprise loss in the Taipei City Council deputy speaker election, calls for party discipline among those who failed to toe the party line have mounted.
Pan Chia-sen, director of the KMT's Taipei City branch, admitted that "between five and seven councilors failed to toe the party line" and he said he would step down to take responsibility.
In the Kaohsiung election, both the KMT and the DPP saw members failing to toe their respective party lines. The KMT's Hsu Kun-yuan won only after two rounds of voting.

In the deputy speaker election, the KMT's Lu Shu-mei and the DPP's Tsai Chang-ta tied with 33 votes each in the first round of voting and 32 votes in the second round of voting. Tsai won eventually through a draw carried out in accordance with the Local Government Act.
The sharing of the top two council seats between the KMT and the DPP is also a first in Kaohsiung City Council elections. (Dec. 26, 2010)
Liberty Times:
The DPP's Lai Mei-hui became the first female city council speaker in Tainan City, the first city in which the DPP has total control.
Tainan Mayor Lai Ching-te of the DPP expressed appreciation to the voters, saying that total control means full responsibility.
Lin You-chang, a DPP spokesman, said the party will mete out disciplinary measures on party members who failed to vote according to party lines soon.

The DPP was positive about grabbing one speaker seat and three deputy speaker seats, saying that it will inject new force into Taiwan's politics through its good images of solidarity, discipline and cleanness.
Cheng Wen-tsan, another DPP spokesman, criticized several hopefuls supported by the KMT for being involved in corruption or local factionalism.
"President Ma Ying-jeou says he is drawing a line with local factions and the 'black gold', but his actions tell a different story, "Cheng said. (Dec. 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT members could be dismissed over council election loss: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 20:34:59 (By Lee Shu-hua and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will discuss punishment for its city councilors who did not support the party in the deputy speaker election for the Taipei City Council, party officials said Sunday.

The KMT suffered an unexpected loss in the deputy speaker election in the capital for the first time a day earlier after failing to secure all the votes from its 31 councilors. The KMT has eight more seats on the council than the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
DPP councilor Cho Po-ya defeated incumbent Deputy Speaker Chen Ching-hsiang by a 30-29 margin.
It is obvious that six KMT members voted for the DPP candidate, said Pan Chia- sen, chief of the KMT's Taipei branch. He added that the party had tracked down four or five of them.
"There is no other choice but to expel them, " Pan said.
He said the party would hold a meeting the following day, after which the disciplinary committee of the Taipei branch will talk about punishment.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who serves concurrently as KMT chairman, said that "we have to reflect on ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's interest rate seen to rise by 0.125%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 20:53:06 (By Kao Chao-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bankers will likely raise the benchmark interest rate by 0.125 percentage points when they meet Dec. 30, to tighten credit and suppress rising real estate prices, foreign institution experts said Sunday.

The move follows an announcement from China that it will raise its one-year loan and deposit interest rate by 0.25 percentage points, effective Sunday -- the second rate hike in China this year. The first came on Oct. 20.

Tony Phoo, an economist with the Standard Chartered Bank Taiwan, said that as the pressure on inflation grew while substantive interest rates remained low, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) will likely up its key interest rate by 0.125 percentage points.

The central bank might also be thinking about raising the reserve ratio for banking institutions and issuing one-year negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs) to claw back capital from the market, said the economist.
He also predicted that the central bank might announce measures for dampening housing prices in municipal areas as soaring prices are creating an impression of a widening wealth gap.
Cheng Cheng-mount, chief economist of Citibank Taiwan, noted that his bank has adjusted upward its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth this year from 8.7 percent to 9.1 percent.
As Taiwan's economy is on track for a strong recovery, Cheng said, the central bank is likely to decide during its fourth-quarter board meeting, to hike interest rates by 12.5 basis points.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to expel wayward city councilors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 21:40:37 (By Wen Kui-hsiang, Wang Shu-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will expel city councilors who did not toe the party line in the Dec. 25 voting for council speakers and deputy speakers, the party's secretary-general said Sunday.

Su Jia-chyuan said he will recommend that the party's Central Advisory Committee kick out those named by the respective council caucuses as having failed to vote according to caucus resolutions in the elections for speakers and deputy speakers in the five special municipalities.

One of these apparent wayward councilors was Lee Wan-yu of Xinbei City, who cast her ballot for herself rather than for the party's nominee for speaker. DPP Xinbei City branch chief Wu Ping-jui said Lee violated the caucus resolution and that the caucus has therefore decided to kick her out. An official request to that effect will be sent to the party headquarters the following day, Wu added.

In the election for the Kaohsiung City Council speaker, the DPP's nominee won only 31 votes, two short of the council caucus expectations. In Tainan, meanwhile, the DPP nominee got only 25 ballots in the first-round vote and 30 votes in the second.

This means that in both cities, some DPP councilors did not follow party orders to vote for their comrades. The identities of the culprits were being investigated, and once the results have been out, the lists will be sent to the party headquarters. enditem nnnn

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students tie with record high in math contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/10 17:46:01 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 124 Taiwanese students clinched perfect scores in the American Mathematics Contest 8 (AMC 8), one of the best results on record since Taiwan was invited to join the international competition a decade ago, the organizer said Sunday at an award presentation ceremony.

The 2010 AMC 8, a 25-question, 40-minute multiple choice examination designed mostly for junior high school students, was taken by over 152,900 participants from over 20 countries, including the United States, Canada, Singapore, China and Taiwan.

The Taiwan section of the AMC 8 was held Nov. 21, with a record high 9,593 participants who averaged 15.7 in the contest, higher than the global average of 9.98, according to a statement from the organizer, the Nine-Nine Cultural and Educational Foundation.
The 124 Taiwanese students, ranging from 11 to 15 years old, accounted for nearly 25 percent of the competition's 499 perfect score students, the statement said.

"This is because the Taiwanese participants are good at solving most types of this year's questions such as proportions, quadrature and number theory, " said Ho Yang-ming, president of the foundation, at the award ceremony.
Taiwan set the record of 124 perfect score students in 2008 among 9,012 local participants, Ho added. The local part of the competition has been running since 1999.
Hsu Min-heng, a 11-year-old elementary student who entered the contest for the first time this year, was the youngest participant among the local perfect scorers.

The child first showed an interest in math at kindergarten age and then spent most of his time reading math by himself instead of going to cram school, his father Hsu Wen-jong told CNA on the sidelines of the ceremony.

"When he was seven, my wife and I found one day that he had been trying to read his older sister's mathematics junior high school textbook. He really enjoys thinking about mathematical questions, " said Hsu's father, who is dean of academic affairs in a senior high school in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Ho also noted that the foundation subsidizes the application fees for more than 300 students from low-income families to encourage their participation in the competition.

"We will continue our subsidies for those children who have few opportunities to take part in international events and we hope the contest will become another credible channel for talent-selection in addition to the basic competence test held by the government, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 27, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.

U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold front sweeping Taiwan to continue until Tuesday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 12:36:50 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a low temperature warning Monday after a cold front swept Taiwan and brought the temperature down to below 10 degrees Celsius in most areas on the subtropical island in the early hours of the day.

Xinbei City's Danshuei, which is located at the mouth of the Danshuei River in northern Taiwan, recorded a temperature of 5.9 degrees Celsius, the lowest in the municipal district since the beginning of winter.

The cold front has also sent temperatures in Keelung in the north, Yilan in the east, Taichung in the central region and Tainan in the south plummeting to their lowest levels this winter on early Monday morning, the CWB said.
The temperature in Keelung stood at 6.4 degrees C., while it was 6.8 degrees in Yilan, 7.5 degrees in Taichung and 9 degrees in Tainan.

Even in the usually-warm southern Taiwanese city of Kaohsiung, the temperature dropped to 11.3 degrees, the CWB added, as it reminded people to keep themselves warm and ensure proper air flows while activating gas-powered water heaters indoors.
The cold front would turn weaker in the daytime Tuesday, the CWB predicted, adding that the next dry cold front would hit Taiwan on Dec. 30.
That could lead to temperatures across Taiwan plunging again, possibly to record lows, the CWB said. It also said that the next cold front would linger until Jan. 2.
