DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's financial stocks gain on interest rate hike hopes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 12:59:41 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's financial stocks attracted buying, outperforming the broader market in Monday morning trade, as investors bet that the central bank will raise interest rates in the upcoming policy meeting, dealers said.
They said that pressure on Taiwan's central bank to hike interest
rates has mounted after China increased its key interest rates by 0.25 percentage points over the weekend.
If interest rates are hiked in Thursday's policy meeting, local banks are expected to benefit from higher interest income, which should lift their bottom lines.
Market observers said that there was a consensus in the market that the central bank would raise benchmark interest rates by 0.125 percentage points.
In Monday morning trade, the financial sector rose 1.89 percent, while the weighted index rose 0.10 percent to 8,870.09.
"More and more investors expect the central bank to raise interest rates further on Thursday, as the local economy has staged a strong rebound," MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said.
"After the People's Bank of China announced a 25 basis point hike in the one- year base lending rate and deposit rate Saturday, interest rate hikes in the local market seem a sure thing," Tang said.

In September, Taiwan's central bank raised the discount rate by 0.125 percentage points, the second increase since June, after the local economy climbed out of a recession, following a global financial meltdown.
Tang said that, with the domestic economy growing, lending to enterprises is on the rise, "so higher interest rates would be positive for the banking sector's bottom line."
Tang said that, once the central bank increased rates, inflows of foreign funds were expected to accelerate accordingly.
"High liquidity is expected to push up local share prices, in
particular, prices of large cap financial stocks which need ample funds to go higher," Tang said.
In addition, as the financial sector has been consolidating for some time, its valuations look attractive compared with the broader market, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: The race is on among five megacities

TEXT.P: The mayors of Taiwan's five special municipalities rushed to begin work right after they assumed office last weekend, each with their eyes on the goal of building their constituencies as the best in the nation.
Some mayors immediately called brainstorming sessions to chart new strategies, while others went on community outreach tours to get first-hand information about ongoing development projects.

Given the special status of the megacities under their control, the five popularly elected mayors arguably will play important roles in Taiwan's political arena in the next four years. It is also very likely that a future national leader will emerge from their ranks.
As a matter of fact, some mayors have already shown their leadership with the selection of their administrative teams.

For instance, the recruitment of former National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yo-yi as deputy mayor of Xinbei City is an encouraging sign of Mayor Eric Liluan Chu's determination to improve law and order in his constituency and uphold clean politics.

For years, Taiwan's city and county councils have been dominated by controversial figures with shady ties to underground criminal gangs. Despite the upgrade or expansion of some areas into special municipalities, this frustrating scenario is not likely to disappear soon. The election Saturday of some corrupt figures as speaker or deputy speakers in some of the new megacities bears this out.

In the speaker and deputy speaker elections, both the ruling Kuomintang and opposition Democratic Progressive Party saw some of their councilors vote in contravention of their party's directives in an apparent pursuit of personal interests.

Against this backdrop, municipality mayors, while respecting the legal supervision of the city council in their administrations, should have the spine to reject shady or improper requests by council members. We hope the newly elected mayors will help correct the long-distorted local political culture and environment. Folding under pressure will endanger not only national interests but also the mayors' own reputations and future. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 27, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China futures firms sign partnership MOU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 14:12:50 (By Wei Shu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Capital Futures Corp. said Monday it has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with its Chinese counterpart Cinda Futures Co. Ltd. on partnership in several areas of business.
Under the agreement, the two sides will join forces to train personnel, develop technology for a trading platform and devise new financial instruments, Capital Futures said.
Cinda Futures approached Capital Futures in the fourth quarter of this year about the possibility of securing a partnership in Taiwan, said Dan Chen, spokesman of the Taiwanese firm.
"China has a huge commodity futures market, while Taiwan specializes in financial futures trading, in particular stock index futures. There is great potential for future cooperation, " Chen said.

Chen said that because Cinda Futures is almost wholly owned by China's Ministry of Finance, Capital Futures has high hopes of benefiting from the connections in the development of its business on the mainland.
Currently, Taiwan's futures companies are allowed to invest in their Chinese counterparts, but Chinese future companies are restricted from doing the same in Taiwan companies.
"Both sides are interested in cross shareholdings in the future. Once cross shareholdings are allowed, we will talk more about the investment issue," Chen said.
Cinda Futures, headquartered in Hangzhou of China's Zhejiang Province, runs 11 operations hubs in major Chinese cities such as Shanghai, Beijing and Dalian and Shenyang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 80% of Taiwanese will voluntarily defend country: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 15:00:08 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang on Monday confirmed the results of a poll that showed 76.5 percent of respondents will voluntarily fight for their country if it comes under military threat.
In response to reporters' questions, Chao confirmed that the military in October commissioned a civilian poll on national defense policies.

In similar survey in 2009, the percentage of people who said they would volunteer if Taiwan came under attack was 74.5 percent, Chao said, attributing the higher percentage this year to what he called successful national defense education.
The results of the poll this year was reported in the Chinese-language China Times, which said it was the highest percentage in recent years.
According to the poll, civilians between the ages of 40 and 59 would be most likely to voluntarily defend Taiwan, and blue-collar workers would be more willing than white-collar workers to do so.

In light of the fact that the military is preparing to switch to a fully volunteer recruitment system, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said, the poll was conducted to determine the level of volunteerism that could be expected in the event of a war, the paper reported.
The results were not publicized because they were meant to be used only as reference by the military's personnel recruitment units, the MND said.
The survey was conducted on nearly 1,000 civilians over the age of 20 around Taiwan via telephone, the military said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close up 0.35 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 16:42:42 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed up 0.35 percent Monday, led by the financial sector, which was boosted by expectations that the central bank will decide in its upcoming policy meeting to raise its key interest rates, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 31.21 points to 8,892.31, after moving between 8,828.67 and 8,908.42, on turnover of NT$111.53 billion (US$3.77 billion).

The market opened up 5.57 points and moved higher as buying focused on financial stocks on high hopes that their profitability will be lifted by the central bank's imminent announcement of interest rate hikes, dealers said.
"Since China hiked its benchmark interest rates, pressure has been rising for Taiwan's central bank to follow suit, " Mega Securities analyst Alex Huang said.
The People's Bank of China announced over the weekend that it would raise its one-year base lending rate and deposit rate by 25 basis points to fight rising inflation.
Huang said there is general agreement in the market the Taiwan central bank will announce 0.125 percentage points hike Thursday since the local economy has rebounded strongly.

"There is a strong possibility that Taiwan's central bank will hike its key interest rates, " Huang said. "Many investors think that the rate increase is a sure thing so they rushed to pick up banking stocks this morning."

However, selling in the bellwether high tech sector offset the gains posted by the financial sector due to a rising New Taiwan dollar, which is likely to undermine Taiwan's global competitiveness, dealers said.
A total of 1,626 stocks closed up and 2,591 down, while 325 remained unchanged.

The financial sector scored the highest gains, ending up 2.9 percent. Textile stocks rose 1.1 percent, and foodstuffs and plastic and chemical shares added 0.1 percent, while the paper and pulp and construction sectors closed unchanged.
Among the financial stocks, China Development Financial rose 6.76 percent to NT$11.05, E. Sun Financial added 5.43 percent to NT$19.40 and First Financial gained 2.88 percent to NT$25.00.
Cement stocks fell 0.6 percent, and machinery and electronic shares lost 0.4 percent.
In the electronic sector, PC vendor Acer fell 0.97 percent to NT$91.80 and flat panel maker Chimei Innolux dropped 0.90 percent to NT$38.40.

Huang said the market remains awash in liquidity, prompting buying to rotate from sector to sector as investors seek safe havens to park funds. Meanwhile, the market lacks a mainstream sector to make a significant breakthrough, he said.
"The index is gradually moving ahead instead of making big swings and such movements are making the market technically healthier, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- New steps to highlight ECFA effects

TEXT.P: With the early harvest program under the Taiwan-China Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) set to take effect on New Year's Day, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will open a new service center Wednesday to offer guidance on ECFA-related issues.

It will also take three steps -- stage large-scale trade forums in 10 Chinese cities to introduce trade and investment opportunities in Taiwan, invite large Chinese enterprises to purchase goods in Taiwan, and organize professional trade fairs in China -- to further maximize the trade deal's impact.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
Economic Daily News:
BOFT Director-General Cho Shih-chao said over the weekend that the new ECFA service center will remain open during the coming New Year holiday from Saturday through Sunday.
The center will mainly help local manufacturers and exporters resolve problems related to merchandise trade under the ECFA's early harvest program.

Starting on Jan. 1, more than 800 items from Taiwan and China shipped to the other side will have their tariffs phased out during a two-stage process over three years under the ECFA's early harvest program.
From New Year's Day, some 80 Taiwan-made products will enjoy duty-free access to the Chinese market.
On Jan. 1, 2012, an additional 400-plus products made in Taiwan will also receive duty-free treatment when imported into China.

Government sources said the number of Taiwan-made products to be granted tariff- free access to China under the early harvest program has increased to 557 from the original 539 after adjusting customs classification code numbers.
The items accounted for 16.14 percent of Taiwan's total exports to China in 2009.
Cho said the BOFT hopes the ECFA will generate initial gains by the end of the first quarter of 2011 so that the average person will feel that the agreement is benefiting Taiwan.
To reach the goal of having the ECFA become a "nationally felt" economic phenomenon, Cho said the BOFT will continue holding "early harvest" presentations in various cities around Taiwan this week.

In addition, the BOFT will collaborate with the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to sponsor seminars starting in the second half of January in 10 major Chinese cities -- Beijing, Shanghai, Guangdong, Qingdao, Dalian, Xiamen, Nanjing, Wuhan, Nanning and Chengdu.

The seminars will be aimed at trying to get large Chinese business groups to source products from Taiwan, particularly those items that will have their import duties reduced or eliminated under the early harvest list.
The BOFT will also organize professional trade delegations, such as those in the bicycle, automotive component, textile and orchid sectors, to embark on market promotion tours of China, Cho added.

Meanwhile, Council of Agriculture Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said the council will cooperate with Uni-President Group in setting up an outlet in Shanghai in April to display and distribute Taiwan-made agricultural products.
"The establishment of the center will enable Chinese tourists to place orders during their trips in Taiwan and pick up their purchases in China," Chen said.

Eighteen Taiwanese agricultural items will enjoy duty-free access to China from Jan. 1 under the ECFA's early harvest program, said Chen, who estimated that the preferential treatment would help expand Taiwan's farm produce sales to China six-fold in three years. (Dec. 27, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait committee at least a few days away: MOEA chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 17:05:53 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang denied a report on Monday that a committee to serve as a window for trade negotiations between Taiwan and China would be launched Tuesday, but said it could be formed by the end of the week.
"Tomorrow is impossible, " Shih said during a question and answer session at the legislature. "It is still being negotiated. It will not take too long."
Asked if the formation of the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation committee would take effect by the end of this year, the minister said "we are trying (to make it happen)."

The Chinese-language United Daily News reported Monday that the committee would be launched Tuesday to fulfill one of the clauses of the Taiwan-China Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), which took effect in September.
Taiwan's Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Francis Kuo-hsin Liang and China's Vice Minister of Commerce Jiang Zengwei are expected to jointly head the committee.

The trade deal's "early harvest" list of products enjoying preferential tariffs under the ECFA takes effect Jan. 1, 2011, and the committee is seen as necessary to facilitate talks on the implementation, interpretation and coordination of the early harvest list and other ECFA-related business.

Panels under the committee are also expected to follow up on commodity trade and service access issues, dispute settlement, and investment protection, which means the two sides would want the committee to be in place before the end of 2010.
Also Monday, several lawmakers cast doubt over the transparency of the proposed committee, but Shih said it would be subject to legislative supervision.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC's stance on ERA TV license draws bipartisan flak
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 17:33:26 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The National Communication Commission (NCC) stood firm Monday on its decision to revoke the license of a TV entertainment channel for what it said was the use of embedded advertisement.

Faced with criticisms in the legislature by lawmakers across the political spectrum, NCC Chairwoman Su Herng said ERA TV had failed to honor its promise to stop the practice of clandestine advertising on its entertainment channel and therefore had to be penalized.

In revoking the channel's license on Dec. 22, the NCC said ERA TV's entertainment channel had repeatedly violated the Satellite and Broadcasting Act by placing illegal product ads and excessive infomercials in its program line- ups.

When the station's license came up for its sixth annual renewal in November last year, the NCC review committee, in consideration of the staff employed at the station, decided to renew the license on condition that ERA would stop advertising certain products on its shows, Su told the lawmakers.
However, the station did not hold up its end of the bargain and the NCC brought to bear the penalty for the total of 46 violations that the station had racked up in six years, Su said.

"It was like telling a student who deserved to be expelled that you would hold off on the punishment if he promised to behave, " she said. "When the student continued to violate the rules there was no choice but to execute the penalty."

But legislators of both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took issue with Su's explanation, saying that NCC, an independent media regulator that was established in 2006, had overstepped its authority and was loosely interpreting the relevant laws.
KMT Lawmaker Sun Ta-chien, who was one of the advocates of the NCC's establishment four years ago, said it was setting a bad precedent and had made a non-objective decision.

"There is no legal basis for determining that 46 violations in six years amount to a serious offense, " Sun said. "Furthermore, the NCC has no clear-cut parameters or definition of what is product placement."

Sun also argued that since ERA TV had bought the station from the Eastern Multimedia Group two years ago, ERA should be held accountable only for the violations incurred during its period of ownership.

Two other KMT legislators, Luo Shu-lei and Chu Fong-chi, also slammed the NCC's decision, saying it had gone beyond its jurisdiction and twisted the laws. The NCC should have temporarily suspended the operations of the station instead of revoking its license, they said.
Joining the chorus of criticisms against the NCC, DPP Lawmaker Pan Meng-an said it was a government tool used to control the media.
Kuo Wen-chen, also of the DPP, said the NCC should leave the public to deal with the ERA TV channel issue.
"Viewers will switch to another channel if they don't like what they see," Kuo said. "It should be their choice."
Bucking the wave of criticisms, senior KMT lawmaker and former teacher Hung Hsiu-chu said the NCC had done the right thing.
"If a driver's license is subject to periodical renewal based on the holder's driving record, why should a TV station be any different? " he asked.

"Some broadcasts such as infomercials contain misleading information that could seriously damage the health of consumers," she said. "The NCC must step in and root out these practices to prevent people from being duped."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower but rebounds from NT$29.481
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 17:57:02 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Monday, dropping NT$0.06 to close at NT$30.425 after rebounding from the day's low of NT$29.481.

The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.525 and then moved to the day's low before rebounding due to the central bank's continued intervention in the local foreign exchange market to prevent rapid appreciation of the local currency, dealers said.
Turnover totaled US$971 million during the trading session.
Selling by exporters and foreign banks pushed down the U.S. dollar after the market opened on further inflows of foreign funds into the local market, dealers said.

They said expectations that the central bank would raise its key interest rates at Thursday's policy making meeting added downward pressure on the greenback as investors were betting higher local interest rates would attract more idle funds from overseas and further boost the local currency.

The likelihood of the central bank increasing interest rates has risen recently, especially after the People's Bank of China raised its one-year base lending rate and deposit rate by 0.25 percentage points over the weekend to fight inflation, they added.
The general market consensus is that Taiwan's central bank will boost its interest rates by 0.125 percentage points.
In late trade, the central bank stepped in again to boost the value of the U.S. dollar back to NT$30.00, a level the market believes is the central bank's bottom line in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sacked JAL flight attendants to protest on New Year's Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 18:32:30 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese flight attendants who were laid off by Japan Airlines (JAL) in July are planning to stage a protest on New Year's Day against what they called the government's apathy toward their plight.

The flight attendants, to be joined by workers' rights activists, will hold a demonstration in front of the Presidential Office on Jan. 1 to draw public attention to their predicament, said Yang Shao-yung, chairman of the ROC Alliance of International Airport Labor Unions.

A Taiwanese JAL flight attendant, one of seven who have refused to accept severance pay from JAL, said she is furious and saddened that the Taiwan government had sat idly by while a foreign company was bullying Taiwan workers in their own country.

The JAL Taiwan branch was fined NT$600,000 (US$20,000) by the Taipei City government last week for job discrimination after the airline laid off 70 Taiwanese flight attendants, reportedly on account of their age.
The flight attendants, whose positions were eliminated at the end of July under an early retirement program, in August filed age-discrimination complaints against JAL, Japan's largest air carrier.

Both the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Taipei City Department of Labor have said that the JAL layoffs were illegal and have asked the airline to reinstate the flight attendants.

The Taiwanese officials, however, did not specify which of Taiwan's labor laws had been violated in the move, which was reported as an effort by JAL to address its financial difficulties by downsizing.
To date, JAL has not responded to the CLA's request and none of the seven flight attendants who have refused to accept severance pay have been invited to return to their jobs.
Sixty-three of the 70 workers who were laid off have agreed to the early retirement deal offered by the airline.
JAL had said that the layoffs were based on evaluations of functionality, cost and performance.

But according to a Department of Labor official, some of the Taiwanese employees who were laid off had been top scorers in the JAL's performance appraisals for several consecutive years and some had received awards as the airline's best flight attendants.
The layoffs were part of a plan by JAL to reduce its global work force by a third this year as part of a restructuring program after filing for bankruptcy in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC in talks with Powerchip to buy buildings, land for expansion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 18:45:22 (By Jackson Chang and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chip maker, said Monday it is in talks to buy property from memory chip maker Powerchip Technology Corp. that would be used for future expansion.
"We have entered negotiations with Powerchip for a possible purchase of land and buildings located in the Hsinchu Science Park, " said Elizabeth Sun, a TSMC spokeswoman.
"It would be possible for TSMC to build a 12-inch wafer plant on the site if we could reach an agreement on the purchase, " Sun said. "But talks remain ongoing and no deal has been reached."
Sun said that even if the purchase were to go through, any expansion project at the particular location would not be completed until 2012.
She declined to disclose further details, but said TSMC would hold an investor conference in January to announce its expansion plans for 2011.

Currently, TSMC operates two 12-inch wafer plants -- one in the northern Hsinchu Science Park and the other in the Southern Taiwan Science Park -- and is building a third plant in the Central Taiwan Science Park.

The Commercial Times reported on Monday that TSMC was likely to spend NT$3 billion (US$101 million) to acquire land and buildings owned by Powerchip that are close to TSMC's 12-inch plant in the Hsinchu Science Park.
Powerchip, which produces dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips, declined to comment on the report.

Grand Cathay Securities analyst Mars Hsu said TSMC is likely to use the possible new 12-inch wafer plant to focus on the development of higher end technology, including 40 nanometer, 28 nm and even more advanced processes.
"The expansion is necessary for TSMC to maintain its technology lead in the market to secure its No. 1 position and leave its rivals far behind," Hsu said.
For Powerchip, Hsu said, the possible property sale could be expected to help the company improve its financial structure by repaying short-term debt.
According to Hsu, Powerchip has NT$7.6 billion in loans with a maturity of one year or less and an additional NT$32 billion in long-term debt as of the end of third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government should not buy media coverage: KMT official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 19:02:46 (By Lee Shu-hua and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Governments at the central and local level should avoid buying news coverage to promote their policies and initiatives, a leading Kuomintang (KMT) official was quoted as saying Monday.
King Pu-tsung, secretary general of the ruling KMT, was quoted as saying that the party and the government should hold a "serious" discussion about the issue.
According to KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin, King made the suggestion during the party's weekly meeting, and for two weeks in a row has expressed concern over the subject.
He quoted King as saying that the KMT has always been opposed to the government practice of "buying" media coverage for political messages.
However, King said there was a difference between political advocacy and charity or public-service messages such as AIDS and anti-fraud information, according to Su.

Su said King criticized the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for buying space in the media during Chen Shui-bian's administration from 2000-2008 to promote a referendum on Taiwan's right to join the United Nations.
"That was political buying of advertorials, which we firmly oppose," King was quoted as saying.
Furthermore, Kim is not in favor of commercial interests buying space in the media for coverage of business messages disguised as news stories, according to Su.

The government should promote its policies openly and transparently, King was quoted as saying. He added that these were principles he had stuck to, whether as information department chief, deputy mayor of Taipei, or KMT secretary-general.
Since both the central and local governments have problems in this regard, King said, a party-government meeting should be held by weekend to seriously discuss the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most college students plan to work during winter break: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 19:06:06 (By Lin Hui-chun and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 90 percent of Taiwan's students plan to work part time during the upcoming winter break, a survey by an online manpower agency showed Monday.

As many as 93.12 percent of the college and graduate students polled said they planned to work part time during the month-long vacation from mid-January to mid-February, the 1111 Job Bank survey found.
The respondents' top three reasons for getting a part-time job were to make more money, gain more social and work experience, and expand their network of social contacts.

Of the nearly 7 percent of respondents who said they would not work during the break, just over half (53.37 percent) said they did not have time to work part time and another 32.14 percent said they could not find a suitable job.
Job bank spokesperson Chang Hsu-lan said students should not consider part-time jobs simply as a way to make money but also as an opportunity to make connections.

Albert Yuan, the marketing manager of the Leofoo Village Theme Park, also saw money as merely an added benefit of doing a temporary job, saying that learning something from the experience should be the most important goal.

The survey was conducted online from Dec. 9 through Dec. 23, with 1,221 valid samples collected. The poll had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.80 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy growing, but at more moderate pace: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 19:19:32 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A decline in November's economic monitoring indicator and an unchanged leading indicator index showed that Taiwan's economy was still growing but at a more moderate pace, the government said Monday.

Last month, the overall economic monitoring indicator compiled by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) fell to 32 points from October's 34 points, but still flashed a "yellow-red" light for the third consecutive month.
In August, the economy flashed a "red" light, indicating it was overheating.
The economic planning agency uses a five-color system to gauge the country's economic performance for any given month.
Blue implies a sluggish economy, yellow-blue represents a slowdown, green indicates a stable economy, yellow-red means the economy is mildly overheated, and red signifies overheating.

Among the sub-indexes forming the economic monitoring indicator, money supply, employment in the non-farm sector, exports, mechanical and electrical equipment imports, manufacturing sales, and retail, wholesale and restaurant sales fell.
Meanwhile, the sub-indexes related to share prices, direct and indirect financing, and industrial production rose.
The composite index of leading economic indicators, which gauges economic performance over three to six months, measured 119.3 in November, unchanged from a month earlier.

The year-on-year six-month rate of change in November stood at 1.0 percent, down 1.0 percentage point from October. The rate of decline narrowed from the previous month, the seventh consecutive month that has happened.
The November index of coincident indicators, which reflect economic activity in the period measured, rose 0.8 percent from October to 126.4.

Though the overall monitoring indicator for November fell, the CEPD said it remained optimistic about Taiwan's economic growth for 2011 as demand from emerging economies remained strong and would provide a spark to the island's exports.
"Although domestic growth will be moderating next year, the pace of growth remains stable," the CEPD said in a statement.
"The government will continue to solicit foreign companies to invest in Taiwan in a bid to boost domestic demand for further economic expansion," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has high rate of trainer plane crashes: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 19:48:16 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The incidence of crashes involving T-34 Mentor airplanes during regular training missions is "relatively higher" in Taiwan compared with other countries, Air Force Chief of Staff Wang Cheng-hsiao said Monday.
Wang made the remarks while answering a question by Legislator Chen Ying of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party at a hearing of the legislative Foreign and National Defense Committee.
Noting that in the past two decades, Taiwan recorded a total of eight accidents involving T-34 airplanes used for air force pilot training, Chen asked what was the cause of the high rate of crashes.
In response, Wang agreed that the number of the T-34 crashes in Taiwan was indeed higher than in other countries, but he did not pinpoint a reason for the high rate.

He said the Air Force's fleet of T-34 pilot trainers has been grounded for safety checks since the most recent crash in a southern Taiwan mountain area on Dec. 15, in which a flight instructor and an Air Force Academy cadet were killed.
It was the second crash this year involving a T-34 trainer plane. In January, an aircraft of the same model went down during a training flight in southern Taiwan, killing the two pilots aboard.
Wang said the investigation into the January crash is still in progress.
The T-34 Mentor that crashed in December was the eighth to go down since the U.S.-made trainer was introduced in Taiwan in 1985.
Wang said that the T-34 Mentor that went down in January had a lifespan of 16,000 hours, and the one that crashed less than two weeks ago had a lifespan that would have lasted until 2031.

Meanwhile, Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang told reporters on the sidelines of the legislative hearing that more than 20 other countries around the world also use the T-34 Mentor for air force pilot training.
In Taiwan's Air Force Academy, the oldest T-34 has only 8,000 hours of flying time, and the one that went down recently had only 7,600 hours, he said.
The cause of the most recent crash is being investigated, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Little Leaguers edge South Korea in Asia semifinal
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 19:51:20 (By M.C. Yang and S.C Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan outlasted South Korea 2-1 in the semifinal of the Asian Little League Championships on Monday, keeping its hopes for a fifth consecutive title alive heading into Tuesday's championship game showdown against Japan.
Taiwan's Chu Yi-kun hit a two-run homer in the first inning to give his team a 2-0 lead against the Koreans, in the game being played in Kurashiki, Okayama Prefecture, in southern Japan.

Taiwan's lineup was shut down after that but its pitching rotation of Chu Yi- kun, Wu Chun-an and Chang Yen-hsun made the lead stand up, allowing their opponents to score only one run in the seven-inning contest.

"The game was a pitching duel. Both teams sent their best pitchers to the mound to frustrate opposing hitters, " said Lee Kuo-chiang, a coach of the Taiwanese team, whose players came from several elementary and junior high schools in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

Lee said Japan, a strong team that trounced South Korea 10-1 on Dec. 24, would be a tough opponent, but he was confident his team could overcome the hosts despite cold and snowy weather that has almost taken its toll on some of Taiwan's players.
Over the past two days, many of them have complained about being too cold, and a few of them had diarrhea or vomited, but Lee said they were all healthy now.

Taiwan swept China, Indonesia and Thailand to win Group A at the Asian Championships while Japan won Group B ahead of South Korea, Pakistan and Hong Kong, setting up Monday's semifinal game between Taiwan and South Korea.
The Asian Little League Championships have been held every two years in a country in the region since they began in 2000.
Taiwan has won the last four championships in a row, played in Wuxi, China, Guanzhou, China, Hong Kong and Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Measure pushing harsher game-fixing sentences passes first hurdle
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:02:46 (By Lee Yu-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two legislative committees passed an amendment on Monday that would deal harshly with game-fixing in Taiwan's professional baseball league, the latest effort to eradicate the gambling and game-rigging that have plagued the sport since 1996.

The draft amendment, which would revise the Sports Lottery Act, calls for jail terms ranging from three to 10 years and fines of up to NT$50 million (US$1.66 million) for group game-fixing involving over three people.

For individual offenses, anybody convicted of game-fixing could face up to seven years in jail and a fine of between NT$10 million and NT$30 million, according to the bill jointly passed by the Education and Culture Committee and Finance Committee.
It still must get through the full legislature's second and three readings before becoming law.
The legislators called for the harsher punishments to replace amendments proposed by the Executive Yuan that they felt were "too lenient" to solve the persistent problem.

In the Executive Yuan's version of the amendment it approved on April 1, individuals found guilty of fixing professional baseball games would be subject to a jail term of under five years and fines of up to NT$10 million.
Game-fixing scandals have nearly caused the demise of Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , repeatedly challenging fans' loyalty to the country's national pastime.
At its peak in the mid-1990s, the league drew an average of more than 6,000 fans, but in recent years its average attendance has ranged between 1,000 and 2,000.
All four CPBL clubs said they welcomed the proposed legislation. Su Ching-hsuan, the La New Bears president, said the harsher sentences would be an effective deterrent to game-fixing.
Brother Elephants President Yang Ai-hua, whose team was ravaged by a game-fixing scandal last year, said, "what we have hoped for has finally arrived."
Yang hoped that if the amendment were passed into law, it would be enforced effectively, with law enforcement forces dealing with future suspects impartially.
CPBL Secretary-General Wayne Lee also said that "the law must be observed and enforced completely."

DOC.HEADLINE: Official calls for renaming of Taiwan office in Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:03:39 (By Charles kang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official in charge of Hong Kong affairs said Monday that the Hong Kong government should allow Taiwan to rename its representative office there as step toward better bilateral relations.

Renaming the office "will serve as a key indicator of closer relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong, " said James Shi Chu, director- general of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, at a seminar in Taipei.
Currently, Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong bears the confusing and often misleading title of Chung Hwa Travel Service (CHTS).

In their dealings with Taiwan, the Hong Kong and Macau governments have been sticking to the "seven-point guidelines" -- based on the "one China" principle -- that were laid out by former Chinese Vice Premier and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in 1995, Chu said.

However, since then, the cross-strait and international situations have changed considerably, therefore, Macau and Hong Kong should try to engage Taiwan in a more practical and flexible manner, he said.
Echoing Chu's views, Former Taiwanese representative to Hong Kong Cheng An-kuo said that the CHTS looks just like a travel agency and not in the least like a Taiwan representative office.
"Taiwan-Kong Kong ties will only progress if they each establish a representative office on the other side, with an appropriate title," Cheng said.

Professor Lee Chih-chiang of Tamkang University said that the proposed representative offices, if managed well, could serve as an important reference for Taiwan and China to set up similar ones in Beijing and Taipei.

David Lie, vice chairman of the Hong Kong-Taiwan Business Cooperation Committee and a member the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, said that the Hong Kong government has assigned a task force to consider the issue, but stressed that the proposal could only be realized under the "one China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will pay fair price for U.S. helicopters: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:05:31 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not have to pay more than other countries to purchase U.S.-made UH- 60M helicopters, Deputy Defense Minister Chao Shih-chang assured lawmakers Monday.

In response to a question by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang at a hearing in the legislative Foreign and National Defense Committee, Chao said the price of U.S.-made helicopters is public knowledge.
"Taiwan will not have to pay a higher price than other buyers," Chao said.

Lin noted that in the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) 2008 budget proposal, it had listed a sum of NT$71.8 billion for the purchase of 60 UH-60M helicopters to replace the old UH-1Hs that are still in commission.
However, in the budget presented to the committee Monday, the MND had an allocation of NT$84.7 billion for the helicopters, Lin said.
In 2007, the price quoted by the U.S. was US$2.1 billion, now it has risen to US$2.5 billion, he further noted, asking the MND to seek a price reduction.
In response, Chao stressed that the MND has always done its best to obtain good arms procurement deals.
The increase in the price of the helicopter package was due to the rising costs of materials over the last few years, Chao said.
At the hearing, Lin also asked about the MND's plans for the purchase of new armored vehicles for the Army, as outlined in the ministry's 2009 policy paper.
In response, Chao said the MND is still evaluating the needs of the Army and may increase the number of new armored vehicles to 200.

DOC.HEADLINE: New CSBC chairman forecasts higher turnover in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:28:07 (by Chao Hsiao-hui & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The new chairman of Taiwan's largest shipbuilder forecast Monday that the corporation will post a turnover of NT$30 billion (US$1 billion) in 2011, about NT$4 billion more than this year.

Tan Tai-ping, who assumed chairmanship of CSBC Corporation, Taiwan earlier in day, said that the world economy is recovering gradually from the financial crisis of 2008-2009, prompting shipyards worldwide to expand production capacity.
However, the shipbuilding sector will not fully recover until 2012, he said, adding that the average price of building ships is now only 80 percent of the 2008 level.
Nevertheless, Tan said, he expects a 20 percent to 30 percent growth next year in the number of ships built by his company.
Tan vowed to push for a more diversified operation by negotiating with China's Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Ltd. for a strategic alliance.
Furthermore, he hopes to recruit new blood, he said, noting that the average age of CSBC employees is 49 years.
"I will try my best to provide a stable, fair and comfortable employment environment for my staff and to make CSBC a family-like company," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Monthly Hakka festivities to add color to centennial
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:44:16 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: A year-round series of Hakka cultural and art festivities will add ethnic color to the Republic of China's 100th anniversary celebration next year, the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) said Monday at the festival launch party.

Held annually for the past two years, the year's slate of festivals will bring together popular events of the past, such as the tung blossom festival and food carnivals, and comic characters created by a well-known Hakka comic master to fit the jovial mood, said CHA Minister Huang Yu-cheng.
"Compared to 19 events held this year, a total of 21 rich Hakka cultural feasts will take place in 2011, " Huang said.
Twelve municipalities, including Taitung County and Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, will present at least one festival per month.
Huang explained that the festivities have helped enliven traditional Hakka villages and the public appreciate the beauty of Hakka culture.

"People involved in the festivities, locals and tourists alike, responded that they felt proud, " Huang said. "Our goal is to promote Hakka heritage among the younger generation and non-Hakka groups."
The council has also promoted Hakka culture internationally.

"We worked with Discovery Channel in Asia to showcase Hakka culture in Taiwan, and a program was broadcast last week throughout Asia, " Huang said. The program, he added, touched many overseas Hakka viewers and made them cry.

DOC.HEADLINE: New digital convergence service set to be launched in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 20:55:54 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan will soon be able to see photos sent from friends' cell phones on their television screen, a local telecom operator said Monday.
Such an experience will be made possible sometime around February thanks to a service to be launched by Taiwan Mobile Co., the country's second largest telecom service provider.

The digital convergence service will allow users to use one single account to access photos, videos and songs through different Internet-connected devices, such as a TV set, a computer, a tablet computer, and a mobile phone, the company said in a statement.

"For example, a married couple in Taipei can send photos of their children via a cell phone during a family trip to a cloud photo album, " the company said, referring to photos being stored on a distant server.
"Their parents in Kaohsiung will receive an alert on the TV screen and can immediately see the photos of their grandchildren by using the remote control," it added.

Taiwan Mobile said it will be the country's first provider of this "four-screen" service and one of its pioneers in Asia. The initiative is the result of two years of effort and a heavy investment of resources, Taiwan Mobile President Harvey Chang said.
Taiwan Mobile hopes to draw 50,000 to 100,000 users to the new service next year.
The company said its new product will focus on videos, online interactive games or online shopping in the future, and it could also be applied to Internet- enabled refrigerators.
Taiwan Mobile said it expects to forge partnerships with Kbro Co. and other multiple system operators to promote the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's Hanvon unveils e-book store in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 21:13:16 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: China's biggest e-reader maker Hanvon Technology Co. unveiled an online e-book store in Taiwan Monday as part of its efforts to extend its business to Chinese- language markets worldwide.

The e-book store has more than 10,000 titles in traditional Chinese, simplified Chinese and English and allows Taiwanese users to preview or subscribe to digital content like newspapers and magazines that is downloadable to the company's e-reader devices, said Hanvon chief strategist Ray Zhang at a press briefing.
Zhang said Hanvon, with a 70 percent market share and more than 1 million shipments of e-readers in China, cannot find a well-matched rival in the China market.

"The density of bookstores and handset makers makes the Taiwan market a challenge for us, " he said. "By establishing an online e-book store here, we are trying to create a business model that can be applied to Chinese-language markets worldwide."
Zhang said sales of Hanvon e-books and e-readers in Taiwan will focus on individual consumers, unlike its business model in China that is supported mainly by government purchases.

According to Gartner Inc., an information technology research and advisory firm, worldwide e-reader sales are forecast to reach 6.6 million units this year, up 79.8 percent from 3.6 million in 2009. The number is projected to surpass 11 million in 2011, an increase of 68.3 percent from 2010.
The growth of the e-reader market is primarily driven by sales of Amazon's e-readers in North America, which is predicted to total 4 million units by the end of this year, Gartner said.

Zhang said if the online bookstore service goes smoothly in Taiwan, the company will launch a similar service in North America in the next few years, in a bid to meet demand there for non-English content.
In September, Hanvon unveiled a 10.1-inch "TouchPad" tablet computer that uses the Windows 7 operating system, a move that was seen as likely to hurt the company's sales of e-readers.
However, Zhang said the company plans to launch an Android-based tablet device in the second quarter of 2011.

He said Hanvon has found that its e-readers do not meet the increasing need for its online bookstore services, therefore, the company is offering more choices of e-book devices in a bid to combine its advantage in handset manufacturing with its platform services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese composer wins Czech award with digitized pipa music
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 21:16:57 (By Huang Yen-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An electronic music composer from Taiwan has won one of the top prizes of an international competition with digitized variations of the timbre and tone of the pipa, a four-stringed traditional Chinese music instrument.

Tseng Yu-chung, a professor in National Chiao Tung University's (NCTU's) Institute of Music, won the top prize in the A-category of Music Nova 2010, an international electroacoustic music competition held in the Czech Republic, with a composition titled "Points of Departure with 17 Variations."
Tseng performed his composition, which he said was inspired by the sounds of the pipa, at a news conference held at an NCTU studio Monday.
The concept behind the piece was to investigate and explore all possible transformations or variations of pipa sounds using advanced digital technology, Tseng said.

Through a compositional technique similar to developing variations employed by Brahms and other masters, Tseng said, he created 17 variations, with each one departing on its own new sound journey with a punctuated percussive sound similar to that of the pipa's plucked sound.
Tseng also recorded sounds of two other traditional Chinese instruments -- the bell and cymbals -- as well as the sound of a mole cricket in his composition.
The Taiwanese composer was the first ever to win top honors at the competition, in which 54 composers from 28 countries took part.

DOC.HEADLINE: One of Taiwan's all-time baseball greats changes clubs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 22:03:10 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: In one of the most sensational acquisitions in Taiwan's professional baseball league history, Sinon Bulls veteran slugger Chang Tai-shan was bought Monday by the Unir-President Lions for an NT$2.5 million (US$83,333) fee.

Both the Taichung-based Bulls and the Tainan-based Lions notified Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League by fax that Chang, the league's all-time leading home run hitter with 241, would join the Lions in 2011.

The club confirmed to the media later in the day that it had paid the Bulls NT$2.5 million in cash to acquire Chang, who will be making NT$210,000 per month with the Lions next year, down from the NT$250,000 per month he was making with the Bulls.

In a news release, the Bulls management said the club had hoped that the 34 -year-old Chang would become a coach or player/coach in 2011 and beyond, but Chang believed he could still be an everyday player.
"The failure in reaching a consensus led the club to try to deal him," the Bulls management said.

Chang, who also holds the CPBL records for RBIs with 1,030 and hits with 1,622 in a 15-year career, first joined the now defunct Weichuan Dragons in 1996 at the age of 19 and later transferred to the Sinon Bulls in 1999.
In an exclusive telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Chang said he would try his best to maintain his records after joining the Lions.
"I will make records of my own and records for the Uni-President Lions as well," a resolute Chang said.
He said he appreciated the Bulls' plans for him to become a coach, but he said he was not yet ready to scale down his playing time.
On the pay cut he took to play for the Lions, Chang said the new contract was acceptable because he had yet to contribute to the club.
The move to acquire a player for a fee is not unprecedented in the CPBL. The Lions acquired left-handed pitcher Hsu Yu-wei from the La New Bears for NT$3 million in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteers bathe 15,400 Buddha statues to greet new year
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 22:30:05 (By Hsia Nien-tsu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: More than 800 volunteers washed and cleaned 15,400 Buddha statues of different sizes at the Fo Guang Shan Monastery in Kaohsiung Monday, an action that senior monk Hui Chuan said would cleanse people's minds as they prepare to greet the new year.

Fo Guang Shan Monastery, the largest in southern Taiwan, kicked off a campaign to clean the Buddha statues as part of the activities to celebrate the 100th year of the founding of the Republic of China.
Hsin Pei, the monastery's head monk, said Buddha himself, as an enlightened being, would not care if his image were covered with dust.
But the ritual and symbolic action of cleaning his statues with water could endear believers to Buddha's body, enabling them to get rid of physical dirt and spiritual disturbances.
Senior monk Hui Chuan said the temple held an activity two years ago asking people to bathe and clothe their seniors in a gesture of filiality and respect.

For similar reasons, he said, bathing the Buddha statues could be seen as a way for people to clean their minds, giving them the peace of mind needed to obtain enough wisdom to weather all difficulties and enjoy a smooth and auspicious future.

A three-floor scaffold was erected on the wall of the main temple hall, and volunteers passed down all of the 14,800 statues to the ground where another group of volunteer workers cleaned them with fresh water.
In addition, another 600 statues were taken from three other halls for the annual cleaning, bringing the total to 15,400 washed.
Many of the volunteers were overseas Chinese hailing from Argentina and other countries, some of whom came with three generations of family members.

Some of the tourists visiting Fo Guang Shan from China marveled at the grand and rare sight of so many people acting together to wash Buddha statues, while others actually joined the ranks of volunteers.
When their tour guides called them to return to their tour buses, they regretted having to leave so soon. "How quickly time passes! It's too bad. I haven't gotten enough out of this," one said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not open doors to Chinese generic drugs soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 22:35:41 (By Pan Chi-i and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Monday that Taiwan will not open its doors to generic drugs from China anytime soon even though the two sides concluded a medical and health care cooperation agreement recently.

"Generic drugs developed and manufactured in Taiwan are of better quality than those from China, " Yaung said after attending an award-presentation ceremony for exceptional pharmaceuticals and biotechnology products.

Generic drugs are drugs produced and distributed without patent protection. In Taiwan, qualified pharmaceutical companies can produce and market the generic product once the patent protection afforded to the original developer have expired.

On the cross-strait medical and health care cooperation agreement that was signed in Taipei last week, Yaung said the pact was aimed mainly at establishing mechanisms on pharmaceutical and medication management between the two sides.
Such a move would not only help ensure the quality of drugs on both sides but also shorten the period of time required for drug examination and screening.
"We look forward to an early passage of the pact by the legislature," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Planned culture park to further boost tourism in Hualien
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 22:52:06 (By Chen Hsun-hsieh and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A planned theater featuring natural scenery will be built along eastern Taiwan's coastline to further boost tourism in the underdeveloped area, Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said Monday.

The proposed site for the arts and culture park is near the coast where the Liwu River feeds into the Pacific Ocean, said Fu as he unveiled the project with playwright and director Stan Lai and architect Kris Yao.
The proposed park will feature a theater whose rear wall can open for the audience sitting on 800 rotating seats that will enable them to enjoy the mountain and sea views surrounding the venue.
Lai said the spectacular dual view inspired him to come up with the idea of adding rotating seats to the proposed design.

The park will be named after the town of Taroko roughly 10 kilometers away that sits at the entrance of the mountain road leading to Taroko Gorge, one of Taiwan's best known tourist attractions that draws 6 million visitors a year, Fu said.
The park, which will likely take three and a half to four years to complete, will be developed along green building principles, including the use of rain catchment areas and solar power, Yao said.
The project, budgeted at NT$3 billion, will have to go through an 18 months to two year environment impact assessment process, said Hualien County tourism director Chen Yu-chen.
The county government cannot finance the project on its own and will have to request funds from the central government and possibly even solicit investment from private enterprises, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President opposes embedded advertisement with political ends
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 23:07:49 (By Lee Shu-hua, Kelvin Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he is opposed to embedded advertisement containing a subtle political message and supports a clear line between news and advertising.
Lo Chih-chiang, Ma's spokesman, said the president attaches great importance to the issue and had exchanged views on it with members of his core team during a meeting Monday.

The issue has aroused attention after the National Communications Commission decided days ago not to renew the license for a TV channel for excessive embedded advertising and scholars criticized the Ma administration for buying news slots to pass off government advertisements as news.
"The issue is complex, and its definition and content should be further defined, " Lo said, adding that Ma has asked the Cabinet to review and study the issue.
He said Ma's longstanding position has been that the government should not engage in embedded advertising and that news and advertising should be clearly separated to not mislead the public.

But to inform the public on the policies being promoted by the government, the government still needed to publicize them, sometimes through advertising, Lo said, and if that were the case, the ads would have to be identified as such, Lo said.
He said President Ma has asked related government agencies to study substantive measures to deal with the issue, such as starting with self-restraint by the government.

Su Jun-pin, a spokesman of the ruling Kuomintang, said the party would definitely exercise self-restraint, and expressed the hope that both the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party will work toward the goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for establishment of long-term care for elderly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 23:08:56 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday urged the government to establish a long-term care system for elderly people in need of help.
The appeal came after an 83-year-old man allegedly killed his wife, who was suffering from Parkinson's disease, by driving a screwdriver into her skull with a hammer.

Legislator Kuan Bi-ling, who concurrently serves as the DPP caucus secretary- general, said the incident was a heart-wrenching tragedy that underscored the need for the government to create a long-term care system for the elderly in need of assistance.
She recalled that the DPP began pushing for the development of a localized, community-based long-term care system in 2002 when the party was in power.

"The drive was suspended after the DPP lost power in 2008. We hope the current Kuomintang (KMT) administration can devise a long-term care mechanism for the elderly in need of help as soon as possible to prevent the recurrence of a similar tragedy," Kuan said.

She said the DPP was opposed to the KMT's idea of developing large-scale institutions to look after elderly people in need of long-term care, preferring community-based and small-sized facilities instead.

DPP legislator Chen Ting-fei said the tragedy could be attributed to Taiwan's flawed and inadequate social security system, which has left many senior citizens on their own without receiving the proper care.

With Taiwan's population aging, she said, the number of people aged 65 or over now accounts for 10.5 percent of the total population, and the ratio will reach 14.5 percent in 2017 and 40 percent in 2060.
The government should pay more attention to problems that an aging society tends to face and figure out a response strategy as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Prosecutors Office said Monday it will collaborate with coroners next week in performing an autopsy on the 80-year-old woman allegedly killed by her husband of more than five decades.
Prosecutors said the octogenarian, identified as Wang Ching-hsi, was taken into custody Sunday evening on a charge of homicide.
The man told police by phone earlier that day that he had administered euthanasia on his chronically ill wife according to an agreement they reached more than a decade ago "to die in peace."
Wang claimed that his wife was miserable because she had long suffered from Parkinson's disease and had lately broken her left leg.
Prosecutors said they will contact the couple's two sons in the United States in hopes that they can return to deal with the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chang Chih-yuan wins 2010 NTSO conducting contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 23:20:46 (By Cheng Ching-wen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A young musician who followed his father in becoming a violinist won the top prize in the 2010 NTSO conducting contest, an honor giving him the chance to become the orchestra's guest conductor, organizers said Monday.

National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra (NTSO) leader Liu Suan-yung said Chang, who has played the violin since he was five years old and was now one of the orchestra's violinists, was the top prize winner.
The son of a man who once was the NTSO's lead violinist and assistant conductor, Chang said that when he was young, his father would show him videotapes of legendary conductor Herbert von Karajan.

"I just felt there must be great energy in the act of conducting, as sounds would come from the stage at the gesture of the conductor," he said, describing it as an experience that made him want to be a conductor one day.

He played violin until high school, when he switched to percussion, majoring in the subject until his graduate school days. When he moved to The Juilliard School in New York for his second master's degree, he focused on conducting.
In 2004, he returned to Taiwan to begin his military service. It was during that time when he had opportunities to play and conduct in front of foreign dignitaries.
He said winning the top prize in the contest was "no big deal, " and vowed to work harder to sharpen his professional skill in cooperating with local and foreign music groups.
Liu said Chang and other prize winners would be given chances to act as the orchestra's guest conductors.
The second prize went to Lin Chao-chin and the third prize to Hou Chao-yung.

DOC.HEADLINE: President opposes embedded advertisement with political ends
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 23:07:49 (By Lee Shu-hua, Kelvin Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he is opposed to embedded advertisement containing a subtle political message and supports a clear line between news and advertising.
Lo Chih-chiang, Ma's spokesman, said the president attaches great importance to the issue and had exchanged views on it with members of his core team during a meeting Monday.

The issue has aroused attention after the National Communications Commission decided days ago not to renew the license for a TV channel for excessive embedded advertising and scholars criticized the Ma administration for buying news slots to pass off government advertisements as news.
"The issue is complex, and its definition and content should be further defined, " Lo said, adding that Ma has asked the Cabinet to review and study the issue.
He said Ma's longstanding position has been that the government should not engage in embedded advertising and that news and advertising should be clearly separated to not mislead the public.

But to inform the public on the policies being promoted by the government, the government still needed to publicize them, sometimes through advertising, Lo said, and if that were the case, the ads would have to be identified as such, Lo said.
He said President Ma has asked related government agencies to study substantive measures to deal with the issue, such as starting with self-restraint by the government.

Su Jun-pin, a spokesman of the ruling Kuomintang, said the party would definitely exercise self-restraint, and expressed the hope that both the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party will work toward the goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for establishment of long-term care for elderly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/10 23:08:56 (By Ho Meng-kuei and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 28, 2010, or the 23rd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter- high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non- binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 09:54:17 (By Y.F. Low)

The weighted price index gained 31.21 points, or 0.35 percent, to close at 8,892.31 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar gains despite derivative limits
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 11:55:01 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar extended its strength in Tuesday morning trading, rising above NT$30.00 again, as investors ignored the central bank's latest measures to limit foreign exchange derivative positions to slow down the pace of appreciation, dealers said.
At 11:45 a.m., the Taiwan dollar stood at NT$29.464 against the U.S. dollar, compared with Monday's close of NT$30.425.

The central bank announced on Monday that the ceiling on banks' holdings of Taiwan dollar non-deliverable forwards and options would be lowered to 20 percent of their total positions, down from the previous one-third, effective immediately.
The central bank said the move was aimed at maintaining trading order in the foreign exchange market and curbing market speculation.
Despite the measures, demand for the Taiwan dollar remained strong, in particular from exporters as the year comes to an end.

Foreign institutional investors also continued to move funds into the local market, betting the local currency would continue to ride the wave of fund inflows as the United States pumps money into the market to boost its economy.

Expectations are high that the central bank will raise its key interest rates in its quarterly policy-making meeting scheduled for Thursday, dealers said, and higher local interest rates would also attract more foreign funds, they believed.

Dealers said the central bank was very likely to intervene in the local foreign exchange market again in late trading to push the U.S. dollar back to the NT$30.00 level against the Taiwan dollar, a level the market believes the central bank can tolerate in the short term.

Since the end of August, the Taiwan dollar has risen 5.22 percent against the U.S. dollar based on closing prices, but by 8.1 percent if actual rates during trading sessions or available at banks, which are now around NT$29.5 to the greenback, are considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Food for thought on elderly care

TEXT.P: A 83-year-old man made shocking headlines Monday after killing his chronically- ill wife by pumping her with sedatives and then hammering a 15 centimeter screw driver into her skull. The man, identified as retired engineer Wang Ching-hsi, said the act was intended as a "mercy killing" to end his wife's suffering from Parkinson's disease.

The couple were in fact quite well off financially. We wonder about the lives of families with similar problems but not similar financial means. Their stories are not reported by the media, but they are probably leading a life that is worse than death.

Statistics show that there are more than 600,000 people who need long-term care in Taiwan, 400,000 of whom are attended to by their own families. The figure does not include unreported cases, and the problem is expected to worsen as Taiwanese society grays rapidly in the coming decades.

The latest tragedy provides food for thought for people and the government. This is an ordeal that every "Mr. Wang" and "Mrs. Wang" might go through. Sufficient social support should be provided to them to keep them company on this long, long road. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Consistency needed in carbon reduction policy
DOC.DATELINE: 12/28/10 13:32:05 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 28, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: As part of efforts to conserve energy and reduce carbon emissions, the central government in recent years has been asking its employees to turn off any unnecessary lights and not to wear suits to work so that less electricity for air-conditioning would be required.
However, it is doubtful whether this policy has been observed at the local government level or in the private sector.

In fact, the policy is often set aside whenever there is a festive occasion or an election. As a result, the Mid-Autumn Festival has become a barbecue festival, New Year's Eve a night for fireworks shows, and elections a season for firecrackers.

We have nothing against festive celebrations, but we believe the government's policy should be consistent. Also, environmental groups should monitor local governments efficiently and promote the concept of energy conservation and carbon reduction in the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwanese insurer, Chinese bank tie up

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Life Insurance Co. announced Monday it would collaborate with China Construction Bank Corp., China's second largest bank, to explore that country's insurance market.

China Life Chairman and CEO Alan Wang said at a news conference that the company will pay 379 million yuan (US$57 million) to acquire a 19.9 percent stake in Shanghai-based Pacific Antai Life Insurance Co., in which Construction Bank controls a majority share of 51 percent.
Wang said the company has filed an application with the Financial Supervisory Commission to gain approval of its China investment plan.

If approved, it will be the first insurance-bank joint venture since Taiwan and China signed the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) in June to pave the way for closer bilateral economic and financial ties.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the event:
Commercial Times:

Pacific Antai Life Insurance was established in Shanghai in 1998 by China Pacific Insurance (Group) Co. and ING Group NV, a Netherlands-based global financial services company. It is the 12th largest of 28 insurance joint ventures in China as measured by total assets.

Construction Bank bought out ING's 50 percent stake in Pacific Antai a year ago. As Pacific Insurance owned another life insurance company, it had to sell its 50 percent stake in Pacific Antai under Chinese regulations governing the insurance business.

Construction Bank decided to partner with Taiwan's China Life Insurance and three other financial service providers to buy out Pacific Insurance's stake in the company, which will be renamed CCB Life Insurance Co.
After the company's management is restructured, Construction Bank will hold a 51 percent stake in CCB Life, China Life a 19.9 percent, and three other investors the remaining 29.1 percent.
Wang said the new insurance joint venture would be able to use Construction Bank's 13,403 branches throughout China to sell its insurance policies and expand its market penetration.

No other Taiwanese insurers are expected to secure access to the retail networks of big Chinese banks in the foreseeable future, Wang said, because the three other biggest Chinese banks selling life insurance on a trial basis -- Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, Bank of Communications and Bank of Beijing -- have already signed up partners to help them expand into the business.
If all goes well, Wang said, his company will be able to formally begin its joint venture operations in China in the second quarter of next year. (Dec. 28, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
In the past, Taiwan's life insurers opted to set up new life insurance companies in China in collaboration with Chinese enterprises.
China Life chose a different path by teaming up with one of China's largest state-owned commercial lenders to buy into an existing life insurance company.

A China Life executive said the company believed its "insurance-bank tie- up" option would be far more effective in penetrating the vast Chinese insurance market than the previous model of setting up new equal-share joint ventures with Chinese partners.
China's insurance market has been growing rapidly and has emerged as Asia's second largest, behind only Japan's.

Given its relatively low insurance penetration rate (the ratio of premiums to GDP) of 2.3 percent, the executive said, China still has great potential for insurance market growth. Taiwan's insurance penetration rate is 13.8 percent. (Dec. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Life expects mainland deal to close in 2011 Q1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 14:57:15 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Life Insurance Co. said Tuesday that it expected its acquisition of a stake in China-based Pacific Antai Life Insurance would be completed in the first quarter of next year.

In the deal announced by China Life on Monday, the insurer will spend 379 million Chinese yuan (NT$1.78 billion) to buy a 19.9 percent stake in Pacific Antai Life from China Pacific Insurance Co., while China Construction Bank Corp. will raise its stake in the Chinese insurer to 51 percent from the current 50 percent.
China Construction Bank bought the 50 percent stake it now holds from ING Group NV a year ago.

After the transaction, China Life, China Construction Bank and three unspecified Chinese investors will jointly operate Pacific Antai Life, which will be renamed CCB Life Insurance Co. It is expected to officially begin operations in the second quarter.
China Life said there was no need for it to raise funds separately to finance the deal because it had sufficient cash on hand.
The deal is pending regulatory approval from Taiwan and China, China Life said.

China Life, one of Taiwan's five biggest life insurers, said the investment represents a big step in its effort to expand its presence in China's fast growing insurance market, after first opening a representative office in Beijing in 2005.
In making the investment, China Life said it hoped to capitalize on China Construction Bank's extensive retail network of 13,000 branches and 278 million customers to penetrate China's market.
According to the local insurer, CCB Life is expected to rank among the top five life insurers in China within five years and rise to the top three within 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close down 0.24 percent
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 15:46:49 (By Frances Huang)
