TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down 0.24 percent Tuesday on a mild correction from the previous session, but ample funds helped to keep the market above the 8,800 point mark, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 21.55 points to 8,870.76, after moving between 8,839.83 and 8,919.26, on turnover of NT$101.34 billion (US$3.42 billion).

The market opened up 0.30 percent on follow-through buying and it briefly breached the technical resistance of 8,900 points in early trade before profit taking emerged to reverse the early gains, dealers said.
A total of 2,915 stocks closed down, 1,092 finished up and 368 remained unchanged.

The paper and pulp sector encountered the heaviest pressure, ending down 1.4 percent. Textile stocks lost 0.9 percent, cement and financial shares fell 0.3 percent, and the machinery and electronic sector dropped 0.2 percent.
The construction sector fell 0.1 percent, while the foodstuff and plastic and chemical sectors closed unchanged.

"With many foreign institutional investors remaining away from trading floor ahead of the New Year holiday, the local bourse appeared quiet, moving in a narrow range," Horizon Securities analyst Benson Huang said.
Huang said a lackluster Wall Street overnight failed to provide any meaningful indication to the local market.
Selling focused on select old economy stocks, which have been significantly boosted by a stronger New Taiwan dollar on hopes of an increase in domestic asset value, Huang said.
"For the rest of the year, the local market is expected to continue range trade, " Huang said. "High liquidity is likely to shield the market from a major pullback."
In the paper and pulp sector, Taiwan Pulp & Paper fell 1.93 percent to close at NT$17.75 and Shihlin Paper lost 1.61 percent to end at NT$73.20.
Among the high tech stocks, PC vendor Acer dropped 1.09 percent to NT$90.80, while Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest contract electronic maker, closed unchanged at NT$117.00.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Little Leaguers grab Asian championship
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 15:59:25 (By Mike Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan defeated Japan 4-1 in the final of the sixth Asian Little League Championship in Okayama Prefecture Tuesday to successfully defend its title in the biennial competition.
Japan had been seen as a tough opponent entering the game after having swept the other three teams in its preliminary round group, including a 10-1 trouncing of South Korea.
But Taiwan maintained its undefeated record at this year's tournament by beating the host team to win its fifth consecutive Asian Championship.
Taiwan had swept China, Indonesia and Thailand to win Group A in the eight-team tournament and then edged South Korea 2-1 in Monday's semifinal game to set up the championship showdown against Japan.
The Asian Little League Championships have been held every two years in a country in the region since they began in 2000.
Taiwan won the championship for the first time in 2002, when the tournament was held in Wuxi, China.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't give up on bullies

TEXT.P: A series of recent bullying incidents in schools has given rise to widespread discussions of the issue in Taiwan, with most people agreeing that it is a serious problem that requires stronger preventative measures.

However, most of the opinions expressed have been from the standpoint of the victims, with many people advocating that school bullies be punished and expelled. Scant attention has been paid to the family background, personality traits or motives of school bullies, who are often stigmatized.

Bullies are also children who need education. If their deviant behaviors can be corrected, there probably will be fewer crimes in society in the future. Giving up on them too early would mean pushing more people over to the side of evil.

To ensure that schools are a safe place for study, an effective mechanism for reporting and dealing with bullying is required. If the bullying acts amount to violations of the law, the police must be called in to deal with the matter.

The top priority now is to restore a safe school environment for our children. But in the process of protecting students from being bullied, we must not give up on the bullies. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower, off low of NT$29.445
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 17:35:49 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Tuesday, shedding NT$0.029 to close at NT$30.396, off a low of NT$29.445 after the central bank's intervention, dealers said.
Turnover totaled US$657 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.435 and moved between NT$29.445 and NT$30.440 before the close.

Soon after the market opened, the New Taiwan dollar rose above the NT$30.00 mark again, although the central bank tightened the rules on derivative trade in the local currency in a bid to curb market speculation, dealers said.

The central bank announced Monday that the ceiling on banks' holdings of Taiwan dollar non-deliverable forwards and options would be lowered to 20 percent of their total positions, down from one-third, effective immediately.

Dealers said the New Taiwan dollar was boosted by further inflows of foreign funds as traders were betting the local currency would continue to strengthen on a strong rebound in the local economic fundamentals.

The New Taiwan dollar is expected to continue to gain against the U.S. dollar also because the greenback is under downward pressure as the United States injects funds into its market through treasury bond purchases to boost its economy, the dealers said.
The Taiwan central bank is widely expected to raise its key interest rates in its quarterly policy meeting Thursday, which is likely to attract more foreign funds, dealers said.
A weaker U.S. dollar in the regional market spurred selling of the U.S. currency in the local foreign exchange market, they said.
In late trade, the central bank intervened to lift the value of the U.S. dollar above to NT$30.00, a level the market believes the central bank can accept in the short term, the dealers added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung citizens unearth weapons cache
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei. Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 17:44:52 (By Hau Hsueh-ching & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A group of Taichung City residents was surprised 11 days ago to unearth guns and ammunition buried near an earth god shrine in the city, Taichung police said Tuesday.

Residents of the Dongshan ward of the central Taiwan City, while leveling ground around the temple, uncovered from a depth of five to six meters a plastic bucket containing 33 guns, including submachine guns, rifles and pistols, in addition to more than 4,000 rounds of ammunition.
Police who investigated the find said the firearms and ammunition could have been buried for over two years, since some of them were corroded.
The central city is notorious for its poor social order. Just months ago, a local gang leader was shot dead in his office while several local policemen were playing mahjong there.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said that it was "good to uncover the firearms" before they could be used to commit crimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better economy pushes up 2010 bonuses: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 18:03:45 (By H.C. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Thanks to an improved economy over the past year, Taiwanese employees will get average bonuses worth 1.4-months' salary at the end of this year, up from an average of 1.07 months a year ago, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

Some 93 percent of Taiwan's businesses -- the highest ratio in five years -- will issue bonuses to their employees for 2010, noticeably up from 80 percent in 2009, according to the survey conducted by the 104 job bank Dec. 6-9 among 663 white-collar workers.

Workers in the financial, transport/distribution and construction/real- estate sectors will receive the most handsome bonuses this year, ranging from a level of 2.08 months to 1.55 months, the survey shows.
In contrast, those in tourism-related businesses and mass communications will get the poorest bonuses of less than one-month's salary.
The poll also found that the amount of bonuses will have an influence on employees' decisions on whether they will change jobs at Chinese New Year.
At the same time, some 77 percent of the businesses surveyed said they will raise salaries for their workers in 2011 by an average of 3.9 percent, or an increase of NT$1,412 (US$46) per month.
About 19 percent of these companies said they will increase pay for all their staff, while 58 percent said they will do so based on performance.
According to government statistics, monthly salaries of Taiwan's office workers in the first 10 months of this year averaged NT$36,205.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China banks sign MOU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 18:19:33 (by Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Cooperative Bank signed a memorandum of understanding with Bank of China Tuesday on partnership in a wide range of services.

Under the "comprehensive business cooperation" agreement, the two banks are expected to work together to offer services such as settlements, trade financing, project loans, syndication loans, interbank lending, risk management and loans for small and medium-sized enterprises.
They will also engage in personnel exchanges, they said.
The MOU was signed in Beijing by the presidents of the two banks, Tsai Chiu-jung of Taiwan Cooperative Bank and Li Lihui of Bank of China.

In a statement, Taiwan Cooperative Bank noted that Bank of China is the most internationalized financial institution in China and said that through the partnership, the two banks will help each other to develop their business in the greater China area.

At a news conference held at the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Hsieh Chung-dea, executive vice president of the local bank, told reporters that his bank is scheduled to open a branch in Suzhou in China's Jiangsu Province Wednesday, following the signing of the MOU.
Hsieh said the Suzhou branch will target Taiwanese companies operating in Suzhou and the neighboring areas of Kunshan, Shanghai and Hangzhou.
Hsieh said the bank will study the feasibility of setting up branches in Chengdu and Chongqing in Sichuan Province as more and more Taiwanese investors are relocating to inland China. Tianjin
is also a possible location for Taiwan Cooperative Bank branches, he said.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank was one of the first five Taiwanese banks to secure approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) to set up branches on the mainland.
The other four were First Commercial Bank, Cathay United Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan.

In an earlier statement, the CBRC said it hoped that the presence of Taiwanese bank branches in China would help promote cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations and maintain the steady development of the cross-strait banking sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister bullish on 2010 economic growth
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 18:26:57 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Tuesday that Taiwan's economy will likely show growth of more than 10 percent this year on the back of a recovering economy.

Taiwan's statistics bureau has forecast economic growth of 9.98 percent for this year -- a 21-year high -- and has predicted growth of 4.51 percent in 2011, when the global economy is expected to slow down.
However, Shih said Tuesday that his ministry will work to boost the economic growth in Taiwan to 5 percent for next year and he raised the forecast for this year.
"Various data show that there should be no problem achieving growth of over 10 percent this year," he said at a press conference.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has set a "pragmatic" goal of attracting US$7.4 billion worth of investments by foreign companies, US$120 million by Chinese businesses and NT$45 billion (US$1.5 billion) by overseas- based Taiwanese companies next year, Shih said.
So far this year, the MOEA said, it has attracted US$7 billion, US$100 million and NT$40 billion worth of investments from these three sources, respectively.
Total investments from these sources are expected to grow nearly 7 percent in 2011 compared to this year.

It is widely expected that foreign investments in Taiwan will rise sharply from next year, when a range of tariff reductions and eliminations will take effect under a landmark trade pact between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chang Hwa Bank plans expansion in China from Jiangsu base
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 18:38:04 (By Tien Yu-pin and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, one of Taiwan's leading lenders, said Tuesday it will use the eastern China province of Jiangsu as a base for its business expansion on the mainland.

At the formal opening of the bank's first branch in China, its chairman Julius Chen said plans are in the works to set up a sub-branch in Huaqiao, which serves as a link between Shanghai and Kunshan, where the new branch is located.
The aim is to build an operating base in Jiangsu, which has been tagged by Chinese authorities for development as an international financial hub, he said.

Property developers from Taiwan are looking to launch huge construction projects there to cater to Taiwanese companies operating in China, and Huaqiao is expected to benefit from the Jiangsu development plan, Chen said.
Chen said the bank will apply to the relevant authorities in Taiwan and China for permission to set up the Huagiao sub-branch in the first quarter of next year.
As part of its expansion plan, Chang Hwa Bank is also eying Dongguan and Shenzhen in Guangdong Province, Chen said.

Chang Hwa Bank was one of the first five Taiwanese banks to secure approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) to set up branches on the mainland by upgrading its Kunshan representative office into a branch.
The others four were First Commercial Bank, Cathay United Bank, Taiwan Cooperative Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan.

First Commercial Bank and Cathay United Bank opened branches in Shanghai last week, while Taiwan Cooperative Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan will open branches Wednesday in Suzhou and Shanghai, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parties mum on presidential running mates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 19:10:48 (By Garfie Li, Wen Kui-hsiang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou declined to say Tuesday during a year-end meeting with reporters who he will choose as his running mate in the 2012 presidential election.

Ma was asked if Vice President Vincent Siew will be his running mate again in 2012. The Ma-Siew pair won 7,659,000 votes in 2008, or 58 percent, to beat the DPP ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang, who garnered 5,445,000 ballots, or 42 percent of the popular vote.
Ma said Siew has been a great help to him over the past two years but added that it is premature to talk about his running mate in his 2012 re-election bid.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has also not nominated either a presidential candidate or legislative candidates for the quadrennial battle for power.

The DPP, which won more votes but fewer mayoral seats than the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) during the Nov. 27 special municipality elections, will hold a special plenary session Jan. 22 to discuss party rules for the nominations, DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher said.

A local newspaper reported that same day that DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan said during an internal meeting of the party a day earlier that nominations for the presidential and legislative elections should be completed by March.
An issue being hotly debated inside the DPP is whether to hold a nationwide survey to help decide the party's nominees for president and vice president.

Party insiders told CNA that the party's leaders have nearly reached a consensus on using a national poll result as a major buttress for naming the presidential candidate, but that members are split over the question of what percentage of the public poll versus the party vote should be used as a basis.

Since the nomination rules will not be set until after Jan. 22, which will be followed by the Lunar New Year holiday in early February, Huang said the process of electing the candidates will probably not be launched until March.

Possible names being circulated for the DPP hopefuls include DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Su Tseng-chang, a former premier and DPP chairman, both of whom were defeated in the municipality elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: High speed rail to help disadvantaged students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 19:13:04 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) said Tuesday that as part of its fourth anniversary celebrations it will launch a charity event to raise funds for school children who cannot afford to pay tuition.
Working with the Christian charity World Vision Taiwan for the second consecutive year, the THSR said, it hopes to help at least 45,000 impoverished students in Taiwan to attend school in 2011.
The campaign last year raised NT$7.89 million (US$268,000), which was disbursed to 3,157 students, according to the company.
The fundraising campaign is part of the company's efforts to address social welfare issues, THSR said.
In July, THSR donated 1,000 train tickets to college volunteers involved in community services.
"We want to use our 'high speed' ability to deliver timely help to those in need, " said the THSR Chairman Ou Chin-der.
THSR said that during the fundraising campaign from Jan. 1 to March 6, 2011, donations can be made onboard its trains or on the World Vision Taiwan website at www. worldvision.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local artist debuts new work in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 19:16:41 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese artist Ju Ming, who is internationally known for his sculpture, debuted his latest work titled "Cube" Tuesday at the National Theater, a work he says has less to do with aesthetics and more to do with problems he sees in society.

The work, consisting of two hexagonal pieces, is a 265-cm tall sculpture that features a human head at the center of a large cube. Inside the head is another cube where the brain should be. Another work shows a human, with arms and legs wide open, locked in a giant cube.
"This is not a work of art or sculpture. Rather, it is about my discovery -- it is about humankind creating the cube, and is framed within it," he said at a press conference.

The 72-year-old told reporters that even though his family was too poor to allow him an education, he has had an immense interest in science sine he was very young and has always had the habit of observing the relationship between people and Mother Nature.
The idea was born when he was watching a TV program introducing bacteria and cells and it suddenly struck him that the shape of a cube does not really exist in nature but was invented by humans.
One can see cubes everywhere in the city, he pointed out.

"Cubes bring limitation and distance among people, and the longer a person is trapped in a cube, the more likely his thoughts will change in a bad way, " he said, adding that the reason people living in the city get irritated easily is probably linked to the fact that they live in a closed, cubical environment.
The two pieces will remain on display at the National Theater from until Jan. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Seven Days in Heaven' among top-10 influential books in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 19:40:00 (By Wei Yun-ling and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The non-fiction work titled "Seven Days in Heaven" has been selected as one of the 10 most influential books in Taiwan of 2010 by the Kingstone Bookstore, the Taipei-based chain bookstore said Tuesday.

The book, which in its manuscript form won first prize in the Lin Rung San Literary Awards in 2006, features a Taiwanese funeral ceremony, through which the author, Essay Liu, tells how a collectivism-dominated society can strongly bind an individual, Kingstone commented.
Liu has also revised her book into a screenplay to show her experience of death and local funeral rites on the big screen.
The film, which bears the same title as the book, made its debut in Taiwan in August and won the 2010 Golden Horse Film Award in November for best screenplay adaptation.
The annual top-10 influential books are selected through a poll conducted by the bookstore among publishers, authors, readers, media outlets and managers of its chain stores around the country.

In addition to the books of the year, Kingstone has also awarded Linden Lin, the publisher of the Taipei-based Linking Publishing Co., and Chiang Hsun, a painter, poet and writer, as "men of the year" in the publishing sector.
Lin was cited for introducing Latin American literature to local readers and publishing works of the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa. Llosa is winner of the Nobel Prize in literature in 2010.
Chiang, meanwhile, was awarded due to his concentration on creation, which encourages readers to raise their levels of thinking, Kingstone said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Koreans persona non grata in many Taiwanese eyes: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 19:57:30 (By Zoe Wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people's overall impression of the people of South Korea has turned sour after two recent international incidents, with over half of Taiwanese respondents to a recent survey agreeing to boycott Korean products, according to the results of the survey released Tuesday.

A high of 65.6 percent of the Taiwanese citizens responding to the poll conducted by Global Views Magazine (GVM) now hold negative attitudes toward Koreans after Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun was disqualified from the 2010 Asian Games and Samsung Electronics' blew the whistle on Taiwanese flat panel makers' price-fixing to the European Commission.

The GVM poll, conducted a week earlier, found that Taiwanese people aged between 40-49 have changed their attitudes toward South Koreans most negatively, followed by those in the 30-39 age group. Those in the 15-19 age group showed little change in their attitudes toward the Koreans, despite the two incidents.
In the wake of the two incidents, 51.1 percent of the respondents said they will reduce their purchases of Korean products and 50.1 percent said they will not visit South Korea.
Another 40.7 percent said they will spend less time watching Korean soap operas and 38 percent said they will listen to fewer Korean pop songs.
Of those in the 40-49 age group, 63.7 percent said they will cut their purchases of Korean goods, the survey found.

On Yang's controversial disqualification, 52.1 percent of the respondents said they are not satisfied with the way the government has handled the case, while 27.9 percent said they are satisfied with the government's treatment of the incident.
A total of 1,002 people aged over 15 selected randomly were surveyed in the poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points, according to the magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei New Year countdown show to feature celebrities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 20:09:44 (By Wang Shu-fen and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Five local celebrities will greet the coming New Year along with large crowds at one of the major countdown concerts in Taipei, Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday.
Taiwanese that have performed well in different fields such as sports and the arts will attend the New Year's Eve celebration in front of Taipei City Hall.

Taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun, ultramarathon runner Tommy Chen and a tug-of- war team from Jingmei Girls' High School have been invited to join the countdown moments, as well as a baseball team from Chongqing Junior High School and Hsiao Ching-yang, a four-time Grammy Award nominee for album cover design.
The move is to express appreciation for their efforts in bringing "glory to Taiwan" on the world stage and to let them share their pride with everyone, said Hau after a municipal meeting.
The concert features a 3D stage and a huge LED screen, said to be the world's first outdoor 3D device, according to the Department of Information and Tourism.
The organizers will give out 40,000 pairs of 3D glasses so that the audience can see the special effects on the stage and the screen.
Meanwhile, a ceremony to mark the Republic of China's centennial will take place at the Dajia Riverside Park that same day, when nearby highways and roads will be closed.
The Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system will run for 24 hours nonstop Dec. 31 to help the expected large crowds to get around the city.
The city will also provide shuttle buses to transfer people from the concert venue to various MRT stations.

Kaohsiung City, where a similar event is scheduled to be held in the square in front of the Dream Mall, will have extended subway and bus services as well as free shuttle coaches, in an effort to minimize traffic jams.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to practice self-discipline to oppose embedded marketing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 20:18:06 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The controversy over embedded advertisements disguised as television programs or news reports prompted Premier Wu Den-yih to promise Tuesday that the government will do its best to stop the practice.

Speaking to reporters, Wu said propaganda is essential for many, such as candidates, political parties, governments and companies. The important thing, however, is to make a clear distinction to the audience between advertising and news.

The debate on product placement and "advertorials" as the ads masquerading as news are known, have become a hot topic in Taiwan in the last few weeks after a former reporter wrote in his blog about the growing trend of the government buying news coverage.

In addition, the National Communications Commission, an independent media regulator, last week decided not to renew the broadcasting license of a local cable TV channel on the grounds that it used excessive product placement and refused to take corrective action.
The incidents have stirred up heated debate among scholars and politicians on the role of government in regulating the media and the proper way of marketing government policies.

While President Ma Ying-jeou and the premier have shied away from making any direct comments on the incidents, both have promised that the government will root out the practice in its own policy promotion.
According to Wu, the use of embedded advertising to further government interests started a decade ago under the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"An upstanding policy should be presented in an upstanding and open manner. There is no need to disguise it as news. The problem has been accumulating for 10 years and now that the Kuomintang is back in power, we regret that in the past two years we have not solved the problems," he said.

Wu said he has already had discussions with the president on how to come up with comprehensive measures to curb the practice and has also instructed the Government Information Office to monitor the way the government does its marketing.
However, Wu was non-committal when asked if the government plans to enact an anti-product placement or anti-advertorial law, saying that would be the Legislative Yuan's prerogative.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese designer gets chance to showcase work in famous play
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 20:21:42 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: Keith Lin of Taiwan has been selected to design the costumes for an edition of the French play "La Dame aux Camelias" that will be staged in Taiwan next February.

Lin was chosen from among a handful of competitors to design more than 30 costumes for a version of the play that will be directed by the famous Tadashi Suzuki of Japan and produced by the National Theatre and Concert Hall (NTCH), said Sylvia Chuang of the NTCH's program and marketing department.

At a press conference Tuesday, Lin said he was very nervous when he first met with Suzuki in Japan but the director was kind and advised him to look for inspiration in the two films "My Heart Will Go On" and "Sin City."

"Suzuki gave me a lot of freedom to design the costumes," Lin said. "While he wants to present the original story written by French novelist Alexandre Dumas, he is looking for something more futuristic in the costumes."

The designer said the 30 costumes will portray a fusion of Gothic style, punk and elements of Chinese skirts. The actresses will wear gray and silver make-up to symbolize their concealment of their true feelings from the rest of the world, he added.
The new production of "La Dame aux Camelias" will premiere at the Taipei International Festival of Arts in February 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong people's confidence in Beijing drops: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 20:37:16 (By Wang Man-na and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: China's persecution of Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo has upset the people of Hong Kong, lowering their confidence in the "one country, two systems" arrangement, and in particular, damaging their trust in the Beijing regime, according to a survey released Tuesday.

The University of Hong Kong conducted the poll among a sampling of 1,000 adults in Hong Kong in mid-December, soon after the Nobel Peace Prize Committee awarded the prize to an empty chair because neither Liu nor his family were allowed to attend the ceremony in Oslo, Norway on Dec. 10.
The survey found that Hong Kong residents' distrust of Beijing has risen sharply by 10 percent since the last such poll in September.
The main reason, according to analysts of the poll, was the Chinese authorities' imprisonment of Liu Xiaobo and the parents of children who had died from the consumption of toxic powdered milk.
The survey showed that 32 percent of Hong Kong residents do not trust Beijing, while 37 percent still have trust, 5 percent less than in the September poll.
Beijing's handling of the Peace Prize issue has also affected the Hong Kong people's trust in the Hong Kong government, according to the poll.
Some 44 percent said they trust the local government, 9 percent lower than in the previous poll, while 22 percent said they do not trust it, an increase of 6 percent.
The latest survey further indicated that 62 percent of the people are confident about Hong Kong's future, a drop of 7 percent from three months ago.
The percentage of respondents who said they do not have confidence in the territory's future rose by 7 percent from three months ago to 30 percent in the latest poll.

As for the future of China, 77 percent of Hong Kong people still have confidence, a drop of 4 percent, while 15 percent said they do not have confidence in the future of the country, up 2 percent from the previous survey, the poll showed.

On their views on the "one country, two systems" arrangement between Hong Kong and China, 61 percent of the respondents said they were confident, a decline of 1 percent, while 32 percent said they have no confidence in the arrangement, an increase of 3 percent from September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fishery talks with Japan hoped to be held next year: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 20:53:20 (By Jenny W. Hsu and Garfei Li)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that a 17th round of fishery talks with Japan will most likely take place next year after a one-year hiatus.

Speaking at a regular press briefing, Association of East Asian Relations Secretary-General Huang Ming-lung said that Taipei and Tokyo have established a "tacit understanding" that the long-stalled bilateral fishery talks will be held in 2011.

Although Taiwan and Japan enjoy a stable partnership in various realms such as trade, culture and trade, conflicts over the East China Sea fishing grounds remain a major flashpoint between the two countries.
The bilateral fishery talks mechanism was initiated in 1996, but talks were suspended for three-and-a-half years in 2005 after the 15th round of talks in Tokyo.

The talks resumed in February 2009 in Taipei, during which the two sides agreed to set up an emergency communication channel and allow two organizations to act as contact windows on behalf of their respective governments.
In December 2009, the Fisheries Administration announced that Taiwan had forged an agreement with Japan to allow inspectors from both sides to conduct on-board inspections of each other's vessels.

In other news concerning Japan that day, Huang said the government will continue to fight for compensation from the Japanese government on behalf of Taiwanese women who were forced into sexual servitude, euphemistically described as "comfort women, " for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II.
In 2008, the Legislative Yuan passed a bill seeking proper compensation from the Japanese government for the surviving Taiwanese comfort women.

Currently, there are 13 surviving Taiwanese former comfort women. According to the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, approximately 500,000 women from Taiwan, the Philippines, China and various other countries, were forced into becoming sex slaves by the Japanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- New law drafted to protect retail investors
DOC.DATELINE: The NT$40 billion (US$1.33 billion) 12/28/10 21:07:36 (Wealth Magazine 361) (translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: losses in Taiwan resulting from the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 has led to the drawing up of a law specifically designed to protect investors in financial products.
The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) submitted its draft proposal to the Cabinet Dec. 14 for review, after which it will be sent to the legislature.
The proposal has gained support from lawmakers, as the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee has said it will speed up the legislative process so that it can be passed quickly.

In Taiwan, not being fully informed about potential investment risk and difficulty in seeking compensation from banks for losses are common complaints related to retail banking deals and the proposed new legislation would impose strict liability on financial institutes.
Additionally, an organization to handle the arbitration of disputes will be set up, the compensation rulings of which will be binding under a certain amount, said FSC Chairman Chen Yuh-chang.

Lawyer Lin Jui-yang said that once the law is passed, businesses in the financial industry will be held liable for customer investment losses if it is decided that the risks were not fully explained beforehand.
The burden of proof will fall on the businesses if the case is brought to court, Lin added.
One bank executive said banks will have to change their current marketing approach that "promises no loss, " since no investment is without risk.

The majority of consumers complain that banks use complicated structures that require depositors to enter into a trust relationship with the banks, which promise total returns of initial funds. In the event, however, such total returns are rarely seen.

On the other hand, Chen said, the commission will implement new regulations to enhance the management of banks' financial advisers that will require them to register with the country's Trust Association.

In terms of another concern of lawmakers that banks at present can deny responsibility by blaming the financial planners they employ to advise their clients, Chen said the bank and its employees will both be responsible in such disputes.

This might be seen as banks' wealth management business being subject to more restrictions in the future, but the banks have actually brought it on themselves because of their inexorable pursuit of profit.

During the financial crisis that began in 2008, some banks have instructed their financial advisers to encourage clients to take out money in deposits to invest in structured notes or derivatives, which have later incurred great losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for action against campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:11:17 (By Lee Shu-hua, Sabine Cheng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the authorities Tuesday to root out campus bullies and deal with them quickly and decisively, without fear of exposing any "skeletons in the closet."
During a year-end meeting with the media, the president compared campus bullying to corruption in officialdom, which he said must be fearlessly disclosed.

Ma put forth four suggestions regarding the growing incidence of campus bullying: School administrators must take the initiative to identify the bullies; such incidents must be tackled quickly and decisively; suspects must be prosecuted if crimes have been committed; and such incidents must be reported to society.
He particularly advised school authorities "not to delay, hide or cover up" bullying.

The president, a former law scholar and justice minister, said it might not be easy for teachers to decide if criminal acts have been committed in a bullying case, so "they have to increase their legal knowledge and let their charges know."

He cited recent news stories about Bade Junior High School in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, in which students are suspected of detonating firecrackers in a toilet being used by a teacher. There are also reports of students locking up classmates in the washrooms.
Were these actions just mischief, deserving of discipline by the school authorities, or criminal acts? he asked.
Ma said some social norms are simple "courtesy, " some are required under school rules and some are "moral" codes of conduct, while others are better defined under the criminal code.
"Kids need to be taught to tell the differences among these areas," he said.
Outside of the norms of social conduct, he went on, teachers should pay more attention to what is actually happening in the class under their care.

Ma said he was told by Education Minister Wu Ching-ji and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah that a mechanism is in place for schools and the police to work together on campus bullying, although not all schools report such cases to the police.

Yuan Tseh Lee, a former president of Academia Sinica, expressed concern about the development of education in Taiwan in the face of so many reports of campus bullying and controversial acts by university students.

In addition to the series of campus bullying incidents, Lee's worry was also caused by reports that a graduate school student flashed his middle finger at an ambulance while it was trying to provide emergency assistance to a patient in danger.
A former leader of an educational reform task force, Lee said the current system just teaches students to try to get good scores by writing the "correct and standard" answers in exams.
Many things need to be examined, such as moral education, interpersonal relationships, and interaction among family members, he said.
"Education must be reformed continuously," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ranger team established in effort to conserve wetlands
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:18:49 (By Kuo Chi-hsuan and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A team of community rangers was formed Tuesday to help protect wetland areas around the Shueiwaku community, the second ecotourism attraction of its kind near Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan.

The community worked with the park's headquarters to set up a ranger team to investigate and monitor the ecosystem of the two wetlands in the area and to prevent illegal activities there, said Chen Mei-hui, a Pingtung University of Science and Technology associate professor who directed the ecotourism development project.
The wetlands were abundant in frogs some 20 years ago, as well as butterflies and fireflies.
However, the construction of the Erchia Highway in 1979 and later human development caused the water to dry up, leading to a decrease in wildlife.
The park began last May to promote ecotourism in Shueiwaku -- about four kilometers north of Erluanbi -- to restore the wetland ecosystem while helping boost the local economy, Chen said.
It also trained the residents as tour guides and taught them how to conserve the environment.

The community, with a population of 200, is the second successful example of ecotourism in the area after a village between Shedin Park and the Kenting Forest Recreation Area implemented a similar initiative in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 might come back, reaching peak in mid-January: doctor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:31:24 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of influenza A(H1N1) infections in Taiwan might reach peak in mid- January as the virus is likely to make a comeback this winter, a pediatrician warned Tuesday.

Using the medical history in Taiwan over the past five years as evidence, Huang Li-min, a pediatrician at National Taiwan University Hospital, said the strains that cause a major flu outbreak in a given area will stay for two consecutive years.

Besides, he forecast, the A(H1N1) onslaught will recur this year since most of the people who contracted the disease or were inoculated against the virus last year will have no antibodies or immunity strong enough to combat a new attack.
This year, few children in Taiwan have acquired immunity against all three major types of flu viruses -- A(H1N1), A/H3 and influenza B.

The cases of A(H1N1) and influenza B infections have been rising over the past week and the two types of viruses are expected to be mainstay of flu infections in the country by the middle of 2011, Huang estimated.
Taiwan was one of the countries hit by the H1N1 flu virus in 2009. More than 800 people in Taiwan were hospitalized with H1N1 symptoms, 35 of whom died.

Meanwhile, according to Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control, 11.33 percent of the people who checked into emergency rooms around Taiwan over the past week were admitted because of flu infections and 1.27 percent of Taiwan's outpatients in the same period were flu patients.
Of these patients, 60 percent were infected with A(H1NI) and 30 percent had influenza B, Shih said.

Taiwan also reported one more influenza death last week, he said. The case was a 62-year-old man from China who had never been inoculated and who came down with flu symptoms after arriving in Taiwan for sightseeing. The man died next day after checking into a local hospital. He tested positive for A(H1N1), according to Shih.
Shih suggested that Taiwanese tourists get themselves inoculated before traveling abroad, as A(H1N1) outbreaks have also been reported in Europe, the United States, Japan and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma challenges DPP head to accept '92 consensus'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei. Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:45:38 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou challenged Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Tuesday to accept the "1992 consensus" between Taiwan and China.

"If the DPP were to become the ruling party one day, I wonder if Tsai would have her DPP administration continue the Kuomintang's existing policy (toward China)," Ma said at a year-end gathering with reporters.
The "1992 consensus" refers to a tacit agreement reached between Taiwan and China in 1992 that "there is only one China, but Taipei and Beijing are free to interpret 'one China' as they see fit."

The term "1992 consensus" was coined in 2000 by then Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi to summarize the tacit agreement, which has been serving as the basis for Taiwan-China negotiations since 2008 when President Ma took office.
The DPP-led opposition camp has refused to accept the 1992 consensus on the grounds that it could result in China's annexation of Taiwan.

Ma said that during a meeting with former President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP in April 2006, he had suggested that the government accept the consensus in order to resume the suspended cross-strait talks.
"After a two-hour discussion, Chen promised to recognize the consensus if China did so first," Ma said

Ma said that in a phone call to former U.S. President George W. Bush on March 26, 2008, Chinese President Hu Jintao indicated a willingness to reopen cross- strait talks on the basis of the "1992 consensus."

Furthermore, Li Yafei, Vice President of the Beijing-based Associations for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , has said that the 1992 consensus refers to "both sides each orally interpreting their own concept of 'one China' principle, " Ma noted.
ARATS and its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, are the semi-official organizations authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges.
"It would be impractical for the DPP to continue to deny the existence of the consensus, " Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei metro annual ridership to top 500 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:04:19 (By Johnson Sun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The annual ridership of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system is expected to top 500 million passengers Wednesday, marking a new page in Taiwan's MRT services since the system's inception in 1996, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) said Tuesday.

As of the previous day, the Taipei MRT system posted a ridership total of 498 million passengers this year, a number expected to top the 500 million mark Dec. 29, according to the TRTC, operator of the MRT.

Expanding from one route in its inaugural year in March 1996, the Taipei MRT system now encompasses 10 routes connecting most districts and townships in the greater Taipei area, with 93 stations and a service length exceeding 100 km, according to the TRTC.

With the expansion of routes, the system's daily ridership has continued to hit new highs. The average daily ridership exceeded 1.57 million in November and the figure surged to a record high of 1.86 million Dec. 24, the company said.

Once the system's annual ridership exceeds 500 million, the Taipei MRT will be able to enter the Nova International Railway Benchmarking Group and the Community of Metros (Nova/CoMET) as a CoMET member, qualifying Taipei to conduct metro technical exchanges with major cities in the world such as London, New York, Paris and Moscow.
At present, the Taipei MRT system is a member of Nova, membership of which requires an annual ridership of under 500 million, according to the TRTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local air accident rate to drop to world average within 3 years: CAS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:10:50 (By Wang Shu-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's air accident rate has been falling in recent years and if the trend continues, will drop to the global average level within three years, an aviation safety official said Tuesday.

Chang Yu-hern, chairman of the Council for Aviation Safety (CAS), told a press conference that there were four aviation accidents in Taiwan this year as the country's 10-year record continues to fall.

From 2000 to 2009, Taiwan registered 1.82 air accidents per million take-offs, higher than the world average of 1.02, he said. "If the current rate can be maintained, by 2013, our record will have dropped to the world average level of 0.61," he added.

Council figures show that prior to 2008, Taiwan's 10-year accident record was above two per million takeoffs. The decade of 1993-2002 saw the highest record of 3.52, followed by 2.82 for 1994-2003, 2.69 for 1998-2007 and 2.26 for 1999-2008.
By 2001-2010, the record had fallen to 1.82, the same as 2000-2009, according to the CAS under the Executive Yuan.
The council said it expects Taiwan's aviation accident rate to continue to fall to 1.21 for 2003-2012 and to 0.61 for 2004-1013, on par with the world average.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature passes special budget to boost public construction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:18:07 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed at a third reading Tuesday a special budget plan for an infrastructure expansion and economic stimulus package worth NT$158.94 billion (US$5.3 billion) for 2011.

After land requisition costs are deducted, the spending plan is expected to fuel the country's gross domestic product (GDP) by 0.88 percent for 2011 and generate more than 50,000 jobs, said Christina Liu, minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Also in the resolution, the legislators pointed out that nearly 50 percent of the public works projects planned under an earlier infrastructure expansion and economic stimulus package worth over NT$170 billion have not been carried out over the past two years.

The legislators therefore demanded that the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan list the execution rate of its special budgets as an index to gauge the performances of ministerial-level officials.

Because of a low execution rate of only 5.23 percent posted by the Construction and Planning Administration for city makeover and industrial zone renewal in 2010, the legislature resolved to freeze 20 percent of the budget for the same project for the new year.

The legislators also warned the Ministry of Education (MOE) about the low execution rate of 34.52 percent in efforts to protect the education opportunities of youths from disadvantaged families in 2010 and they told the MOE to come up with a more detailed plan on those efforts for the new year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 to feature fireworks designed by Chinese artist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:26:01 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest skyscrapers, will feature a 288-second fireworks display designed by renowned Chinese artist Cai Guo-qiang to mark the turn of the new year, the organizer said Tuesday.
Speaking at a press briefing, Cai described the Taipei 101 building as "a huge stage" on which he will feature 15 different types of fireworks.
The 53-year-old said he will "turn the building into a red lantern, a waterfall, a pagoda and a rocket" during the New Year's Eve display.
There will also be a "big flower" on the skyscraper, after which a "golden Chinese dragon" will climb up the building, according to the designer.
"I have tried to include natural and folk custom elements (in my presentation)," he said.
He also revealed that there will be "Chinese characters" appearing in the sky to reflect the common voice of the public, but he declined to elaborate on what the characters will be.
The show will end with "flare bomb" fireworks.
"These bombs, one after another, will turn the night sky into day. When the sky returns to dark again, I hope it will create a sentimental atmosphere," Cai said.
Cai was the chief fireworks designer for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) summit in Shanghai in 2001 and a chief visual effects designer for the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
This year's show will also mark the 100th founding anniversary of the Republic of China, the Taipei Financial Center Corp., owner of the skyscraper, pointed out.
As a result, the fireworks will also show "100" in the sky, the result of one of the world's top fireworks technologies, the organizer said.
Various buildings and 18 schools around Taipei 101 will also set off fireworks simultaneously with those of the skyscraper during the show.
The display cost NT$60 million (US$2 million) and is being sponsored by 10 local companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan uses Taiwanese technology to read damaged GPS chips
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:31:35 (By Wang Shu-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has developed a technology to retrieve information from damaged chips in the global positioning systems (GPS) used by helicopters and other vehicles, which has been provided to Japan, the Council for Aviation Safety (CAS) said Tuesday.

Kuan Wen-lin, CAS laboratory director, briefed the media on the use of the technology, noting that Japan's Transportation Safety Board (JTSB) sought the council's help in September to help determine the cause of a helicopter crash.
The council used the technology to read the information in the Japanese helicopter's GPS and discovered that it was caught in a heavy fog and crashed into a mountain, Kuan said.

Chip makers usually are unable to retrieve information from chips that have been burned, soaked or broken in an accident. Chang's lab, however, uses reverse engineering to "rebuild" the data on the damaged chips.
In cooperation with GPS manufacturers, the lab last year designed a device that can "read" the retrieved data, he noted.
Kuan presented a paper on the lab's research and the new device at an international meeting of aviation accident investigators earlier this year, winning an award for best paper.

The device was first used to help investigate an accident in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, in May last year. In August, 2009, the device was again used to read information from a damaged GPS aboard a helicopter on a rescue mission after a typhoon.

Most helicopters and super-light aircraft are not equipped with the "black boxes" -- flight data recorders -- that are installed on larger aircraft, but instead have GPS, which records flight times, positions, directions and velocities, which can be used to help determine the causes of an accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asustek sees 50% growth in Taiwan's smartphone shipments in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:36:35 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Personal computer vendor Asustek Computer Inc. said Tuesday it expects total smartphone shipments in Taiwan to grow 50 percent next year, with the company launching its first own-brand smartphone following a split with Garmin, the No. 1 U.S. maker of personal navigation devices.

In 2010, smartphones in Taiwan accounted for 30 percent to 40 percent of total mobile phone shipments, lower than the 50 percent in the United States, said Benson Lin, general manager of Asustek's personal mobile devices unit, at a product launch conference for the A50, its new Android-based phone.

Lin said the smartphone penetration rate in Taiwan will surpass that of the U.S. market and grow to 50 percent-60 percent next year, representing an increase of 50 percent in total smartphone shipments.

In October, Asustek, which had been selling smartphones under the Garmin-Asus brand since early 2009, said it would not introduce new co-branded handset models in the future, but the company will keep using Garmin's navigation software on its Android-based smartphones such as the A50 for the next few years.
Lin said he expects shipments of the 3.5-inch A50 to exceed 25,000 units in Taiwan in 2011.
Meanwhile, Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., Taiwan's third-largest telecom operator, forecast a 40 percent growth in smartphone shipments in the local market in 2011.

"Even though more than 50 tablet computers are expected to be launched in the global market next year, prices have not yet decreased to the level of NT$6,000-7,000 (US$203-237) that will be generally accepted by Taiwanese consumers. Therefore, there will still be great demand for smartphones, " Far EasTone President Yvonne Li said at a press conference to introduce new applications in its online software store.
Li also noted that the 2010 total shipments of mobile phones in Taiwan is forecast to reach 7.2 million units, a number that will increase 5 percent to 10 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to revise law to restrict embedded advertising
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:46:11 (By Lee Hsu-hua, Kelvin Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will study law revisions to restrict embedded advertisements disguised as television programs or news reports, according to a consensus reached at a high-level meeting Tuesday.

Participants at the meeting said the Executive Yuan will immediately embark on amending the law so that government agencies will no longer be able to buy news coverage or engage in embedded advertising containing political messages.
The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus has agreed to work toward such legislation.

Until the law is amended, government agencies are required to "practice self- discipline, " according to the participants, who included Liao Liou-yi, Lin Join-sane, and King Pu-tsung, secretaries- general of the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the KMT, respectively, as well as Lin Yi-shih, director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee and Lin Tsang-min, KMT legislative whip.
The spokesmen of the Presidential Office, Government Information Office and KMT -- -Lo Chih-chiang, Johnny Chiang and Su Jun-pin, respectively -- were also present at the meeting.

Meanwhile, the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reached an initial agreement on a proposal that ads publicizing government policies should not appear on news pages in the form of embedded advertisements.
Rather, they should be clearly marked as "advertisements."

The DPP legislative caucus proposed that all government agencies while publicizing their policies should make a distinction between such ads and real news, and that such ads should not appear as embedded advertisement in the form of seminars or special reports.
In addition, they should be clearly marked as policy promotions or advertisements and the name of the government agencies placing the ad should also be clearly shown.

The debate on embedded advertisements has become a hot topic after a former reporter wrote in his blog about the growing trend of the government to buy news coverage and a recent decision by the National Communications Commission to not to renew a licence for a TV channel accused of multiple violations in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negotiations on health care bill break down, showdown looms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:00:46 (By M.H. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Negotiations between lawmakers of the ruling and opposition camps on reforming the national health insurance (NHI) system broke down Tuesday, creating concern that the legislation will not be completed this week and that a showdown will be needed to push the bill through the legislature.

Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) renewed discussions on the disputed bill to bail out the cash-strapped NHI program, but the basic stance of each party made it difficult for them to reach agreement.

The DPP caucus insists on calculating NHI premiums based on household income, while the KMT caucus's modified version proposes collecting premiums based on individual income, as is the case at present, along with additional "supplement premiums" -- premiums to be collected from income on dividends and bonuses.

Criticizing the KMT for holding back from its original plan to adopt a fairer system based on household income rather than the existing individual income, the DPP caucus demanded the Department of Health (DOH) calculate premiums based on household income next week and to publish its calculations.
Ker Chien-ming, the DPP's legislative caucus convener, accused the KMT and the DOH of having failed to hold substantial negotiations on the bill with the DPP.

"The DOH has since last week failed to present us with its calculation results based on household income, " he said, adding that "the DOH's attempts to return to the first-generation NHI format mean that the long-term effort to build a fairer NHI system has come to an end."
Lin Yi-shih, a KMT caucus whip, said the KMT will definitely seek to get the second-generation health insurance bill through the legislature before the current session ends by the end of January.

According to DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang, if the proposed supplement premium could be included under the current NHI system to keep its current financial shortfall of NT$60.4 billion (US$2 billion) from worsening, a regular premium of 6 percent will need to be imposed to keep the system operating for two or three years.

"As the KMT's and the DPP's versions vary widely, it will be almost impossible to have the second-generation national health bill clear the Legislative Yuan in the next legislative meeting slated for Dec. 31," he said.
"A vote showdown will be unavoidable in a Jan. 4 legislative meeting if the two parties are unable to forge a consensus through negotiations by the end of this month," Yaung said.

The bill has failed to pass the Legislative Yuan since early December, with issues related to the premium base, premium scope and the premium rate being the focus of the row. The two parties have each come up with major changes to the bill in a bid to gain greater popular support and have their own version rammed through the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's emissions trading platform set to be completed soon: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:12:12 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first government-recognized carbon emissions trading platform is slowly becoming a reality, the Environment Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday, although it did not give a definite timetable.
EPA Minister Stephen Shen said carbon trading is becoming a global trend, as the international community is seeking various ways to reduce greenhouse gases.
As an industrial country, Taiwan must not be absent from this movement, he said.

Emissions trading is a mechanism to encourage companies or countries to go green by using economic incentives. Also known as "cap and trade," under the scheme, participants are allowed a certain quota of emissions. When a big polluter maxes out on its allotted level, it can purchase the unused quota from another firm.

According to the EPA, the establishment of a domestic carbon trading platform will be divided into three phases but so far, only phase one has been completed, with the next phase estimated to be completed only after December next year.

Phase one includes an online registry through which the buyer and the vendor can find out more information about each other. The second phase will allow the registered companies to bid on allotted quotas.
The third phase will allow participants to buy quotas beforehand if it foresees the need for a bigger allotment in the future, said Shen.

The EPA said the platform will contain information on the emission levels of over 300 domestic factories and plants. It will also be the second platform of its kind to be established in Asia following one in Japan.

Earlier that same day, six car makers, including BMW, Ford, Honda Taiwan, China Motor Corp., Hyundai and Mercedes-Benz signed an agreement with the EPA promising to import low-emission cars for domestic consumers.
The goal of the agreement is to cut the country's carbon dioxide emissions by 10 percent to 15 percent by 2015.
Premier Wu Den-yih recently applauded the country's carbon reduction efforts, saying that overall, Taiwan emitted 5.14 million metric tons of greenhouse gases less than last year.

Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Pact, a binding international agreement under the United Nations to fight climate change, but despite this, the government earlier this year set a goal of cutting back carbon emissions by 84 million metric tons by 2020. It is hoped that in 10 years, the country's emissions will be the same as 2005 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA urged to display history-rich photo archives
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:20:07 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The secretary general of the National Security Council (NSC) expressed amazement Tuesday that a collection of photographs documenting the Second Sino-Japanese War had been so well preserved at the Central News Agency (CNA) and he suggested that the photos be put on display.
Hu Wei-jen praised the agency for the work it has done to preserve news photos dating as far back to 1924.
"These photographs are extremely valuable because they bear witness to history," he said.
Just by browsing through the CNA archives, one can gain deep insight into the harsh times that prevailed during the establishment and development the Republic of China, he said.
"One photo is worth a thousand words," he said.

Hu said he was especially touched to see a picture of his father, the late General Hu Tsung-nan, in full military dress standing next to then President Chiang Kai-shek during the war of resistance against Japanese invasion.
"I don't think even I have these photos," he said.
He encouraged the CNA to collaborate with the Ministry of National Defense, the Government Information Office and other government agencies to hold an exhibition of the historical photos.
The CNA, the national news agency of the ROC, has been in operation since 1924 when it was founded in Guangzhou, China.
It has a wide collection of photographs that document historical events such as the Second Sino-Japanese War, Taiwan Retrocession Day, and the island's Ten Major Construction Projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's MSI launches tablet PC, more planned in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:22:59 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Local hardware manufacturer Micro-Star International Co. (MSI) unveiled its first tablet computer Tuesday amid company plans to launch three to four more similar devices in the first half of 2011.

More than 2,000 units of The WindPad 100W, with a 10.1-inch screen and Windows 7 operating system, has been ordered by a telecom operator in Japan, and the model is slated to be shipped worldwide in January, MSI President Joseph Hsu said at the company's product launch.

"We will begin sales of the WindPad 100W in the Asian market and then introduce it to Europe. In 2011, we will launch three to four more tablet devices, including models that use the Android operating system," Hsu said.

The company's new tablet computers, which are expected to be featured at the annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) next month in the United States, will all be 10.1-inch models, while the launch of smaller-sized devices will depend on consumer demand, according to sources familiar with the company's strategy.

Regarding the Android-based tablet PCs, MSI will not begin mass production of those models until Google Inc. releases the latest version of its operating system -- Android 3.0 -- in March, the sources said.

MSI is listed among the world's top 10 notebook brands in 2010, while the company is also the largest all-in-one PC maker in Taiwan, with a 55.6-percent market share in the third quarter of this year, higher than the 12 percent of the second-place Apple Inc., according to Gartner Inc., an electronics industry and market research firm.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for action against campus bullying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:11:17 (By Lee Shu-hua, Sabine Cheng and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the authorities Tuesday to root out campus bullies and deal with them quickly and decisively, without fear of exposing any "skeletons in the closet."
During a year-end meeting with the media, the president compared campus bullying to corruption in officialdom, which he said must be fearlessly disclosed.

Ma put forth four suggestions regarding the growing incidence of campus bullying: School administrators must take the initiative to identify the bullies; such incidents must be tackled quickly and decisively; suspects must be prosecuted if crimes have been committed; and such incidents must be reported to society.
He particularly advised school authorities "not to delay, hide or cover up" bullying.

The president, a former law scholar and justice minister, said it might not be easy for teachers to decide if criminal acts have been committed in a bullying case, so "they have to increase their legal knowledge and let their charges know."

He cited recent news stories about Bade Junior High School in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, in which students are suspected of detonating firecrackers in a toilet being used by a teacher. There are also reports of students locking up classmates in the washrooms.
Were these actions just mischief, deserving of discipline by the school authorities, or criminal acts? he asked.
Ma said some social norms are simple "courtesy, " some are required under school rules and some are "moral" codes of conduct, while others are better defined under the criminal code.
"Kids need to be taught to tell the differences among these areas," he said.
Outside of the norms of social conduct, he went on, teachers should pay more attention to what is actually happening in the class under their care.

Ma said he was told by Education Minister Wu Ching-ji and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah that a mechanism is in place for schools and the police to work together on campus bullying, although not all schools report such cases to the police.

Yuan Tseh Lee, a former president of Academia Sinica, expressed concern about the development of education in Taiwan in the face of so many reports of campus bullying and controversial acts by university students.

In addition to the series of campus bullying incidents, Lee's worry was also caused by reports that a graduate school student flashed his middle finger at an ambulance while it was trying to provide emergency assistance to a patient in danger.
A former leader of an educational reform task force, Lee said the current system just teaches students to try to get good scores by writing the "correct and standard" answers in exams.
Many things need to be examined, such as moral education, interpersonal relationships, and interaction among family members, he said.
"Education must be reformed continuously," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ranger team established in effort to conserve wetlands
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:18:49 (By Kuo Chi-hsuan and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A team of community rangers was formed Tuesday to help protect wetland areas around the Shueiwaku community, the second ecotourism attraction of its kind near Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan.

The community worked with the park's headquarters to set up a ranger team to investigate and monitor the ecosystem of the two wetlands in the area and to prevent illegal activities there, said Chen Mei-hui, a Pingtung University of Science and Technology associate professor who directed the ecotourism development project.
The wetlands were abundant in frogs some 20 years ago, as well as butterflies and fireflies.
However, the construction of the Erchia Highway in 1979 and later human development caused the water to dry up, leading to a decrease in wildlife.
The park began last May to promote ecotourism in Shueiwaku -- about four kilometers north of Erluanbi -- to restore the wetland ecosystem while helping boost the local economy, Chen said.
It also trained the residents as tour guides and taught them how to conserve the environment.

The community, with a population of 200, is the second successful example of ecotourism in the area after a village between Shedin Park and the Kenting Forest Recreation Area implemented a similar initiative in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: H1N1 might come back, reaching peak in mid-January: doctor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:31:24 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of influenza A(H1N1) infections in Taiwan might reach peak in mid- January as the virus is likely to make a comeback this winter, a pediatrician warned Tuesday.

Using the medical history in Taiwan over the past five years as evidence, Huang Li-min, a pediatrician at National Taiwan University Hospital, said the strains that cause a major flu outbreak in a given area will stay for two consecutive years.

Besides, he forecast, the A(H1N1) onslaught will recur this year since most of the people who contracted the disease or were inoculated against the virus last year will have no antibodies or immunity strong enough to combat a new attack.
This year, few children in Taiwan have acquired immunity against all three major types of flu viruses -- A(H1N1), A/H3 and influenza B.

The cases of A(H1N1) and influenza B infections have been rising over the past week and the two types of viruses are expected to be mainstay of flu infections in the country by the middle of 2011, Huang estimated.
Taiwan was one of the countries hit by the H1N1 flu virus in 2009. More than 800 people in Taiwan were hospitalized with H1N1 symptoms, 35 of whom died.

Meanwhile, according to Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control, 11.33 percent of the people who checked into emergency rooms around Taiwan over the past week were admitted because of flu infections and 1.27 percent of Taiwan's outpatients in the same period were flu patients.
Of these patients, 60 percent were infected with A(H1NI) and 30 percent had influenza B, Shih said.

Taiwan also reported one more influenza death last week, he said. The case was a 62-year-old man from China who had never been inoculated and who came down with flu symptoms after arriving in Taiwan for sightseeing. The man died next day after checking into a local hospital. He tested positive for A(H1N1), according to Shih.
Shih suggested that Taiwanese tourists get themselves inoculated before traveling abroad, as A(H1N1) outbreaks have also been reported in Europe, the United States, Japan and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma challenges DPP head to accept '92 consensus'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei. Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 21:45:38 (By Garfie Lee & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou challenged Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Tuesday to accept the "1992 consensus" between Taiwan and China.

"If the DPP were to become the ruling party one day, I wonder if Tsai would have her DPP administration continue the Kuomintang's existing policy (toward China)," Ma said at a year-end gathering with reporters.
The "1992 consensus" refers to a tacit agreement reached between Taiwan and China in 1992 that "there is only one China, but Taipei and Beijing are free to interpret 'one China' as they see fit."

The term "1992 consensus" was coined in 2000 by then Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi to summarize the tacit agreement, which has been serving as the basis for Taiwan-China negotiations since 2008 when President Ma took office.
The DPP-led opposition camp has refused to accept the 1992 consensus on the grounds that it could result in China's annexation of Taiwan.

Ma said that during a meeting with former President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP in April 2006, he had suggested that the government accept the consensus in order to resume the suspended cross-strait talks.
"After a two-hour discussion, Chen promised to recognize the consensus if China did so first," Ma said

Ma said that in a phone call to former U.S. President George W. Bush on March 26, 2008, Chinese President Hu Jintao indicated a willingness to reopen cross- strait talks on the basis of the "1992 consensus."

Furthermore, Li Yafei, Vice President of the Beijing-based Associations for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , has said that the 1992 consensus refers to "both sides each orally interpreting their own concept of 'one China' principle, " Ma noted.
ARATS and its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, are the semi-official organizations authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges.
"It would be impractical for the DPP to continue to deny the existence of the consensus, " Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei metro annual ridership to top 500 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:04:19 (By Johnson Sun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The annual ridership of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system is expected to top 500 million passengers Wednesday, marking a new page in Taiwan's MRT services since the system's inception in 1996, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) said Tuesday.
