DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 to feature fireworks designed by Chinese artist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:26:01 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taipei 101, one of the world's tallest skyscrapers, will feature a 288-second fireworks display designed by renowned Chinese artist Cai Guo-qiang to mark the turn of the new year, the organizer said Tuesday.
Speaking at a press briefing, Cai described the Taipei 101 building as "a huge stage" on which he will feature 15 different types of fireworks.
The 53-year-old said he will "turn the building into a red lantern, a waterfall, a pagoda and a rocket" during the New Year's Eve display.
There will also be a "big flower" on the skyscraper, after which a "golden Chinese dragon" will climb up the building, according to the designer.
"I have tried to include natural and folk custom elements (in my presentation)," he said.
He also revealed that there will be "Chinese characters" appearing in the sky to reflect the common voice of the public, but he declined to elaborate on what the characters will be.
The show will end with "flare bomb" fireworks.
"These bombs, one after another, will turn the night sky into day. When the sky returns to dark again, I hope it will create a sentimental atmosphere," Cai said.
Cai was the chief fireworks designer for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) summit in Shanghai in 2001 and a chief visual effects designer for the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
This year's show will also mark the 100th founding anniversary of the Republic of China, the Taipei Financial Center Corp., owner of the skyscraper, pointed out.
As a result, the fireworks will also show "100" in the sky, the result of one of the world's top fireworks technologies, the organizer said.
Various buildings and 18 schools around Taipei 101 will also set off fireworks simultaneously with those of the skyscraper during the show.
The display cost NT$60 million (US$2 million) and is being sponsored by 10 local companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan uses Taiwanese technology to read damaged GPS chips
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:31:35 (By Wang Shu-fen and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has developed a technology to retrieve information from damaged chips in the global positioning systems (GPS) used by helicopters and other vehicles, which has been provided to Japan, the Council for Aviation Safety (CAS) said Tuesday.

Kuan Wen-lin, CAS laboratory director, briefed the media on the use of the technology, noting that Japan's Transportation Safety Board (JTSB) sought the council's help in September to help determine the cause of a helicopter crash.
The council used the technology to read the information in the Japanese helicopter's GPS and discovered that it was caught in a heavy fog and crashed into a mountain, Kuan said.

Chip makers usually are unable to retrieve information from chips that have been burned, soaked or broken in an accident. Chang's lab, however, uses reverse engineering to "rebuild" the data on the damaged chips.
In cooperation with GPS manufacturers, the lab last year designed a device that can "read" the retrieved data, he noted.
Kuan presented a paper on the lab's research and the new device at an international meeting of aviation accident investigators earlier this year, winning an award for best paper.

The device was first used to help investigate an accident in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, in May last year. In August, 2009, the device was again used to read information from a damaged GPS aboard a helicopter on a rescue mission after a typhoon.

Most helicopters and super-light aircraft are not equipped with the "black boxes" -- flight data recorders -- that are installed on larger aircraft, but instead have GPS, which records flight times, positions, directions and velocities, which can be used to help determine the causes of an accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asustek sees 50% growth in Taiwan's smartphone shipments in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:36:35 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Personal computer vendor Asustek Computer Inc. said Tuesday it expects total smartphone shipments in Taiwan to grow 50 percent next year, with the company launching its first own-brand smartphone following a split with Garmin, the No. 1 U.S. maker of personal navigation devices.

In 2010, smartphones in Taiwan accounted for 30 percent to 40 percent of total mobile phone shipments, lower than the 50 percent in the United States, said Benson Lin, general manager of Asustek's personal mobile devices unit, at a product launch conference for the A50, its new Android-based phone.

Lin said the smartphone penetration rate in Taiwan will surpass that of the U.S. market and grow to 50 percent-60 percent next year, representing an increase of 50 percent in total smartphone shipments.

In October, Asustek, which had been selling smartphones under the Garmin-Asus brand since early 2009, said it would not introduce new co-branded handset models in the future, but the company will keep using Garmin's navigation software on its Android-based smartphones such as the A50 for the next few years.
Lin said he expects shipments of the 3.5-inch A50 to exceed 25,000 units in Taiwan in 2011.
Meanwhile, Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., Taiwan's third-largest telecom operator, forecast a 40 percent growth in smartphone shipments in the local market in 2011.

"Even though more than 50 tablet computers are expected to be launched in the global market next year, prices have not yet decreased to the level of NT$6,000-7,000 (US$203-237) that will be generally accepted by Taiwanese consumers. Therefore, there will still be great demand for smartphones, " Far EasTone President Yvonne Li said at a press conference to introduce new applications in its online software store.
Li also noted that the 2010 total shipments of mobile phones in Taiwan is forecast to reach 7.2 million units, a number that will increase 5 percent to 10 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to revise law to restrict embedded advertising
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 22:46:11 (By Lee Hsu-hua, Kelvin Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will study law revisions to restrict embedded advertisements disguised as television programs or news reports, according to a consensus reached at a high-level meeting Tuesday.

Participants at the meeting said the Executive Yuan will immediately embark on amending the law so that government agencies will no longer be able to buy news coverage or engage in embedded advertising containing political messages.
The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus has agreed to work toward such legislation.

Until the law is amended, government agencies are required to "practice self- discipline, " according to the participants, who included Liao Liou-yi, Lin Join-sane, and King Pu-tsung, secretaries- general of the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the KMT, respectively, as well as Lin Yi-shih, director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee and Lin Tsang-min, KMT legislative whip.
The spokesmen of the Presidential Office, Government Information Office and KMT -- -Lo Chih-chiang, Johnny Chiang and Su Jun-pin, respectively -- were also present at the meeting.

Meanwhile, the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reached an initial agreement on a proposal that ads publicizing government policies should not appear on news pages in the form of embedded advertisements.
Rather, they should be clearly marked as "advertisements."

The DPP legislative caucus proposed that all government agencies while publicizing their policies should make a distinction between such ads and real news, and that such ads should not appear as embedded advertisement in the form of seminars or special reports.
In addition, they should be clearly marked as policy promotions or advertisements and the name of the government agencies placing the ad should also be clearly shown.

The debate on embedded advertisements has become a hot topic after a former reporter wrote in his blog about the growing trend of the government to buy news coverage and a recent decision by the National Communications Commission to not to renew a licence for a TV channel accused of multiple violations in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negotiations on health care bill break down, showdown looms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:00:46 (By M.H. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Negotiations between lawmakers of the ruling and opposition camps on reforming the national health insurance (NHI) system broke down Tuesday, creating concern that the legislation will not be completed this week and that a showdown will be needed to push the bill through the legislature.

Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) renewed discussions on the disputed bill to bail out the cash-strapped NHI program, but the basic stance of each party made it difficult for them to reach agreement.

The DPP caucus insists on calculating NHI premiums based on household income, while the KMT caucus's modified version proposes collecting premiums based on individual income, as is the case at present, along with additional "supplement premiums" -- premiums to be collected from income on dividends and bonuses.

Criticizing the KMT for holding back from its original plan to adopt a fairer system based on household income rather than the existing individual income, the DPP caucus demanded the Department of Health (DOH) calculate premiums based on household income next week and to publish its calculations.
Ker Chien-ming, the DPP's legislative caucus convener, accused the KMT and the DOH of having failed to hold substantial negotiations on the bill with the DPP.

"The DOH has since last week failed to present us with its calculation results based on household income, " he said, adding that "the DOH's attempts to return to the first-generation NHI format mean that the long-term effort to build a fairer NHI system has come to an end."
Lin Yi-shih, a KMT caucus whip, said the KMT will definitely seek to get the second-generation health insurance bill through the legislature before the current session ends by the end of January.

According to DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang, if the proposed supplement premium could be included under the current NHI system to keep its current financial shortfall of NT$60.4 billion (US$2 billion) from worsening, a regular premium of 6 percent will need to be imposed to keep the system operating for two or three years.

"As the KMT's and the DPP's versions vary widely, it will be almost impossible to have the second-generation national health bill clear the Legislative Yuan in the next legislative meeting slated for Dec. 31," he said.
"A vote showdown will be unavoidable in a Jan. 4 legislative meeting if the two parties are unable to forge a consensus through negotiations by the end of this month," Yaung said.

The bill has failed to pass the Legislative Yuan since early December, with issues related to the premium base, premium scope and the premium rate being the focus of the row. The two parties have each come up with major changes to the bill in a bid to gain greater popular support and have their own version rammed through the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's emissions trading platform set to be completed soon: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:12:12 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first government-recognized carbon emissions trading platform is slowly becoming a reality, the Environment Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday, although it did not give a definite timetable.
EPA Minister Stephen Shen said carbon trading is becoming a global trend, as the international community is seeking various ways to reduce greenhouse gases.
As an industrial country, Taiwan must not be absent from this movement, he said.

Emissions trading is a mechanism to encourage companies or countries to go green by using economic incentives. Also known as "cap and trade," under the scheme, participants are allowed a certain quota of emissions. When a big polluter maxes out on its allotted level, it can purchase the unused quota from another firm.

According to the EPA, the establishment of a domestic carbon trading platform will be divided into three phases but so far, only phase one has been completed, with the next phase estimated to be completed only after December next year.

Phase one includes an online registry through which the buyer and the vendor can find out more information about each other. The second phase will allow the registered companies to bid on allotted quotas.
The third phase will allow participants to buy quotas beforehand if it foresees the need for a bigger allotment in the future, said Shen.

The EPA said the platform will contain information on the emission levels of over 300 domestic factories and plants. It will also be the second platform of its kind to be established in Asia following one in Japan.

Earlier that same day, six car makers, including BMW, Ford, Honda Taiwan, China Motor Corp., Hyundai and Mercedes-Benz signed an agreement with the EPA promising to import low-emission cars for domestic consumers.
The goal of the agreement is to cut the country's carbon dioxide emissions by 10 percent to 15 percent by 2015.
Premier Wu Den-yih recently applauded the country's carbon reduction efforts, saying that overall, Taiwan emitted 5.14 million metric tons of greenhouse gases less than last year.

Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Pact, a binding international agreement under the United Nations to fight climate change, but despite this, the government earlier this year set a goal of cutting back carbon emissions by 84 million metric tons by 2020. It is hoped that in 10 years, the country's emissions will be the same as 2005 levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA urged to display history-rich photo archives
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:20:07 (By Nancy Liu)

TEXT.P: The secretary general of the National Security Council (NSC) expressed amazement Tuesday that a collection of photographs documenting the Second Sino-Japanese War had been so well preserved at the Central News Agency (CNA) and he suggested that the photos be put on display.
Hu Wei-jen praised the agency for the work it has done to preserve news photos dating as far back to 1924.
"These photographs are extremely valuable because they bear witness to history," he said.
Just by browsing through the CNA archives, one can gain deep insight into the harsh times that prevailed during the establishment and development the Republic of China, he said.
"One photo is worth a thousand words," he said.

Hu said he was especially touched to see a picture of his father, the late General Hu Tsung-nan, in full military dress standing next to then President Chiang Kai-shek during the war of resistance against Japanese invasion.
"I don't think even I have these photos," he said.
He encouraged the CNA to collaborate with the Ministry of National Defense, the Government Information Office and other government agencies to hold an exhibition of the historical photos.
The CNA, the national news agency of the ROC, has been in operation since 1924 when it was founded in Guangzhou, China.
It has a wide collection of photographs that document historical events such as the Second Sino-Japanese War, Taiwan Retrocession Day, and the island's Ten Major Construction Projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's MSI launches tablet PC, more planned in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/10 23:22:59 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: Local hardware manufacturer Micro-Star International Co. (MSI) unveiled its first tablet computer Tuesday amid company plans to launch three to four more similar devices in the first half of 2011.

More than 2,000 units of The WindPad 100W, with a 10.1-inch screen and Windows 7 operating system, has been ordered by a telecom operator in Japan, and the model is slated to be shipped worldwide in January, MSI President Joseph Hsu said at the company's product launch.

"We will begin sales of the WindPad 100W in the Asian market and then introduce it to Europe. In 2011, we will launch three to four more tablet devices, including models that use the Android operating system," Hsu said.

The company's new tablet computers, which are expected to be featured at the annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) next month in the United States, will all be 10.1-inch models, while the launch of smaller-sized devices will depend on consumer demand, according to sources familiar with the company's strategy.

Regarding the Android-based tablet PCs, MSI will not begin mass production of those models until Google Inc. releases the latest version of its operating system -- Android 3.0 -- in March, the sources said.

MSI is listed among the world's top 10 notebook brands in 2010, while the company is also the largest all-in-one PC maker in Taiwan, with a 55.6-percent market share in the third quarter of this year, higher than the 12 percent of the second-place Apple Inc., according to Gartner Inc., an electronics industry and market research firm.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 29, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 09:51:17 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened modestly higher Wednesday from its previous close, moving up 7.34 points at 8,878.10 on a turnover of NT$2.538 billion (US$84.6 million).
The weighted price index fell 21.55 points, or 0.24 percent, to close at 8,870.76 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 10:18:46 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$29.44 at 10 a.m. Wednesday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.956 from Tuesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: People's humble wish

TEXT.P: "Living in peace and enjoying one's work" has been the most fundamental wish of people since ancient times. If this standard is used to examine the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration, then it clearly still has much room for improvement.
People in Taiwan cannot live comfortably because their salaries have long remained stagnant while housing prices have continued to rise.

Although the number of self-owned housing units as a percentage of total households is nearly 90 percent in Taiwan, the ratio is inflated because many owners possess more than one home. This may be attributed partly to speculative purchasing, a situation fueled by excess liquidity, low interest rates, the slow adjustment of the publicly announced land value, and the fact that actual market value is not used to calculate land value increment taxes.

People cannot find stability on the job either. Although Taiwan's unemployment rate has dropped to below 5 percent, the number of workers in unstable jobs, such as part-timers, temporary workers and contract workers, has hit a record high of 723,000. Furthermore, 3.6 million employees, or 4.5 percent of the workforce, earn less than NT$30,000 a month, indicating decreased quality of employment.

We earnestly hope that the government can present effective measures to solve the problems. Otherwise, this will become a serious issue in the 2012 presidential election. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Learn a lesson from municipal upgrades
DOC.DATELINE: 12/29/10 11:30:32 (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 29, 2010) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: According to media reports, the Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung city governments experienced a chaotic day on Monday, the first work day following their upgrades to special municipalities through city-county mergers. The situation in Xinbei City was much better because its upgrade did not involve a merger with another administrative region.

The chaos highlights the lack of proper planning beforehand. In fact, bills aimed at adjusting revenue allocation and the debt ceilings of local governments still had not cleared the legislature when the new special municipalities began operations Dec. 25.

This inevitably leads to worries over the prospects for the central government's restructuring project, set to be implemented in 2012, in which the number of second-level agencies will be reduced from 37 to 29 and third-level agencies from 279 to 70.
It is almost certain that the Legislative Yuan will not finish handling all of the 147 bills related to the restructuring within the coming year.

We hereby remind the administrative branch to recognize the unrealistic nature of the goal and make preparations early. If the project is launched in haste in 2012, the situation will be even more chaotic than what has happened to the new special municipalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD chief urges enterprises to raise wages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 12:09:04 (By Lin Hui-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Christina Liu, minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, has urged enterprises operating in Taiwan to raise wages to match a strong rebound in the local economy.

Liu said Tuesday that Taiwan is witnessing a significant increase in private investment this year, boosting local employment, and she believed that the improving job market was paving the path for an increase in wages.

According to Liu, private investment in Taiwan is expected to grow 31.91 percent in 2010 from a year earlier, the highest growth rate among the four Asian tigers -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea.
The island's jobless rate fell to 4.73 percent in November on an improvement in the local business environment, largely due to the lowest level of corporate downsizings and closures in two years.
In October, the local unemployment rate fell below 5 percent for the first time since November 2008, down from a high of 6.13 percent in August 2009 following the global financial meltdown.
Based on these favorable economic factors, "we think it possible for enterprises to raise wages next year," Liu said.

A recent local survey showed that almost 80 percent of local companies said they were planning to raise their employees' salaries next year, by an average of 3.9 percent, but the survey also found that 64 percent of employees polled remained cautious about the pledge.
Liu said an increase in wages for next year has become a trend, and she hoped employers would take notice of it.

In October, Taiwan's regular salary rose 1.62 percent from a year earlier to a monthly average of NT$36,480 (US$1,220) , the 12th consecutive increase, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
In November, the government raised its forecast for 2010 gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 9.98 percent from a previous estimate of 8.24 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares of Yulon Group units higher on market share gain
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 15:22:19 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Shares of three major units of automaker Yulon Group outperformed the broader market in Wednesday trading on a report that the group had overtaken Hotai Motor as the largest car vendor in Taiwan during the first three weeks of December.

Yulon Motor closed up 2.23 percent to NT$59.70, Yulon Nissan Motor gained 1.48 percent to NT$137.50 and China Motor added 1.03 percent to NT$29.30, while the benchmark weighted index closed down 0.04 percent at 8,866.35.

The Economic Daily News reported Wednesday that Yulon Group, including its upscale Luxgen brand, sold 7,851 units from Dec. 1 to Dec. 23, or a 31.6 percent share of the local car market during that period.
According to the report, Yulon's sales sent it past perennial market leader Hotai Motor, which sold 6,029 vehicles for a 27.8 percent market share.
"It is the first time Yulon has taken first place in the local auto market," MasterLink Securities analyst Tom Tang said. "Investors are excited about it."
Hotai Motor is the Taiwanese distributor of Japanese car maker Toyota Motor Corp.

Tang attributed Yulon's larger market share largely to sales of the popular upscale Luxgen multi-purpose vehicle (MPV) and sports utility vehicle (SUV) models at a time when the local economy is staging a strong rebound.
Luxgen models are produced by Luxgen Motor Co. Ltd., a wholly owned unit of Yulon Motor. Luxgen Motor, founded in June 2008, first launched its MPV models in Taiwan in September 2009.
Market observers said sales of Luxgen models in Taiwan are expected to exceed 10,000 units in 2010 and reach 16,000 units in 2011.
In addition to the higher sales in the domestic market, Tang said, investors have high hopes that the Luxgen brand will generate significant revenues for Yulon Group in the huge China market.
Yulon Motor and China-based Dongfeng Yulon Motor Co. have set up a joint venture in Hangzhou in Zhejiang Province to produce Luxgen models for the China market.
"China's annual auto sales are about 20 million units, compared with Taiwan's 300,000 units. Only a small slice of the Chinese market would be significant to Yulon," Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry of Environment and Resources A Milestone in Building Sustainable Homeland

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has passed the revised Organic Act of the Executive Yuan in third reading. Starting on January 1, 2012 the number of Cabinet-level agencies will be reduced from 37 to 27, including 14 ministries, 8 commissions, 3 independent agencies, the Central Bank, the National Palace Museum, and two newly added general offices. The Ministry of Environment and Resources will be a newly established ministry.

Director Jun-hong Yeh of the EPA Department of Comprehensive Planning said in an interview that Taiwan's environmental quality has been significantly improved and upgraded under the joint efforts of all people since the EPA was established in 1987.

Yeh pointed out that in response to the new challenge of climate changes caused by global warming and in line with the international trend of environmental protection, the establishment of the Ministry of Environment and Resources is both the realization of President Ma Ying-jeou's policy on environment and an important milestone in safeguarding Taiwan's quality environment.

At present environmental protection, water resources, mining industry, geology, national parks, forest conservation, meteorology, soil and water conservation, and ecological conservation are under the jurisdiction of different ministries and commissions. Establishing the Ministry of Environment and Resources will put the management and protection of water, soil, forest and air resources under its jurisdiction, and strengthen the protection of environmental resources and maintain the balance of ecological environment through environmental planning and management, noted Yeh.

To be prudent, the EPA has repeatedly revised the drafted structure of the Ministry of Environment and Resources and the latest proposal is for the new ministry to govern seven departments: comprehensive planning, climate changes, atmospheric environment, water and river valley, resource regeneration, pollution control, and disaster prevention and ecology.

In addition, the new ministry will have 10 third-level agencies: Bureau of Pollution Prevention and Sewerage, Weather Bureau, Water Resources Agency, Water and Soil Conservation and Geology and Mineral Resources Agency, Forest and Conservation Agency, Environmental Education and Training Institute, Forest and Natural Resources Research Institute, Institute of Biodiversity, and Taiwan Water Corporation.

Yeh said the EPA has a staff of more than 800 at present and the Ministry of Environment and Resources is expected to have a staff of over 14,000 because of increased responsibilities. He expressed the hope that the new ministry will maximize the effectiveness of resources development and environmental protection with unified powers. Contacts:Environmental Protection Administration, Taiwan

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait negotiating channel will not be replaced: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 15:52:26 (By Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reassured a group of foreign diplomats in Taipei Wednesday that a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait committee will only serve as a negotiation tool and will not replace the existing communication channels authorized by both governments.

Speaking at a briefing set up by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on the sixth round of cross-strait talks held earlier this month, MAC Deputy Chairman Chao Chien-min said the proposed Cross-Strait Economic Cooperation Committee (ECC) will be responsible for consultations on issues following the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) signed in June.

The effect of the ECC was one of the questions asked by the group of 41 representatives from 36 countries, who were wondering if the committee will override the existing authorized channels -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- as claimed by Taiwan's opposition parties.

"The SEF is here to stay, " said Chao, pointing out while there will be some overlapping functions, the joint committee is only a consultation tool and has no right to sign any agreements on behalf of either government.

During the most recent round of talks, Taiwan and China also signed a health cooperation agreement and agreed to open Taiwan further to Chinese tourists. Moreover, both sides agreed that the long-stalled issue of cross-strait investment protection will be the main issue in the next round of talks.

Chao said that unlike the ECFA, the investment protection pact will not be submitted to the World Trade Organization for reference because it does not pertain to trade, although it will follow international standards.

On tourism, both sides earlier this month shook hands on a deal to increase the daily cap of Chinese tourists from 3,000 to 4,000 and starting next year, a small number of qualified Chinese tourists will be allowed to travel to Taiwan individually without being confined to tour groups.

Answering a question on the effect of Taiwan's national security in relation to the health agreement, Chao said the pact will only provide further protection for Taiwan patients and consumers' right to health without affecting the country's overall security.
The sixth round of cross-strait talks were held in Taipei in late December, headed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin.

The series of meetings, which started in November 2008, is interpreted as an indication of cross-strait rapprochement since 2008, when President Ma Ying-jeou took office. Over 14 agreements ranging from non-political topics such as postal services, joint efforts to combat crime, and direct flights have been forged.
MOFA holds a briefing for the diplomatic corps the week following each cross- strait meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to help machine tool sector meet duty-free challenge
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 16:14:07 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government will invite Japanese and German manufacturers of sophisticated machine tools and components to invest in Taiwan and ensure that the machine tools' controllers are made locally, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Tuesday.

The origin of the controllers, which link a computer system and the mechanical components of a CNC (computer numerical control) machine, will decide whether exports of computer-controlled machine tools from Taiwan remain eligible for duty-free entry into China in three to five years.

Seven categories of sophisticated machine tools with CNC functions are set to be given duty-free treatment by China under the early harvest program of the Taiwan-China Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), set to be launched on Jan. 1.

But that status will change in a few years unless the machine tools' controllers, 60 percent of which are currently imported from Germany or Japan, are made in Taiwan, according to Duh Tyzz-jiun, head of the ministry's Industrial Development Bureau.

Under the agreement, makers of CNC cutting, stamping and grinding machines will have a three-year grace period, after which all of the controllers used in products exported to China will have to be made in Taiwan to retain the products' zero-tariff status, Duh said.
For CNC lathes, the adaptation period will be five years, he added.

At the same time, at least 50 percent of the machine tools' value-added will also have to originate in Taiwan to retain duty-free eligibility, but that threshold is already being met and should not pose any problems to local machine tool manufacturers, the MOEA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares close little changed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 16:24:47 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed little changed Wednesday as rotational buying in the financial sector offset the losses suffered by bellwether electronic stocks, which have been pressured by a rising New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
The weighted index fell 4.41 points or 0.04 percent to 8,866.35, after moving between 8,844.67 and 8,893.14, on turnover of NT$145.09 billion (US$4.90 billion).
The market opened up 0.08 percent and moved to the day's high before selling in the high-tech sector set in to weigh on the movement, the dealers said.

However, interest in the financial sector emerged during the trading session, helping the broader market fend off the gloomy mood about the harm done by a stronger local currency to Taiwan's global competitiveness, they said.
A total of 2,914 stocks closed down, while 1,453 finished up and 298 remained unchanged.

The machinery and electronics sector posted the steepest decline, ending down 1.1 percent. Plastics and chemicals fell 0.4 percent, and cement and textile shares lost 0.3 percent, while the paper and pulp, and construction sectors closed unchanged.
The financial sector rose 3.6 percent and the foodstuff sector added 0.5 percent.

"Investors were upbeat about increasing financial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, in particular after five major local banks officially opened branches in China, " Hua Nan Securities analyst Henry Miao said.

Right after securing approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) , the branches of First Commercial Bank, Cathay United Bank, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, Taiwan Cooperative Bank and Land Bank of Taiwan started operations last week and this week.
Miao said that following recent consolidation, financial stocks have appeared attractive in terms of valuations.
"Amid adequate liquidity, the financial sector has become a safe haven for many investors needing a place to park their funds, " Miao said.
"Due to the strong interest in the sector, the broader market appeared resilient despite the high-tech losses," he added.
Miao said that with many foreign institutional investors remaining sidelined for the New Year holiday, the local market is expected to move in a narrow range until the end of this year.
Among the financial stocks, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank rose 6.93 percent to close at NT$24.45 and First Financial, which owns First Commercial Bank, gained 6.83 percent to end at NT$26.60.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenage violinist to perform with National Symphony Orchestra
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 16:34:03 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: A sixteen-year-old Taiwanese violinist, Tseng Yu-chien, will perform with the National Symphony Orchestra (NSO) in two concerts in Taipei on Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, the organizers said Wednesday.
Tseng is a student of the Curtis Institute of Music in the United States, where he studies under the versatile musician Ida Kavafian.

The young violinist was the winner of the 10th Pablo Sarasate International Violin Competition in 2009 and took third prize in the junior section of the Yehudi Menuhin International Violin Competition in 2006. He also played a major role in a locally produced movie in August.
At a press conference Wednesday, Tseng said he was very excited about the two concerts because he would be performing under the baton of NSO resident maestro Lu Shao-chia for the first time.
He said the presentation of Ravel's Tzigane, Rapsodie de Concert, for Violin and Orchestra is sure to uplift audiences on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day.
His biggest dream is to become a great soloist, he said, adding that he will continue to take on the challenge of international competitions.

At the two upcoming concerts, which will be held at National Concert Hall, the Vienna State Opera Concert Society and the Taipei Philharmonic Chorus will present Bizet's Carmen Suite (3 pieces) ; Ravel's Tzigane, Rapsodie de Concert, for Violin and Orchestra; Rimsky-Korsakov's Capriccio Espagnol, Op. 34; and Orff's Carmina Burana.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sale of three Morgan Stanley funds in Taiwan approved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 17:31:51 (By Pan Chi-i and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The applications for the sale of three Morgan Stanley investment funds in Taiwan have been approved by the Financial Supervisory Commission, Cathay Securities Investment Consulting said Wednesday,
Cathay serves as the master agent for the three funds and is gearing up for their launch in the domestic market soon.
The three newly approved investment funds are Morgan Stanley Global Brands Fund, Morgan Stanley Emerging Markets Debt Fund and Morgan Stanley Asian Equity Fund, according to the master agent.

The Global Brands Fund, which is currently valued at US$2.2 billion (NT$66 billion), focuses on investments in equity securities of those companies in developed countries which have earned a reputation in brands, copyrights, or other intangible assets, Cathay said.
Cathay said the Global Brands Fund pursues long term returns valued in U.S. dollars.

As for the Morgan Stanley Emerging Markets Debt Fund, which is currently valued at US$407 million, government bonds issued by emerging countries account for 70 percent of its total porfolio, while bonds issued by state-owned companies and private companies makes up the rest, Cathay said.

Since the fund is valued in U.S. dollars, investors are expected to avoid possible foreign exchange risks resulting from volatile fluctuations of local currencies in the emerging economies, the master agent said.
In addition, because the fund is denominated in U.S. dollars, it has been liquid, which means that investors are faced with fewer risks, Cathay said.
The Morgan Stanley Asian Equity Fund, which is currently valued at US$580 million, holds large equities issued in China, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Indonesia, according to Cathay.
The five markets account for 90 percent of the fund's portfolio, with China in the lead with 33 percent, Cathay said.
The master agent said the fund is raising investments in Indonesia -- a country that is emerging as a promising market behind China, Brazil, Russia and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: All-volunteer military system to be launched in 2015: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 17:39:15 (By Kelven Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will introduce an all-volunteer military system in 2015, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Wednesday.

To pave the way for the new system, the MND will begin a policy assessment process Jan. 1 that will be completed by the end of 2014, said Chao Ke-ta, head of the ministry's Department of Manpower, during a hearing held by the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

Asked whether a planned exchange of visits between China's People's Liberation Army and U.S. military officials in January will affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Vice Defense Minister Andrew Yang said the ministry is "cautiously optimistic" about the sales and believes they will not be affected.
According to Yang, high-ranking U.S. officials have on many occasions told Beijing that the issue of arms sales to Taiwan does not fall within the scope of U.S.-China exchanges.
Washington will consider whether to sell certain weapons to Taiwan based on the defense needs of Taiwan and the West Pacific, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes lower but rebounds from NT$29.375
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 17:55:31 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the New Taiwan dollar Wednesday, dropping NT$0.029 to close at NT$30.367 after rebounding from a low of NT$29.375 upon intervention by the central bank to protect the country's exporters.
Turnover totaled US$875 million during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$30.426 and moved between NT$29.375 and NT$30.430 before the close.
Selling in the U.S. dollar by exporters was on the rise amid increasing demand for the local currency as they moved to close their books for 2010 with the approach of the year's end, dealers said.

While local media reported that day that the central bank had launched a probe into possible speculation by foreign banks that has shorted the U.S. dollar, selling in the greenback continued as soon as the market opened, the dealers said.
Investors remained upbeat about further appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar as foreign institutional investors kept moving funds into the local bourse, they added.

The market is expecting the central bank to raise its key interest rates in a quarterly policy making meeting scheduled for Thursday, the dealers said, adding that higher local interest rates are expected to lure more funds to the country.
In late trade, the central bank stepped in again to boost the value of the U.S. dollar to above NT$30, a level the market believes is the central bank's bottom line in the short term, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA unveils national plan for low-carbon environment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 18:12:29 (By Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday it has come up with a national plan to create a low-carbon environment to fight global warming.
The plan includes using clean energy, building a low-carbon economy and designing eco-friendly homes, the EPA said.

In 2011, every city or county will complete two model green communities, and the number of such communities will be increased gradually, said Lu Hung-kuang, executive secretary of the eco community project.
The EPA proposes to expand the low-carbon plan eventually throughout the entire country, in three stages, between 2011 and 2020, he said.
Development of a low-carbon environment involves changes in areas such as energy conservation, architecture, transportation and environmental protection, which is a challenging undertaking, Lu said.
Taiwan has set a goal of reducing its carbon emissions to the 2005 level by 2020 and to the 2000 level by 2025.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office continues to question Tsai's China policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 18:19:36 (By Garfie Lee)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office asked Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen Wednesday to clarify whether she supports the concept of Taiwan independence.

In the latest clash of words between the Presidential Office and the DPP over Tsai's China policy, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih- chiang said Tsai should tell the public what kind of formula she plans to use as a substitute for the "1992 consensus" in developing relations between Taiwan and China.
On Tuesday, President Ma Ying-jeou challenged Tsai to accept the "1992 consensus", a tacit agreement between Taipei and Beijing that has been serving as the basis for warming cross-strait ties.
Under the consensus, both sides agree that "there is but one China" but are free to interpret "one China" as they see fit.
The DPP-led "pan green" camp has refused to accept the consensus on the grounds that it could lead to China's annexation of Taiwan.

In response to Ma's comment, the DPP hit back late Tuesday night, saying that the three key persons involved in the 1992 cross-strait talks -- former President Lee Teng-hui and Taiwan's top two cross-strait negotiators the late Koo Chen-fu and his deputy Shi Hwei-yow -- had all denied the existence of such a consensus.

On Wednesday, the Presidential Office picked up the ball again, saying Tsai's statement that if the DPP returned to power it would retain President Ma's China policy was contradictory because she had often accused the government of leaning towards China.
"Tsai should tell us if she would keep in force the cross-strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement if the DPP returns to power," Lo said.

The DPP, which has been an advocate of Taiwan independence, is set to revise its anti-China stance by setting up a think tank to map out ways to engage Beijing, in what is said to be an attempt to increase the party's chances of winning the 2012 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai Group's revenue up 60 percent in 2010: chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 18:35:58 (By Jeffrey Wu)

TEXT.P: The Hon Hai Group, the world's largest electronics contract manufacturer, will post better than expected revenue growth this year but is likely to grow at a slower rate in the future, the group's chairman said Wednesday.

The group's consolidated revenue is expected to grow 60 percent this year to nearly NT$3 trillion (US$102 billion) in 2010, with the group's core company, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., accounting for more than NT$2 billion of that, Hon Hai Chairman Terry Gou said at a seminar on Wednesday.

Gou acknowledged, however, that his longstanding goal of 30 percent annual revenue growth would be "very hard to achieve" next year because of strong sales in 2010, and he said an annual growth target of 15 percent was more realistic in the future.

"We would rather think optimistically but forecast conservatively and be responsible to our shareholders instead of misleading them with exaggerated numbers, even though it may hurt our share price, " he said.

Asked what he thought of the overall prospects for the coming year, Gou said companies should not worry about the general economic outlook but rather focus on improving their competitiveness, which is a key to success in any kind of unfriendly environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Land Bank expects Shanghai branch to make profit in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 18:50:11 (By Lawrence Chiu and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Land Bank of Taiwan Chairman Wang Yao-shing said in Shanghai Wednesday that he expects the bank's Shanghai branch to make profit in 2011, riding the wave of China's fast-growing economy.
In an inauguration ceremony for the Shanghai branch, Wang said that once it starts making a profit, the bank is expected to open more branches in other Chinese cities, starting from 2012.
Wang said that as Shanghai is an international financial hub that has attracted a great number of Taiwanese investors who have relocated to the city, the bank is very excited to have a branch there.

He noted that prior to opening the branch, the bank had operated a representative office in the city for eight years, and he said the expanded presence is expected to provide a wider range of financial services to Taiwanese companies operating in China.
Meanwhile, the bank is planning to seek further business cooperation with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) , one of the leading lenders in China.
Wang said that as far back as Land Bank's establishment of its Shanghai representative office, the Taiwanese bank and ICBC have built up a good relationship in financial service cooperation.
Among the Chinese guests at the opening ceremony, ICBC Shanghai branch President Shen Liqiang said ICBC is also willing to forge even closer business ties with the Land Bank.
In Shanghai alone, ICBC has 501 outlets and employs 13,000 people, with a base of 350,000 corporate customers and 15 million retail clients, according to Shen.
Shen said he believes Land Bank and ICBC will build a good model on business cooperation for the financial sectors on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He also said ICBC is planning to set up a foothold in Taiwan and will send a delegation to survey the country's financial market in April or May.

DOC.HEADLINE: ERA TV's entertainment channel to be axed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 19:13:59 (By Huang Hui-min and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) went ahead Wednesday with a decision to force ERA TV's entertainment channel to cease broadcasting at midnight Dec. 30, despite a protest by the channel and a call from lawmakers to put the decision on hold.

The independent NCC announced that from that time onward, channel 45, which at present is allotted to ERA TV, will carry the signals of Star TV's entertainment channel in northern Taiwan and Top TV's entertainment programs in the south.

The Taipei High Administrative Court has begun to set up a procedure to hear ERA TV's complaint about the closure order, a process that might take a while. Any ruling it hands down can be appealed at the Supreme Administrative Court.

ERA TV took out a front-page newspaper advertisement Wednesday in which it accused the NCC of backpedaling on the country's democratic progress by "revoking its operating license and shuttering its entertainment channel, seriously damaging freedom of expression."

However, the NCC pointed out that the decision was made based on the fact that ERA TV has repeatedly violated the Satellite Broadcasting Act and that the decision "has nothing to do with freedom of expression."

NCC spokesman Chen Cheng-tsang said that TV broadcasters are reviewed every two years and that NCC records show that since 2004, ERA TV has been warned of the possible consequences of its continued and repeated violations of the Satellite Broadcasting Act.
In February this year, when ERA TV requested a renewal of its license, the NCC gave it a one-year grace period, on the condition that it must not break the law again, Chen said.
However, within one month, ERA broke its promise not once but several times, leading to the NCC decision not to renew its license, according to the spokesman.

Ho Chi-sen, a NCC department director, produced evidence of ERA TV's lawbreaking. Ho showed a video recording of an ERA program in which the host and the guest touted a commercial product, an act of advertising rather than giving the audience real information.
Some of the channel's embedded advertising went as far as exaggerating the medical effects of various so-called "health products," in violation of medical and health products laws, Ho said.

According to Ho, an absolute majority of the members of the public who called to comment on the matter took the side of the NCC, with some of them saying the NCC should have punished the law-breaking broadcasters much sooner.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEOs predict slowdown in Taiwan's opening to China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 19:55:22 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the chief executive officers (CEOs) in Taiwan's manufacturing, service and financial sectors think the pace of Taiwan's deregulation in cross- strait exchanges will slow down, according to a poll released Wednesday.
Some 47 percent of the CEOs said the slowdown will be one of the effects of the recent municipality elections on cross-strait relations, the survey by Taiwan's CommonWealth Magazine showed.

In the Nov. 27 elections, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took two of the five municipality mayoral seats but garnered 5 percent more of the popular vote than the ruling Kuomintang, which won three seats. The five municipalities account for 60 percent of Taiwan's population.

In the public opinion poll that asked CEOs about the possible effects of the elections on cross-strait relations, 28.11 percent said they did not think there would be any impact, 24.25 percent forecast that the KMT government would step up the pace of opening toward China, and 47 percent said the pace of liberalization would slow down.

Taiwan-China relations have greatly improved since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008. The two sides signed a landmark Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) in June this year to pave the way for a range of tariff reductions and eliminations from the start of 2011.
On the question of the effects of the ECFA on their companies, 4.05 percent of the executives said their businesses had already benefited from the pact.
Another 60.98 percent said the trade pact had not yet affected their companies in any way but they believed it would bring their businesses benefits in the future.
The majority of CEOs, 72.16 percent, said that what they wanted most from pacts between Taiwan and China was an investment protection agreement.
Taiwan and China are working to sign such an agreement in the next round of trade talks, according to the main negotiators on both sides.
In the poll, the CEOs said what is needed most to improve the business climate in China is "clean and transparent government" there.
The poll was conducted Nov. 29-Dec. 17 and collected 470 valid questionnaires.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau reports record low number of typhoons in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 20:08:50 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Only 14 typhoons formed in the northwestern Pacific Ocean in 2010, the lowest number since the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) began keeping typhoon records in 1958, a meteorologist said Wednesday.
"The figure shattered all previous records, including the record low of 17 in 1998, " said Lin Hsiu-wen, deputy director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center.
Despite the small number of typhoons this year, five of them posed threats to Taiwan's land and sea areas, which prompted the weather bureau to issue storm warnings, Lin said.
"The number of storm warnings this year was higher than in 1993, 1999 and 2002, when the bureau issued three typhoon alerts for each of those three years," Lin said.
Last year, when 22 typhoons were reported in the Pacific area, the CWB issued four storm warnings for Taiwan, Lin noted.
Based on the figure of 22 typhoons in the northwestern Pacific Ocean in both 2009 and 2008, the CWB predicted in June that the number this year would be 20 to 23.
"Although we forecast that there would be fewer typhoons this year, but we did not expect the number to be so low," Lin said.
The meteorologist attributed the low number mainly to stronger high-pressure systems caused in part by global warming.
"Strong high-pressure systems led to strong eastward winds and larger wind shears, which together prevented the formation of many typhoons in tropical areas," Lin said.
However, "this might not necessarily recur," Lin added.

Based on meteorological data for the past 30 years, Lin said, there should be an average of 26.6 typhoons in the northwestern Pacific Ocean each year and an average of 3.1 are likely to hit Taiwan annually.
However, in the last decade, the actual number of typhoons formed in the area has fallen below that number, she said, noting that there were only 22 to 24 typhoons per year between 2005 and 2009.
During that period, an average of three to five typhoons per year hit Taiwan, she said, cautioning that fewer typhoons do not necessarily mean less storm- related damage in the country.

Despite the record low number of typhoons this year, Typhoon Fanabi caused serious flooding in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in September. A month later, Typhoon Megi wreaked havoc in the northeastern county of Yilan, claiming 26 lives, including 20 Chinese tourists, on the Suhua Highway alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wealthier households consume more energy than poorer ones: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 20:13:58 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Better-off families in Taiwan were found to have used more electricity than average households in 2010, while central Taiwan residents were the heaviest users, according to the results of a study released Wednesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The average amount of electricity used by families with an annual income above NT$2 million (US$68,120) was about 1.6 times higher than those with yearly incomes of between NT$600,000 and 800,000, according to the ministry's statistics.
There was also a correlation between the total family energy consumption of all types, including electricity, natural gas and liquefied natural gas, and annual incomes.

The central area topped the country's four regions -- north, south, central and east -- in terms of average family energy usage, due mainly to generally bigger floor areas per household, an Bureau of Energy official said.
Air conditioning accounted for 23.8 percent of electricity consumption, followed by water heaters at 14.5 percent. Lighting was the third-largest source of electricity utilization.

Compared with the last such study, carried out in 2000, the trend toward smaller families was more obvious, the bureau said. An increase in the number of families and available housing areas for each family member has led to a higher demand for electricity, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to be banned from buying media coverage: KMT official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 20:21:09 (By Lee Shu-hua and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A senior Kuomintang (KMT) official said Wednesday that the party and the government are taking steps to ban the practice of so-called embedded advertising or the buying of news coverage.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung made the remarks during an interview with radio presenter Cheng Tsun-chi.

A party-government meeting a day earlier resolved that the budget act should be amended in such a way that bans the central and local governments from using government budget to buy media coverage or to run advertorials -- advertisements that masquerade as real news, King said.
He admitted that the issue has been around for a long time and described it as "very complicated, " but he added that the KMT is determined to get to the root of it.
"This is a problem that must be faced by the central and the local governments, be they pan-blue or pan-green, " King said, referring to the two major political camps in Taiwan.
He accused the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of initiating the practice when it was the ruling party between 2000 and 2008.
"When the DPP pointed its finger at others, " King said, "it forgot that its other fingers were pointing at itself. "
If the government wants to promote its policies or initiatives in future, such messages must be clearly marked as "government messages," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese property agency holds biggest year-end party
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 20:52:16 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Evertrust Rehouse Group, one of Taiwan's largest real estate agencies, kicked off what it boasted is the biggest year-end party in the local property sector Wednesday to reward its thousands of employees after this year saw a flourishing property market.

More than 6,000 real estate agents around the country flocked to the Nankang Taipei World Trade Exhibition Hall in Taipei to attend the party in which more than 1,000 prizes including two cars, scooters, flat-screen TVs and iPad tablet computers were given away.
The event marked the first of the group's three year-end parties for its more- than 10,000 employees and their families.
The group saw a 20-percent growth in this year's sales, valued at NT$300 billion (US$10.3 billion) , and aims to achieve another 20-percent growth for next year to total a projected NT$360 billion.
"We are neutral-to-optimistic on next year's market," the group's president, Benson Liao, told reporters.

Liao based his optimism for the market on Taiwan's low interest rates, the recent Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement with China and the inauguration of four new special municipalities, in addition to the already existing Taipei City, in late December.
Soaring property prices have prompted the government to launch cooling measures earlier this year due to mounting complaints from the public of unaffordable housing in the nation's capital.
Liao said the government's efforts have targeted short-term speculative investors and will not cause a negative impact in the long run.
"There will be not much impact if the central bank further raises interest rates by 0.25 or 0.5 percentage points," he added.
His remarks came as the market waited to see if the central bank will hike interest rates the following day.
Evertrust, which has 760 outlets around Taiwan and in Shanghai, has vowed to boost the number to 900 in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stock Exchange to compile 'Taiwan Top 99 Employers' index
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:04:28 (By Tien Yu-pin and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange said Wednesday it plans to post a "Taiwan Top 99 Employers" index online from Dec. 30 to encourage corporate social responsibility though the employment of more people.

The main criteria for selecting the 99 companies include profit per employee and turnover rate, according to the exchange. Those companies with turnover rates of one percent or lower will not be selected, it said.

As for profit-making ability, the exchange said, this will be calculated on the basis of a company's average net profits over the past five years, divided by the number of employees in the last year of that period.

The index will be composed of 18 highest profit-making firms in the banking and insurance sector, 48 top-earning electronics and technology firms and the 33 most profitable companies in the traditional industries.

Currently, Cathay Financial Holdings, Chung Hwa Telecom and Nan Ya Plastics are the leaders in these three sectors, respectively, with Cathay Financial being the No. 1 contender for the "Top 99" list.
The exchange said the list will be an indicator of the companies' social responsibility, which will be mirrored in their stock prices as well as in public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tennis player selected as 'Man of the Year' in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:22:33 (By Oscar Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lu Yen-hsun, widely regarded as the most outstanding male player in Taiwan tennis history, has been selected as the country's 2010 "Man of the Year," according to a poll that was made public Wednesday.
Lu, 27, won the title with 60 percent support among the respondents in the survey conducted by the 104 job bank.
Bread maker Wu Pao-chun was second, beating President Ma Ying-jeou into third place, while U.S.-based fashion designer Jason Wu was fourth, and singing sensation Lin Yu-chun placed fifth.
In a press release issued late Wednesday, Lu said his selection as Man of the Year was an unexpected honor.
According to 80 percent of the respondents in the poll, Lu's success was linked to his determination to fight to the end, rather than the achievement of fame or fortune.

Lu, who is preparing for the 2011 Australia Open, has performed outstandingly this year. In June, he reached the quarterfinals at Wimbledon by beating American tennis player Andy Roddick. With that win, Lu became the first Taiwanese male player to reach the quarter-finals of a Grand Slam and the first Asian to compete in a major since 1995.
Many critics regard Lu's win over Roddick as one of the best performances ever by a Taiwanese player in a grand slam.
Lu's world ranking has jumped to 35th from 98th early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Hungary tax agreement takes effect
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:37:11 (By Cheng Chong-sheng and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A tax treaty that was signed earlier this year between Taiwan and Hungary took effect Wednesday, to the benefit of many Taiwanese investors in that central European country, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Wednesday.

Under the pact, the 19th of its kind that Taiwan has forged with other countries, the tax rates on interest income and stock dividends earned by investors in each other's country will be lowered to 10 percent.
In Taiwan, the interest income tax for foreign nationals ranges from 15 percent to 20 percent, while in Hungary the rate is 30 percent.
On stock dividends, the tax rate for foreigners is 20 percent in Taiwan and 25 percent in Hungary.
The Foxconn group, YAGEO group and Quanta Computer Incorporated are among the Taiwan investors that will benefit from the tax agreement, the MOF said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% of major Taiwan companies plan to raise salaries: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:38:37 (By Stacy Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The majority of chief executive officers (CEO) of major Taiwanese companies plan to raise their employees' pay next year, a survey revealed Wednesday.

Seventy-five percent of the CEOs in the CommonWealth Magazine survey said their companies will offer higher pay in 2011, with 47 percent estimating raises of within 3 percent, 25 percent forecasting a 3-5 percent pay hike, and about 3 percent predicting a 5-8 percent pay increase.

The survey was conducted between Nov. 29 and Dec. 17 among CEOs of 1,270 corporations selected from among Taiwan's top 1,000 manufacturing firms, top 500 service providers, top 100 financial companies and 15 financial holding groups. A total of 470 valid samples were collected in the survey.

Speaking at a news conference at which the results of the poll were released, Charles Wang, managing consultant of the Taiwan branch of U.S.-based Towers Watson Delaware Inc., said Taiwanese companies need to raise salaries to reflect a rebound in their sales and the country's economy.

Salary increases have been relatively slow in recent years, Wang noted. If local companies fail to raise their employees' pay, Taiwan may see a brain drain to neighboring countries where the salaries of white-collar workers have been rising much faster, he said.
On Tuesday, the government's top economic planner also urged local companies to raise employees' pay to help spur private consumption and bolster continued gross domestic product (GDP) growth.
Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairwoman Christina Liu said the government has designated 2011 as a year to promote private consumption to boost GDP growth.

Because some companies have offered their employees pay raises in recent months to match a rebound in sales, private consumption is expected to rise in the coming year. She also urged other corporate leaders to acknowledge the trend and follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Extra cross-strait flights during Lunar New Year announced
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 23:03:10 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The number of extra flights on cross-Taiwan Strait routes to major Chinese destinations during the Lunar New Year holidays were announced Wednesday as big crowds are expected over the four-week period from late January to mid-February.
According to the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) , from Jan. 20 to Feb.17, the total extra flights to be operated for Taiwanese carriers to Shanghai and Shenzhen are 32 and 16, respectively.

Aviation officials from Taiwan and mainland China also agreed that Taiwan airlines could operate no more than 10 extra flights to each of these Chinese destinations: Beijing, Guangzhou, Nanjing and Hangzhou during the period.
Four more destinations--Wuxi, Xuzhou, Quanzhou and Sanya-- have been added to the cross-strait routes during the New Year holiday period, with no limits to the number of flights.
Some of these extra flights to major cities are expected to depart and arrive late at night or early in the morning, the CAA warned.
"Chances are that passengers are more likely to get red-eye flights this time than a year ago, " said Betty Cheng, CAA's planning division director.
According to three major Taiwanese carriers, the proposed numbers of extra flights operated by China Airlines, EVA Air and TransAsia Airways are 66, 33 and six, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recalcitrant city councilors expelled from KMT, DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 23:17:02 (By Lee Shuh-hua, Wen Kui-hsiang, Yang Sz-ruei and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two major political parties decided separately Wednesday to revoke the membership of newly elected municipal council members who failed to toe the party line in the recent elections for council speakers and deputy speakers.

Secretary-General of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) King Pu-tsung said the party's Central Disciplinary Committee's decision to expel 10 Tainan City Council members must be carried out in order to reassert authority within the party.
The 10 KMT members, including Chang Shih-hsien and Lee Wen-chun, were found to have disobeyed the party's directives during the elections for council speakers and deputy speakers last week.
The other eight were Lee Kun-huang, Chen Wen-ko, Tseng Pei-ya, Tsai Shu-hui, Lin Mei-yen, Chen Chin-yi, Huang Li-chao and Tsai Yu-chih.

With only three KMT members remaining in the city council's KMT caucus, party workers said, the councilors who have been kicked out of the KMT are expected to work with the caucus so they could return to the party fold in two years time.

Some KMT councilors in Taipei City were also reported to have acted independently during the speaker elections, but King said that without any solid evidence to prove the reports, he could not discipline them.

In the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the Central Standing Committee has decided to refer five recalcitrant members to the Central Advisory Committee, which will confirm their expulsion from the party at a meeting on Jan. 11.
The five are Lee Wan-yu of Xinbei City, Hung Ping-lang of Kaohsiung City, and Liang Shun-fa, Tsai Chiu-lan and Tang Pi-er of Tainan City.
DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the five had bucked a party resolution to vote for their fellow party members under the watch of their council caucuses.
According to DPP regulations, once the councilors have been expelled, they would not be allowed to rejoin the party within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tennis player selected as 'Man of the Year' in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:22:33 (By Oscar Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lu Yen-hsun, widely regarded as the most outstanding male player in Taiwan tennis history, has been selected as the country's 2010 "Man of the Year," according to a poll that was made public Wednesday.
Lu, 27, won the title with 60 percent support among the respondents in the survey conducted by the 104 job bank.
Bread maker Wu Pao-chun was second, beating President Ma Ying-jeou into third place, while U.S.-based fashion designer Jason Wu was fourth, and singing sensation Lin Yu-chun placed fifth.
In a press release issued late Wednesday, Lu said his selection as Man of the Year was an unexpected honor.
According to 80 percent of the respondents in the poll, Lu's success was linked to his determination to fight to the end, rather than the achievement of fame or fortune.

Lu, who is preparing for the 2011 Australia Open, has performed outstandingly this year. In June, he reached the quarterfinals at Wimbledon by beating American tennis player Andy Roddick. With that win, Lu became the first Taiwanese male player to reach the quarter-finals of a Grand Slam and the first Asian to compete in a major since 1995.
Many critics regard Lu's win over Roddick as one of the best performances ever by a Taiwanese player in a grand slam.
Lu's world ranking has jumped to 35th from 98th early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Hungary tax agreement takes effect
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:37:11 (By Cheng Chong-sheng and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: A tax treaty that was signed earlier this year between Taiwan and Hungary took effect Wednesday, to the benefit of many Taiwanese investors in that central European country, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Wednesday.

Under the pact, the 19th of its kind that Taiwan has forged with other countries, the tax rates on interest income and stock dividends earned by investors in each other's country will be lowered to 10 percent.
In Taiwan, the interest income tax for foreign nationals ranges from 15 percent to 20 percent, while in Hungary the rate is 30 percent.
On stock dividends, the tax rate for foreigners is 20 percent in Taiwan and 25 percent in Hungary.
The Foxconn group, YAGEO group and Quanta Computer Incorporated are among the Taiwan investors that will benefit from the tax agreement, the MOF said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% of major Taiwan companies plan to raise salaries: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 29 (CNA) 12/29/10 22:38:37 (By Stacy Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The majority of chief executive officers (CEO) of major Taiwanese companies plan to raise their employees' pay next year, a survey revealed Wednesday.

Seventy-five percent of the CEOs in the CommonWealth Magazine survey said their companies will offer higher pay in 2011, with 47 percent estimating raises of within 3 percent, 25 percent forecasting a 3-5 percent pay hike, and about 3 percent predicting a 5-8 percent pay increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 30, or the 25th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar.
Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1922: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or the Soviet Union, is established.
1927: The Ueno-Asakusa line of Tokyo's subway begins operating.
1947: Romania abolishes monarchy and establishes republicanism.
1949: The Republic of China announces the severance of diplomatic relations with India.
1965: Ferdinand E. Marcos takes the post as president of the Philippines.
1997: South Africa and mainland China sign a communique to establish diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 30 (CNA) 12/30/10 10:11:54 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened modestly higher Thursday from its previous close, moving up 16.86 points at 8,883.21 on a turnover of NT$4.411 billion (US$33.33 million).
The weighted price index fell 4.41 points, or 0.04 percent, to close at 8,866.35 Wednesday.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 30 (CNA) 12/30/10 10:16:00 (By Sofia Wu)
