Nevertheless, Yaung said, if the system is put into practice in 2012, the premium rate will need to be raised to 5.12 percent in 2017 and further adjusted annually to 6.11 percent in 2021.
As the existing NHI Act caps the premium rate at 6 percent, the law would have to be revised by then, Yaung said.
Although the DOH has proposed two other premium collection formulas, the minister said, the first version is most preferable in terms of "professionalism."

The second version does not require raising a monthly reserve fund, which would allow the 5 percent premium rate to remain unchanged in the first six years until 2017. But the rate would be raised to 5.09 percent in 2018 and would also exceed the 6 percent ceiling to hit 6.1 percent in 2021.

The third version proposes lowering the premium rate from the current 5.17 percent to 4.61 percent in 2012 and then raising the rate to 4.72 percent in 2013, 4.84 percent in 2014, 4.96 percent in 2015, 5.15 percent in 2016 and 5.31 percent in 2017. The rate would also surge past 6 percent to hit 6.02 percent in 2021 under this formula.
The differences in the three versions mainly lie in whether the NHI system should raise reserve funds as a hedge against financial instability, Yaung said.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said earlier in the day that the legislature will deal with issues surrounding the NHI Act Jan. 4, with the KMT- proposed revisions as the basis.
Given the lack of consensus between the ruling and opposition parties on 28 to 29 articles of the draft package, a showdown vote could be inevitable, Wang said.

"Legislative caucus whips from both the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party will be allowed to air their views and positions in the Jan. 4 legislative session before a vote on the package is held," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$50,000 in prizes await 3 millionth visitor to Taipei Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 30 (CNA) 12/30/10 23:12:41 (By Chen Hung-chin and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A prize worth NT$50,000 will be awarded to one of the 1,100 visitors who buy entry tickets at around the 3 million mark to the Taipei International Flora Expo, expected by the organizers to be sold around New Year's Day.
The expo organizers said Thursday that with more than 50,000 people visiting the expo each day since it opened nearly two months ago, the 3 millionth visitor is expected Jan. 3.

Holders of the 550 tickets issued before and after the 3 millionth will be entered in a draw for prizes including two vouchers for upmarket hotels at Sun Moon Lake and in Taipei worth NT$50,000. Other prizes will include gift packs and coffee coupons.

Ting Hsi-yung, producer of the expo's operational headquarters, said a number of new exhibitions will be staged to welcome the 100th year of the founding of the Republic of China, including an agricultural technology show featuring cloned sheep.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 31, 2010, or the 26th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: The Dutch Administration in Batavia (now Jakarta) takes over the Dutch East India Company's territories in Indonesia.
1879: Thomas A. Edison, American inventor, demonstrates for the first time his electric incandescent light at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1880: George Marshall, U.S. Army general and statesman, is born. As secretary of state, he devised the Marshall Plan for post-war economic recovery in Europe.
1909: The Manhattan Bridge, a two-section suspension bridge, is opened to traffic in New York.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, who promised to establish a republican government when he assumed the provisional presidency of the Republic of China, orders the restoration of the imperial system, with himself on the throne, beginning from 1916.
1919: The United States, Britain, and Japan sign an agreement on East Siberia.
1924: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had fallen ill earlier, arrives in Peking from Tientsin to hold talks with Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government. While in Peking, Dr. Sun succumbed to liver cancer and died on March 25, 1925.
1946: U.S. President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of World War II.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates the government's policy of continuing attempts to settle disputes with the communists by political means.
1946: Chang Hsueh-liang, the commander of the Northeastern Army who played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Xian, is escorted to Taiwan and put under house arrest at the Chingshang hot spring in Hsinchu. The Xian Incident was a severe setback to Chiang's efforts to subjugate the communists.
1956: President Sukarno proclaims a state of siege in Sumatra, Indonesia.
1964: President Sukarno threatens to quit the United Nations if Malaysia is given a seat on the Security Council.
1971: Kurt Waldheim of Austria takes over as the United Nations secretary- general after U Thant retired.
1975: More than 1,600 foreign students present an autographed album to Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at a year-end meeting.
1976: Education Minister Y. S. Tsiang hosts a dinner to honor foreign students and visiting professors at the Chientan Youth Activity Center with more than 1,000 students and teachers from 30 countries attending.
1977: Cambodia breaks off diplomatic relations with Vietnam and suspends all air services between the two countries.
1979: The Sino-U.S. Mutual Defense Treaty against the Chinese communists in the area is ended.
1983: The United States deploys Cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles in Britain and West Germany.
1985: The Taipei World Trade Center is inaugurated.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto sign the first agreement between India and Pakistan in 16 years, agreeing not to attack each others' nuclear facilities.
1991: All senior delegates to the ROC's First National Assembly, Control Yuan, and Legislative Yuan retire from office.
1996: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong submits his resignation to Premier Lien Chan.
1997: Mohammed Rafiq Tarar becomes the ninth president of Pakistan.
1998: Finance ministers of the European Union announce definite rates for converting the currencies of the 11 nations due to launch the single euro currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui calls for increased constructive dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits on an equal footing so as to contribute to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian calls on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) issues operational certificates to seven financial holding companies, the first batch of its kind in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only men of moral character who know how to love men or to hate men. If you fix your mind upon a moral life, you will be free from evil."

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Muster a positive force

TEXT.P: Tomorrow will be the beginning of the second decade of the 21st Century and the 100th year of the Republic of China.
We earnestly hope that in the new year, Taiwan will be able to leave "chaos" behind and bid farewell to "sluggishness."

"Chaos" was the word chosen by the Taiwanese people to represent the year 2008, when the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers triggered a global financial crisis. The word in fact also epitomizes the general state of mind of the Taiwanese people in recent years.
"Sluggishness, " meanwhile, was selected to represent 2010, which reflects the phenomenon of an economic recovery that has not been felt by the majority.

The economic growth for 2010 is projected at close to 10 percent, but this has not been felt by average people. The government therefore has a responsibility to find a reasonable mechanism to spread the gains made by the business sector, so that everyone can benefit from them.

In fact, in order to muster a positive force in society, it is important for the rich to be generous. It would be very helpful if Taiwan's richest man -- Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou -- could initiate a philanthropic drive similar to the "The Giving Pledge" promoted by billionaires Warren Buffett and Bill Gates.

The 100th year of the ROC will be the inaugural year for municipal restructuring and for the cross-Taiwan Strait Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement. It will also be the homestretch year to the 2012 presidential election. Despite all this, we hope to see greater "domestic stability" in the coming year. (Editorial abstract -- Dec. 31, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Arbitration begins over Taiwanese athlete's disqualification
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 13:02:27 (By Neil Lu, Oscar Wu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Switzerland-based Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has officially initiated an arbitration on the disqualification of Taiwanese taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun at the 2010 Asian Games, a CAS official said Friday.
Matthieu Reeb, secretary-general of the international arbitration body, told CNA via e-mail that the procedure will be divided into two phases: filing of written submissions, followed by hearings.
"For the moment, we are still in phase one, which will probably last four or five more weeks," Reeb said.
However, he declined to offer any further details, on the grounds that confidentiality is required by the procedural rules.

The news came just as Yang was considering whether to retract her appeal, which was filed Dec. 8 with the CAS. There have been concerns that once the case enters the CAS arbitration process, the World Taekwondo Federation (WTF) might suspend the Chinese Taipei Taekwondo Association, which will affect other athletes' chances of competing in international competitions.

Yang was disqualified Nov. 17 for allegedly wearing extra electronic sensors in her socks at the Asian Games. Yang was enjoying a 9-0 lead at that point, and replays of the match show that as instructed by games officials, she had removed the two extra sensors before entering the ring.
The WTF banned Yang from competition for three months Dec. 21 on the grounds that she sat down in protest and refused to leave the mat following her disqualification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan company sets sights on expansion in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 30 (CNA) 12/31/10 13:11:26 (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Hannspree, a Taiwanese company known for its trendy LCD TV products, said Thursday it is aiming to expand its presence in Europe now that its flagship store in the United Kingdom is doing well.

Chung Fu-lung, general manager of Hannspree Europe, told the Central News Agency that the company is planning to open a second shop in London next year. At the same time, it will open stores in the German cities of Berlin and Hamburg and in Milan, Italy, he said.
Hannspree has decided to set up its base in the UK and Germany because it thinks these two markets are the engines that will drive the European economy, Chung said.
He has confidence in the business environment in the two countries where young consumers are keen to buy customized products with unique and personal characteristics, he added.

The Hannspree store is situated in the Westfield shopping center, Europe's largest urban mall. A 55-inch LED display in the shape of London's signature double-decker buses draws attention in the front of the store.
Last year, Westfield attracted 23 million consumers, Chung said. The mall, which is located in a high-income district, is an ideal spot for business, he said.
Since the store's opening in mid-November, sales have grown steadily, according to Chung. "They are higher than we had expected," he said.
Hannspree is the only Taiwanese high-tech company that has its own retail store in London.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU To Give Lectures at NQU To Benefit Students from NQU and XMU

TEXT.P: Based on the cooperation foundations of the strategic alliance, National Cheng Kung University will first organize a team of excellent professors to start giving lectures at National Quemoy University starting February, 2011, and in the future start giving lectures at Xiamen University as well.

Similarly, when the time is ripe, Xiamen University will also organize a team of outstanding professors to give lectures at National Quemoy University, and the lectures are open to students from National Cheng Kung University, National Quemoy University and Xiamen University and will allow them to choose credits freely.

The participants of the conference call, which took place at 9am, December 30th, in the offices of each university, include President Chin-Cheng Lee of National Quemoy University, Vice-President Zhang Ying of Xiamen University, Senior Executive Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng of National Cheng Kung University, Director Jiunn-Der Liao of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, and other senior heads.

NCKU Senior Executive Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng expressed,Xiamen University is one of the top universities in mainland China, and National Cheng Kung University is also one of the top universities in Taiwan. National Quemoy University, because of its unique geographical location, is the best cross- strait exchange platform. Particularly, NCKU is the only university named after Koxinga Cheng-Kung Cheng with historical elements and culture aspects tracing back to Southern Fujian Culture. The cooperation mode of the three universities is the beginning of cross-strait higher education cooperation. In the future, we can expand the level of cooperation and quicken the development of cross-strait higher education for the 21st century to become an era of Asia.

President Chin-Cheng Lee of National Quemoy University revealed,The conference call with Xiamen University and National Cheng Kung University is a new undertaking of cross-strait academic exchange. Koxinga Cheng-Kung Cheng landed at Tainan from Kinmen and Xiamen 400 years ago and National Cheng Kung University is the only university named after him. Following the route, we are on our way to success. The strategic alliance formed by NCKU, XMU and NQU already has many cooperation plans. National Quemoy University is extremely honored to be part of something great. Step by step, we will contribute to the road of success and make it worthy of its name.

NCKU Senior Executive Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng pointed out,National Quemoy University plays a significant role in Taiwan Strait. It is an important island in the Xiamen living circle but it is also part of Taiwan and the residence of overseas Chinese people, embodying the unique characteristics of mainland China, Taiwan and Southeast Asia. As I grew up in Singapore, I have a strong feeling toward Xiamen University. I have also attended classes offered by Xiamen University during middle school. It is truly a historical coincidence.

NCKU Director Jiunn-Der Liao of the Department of Materials Science and Engineering said,We have visited National Quemoy University and Xiamen University and some of the professors in March, 2010, and reached a consensus on jointly opening programs. NCKU has especially selected 9 renowned professors to participate in the program starting February, 2011, in National Quemoy University.

The 9 professors, including Director Jiunn-Der Liao of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Distinguished Prof. Wen-Ta Tsai of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Prof. Lien-Chung Hsu of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Prof. Kuan-Zong Fung of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Prof. Xiao-Ding Qi of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Director Jia-Jin Chen of NCKU institute of Biomedical Engineering, Prof. Shyh-Hau Wang of NCKU Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, Prof. Hsi-Wen Yang of NUU Department of Materials Science and Engineering, and Prof. Yung-Der Juang of NUTN Department of Materials Science, have been appointed as Adjunct Professors at National Quemoy University.

President Chin-Cheng Lee of National Quemoy University has revealed his sincere gratitude toward Director Jiunn-Der Liao for his efforts in organizing a professional team to come to National Quemoy University,The professors are not only highly educated, their research achievements are also excellent. In the future, the professors will take turns to give lectures, 6 hours each time, and NQU will arrange a professor to be responsible for the whole course, so students' learning can be more smooth and complete.

In addition, in response to XMU Vice-President Zhang Ying's inquiry about the programs offered at National Quemoy University by the NCKU professional team, Director Jiunn-Der Liao mentioned,The 9 professors will give lectures twice per week on Thursday afternoon and Friday morning, and they may also give lectures at Xiamen University on Friday afternoon.

Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng suggested,We should create a website for the teams of professors organized by Xiamen University and National Cheng Kung University to show their information and the lecture information in details and produce a space for mutual exchange and discussion. This would be absolutely unprecedented.

President Chin-Cheng Lee of National Quemoy University also stated,The academic performance of NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering in the world ranking is extremely well, and it is definitely the world's top team. To become the first in opening cross-strait cooperation programs, NCKU Department of Materials Science and Engineering undeniably has the mind of looking international.

Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng pointed out, In the current cross-strait political atmosphere, it is not convenient for professors or students from mainland China to go to Kinmen. I hope through future academic exchange, cross-strait senior personnel can understand the academic needs and consider loosening restrictions, allowing a more convenient come and go for the professors and students. Even though it is a huge project, I am confident that we will gradually overcome the difficulties in the future.

Agreeing with Vice-President Feng's thoughts, Vice-President Zhang Ying said,We welcome NCKU professional team to come to Xiamen University to give lectures. In the beginning, we can arrange Friday afternoon for the lectures. The lectures are regular courses with credits. I hope NCKU and NQU can pass the proposal to XMU as soon as possible, so we can make early planning.

President Chin-Cheng Lee also said,Kinmen is more than 300 km away from NCKU, which is a little bit far. However, the distance between Kinmen and XMU is merely 10 km. Therefore, following the example of National Cheng Kung University, it is possible in the future that Xiamen University may also organize a team of professors to give lectures at National Quemoy University and participate in other academic exchange and cooperation.

Vice-President Da-Hsuan Feng has praised the macro cooperation under the joint efforts of the three universities to be a significant step for the development of cross-strait higher education. DOC.HEADLINE: Pitcher prepares for return to MLB in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 16:09:31 (By Posan Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese right-hander Chien-Ming Wang, who has recently signed a one-year contract to rejoin the Washington Nationals in U.S. Major League Baseball (MLB), said at a function in Taipei Friday that he looks forward to returning to the MLB in the coming year.
Wang said at a charity drive that he has made a New Year resolution to return to the MLB next year, hopefully in May.

He signed with the Nationals in February for one year with a guaranteed US$2 million salary, but has been in rehabilitation for the past 15 months and has not pitched for the Nationals in any MLB game.
The 30-year-old Wang, who has been on a home visit in Taiwan since November, said he has spent most of his time training and rehabilitating to prepare for a comeback.
He met with the press and children that his foundation -- the Wangderful Kids Fund -- has sponsored at the event to raise funds and renew the foundation's commitment for 2011.

The recipients of Wangderful Kids Fund donations over the past two years include the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families, the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China and the Paper Windmill Cultural and Educational Foundation.
Although Wang will receive only half the guaranteed salary of his previous contract, he can secure up to US$4 million in incentives next season.

He will be paid US$250,000 if he stays on the 25-man roster for more than 30 days, a further US$250,000 if he stays for 30 more days and an additional US$250,000 if he stays for another 30 days after that, according to his new contract with the Nationals.
Wang won more games than any other big league pitcher (38) between 2006 and 2007, but his injuries have limited him to just 27 appearances over the past two years.
In 2009, when he earned US$5 million with the New York Yankees, Wang was 1-6 with an atrocious 9.64 ERA before being shut down for the season because of his shoulder injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magazine digest -- Convenience stores' new focus
DOC.DATELINE: 12/31/10 17:11:42 (Business Weekly 1204)(translated by Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Tough competition among convenience stores in Taiwan has forced them to abandon the traditional business model that focuses on revenue per ping (3.3 square meters) and employ new store designs to enter the coffee shop and eatery market.

"Opening bigger stores is the current trend," said James Hsieh, chief operating officer at President Chain Store Corp. that operates 7-Elevens in Taiwan. He noted that 60 percent of the 4,750 7-Eleven stores in Taiwan now have a seating area.

In the last three years, expansion in terms of the number of convenience stores in Taiwan has slowed down. On average, convenience stores are now only about six minutes walk apart. The challenge therefore is how to increase the chains' customer base in a crowded market.

Based on its surveys that showed shoppers at convenience stores like to have a place to sit, 7-Eleven two years ago began setting up seating areas comprising counters and stools in its stores -- a move that has been well received.

Similarly, 80 percent of FamilyMart stores, Taiwan's second largest convenience store chain, have also been outfitted with seats as part of a goal to increase sales of fresh food products such as packaged meals and sandwiches, which have a higher gross margin.
FamilyMart said the sale of fresh food items currently accounts for only 12 percent of its revenue. In Taiwan, the industry average is 20 percent, while in Japan and Shanghai it is 30-40 percent.
While its fresh food prices are not as competitive as at food stands and other sidewalk eateries, FamilyMart said, it has the advantage of being open around the clock.

The changing trend in convenience stores means that smaller 25-ping ones that serve as modern grocery stores are being expanded to 35-45 pings so they can also function as coffee shops and small restaurants.
"In the short term, the revenue-per-ping might appear to be falling, but the total revenue will increase in the long run, " said Wu Sheng-fu, vice president of FamilyMart.
The site preference is changing as well, as the chains are no longer going for the high-cost corner locations but rather are choosing less expensive but bigger spaces.

The trend now is to have more spacious convenience stores with lower shelves and wider aisles, according to Wu Shih-hao, associate professor of National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology's Marketing and Distribution Management Department.
"The layout of the stores is being altered," he noted.

Hi-Life, the third largest convenience store chain in Taiwan, has gone a step further and installed bakeries at 175 of its stores, which means fresh bread is made on-site every day. At some of its shops, fresh sandwiches and burgers are also made on site.
Beryl Lee, secretary-general of Taiwan's Association of Service Industries, said that after a period of rapid expansion, the convenience store business is now in the process of fine-tuning.

"Unlike the manufacturing sector that makes specific products, the service sector has an invisible yet dynamic research and development aspect, " Lee said. "In fact, convenience stores have innovations every day."

DOC.HEADLINE: Passage of ECFA tops list of 2010 legislative news stories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 17:35:24 (By Angela Tsai and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The passage of the Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) amid clashes and differences between the ruling and opposition parties in August was selected as the top legislative news story in 2010, the Citizen Congress Watch said Friday.

The story was considered the most edifying, influential and controversial legislative event of the year, according to the watchdog group, which compiled a list of the top 10 legislative news items based on an online poll.

The year's second-biggest legislative news story was the obstacle-plagued efforts to introduce a second-generation National Health Insurance system, followed by the passage of bills related to the central government's restructuring project.
Also, "bluff" was chosen as the word that best represents the performance of the Legislative Yuan in 2010.

According to Ho Tzung-hsun, executive director of the group, the word was selected because the legislature has failed to honor its promises to enact many important legislation, including a number of sunshine laws.
The world "selfish" was picked in 2009, while "dark" was chosen in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Centennial commemorative railway tickets sell like hot cakes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 17:45:43 (By Yang Sz-ruei, Johnson Sun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thousands of people flocked to the Yongkang railway station in Tainan, southern Taiwan Friday to buy Republic of China Centennial commemorative tickets for the route between Yongkang and Baoan, according to Yongkang station master Lin Wen- chin.
Lin said people started queuing up at the Yongkang railway station on Thursday night to obtain the Taiwan Railway Administration tickets, which were not due to go on sale until 8 a.m. Friday.
At one point, the queue stretched for one kilometer, Lin said, estimating that it took buyers at least two hours to get to the sales counter.
In Chinese, a rearrangement of the characters for Yongkang and Baoan produces the Chinese phrase "Yong Bao An Kang, " which means "peace and health forever."

The commemorative tickets are being sold in sets of two, with one dated Dec. 31, 2010 and the other Jan. 1, 2011 -- the date when the Republic of China will mark 100th founding anniversary. New Year greetings are printed on the back of each ticket.
The TRA issued a total of 50,000 sets of commemorative tickets in red packets that symbolize good luck and fortune in Chinese culture.
Meanwhile, the EasyCard Corp. will release a limited edition of commemorative cards Saturday, also to mark the 100th anniversary of the ROC.
In the two-card sets, one of the cards bears the words "ROC Centennial Easy Card" in Chinese calligraphy, while other features the national flag of the Republic of China.
Easy cards are used for payment on the Taipei area mass rapid transit and public bus systems, as well as at convenience and other retail stores in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar closes higher on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 18:05:12 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar Friday, gaining NT$0.151 to close at the day's high of NT$30.368 on a turnover of US$1.089 billion.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.217 and moved between NT$29.083 and NT$30.368 before the close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fishing vessel feared hijacked by Somali pirates: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 18:11:45 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat was feared to have been hijacked by Somali pirates in waters near Madagascar off the coast of eastern Africa after having been out of contact since Dec. 25, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release Friday.

The Kaohsiung-based longliner Hsiuh Fu No. 1 lost contact with its Taiwanese owner after being chased by unknown vessels Dec. 25 and the MOFA said it could have been hijacked in Madagascar's exclusive economic zone, given recent extensive Somali piracy activities there.
There were 26 people on board, including the Taiwanese skipper, as well as 12 Chinese and 13 Vietnamese crewmen, according to the Council of Agriculture's Fishery Agency.

The MOFA launched an emergency mission upon learning about the vessel's disappearance, instructing Taiwan's representative office in Cape Town, South Africa to seek assistance from the government of Madagascar as well as contacting the Malaysia-based International Maritime Bureau's Piracy Reporting Center, the ministry said in the press release.

The maritime watchdog Ecoterra International said on its website that the Shiuh Fu No. 1, which is licensed by the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission to fish in the waters, had been hijacked and that "on Dec. 28 the vessel maintained a strange, patrol-like pattern along Latitude 52 on the northeastern side of Madagascar."
The European Union Naval Force (EU NAVFOR) Somalia reported that there are "strong indications that FV Shiuh Fu No. 1 has been pirated" and the conditions of the crew and the vessel are unknown.
According to the EU NAVFOR, there are 26 vessels and 613 hostages being held by pirates off the coast of Somalia.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Museum of Natural Science opens commemorative exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 18:44:15 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: The National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung is offering a "Surprise! " to visitors for the next six months to mark the Republic of China's centennial and the museum's 25th anniversary.

An exhibition called "Surprise! " that showcases 100 of the museum's top specimens and objects from its collection opened on Friday, and museum director- general Chang Tien-jye said it will surprise visitors with its diversity and help them better understand Taiwan's natural environment.

Among the items on display is a 430-year-old disc-shaped specimen of a Taiwanese spruce (picea morrisonicola Hayata) seen at the entrance of the exhibition, which Chang said tells the natural history of Taiwan through its detailed rings.

Figurines based on the skeletons of ancient creatures or cetaceans are also on display in the 3rd Special Exhibition Gallery, where the exhibit is being held, to infuse the show with a sense of fantasy, Chang said.

Commemorative stamps featuring the exhibition will be available beginning Saturday morning at 9 a.m. at the museum's Life Science Hall, where the museum will set up a temporary office distributing commemorative envelopes with special postmarks, Chang said.
The exhibition runs until June 12, 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, France sign agreement on avoidance of double taxation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 19:18:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and France have signed an agreement on avoidance of double taxation, which will take effect on Jan. 1, 2011, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced separately Friday.
Michel Lu, Taiwan's representative to France, and Patrick Bonneville, director of the French representative office in Taipei, signed the agreement on Dec. 24, the MOFA said in a statement.

The agreement was screened and passed by the French Parliament on Dec. 21 and approved by Taiwan's Executive Yuan on Dec. 23 before the Christmas Eve signing, according to the MOFA and MOF statements.
France became the 20th country to sign a double taxation agreement with Taiwan.
The MOFA said the pact represented a great step forward for economic and investment relations between Taiwan and France, Taiwan's fifth largest trade partner in Europe.

The agreement is expected to be beneficial to businesses of both sides, helping to attract French investment to Taiwan as well as providing a fair tax environment for Taiwanese businesses in France, the MOF said.

According to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , Taiwan's quasi-official trade promotion agency, French exports to Taiwan totaled 1.02 billion euros and imports from Taiwan totaled 2.16 billion euros in 2009.

More than 60 Taiwanese companies have invested in France, including mobile phone maker HTC Corp., computer manufacturers Asustek Computer Inc., BenQ Corp. and First International Computer Inc., and transportation companies such as China Airlines Ltd. and Evergreen Marine Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family caregivers need time off, more support: groups
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 19:39:31 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: The recent case of an 84-year-old man who killed his bedridden wife highlights the need for greater support for family caregivers, a group of social organizations said Friday.

"The tragedy is an indication of a serious problem among long-term caregivers, many of whom suffer from severe psychological stress as a result of looking after loved ones around the clock, " said Wang Tseng-yung, president of the Taiwan Association of Family Caregivers, at a press conference in Taipei.
The elderly man stabbed his wife in the head with a screwdriver on Dec. 26, saying he wanted to end the suffering she had long endured because of Parkinson's disease and two broken legs.

Citing a survey conducted in 2009 by his association, Wang said family caregivers, 80 percent of whom are female, work 13.55 hours per day on average and many do not have a day off. About 20 percent of them are diagnosed with depression after working like that for one year, he said.
Family caregivers are classified as people who take care of incapacitated or elderly family members.

According to the association's statistics, there are approximately 600,000 people in Taiwan who require long-term home care. About 400,000 of them have family caregivers, 170,000 have immigrant caregivers, and 30,000 are in homes for the elderly.

In this area, Taiwan differs from Western countries in that the rights of its long-term caregivers are often neglected, Wang said. Since mothers and daughters are usually the main caregivers in Taiwan, it is taken for granted that they would work without rest or complaint, he said.
According to Tseng Chao-yuan, a senior researcher at Awakening Foundation, this kind of sacrifice by family caregivers is often viewed as "a labor of love."

"But no one can work 14 hours every day without rest, " Tseng said. "The government should train more professional caregivers, with the dual goal of increasing job opportunities and allowing family caregivers to take a break."
Tang Li-yu, secretary-general of Taiwan Alzheimer's Disease International, said family caregivers have told her that they rarely sleep well because of the emotional stress associated with their work.

"An Alzheimer's patient can repeat the same thing 50 times a day, which is completely okay if the family caregiver is under no pressure, " Tang said. "However, when the caregiver is under stress, listening to this kind of repetition all day could lead to a serious nervous breakdown."

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of applications to invest in China soar in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 19:53:21 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of applications by Taiwanese companies to invest in China grew significantly by volume and value in 2010, the result of improving cross-Taiwan Strait ties and a rebounding global economy, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

In 2010, the MOEA's Investment Commission approved 408 applications to invest a total of US$13.32 billion in China, 63.85 percent and 119.82 percent higher, respectively, than in 2009, according to commission figures.
The commission said the investment proposals were concentrated primarily in the optoelectronic, conventional manufacturing, distribution and financial sectors.
One of the most high profile applications was AU Optronics Corp.'s (AUO's) plan to invest US$3 billion in a 7.5-generation plant in Kunshan in eastern China to produce flat panels.

Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., the world's largest contract maker of electronic products, also won approval in 2010 for US$1.2 billion in investment projects aimed at expanding its presence in China, the commission said.

Earlier in the day, the commission held its last meeting of the year, in which it gave the green light to three proposals by overseas Taiwanese to invest in Taiwan and two proposals by local companies to invest abroad, including one to invest in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan showcases homegrown agricultural technologies at Flora Expo
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 19:54:08 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An agricultural technology show opened at the Expo Dome of the Taipei International Flora Exposition on Friday, presenting 192 examples of new technologies, products, and flora and fauna species developed in Taiwan.
The exhibition was held to showcase Taiwan's best and most competitive innovations in the agricultural technology sector, said the organizer, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
Exhibits cover the farming, forestry, fisheries and livestock sectors and include fluorescent fish, nutrition-enriched rice, and blossoming orchids in an enclosed container.
The venue also features an exhibition zone in which models of potential agricultural innovations of the future are displayed.
The COA hopes the show will help more people realize that Taiwan's agriculture has applied new technologies to become a sector with a sharp international competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold weather not likely to deter crowds at New Year's celebrations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:06:08 (By Chen Hung-chin, Kuo Chu-chen and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: Large crowds were expected to swarm New Year's celebrations throughout Taiwan despite a cold front that will push temperatures to below 5 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan over the weekend.

Taipei City estimated that as many as 750,000 people could gather around the landmark Taipei 101 skyscraper on New Year's Eve for the annual fireworks show that this year was designed by New York-based gunpowder project artist Cai Guoqiang.
Another ceremony to kick off the Republic of China's 100th year will be held at Dajia Riverside Park in the city.

To accommodate the throngs of people expected to celebrate the new year, the city's subway system was operating for 42 consecutive hours from 6 a.m. Friday morning. The Maokong Gondola will also run until 1 a.m. on Jan. 1.

Many people were also expected to scramble to the coast, the mountains, or outlying islands to catch the first sunrise of 2011, where all-night concerts were being held to get people in a partying mood.
One of the events to welcome the first rays of sun of the new year was scheduled to take place at Lishan in central Taiwan, located at an altitude of 2,614 meters above sea level.

Orchid Island, off Taiwan's southeastern coast, will be the first sea level site in the country where people can see the sunrise on Saturday, with visitors able to enjoy the view on traditional boats of the island's indigenous Yami people.

Two major hotels in the popular beach resort of Kenting in southern Taiwan, the Caesar Park Hotel and the Howard Beach Resort Kenting, said they were fully booked and had not received any cancellations because of the cold weather Friday.
A concert will begin early Saturday morning in Lungpan Park, one of the best locations to watch the sunrise in the area.
The overnight temperature in Kenting was forecast at 15-17 degrees, compared with 5-14 degrees in northern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP files suits to invalidate election results in 3 municipalities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:13:09 (By Sophia Yeh, Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) filed suits Friday to invalidate the Nov. 27 election results in three of the country's special municipalities -- Taipei, New Taipei and Taichung cities.

The DPP said the party decided to file the suits because it wants to respond to "the public's aspirations" to learn the truth of an election-eve shooting that the DPP believes boosted the KMT's momentum and helped it win in the three cities out of five up for grabs. The DPP won in Tainan and Kaohsiung cities.
Three of the DPP candidates in the Taipei, New Taipei and Taichung elections -- Su Tseng-chang, Tsai Ing-wen, and Su Jia-chyuan, respectively -- instructed their lawyers to file the suits.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang contended at a news conference later in the day that the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) used the Nov. 26 shooting to gain public sympathy and sway the election results.
"The suits are aimed at getting to the bottom of the incident, " Cheng said, adding that "it is to safeguard Taiwan's basic rights and wrongs and to avoid its democracy from being damaged."
He said the filing of the suits is not intended to incite populism or create confrontation.
"If the truth is not unveiled or if the case is rashly closed, it will create confrontation and the disintegration of society, " Cheng added.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen had a final discussion with lawyers and staff before reaching the decision to go ahead with the legal action.
On hearing the news, the KMT said the move was simply the DPP leadership trying to find an excuse for the party's election losses.

"The KMT respects the legal rights of the DPP to file suits to invalidate the election results, but every political party should take responsibility for its actions," said Su Jun-pin, a spokesman of the KMT.
He also questioned why, if the DPP really thinks the shooting affected the election results, it is not filing suits to invalidate the election results in all five cities.
"This is merely the DPP leaders trying to find an excuse for the election losses and it is ill-befitting of a responsible party leader," he said.

Lien Sheng-wen, also known as Sean Lien, the son of former Vice President Lien Chan, was shot in the face while stumping at a campaign rally for Chen Hung- yuan, a Taipei county councilor bidding for re-election in New Taipei City, an upgrade of the former Taipei County.
A lone shooter was arrested on the spot and his gun seized, but the motive for the assault remains a mystery after more than one month of investigation.

Meanwhile, Lien Sheng-wen said through his special assistant that same day that he welcomes anyone trying to get to the bottom of the shooting, but he also noted that some DPP politicians have recently used vicious remarks in an attempt to bully him, for which they should openly apologize.

DOC.HEADLINE: 16 more Kaohsiung elected officials charged
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:17:22 (By Chen Chao-fu, Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office filed invalidation suits against 16 more elected officials Friday, following 16 others it charged the previous day.

The 16 people sued Friday -- three newly elected Kaohsiung city councilors and 13 ward chiefs -- were charged with bribery committed by themselves or vote- buying carried out by their relatives or campaign aides prior to the Nov. 27 special municipality elections, the prosecutors said.
A day earlier, the prosecutors office brought invalidation suits against four city councilors and 12 ward chiefs, also on bribery and vote-buying charges.
In total, seven newly elected Kaohsiung councilors and 25 ward chiefs were charged.
A stunned Sun Ching-lung, one of the three councilors sued Friday, said he had no idea why he was charged and attributed the development to a frame-up plot against him by his opponents.
Under the law, lawsuits for invalidating the election of public office-holders must be filed within one month of the election commission making the election results public.

Kaohsiung City's election commission announced the winners of the Nov. 27 special municipality elections Dec. 2, so the prosecutors still have one day to file suits against other suspected law-breakers.
The court will accept invalidation suits Jan. 3 at the latest, as the first two days of January are holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Range of new programs to take effect in Taiwan Jan. 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:29:15 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A raft of new programs and government policies that are expected to bring benefits to society at large will take effect on New Year's Day.

Among them is a child welfare program sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior, which would allow Taiwanese families with an annual household income of less than NT$1.5 million (US$50,000) and children under 2 years of age to receive a monthly subsidy of NT$3,000 per child.
In addition, families in all income brackets will be eligible to receive the subsidy after the birth of a third child.

In the capital Taipei City, a campaign to boost the city's birth rate will be launched at the start of the new year. Couples who have lived in the city for more than a year will be offered an incentive of NT$20,000 for each newborn, once at least one of the parents maintains his or her household registration in the city.

The campaign also allows for a monthly subsidy of NT$2,500 to be granted to children under 5, providing that their parents are registered Taipei City residents who have lived in the city for more than a year and are in an income tax bracket of below 20 percent.
Apart from the social welfare programs, there are a number of policy changes and initiatives that will also become effective Saturday.
One of them is a decision to increase the country's monthly minimum wage from NT$17,280 to NT$17,880 and the hourly minimum wage from NT$95 to NT$98.

In the area of cross-strait trade, the tariffs on a range of goods and services will be removed or reduced with effect from Jan.1 under the terms of a landmark Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) signed in June between Taiwan and China.
The special tariff treatment will apply to 539 items on Taiwan's "early harvest" list and 267 on China's, over an initial two-year period.
The value of Taiwan's "early harvest" exports to China has been estimated at US$13.8 billion per year, while China's are expected to amount to an estimated US$2.86 billion to Taiwan annually.
Meanwhile, the European Union visa waiver privilege for Taiwan passport holders traveling to the Schengen Area and three EU member states will take effect after the New Year, on Jan. 11, 2011.

The exemption applies to 25 Schengen Area countries, comprising 22 EU member states and three non-EU states -- Norway, Iceland and Switzerland -- and three non-Schengen EU member states -- Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus.
It also includes seven smaller European countries and territories -- the Vatican, Monaco, Andorra, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Greenland and the Faroe Islands.
The visa waiver allows Taiwanese travelers to enter countries covered under the exemption for stays of up to 90 days within a six-month period.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP head for showdown on health insurance program revision
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:36:42 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Legislators of Taiwan's two main political parties appeared poised for a showdown on a proposed revision to the health insurance system next week after failing to reach a consensus on the issue on Friday.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which have been wrangling for a month over an amendment to the National Health Insurance (NHI) Act to help the debt-ridden system stay afloat, could no longer discuss the substantive content of the proposal.
He expected the issue to be resolved during a session of the full legislature on Jan. 4.
On Thursday, the Department of Health (DOH) unveiled three possible versions of the revision, designed to adjust how national health insurance premiums are collected.
But Legislator Lin Yi-shih, who heads the KMT's policy committee, said Friday he was still trying to forge a consensus within the party over which version it would support.

The DOH's three formulas were based on a revised package proposed by the KMT, all of which allow for premium rates that are lower than the current rate of 5.17 percent of regular salary, at least in the initial stage, Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday.

The KMT's package suggested establishing two different premium rates, one for regular wages of the insured and one on four additional types of income -- interest income, stock dividends, professional income, and bonuses more than four times a person's base salary.
None of those income categories are currently included in the income on which premiums are calculated.

In the first of the DOH's three proposed versions, the premium rate would be set at 5 percent of the insured's regular salary in the plan's first five years, with the government contributing at least 36 percent of the premiums owed.
The premium rate on the supplemental income categories would be tentatively set at 2 percent and would have a goal of raising an additional NT$20 billion in revenues.
According to the DOH's estimate, this version would allow the NHI system to remain solvent for five years, with at least a one-month reserve.
Yaung cautioned, however, that if the system took effect in 2012, the premium rate would have to be raised to 5.12 percent in 2017 and further adjusted annually to 6.11 percent in 2021.
As the existing NHI Act caps the premium rate at 6 percent, the law would have to be revised at that time, Yaung said.
Although the DOH has proposed two other formulas, the minister said the first version was the most preferable in terms of "professionalism."
The second version would not require preparing a monthly reserve fund, which would allow the 5 percent premium rate to remain unchanged in the first six years until 2017.
But the rate would be raised to 5.09 percent in 2018 and would also exceed the 6 percent ceiling to hit 6.1 percent in 2021.

The third version proposes lowering the premium rate from the current 5.17 percent to 4.61 percent in 2012 and then raising it to 4.72 percent in 2013, 4.84 percent in 2014, 4.96 percent in 2015, 5.15 percent in 2016 and 5.31 percent in 2017. The rate would also surge past 6 percent to hit 6.02 percent in 2021 under this formula.
The differences in the three versions mainly lie in whether the NHI system should prepare a reserve fund as a hedge against financial instability, Yaung said.
DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming said his party would convene a caucus meeting on Jan. 3 to determine the party's stance on the issue.

DPP Legislator Huang Sue-ying criticized the reform proposals, saying they failed to address the inherent flaws in the current system, and warned that if the KMT tried to ram the amendment through on Jan. 4, she would not attend the session.
Huang said the system as it currently stands has offered loopholes to wealthy individuals to avoid paying high health insurance premiums.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Year's Eve crowds test Taipei's traffic control ability
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:40:34 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: Taipei city government transport authorities are deploying extra manpower and extending the service hours of the city's public transport as record crowds are expected to throng the city on New Year's Eve.

A total of 750,000 people, about 150,000 more than last year, are expected to gather in front of Taipei City Hall for the countdown party, according to the city's Department of Transportation (TCDOT).

In response, five additional shuttle bus routes will be added to transfer people from the concert venue to various mass rapid transport (MRT) stations after the party, said Liang Guo, division chief of the TCDOT Mass Transit Section.
Half of the staff of Liang's office have been told to work overtime, and those 50 people "might not be able to finish their work and get home until 3 a.m. or 4 a.m.," he said.
Evacuating such huge crowds from the area after the party will also be a challenging task for the MRT, according to Wilson Chiang, a manager with the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC).
"We have deployed an extra crew of 125 people at the Taipei City Hall Station alone," Chiang said.
He said the new Luzhou Line, which opened in November, however, could help ease traffic at major junctions.
"The public can now transfer more smoothly to suburban Taipei, as the launch of the Luzhou Line has created two new transfer stops other than the Taipei Main Station," he noted.
The MRT transported nearly 2.16 million passengers between 6 a.m. last Dec. 31 and 6 a.m. last Jan. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Near normal or less rainfall for next three months: CWB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 20:50:49 (By Lee Hsin-Yin)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Friday that total rainfall from January to March will be near or below average around Taiwan, as the island is experiencing a La Nina event.

According to the bureau, the probabilities of predicted rainfall in three categories -- below normal, near normal and above normal -- over the next three months nationwide are 40 percent, 40 percent and 20 percent, respectively.
In January, normal rainfall in northern Taiwan is defined as between 60 mm and 100 mm, while in the south it is defined as between 45 mm and 70 mm.
The CWB noted that the current La Nina, reflected by below-average sea surface temperatures across the equatorial Pacific, is a moderate to strong one.
A moderate La Nina episode tends to be accompanied by less rainfall in spring in Taiwan, the bureau said.
Accordingly, temperatures forecast for January are likely to be slightly lower than in the past few years.
"We do not rule out the possibility of more cold fronts sweeping across Taiwan by mid-February," said Cheng Ming-dean, director of the bureau's Weather Forecast Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental group selects 'falling' as 2010 word of the year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 21:03:01 (By Hermia Lin)

TEXT.P: An environmental group on Friday declared "falling" as the word of the year for 2010, while urging the government to fulfill its promise to improve Taiwan's natural environment in 2011.

"The word 'falling' clearly resonates with many people this year, " said Wang Chun-hsiu, president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, at a press conference in Taipei Friday. The union was established in 1987.

He said Taiwan's extreme weather conditions in 2010 have led to many climate refugees, whose quality of life is falling, and that heavy rainfall, typhoons, and mudslides have seemingly become increasingly prevalent -- or even the new norm -- on the island.

Wang attributed the phenomenon of climate change to Taiwan's lack of substantial progress in cutting carbon emissions and promoting renewable energies, and he argued there would be more new poor if no action were taken by the government in 2011.

Gloria Hsu, the former chairwoman of the union, said that according to Carbon Monitoring for Action (CARMA), Taiwan Power Co.'s coal-fired power plant in Taichung was ranked as the most polluting power plant in the world in 2010, producing 39.7 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions.
In addition, Formosa Plastics Group's coal-fired power plant in Mailiao, Yunlin County, was ranked as the world's fifth biggest emitter, spewing 29.9 million tons of carbon emissions, she said.

In May, Hsu said, President Ma Ying-jeou mapped out a vision for a "golden decade" supported by six pillars of national development -- technological innovations, cultural development, environmental improvement, constitutional reform, social welfare and peace.
But environmental groups in Taiwan had yet to see changes in policies regulating carbon emissions and energy efficiency, Hsu complained.
"We sincerely hope 2011 will be a better year for Taiwan's environment," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Year-end symposium reviews politics, economy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 21:12:29 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The signing of a historic trade pact with China and fierce competition in the five special municipality elections were the most significant developments in Taiwan this year, scholars said in a year-end symposium Friday in which they also predicted a tumultuous year ahead.

"The past year has been more about fear than pain for Taiwan. However, 2011 will be a troublesome year, " political pundit Nanfang Shuo said in the symposium organized by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum to examine the domestic political and economic developments in 2010 and preview the coming year.

Taiwan's economy in 2010 has shown a strong recovery from the financial crisis that began in 2008, Nanfang said, but the rebound will not be as robust in 2011 because the global economy is expected to slow.

Politically, the atmosphere of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges is expected to cool off in 2011 as Taiwan will be embroiled in a campaign year ahead of the 2012 presidential election, he said, adding that China will also try to engage in dialogue with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The exchanges are expected to slow down because President Ma Ying-jeou, who is expected to seek re-election, "is always more cautious and tends to appeal to the opposition electorate more during the campaign season, " according to Nanfang.

The scholars lauded the June signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China -- designed to liberalize cross-strait trade ties -- as the biggest breakthrough in Taiwan-China relations of the past six decades.

While legislator Lo Shu-lei of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) warned that pinning Taiwan's economic hopes solely on China could be dangerous and that the long- term effects of the ECFA remain unknown, George Tsai, a political scientist at Chinese Culture University, said Taiwan's trade interdependence on China could also be "healthy" because China will have to have second thoughts on military action against Taiwan.
Taiwan also needs to recognize that its trade relations with China "will go from partnership to competition" because several strategic industries on both sides overlap with each other, he said.

On domestic political issues, the streamlining of government agencies from 37 to 29 will begin 12 months from now and the creation of the four new special municipalities -- bringing to five the total number in the country -- is expected to solidify the system of two levels of government in Taiwan, said Thomas Peng, an associate professor at National Taiwan University.
"The measures, if successful, are expected to improve administration efficiency, " said Peng.

Former DPP Legislator Lin Cho-shui questioned whether the five municipalities will be able to function as "regional hubs" to boost the economy in their areas, saying that the design of the system is purely politically motivated without sufficient deliberation, because the five cities pale in comparison with true mega cities like Shanghai and Tokyo.

Looking at the coming year, the scholars agreed that the increasing wealth gap, the transformation of Taiwan's economy and the continued exodus of local manufacturing industries will be among the issues at the top of the government's agenda in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock market has highest close of the year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 21:49:21 (By Maranda Hsu and Maia Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices threatened to break through the 9,000 point barrier on Friday before finishing at their highest close of the year, helped by an appreciating New Taiwan dollar, dealers said.
The weighted index rose 0.73 percent, or 64.59 points, to close at 8,972.5, after trading between 8,932.64 and 8,990.38 on turnover of NT$152.53 billion (US$5.8 billion).

The benchmark Taiex rose 784.39 points, or 9.6 percent, in 2010, and it is expected to reach 9,000 in the near future after the early harvest list of Taiwan's Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China takes effect.
The items on the list exported from Taiwan to China or vice versa will be given preferential import duties, making them more competitive in their target market.
In Friday trading, financial shares scored the highest gains, ending up 2.4 percent, led by Shin Kong Financial Holding Co. and China Development Financial Holding Corp.
Construction shares rose 1.6 percent, with Huang Hsiang Construction Corporation, Sweeten Construction Co. and the Shining Group rising by the maximum daily 7 percent limit.

Machinery and electronic shares underperformed the market, rising 0.4 percent, and accounted for only 40.6 percent of total turnover, an indication investors are worried the export-dependent sector could be hurt by the local currency's appreciation.
The movement of share prices next week will depend on fundamentals as investors adjust their strategies for the new year, a Dah Chang Securities analyst said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Taiwan-approved Chinese magazine to hit shelves in January
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 22:09:59 (By Zoe Wei and Kendra Lin)

TEXT.P: The first magazine published in China ever to be approved for sale in Taiwan will be available in the local market beginning in January.

The "Duzhe" magazine, meaning "reader, " will be published in traditional Chinese characters every month for Taiwanese readers, as it is now for Chinese- speaking audiences in Hong Kong and the United States.
Dubbed "Chinese people's Chicken Soup for the Soul," the magazine was approved for sale in Taiwan by the Government Information Office in August.
Ji Xipin, chairman of the Duzhe publication group, and Taiwanese writer Tom Wang attended a press conference in Taipei on Friday to launch the publication in its new market.
The magazine, which contains literary works by Chinese writers around the world, has a monthly circulation of about 8 million in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 officials sentenced over illegal land deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 22:55:55 (By Sherry Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court handed down sentences on Friday to 15 former and incumbent officials of the National Property Bureau (NPB) under the Ministry of Finance who were convicted of corruption charges.

Eleven others, including property developers and a land administration agent, were also sentenced in the case, which involved the sale of a piece of land located on Hangzhou South Road in Taipei City's upscale Daan District several years ago.

Su Wei-cheng, a former NPB deputy director, was sentenced to 15 years in prison, fined NT$10 million (US$333,333), and had his civil rights suspended for 10 years for masterminding the illegal sale of the land, formerly owned by the now defunct Taiwan Provincial Government, while he was in office.

According to the Taipei District Court ruling, Su and his accomplices, including Chen Kuan-pao, another former NPB deputy director, and Chuang Tsui-yun, an incumbent NPB deputy director, started organizing the scheme in 2002.

The land had been held in trust by the NPB since 1999 after the downsizing of the provincial government, and Su and the 14 other officials first arranged for several proxies to rent the Japanese-style wooden residential houses built before the 1940s on the site.
That enabled the proxies to be able to enjoy priority rights to purchase the land, which they later used to acquire the land at prices much lower than normal.
Su and the other 14 officials then had the land sold to two property development companies, costing the government NT$120 million in revenues, according to the 400-page verdict.

Chen Kuan-pao was sentenced to 13 years in prison, fined NT$5 million, and deprived of his civil rights for 10 years, and Chuang Tsui-yun got an eight-year jail term and an NT$3 million fine and had his civil rights suspended for eight years.
Twelve other former and incumbent NPB officials got sentences ranging from 10 years to five years and six months, according to the ruling.

Tsai Ming-jun, president of a property development company, was given a jail term of 10 years and four months, along with a fine of NT$20 million, while Chien Hsing-chi, a vice president of the same company, was sentenced to 10 years and two months in prison and fined NT$18 million.

Wang Ming-dao, owner of another construction company involved in the scheme, was sentenced to eight years and six months in prison, while Chan Teh-yu, a land administration agent, got an eight-year jail term, according to the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan dollar gains strength in 2010, may rise even higher in 2011
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) 12/31/10 23:34:23 (By Lin Yi-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated 5.47 percent against the U.S. dollar in 2010, the second highest annual rise in the past 10 years behind only 6.07 percent in 2003, and it is expected to face similar pressure next year.
Taiwan's central bank believes that the United States' expansionist monetary policy should put pressure on all Asian currencies in the coming year.

But the impact of Federal Reserve's quantitative easing policy on Taiwan's currency remains uncertain because the central bank has shown its determination to prevent the country's currency from appreciating too rapidly to avoid hurting exports.
The Taiwan dollar closed at NT$32.030 against the U.S. dollar on the last day of 2009, compared with a close of NT$30.386 Friday, according to Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan).

Among Asian currencies, the Taiwan dollar appreciated against the U.S. dollar by more than the Chinese yuan (3.59 percent) and the Korean won (2.62 percent) but less than the Japanese yen (13.32 percent) and the Singapore dollar (9.19 percent).
Central bank Governor Perng Fai-nan said Friday that many people criticized him this year for not letting the Taiwan dollar depreciate as much as the Korean won.
With the Korean currency only appreciating 2.62 percent this year, the market share of Taiwan's flat panel sector has lagged behind South Korea's.

But Perng said he did not think it was possible for the Taiwan Taiwan dollar to depreciate as rapidly as the South Korean won, referring to the Korean currency's plunge from 920 to 1,534 to the dollar between the end of November 2007 and the end of March 2009.

Yang Chia-yen, a director at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said he believed the central bank would not mind if Taiwan's currency appreciated against the greenback at the same rate as other Asian currencies.
But he said the central bank would feel compelled to intervene if the Chinese yuan and Korean won continued to rise at a slower pace than the Taiwan dollar.
